column4: Currently, this sits on my list as my favorite game.
I know it says how many plays, but many, many were uncounted. I liked this version the best.
i will never tire of this game.. Awesome
This is probably the best game I ever played.  Requires more than just thinking; develops negotiation skills
Fantastic game. Got me hooked on games all over again.
One of the best games ever created. Period. New board setups allow practically infinite replayability. Expansions are worth having, too.
Game itself is 9. Only strategy game my family asks me to play. Never gets old.
This is a great game.  I've even got a number of non game players enjoying it.  Fast to learn and always changing.
One of my all time favorite games. I usually only get to play with 2 players. We use the 2 player variant by Ethan Sprang found on Mayfair Games website under Variant and Scenarios Section.
Settlers is a gem. If you havn't played it I suggest you go get it right now.
Everyone I've shown this to, gamer and non-gamer alike, get hooked.
Played this game more than any other, a new classic that will not gather dust.
One of the best games ever, and one that gets more interesting the more you play it. It deserves its reputation.
Everyone that I've introduced this game to has liked it: friends, family (even my grandparents), everyone.

THE classic game of the 90's. Belongs in every game collection. I still play this fairly often - just the basic game alone has surely cracked 100 plays, and throw in all the variants and expansions and this is an incredible system. --- Version Notes: Overall, I think the 2005-ish re-issue of Die Siedler von Catan from Kosmos - featuering plastic pieces - is the most attractive, funcational version of the game. It has bright, pleasing graphics, the smaller resource cards are easy to manage, and the plastic inserts are the most functional inserts ever for a game. It is in German, though. But every version has its charms, even going back to the borderline-ugly Mayfair 1st and 2nd printings (the ones that used photos - I don't actually own either of those printings, but I'd like to just to add to my collection). The 2007 Mayfair edition (the bigger box) is probably the nicest version that Mayfair has done, and is comparable and even superior in some ways to the 2005 Kosmos edition, the first time Mayfair has gone their own way  and done something at least as good as Kosmos. It also has the advantage of being in English. I generally like Mayfair's 3rd printing better than most players - I think it's a nice, distinct set with its own flavor apart from the other versions - but I'd also agree that it's overall not as graphically effective as the other versions, being a little dark.
6 players only with the expansion set, of course, which I suppose I could use...
My all time favourite when the boys are around.

So, it's a ten then. I hate to have to go with the crowd, but after several years playing, it's still one of the first games to come out during a session. Yes, there's a certain ammount of luck (I once won a game becuase the dice simply WOULD NOT stop coming up 4's. Guess who had 4) but it's usually up to the individual players as to what use they make out of their resources. An real winner.

The best game invented in the last decade. With the changeable tileset and the trading system you don't get hardly boring. Also the subject reponds of one's desire: everyone wants to seek their fortune in the unexplored world. We've played once with ten players with two games and a 5&6 player expansion. Great fun.
I love this game because I can play it with my wife.
With the Seafarers Expansion, a near perfect game. A must-own for any gamer.

The game that really started it all for me. I'f always loved games but this one has all the elements I love - no down time, constant interaction, non-zero sum, symmetric and no one gets kicked out early.
Our favorite game.  Gaming geeks and
This is a beautifully designed game.  Everyone should try this at least once.
One of the great ones. Of course, I played this game over and over until I was sick of it, so now as far as my desire to play goes it's probably a 6.
All time classic super favorite - my first German game!!! Easy to teach because the rules are intuitive.  Scoring is simple.
This game single handedly started my board game addiction back in the fall of 2002.  A must for any game player.

I am so glad this game exists.  Fun.  It's for the random folks who game.  Playable with folks who want to be gamers, but really like a bit more light fare.  The dice are the deciding factor.  I sware.. put everything on 9, it's better than 6/8 in our games :).  It reminds me of gambling a lot.  Hard if there is someone who gets seriously.. painfully beaten each time because the dot discussion on probabilities is a bit too much for them.  So.. in a certain group, it's great.  I still love it for certain groups.

Simply the best boardgame of all time. THE PERFECT game. It's impossible to have better. Klaus Teuber is the boardgame genious of the century. He must have one place in history. This game, in a scale of 1 to 10, deserves 12.
Despite the desperate luck factor it is massive fun (must be played quickly because someone often gets smacked). Greatness.

Quite simply, this is the best and most elegant board game I have ever played.  I have hooked many of my friends on it over the last six years, many of them not people one would describe as game fans in general.  Its appeal is broad, and I have never grown tired of it.
Nothing to say... you should know it!

Probably the best and most balanced four player game ever. Settlers defines simplicity in game play, which leads to wins by more than a few folks new to the game over more established players. The mechanics are a blend of sheer dumb luck, careful strategy, and some real good smak. I am the sheep king...baaaah........

Own Kosmos (German) edition, which has much better graphics with cute small cards. I over played this (300+) just like many other people but I still play this time to time. Most expansions are also good, especially from Catan Book.
Great game! Very easy to learn and very funny to play. Also with non gamers friends. I like it very much

Best game ever designed, but I've played it too much and now I'm burnt out on the basic game.  Bring out any of the expansions, however, and I'll play anywhere, anytime!!  This is one of the few dice games that I really enjoy.  It's very exciting when you have a hand full of cards and you are praying that no one rolls a 7, or you have 2 cities on a 9 wheat field and a 9 is rolled!!!  Brilliant game by a brilliant game designer.
Still a favorite after more than 4500 plays.  Prefer 3 players.
"Hall of Fame" game.  Simple rules, fast pace, always a chance to come back, make this game a crowd favorite.  Don't own it?  Slap yourself and run out and purchase a copy before someone notices.
Ok, maybe not a 10 anymore, but that's just because I've played it to death.  A great blend of strategy, luck, and negotation.

Great game to get new players into strategy gaming.  Easy to learn and still has enough strategy to keep most players interested.  Lots of interaction between players which might help get the female audience interested as well.
Probably my favorite game.  Good blend of strategy and luck.  Games are usually close.  If using a sound plan, you're usually completively fighting for the win.
Great! A nice balance between strategy and luck combined wit a different board every time and true interaction among players.
the game of games i guess

This is an excellent game as a game, but it also has a social interaction component that few games offer.  My favorite Settlers story comes from my friend Andy, who played a game in which all his opponents were extremely agreeable when it came to trading ("anyone trade me a sheep and a wood for a wood?  I need a sheep?"  "Sure!")  He was way too smart to do this.  Halfway through the game he realized he was hopelessly behind...  We always call this game "Settlers", but you can't find it using the Search function on BGG if you type in "Settlers".  It's stupid.
For me this has stood the test of time well; It's still a great system and a lot of fun to play. Stick to 4 player and the original island. (Maybe add Seafarers if you must)
After 100+ plays, I'm still not tired of it!

This game gets a 9+1=10. Here's why:  Not only is Settlers fun to play (the expansion availability bumps it from an 8 to a 9), but it is an amazing gateway game.  This is a real game that I can get non-gamers to play.  The existence of this game has saved me from playing annoying party games with non-gamers time and time again, hence the "+1".

Quite possibly one of my favorite board games ever.  Fun, deep, and different with every game and every group you play it with.  No one is ever safe and no one is ever too far behind to pull out a victory.  No other game has drawn the enthusiasm of my usually non-gamer friends like this one has.  Simply elegant.  A true gem of game design.
This is a must have game.
The game that started it all for me - brilliant.

Haven't played this that much lately since the days when we used to play nothing but this, but I don't care.  Yeah, it's not flawless, but I always have fun playing it, and when I'm playing it, I almost always admire it, as well.  Great stuff.
Probably the best boardgame I ever played!
One of the best game ever. Simple mechanism, a lot of players interaction, the board is never the same.

Best game ever. They created an environment that easily lends itself to variations. After we played out all 3 games as is, we tried many variations found online (including 2 that i bought on Ebay) & ideas that we came up with ourselves. Practically each game is a brand new game. Any one version might not stand up on it's own to Puerto Rico (getting it this week), but the possibilities kept us busy for a year once a week. Also, my 8 year old son understands this game (not enough to win though).  10/15/03 haven't played in monthes but feeling still the same.
This is always a great game to bring out, everyone has serious fun, esp. when we play with certain house rules, such as bribing.. :-)
It is a wonderfull game. You can't be bored, because you are trading and taking cards all time. It is a simple and effective game system.  It is my favourite game
we never chose to play this anymore, but then we have played it over 200 times!
Simply the best. Why isn't this on Wal-mart's shelves? If any game should be able to cross over to mainstream it should be this one.
The groundbreaker for serious games in the gaming industry. A lesson to all games old and new alike what a great game should be like. Clear story, immersive gameplay, liked by boys and girls alike!
Wow!  This is the game that really made a spielfreak out of me.  Such an elegant design!  I own two copies so that I can get up to an 8 player game going.
Will I ever tire of this game?
The "10" rating is with the 5-6 player expansion, and whether playing Seafahrers or not. Without the expansion - it is still a 9.5. I prefer games with more than 4.
If you have never played this game then shame on you.

The classic game that got me into board gaming and has got all my friends addicted too.  It seems like every game there's one or two numbers that don't produce like they should (last game 8 was rolled once the entire game), and that can be frustrating, but overall the game is still the king.

This was my favorite board game.  The social aspects of this game are amazing, though in the end, most strategies to keep people off your back come down to, "Look at the shiny thing."  Where the shiny thing is anyone else doing remotely well.  It is true though that I will no longer play this game.  I have just worn it out.  But that is after hundreds of games
My first german game. The best game that i have played with Carcassonne Hunters and Gatherers
I enjoy this better with the Cities and Knights expansion...
The game and the expansions are brilliant. Still one of my top ten games... hey, maybe we ought to play this tomorrow night!
I have never played this game with anyone who did not think it was a great game after their first game. It still holds up after countless playings.
The one that started the craze. Yay!
Some randomness that can be ameliorated and a lot of player interaction.  The modular board makes each game different enough to prevent it from getting stale.  Very fun game!
I'd give this game a [12] if I was allowed.  It truly is that good.  I have played somewhere near 100 games of Settlers and I'm not getting remotely bored yet.

There's nothing more that can be said about this incredible game that other reviewers haven't already covered.  Absolutely the best game I've ever played, even considering the new kids on the block garnering a lot of attention, such as Puerto Rico.
A terrific game with a simplistic design for families yet enough strategy for gamers.
I think,this may be perfect ballance game! We always play this with some beginners at first to know them fun of German board game.
Excellent and balanced game.  Good for new people and still enjoyable for repeat playings.
Can be played from simple to complex - great adaptability to compensate for new and old players.

The Settlers of Catan may well be the single greatest board game ever designed. Like many other German games, it combines simple rules and a short playing time with the potential for intricate strategy and battles of wits. But Catan is arguably the best example of bringing all these elements into perfect balance.  Catan satisfies a wide range of people, even those who normally hate board games, since it is the players themselves that choose the character of each game. It can be as cutthroat or as amiable as you want (or both!). It also excels at keeping every player actively involved at all times, both through the ingenious system of resource production and the constant opportunities for trading and deal-making. I could go on, but others already have.  I have no hesitation in recommending Settlers of Catan to pretty much anyone. From there, you may choose to explore more complex or more simple-structure games, but Catan is good for all!
Will always be one of my favorites. Resource management, changing board, trading and fun table talk.
A fantastic game, outstanding. Feels like I'll never get tired of it! We build our own expansion set for 5-6 players and it works quite well.
The game I use to bring people into the world of Board Games.

Probably the best new game of the last decade. This will go down in gamer history as a watershed game; Klaus Teuber has written an endlessly variable thinking man's game that never runs out of possibilities.
First american version from Mayfair Games. Beatiful graphic.
A great game, always fun, good game for new players, everyone always enjoy
Wooden figures edition + Catan - exp: Pre-2007 Adapter Kit, Settlers of
IMO the perfect game. As well as enjoying this myself, it's one that both gamer friends and non-gamer friends and family will all play, and which has converted several of the later into the former.
This is an outstanding game. Simple and efficient rules and much player interaction. The expansions work very well. Especially Seafares. This game is a must!!

Such a simple game but yet you have so many decisions.  I played this with my friend Lyman and immediately saw the potential for a great game.  I brought one copy to the gaming group and started the whole trend.  I ended up contacting a German MTG player who arranged to shipped about a dozen copies of the game plus the 5-6 expansion kit to our group.  This was before German game was avail in the US. I have one very beat up copy and one unopened copy.  Both of them are Kosmo(red box) edition.
I like to trade and build.

A real family favourite - we even have special rhymes for certain circumstances:  Caught with more than seven cards when the Robber turns up?  All together:  "You're a hoarder!  Out of Order!"  Well, it's fun for us!
This is the best game I have played! Everyone I introduce it to loves it.
I give it a meta 10, because it pretty much single handedly opened the door for Americans to the world of Euro games.  Yep, luck is a factor.  If you hate dice, go play Go.
Absolutely top of the board games except for Chess.
got me back into board gaming. the $40 i spent on it was more then worth it.
One of the best ever created!!!!!!!!
there's no reason to post less than a 10
The highest replay value of any game I've ever played.  Some great online versions out there too!  Only game I can claim to have played hundreds of times.
My favorite right now.  The trading makes this a little more fun for me than Puerto Rico.
What good can I say about this game that hasn't already been said?  I've even taught it to my ten year old niece who now loves to play it.  One of my favorites.
It has a ton of strong elements - random board patterns, player-trading elements, randomization, expandability, and a broad theme (which I can sell the game to anyone).

This is the only game that I'm willing to give a 10.  Settlers does have minor flaws, but it's still the king.  No other game draws more people into the board gaming hobby, and no other game comes off the shelf more than Settlers.  I hope that everyone interested in board gaming will give this masterpiece its due.  Klaus Teuber hit the ball out of the park when he designed this game.
I could give it a 10 for historical/commercial reasons, but I'm happy to award this 10 for its enjoyable gameplay and accessibility for non-gamers.
I love it and will continue to play it always

This is my first real game. Not a toys-r-us one lol. I may be sold to this one but I dont really car because evrybody I know who touch this game for the first time fall in love. Its like our first date with a girl/boys. I had and have great time with this game.
Probably my favorite game of all time.  I'm always up for a round of Settlers.
Awesome game, got my non-gaming buddies into the hobby.
Great game. People who like chess like this.
Simply a perfect balance of game mechanics.
Whatever else we play, this is the one we come back to. Whether I want an intense challenge or just some light entertainment, this game seems inexorably to mould itself onto the playlist. Fantastic!
One of the best games ever.

One of the few games I will give a ten. You can play this game a LONG time before you figure out the best strategy in each situation. Read my article "Number never rolled? Got blocked? General playing tips" if you have trouble with the random elements in the game, each random element has it's counter.
Clearly one of the very best games ever.  Simple rules, lots of strategy.
Best game ever i.m.o (well next to Magic: The Gathering). Good interaction, nice gameplay. Instant classic. Even better with the expansion sets.
This is our favorite game of all time.  I love the interaction.  Excellent gateway game.
This one got our group started onto a new addiction (boardgames) and we didn't even see it coming, it's just not right!

This is *THE* game that got me into board-gaming. Most definitely the board game that I have played more than any other game. Not many games have greater replay value since every SoC game will have a different board. This game has a near perfect blend of strategy and luck. Even the theme is fun. Gotta love it!
The 1st boardgame I purchased in the "modern age" (pre-modern age is monopoly, risk, stratego, MB gamemaster, BloodBowl).  I'm still in love with it.
Oh, only the best game ever designed of all time.
Deserving of its popularity, just a terrific game.  Best with 4 players.
Addictive and fun. After 100 plays, don't play it much anymore.
Although played to death, Settlers of Catan is still a true masterpiece in the history of board games. Long live Klaus Teuber!
Played this for the first time over the holidays.  One game and we were all hooked, playing past 4am three nights in a row!

This is one of the best games that I have ever played.  Its never the same exact game twice due to the random placement of the board hexes.  I highly reccomend it to anyone. This is an absolute must have in ever gamers collection.
A challenging game of resouce management
What can I say? This is still the games of games and the first in a whole new genre. I don't like the various extensions too much, though (only 5-6 Players is essential).
Replayable.  Strategic.  Social.  Wood and Sheep.
got me into board gaming.  Although there is a luck factor, it is still a great game to play.
You can never play too much Settlers.  What can you say - the seminal moment in modern gaming

Settlers was my first Euro game, the game that taught me how to say "Game of the Year" in German (even if I can't spell it), the first modular board game I ever played, and really my bridge game from role playing to board games.  I never knew games like Settlers existed until GenCon in 1997.  I played it a ton (many, many times before I started logging plays on BGG), and taught it to so many friends that I got sick of teaching the rules.  Even though it rarely sees the table these days, I still put it in my own personal Hall of Fame, and therefore rate it a 10.
My group likes it so much, I've crafted customized versions for friends, just to keep them hooked.

I love the social aspect of this game. It's very easy to learn even for first time players. Everybody I've introduced to the game enjoyed it so much they eventually bought a copy. The publisher was also very good about replacing a misprinted piece.
Remains my #1 favourite.  A masterpiece that can hook serious, casual, and even non-gamers alike.  Best balance of strategy and sociability that I know of.
Having played well over 400 games, I can safely say this is an amazing game.
The one that started it all.  I prefer playing Cities and Knights, but no Cities and Knights without Settlers, right?
The mother of all modern German games. (Norsk utgave).
I need to make my own [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/image/514490]Hardwood Catan[/url]
Best Game I have played - very dejected when I am behind and happy when I am ahead - most games I just enjoy playing win or lose, but this one gets me nearly every time.

My first modern board game. Good for all kinds of players for its moderate length of play time, superb player interaction, and appropriate game complexity. One (out of 3) of my selected games for gateway beginners.
I still love Settlers despite its flaws.

A game that (to me) seems to get better and better each time we play.  I don't find myself getting tired of it.  We play it just often enough to keep it freshly at the top of our selection list.  When we game, we think Settlers first.  You have to CONVINCE the group to play something else.
I never tire of playing this game. People whine about it being luck based but my group's games are always close with usually all players being in contention to win the game.
I love this gamee, more players more fun.
After 2 more plays tonight and countless playings over the past 10 years, this game continues to be a true classic! Always a candidate to hit the table with 4 players.

A classic!  Spent many sleepless nights at Denny's with friends over this game.  Played it since the first Mayfair English version came out.  I'm glad to see that it is finally catching on to the mainstream gaming community!  Bit too much luck is involved with the dice rolls at times, but the game is well balanced over time.  Loved by my guy friends and gal friends, gamers and non-gamers alike.  Scoring is simple, and almost every game everyone gets the feeling that they are somewhat close to winning.  Perhaps not the best game ever made in the modern time, but definitely the first of the best that opened the door for many more to come -- for that, it deserves a 10!

A classic, for a reason.  Tried and true.  Boardgame vets may forget just how fantastic and seminal this game is because you've played it into the ground, but play it with a few newbies and from their reactions you'll remember just how great this was when you first played it.
Great replay ability. I have played this game 5 games in a row and still had fun with it new board every time.
This game introduced me to European style gaming and it allows me to introduce others to it as well.
When my friend purchased this game, I was less than enthusiastic about trying it.  But after the first game, I became hooked!  I love this game!

Rated 10 because this is the game that first brought me into the hobby (and BGG)... because after 10 years, this is still our family's favorite game.  It's easy, it's friendly, it's cooperative yet competitive, it's fun, and it finished in an hour.  This is what we still play when we can't decide what to play.  We usually stick with the basic game, rarely the expansions.  I don't believe that "no game should rate a 10" (if so, then why have a 10?)  This is it.
Awesome, easy for new people to pick up and get addictive. Pefect for lazy weeknights although it can go a bit long sometimes.
A superb game. Random every time, fun interaction with trading, and a good mix of skill and luck. Im always in for a game.

When I first got this game my roommates and I played non-stop for months.  I still love it, still want to play, still get excited about it.  A perfect balance of fun and strategy, heavy and light.  Plus, as noted elsewhere, a great gateway game.
A classic that we all love to play!
A classic non-confrontational game of developing ones own area next to ones opponents' areas.
Always different. I like playing many variants too.
Fantastic Game!!!!  Everyone should own it!!!
My first entry into German-style board games.

It's a great all around game and a fun way to hang out with friends.  Without exception, everyone who has played this game has loved it, even non-gamer types.  I have one friend who I wasn't sure would like it and he suggested, even though it was late, to play another game  right after we finished.

The obvious substitute for all those copies of Monopoly in your home.  Only 3-4 players.  With 4, game can slow down a bit if trading gets bogged-down.  But between the variable board setup and the multiple strategies allowed, it's a great beginner's game that doesn't feel like a beginner's game.
An amazing game, one of those great games that seem to have limitless strategies.
For strategy board games, this is my current favorite!  I can't get enough of this one.

Our first introduction to German style games. A classic. Will play anywhere, any time with any one. Will even eat green eggs and ham to play. The trading adds an element of social interaction unmatched in any game I have played. Note low number of plays is because I count plays against the highest expansion.
One of the best games - ever

My favorite play ever was trading away all my ore in an ore-poor game, then playing the monopoly card to get it all back.  Unfortunately, I got suckered by the same trick late in the game by one of my victims, who managed to win the game because of it...

After numerous games I still enjoy the basic game. The random board makes every game a bit different. I really enjoy the trading and negotiating aspect in the game. EDIT: For some reason I cannot get this to the table anymore at all. I don't feel burned on it at all, but maybe all others are?

Played 200+ A lovely social game. The robber reigns in the leader helping to create a close game. There is nearly no down time. Card trading is friendly. How well players are doing is clear to see. The excitement builds as the game reaches its conclusion. The board changes making every play unique. This is an excellent game with the added bonus that it appeals to both the sexes. Mar 05

The most played game in my collection.  Everyone that we have introduced this to has loved it and ussually gone out and bought it.  There are so many variants you can play with this game that it is always a winner.
Played this a lot and burned out. Still up for a game now and then, if it's fast. Don't really care for all of the expansions.  Play with my kids from time to time.  Rating -- Suggest

A venerable classic to some people, to me it’s a relatively recently discovered game that led to many other new games.  Simple, involving, different each play. A game where luck is a virtue, forcing trading, attention to hand-limits and use (& defence against) the blocking robber.  A gateway game that’s a wonderful destination in its own right.  While the basic game is a 10, almost every expansion adds complexity or downtime, and reduces the rating.

Even though seeing what part of the bell curve is going to implode has too strong of an impact on the game, I'm still rating this a ten.  Not only am I always willing to play, but I look forward to teaching my daughter someday.  Besides, with the modular board, you never play the same game twice.
I enjoy this game so much that I made the Hold-it! Game Card Organizer for it.
This is my all time favorite game.  I love the balanced gameplay - and the replay value is extremely high.
A classic, that provides a game to play amongst almost any set of picky gamers.

Settlers is an absolute classic. It is one of my personal favorites and it is the "gateway game" that allowed me to bring countless new players into gaming. It is the quintessential resource management game. It uses a tile-laying mechanism similar to that of [gameid=58], which ensures a different board layout every game. Players then populate this map with settlements to obtain resources like wood and stone that can be used to build more structures and roads. There are several routes to victory and discovering different strategies and other subtleties of play ensures a high replayability factor. Most importantly, it gives players the opportunity to ask the age-old question, "Do you have wood for sheep?"
My favorite multiplayer game (best 3+)  Dynamic setup & variable victory points.  Plays in under an hour.  Great family game.  First time players can win.

There's a reason this is considered one of the best gateway games: it's quite fun, has a lot going on, and people seem to enjoy it. Won't please you if you insist on having complete control over every molecule of the game, but it's actually quite fun.
one of the best balances between luck (lots of it), skill (a little bit) and player interaction (as much as you want), IMHO
Definite must for anyone who plays board games!
The game that brought me into this world of gaming and to the Geek.  I owe my gaming life to this game.

The introductory Euro-game for me and the one which has achieved the best penetration amongst my non-gaming friends. Evidence: We hosted a Settlers tourney at our house with 24 players, and none of those people with the exception of myself owns a game invented since 1980.  Settlers has many attractive elements to it. The easy lingo, the constant engagement created by the resource-generation system, and the cute little network that you build are some standout features that are very appreciated by new players.
An absolute for any board game enthusiast. Great instruction book, great concept, an innovation for the gaming industry.
I WISH I could play this game more often.

Probably my all-time favorite game. I never seem to get tired of it.  I've played it literally hundreds of times.  I have a friend who played it 30 times in a row one night.  She does admit this probably wasn't a great idea.  There is a lot of luck in the rolls, and no game is complete without everyone constantly whining about bad rolls.  Someone on BBG calls the game "Whiners of Catan," and ain't it the truth!  As soon as someone stops whining, it's time to start stealing from them.

My introduction to the german games. I think that's the best game to introduce non-gamers to german games. In my opinion, the version with the wooden figures is much better than the new one that comes with plastic figures.
I love settlers and have all the expansions for it.
Settlers of Catan is the perfect balance between skill and luck, where the best strategy usually wins.  If I had to have only one game in my colection, this would be it.

Considered by many as one of the premiere “gateway” games, this is the title that got me into the much broader and deeper world of board games so, it holds a special place in my heart. Players are settling the world of Catan by trading resources and building settlements, cities and roads to be the first player to achieve the number of points needed to win the game. Easy, elegant, quick to pick up and explain and, of course, fun to play!  Trading and strategically placing key roads and buildings are well balanced. A must for any game household!
This is a great game and I am glad it was introduced to me by a Exchange Student from Hollan.

Add me to the list of "Love It"s.  As does everyone i've introduced to it.  The 'gatewayness' is what makes it a 10 for me - you can introduce this to anyone!  You'll have a good time, and so will they
One of the best game systems ever devised. Easy to play with family and friends.

In the beginning I thought this game would be more about the luck of the dice then strategy, but after my 1st game I have found that it is how you utilize the dice rolls to win the game. People who say this is all about rolling the dice and taking resources are not seeing the complete and total genius of this game. I have been gaming for over 20 years and this is a "must have" for every strategic gamer.

The modular board and trading are fantastic mechanics for replayability and player interaction. Settlers provides a nice balance between long-term planning and randomness. Its always a thrill to have your cities start producing after clawing your way forward in the early game.   I've always preferred vanilla Settlers to the expansions. For a so-called gateway game Settlers has a LOT of rules. Adding in expansions doesn't seem like a productive way to recruit new board game enthusiasts. Why complicate a fantastic game when you can pull out any number of other games that will introduce new mechanics?  ASIDE: I also have the Korean version (카탄), which is basically the Kosmos version. However, the new plastic mold pieces were missing from the box! If only I knew who to contact. Kosmos did not reply to my email. Oh well.

I especially like this game three-handed, as it's fast and easy to play quickly.  However, with four it's a bit more crowded and luck's harsh mistress has more time to kick yer butt.  I also like the Cities and Knights expansion, but it's pretty darn long that way...
Like most Eurogames, I like how there is more than one set way to win, your strategy must be tailored to the board's layout each game, and it is easy to teach to new players.
Every game should be like this one: simple rules, always under 1,5 to 2 hours, half interaction, half some thinking. THE perfect game.

My rating perhaps is particularly biased.  And, to be sure, this game gets its share of derision here at BGG.  Maybe some of it is just; after all, there is a significant luck factor.  But I am among the legions of gamers for whom the genesis of eurogames began with Settlers.  And after ten years, I'm still happy to play it.  I love the interaction, the planning, the scheming.  So yes, Settlers deserves its pedistal in my household.
Classic and must have for every gamer... and nongamer too :) A lot of fun and interaction between players. We play this game for many years now.

Wasn't really thinking of getting this, but the guy at my local store told me it was a "Must have", so I bought it. He was right! Can't play this enough. My kids like it, my g/f likes it. All of my friends who've tried it like it. The dice roll for production makes things just random enough to lessen the advantage a veteran player has over a novice.
Greatest family game of all time.  I've introduced it to 8 year olds, and construction workers, and professors and  they all loved it.  A staple game for any collection.  even better with expansions.
The one that taught me to love boardgames!
A modern classic. The ten rating includes my favorite variants.

Love the possibilities of intrigue. When I play, I consider everything that is of benefit to a player as legal, even if that means colluding with others to prevent a win by someone else. After all, it's all about winning, and if someone else wins, you can't...

This one is a modern classic for good reason--it's great! An outstanding example of how to blend strategy, luck, attractive components, player interaction, and reasonably short gameplay. (The games that go too long are the ones where someone is overworking the trade negotiations.)

My first Euro!  Despite BGG complaints about the dice and luck, I've always loved this one and haven't played it so much that I'd ever turn down a play.  4 players is better than 3. Great interaction and table talk.
The game that got me addicted to board games. I've gotten my wife, parents and inlaws hooked on it.  Must have game for everyone.

Great game and one of my favourites, even after 30  games played. Lots of interaction and most people i've played with like it too. There is not an awfull lot of strategy about it, the game can however be spoiled a bit by bad placement of your starting villages. (12 jan 08 after 39 plays)
I like the mix of strategy, negotiation and luck, but the most important is .... fun
Finally moved this up to a 10. I love this game. And, I can play it with gamers and non-gamers alike, always a plus.
one of our first games, nice to see buildings groove up. new games around but this is still played again and again.
My favorite all time game--no expansions, 4 player.  Nowadays, I like to play fast (30-45 minutes) with experienced players.

12/18/08 - It took me a *long* time to warm up to this game.  I guess I was just too daft to understand it before.  Now that I'm enlightened, I guess there really isn't much more to say about it that hasn't already been said (by its advocates).  I will say, however, that comments that this game is random reek of more ignorance than just about any other stereotypical BGG comment.  I guess this is yet another example of a game whose ultimate pay-off has turned out to be inversely proportional to my original dislike of the game (Ra, Dune, Antiquity being a few others).
This is a great game, it is easy to learn but has sufficient depth to keep me coming back for more. The random board layout is a genius piece of design making every game feel different.

Easy to learn game with more strategy than meets the eye. Too many people point at luck of the dice roll, but when the same good players can consistently win that says there's far more than luck at work here.

This game is probably one of my top favorites. It might be because it was the first game that I played at my school's game club, but it is just a really great game. Pretty much good for everyone to have and play.
After about 12 plays, love this game, and to hate the robber! I need to contain myself while playing, as this game can provoke the beast!  #1 on my list.

I have Settlers, Cities and Knights (without which I would never ever play again), Seafarers, and the 5-6 players expansion for everything.  It takes 1 big and one small box to fit everything in, and has travelled to the US and back with me :D
Always THE GAME to get new people to play Eurogames.
To me, this is the "Dark Knight Returns" of the board game world.  Like many others, this is the one that really turned me on to board games again.

SoC isn't a perfect game.  It's not even a game that I like to play often.  A string of dice rolls that go in someone's favor will almost always give them the game since the rich get richer.  However, no other game I have has as much power to pull in non-gamers.  SoC's blend of building, trading, and conquering new territory is amazingly engaging for most people.  It's not until you've played it several times that its flaws appear, but by that time you can migrate budding gamers over to Puerto Rico.  ;-)
A good game to play with friends and other life forms

Great game to play with friends. Game can drag for players stuck with poor resources; basic games runs quicker and is a good intro game.  Expansions give the game more depth - but lengthen the game considerably. UPDATE: This has made it out a few more times onto the table as the plain-vanilla version. Still enjoy this game alot.
The main reason why my Boardgame collection has taken over the house! Great

This was my introduction to European games, and it still stands as one of the very best.  Short enough to get played often, but long enough to be satisfying.  Simple enough to teach casual gamers to play (and they like and understand it), but still a very engaging and fun game.  Has lots of decision making and player interaction, and requires a good mix of luck, strategy, and trading.  Loving civilization-type games, I really like the way this one plays.  Also, I made my own board, which makes it look awesome: www.boardgamegeek.com/image/152673
Such a well crafted, accessible and replayable game. Only thing I can say is about the randomness of dice which sometimes can turn your "6-8-8-5-9" developpement into a lack of ressources nightmare.
With all the expansions, the best game in the world
A perfect game to play with or without expansions.
Ratings for Catan are largely for historical reasons.  This game should be in the Hall of Fame.  I like the Seafarers and Cities&Knights expansions, too.  Seafarers is part of the core game, for me.

(5/6 players needs expansion.)  Nearly continuous interaction, rare downtime, beautifully balanced, suffers only from positive-feedback syndrome, sometimes.  We play and enjoy straight from the box with 2.  (Playing with 2/3/4/5/6 is 5 different games.)
I still have 2 more boxes of cards.  I wanted the card game, but ended up with the extra cards that are used to replace the existing resource cards.

The balance of the game is really good and I like the fact that there is some cooperative interaction during the trading.   It is also a game that I can get people interested in.   An eight year old has played the game several times with us.  She has the basic concept of the game and she has even won once.
Very fun game to play.  Balanced play, nice bits, and a lot of replay value
The Gateway Game to other Eurogames, an econ professor at college introduced me to this game at one of the college-sponsored game nights. Been playing ever since

My "10" rating is really for Settlers and all of its variants; nearly infinite variety from a simple system.  Yes, there can be a problem with a fall-away loser (but you can play the "food stamp" variant for that) or one can be frustrated when the dice don't roll "properly" (one can use chits or a dice deck for that problem).

I'll play this anytime there are 3 or 4 players with an hour and a half, so I give it a 10.  Have gotten back into playing this recently with the Fishermen expansion and Great River tiles.  And the new Event Deck is great!

My vote for the best game ever invented.  Should be played as is, without expansions.  I don't care if its ranked 100 or whatever: Settlers is the greatest.  Even 15 years on there are still no better games out there. Why?  First would be that every game is different, right from the start.  The modular board presents the players with a significantly different challenge each time - not many games do that.  Second, there is very little downtime.  Third, there is genuine end-game tension, not present in most multiplayer euros.

I've been playing this since the year it was published and I haven't bored of it yet (perhaps through scarcity of opponents - it's only flaw really is needing atleast 3 players), but IMHO as a game it's damn near perfect.
my favorite game of all time with all the different versions

It's classic for a reason. Neat, elegant and accessible. A game my gaming group is almost always in the mood to play. Almost no downtime due to everyone being involved on each turn and with right amount of interaction.  With 4 equally skilled players this is an almost perfect length and weight game for me.

The grand-mother of Euro games and up there with Ticket to Ride as the best gateway game out there.  Dice rolls produce resources, for each player on every turn, that they can trade or use to build bigger roads, settlements and cities for VPs and even more resources.  An accelerating game, it is always a sprint at the end, rather than a crawl like American counterpart games.  And must have addition to any gaming closet.
Excellent!!!It feels like is always your turn, love that. Never boring, fast paced.
I have never had a bad game of this.  Maybe I've played 50+ times, many of those with new players.  Just love the social aspect of this game.
This game always wants to be played
What can I say that hasn't already been said.  A great game that I will still play at any time (despite having played it over 500 times).

Simply one of the best games I have played in many years. Modular board ensures a different game every time. The luck of the dice can be a factor, but not enough to put you off playing again and again. Have played this or one of its expansions almost every week for a year now and still not bored by it yet.

Absolutely do not play with 3 players unless you first restrict the board size.  Resources must be tight or the game does not function.  Note also that there is a lot of random noise in this game, and occasionally you'll just get killed by fate.

[Original comment] This is currently the favorite game in our family (April 2005). It has most of the features we enjoy about gaming. There is a lot of interaction and negotiation with other players; the gameboard is different every time; there are enough important factors to consider that no single strategy will win every time; there is just enough randomness to make it interesting (and sometimes frustrating); the rules are not complicated; the game time is just right (we can now play a 5-player game in about an hour); and players have a number of options almost every turn, to require some decision-making. It's an excellent family game.  Update February 2006 -- We usually play with 6 players now, and it is still a family favorite.  (December 2006) And now, we're playing with 7 players, and it's still a favorite, although we've had to modify some rules to play with that many.  May 2009 -- This is still a family favorite, and we play it often.  October 2011 -- This long-time family favorite continues to be at or near the top of our selection lists for game days. We always play with at least 5 players, which makes for a crowded map. The negotiations, blocking, the moans over the dice rolls, and the surprises (like stealing the Longest Road to win the game) keep it high on our list of favorites. I doubt we will ever tire of this game, which is about as high a compliment as can be made.  November 2012 -- We may play this game forever. Our daughter and son-in-law purchased the fancy version with wood tiles, which makes the game much more attractive. It continues to be a family favorite.  2013-November:  We haven't changed our minds about this game -- it's still a family favorite.
I love this game! We have all the "flavors'' of Settlers, and for me it never gets old. It's simple enough to be a family game, but there's enough strategy for it to be fun for gamers.
more than a game... a gaming system, an almost unlimited capacity for fanexpansions, a true game engine.
Excellent game. We played this 5 times in a row the day that we got it!!
I will say that I have played this 200+ times - especially with C&K.  Before I knew any other Euro's we played this 3 times a night every night one summer.  Random set-up makes great replayability.
Great replay value and low entry point for non-gamers.  A must have title.

I rate this a 10 because I expect I'll always enjoy a game of Settlers, not because I have any delusion that this is one of the best game designs.  Because I've played it so many times, this is a comfort game for me.
Excellent game. Many different strategies and approaches. A great gateway game, especially for learning to think of multiple strategies.

A great game. Simple to play, has a good balance of luck verses strategy. I Like how you are encouraged to trade to get ahead. The hand size limits imposed by the robber keeps you from hoarding. It is easy to fall behind the development curve, but you can restrain a runaway leader by not trading. Anyway if some of the charity variants can level out the bad die rolls. A good family game.  On of the best games I played was a 4 player settlers - on player announced that he was building a settlement for the win only to find out he didn't have one more. The look on his face was priceless
Large Improvement w/ Cities and Knights Expansion
I just love it. It was my first "euro", and even though I play it often I still enjoy it. --------- Me encanta. Es el primer eurogame que conoci y no me aburre aunque lo juege siempre.
She's getting a little beat up. After 200+ plays, I'd say I've gotten my money's worth.
Arguably the best designed game of all time.
NEVER gets old. especially with the expansions.

This game deserves an emphatic 10 because it is a landmark in the development of modern boardgaming. It showed that the best rules-mechanical insights of wargames could be brought to bear to other kinds of boardgames to improve their designs too. Today's games are more interesting and challenging than all but a few favourites from my childhood.  Klaus Teuber didn't do this single-handed, but Settlers was a big contribution. It's great fun to play, and will long continue to win many new fans.
Simply awesome.  We got friends hooked on it, too, and it has spread.  This is a new classic.
You will need the 2 player varient as found on the Geek to play with 2 players.  I love this game even better than Puerto Rico.
This is really one of our favorite games. Can be insanely tense with the right players.

The game that got me back into games!    Though I have played this game a lot, I continue to love the balance of strategy, probability, trade, and animated negotiations.  The randomization of start tiles provides substantial replayability value.  I have not played a game I consider its equal for being simultaneously enjoyable to both new and experienced gamers.
After hundreds of plays I still love this game.
One of my favorite games since its release in 1995. Thanks to never ending stream of scenarios (both official and inofficial) have the game never grown stale.
Trading and multiple paths to victory really make this game what it is.

F&%k all the elitist, snotnose backlash this game gets from people who think they've "moved on" to supposedly superior fare like PUERTO RICO- SETTLERS is the definitive Eurogame and the absolute best in its class, a truly transcendant title that encompasses the best that gaming has to offer.  Direct and meaningful player interaction, luck and strategy, long term planning and situational flexibility, competition, and a sense of narrative development serve to ensure that SETTLERS will long outlive the 5000 or so inferior European designs that have followed in its wake.  This is truly one of the watershed titles in the hobby on par with DUNGEONS AND DRAGONS and MAGIC: THE GATHERING in terms of industry impact, accessibility, and paradigm shifting.  It saddens me to see folks say how they've somehow burned out on SETTLERS when this is one of the rare games that has virtually unlimited replayability and is almost always a unique and fun experience.  You don't like the dice?  Go do Sudoku puzzles and cram your statistics textbook up your ass.  The dice make the game dramatic, variable, and it forces players to adapt and adjust throughout the game.  With trading, you are _never_ screwed unless you're one of those shrewish gamers who's afraid to speak up at the table to get what you want.  Without a doubt, one of the greatest games ever published and a timeless classic.
Settlers of Catan is a pure classic.  If you have not played Settlers yet, you do not know what a good game is.
The perfect game.  I love everything about it and will never tire of playing it.
This has to be one of the funnest games I have ever played. It is timeless. It makes frequent appearances at our weekly get togethers.
I only log games on this one if we play under 5 players - which is rare.
I have loved this game since getting it years ago both friends and family have enjoyed playing for hours.
Great fun, wish I could play it more.

This is THE game, the first german game I played in 1996 and was a total revelation. It literally changed my life, 10 years later and I have nearly 1400 german games. Siedler had such radical design ideas, the modular board, the probablity theory in play, the player interaction, but above all the positive progression to a winning target. Such a huge influence on gaming, and Klaus Teuber deserves the rich rewards it's earnt him.
If this isn't a classic, what is?
I love settlers.  I have played most of the settlers games and enjoy almost all of them.
Although I like the Cities & Knights expansion, nothing beats the basic game.  Perfectly adapts to 2-4 players with simple variant.
This is a must have staple of gaming.  It is the perfect balance of strategy and luck.
This game is just fun! Easy to learn, hard to master and damn addictive.

This game got a lot of people interested in games for the first time.  It involves strategy, negotiation, luck, and fun.  Just look at the number of people who have voted on this game.  It's solid (although the 2 additional player expansion is a must).
One of the most beautiful and perfectly balanced games ever devised.

Acquired 2/28/97 (original German edition, 2 copies)  A favorite! Snagged my brother's copy in the fall of 1996 and have loved it since the first game. Have introduced many friends and family to this game as well.
Very good game. I have it for two weeks know and I play almost every day since then. Just great.
This is the game responsible for changing the way I think about board games.  I think my first play was in late 2005.  I only wish it were a bit quicker to set up.

It annoys me that this is not higher up in the BGG rankings.  This is the superlative game.  It is short, it has endless replayability.  Each game feels completely different even after thousands of games (which I have played).  A beginner can win on their first try although the game rewards experienced play.  Everyone is involved in the game on every turn.    And best of all this game is FUN FUN FUN.  If you haven't played this yet then what on earth are you waiting for???
My gateway game. Still love to play it, but it seems like everybody I know has been burned out on it. :(

This new classic is a favorite that I have played many times.  Build a colony to get 10 points before the other players.  There is luck invovlved in what resources you recieve, but good placement of settlements and cities can help balance the luck.  Trading for what you need is almost necessary to win consistently.
I am looking for any additions to the original game!
This game is simple, easy to learn, fun to play, and is hard to beat.  One of the best games ever made, especially once you add the main expansions.
Fantastic game, first of the Euro-style games to grab my attention
la madre de los juegos de mesa

I don't have anything to say about Settlers that hasn't already been said, but I'm still compelled to point out that, in my experience, nothing gets newbies hooked on contemporary board games quite like Catan.

This is the groups top favourite game. Though we ALWAYS play it with C+K, and Seafarers (scenario 1), and fishermen. C+K does make it a longer game, but the expansion adds a lot to strategies and tactics.
One of my all time favorite games.  I love the strategy, rule set, and potential quickness of play.  When you get four good strategists together for Catan, you can have hours of fun.
The bar was set very high with this game. The benchmark that all others will be judged. This game is best if you can get the cards that replace the dice and the Cities and Knights expansion.

Like many people, this is the game that introduced me to German games, and probably the boardgame I played the most for a long time.  It almost never fails when introducing new people to hobbyist games.

A guy I knew from GW gaming showed us Settlers... I loved it. Later on in college, a friend showed me the copy he picked up during a visit to Germany. The rest is history! I absolutely love this game. My personal favorite of the millenium. I have introduced countless people to Euros through this game, and only a handfull have not enjoyed themselves. When I think about Eurogames, I think about Settlers of Catan.UPDATE: I finally have grown a little weary of Settlers. It is an amazing game, for sure, but I realize that there are many more games out there to be discovered. I'll still play it gladly if requested, but will probably push for Cities and Knights over the basic game. I do, however, give in to the fact that Settlers is the biggest deal as far as my board gaming history goes, and for that reason it now gets a 10, even though I'm a lot less likely to play it.
Really great game, nice, simple and playable by anybody. Everything sticks well together.
superb - the most popular game in our group
Classic family game with some strategy.

Always a great time. Easily one of my favorite games and it's been that way for years.  Adding expansions only makes it better (generally speaking at least) and in picking and choosing which you use and what possible varieties and scenarios, you can create a lot of different feeling games within the Catan universe.
No other Eurogame does Eurogames better than Settlers.
Still the most played game on our household.

Love this game. Very friendly, family game. The only thing is the time to set it up requires some time before the game. But I love the Seafarers edition, as it adds the whole border around to keep everything in place and ships as another option.   I'll never pass up Settlers.

In my fantasy world of infinite lifetimes, one of those lifetimes is spent as a games evangelist, teaching Settlers to every interested person I meet.  I think it has all the essential ingredients necessary to change the way people think about games.

If I'm going to play a Euro, it should be exciting, and Settlers is certainly that.  The dice rolls really make the game--they let the drama of not getting what you need, of being forced to make new plans, rise up.  My only complaint is that you can be out of the game before your first turn if your initial set up isn't well thought out.  That is a huge barrier for new players versus experienced players, but the game seems to have done alright for itself.  Certainly worthy of its status, and I don't understand why it isn't ranked higher.

Don't believe the revisionists and the people who are too hip to like Settlers anymore.  This game is incredible.   It single-handedly rejuvenated the boardgaming hobby.    It is one of the most reliable games for introducing non-gamers to real games.  As such, its the game I still play most often.
Total number of plays of All Catan games is, really, undeterminable.  Back in college, we played like 2 games a day. I inserted a random 70 as a base value, probably more in the 300 range...

Once my favourite game. I played it excessively for years. My cards and tiles are really worn out, but I don't want to buy the new version with those awful plastic pieces. Still a very good game, but I just got a bit tired of it and play it not that often anymore. I'm still using it to lure people away from playing only Monopoly and to introduce them to the world of board games.

This is possibly the greatest family boardgame I have ever played.  My wife and I both love this game and we have introduced it to so many people, we've lost count. A great game for after-dinner, mini-tournaments, anytime..!
I have been introduced to many Euro/Designer games since the beginning of 2000.  After all of these years, this game is still my favorite.
Brilliantly simple, clean, and fun.  All you Catan haters better come correct.
It's Settlers of Catan. Maybe the quintessential Euro. If you haven't played it, you need to. Then decide for yourself if you like it.
Classic. Does nevet get boring. Played it hundreds of times, and still fun. Quick easy, can be won with skills. Best game so far.
Excellent game.  Have played hundreds of times and hope to play hundreds more.
3rd edition  I know, the random aspect of supply usually gets this game knocked down a little bit... but I still think it is one of the very best games out there.

* Upped my rating from an 8 to a 10 as I realized that I would likely never turn a game of Settlers down.  It's a well distilled ruleset that epitomizes the "euro" game.  Simple enough for folks to grasp and play in a single evening, yet still provides plenty of opportunity for thinking and anaysis.
This is my favorite board game.  I can't play this enough!
What can I say that hasn't already been said? An amazing game, through and through.
So many classic nights of Catan and vino... I even have stains on my original board where the glass has been spilt numerous times once you're hooked you must get all the expansions!!
I have an extra copy of the third edition of the base game
This game single-handedly turned my non-gamer fiance into a gamer.  What more could you wish for?  ;-)

The game that got me back into thinking about board games and ultimately finding Board Game Geek. Made it to the final four in the Australian championships 2006 in Albury. What a fluke! ...... and did it again in 2007. Maybe it wasn't such a fluke after all!

The day after I played this game for the first time, I set to work making my own version of the game out of tag board, colored paper, and random pieces from other games. After about 75 games on said board, I passed it onto my nephews and forked over some cash for the real deal. Hundreds upon hundreds upon hundreds of games later and I'm still addicted.
This game is the number one game in my collection. Everyone loves it, and it gets used often. Tip: sleeve the cards for this one.
Excellent game - everyone should own it

Awesome.  My D&D friends got me hooked one night, I bought it for myself the next.  My wife is now totally addicted and our epic confrontations determine who buys dinner on Friday.  Yes free dinner.  Totally sweet.
This is the best board game I have ever played!

Yeah, I know. It was my first Euro love - german version purchased from Games People Play way back. I haven't played it to death, so I still love a good game of it.   I probably am technically breaking the description for the "10" rating. It is true that I don't play this much, so a game of it is generally welcomed. The 10 largely reflects my admiration for both that the game was my gateway into the whole world of Euros, and the mechanics it introduced to me.
The first game any lover of board games should own, and arguably, the only one you'll need.

This is the game that got me really into Eurogames back in '96. I had a (very) small selection of Euros at that time, but was mostly playing Magic and Warhammer FRP. Settlers and the Settlers card game were the games that changed it all. But even if another game had been my introduction, I still would appreciate Settlers for what it is: an instant timeless classic, that got a whole generation back to the playing table. I don't play it as regurarly anymore (certainly not the base game only), but it's always a blast when I do. I'm really looking forward to play this with my girls one day.
The FIRST game I played, and one of my all time Favorites!! But I'm still looking for other new games to play with my bf and our friends.
what else is there to say - my favorite game of all time
Classic. Best with 3 players, so the chances of someone having to overcome a dramatically worse opening position are lessened. Lots of dice but it's short (esp. with 3!) so that's ok.
Almost my favorite game.  I like it best with 3 players though. Gasp!

I finally, and I mean, finally played this game in 2007 after years of hearing about it from several different people over the years, and sure enough, I was hooked. And now, because of Settlers, I'm discovering all of the other great games that have come out in its wake.  But having played several others and checked out many more, I realize just how great Settlers really is.  Such a terrific balance of factors and a lot of interaction, and so many games that are very tense and come down to the wire in that "anyone could win it in their next turn" kind of way that Settlers is famous for.
A great game. Very easy to learn, with a lot of variety and possible strategies once you get used to it. Try the islands variant for a real challenge.
It's Settlers of Catan.  Do I really have to say anymore =P?

Incredibly fun and replayable game, due to randomness and each player's personality expressed in his/her choices and way of trading.  Lots of interaction anytime, which makes it good for almost no downtime at 4 players.
Own 2 copies of 3rd edition.  Also have 2 Settlers wooden game boards, 1 set of 4th edition replacement cards and 2 longest turn (negative victory point) cards.
I think settlers of Catan is one of the best board games ever created. I usually play a variant (cards are visible and a lot of trade is being conducted among players).

A classic that should be in the top ten. Many NEWNEWNEWBUYBUYBUYERS find this game 'dated', which is absurd really. Dated in what sense? How? Not only do I owe Settlers my entire existence as a game hobbyist, but it is a fantastic game that manages to appeal to both the strategic gamer and those who have only played mainstream games. As the groupthink wheel slowly turns and the NEWNEWNEWERS get sick of the 10-mechanics-and-a-pasted-theme Euros, when the simple, elegant loveliness of the classic Euros comes back in fashion, Settlers will return, slaughter the suitors and reclaim its crown.   I love the dice. They add a tension and risk management to what might otherwise have been a dull resource conversion game (as if we need another one of those).   COPY AND PASTE FROM MY GEEKLIST RANT:  Settlers of Catan's slide towards the bottom of the top 100 is proof again of the silliness of BGG's ratings system and its bias in favor of new-and-shiny games over the classics. Like Monopoly (which is also much better than BGG gives it credit for), Chess, and dozens of other older games, Settlers of Catan's popularity, age, and ubiquity work against it having a higher rating, but it is still one of the best introductory games and one of my favorite Eurogames.   The saturated, consumerist board game market, with dozens of new releases every week, encourages players to shallowly rate games after one or two plays--which makes no sense since it often takes several plays to internalize the rules for even a simple game to the point where a player can focus on actually playing the game well. Market saturation encourages us to "take his word for it" and rate with the group (many members of which will be doing the same thing) so we that can unwrap the next package.   Coupled with the saturated market is BGG's stranglehold on board game culture. The dominance of one information-outlet is not conducive to a free thinking environment, even in the case of user-generated content websites like BGG. A glimpse through the comments section for any top-100 game shows that raters are often repeating or paraphrasing the comments and judgements of other raters. Absolute democracy, which under-informed (because few of us have time enough to play any but our favorite games more than once or twice), user-generated content websites often resemble, encourages groupthink and the tyranny of the single persuasive voice. The practice that a few well known "game critics" have of passing judgement or rating games after a single play is intellectually dishonest and ethically suspect.   Don't get me wrong, I love BGG and spend too much time here looking for new games, but the ratings system has never been much use to me beyond providing a starting point for game research. Giving anything but the most minor significance to which game lies where on the scale is the equivalent of basing judgements of worth and value on the results of a popularity contest.   A thousand unwise voices rolled into one do not necessarily become one wise voice. It's too bad that Settlers may not show up on the first page of the top 100; it is a fantastic game, and one that I will play any time and anywhere.

The very essense of what makes a game elegant: simple rules, fun to play and there's nothing in the game that doesn't have a place or that shouldn't be there. OK, it's a probability-based game, so you can play optimally and still lose, while the random setup occasionally produces a board so imbalanced that the start player effectively wins by placing his first settlement. Overall though, a superlative game with bags of appeal to both gamers and families alike that would have entirely eclipsed Monopoly by now, if only Settlers were better known. This is the gateway game that I turn to whenever I'm playing with casually interested 'non gamers'. It's never missed yet.

Still enjoyable after all these years. The standard four player game is my favorite. Nice blend of player interaction (trading) with resource management. I find it amazing that the dice rolling alone turns some people off.  Here's a nice quip about the game:  "You don't like the dice? Go do Sudoku puzzles and cram your statistics textbook up your ass. The dice make the game dramatic, variable, and it forces players to adapt and adjust throughout the game. With trading, you are _never_ screwed unless you're one of those shrewish gamers who's afraid to speak up at the table to get what you want. Without a doubt, one of the greatest games ever published and a timeless classic." -- crackedlcd81

For my 13th birthday 1995 I got to buy two games. One was a version of Risk with nice plastic miniatures, the other was the first edition of Catan. I dont know where Risk is lying around right now (it's not that bad of a game though), but Catan has always stayed with me.  It's a great combination of theme and mechanics, everything works neatly together. Best family game of all times, for sure.  Dont like the new plastic pieces though. I'm glad I got the wooden ones!

Settlers is great for its accessibility to new players and the way the game encourages player interaction. The variable board setup adds replayability and long-term interest, while the (mostly) static number arrangement ensures the probabilities are always balanced, even when some resources are scarce. The element of luck can be overly strong at some times, particularly if one player gets a string of bad rolls at the beginning of the game. In other games (Tigris & Euphrates, Puerto Rico, etc.), the player can always take some productive action even when luck is not on his side; in Settlers, the player simply cannot act. I would like to see an official way to mitigate bad luck, but some version of the '[url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/150443/the-famous-welfare-variant]welfare variant[/url]' should work well enough. While I appreciate that trading keeps players engaged, I do not enjoy the mechanic as much as other modes of player interaction, as I feel like I have to 'act' in order to play well. For this reason, the game isn't at the top of my list, but I do enjoy playing it with the right group. [8] (2012-03-23)  After many more plays of Settlers, my appreciation for the game -- and rating -- has improved greatly. Strings of good/bad luck can still hurt, but with good placement (diverse numbers) and repeated play, I don't see it as a major flaw in the game; rather, it is most often the result of a flaw in a player's initial placements. Sometimes it's not, but that's to be expected in a game with dice, and it's not likely to happen again in the next game (or if it does, it's an indication that the fault may in fact be with the player). I will now gladly recommend Settlers and will play it any time I am offered the chance to do so, especially with 4 players (3 is also ok; 5 and 6 work but 4 is preferable). I appreciate the fact that though the game is fairly simple (very few rules) and repetitive (each turn offers the same single mandatory action and few voluntary actions, compared to worker placement or role selection games), the game is still tense and exciting due to the competition for key settlement spots, the need to make a critical trade, and the fear of letting one player get too much of a lead before others are positioned to catch up. A great design worthy of all the praise it has received. [8 -> 10] (2014-01-22)

Great 4 player game if played quickly, though usually more even as a 3 player game. Slow players can spoil the game, simply because there is no excuse for AP; decisions are rarely difficult (initial settlement placement excepted). Has a lovely acceleration towards the end game, when 3 players (4 if you're lucky, but more typically someone is being crushed) are often in with a shot of winning if the dice roll their way. Fun with kids if you give them a smaller VP target (e.g. 7 or 8 vs. 10 for adult). Liked this game enough to make a custom 3D board... guess it has to be a 10.

The idea that you take a turn, and roll the dice, but you may not get resources and your opponents may get them - brilliant! Keeps everyone engaged throughout the game - and nobody is eliminated and can play all the way thru till the end. Wonderful! Pretty much tied with Boggle for my favorite game. Settlers has so much room for change with the unique board for every game, and the complete arbitrariness of luck on the dice roles that I almost never get tired of playing. The game is great both for 3 or 4 players, with each situation providing for a very different kind of game. It's also possible to combine two sets of the game to play with 5-7 players (though I wouldn't recommend going over 6), and without needing to buy any of the expensive expansions. Every time I introduce a friend to this game, they get hooked by about half-way through the first game. Settlers is a great strategy game which doesn't rely solely on brute force and has no military based. Rather, one relies on trading resources as well as timely and intelligent use of them buy, barter and build one's way to victory. Highly addicting, but you'll never regret getting hooked!

Get the 5-6 player expansion and use it even for 4-player games; the more open island keeps players who get off to a slow start from becoming frustrated in their attempts to build.

This is the game that got me into the hobby, as seems to be the case for a lot of people on BGG. It also appears that many have abandoned the game as too "random." I've toyed with posting a defense of Catan in the forums, but I think there are several threads already discussing that. In short, the strategy is certainly obscured somewhat by the dice rolling mechanic, but to argue the game is random or luck based is far from the truth. After countless plays both in person and on XBox Live, I argue that the number of games that are severely tainted by absurd dice rolling statistics are fairly rare. Much more often, mistakes in judgement, or strokes of genius drive the outcome. Most importantly, getting the final 1-3 points often feels like a rewarding puzzle. Throw in that there is usually at least one other person vying for those points, and you have a quite satisfying climax.
The game that brought me back in the boardgame world. And it is a great game.

I rarely see true mastery in game design, but, at least in my opinion, Settlers of Catan has it. The game is based enough on luck that a newbie can reasonably have a chance but based enough on skill that experienced players will have the edge. The social aspect of this game is brilliant. Half the fun is not spent actually playing the game, but rather playing with friends or complete strangers and making stupid jokes about "building a walmart" that "buys out the other settlements". If you can, purchase this game. You won't regret it.

This is the game that got helped me rediscover my love for boardgames.  Up until I played Catan (circa 2005) the games I mainly played were Risk!, Samurai Swords (Ikusa), and Strat-o-matic Bball.  Catan served its purpose well of a gateway game.  I played this game (usually 1-3 in one sitting) and its variants once a week with a gaming group (usually 4-6 players) for about 2 years.  Catan led me to playing other games from other publishers and is no longer played much at all.  Nonetheless, Catan is in my hall of fame.

Love it!  I don't care if we have the strategy down; the games are still different every time!  But I like the Cities and Knights expansion with it even better.  The fish are OK.  And I just won a 4th annual Settlers of Catan tournament, the first lady to do so.  So fun.

Settlers is the game that really turned me on to board games in a big way. It is the first eurogame that I ever played and I have yet to get bored of playing it. Ótimo jogo de negociação, administração de recursos e construção de aldeiras, cidades e estradas. Fator sorte tem seu peso, mas a estratégia também. Divertido, ágil e de boa aceitação entre todo tipo de jogador.
THE best game ever made. Nuff said.
May not be the game I want to play most often these days, but as far as I'm concerned this and Titan are the pinnacle of board game design. Will always be up for a game.

My rating: (out of five) Strategy: 4 Luck factor: 3.5 - medium (ok lvl). Players interaction: Medium Passive, High Active Play/Wait Ratio: Medium.  Replayability: 3.5. Strong rich-get-richer mechanic.

OK, why this game isn't rated higher is beyond me. I have the original 1995 German verion, and even though I like some of the expansions, the plain old normal Catan is still my favorite!
