This is the game that started it all for me. Now it's four years later, and no matter how many other games I try I can always be convinced to go back and play a game of Settlers.  This game is everything a board game should be. It's simple enough on the surface that anyone can pick it up, but there's enough depth of strategy that you'll be just as entertained on the 50th play through. Games are long enough to be satisfying, but you don't have to give up an afternoon to play. It has the perfect level of randomness; skilled players win more often than not, but it doesn't mean they always do (which keeps it fun for all). Last of all, the shifting board and the importance of politics make this game endlessly replayable.  The only con I can see is that sessions of this game have on occasion almost descended into fisticuffs over particularly jerk trades.
a great game that many non-gamers can get into, a lot of fun, and despite depth of strategy the new player often wins

What can I say. Everyone should play that. It's the new, awesome, and much, much better, Monopoly. The ultimate non-geek and family friendly board game. I use this when I want to convince people that board games really are fun, and it works every time. I play almost every week, it's never boring.

I give it a 10, not because it is the best game ever, but because for what it is, it's basically perfect.  The key is not expecting more from it than what it is -- a light, luck-based social game.  It's qualities make it the most played game I own, largely because most of my friends are non-gamers -- for now.

A fun classic game that appeals to both more serious gamers and party gamers who want social interaction. In a mixed gaming group of friends, this is a huge plus. This game is classic for a reason. If you've never played it, it's not outdated, it's the best game of its type. Play it today.
Excellent game, the standard for introducing and teaching new game players and still satisfying after a hundred games.

I initially though of it poorly, seemed for newbies, too simple, too random, too shallow. I was too dumb, there's more than meets the eye in this game, it offers infinite replayability, with each new game a new scenario and a new experience arises. Never ending fun.
This is great game to play with friends, and is very easy to learn.
Simple.  Elegant.  One of the best games of all time.

Settlers of Catan moved me from Chess into board games. If I mess up in Chess, it's my fault and I am punished through the rest of the game. In Settlers of Catan, if I mess up, I have many options to recover. Let's face it, Settlers is the best game out there. People complain about luck and dice and, well, that's life, suck it up. This allows experts to have an advantage, but it always allows other players to be included. Strategy, interaction, little downtime, re-playability - Settlers of Catan has it all. Don't let people complain about thinking that it has too much luck. It is good to lose sometimes, even though you are as prepared as possible. This got most of us into board games, and is available everywhere for good reason.

This is hands down the best board game ever created! Every play is different!  There are different strategies and different variations to try to change it up a bit.  I'm always up for a game of settlers!  You must get the 5-6 player expansion too though so that you have the opportunity to play with a more varied number of friends/family.

I can only think of 3 games I've played hundreds of times and this is one of them. It has relatively simple rules and a randomness associated with setup and resource production which leads some people to believe that this game is more luck than skill. They are wrong. A combination of strategy , trading, and diplomacy can overcome bad initial setups and bad rolls of the dice.  The only thing that stops very experienced players from winning the vast majority of games against less experienced players is that the less experienced players learn after a few games that their only chance is to gang up on the more experienced/skilled player if it looks like they're in the lead. And that leads to more experienced players adopting strategies that make it appear as if they're behind in the first half of the game even though they're setting themselves up for a sprint at the end . . .  One thing I particularly love about this game are the slow-the-leader mechanisms (robber, trading embargoes, development cards) that makes it possible for people to come back from behind and win, which keeps everyone engaged, and makes this game fun to play even when player age and/or skill level is a wide range.
Great family game.  My wife and daughters (7 & 8) love to play.

IMHO This game really deserves to be number one.  I have played and enjoyed hundreds of games of this.  We play with randomised island setup, the ability to respond directly to robber attacks, with only a single development allowed for each player turn (unless retaliating attack).  All rules which were available to be used if preferred in the original game.

It had to be a 10. It is the one game that has seen the most plays in my collection of over 150 board games. Even after so many years it is the first one that gets picked when I want to introduce new people to the tabletop gaming fraternity. It's simple. The rules are easy to teach. People learn how to play and get into the game quickly. It provides a lot of player interaction. And almost every time this game is rolled out for a gaming session, it never stops at just one game, someone always says "Ooh, can we play again? I know what I want to try this time..." There is an element of luck, yes. But also the chance for negotiation and strategy.
love playing this game, i've introduced many friends to it.

Excellent!  - Good long term strategy game. Although luck affect the game a lot, you usually don't change your strategy. - Many possible ways to win, but yet, easy to learn - Good replay value. Also, have many good expansions. - Growing mechanism (except using resources or aiding other players more than to yourself, your in-game choices in game don't make things harder to you or block options for you)

O jogo conta com a sorte dos dados, sendo imprescindível escolher os terrenos com alta probabilidade de sair no dado (6 e 8), além de ser importante ter terrenos com minérios e trigo, estratégia mais comuns nos jogadores mais experientes...

Settlers of Catan with all its variants, is in my opinion perhaps the finest board game ever designed. Whereas Twilight Struggle and Through the Ages are both very flawed games which are insanely highly rated on Board Game Geek, Settlers of Catan is an unflawed masterpiece of game design. This should be rated #1 on BGG instead of #100.  When 25-30% of the people rating Twilight Struggle have never even played the game and the game reinforces American political delusions and thus is quite harmful in fostering such prejudices; in contrast Settlers of Catan is pure gold deserving of the number one rating when all of the hype from BGG is cut through.

I've gotten into the hobby for a little more than a year as of this writing. I realize this game is now generally thought to be past its time, and its merits as a "gateway game" are questioned, but it was the gateway game for me and my game group, and we do go back to this game regularly.  I've found it useful as a parent, my kids have learned the basics of setting up a game, taking turns, rolling dice, gathering resources, building, etc. They don't like the robber much at all (who does), and I found it interesting and funny when they banish the robber to a part of the board that isn't inhabited, so it doesn't hurt anybody.   When this game goes bad for a particular player, it definitely is frustrating eg. when the rolls aren't going your way or the robber is on you constantly as the rest of the table gangs up on you. And the 5-6 player expansion is not as enjoyable. Nevertheless the controlled but open negotiation of trades generally keeps people engaged throughout the game.  Our favourite "base game" is to add in the fish from Traders and Barbarians (takes away the desert, and gives the table another resource), and to also play with the Harbor Master to go along with the Longest Road and the Largest Army.   The 10 rating is in part given to historical context of my own personal journey into this hobby, as it is far and away the game I've played the most, that I continue to enjoy. It's also boosted up by our "base game" add-ins from the expansions. "Vanilla" Catan I would rate around 8 out of 10.

This game started my whole Board Game obsession!! Build settlements and cities, collect resources, grow your army and extend your roads. Gain victory points along the way. Reach 10 and your the winner! My number 1!!

The Perfect Game. Fast and easy turns, constant engagement with the board and other players no matter whose turn it is. Just the right amount of strategy and randomness with a little spite thrown in (the all-powerful Robber). Brilliant game, perfect for any group, new and old.

An elegant, perfect blend of player interaction, secret information, catchup mechanics, meta game, trading, area control, replayability, and luck.  People say that Catan introduced concepts that other games have since perfected, but I can think of no others that balance all these facets so seamlessly. A classic for a reason.
This game started my board game obsession.. love the way this game is played.

[b]Catan[/b] is one of my favourite games, and I rate it a "10" because I think every board game collection should include this game.  The game board is modular and therefore no two games are exactly alike.  Great game to introduce to non-gamers.  Everyone to whom I introduce this game ends up loving it.

A beautifully simple game.  The rules can be taught in a couple of minutes and due to the changing board and dice roles every game is different.  I've played literally hundreds of games and they're always fun.  Yes, sometimes you can have run away winners, and with the huge amounts of luck involved you can have a very poor game without really doing anything wrong, but the game is quick enough to play a few times an evening.  The more you play the more you find ways to mitigate against all the dice roles and maximise your resources, and quite quickly you find the number of games where you think you were unlucky dramatically starts to drop.
Currently, this is my favorite board game of all time.

I love this game.  Not because it is the best game in the world, it isn't; but because, I can bring it out at a dinner party getting everyone to play it and watch all those, who grew up thinking monopoly was the only game, suddenly start having a fun time.   Having played hundreds of games of Catan,I don't play that often; but it is my goto game for people who claim that they "don't play board games."

This game is a staple in our house, and the favorite go-to game among all our friends.  Occasionally we'll venture away from the game to try another, but we always come back to Catan.  The game is extremely repayable as the board game is set up differently each time you play, offering different strategies and obstacles to overcome every time.  This game isn't too heavy.  It doesn't feel like a game of chess, but it's not all up to the dice rolls either.  The balance between luck and strategy is like milk and cookies, a perfect balance and combination.

The game that will define Millenials and Gen X, Catan will forever be a staple in my collection and numerous others. Fantastic game mechanics, unique set ups, and nuanced strategy. My all time favorite game. Even if you are rolling bad, have bad tiles, or bad numbers, there are always ways to win. Comebacks and last minute twists are always in store. Also, unlike many games, there are things to do, when it's not your turn to keep inactive players, active.

I didn't want to give Catan a perfect ten, because it's not even my favorite game. Definitely get the expansion for 5-6 players.
I've played this game probably close to a hundred times. Favorite game of all time.

I always love to play this game, every time is different and whenever the odds are against me is enjoyable because I can still win, a must in every collection.

A game for statisticians: Catan cannot be won if the right numbers do not come. Nevertheless it is not a gambling game, because the different probabilities of two dice should be known. Those who are surprised that 2 and 12 are rarely rolled miss the appeal of the game. It's not about playing chess and it's not about gambling either, it's about improving your chances in a calculated way. Moreover, the game does not follow a more or less sophisticated game mechanics, but leaves the players room to make each other's lives difficult. This build-up game also appeals to children and it is a pleasure to see them grow into the mechanisms of trading and tactics.
The 4th edition is better looking than the 5th

Settlers of Catan  IMNSHO, this is the best multiplayer negotiation game ever to hit the market!  It has an incredible depth to its strategy that gets overlooked by “gamers” because they dislike the amount of luck in the game.  I used to despise the luck factor because I wanted to win if I was the best player at the table.  Now I'm just as interested in who I get to play with.  and the great amount of luck in Settlers makes the outcome of each game unpredictable even when I am playing with non-gamer friends.  At the same time, I am never bored during these games because the optimal strategy is in continual flux.  I am always amazed by how difficult it is to determine the value of each resource as the game proceeds.  Learning how to negotiate with different types of players is another aspect that never gets boring.  I have played this game well over 50 times and I still enjoy it.  This is unusual for me as I normally get tired of games that I can play with non-gamers after 1 - 3 tries.

Mayfair 4th edition.  Tossed out the plastic insert to make room for: 5-6 player extension, caravans, fishermen, great river, volcano, jungle, & rules for all of the above.Friends liked it so much, they ordered one, too!

[COLOR=#663300][b][size=11]Settlers of Catan[/size][/b][/COLOR] [COLOR=#663300][i]Note: My numeric ratings disregard BGG's associated verbal descriptions.[/i][/COLOR]  [COLOR=#006600][b]Comments: [/b][/COLOR]  We [b][i]always[/b][/i] play with a variant I found on an old version of Herr Teuber's site.  (I haven't seen this particular variant listed anywhere in the years since.)  As in "Poverty Is No Dishonor", a player who receives no resource on any single dice-roll receives a chip.  On his turn, if he has as many chips as he has visible points, he must trade them in to the bank for a resource of his choice.  This mitigates luck and helps less as a player's position becomes stronger.  I would not rate this game so highly if we did not play with this variant.  [COLOR=#006600][b]Why we own it: [/b][/COLOR]   This game is comfort-food for my gamer's soul.  In all the years since discovering Settlers, I think it's fair to say that almost all of our game purchases have been in the hopes of finding other games that please us as much as Settlers.  [COLOR=#006600][b]Details:[/b][/COLOR]  [COLOR=#006600]Version played: [/COLOR]Kosmos original, Mayfair 3rd & 4th editions [COLOR=#006600]Play History: [/COLOR]  [COLOR=#006600] • 3 players: [/COLOR] Many times — Space is less crowded; play is more relaxed  [COLOR=#006600] • 4 players: [/COLOR] Many times — Space is more crowded; play is more competitive  [COLOR=#006600] • 5 players: [/COLOR] Not good  [COLOR=#006600] • 6 players: [/COLOR] Not good  [COLOR=#006600]Instructions: [/COLOR]It's been years since I've read the rules, but I do recall feeling daunted by the separate rules and almanac booklets in the third edition.  That much printed material made the game seem more complex than it actually is.  I do appreciate the distinction between rules (for learning the game) and almanac (for clarifying details).  The fourth edition was printed in color, making the illustrations that much more helpful. [COLOR=#006600]Learning Curve: [/COLOR] Rather involved, yet intuitive.  In only a couple of rounds, a new player will have the gist. (Best to learn from an experienced player, rather than from the rulebook.) [COLOR=#006600]Depth: [/COLOR]Placement and expansion are quite strategic, but the social aspects dominate. [COLOR=#006600]Luck: [/COLOR]Dice can be cruel, so initial placement is crucial. [COLOR=#006600]Downtime: [/COLOR]Production and trading affect all players on all turns, so downtime is minimal.  Some friends have complained that the game bogs down during the trading phase.  [COLOR=#006600]Fiddliness: [/COLOR]Set-up is a bit fiddly. [COLOR=#006600]Components: [/COLOR]Some editions are sturdier than others, but they're all attractive. [COLOR=#006600]Player Interaction: [/COLOR]Trading is at the heart of this game, so player interaction is high. [COLOR=#006600]Conflict: [/COLOR]Particularly in a four-player game, room to expand can be tight.  This often means players will block one another's roads. [COLOR=#006600]Theme: [/COLOR]The theme is rather diffuse: settling a new land, and expanding and improving one's holdings.  The mechanics represent the theme well.  [COLOR=#006600]Travel related: [/COLOR][COLOR=#CC0000]Unsuitable.[/COLOR]  [COLOR=#006600]• Size: [/COLOR]Medium  [COLOR=#006600]• Weight: [/COLOR]Medium  [COLOR=#006600]• Table Required: [/COLOR]Yes  [COLOR=#006600]• Footprint: [/COLOR][COLOR=#CC0000]Large[/COLOR]  [COLOR=#006600]• Component Trackability: [/COLOR][COLOR=#CC0000]Poor[/COLOR]  [COLOR=#006600]• Replaceability: [/COLOR]Excellent

At first, I was a little wary about Settlers, with its dice rolling mechanics and such.  However, after playing it, I have to say that Settlers is what gaming should be about - great social aspects with viable strategies and tactics.  Sure, the dice may be unfriendly and give you nothing for a while, but for the most part, the game rewards the players who plan best and make the best choices.  When I first got onto BGG, this game was still rated an 8, but now it's fallen quite a bit.  I understand this is not truly a gamer's game, but I think people are either rating it based on no plays, or only 1 or 2.  This game needs to be played - it's fun and quite addicting =)
My Favorite. the perfect blend of luck, strategy and players interaction.

The first real Euro-game my gaming friends and I played.  My old college room mate brought it back from Germany from a business trip.  We played it and loved it.  The basic game is the best without any expansions.

This is the game that started our gaming revolution.  We'd always played boardgames, but when we discovered Settlers, everything changed.  For a long time, we played this almost every week, getting every expansion along the way.  We found this before we found BGG.  A great game.
I enjoy this game alot. Very simple game that is easily explained. The expansions only make this game better in my opinion.
I like this better than my husband.  He hates the dice.

March 2010: This game stands the test of time. I am a proud board gamer due 100% to this game. It just works. It's well designed and has interesting mechanics like negotiation that negates some of the luck factor of dice-rolling. Great gateway game that I'm still happy to play and teach to potential new gamers. Scoring a 9.5 for replayability, longevity, and ease of learning.

One of my favorite board games. A very good "gateway" game, the rules are simple, yet the strategy can be relatively deep. There is a lot of luck and taking chances involved as well. Very high player interaction with all the trading. Very fun game liked by a wide variety of people, easy to teach to beginners.
Same game I have, but German version!
Played to death and back again...

The basic game is great, but the myriad variations and expansions make this one of the best games, period. Easy to learn, not so easy to master. The one downside is that when all players are skilled at the game, it often just comes down to how the dice roll and where you are in the order of initial selection. If you haven't played Catan and play board games, what are you waiting for?

I came late to the world of Catan, but after having the game's merits described to me, I took a chance and brought the box home from the game shop.   I have never once been disappointed by this game. It's a perfect mix of strategy and simplicity. Everyone gamer I know loves this game, and there's good reason for it. The game mechanics are simple to learn and understand, but the strategy and luck elements keep it interesting (or frustrating) every time.  Setup time is relatively quick after the first few plays, and average game time has been around an hour depending on how chatty people get during trading and making up elaborate stories about why they're attempting to dominate sheep production.  I've never had this much fun simply playing a game and not caring whether I'm winning or losing. My experience with Settlers of Catan is becoming the standard by which I judge all other games.
The game that started it all (for me).
Самая лучшая стратегическая игра в нашей коллекции. Пока ничто не может с ней сравниться. Жена ее обожает. Жаль, что не всегда можем поиграть втроем.
I like the game. However, the dices annoys me everytime... If I don't put a village for first on "3", then in that game the dices will roll "3" for several times...

I've probably played over a hundred games of Catan. The only reason I don't give this a 10 is the excessive impact of the placement of the two starting settlements. You can knock yourself out of the running within the first ten seconds of the game, which can produce some icky feelings of remorse. For new players, I recommend playing with a fixed setup variant.

Love this game!  Got on a trade. Played the first time with my wife and cousin and we all loved it!  I've gotten to play with 4 players as well and still great game play. Like to see how the expansions play out.

What a fantastic game. This classic game has become the cool thing to not like by hardcore gamers. Very fun, very social, great combination of luck and planning, the perfect gateway game.
This is quite simply a classic board game.  Never boring, always a decent amount of fun.
Perhaps the best multiple plays game I have ever owned.  One of my all time favourites!
One of my favorite games of all-time, I prefer playing with the Cities & Knights expansion.

Euro gaming's biggest star: dice-directed resources that lead to building settlements and cities for increased power. This 3-4 player game involves all players through most of the game, offers decent challenges, excellent expansions, medium learning but easy to play -- and good for those who have wood for sheep.  MEGA PLUS: excellent iOS app HUGE PLUS: involvement BIG PLUS: expansions, challenge, ease of play BIG MINUS: length of play, 5+ player expansions are poor

+ Catan Event Cards + Fishermen of Catan + Helpers of Catan (PnP in sleeves) + Frenemies Scenario + Explorers and Pirates  Will only play base catan with newbies. I love the Explorers expansions. Makes it so much more deep and adventurous.

I own the Family Edition and it's the only version I've played so far because I wanted to start with the simpler version to play with my kids. They love it and we will probably pick up the full version soon.
