A great resource based strategy game whose board changes with every game. I love this international phenomenon as it is easy and complex at the same time excellent game

Definitely what started my enjoyment of board games. You can sit down and play this with your friends and just have a great time. The ultimate mixture of just enough strategy and luck to really have a good time... unless you get screwed by your opponents dropping the robber on you every time.

A estas alturas no voy a descubrir el Catán a nadie. Grandísimo juego de negociación, con mucha diversión, algo de azar, sobrado de tensión e interacción entre los jugadores. Jajaja... ideal para perder amigos ;).
Classic group game. A must for all board gamers
The game that introduced me to the world of games. I have fond memories of it, although I've already had enough of it.
I love this game because I can teach it to friends who don't play games and they tend to get really into it. It's always a great starter.

The base game is great, but not as much fun anymore after getting used to the expansions. The real Catan addiction started with Cities & Knights for me, together with Seafarers it's the best game i've ever played. And still doesn't bore me after loads of plays.   Freedom to pick strategies, some luck, strategy and player interaction. It's all there in perfect balance.
Mi primer juego. Sin duda, el que mas me gusta y el que primero saco para jugar

Catan, such a classic game. This is the definitive board gamer's game. It is expandable, full of strategy and is truly the definition of next level of board game beyond the Monopolys and Sorrys of this world. I have had a great deal of game nights in which the only game we played was Catan, and while I cannot say it is my all time favourite board game, I can say it is in the top 10. The only issues Catan struggles with is how brutal bad luck can be. Running low on luck (especially in the 4 or 6 player games) can make the game painfully slow and impossible to win if you get locked in.to a corner. This doesn't happen often to skilled players, but when it does it can just make the game drag on. I also added Harbor Master to the game and kept it at 10 points to win to keep things moving smoothly towards the end of the game. Overall, Catan is a classic everyone who is a gamer should own.
Gets too much hate in the board-game world; still a great game!
Best for 4 players.  4 of 10 for the weight.  Trading game that have a balance aspect between strategy and luck.  Great choice to convert others to board gamer.

Easy to learn, always fun and I've yet to find someone who doesn't like Catan. Only slight "problems" are that you can only have 4 players out the box and I've personally found the expansions not worth the time and money. Highly recommended though!
Positives: + Easy to teach + Players are engaged during everyone else's turns
In a review vacuum, this is an excellent game. It is not fair to penalize it for being old. This is easily the most influential game of my career

I don't think I will ever get tired of playing this game. I think a large part of what makes this game fun is how often you use puns in your trading and offers. "Can I get wood or ore" response should always be "ore what?!?!". But ultimately this game will always keep changing each time you play, and leave you wanting to kick your friends butt the next time you play.

A classic and my all time favorite.   Pros: Impactful decision making       Satisfying player interaction       Multiple routes to victory       Good length of time - not too long, not too short  Cons: Some players can be prone to analysis paralysis
I love this game! It is near perfect. It plays well with 3, but really seems like a game for 2 couples. When we have 4 to play, it's Settlers at my house!
Even since the occurrence of "better" games , this one stays near the top of my list.  Like most, it was my introduction to Euros.  I'll play it any time, anywhere, with anyone.
My gateway game. 3 or 4 friends  + beer + Catan = great time.
I will absolutely never turn down a game of Catan.

3-6 Player:  The second oldest game in my collection. I think Settlers of Catan is brilliant and really simple. It is very much responsible for getting me started into board gaming, and I still think it is a great unique design. It is also the best board game for trading. And I love Cities and Knights.  Expansions: Cities and Knights  By: Klaus Teuber

A Family favourite. 24/12/16: welcome back to an old friend:  27/12/16: Introduced E KP - another convert: 28/12/16: Introduced JS - Another convert: 23/05/17: Enjoyed another game, but finished a poor third. 21/11/17; TLGC - Introduced Sam as a 3 player. 25/04/18: TLGC - 150th play - Introduced Mikey and Stef. 2 more converts. 06/05/18: Another enjoyable game:
If you haven't played it, do so.

This is a great game.  I have scarcely found someone who doesn't like it, and can not grasp the rules quickly.  There are many different possible successful strategies.  The board is always random.  2 points I like about it.  I think it plays better with 3, rather than 4, if you are not using the expansion.

[color=#CC0000]  Every time I play I think I have it figured out, and as the game progresses I have to change my strategy.  The game is legendary, you owe it to yourself and to your kids to have a copy around the house.  Catch-phrases from Settlers are entering mainstream culture the same way "Do not pass Go" and "Free Parking" have from Monopoly.  This may be the one game from the last quarter of the 20th century to establish ubiquity.  The discussion after any game will give you a good clue about how good a play it is.  Settlers [b][i]always[/i][/b] produces a good post-game show.  [/color]
Ein absoluter Klassiker. Gesellig, interaktiv und immer wieder schön.
This was the game that introduced us to the world of Eurogames.  Will always hold a soft spot because of that - and the fact that it's an excellent game.
My gateway game! The only thing holding me back is possible optimal positions due to random layout.
~COMPETITIVE~  My introduction to "real" boardgaming, with all the adoration a first love can have. Also, the very successful gateway game I've used to convert around 20 people

A true masterpiece of a game. Doesn't seem like it could be so fun, to grow crops on a hexagonal board. But there is something about the game that makes it fun. Guess it's the combination of hoping that the dice will score your crops together with the trading part of the game. Also fun to build, try to block other players and plan in the beginning where to put your starting markers. The robber is surely also part of the games success. The game is a nice mixed between skill, luck and social skills.
Hall of Fame! Play it with the expansions only.
Great design. And great author... He made several other games that are really worth!
Plenty of positive player participation.  Sufficient strategic subtlety.
Classic for all time. Every game is really different. bought $100 w/T+B 5-6
You always feel like you have a winning plan.

One of my favorite aspects of this game is having a modulor board. 3 players is best. Playing with 4 players can get cramped when competing for start positions. It can lead to one player being left on the back burner not getting many resources.
Well, an absolute must for any game player. You can't call yourself a gamer if you don't own this game.
Great balance, easy to introduce to people. Only problem is that the magic number of players is strictly *4*.
I never seem to tire of this game. The Seafarers expansion set adds a lot of interesting game dynamics. This is a "must have" game.
I should recommend to play this game with the max number of players; this way, it's more challenging and balanced.
Easy and doesn't repeat itself easily. One of the greatest games ever.
A magnificent game of resource and expansion. I now consider all the expansions to form part of the original.

Everybody loves this one.  The first 'German' game I purchased... then it sat in my closet for almost a year.  After I finally played it, I slapped myself in the forehead and thought... "I better buy another copy...cause this is gonna see a lot of wear and tear."
Really liked this game. A lot of possiblities. I expect to play this often. The rating may go up.
A very well designed and balanced game. Games can drag a bit between your turn, though and the end can be tedious since it's often clear who is likely to win and who has no chance.
It's famous because it's a great game.  What can I add?  Try it and you'll love it.

However recently I've played this game - even if I've just played it twice on the trot - I'll always want to play it again.  I've played it many, many times and it is still as enjoyable as ever.  That's how addictive it is.  I still find the basic game superior to any of the expansions because of its elegance and simplicity.
A classic that will never get dusty on my game shelves.

A very well balanced dynamic tile based board game. Lots of fun, incorporates skill as well as chance in a great mix. Allows the opportunity for competitive play as well. A wonderful game all around, still one of our favorites.
Pick the wrong starting hexes and you will NOT win. Trade, trade and collect victory points!

Simply my favourite game.  Simply enough to teach people quickly, but interesting enough to spend devising strategies.  Excellent that several games can be played in one night.  Gave it recently to some friends for a wedding present, and it was their favourite present!!
A million Germans can't be wrong.  Oh wait - the Nazis...
GREAT game. I only give it a 9 because of its reliance on randomness, but I think a good strategist can maximize the randomness of the game. 4 players best, really doesn't play as well 3 player.
7 and 8 player games can only be played with 2 complete sets, but it is posible

the game that got me into gaming well actually it was the milton bradley gamemaster series, then battlecry which I bought by mistake which led me here, Settlers was my first foray into euro games...it's been all downhill since:)
With 4 players this is still one of the best games around. Downtime is basically non-existent as everyone is engaged on every players turn.

"blessed are the flexible, for they will not be broken" i really like tactical games that force you to modify your strategy during the game. this game is good for those who can best capitalize on whatever cards they have, good or bad. some say this is one of those "gamers games" but i can get almost anyone to play. once they play, they like it. slight element of luck allows even weak players to win one every so often. i usually play with 4 people total. once i played with 2, didn't like it. it will be a long time till i'm sick of this one. also get the computer version at www.the-underdogs.org
THE crowd pleaser for gamers and non-gamers alike.  Great player interaction...unusual for a Euro.

One of my favorites. Easy to learn and fun to play. Player interaction is good and the random board feature is just great. I have introduced this game to two different groups and they both love it. It's one of the favorites for both of my groups. I also got the Seafarers expansion (see my comment there) and the Cities & Knights is on my wish list.
A nearly perfect blend of strategy, luck and trading.

This is a great game and gets played often in our group, however, it wasn't quite a ten. I think that the player who goes first/last during the round in which the settlements are placed is at a high disadvantage. (At least, that seems to be the case in the four-player games.) Also, during some games, you can tell very early on who will be the winner, or at least who will be contenders for the winning spot. If you are not one of the contenders, the game is a real drag and you have to finish out the game.

What a wonderful game.  It was my, like many others, first "german" game.  I've always enjoyed playing it, even to this day.  It's cleverness, although somewhat faded after a BUNCH of plays, never completely fades away.  It's also a wonderful tool for converting new people to gaming.  The best of it's kind, in my opinion.  So, in addition to being fun, it serves a purpose at the same time.
Hugely popular, but a game which in my opinion favors luck over skill.

Wonderful mix of trading, planning, spatial maneuvering, and dice (used quite effectively despite their randomness). Much fun for all levels of gamers. Drawback is that sometimes the winner is determined early, and half of the game becomes just watching the inevitable.
A classic.  This is one of those games that I just can't get enough of.
I'm not sure exactly what I like so much about this game, but it's fun and seldom generates hard feelings when we play.

Sure, there's a fair bit of luck, but this is a great game.  No two games the same.  Cliche, but true.  There's a lot of replay value even without the expansions.  IMO, the game has the perfect length.
Very good game. Buy it. Simple to play. Endless fun, multiple strategies. I was never disapointed by this game.
Probably the most-played game I own.  The "food stamp" variant reduces the effect of skillful initial choice, but I think it's worth it, to avoid the frustration of many turns with no production.
Awesome game, fairly simple rules. Mid lenght duration, which means you can often play 2 games in the evening.
FANTASTIC multiplayer strategy game!  If anything, I've almost played it too much.

Excellent potential for getting future gamers hooked. Good variety with all the different expansions as random setup. Excellent player interaction - the more the merrier. I love playing 6-player with everything, where the trading is intense. I've played enough that I really do need to replace my resource cards. (Only started logging plays in 2003.)  And yet tonight, it is no longer a 10 for me. There's just too much sensitivity to the initial setup, and once in a while the game just becomes a chore. It's not short enough that you can just wipe that off and play again, so it's not a 10.
Very addicting.  Trading is key and a fun aspect of the game.

Great game for non-gamers; refreshing and fun.  I love the variable board and the concept is solid as well.  Lots of dice rolling, but as playing the odds is central to the point of the game instead of a quick fix for a conflict resolution, it does not harm the game at all.

I have done as so many people warn against and played this one out, bad.  The positive thing is it got me into boardgames, well I guess I am not sure how good of a thing that is.  Great game still and I will always be willing to play.

I give Settlers a 10 - it's not my favorite game (that award goes to Twilight Struggle), but I have to recognize what Settlers of Catan has done for board games.  It's introduced a lot of my non-gaming friends to a new world of board games.  For that, and elegant gameplay, I give Settlers a perfect 10.  Update (Summer 2012):  Moved to a 9, as I rarely play it anymore.  But it's still a classic, and incredibly important to the hobby.
Great game. Nice mix of strategy and trading. Not overrated.
Love this game too. Fast play, wife and kids love it. Very tense game too.
Great game, very well done, I own the Tilsit italian edition very amusing. Great fun for me and my family.

Critically acclaimed, and with good reason. One of the oldest Euros, but still one of the greatest. So many ways to victory, with great screwage throughout. It never gets old, and the balance of building and trading for VP is perfect. Definitely has lasting power.
A good "play with my GF" game.
Excellent game. Good for non-gamers as well.
Maybe an over-rated game, maybe not. I really like it. Good balance of luck and strategy. A nice "first" game for non-boardgamers.
A must! Every player must have a copy of this game.
Best intro to boardgames I've seen for nongamers.  Variety, elegant rules and quick gameplay after first game.
Been there, played that, again and again
Teuber`s masterpiece. Just like Monopoly, this one will sell forever. With "Cities & Knights" ita a "10!"
Very good for introducing boardgaming to not-players. Simple rules, variable board makes every game different.
A classic. Simple enough for many non-gamers, rich enough for most connoisseurs. Basic game is fairly quick and easy to learn, expansions add variety and depth.
I love it. So many strategies to choose from & different every time. I just need to keep teaching it to others so I always have someone to play with.
Great game.  I still call it Settlers :)
Very fun. First copy had all the wrong cards (28 ore) so i have to take it back and trade in the cards for good ones.

The first German style game I learnt, and still with me.  I bought a copy as soon as I could, and have since convinced a good half dozen others that it is an excellent game.  Simple rules, but they give the game a good deal of depth.  Unfortunately, "Settlers fatigue" is starting to kick in.
The Monopoly of the XXI century.
Great game, what else can I say.
Playing with three is actually far from optimal but still decent. I give it a 6 for three players.
Awesome way to get non-boardgamers into a game.
Very fun game, that's it, and thats enough...
One of the best games ever made. I give it a 9 though, cause the basic game gets too much alike when you play several games. With the expansions though it's an absolute 10!
Great game, one of my favorites.  Can't seem to get my kids to play quickly enough though.  Other than that it is one of my favorite games.
I love this game, top 10 definitely, but playing it for 9 hours straight just gets tiring.  Don't ask me why I keep playing it, but I get addicted

The one classic game you must have in your collection. Easy to learn, much more fun than Monopoly and a great family game. Expansions are great as well. Must buy! This will help you to introduce other games to non-gamers, as they will realize there is so much more out there than Monopoly and Risk. Gets even better with the [GAMEID=926] expansion. THE Gateway game, if there ever was one.

Settlers of Catan is the classic eurogame of building settlements and cities on the vertices of a hex map in order to produce resources when the numbers on those hexes are rolled.  Not only do you have to manage the probabilities associated with rolling 2d6, but also the types of resources you receive (which build different things) and the spatial aspect of having to build only next to things you already own.  Trading adds another thing to think about in the game, and can help mitigate the dice luck, but also can create player-enforced balance (no one trades with the leader).  After all these years, Settlers is still a favorite of mine.   (5+ plays)
The German game that started it all.  Still lots of fun.  A little too much randomness, but that is part of the charm.  Among gamer-geeks I find this is about the easiest game to get started up.
One of the greatest games ever created, but lacks a lot with anything less then 4 players
An all time favourite.  So much fun from such a simple game.
I never turn down a game of Settlers. P
A classic.  Random board setup ensures a slightly different game each time.  Lots of strategy.  Trading keeps all players active even when it's not their turn.
Well, Settlers of Catan was an instant classic, I suppose. Got many people into gaming. Its influence cannot be over-rated.
The game that introduced me to games from Germany.  Resource management + trading + land management.  Great fun!

This is a great game, although not that challenging, I will always welcome a game.  Very well designed, a pleasure to play when not in the mood for the more complicated games or between the longer games like Titan, Civilization or 1800's railroads for example.
Another classic that needs to be in a players' travelling bin 'o games...
The game that started the craze.
Great game for beginner players. I usually use this to initiate the new's ones.
Great game. Seems to be just as popular with my female friends as the male ones. Not too hard to learn, and always different

Any game that grabs my attention, as well as my wifes is great! Settlers goes even beyond that, every couple we have ever introduced to it, is soon addicted, we've had more opportunity to game with this (and its variants) than any other game (together) before... and for that, a strong rating from me! this is better than watching movies ANY day... thank you mr T :)
This one is a timeless classic that will always be in people's top ten lists
A defining "German" game, with part luck, part negotiation, and part growth management.  Almost always willing to play this.  With 4.

This game is very easy to learn, but not at all deficient in terms of strategic content. There is luck involved, but the strategy is based partly on understanding the probability distribution (the game and rules are designed to remind us of this ad nauseum) involved, and each game ought to provide a large enough sample of dice throws to have a fairly normal distribution.  It is not easy, however, to pick an optimal strategy. Like Go, it seems that this game cannot be reasoned out by brute force-- players must be able to adapt to their current situation and pick an optimal move using a sort of sliding time scale.  I have only played this game a handful of times, but I expect that I will continue to enjoy it and refine my strategy for a long time.
A classic that never gets old.  Despite my initial reservations, the Cities and Knights expansion adds a whole new level to the game.
Fun.  Addictive.  Right on the cusp between gamers-only games and regular-people games.
A regular in our house... friends love it.
The best of the best so far!

This is a game I have never tired of.  I really enjoy the trading element.  However, this can be annoying when playing with someone who will not really trade.  In my experience, the dice do not beat people with superior play.  Sure people have dry spells from time to time, but you have to adapt.  Those who adapt best, win.  Same goes with being shut out.  I have only seen one time where a person was truly shut out of a game, and he could probably have still competed -- if he had actually tried.  All in all, a lot of fun.  For the record, Seafarers is not my cup of tea and C&K is not on my desired to play list.
The dice are nobody's friend, but a fresh setup each time and the need for trade make an engaging and lively game.
Great game and like We the People gets an extra point for being influential.
It has a high luck factor, but it's still a classic.
Excellent game that I have played many times. Pretty easy for non-gamers to pick up the rules and have a good chance at wining (or maybe I'm just a soft-touch).
A classic! Better at teaching economics than Monopoly. You can't horde for long and everyone needs everyone else's commodities. Winning does not rely on bashing your opponents.
Excellent game. New game every time
Still gets played at least once a month.
This game is Awesome, Highly Recommend
Great all round game. Good for beginners and experts
Always ready to play a game.
Some luck and some skill make me like this game !

Excellent.  Redefined how the world perceives board games.  Only flaw is that of many German board games: the stringent 3-4 player requirement. (The expansion takes care of that, I know, but still, it's annoying to not have it all in one.) Brilliance in a box.
Played this game again, and I just keep liking it more, and more.  My wife's favorite too.
Great game! Even the girls want play it again and again ;)
As close to perfect as I have witnessed
Great game, the dice can be frustrating some times

Easily approachable. Fun to play. Great interaction. The only problem is the difficulty of directly damaging players who are on a streak towards victory. An excellent introduction to european board games.

When we bought this game after having played a few times, me and my friends took a day of from work so we could play this all day. After 23 hours of playing, we went to bed, woke up 8 eight hours later and started playing during breakfast, what more do i have to say?
I like this game so much that I even bought its card game! Not much of a brag around BGG'ers but those who know my spending habits will understand my point... :-)
This is for the game with the standard expansion sets. I'm a little bit tired of the basic game and would rate it 7.
The greatest gateway game of all time. It got me started on the eurogame craze back in 1998. Rating is for the game, not my enjoyment of it, which would probably be a 6 after 100+ plays.
My intro to German games. Still pretty good but I prefer other games now.
One of the best games ever!  We must have played the game and its variants over 100 times.  The modular board is a huge bonus.

UPDATE: 01/10 - Well, I've been the hobby for quite a long while, and even though I don't play Settlers with my gaming partners much any more, I still use it as my main game to bring people into the hobby, and I still always have fun when I play it.  One caveat - I only like playing it as a 4-player game.  With 3, I think the board is too 'open' (Play RA instead!)  ---  A classic.  Settlers introduced me to the world of 'real' games.  I've played it a ton a times, and still never say no to a round.
My first proper German Game. It still gets played and enjoyed and is the perfect introduction for newbies.

The game that got me started on the voyage of board gaming... this game took the original idea of board gaming and turned it upside down on its head. Certainly, games of its caliber had existed before, but this raised the bar for how gamers while away their hours. Also helping it was the fact that it is very newbie friendly. Its greatest strengths are its elegant simplicity and variable map board. It has enough building and options to keep you entertained. It is criticized heavily for randomness in the dice rolls though, but that doesn't bother me too much.
I just plain love it.  It doesn't get a 10 because games tend to be "over" at about the midpoint of the game when the strong continue to get stronger.
Still the one of the best games I have ever played; I always bring it out with new gamers.
Never get bored of playing this one ...
I just have the basic game, for now.  It's a winner for my family.

I kind of have to give this one a 9, as it was my first Euro. I can't even remember where I heard of it from, but told my parents to get it for me at Christmas. They did, and here I am today :) - still hits the table a fair bit, and is popular with the friends I play with as well.
Not the game that started the collection, but did fire up the slide into Geekdom
My favourite game, very easy to get new people into board games with this one.
About as smooth and perfect a game (mechanics wise) as you could ask for.  You don't need me to tell you... look at the amount of people that love this game!
This is one of the best games ever, strategy, trading, easy to learn, fast played...  We played it all the time until we finally got bored... still play it sometimes though.

This game deserves its reputation.  Everyone with whom I have played this game has really enjoyed it.  The trading portion of this game really brings up the social interaction, as well as providing a mechanism to keep the leader from pulling too far ahead.  I bumped this down in score because the Cities & Knights expansion makes this even better, so it couldn't be a 10 by itself, right?

I do like this game.  Game I used to start a monthly game night with some friends at work.  They all loved. Good gaming and social interaction.  Complaint is the color of the pieces.  I repainted mine. Favorite is "Guts" Catan with three players.  Fast and furious.
I trained my parents to play this one, and they're finally (after 4 years) starting to win occasionally.
This was a "10" until we got the Seafarers expansion
Tremendous game that I never get tired of. Very different strategies required for 3 and 4 players.
This is, without a doubt, my most-played and most-loved game.
Really great family game.  I have not found anyone who does not like this yet.
Great game for a Friday night group.  Add one player's magnificent home brewed beers and we have a real blast.  Always a popular choice for all of us.
A Classic. Game grows in depth with each additional player.
Deceptively simple rules, complex game that is great to teach to beginners.  Not that long to play.  High replay-ability.
Got it for Christmas 2004, after playing it (friends copy) at work (lunch) 2-3 times a week for the last month or two.  Looking forward to getting some expansions!
What started it all for me.  Read about it here on the geek, then bought it.  The rest is history.

Acquired on June 10, 2002. As for many, this is the game that re-introduced me to boardgames. Well, I suppose that I really never left, therefore, I did not need to be re-introduced, but this was the game that showed me the way to BGG and opened up a world with thousands of boardgames waiting to be played. Still one of my first choice to introduce the boardgaming world to occasional tourists.

The first 'German' game I played.  My entire family got addicted to this, and we played this non-stop for about 6 months.  I've moved on to other things now, but we still get it out during get togethers occasionally.  I always enjoy teaching this to new people and seeing them light up.
a Delicious fun game! Easy rules, easy playable but with lots of "depth" Not much (NO) downtime when ít's not your turn. luck plays a part too. a Classic!
What can I say? I think it's a great game, but others I play with have developed a bit of a hatred for it...just a case of playing too much. Too bad.

A tremendous ammount of fun. The road building is very compeditive, but it wasn't a dicefest, or overly obnoxious. Also there were some quick turn-arounds in player satus that really kept you on your toes.
Just a great game!  If you don't own it, buy it right now!  You should also buy the Seafarers expansion.  It adds exploration to the game, and it makes it even more interesting.

With City & Knights it is my favorite German game.  Without I still love to play it and it is great to play with the kids.  They can beat you !!  Ok, so you will still probably be King of Catan most of the time.  (My wife is vicious in this game and I have to watch her like a hawk or she will frickisee me at the first chance).
THis game NEVER gets old to me. By far the most played game in my collection.
This was the game that got me (and my gaming group) into Eurogames ... so it will always have a very special place in my heart!  In my humble opinion, it's a superb game that everyone should own!

Really pleased with this game. Spent Xmas playing this with my wife, son and my parents. Easy to learn and devilish fun almost immediately. We are all hooked and no two games have yet played the same. Great stuff!
The one that started it all.

Awesome strategy game that includes building, trading and military.  Not much idle time in this game, for everyone playing is pretty much participating during all turns of the game.  Expansions make it even better.  Even bought the Travel version.

Great Game.  Love the mechanics and interaction.  Have played this with Seafarers expansion and enjoyed it as well.  One thing that I do find is that one person always seems to be on the out resource wise and that can make for a long and frustrating game.
If this was the only board game in the world, I probably wouldn't think to complain.  Everyone, just everyone, should try this at some point.
Great game that holds up quite well after 10 years.
I use this game to get non-gamers and gamers together.  Easy for non-gamers to learn fast and become competitive within a couple of rounds.
Great game! My non-gamer friends like it, too.

This was my very first board game, what a great start!!! I was an avid collectible card game player, then one of my gaming buddies introduced me to this great board game and now I have been hooked on German board games. I also have the travel edition, very cute.  I love this game, now playing the computer version, since I'm unable to get together with friends to play the board game...
Great, easy, clever game. Has some tendencies to get 'thin' after a while if you don't have the expansions though.
Fun and simple game.  Good for family playing as well.
Negotiation rules, and this game's got it.

Very fun, light strategy game; great game to teach to gamers not used to anything more complicated than Monopoly.  Engaging theme that helps you feel like you really are building something, not just collecting victory points (even though you are collecting victory points).
Played with friends copy, will have to have this in my collection, one of the best
The first Euro my hubby introduced me to

Original rating was a 9 for this classic and still enjoyable game - however having played the Seafarers expansion has caused me to demote the base game when played by itself.  ----- Update...forget that foolishness about not being as good without an expansion.  The base game earns those points back for being so much game in so little time.
Game of the decade. Deserving of its high reputation.
Very good game that my friends and I always want play.

The ultimate gateway game, and the one that brought me into the euro-game fold.  Although it's hard to criticize the solid gameplay mechanics and innovative design, it's also been hard to get Settlers to hit the table with so many other great games now residing on my shelves (including Klaus Teuber's own Domaine, which I greatly prefer to Settlers).  Still a fantastic game for just about anyone, gamer or not.
My first Eurogame, of course. Initial placements are often extremely important. The game is just random enough but just strategic enough to satisfy a wide variety of tastes.

A nice balance of simple rules and not so simple strategies.  If I was able to play more often I would probably want to add one of the expansions to make it a bit more interesting but at the moment I can't get enough.  The only negative I can think of is the fact that you really need to have exactly 4 people for a good game.
I love to play it but never manage to win it!

Come on - this is Settlers - being a gamer without owning Settlers is like being an elephant without a trunk. Not only is it against nature, but you look pretty dumb to all the other elephants. Absolute classic.
One of the greatest games ever.  It is able to move quickly and even-handedly thanks to several basic rules.  Easy to learn, tough to stop playing
After dozens of plays I have grown tired of it. Nevertheless, it simply is one of the best family games out there and an immediate suggestion after TtR or Carcassonne.

I bought this game when it first came out Stateside and I still love it.  I'm a bit of a purist; I prefer the original game to the Seafarers expansion (although I like Cities & Knights).  Best with 3-4.  2 players is fun but feels kinda pointless.  More than 4 and players start using the wooden pieces to spell out "Help Me."
Really neat game.  Simple and yet complex enough to be interesting.  I'll never get tired of settlers.
Great game you can play with both hardned-gamers and newbies
It's just drop-dead hexy.  Still crazy after all these years.  But, expansions, exshmansions, I say.  Keep it simple and play quickly.
Probably our first "real" game so will forever remain a favorite.

With several game sessions under my belt, I am quite happy with Settlers.  Maybe I've got a bit of an edge on board-analysis among my game cohort, but I have come out on top in my last couple of games.  A good, solid game that I can see playing for quite some time.

One of the best luck based strategy games I've ever played.  It's actually quite easy to learn, as my players can atest to.  The player expansions, as well as seafarers and knights, is a must have to expand the game and bring it to that extra step of strategy that's needed.
One of the world's most perfect games.  If you want your friends to start playing more German Games, begin with this one.
The prototypical German game for most Americans and still fun to play.  Spawned a ton of variants to spice up play.
I play this game far too often. Settlers was definately the game that got me interested, but Carcassonne was my real gateway game.
I play the PC game on and on... it would be a 10 if sometime you didn't get really mad with bad roll dice! Anyway it is addictive...

Quite simply, the best game I have ever played.  This was my first Eurogame and I am truthfully not sure if I would have become as hooked as I am now playing any other game.  I believe that this remains the best game to introduce nongamers to when trying to convert them to Eurogames.  Further, if the nongamer has a dice game background, such as Monopoly, it makes my argument stronger as they will be comfortable with the dice roll.  The rules are quite simple and after a ten minute quick explanation and quick couple of rounds, most newbies will have things down pat.  Settlers has some randomness to the game as resource production is determined through the roll of dice, but more often then not I find that the person who manages their resources best wins the game.  Trading plays a very important roll in this as people who are able to complete more trades improve their position more often then not.  This game is a lot of fun and very addicting!  A must have for every gamer and a great way to send you down the path of gaming for nongamers.
The first game I bought when I moved to Germany.  Brilliant and beloved by all.
Most played in my group.  Along with PR and Carcassonne this is the third part of the holy trinity of euro-games.
Why comment?  Everyone knows this is a great game.

Acquired June 3rd, 2005. I'd passed on playing this game for years, feeling that it was a little pricy for the box contents.  And while it is too expensive (especially once you get into the expansions), the game is a lot of fun and addictive and has rapidly become a favorite of my gaming group.
Superb, but I've played it too much. Great introduction to German games. It is deceptive, as it feels deeper than it actually is.

The GATEWAY game for most that rediscovered board games in the 90s. This and Elfenroads (Elfenland + Elfengold) are what did it for me. I used to be willing anytime with any number of players but more than 4 generally takes too long.
Great game. I and a few friends were addicted to it for such a long time, we got sick of it. Yet, it still haunts me in my sleep.
The game that got me into Euros.  I currently own the "Simply Catan" version.
The old standby. My friend bought this at Origins one year and our gaming group never looked back.
Quite possibly the best game ever created.    Some luck involved, but the better haggler, with a good starting spot, should be able to overcome this aspect.
Great game that is accessable for everyone.  Casual players can play and have fun, yet it has just enough depth to keep vets coming back.

As for many this was my gateway into modern gaming. I hadn't played it for a long time when I took it up again this year (2010) and it still rules. Had to bump it up from a 9 to a 10.  I have moved it down to a 9 again since there are many games that are better than this.
Great game with a lot of depth and hidden complexities and strategy, but it still can be enjoyed and played successfully by kids.
I have all of the expansions + 5-6 player packs
The game that start it all! Good interaction. great theme, easy to understand. One of the best gateway game.
The first game i got after reading BGG. Have played many enjoyable games.
Excellent game. One of my top 3 favorites, even to this day.
One of the most replayable games ever made.
What more can i say, I love it. Only thing though is that the game and its expansions are pretty expensive.
Usually I hate trading games, but in this one, the trading just works.
Lots of luck balanced by lots of fun, this will be a classic for at least the rest of my life.

The classic that was my springboard into this hobby.  I have had a lot of success at getting repeat players for this one.  After playing with many expansions for the right length of playing time I think the base game is the best for its weight.
One of the best games of all time.  I have grown tired of playing it - but I can still respect its elegance.
One of the first big games, that intruced me to the world of boardgames. Will always be a classic game for me and will stay as one of my favourites no mather what :)
This is the game that has persuaded some of our friends that it is worth playing games.
Great game. The only reason it's not a 10 is because "Settlers Cities & Knights" is better.
I can play this game for hours.

At one time I used to think this was one of the greatest games ever made.  Now I know better.  Still, though, it can be fantastic, but it really is prone to certain circumstances.  If the dice get screwy it can make for a long and arduous game. When playing with 4 there is enough opportunity to yield resources so that when your turn comes around you have something to do, but of course one player gets the bone usually and gets pinched out (although there are enough other things that they can still do to win if they don't get too worked early on in the game).  With 3 even more dependent on dice rolls to yield for you to be able to do anything that turn.  I would never give up my copy, as it still hits the table fairly often.  UPDATE: You know, the rating on this has gone all over the place depending on how jaded I am, but in reality, this is a damn fine game.  Really one of the best of its kind.
This is a great game with a good blend of luck, strategy and player interaction
Great game. Fun to play. Easy to learn, difficult to master.
This is the game that started it all for us... Great parts, interaction, tension leads to an exciting game & excellent intro for non-gamers.
Brilliantly simple and addictive. Best gateway game I know. Main problem is that its too short, which allows bad die rolls to ruin a game too often.

I have played this a lot and still enjoy it.  Has a fair amount of luck, but that is what makes it fun!  The roll of the dice affects everyone and is met by cheers and groans each turn!  I also think that there is a lot more strategy and skill involved than many people give it credit for.  If you play board games to have fun with your friends and family, then you should check out this game.  When I play with my family I stick it to my brother by blocking his roads and trading tough, but I'm nice to my mom by giving her what she needs in trades.  This is one of the few games where you can be both nice and mean, which makes it suitable for most any mix of people.

This was the game that introduced me to the world of board games that you just can't get at your local Target or Toys R Us.  Grade A game that has limitless replay value.  I've introduced over 4 more people to the world of non-mainstream games w/this one myself.  MUST HAVE!
One of the ultimate bridge games.

Settlers one weakness as a gateway game is it's set up. With some other gateway games you open map board, pass out pieces, shuffle and pass out cards, and your good to go in under 5 minutes. With Settlers, laying out the hexs and letters on top can intimidate casual gamers.
Quite possibly the best gateway into the boardgame hobby ever.  Random island layouts (using the island setup rules that come with the game) keep each game fresh and new.
The game that got my family and I back into gaming.  We don't play it as often as we like, but we still love it.
This is the game that got me back into board gaming.
very simple, very challenging, very good

A must-have game. Lots of interaction between players, and strong luck and strategic factors make this game, in my opinion, the best one to introduce non-gamers. The rules are easy to explain. The downside is that one tends to get tired of it after repeated play.
Offers great player interaction.  Appeals to a wide range of people.

The gateway game, Catan is a modern classic. Trading resources keeps everyone involved and offers high enough interaction between players. It looks simple but under surface it offer surprisingly deep gaming experience. Only reason why I usually wouldn't suggest Settlers in a gaming night is the fact there are games I haven't played as much and want to try them instead. Best with 4 players, I'd rather play something else with 3.  Update (15.5.2009) : My rating for Catan has shifted between 6-9 during my time on BGG. (Rating of 6 was when I had overplayed). Right now it feels that because of intense gaming experiences (when played with 4 players) it offers every time when you play it, it deserves at _least_ a rating of 9.   Update (28.6.2018) : That is if everyone play cuthroath enough. Even one player making too loose trades (that benefit too much one party breaks game a bit. When played with players of similar skill it is tense, good game even after 20 years. A modern classic.
One of the best games ever. A must for every geek.
Very elegant, lots of fun, moderately deep, lots of replayability.  Only downside is often 1 person falls behind early with no chance to catch up.

A great "base game", teach people how to play with this version, hook them well, and then get them totally addicted by adding in Seafarers!  This game caused the creation of our gaming group and would be rated even higher were it not for the fact that it's got a Seafarers shaped hole in it.
Perfect blend of strategy and luck.

Still one of the greatest out there. I love the "beer and pretzels" games like this and Acquire, as it's easy to get non-gamers excited about playing with you and there is a high level of strategy that can be achieved.
The game that got me into euros.  I like the hex-board that is different every time.  Was so much fun to play for so long, i.e. took many plays to tire of it.  In fact I would still gladly play it!

The game that got me hooked on boardgames (and BGG).  This is one of those perfect games that enthralled me from my first play till my latest play.  I'm starting to overplay this, but its still great.

GERMAN EDITION This was probably the game that finally got me addicted to this hobby. I bought a few other games before this one but my collection exploded after I got Settlers. Haven't played for a while now but would not turn down a chance to play. It's also a great game to get your non-gaming friends into the hobby. I have the German Edition now because I wanted the nice bits but couldn't afford the $500 plus price tag for the 3D treasure chest version.
great game lots of strategy, but still great fun. (for families to!) hint:build cities near the 3 of one kind for 1 of another kind
The first non-traditional board game we purchased. Tons of fun and always a favorite when we have family over. :)
Still the best family strategy game made, even if it's been played to death. House rule: No bandit first two rounds.
Love the game.  Great game to teach others
A classic.  Retired for having played it so much.

I've loved this game ever since only 3 people showed up for poker night at my friend Daniel's house one day, and he said "you should play this new game my brother showed me; I had to go to one of those weird game stores to get it..."
This is my favorite game ever.  I rank all others by this one.
Had a couple hundred plays before I found the 'Geek. Absolutely great game.

This is SO much fun, and one of the few games that I've played to the point of burnout and it still bounced back to where I wanted to play it again a few months later.  You would be amazed at the naughty wood & sheep jokes you hear when a bunch of nice respectable housewives play this ;) Update 04/2013: Y'know, it's been YEARS I've been playing this, and I'm still very unlikely to turn down a game of it.  A true classic, the one that started it all.  EVERYONE needs this game.
My first German game. I've probably played this about 30 or 40 times.

Third Euro game I ever got and I still love it. Plenty of people bemoan the luck element of this game and I can understand that. However for me it's a great leveller and gives all a chance to be in the running.
OWN Jan/02: Only thing better would be some sort of frame to keep the 'board' from sliding apart (like SeaFarers has).

Settlers of Catan is the first German game that I ever played, and it has definitely led to an addiction.  I know a lot of people have played Settlers to the point of burn-out, but I am no where near that point yet.  I love the interaction of the trading phases, playing the seemingly fickle bell curve (Another six??? How's about an eight every once in a while??), and beating an opponent in a race to a crucial intersection.  We are still developing theories about the relative importance of each commodity (Good ol' rock, nothing beats rock), discussing whether nines are actually better than eights due to the robber effect, and making lots of sheep jokes.  To put it simply, Settlers is a lot of fun.

This is the classic eurogame and is still a great player experience, despite its randomness. This game often causes tension within our gaming group as it is brilliantly designed to make the player feel that he is always only one turn from victory. This can really crank up the atmosphere.We always come back though because this is such a good game.  I would be interested to try it with the cards replacing the dice, to stop the three 12s in a row syndrome.
Even my non-game-playing boyfriend liked this game.
Very good game, played many times and it still holds up.
best game to keep in your law school locker.

Played this for the first time the other day. Enjoyed it very much. A nice change of pace from the usual combat oriented games. Takes a bit of getting used to to not be able to attack the other players :)

My Original Gamer's Game.  Easy to teach, easy to play.  Fun for hours, without taking hours per game.  Fun-factor increases with the experience of your opponents, but decreases ever-so-slightly with your own experience.
A dream come true. Medium length playing time, beautiful components and feels ok even when losing. A success and rightfully so.
Great game.  Can't wait to play again.
Count me in on the "love it" group. Fun fun fun middleweight eurogame.

Awesome, awesome, awesome game!  It's simple yet so much fun!  I love the negotiation aspect of it...  who knew pawning off wool would be such fun?!  I can't wait to try this on my co-workers!  EDIT:  Amazing game...  my co-workers love it to death!  Tense trading and tight building have lead to some real races at work...  this had to be a 9 after the success it's had with them!

My kids and I love this.  They like it even though I am almost always declared Lord of all Catan in the end.  My wife is wary, though, after one particularly long game with really bad luck with the dice all around.  She won in the end, but she's been a bit hesitant to play since.
I play this game twice a week with friends.
Sweet game.  Sometimes I hook up two games and the 5-6 player expansion and have a settlers of the continent Catan.  It's pretty awesome.
Good all rounder game that your girlfriend will even like.

There's not much I could say about this game that has not already been said. It's the constant player interaction and the multiple strategies that makes this one of my favourite games. Its accessibility ensures I'll always be able to find players. The many variants and expansions add variety, but aren't necessary. I'll be playing this for many years, I'm sure.
Quite possibly one of the greatest games I have ever played.  Some really fun player mechanics involved with trading and backstabbing.  Good balance here and incredibly fun!
Great game and mechanics. Love the strategy and the little bit of luck with the dice. The more players, the more challenging it becomes because space gets eaten up very quickly.
A very enjoyable game to play with 4 people.
Good misture of strategy and randomness. Perfect for family play.

I rate this game 9 because it is a great game but also considering the following...  We never play it anymore without Seafarers and almost never without Cities and Knights as well.  But Settlers is a terrific game even without the expansions.  The masterful balance of strategy and luck is just right.  You have to be able to adjust your strategy frequently. You can achieve a sense of accomplishment in obtaining one goal and then refocusing your effort to the next development in your game plan. It is exciting to disguise your agenda by building many things at once at the risk of someone (or yourself) rolling a 7 or the risk of an opponent building in your way.  One of my favorite things about this game, however, is to see the blank stare of quite clever people as the game is explained to them for the first time and then seeing how quickly they pick it up when we play.
This is what got our family started on Eurogames
I've played this so much that it's easy to forget how good it is.

I lose this game a lot, but it is the standard by which I judge all multiplayer games.  Why not a 10?  Hard to teach (any action can be taken any turn), setup takes an age, and no two player variant in the box.  The beginner board suggested in the almanac helps with teachability, pushing this to a 9 rather than 8.

Really fun and excellent gateway to Eurogames (is it THE first real Euro?). Beware the dice. With some players the dice feels like a constant problem that just messes up your plans. Use a dice deck for these players. Others will simply see the luck of the dice as just part of the game and will be ok with the base game.  [Gave to a friend.]
Yep, I still play this now and then. And, yes, I still think it's a great game. So there.

My first real Eurogame. This is THE ultimate family/newbie game. I admit that I sometimes don't want to play this game as I've worn it out a bit, but it has such a history that I think it deserves such a high ranking. There's nothing like being one turn away from winning and having to sweat it out, then play a beautiful hand to end the game.

I have played this game so many times and it never gets tirening. What is especially like about settlers is that each game is different, whether I play it with the same people, or with complete strangers.
I like the game, it's a great game to teach new players and it's a good gateway game to German games.
This is the first game that I have bought because of BGG and I never will regret it. This is my favorite game so far and I play it every chance I get.
Another of my all-time favorites - Strongly recommended!

This is a great game, however, it seems easy to burn out on.  I loved it once, then grew extremely bored of it, and now like it again.  I sometimes forget how univeral a game it has become.  Whenever I find out a non-gamer friend has played it, I'm a little surprised.  I'll get used to it someday.
I've been unable to flatten my hexes.
Comment: I have played with as many as 11 Players on one board. Larger games can be so much more fun. I do have almost all the expansions
If you play it at a good clip, this is one of the all-time greats.  Take too long, though, and odd dice rolls or early mistakes will make the game frustrating.

My family has been playing about once/week, since we got at Gencon 2004.  My wife who is not a serious gamer like this game. Edited 11-21-05: We do not play as much as we once did but we still play once or twice a month (too many other games).
Elegant rules and involving gameplay make this one of my favourite games.
Amazing game.  Lots of fun.  Always enjoyed by anyone I show it to.  And Wood for Sheep.  Lots of wood for sheep.
When my wife actually ASKS to play this with me, I know I have a winner.

Excellent game, simply superb in its simplicity and yet extremely rich in the strategic thought involved. It's like a multiplayer chess only much more fun. Time and again I have been utterly frustrated by this game as my near perfect strategies in the end didn't win me the game:-). A must have and a great game to seduce pottential newbies or people who don't like/are against board games.

Upped my rating from 7 to 9 after about 50 plays.  Good players consistently win.  Luck plays a smaller part than I initially thought.  Update: I've played so many of the Settlers series, both two player and more and I've liked every one of them.  I've yet to see a bad design from Klaus Tauber.

I wish this game was shorter so I could play it at lunch. I just introduced this game to my parents. They are finally on the road to modern boardgames! Great family game!  The physical game is located at my parents house.

Settlers is the game that got me back into boardgames after many years away.  Thank you, Klaus!  Even after a few years of playing it ad nauseum, Die Siedler still holds up.  One of the very best, and will go down as one of the all time classics.  Can millions of people really be wrong?  In this case, an emphatic NO!  (Admittedly, I'd rather play Cities & Knights than basic Catan at this point... but that surely isn't a knock against this fantastic game.  Indeed, I rate Settlers higher by .5 simply because it's far easier to get to the table and play in a reasonable time.  The wrong group kills C&K.)

An excellent multiplayer, social game with a nice balance of skill/luck (i.e. enough depends on skill that you have to plan your strategy well, but luck can kill a great strategy).  For a game that depends less on luck, use a dice/roll deck.  Also, to blance games have the best player/winner go first, with worst/last place playing last.  I have not played expansions, but look forward to trying them.  GAVE TO FAMILY
I really like both the theme and mechanics of this game. Everything fits so well together and because of the trading part  every players is always involved.
Still a game my friends will play no matter how drunk we get.
all time classic that is hard to beat in my book

This was my gateway game.  I first played this in mid 2005 and I've been hooked ever since.  The resource system is great, and the trading can lead to some very interesting round-table politics and scheming.    This game gets even better with the expansions, I'm particularly fond of Cities and Knights, although Seafarers is also a nice touch.
Still crazy about it after all these years. Yes, the luck factor is frustrating, but I'd still rather play this than most other games.
A great game, almost Civ Lite. Trade, development, economical growth. A true classic.
Once my friends caught on, I never stopped hearing "So...Sheep?" - Which surprisingly wasn't a problem.
One of the greatest games ever periop. But... played it to death (1000+ plays, also online) and i'm tempted to rate it a 3 because of the big merchandising BS run by Kosmos and Klaus Teuber.
Fun game.  Placing starting towns and roads very important.
A charming game with a great replay value. Its the perfect family game.

Based on countless plays.  I've played Settlers dozens of times and converted around twenty individuals to German-gaming with it.  The simple framework of rules allows a surprising depth of strategic potential which still surprises me every time I play it.  Some complain about the luck of the dice, which is a legitimate criticism.  But we use a deck of dice cards and have had no problems with errant laws of probability since.

It's settlers.  What else can I say about this one.  Everybody on this site has played it, most likely overplayed it.  This one isn't my top choice to play anymore but as a gateway game, it's great.  Not only that, but I think this is just a great game overall (gateway or not).    Over this past year, I have played a big variety of games and it really shows how great of game settlers is as compared to many of these.
Can't give this a 10 because I think Seafarers is a little better.
A classic game that is deserving of its status.
The first "real" boardgame I ever purchased. Love its viciousness!
This is the game that got me back into playing board games.  Rock solid fun every time.
this is a fun game to play. it is hard to set up but it is werth it.

This game gets a high mark because in 1995, I didn't care about board games.  Now, 10 years later, the entire board game industry has exploded thanks to this game, which most people now hate.  And it is still played often in my gaming group.  Sure, it's got aggravating dice, but it's still fun.

Brilliant game with plenty of player interaction and deep strategy. Extremely high replayability, there's no sense of growing weary of this game, even after years of play. Like all trading games though, don't play with certain groups.
wish I had actually listened to my friends and played this earlier.  A hit with any/everyone who's played it

Tough to say anything bad about this one. Easy rules, strategic depth, meaningful choices, beautiful components, just the right length, a gateway for many people to eurogames. I find it really works best with 4 players (or maybe 3), but more than that really changes the dynamics. So much depends on the initial placement that it can be frustrating for someone new, so the recommended setup can ease this. I still love to play it and I can't see that ever changing. I don't understand the burnout some people feel on this game, there really is still nothing quite like it.
One of the old classics.  Incorporates mechanics such as modular boards, trading, and was the first to introduce dice-based production.
THE staple board game; a classic.

It's not a perfect game, it's theme doesn't exactly match the mechanics and it does have that random element that probably drives some people nuts, but judging by the amount of time spent on the table it's still our gaming group's favorite game.    I have bought the Seafarers expansion and played a game of that, but I personally prefer the original.  Settlers is an "island" generated by laying hexes of various resources (+ one desert), and then surrounding it by sea hexes.  Numbers (reflecting die rolls, which also includes probabilities in a simple dot system) are placed on each of resources, and the black piece -called The Robber- is placed in the desert.  The mechanic of placing settlements over corners of hexes and then a road segment adjacent to it seems at first blush to favor the player who places two settlements in a row, but that is not the case as smart roadbuilding and sticking to a sound strategy will win out in general.  The rolling of the dice to get resources makes a statistician want to play the resources with the best chance of coming up (6 and 8, because 7 moves the Robber), but if those resources are mainly wood and brick, then in the late game that doesn't help you very much.  You have to balance out the early game (building roads and settlements) with the late game (cities, soldier cards, and development cards).
Need I say more? Wood for sheep, power to the people!

Very good game. Relatively simple rules and strategic gameplay, lots of interactions between players. My little negative experience with 4 players is that it is common that somebody gets hopelessly blocked, then only waiting the end of game.

This is my first game and the one I always seem to go back to. I love how every game is different because the board changes and so the probability of getting different resources changes. I love trying out different strategies to win even though I've played more than 200 times!
One of the first three Euros I played and one which I used to introduce others to the hobby. This one doesn't see the table much anymore, but it's still a classic.

Like so many other gamers, this is the game that sparked my love affair with German / Designer games.  It doesn't come out as much as it used to, but I still enjoy it and am always happy to play it.  I prefer it with the Seafarers expansion slightly more than the original alone.  All that said, this is still a great game.  Recommended!
Build roads, settlements and cities to get you more resources - so you can build more roads, settlements and cities...

I'm new to Eurogames and I readily admit to loving this one. I've only played a handful of games, but it feels well-balanced to me, if not a bit iconography-challenged. (I'm sure others have ranted about the ore/brick color schemes.)  I'm in the honeymoon phase where I will enlist nearly anyone to play with me. I have not, however, endeavored to teach it to my kids yet (currently ages 7 and 5). They are swimming in new eurogames, and I would like them to enjoy the ones they're currently playing for a while longer.
The original classic strategy board game.

The one that started it all and by far my most played game face to face. After 1 gazillion games played, I stoped for a while and played again recently. I was amazed with how good it felt. Great game!

This is the game!  Wonderful bits, satisfying play, try to mitigate the luck with strategy.  And there's a cool robber.  Looks complicated at first glance, but gameplay is really quite simple, but the strategies run deep.  Lots of choices, and interaction.
Great Eurogame for a fun afternoon.  Game length allows for multiple games in one sitting with experienced players.
Fantanstic game, which introduced me to the wonders of board games.  The easy rules allowed me to introduce this to my non gaming friends and family with ease, providing fun for all.

It's quite interesting that I haven't gotten around to playing this game until ten years after its original release. Without a doubt, it hasn't lost its charm since then. Our game group plays it more or less regularly, and it never seems to grow old. It truly shows what a great design Settlers really was and is.  I'm not to big on the other Catan games, but the original will last in my board game library for a long time to come.
One of the best all around games. Can be played by anyone and a great game to introduce non-gamers to our world.

Luck can have an impact (alleviated by the poverty variant), but it's proven very replayable over time. I've played most of the expansions, but the relative simplicity of the original has provided lasting appeal. Attractions include the building theme, the sociability of the trading, and the requirement to carefully consider risk and probabilities. All of which adds up to an engaging and enjoyable experience.
great game, wish it came with the 5-6 player expansion, all the extras are costly
Played this a lot in the mid-90's. This was my first exposure to German-style games. Worthy of its praise.

I have never seen so many good ideas together. I play Catan with my wife (she likes it very much) and...with my mother-in-law (she loves it in fact!) We all three have many good times playing this game.

Wow.  For a long time I was ashamed to call myself a gamer having not played this, but now I'm ashamed that I missed out on playing this earlier.  This really is worth the hype - a truly magnificent game.
Jeu simple amusant pour jouer en famille. le fait d'avoir une extention pour jouer a 6 rajoute encore plus de fun ^^.
My gateway game to Euros.  I own the excellent KOSMOS version with beautiful artwork and plastic bits!!!
Simply THE gateway game, loads of replay.
Using dice decks makes a big difference, avoids frustration, but still keeps the requisite amount of randomness. Much improved by Seafarers, although lengthens the game.
Maybe it's not that strategic, but it's a great fun

Played many times(50+) without loosing any interest, frequently several times in a row.   Game is great for its interactive part. Interaction between players is very attractive for adults and kids, or between them. Game becomes less interesting at the end, if people realize they can not win. Rich gets richer is also a minus.
Great game for casual gamers, still fun after hundreds of plays
juego basico que debe estar en toda coleccion de un jugador de tablero.... un clasico que no se cansa de jugar
Amazing game, with the cities and knights expansion, it is almost the perfect game!
Perhaps my favorite game right now, it's gotten a lot of play since I got it.

Excellent introduction to german games for a number of reasons:       The number of brain parts stimulated in the game is large, though stimulation is fairly gentle.  This is not your hitachi magic wand vibrator that focuses on one organ and wiggles the hell out of it. no.  it's more like a vibrating tub of warm, soft jello that you jump into hairless and naked, all nerve endings exposed. there's cajoling, laughter, tension, secrets and bluffing, memory, press your luck, arms races, strategic thinking, tactical considerations, the joy of building.     there's just a *little* viciousness, enough to make the game juicy, but not enough to provoke any real hurt feelings (for most people).    virtually zero downtime for anybody, as everyone is interested in everything that happens at all times.   the game has been designed to give every person playing the hope of winning at all times, even if it's the smallest glimmer.  the person that is waay too far in the lead can be effectively slowed down by other players, leading to close, tense finishes.  Some here have argued that this aspect makes it an inferior game, as skill is constantly being stymied by luck and group-lynching, but I believe that a game for non-gamers should allow everyone the possibility of winning.       On the minus side, the start-up is intimidating (to a non-gamer), as rules are moderately complicated, and the board looks geeky, with the hexagons and #s and pips.  But most non-gamers with whom I've played have warmed to the game after playing just two rounds, and are extremely enthusiastic (and exhausted) by the end.  Complexity is an issue, however, for grandma or grandpa who have trouble with all the rules.

Our first game, 5 players, only 1 had played before, with the City and Knights expansion. The game is fun, but last a bit long. However, this is now on my wish list. For us, though, I will want the C&K expansion for sure!  Played MANY 2 players variant game and increased my rating from a 7 to a 9. I guess that 4 is probably the best number, more is not better in this case. IMO.  Traded for this game. THANKS! :D

With four players, this is about as perfect a game as I could hope for. I've lured more people into gaming with this game than anything else. My only complaint is if the ore and brick end up having rare numbers on them, you're going to be in for an excruciating game. Also, I've seen people through no fault of their own get boxed into an area and thus it becomes an impossibility for them to win (because there aren't enough victory points in the deck, and that ends up being their only option). That sort of thing doesn't bother me so much in conflict-oriented games, but in a game like Settlers, it can be a drag. Still, this game is usually a tremendously entertaining time.
Simple game but I really like it

The game's pretty meaningless with anything other than 4 players, and it certainly does get old after awhile, though since friends own Cities+Knights and Seafarers, those definitely help keep things fresh.  My only real complaint is that the robber is quite devastating early in the game, especially if the dice aren't behaving and another seven doesn't pop up for ages.
The game that brought me back into board games.  My only real complaint is that you really do need at least four players to play;  games always seem one-sided with just three players.
It's Settlers.  Need I say more?
Great game that has really held up well over time. This is the one that got me into all of this, just like so many other geeks : )
usually games with dice don't work for me. But this is one exception I trully love!

I played this many times over a year ago and stopped since we typically played with the expansions and found them time consuming as well as found new games to play that were intersting.  I played this again on Dec 20, 2006 with a group from work and it was refreshing to play again.  We played with another member's board so it was a little confusing since his game was the original series and mine was the recent version.  This game takes some time to setup and go over the rules, however it's simple once you have the hang of it.  It has just the right amount of strategy and luck to make it enjoyable for everyone.  In the game we played we were shorted brick so it was a scramble to build much with those components so we spent most of our time trading in goods for what we needed.  Rock and Wheat were in over abundance.
One of my personal favorites.  Although one thing always bothered me.  Why is the robber black???

The game has a good deal of intertia, in terms of developing slowly and to a good deal due to initial placement. The staged nature (initial expansion through roads and ships), however, gives way to intensive expansion (upgrading cities), and that's where the pattern of the game may change quickly. The US version seems to be designed/implemented somewhat more poorly than the original German Die Siedler: the tiles are of rather weird and poorly understandable colors. The expansion potential is nice. The give away that we allow for our 7-yr old is to let him start with more cities.

An increadibly balanced game that suffers slightly from its random nature. At the same time, the random aspects keep the game interesting, ensuring that no two games are ever exactly the same and allowing new players a chance to compete with the more experienced. Settlers is a fantastic "2nd step" for new players that have tired of A Ticket to Ride and Carcassonne and are ready to try something new.
It's one of the games that no respecting board game geek can live without. I'm ashamed to say I've gone without it for quite a while. It's on the top of my list to get though.
A very nice game of medium weight.  Best with more players.

The Gateway Drug (tm) - still never gets old, great introduction to real boardgaming for people who think they like monopoly or risk purely due to their lack of exposure to boardgames that don't suck.

Update - After playing a quite a few games, I have come back to this one and like it a lot more.  It is much more streamlined and strategic than I had thought previously. Plus the old Mayfair edition that I have has very average artwork.  I marvel at the design genius of Settlers, but not the game play. I just don't enjoy it all that much. In my opinion, it takes a bit too long to play.  The foodstamp variant helps balance the luck of the dice.  I have had little luck using this as a gateway game, many others work better.

Very enjoyable when playing with quite fast players. The different maps keep this game always refreshing. This is slightly luck oriented, but less so when everyone understands to beat the leader and the initial setup really matters more than luck I think.

My all time favorite board game. I like the Cities and Knights Expansion the best but will play it in any of it's variants.

Original fun concept with plenty of expansion and house rules. It bridges the gap between die-hard gamer favorites and traditional family games. The price is a bit daunting if you wish to get the whole set but worthwhile and the basic game is just as fun as the expanded. I know that I will always own the game in some various form until my dying day. My rating is based on using Cities and Knights.
Great game.  Easy to learn- a great game to share with friends who aren't big game players.

The classic, the masterpiece, the fun and addictive Settlers of Catan. We've played this more than any other game. I will never turn down a game, but will give up my seat to see someone else learn to play. It deserves a 10 if any game does for what it has done for our hobby/lifestyle. The perennial game - a classic. My game group played countless games over the years, before we even heard of BGG. We've had marathon gaming nights lasting until dawn. We even keep a game log (complete with questions/answers to complex game situations and a list of winners).  Even though SoC is a dice game with a med-high luck factor, my group believes that you can effectively strategize and change tactics depending on what's rolled and what resources people have. Why build a settlement on the 8 or 9 when the 10 or 11 is hot? What do you do when 3 is rolled 3 times in a row and the 6 hasn't been rolled all game? Where's the best place to put the robber, on a hot number or a more likely number?   The player interaction level is fairly high too. Screw someone too early in the game, you have an enemy working against you. If you take the lead too early, you're a marked player. We love to talk during trades too (look, my sheep is better!). And perish the thought of trading someone with 7+ points, you'll be heckled for the rest of the game. Oh look, so-and-so has all those development cards, must be victory points, they are in the lead! Hours of fun!  I rate plain SoC higher than the expansions because it's fast-paced and easy, and we can get in multiple games in a night. Also, SoC games are typically close games where everyone has an active role. Even if it's a blowout, it's usually quick and painless.   Played SoC dozens of times before I started tracking my games played (approx. 50-100 games).  UPDATE: Finally played this again after a long hiatus. We started with the sample board and starting positions to even out the board for the 2 new players. Turned out, the sample board was awful - poor settlement and road placements that didn't make sense (for example, some second round choices settlement and road placements would have been better in other places).   New version: Flimsy board pieces, ports are permanently set on border pieces, but they don't sit well to frame the hexagonal board.   Tracked on family list (grooven)!
