We don't play it as often as we used to, but we've had many fun games of Settlers.  If it had a decent 2-player game, we would likely have played it a lot more.  The tile-constructed board, and differing scarcity of resources makes each game different, and gives the game enduring appeal.  The game naturally encourages players to target the leader, which gives some people the grumps, but also produces close finishes with most people "in the hunt" until the end.  Still a very enjoyable game, that often earns a place if we have a weekend away.  If I'd started logging plays 5 years earlier, this would probably have another 30 plays against it.
20+ plays.  A great game that has more than proven itself. Better with the expansions? I'm not sure. The vanilla version is short and sweet... though the expansions add depth.
(25+ plays)  Who can play?  Family game for 3-4 players.  A true classic.  This one gets a lot of play.

A classic period. Easy to teach and a perfect intro into the gaming hobby. Sadly does not get much playtime due to more advanced options in other games i prefer to play. As a gateway game highly recommended.
Strangely addictive, just wish I could corner 2-3 people to play against more often  >8(

Settlers was for me, like many others I'm sure, THE gateway game, and will always hold a very special place in my heart.  I actually learned Settlers in 10th grade, every week I would go to a club at Cornell University where a bunch of the college students gathered to play games, almost exclusively Magic: The Gathering. I had been going for a couple years and would continue going for a couple more years, and throughout most of that time I mostly just played/traded Magic, spending far too much money in the process.  One fateful evening, I looked over and saw people playing this rather odd boardgame. Up until that point in my life I'd only played Monopoly, Risk, Life, Backgammon, etc. It looked so strange and interesting, I actually tore myself away from Magic for a few moments to watch. I became so engrossed that I watched the entire game. In fact, up until last year I'd never even read the rule book for Settlers, I simply learned by watching that game very closely. So throughout the years I started to play Settlers from time to time at that club at Cornell.  Eventually I even bought my own copy, which I found at the local comic book store; I bought the old brown Mayfair edition.  And I played this, and I played it some more, actually I played it for years and years.  All the time never stopping to realize that there might be more games out there like this one.  I loved Settlers, but somehow it didn't occur to me that there were other games of the same or similar ilk.  Fast forward a bit, I move to Chicago and go to college, I meet a couple good friends, and show them Settlers, the three of us end up playing Settlers almost every week together, and all this time, never think that there could be any other games out there I should be checking out.  So then I leave the country to study abroad, and while I'm away one of the friends I'd been playing Settlers with tells me about this board game fair on Navy Pier in Chicago and how he found out about and saw all these neat board games somewhat like Settlers but different and great, and they even had a giant life-size 3D version of Settlers.  I'm very jealous, but my interest is piqued.  Shortly thereafter, that same friend goes to California to visit someone, and comes back raving about this incredible game called Carcassonne that he was introduced to and that I just have to play. I'm like Carca-what?  He's like, you haven't heard of it?  I thought you were all into board games, isn't that your thing? And I'm like, uhh, no, I like Settlers, but haven't really ever played any other good games.  Anyway, I blame it all on him (or rather I thank him profusely) because from that point on I decided that maybe board games should be my thing, so I got Carcassonne shortly thereafter, played it, and fell in love with it.  My collection began to grow very quickly indeed, and now I'm as addicted as ever.  So it was Settlers that I played first, and Settlers will probably always be the game that I played most, I still can't believe it didn't occur to me for so long to see if there were more games I might like.  Purchased: Date unknown
The game that introduced me to the world of German board games. Klaus - you are THE MAN!

Well-deserving of its place as the #1 gateway game. Definitely doesn't feel dated, and is one of the only SdJ winners that really shines. Has an incredible amount of non-conflict, pseudo-cooperative interaction. People complain about the dice--eh, stuff happens.

This game is great for board gamers of all experience levels. It is easy to learn but also strategically rich. Games are usually less than an hour long.

This game is fun to play with gamers or non-gamers.  The rules are simple and the game really flows once players get a feel for the game.
One of the most popular games, and for a reason! Settlers is always a fun game even for new gamers.

The standard for the Eurogame. This game has stood the test of time, and its popularity is still high.   A great family game, and is also a great game to play with others that don't play a lot of games (the infamous "Gateway" word). The game is well balanced, well designed, and is just fun to play.    This is my favorite "family" game.

There is 'something' about this game the makes you coming back to play it with friends even after 50  games. For probability freak like me it is a great title. I love to play it even without any expansions. It is great title for introduction to new players ( not the best but it works quiet well with some ) but it is also fun to play with semi-expirienced players. I recomand buying this game if it is one of your first titles to buy.
The one that started it all!
Great game - one of my first Euro-games.  I enjoy playing this because it is always different.
Classic. Can be played by non-gamers yet has enough strategic appeal for those with meatier appetites. A game of numbers, probability, diplomacy, and negotiation. Love it.
Great game filled with player interaction, trade, and development.  Highly engaging game.  It can be a little repetitive as the game comes to a close, but overall still great.
Addictive game in my group.  I like the two player variant on BBG.  A must have in any beginning game collection.
Kara Pratt-Frome: 7 John Jansma: 10 Melissa Jansma: 9 Justin Heimer: 7 (Justin owns) Rosalie Phillips: 9 Amy Peschong: 10

Very social and entertaining game. We mostly play with The Seafarers expansion. And there is some strategy in this game... Now I have just played this too many times to ever suggest it any more, but I will play it anyway.
A brilliant game as, it seems, everyone who can say the words 'modern game' knows. And I agree.
This game was my gateway game into gaming.
My friend (Jeff) introduce this game to me and I have been a fan ever since. (2006)

Like many this was the game that got me into boardgaming as an adult. Both tense,taut and with that slight chaotic element (which I really like)due to the dice. The only cloud over this game is that I've played it to death so not really one I'm keen to play much these days. Sure I'll come back to ti though.
Great game to play with friends as long as you have a few hours to sit down together.  A definite favorite with my group of friends.

This is the game that got me out of the Monopoly rut.  Opened my eyes to boardgames it did.  Will always be a 9 in my book, and will never loose the luster (at least it has not for 8 years).  (added 2/12/08)  I now own the game (and the extension) and have played it twice today against my students who all say that they enjoyed it.  Looking forward to many more times of play with my students!
I'm crazy about this game for some reason.  I could play it all the time
The first "Euro" I ever played, and still likely one of the best.  Great game for introducing family and friends to a world of boardgaming beyond Monopoly and Candyland.
This is my gateway game. The rules is really simple but it got some depth. This is a classic.

After all these years I still really like this game! The player interaction (trading, robber dynamics, etc.) is really the key to the fun here. There's no down time, because during any player's turn there can be haggling and extortion happening.  I think Settlers is at its best when played quickly with only 3-4 players and minimal add-ons.

My copy is actually missing parts but I have friends who own it as well.  One of the first geekworthy board games I played.  Possibly my gateway game.  I still remember the day the group I was with first played the game and the amazement at the ability to do so many different things.  My only dislike of the base game is that the dice never seem to roll anywhere near the numers you would expect on the average.  Then again dice hate me more often than not.  I've advanced on to the expansions now but the base game still gets alot of credit for bringing me into the hobby.
A fine game - engaging and fun to play. The random variations offered by the game board are excellent. Can be frustrating, due to the luck aspect, but otherwise superb.

I was juggling between 8 and 9 for Settlers. Technically, I think the game deserves a 9 for being elegantly simple and always fun to play. I eventually bumped it up to a 9 for the game's uncanny ability to draw non-gamers into the Eurogame genre. I am one of those converts myself.
Original First Edition Mayfair. The graphics make distinguishing resouces a bit difficult.

This is one of the best games for both new and experienced gamers. There are enough expansions out there to keep anyone interested and scale up to 6 people easily. Makes a good evening meet up game too. Only complaint is that the cost of the whole set is a bit much, but there's always e-bay. I don't like the images on the new printings either, but that's just personal preference, and is probably somewhat biased by the fact that since I learned on the old set, the new one "just doesn't look right."
The best one night light game on the market
So far I have always enjoyed this game. I don't know if my feelings will change over time, but it doesn't look like it will any time soon.

This game has a great balance of elements, which makes it a lot of fun. It has variation (with the random board) which keeps it fresh, good player interaction (with trading) and luck! It's a great game to teach and it's almost always a success which is indicative of what a great game it is.
Great game, lot of resources! It's cool, buy this!

I used to give Settlers a 10 (not because it's the perfect game) because it was my introduction to eurogames and it opened a whole new world to me. Boardgames were no longer Pictionary and Scrabble.  I've since downgraded my rating of it, purely because I've overplayed it and I really need to stop playing for a while.  It's lost much of it's attraction through overexposure.

A great game but its too me a very strong luck based game. If the dice gods favor you - you will run away with the game. I love the trading aspect but where and what goods you try to produce will determine this game. Always place your best piece (token)with the highest probability near Wheat.
This is a great introduction game for your non boardgames playing friends.
Otro de mis favoritos, muchísima interacción entre los jugadores y muy buena mecánica.
The game really is about who you play with.  The game plays best with 3.
Amazingly simple, but strategy will beat luck every time.
Great but can get repetitive after a few plays.
A terrific game, but the graphics could be greatly improved.

We played this so much I got a little burned out, but having been away from it for a while I enjoy playing it when it comes out. A classic gateway game and the one that gave us  the unforgettable "I've got wood for sheep!"
I'm new to this so I'm finding this a fun game.
Herkesin elinde olmasÄ± gereken bir masaÃ¼stÃ¼ oyunu. Basit, gÃ¼sel ve eÄŸlenceli.
All-around excellent game.  Light enough that it's easy for new players to get into it, but with enough depth and replayability that it's still enjoyable after countless plays.

Re-introduced me to the modern world of board games.  I actually have a good 75-80 plays of Settlers but most of these were before I started recording them on BGG.  Still in my Top 10 and still requested to play on occasion when nothing else seems to fit.  The trading negotiations are the best part of the game.
I accidently bought the cards for this game instead of the card game - ughs Ebay kills me sometimes! If you want nice new cards for your settlers game - let me know!
This was the game that started it all for me. Have always loved the randomness of setting up the board and rolling the dice. Lots of strategy and good to show non-gamers. Love it.
A solid game. Simple to learn, simpler to play.

this game gets a bad rap because of the dice.  they can be frustrating, but really, stop taking it so seriously. it's a good excuse for why you lost.  it's always a fun time, even if you lose badly.  unless people are picking on you and you're way behind.

Great game I am currently working on all the expansions for this excellent set.  We have a great group of gamers that play regularly and can bust a game in under 40 min.  Have seafarers, cities and knights and currently looking for atlantis expansion
Still the house favorite.  3-player games work great.
the all-time classic of European boardgames. Never gets dull great player interaction. It is competitive without being standoffish. this is a must for anybody's collection.
Thanks Whitney who introduced Kate and me to this game one evening after a very rainy Picnic Day in Davis after a wonderful meal together.
A great game. The game that started it all for me.
Have been playing for over 10 years. I've never turned down a game and I won't in another 10 years.
own two copies, one for trade
Also have other copies for trade (all 3rd edition) and my personal copy I'm keeping.

What is there to say about the ultimate gateway game?  It’s an incredibly social and competitive game that is just so much fun.  The only criticism is that the 5-6 player expansion really should be part of the base game.  This has fallen of our gaming radar but I would not hesitate to take it out gain if requested.
It is an Eurogame with dice? Amazing!
One of my favorite games!  Easy enough for my 7 year old to learn but can become quite competitive.
Playing this game on Xbox 360 is what got me into boardgames...
My wife, kids (21,18, & 13), and I all enjoy it every play. Win or lose we have a good time.

SoC - get the Basic game if you want to introduce someone to boardgaming. It is quite fun, easy to understand and will most likely get you a lifelong boardgamer friend. SoC - Seafarers adds complexity and some more flexibility to the basic game. But What takes the prize is the SoC - Cities and Knights. It provides good complexity and has lots of options and will also force you to learn how to strategise. Of course all settlers games are dependent on luck (of the dice). After countless hours of gaming fun, I wish to play more.
One of my first games, we played it until the pieces were destroyed and then we bought another copy.

Ok, lots of gamers have moved on from here and it tends to get a lot of flak.  However...this is still THE gateway game for many people, and it still sells by the bucketload.  It's fun, accessible, and there's nothing else out there that gives the same feeling.  Yes, it can sometimes be unbalanced and a bit random, but good play can mitigate all of that.  4P is the most balanced; 3P can suffer from runaway leader, and the 5-6P expansion is a bad implementation.  I've played literally hundreds of times, and will still come back for more.
It's easy to teach, easy to play, and encourages sociability among players.  I love it.
(2-4 players) I like this game a lot but haven't played what I would consider to be a rousing game of it yet.
This is the strategy game I play with newbies to gaming first.  It is a classic in strategy games and I still play it with family, friends, and co-workers!
Great with 3 players, bogs down with more.
A modern classic... I like to teach this to people as a gateway...  My review: http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/308851

I love this game.  It's got everything our family likes: high interaction, some strategy, some luck, and it's FUN. I know a lot of people around here say that it sucks, it's had its day....blah, blah, blah.  I really don't care; it was a great game fifteen years ago and it's still a great game.  I brought it down to a 9 because it's got ugly components.  However, the 3-D set is a solid 10, and that's the one we play with anyway.

This has got to be the game I played to most, ever.  It's a classic, always solid, always good, reliable gameplay.  Sometimes the dice can screw this up a little, but that's part of the management.  Must have.

Gotta own this game! A great classic. Yes, there is luck factor because of the dice. However, there are some controls that you can have during the game. A great combination between luck, strategy, and tactics. Good with 5 players. Most played game by my group so far.
Our first "geek" game. Wish it were better with two players, but its fine. Great first game. Looking forward to getting some expansions.
4th edition.  This is a wonderful little game to play.  I mistakenly bought it as a 2 player (occasional) game though, but that doesn't work quite well.
My gateway game, so I might be biased. This game is so great for kicking back and the table talk is some of the best.
The more you play with the same group the more intense the games can get. However, this can lead to some crazy pick on the leader scenarios.
Spectacular game. An incredible mix of luck and strategy, with many hard choices to make.

We finally bought the classic.  I really enjoy it.  Settlers of Zarahemla was my first introduction to euro games so this is a little nostalgic in a way.  SDJ-1995  DSP-1995  MC-1995  -->Gave to Mom and Dad Scholes
I enjoy Agricola, Puerto Rico, and Settlers as much as Magic, but I'm limited by time and space by these games.

This game is a great classic.  While I enjoy it the most with three players, it's also great to play with two couples, or just a bunch of friends.  My husband and I even went through a period of time when we played every evening with just the two of us.
This is a great game, so glad this one got brought to the house
Our friends new favorites. You know we did something right when they ask to come over and play Catan. Lots of fun and the one game I have not won.
A game that requires strategy, lots of planning, good trading skills and a bit of luck on the dice-rolling. There are several ways of winning, which makes the winner very unpredictable.

Out of the 2 or 3 groups I've played with on a regular basis this is just a classic and can't be replaced. We may not play it as much nowadays, but it's the first thing we start our newbies out on and it's always something people are glad to see out on the table.
This is the game that got me hooked on games. Classic.
Most classic German-style games. Used to be my long-time favour, and still is very good game.
Karen got me this for Christmas.  Additional electronic games have been played that are not logged.
Would be a 10... but I still haven't won a game on my own board!
Excelent and entertaining game Great for family and friendly games Easy to learn, easy to play, fast deployment, fast game

Yet another follower-placement game (the First that I've owned, in fact!). It's strength lies in replayability, as the gameboard is never the same. And luck goes the same for that matter!  As this game can be played with 2 players, I strongly recommend to gather up at least the third one. In two player games, there's just no need in trading, which in my opinion is one of the most intriguing aspect of the game as it enforces conversation and diplomacy, which is absent from two-player games.  Totally recommended for fans of games like Carcassonne!
This game started a whole new kind of addiction...

I like the game but the only problem I have with it is there is a lot of luck involved with the die role. Don't get me wrong, I like some luck in my games. But this one requires too much luck in order to win. For example, I played my 13 year old daughter and son and we all kept rolling 9s all of the time, which gave my daughter tons of resources. She clobbered us, getting 10 points before my son and I got to five points. I bought this game expecting a lot more strategy and was dissapointed.  Edit: I have played this a few more times and, while I still don't see a ton of strategy in this game, I am seeing more possibilities. I think the expansions will probably go a long way toward increasing replayability. I increased the rating from a 7 to a 8.  Edit 2: I got Cities and Knights and it makes this game a solid 9 for me. We're having a lot of fun with it!
Awesome 3D hexes for 6 players...its huge! See pics on BGG.
This game introduced us to Euro-style games.
One of the first boardgames played, simply amazing.
now that i've played Catan so many times, I prefer the expansion and playing with 5 players more than the base game.

This was another of the first board games I ever got. This was a staple game for the missus and me when we were entertaining for a fairly long time. Simple gateway gaming at it's best. you really can' go wrong with this.
Fantastic game.  Simple yet challenging.  Easy to set up and the replay ability is high.
Started me in the board game hobby.

2 sets. the 1st is magnetic portable edition by Hanayama, 2008.6 Japan travel souvenir. the 2nd is Mayfair 4th edition. SoC gets better and better with each play.   basic (8) +Seafarers (9) - seamless and fun, but takes much longer time to setup +C&K (7) - complex and long, less fun +T&B (9) - nice variations without other expansions' fallbacks.
This game started it all.  Gotta give respect when its due.
Best All-Round Strategy Game Able to play it with the whole family (that never happens)

Wonderful game--perhaps should be a 10, but I can see that the base game might get old eventually (hence the existence of so many expansions, right?). I have played this more times than my log of plays suggests--probably more like 8 or 10. Initially I found the luck frustrating, but I have learned that much of my frustration came from an overly simplistic understanding of how to place settlements, which led to my not having settlements on a broad enough variety of numbers and resources. Initial placement is maybe a bit too important, but as I have gotten better at that aspect of the game I've enjoyed the game as a whole much more.
homemade copy using the magnificent Hexes of Kaahtan by BGG user Itomi Bhaa

This is another game that is great with 6 people (we have the expansion set).  I love the negotiating of resources - I've always liked Monopoly because of this, and the same principles apply in Catan.  The fact that dice rolls can affect who wins the game is not the best game mechanic, because there may be too much chance involved.  But if your placements are evenly spread out among many numbers you can limit this risk - which is a good game strategy.
A classic of course, and always worth a play, but after a few years, it hardly ever comes to mind as something you really want to play.
Easy to learn and a new game every time. Beginning gamers and experienced gamers alike seem to enjoy this one. I use this game in my school board game class and the middle school students love it.
The best game ever, Holy Graal of board games - even after hundreds of newer and "better" games played, I rate it number 2 in my games collection.

Excellent game. There are so many things to like about this game. Everyone is involed every turn so there is no "dead time" between your turns. It is simple and it is short but there is a lot to it. I really like the trading aspect of the game. If you are shrewed and trade well you will win a lot of games. Also the other players tend to gang-up on the leader which tends to make every game a close finish which is always exciting. We have played this to death but still enjoy it everytime we play.

A classic, and highly rated in my collection because of its interactiveness and ability to be played by many family members.  This is truely a break-out game for introducing new players to board games.   I have many of the expansions and variants, and have had fun building historical expansions.  (I modeled my own Settlers of Cannan with sculpey and cards, and have turned it into a historically educational variant...)    You have a wide range of complexity, and a great deal of luck within the game, making it addaptable to many audiences.  Finnaly, the end game is very visually appealing, with all the pieces and tiles togther.    Downside is storing all the pieces and parts, keeping instructions of all the variants, and setup time for many of the variants.  Another down side is getting players to not roll the dice into the board!

I will always treasure this game.  It was introduced to my wife and I by some great friends while my wife and I (fiancee at the time) were on a pre-marriage encounter trip in 1999.  It was the first game that I enjoyed since picking up Magic several years earlier.    Anyway, the same friends bought us a copy for our wedding.  The rest is history.  Although we play more Gulo Gulo and Kids of Catan now (2 kids later), my wife and I still love to introduce this game to other couples on date nights.
Probably my favorite game right now. I'm itching to play more. It's a classic and I can easily see why. I love the trading negotiation and diplomacy aspects. Not too complex and not too simple.

Great way to introduce new players to modern boardgaming.  Enjoy other games more these days but has a special place for getting me back into the hobby and will always play with potential gamers.  Have many more plays of this, many before I started tracking. Likely to be +15 or so.
I see why the game has the attention and reputation it has, it's mechanics and play are flawless and a work of art.
This is the game that showed me what real board games are. This is a fun, simple game that I always have time for. If you want more depth and strategy pick up the expansion Cities & Knights as well.

The game that got my group into board gaming.  The right amount of fun, randomness, interaction, and strategy for a good time.  Easy to learn, I feel like it's a 'Board Game Buffet' for games - it's not the best example of any one game mechanic, but it has a little bit of everything to result in a good time.  The one caveat I have is that setting up the board can be a pain.
The first Euro game I ever played.  Love the way the board changes every game.  Much better with 4 players than with 3, in my opinion.

The first game we bought, and still one of our absolute favourites. The random board setup, and luck aspect of the dice provide a level playing field at any given time.  It's great to have a game we can play where a) anyone can win, no matter the strategy/experience level; and b) even when you lose you have a great time.
Just a lot of fun to play with friends. It's easy to learn and non geeks can still have a blast with it!
El juego con el que empecé y al que he jugado tropecientas partidas. Ahora mismo prefiero otros pero si se tercia una partida pues.....
One of my favorite games.... but don't play if you get stressed over trading and haggling.
This really is a classic.  My board is worn enough that it won't lay flat very easily.
The game that introduced me to this wonderful hobby!  A classic!

One of the very few games that my gaming group (such as it is) asked to replay immediately. There's shouting, stomping, and victorious yells: this game is awesome. UPDATE: The Asobrain implementation -- especially with variant maps -- is phenomenal. UPDATE: Keeping it as a 9 for now, but to be frank I am bored of base Settlers. I always insist on playing C&K when possible, and preferably with some of the more exotic scenarios rather than the original hex board.
This is it, the gateway drug. Quite possibly my favorite game of all time, only gets better with each expansion... well until Cities and Knights
Played it lots before getting seriously into boardgames. I have the old Mayfair edition, so unfortunately no new expansions.
Trading resources in this classic game is my favorite part.
Excelente juego y de verdad no me arrepiento de haberlo comprado. Dispuesto a jugar cuando sea! :D
Don't hate. Just play and enjoy. This hobby owes Settlers a ton.
Why didn't I buy this years ago like I wanted? Now that I have it, we play it every chance we get. But its three players, so I don't get to play it as much as I would like.
Very funny to play 4 or more people. Simple and elegant, it's great to play with it and the friends.
Settlers was my first Euro, and I still love it.  The luck factor doesn't really bother me.  Lots of player interaction.  I try to bring my well-worn copy out as often as possible.

Probably the best game I have played in a long time.  Actually, I was thinking of dropping this down to a "9" recently, but I just pulled it out again for three more plays with a new player.  It's easy to remember why this game is so fun and why it attracts people to it like moths to a flame.  Every player is constantly engaged with it at all times.
Broke down and got a 4th edition.  For gameplay I would probably rate it an 8 but the game itself and the effects it has on nongamers bumps it up to a 9.  It can bog down with 6 players though.

Got this in the mail.  Wife, daughter, and I played it, and it was a very nice game.  Since we've played Settlers of Canaan so much, it's hard to stop calling the robber the plague.  I like the replayability of this game with the mixing up of terrain hexes and port tokens.  Downside: harder to setup and no point tracker.  Update: Since sold Canaan. I really enjoy this with Seafarers and the Fishermen of Catan (Traders & Barbarians).  Family likes it that way too.  One of my favorite games.
This is one of the most addictive board games I've played.  The perfect mix of strategy and luck just keeps me coming back again and again.

I love this game even though sometimes it can drag a bit too long and you can get so screwed your hopes are all but lost... But then again, luck with dice just might make up for it...   I think this game has a perfect amount of controllable randomization - player skill determines the winner nearly every time.
A very good game.  I would probably rate it higher but I've played it enough times that I've gotten tired of it.  I'd like to try the expansions.
Duh. Love it! For whatever reason, it is also the game most likely to get me involved in all-night game sessions with new gamers. For that, a gold star! Two gold stars! A thousand!
What needs to be said: it's Catan!
Dice Rolling Hand Management Modular Board Route/Network Building Trading
I love settlers. It's fun, cute, clever and suits almost all players.  Write a reflective review - starting gaming.
The game that got me into Euros. It's just a skosh over-familiar to me by now, but I still pull it out to introduce new people to Eurogaming, and I'm always up for a game.
Popular euro-game about settlement and trade on the island of Catan.

You can become an adict after playing the first game... after some time you need more... and more...you look for new more challenging games... and you finish  becoming a gamer!!!  I have now a lot of games and no people to play them!!! you should never play this game if you do not want to finish  like me.
My friends always want to play this
Great game, a ton of communication (which I love) and the dice action normally equals out over the course of the game.
The game is a must for any collection.  I always forget how great the game is--then we break it out to play and I am reminded of its greatness.
Probably the most played game we own.
Classic Game.  Does it need a comment?  Never had anyone say they didn't like playing, but I can see how overplaying it could make one lose interest.  I am surprised it is not rated higher on here.
See my video review of the game!
For two years we played so much Catan, that we have become bored...  However with the gamecards expansion (a fan-developed exp.) it has become again a fantastic game
As it has been said before "Great gateway game"
Played it too many times for it not to deserve such a score. It earns its keep, it blew me away when I first played it, and I'd gladly still play it despite having done so over 50 times.
Number of plays is really in the hundreds.  A great active game, there's always something going on even when its not your turn.

An increadibly balanced game that suffers slightly from its random nature. At the same time, the random aspects keep the game interesting, ensuring that no two games are ever exactly the same and allowing new players a chance to compete with the more experienced. Settlers is a fantastic "2nd step" for new players that have tired of A Ticket to Ride and Carcassonne and are ready to try something new.

This was my gateway game into the more complex world of games.  Its always fun to play, and is never the same game twice.  Don't play it as much now that we've discovered the Cities and Knights expansion though.
Great gateway game.  Hard to play anymore though as no one will trade with me now.
The trade communication/negotiation aspect can be so much fun.
Only showing 14 plays at the moment but that is totally inaccurate: been playing regularly since introduced to it 6 years ago.
One of my all-time favourites. I got bored with it for years but now I play Catan regularly again.
One of the best games I've ever played.

What a great game - so much more depth than the first impression, especially when playing against evenly matched opponents. Found the NDS and iOS versions and love them too. Even my wife has overcome her boardgame phobia and thinks this is a good to very good game.
The game that started me down board gaming.
I'll never turn down a game of Settlers.
The first game I bought that made me a gamer. The one I have played the most and is still my  wife's favorite with Dominion and San Juan a close second.
Innovatium boarder is a must. Ensure continues sanity throughout the game.
first game i introduced to non-boardgaming family...it's spread like wild-fire through them.
@Sara  It all started with....die Siedler von Catan. Back in Austria 1997.
What can I say, a classic that is still fun after a gazillion plays.

CLASSIC  Two sheep for 1 wheat?  Brian (BBD): "When you all play Catan do you say things like, 'Hey, we should play a game of Catan!' when you ask people to play? Or do you say things like 'A large natural disaster has destroyed an entire island nation and reformed it with a completely different setup of natural landmarks. 4 hardy adventurers are needed to bring civilization to this untamed land. Much danger lies ahead, but this task is essential to bring balance. Do you have the guts to be one of those 4 chosen?'"   "Also I will kick all yall asses in Catan. I swear on my confederate pride and the grave of Robert E. Lee. When my longest road cuts off your attempt to get to that sheep port, remember the South Will Rise Again."  BBD: "There is boring Catan and then there is "Real World: Catan" where danger lies ahead and the stakes are high" Robin: "Probably the former, but should I be invited to a game of Catan with the latter, I will surely accept."   Me: "We never talk anymore, Twin." Drunk Seth: "Yes we do! We talk all the time! I'm always asking you if you want to trade 2 grain for a wheat!"
I have played this game more than any other game to date (we're talking 100's of times).  It's always a little different and is the gateway drug of board games in my opinion.

'Settlers' is a fantastic family game. Great for those occasions when you want to host a game that isn't focused on warfare. It really gets people interacting in a big way. Good or bad things can happen to you at any time, even on other players turns. The 5-6 player extensions are great, because they modify the gameplay further, allowing each player the chance to conduct some activity for themselves, on other players turns. It's definately not a game where you get bored waiting for your next turn to roll around. The rules are simple to pick up, and yet the game has tremendous potential for modification or adapting 'house rules'.
I've always enjoyed this one - even though I seem to be good at coming in 2nd :)  Fun game.
Introduction to Euro... played countless games with varoius groups... always fun... a solid 9 for the great memories it has given me.
I played it too much so I do'nt like it anymore but had to give it a 9 for there can be only one reason for playing it so much.
Classic, my first non American game, got me into the hobby.
This is the only game you should be more familiar with than Carcassone.
Lots of fun with 4 players, less fun with three players.  However, I'm not big on the set-up.

I can't praise this game enough. It has HANDS DOWN the best player interaction out of any game ever made.  People criticize it for having too much luck, but that just means they aren't very good at it. If you play well, the dice should be heavily mitigated.  The only real flaw with this game is that it's pretty easy to get completely shut out within the first few turns if someone blocks you. This can particularly happen in a 4 player game. Generally this only happens if there are some newbies at the table though.

After Carcassonne, Settlers is probably the most played game in my library. This and Stratego Legends were my gateway games. There was a time when I would have rated Settlers an 11, but now I only feel that way about the game when playing with the Cities and Knights expansion. Regardless, I believe that a house may be a house, but it's not a home until it has Settlers.

After 200 plays with regular Catan, we upgraded to Cities & Knights and never looked back! Now we've had about 150 plays of Cities and Knights. The cards and hexes are knackered!  They've had water spilled on them 3 times and still going.

Plastic miniatures version + exp 5-6 Player Extension (1996) + exp: Seafarers (1997) + exp Cities & Knights (1998) + exp Seafarers – 5-6 Player Extension (1999) + exp Cities & Knights – 5-6 Player Extension (2000) + exp Catan Scenarios: Oil Springs (2011)  With Seaferers, cities and knight and all ext for 5-6 players, I give a 9 !

Good introduction to the genre because the rules are straightforward, gameplay is quick to pick up and the strategy is reasonably complex so that you don't put anyone off and you feel like you have a chance to win, even in your first game.
It's Settlers. Great game for its time, and trading is still pretty great. But I can't say I play it much anymore.
A great game for the whole family to play.  Easy to learn and teach, the random board makes for great replay-ability.  My kids love it.

column2: V I C T O R I O U S

column4: Good clean fun that doesn't get old. Manages to feel rewarding even when I'm losing.

You can't go wrong with Catan. A great game that helped get me go deeper into the rabbit hole of hobby board gaming / euro gaming. Settlers can get old pretty quick after playing so many games, but it's definitely a solid game.

I LOVE THIS GAME!!! My friends and I play it almost every time we get together.  If it's possible to play a single game too much, this would be it. Game is great, but gets a 9 of 10 due to the fact that after many game plays with the same people it feels repetitive.
favourite game of all time, bought all accessories, play all the time
plays with my wife .. are interesting ... (sometimes i have to sleep in the sofa)
Like to have a game or two with my brother and wives. No one ever have won two games in a row.
For me it is the definitive board game. It seems to never get boring for me. Excellent with the expansions.

I love this classic game. I know many have moved on to other Euros, but I keep coming back to it. It is so well balanced and there are at least three viable paths to victory. This one will have a home in my collection forever.
A fantastic game, simple as that.  I can't believe it took me until 2009 before I played this game for the first time!

Oh god.  Traded away.  Participated in a tourney and enjoyed it. Zach gave me his second copy.  Then I gave that away and bought myself a nicer copy.  Then I played at a friend's with Cities and Knights. Wow. Here's a game.  Such a reversal. I play all the time now. I was a fool... a damn fool.
Echangez 1 mouton contre 2 argile et vous verrez le monde autrement !

After more than 500 games played (mostly online), I can say that for experienced player this game is very well balanced. It's all about where you put your first settlements: if you know what you're doing, you cannot made a mistake. Once you figure out what numbers can roll how often, even the dice doesn't add to randomness to much. It can surprise sometimes, but for me that's one of the joys of this game (I'll always remember game where we had like 6 two rolled and one 6 :D ).
I always play with the white bits so my roads will "blend into the tiles" and escape notice...
On Nintendo DS and Xbox live
Excellent game.  Fun family strategy.  A personal favorite.
A modern classic.  The game that got me playing boardgames again, and is still the game that my "non-boardgaming" friends want to play when they do play.

You really can't go wrong with this game.  I love the trading aspect with players (and how no one will trade with you near the end of the game if you are leading!).  I love how no two games are alike based on the random board setup.  I love how you can teach it to a new player and they can play mostly appropriately during their first time.  I would play this every day!
my first boardgame (not counting Monopoly and Uno, of course)

Love this game. Intending to buy more expansions and wanting to try new rule variants. Feel free to contact me about either if you have something you want to sell (that I don't have) or have a new variant you want to chat about. I'm no master, but I'm learning bit by bit as I find chances to play.
A modern classic and my gateway game to the world of designer boardgames. DON'T USE THE SUPPLIED DICE, though - wooden dice are biased.

An instant classic and always a great standby, even when I've had it for a long while. Simple to understand but with meaningful decisions, and with just enough randomness for the game to swing in unexpected directions. I recommend the Seafarers and Traders & Barbarians expansions in particular
No other board game can draw more people.
Best to introduce friends to board games!   Not too complicated, but with a great fun factor.
Bought it in 2010 after playing it with the Chippewa Valley Board Gaming Group. Is really fun and everyone that I get to play it with me thinks so too.

I must say its definately a great game.  I've played 2 and 3 player games so far and they've been entertaining.  I love the game because every time you play the board is different.  So its almost like playing an entirely new game every time.    I highly recommend getting this for anyone looking to get into the more advanced board games but don't want to dive into the big expensive monsters quite yet.    Instruction manual is easy to read and to look up things.  Also the useful website where they had game tutorials on how to play helped a ton.  I was able to pick up the game in one night.  Fairly simple game but still very strategic
one of the most perfect games ever created.
best game of all the times. full of strategies, coorporating and fun.

Very fun ever changing game.  Your get to build cities, race people for resources, attack opponents, trade, and roll dice.  This game does a little of every thing games do right.  Fun for all and enough strategy for the gamers.  My favorite game.

I love this game.  The production of resource mechanic means it's very difficult for players to be cut out entirely even if others refuse to trade, and in all the games I've played there's never been a serious dispute.  The variety of contributing elements to a win, the modular design for freshness...for me, it's perfect.  I look forward to someday getting the expansion and trying out 5 or 6 players. (9) 2011-04-08  UPDATE - I've played the 5-6 player expansion and like it.  Each player having the option to build at the end of each turn means your plans haven't been lost by the time it takes to go round the table, but in merry circumstances it does help to have someone 'chair' each round.  'Any building? Any other business? No?' (still a 9) 2016-12-08
A classic.  I got my copy for free!
I have to give this a high score, because it is what made me love games again.
Great classic resource management game. My flagship game into designer board games.

We have delayed playing this until our son was 'old enough'. The box recommendations are for 10+ age group. Seeing him take to it so effortlessly in the last few days makes me wish we'd started a year ago when he was 8.   This is an excellent structured game for mid primary and above, which keeps all players involved. Takes us a comfortable hour to play.

This game usually goes over well with new gamers.  I love the interaction and table talk.  It can be boring if your numbers never come up on the dice, or an opponent blocks you.  There can also be run away leaders.  Even with those issues, the game is fun.  I love the concept of having a wide open board to execute your strategies upon.  One of the few games where I sleeved the cards because it is played that often.
Possibly the best 4 player game there is.

Not super deep but enough strategy to keep you interested, plenty of variety in the game board to keep it fresh, and enjoyment for a variety of ages and gamers. Settlers is a great standard to begin or end a session of gaming because of its 60 minutes or less play time.  Over played on my part now, and use to be a 9, but it is still a fantastic game.

I feel like this one is a gold standard.  It's deep enough for repeated play by serious gamers while easy enough to be enjoyed by newcomers and casual gamers.  It's shocking to me that it isn't rated higher.  Maybe there's a bias against it because it's popular and you can buy it at some mainstream stores.    I was kind of against Catan myself before I played it.  It's hard to get excited about an agriculture based game.  It seems like the most boring thing you could spend an hour involved with. However, first appearances can be deceiving.  Catan is super well balanced, each game is different and there are multiple strategies to winning.  I would be embarrassed if I didn't have this in my collection.

I love the game but too many games have ended with one person saying, "If there hadn't been 6 8's rolled before a single 6..."  Despite the luck factor of dice, the strategy involved with settlement placement and resource manipulation make for a very enjoyable 3-4 person game.

Had a lot of fun playing this one at Ding Con, New Years Day 1/1/11.  Played with Sandra, Julie and Nelson.  Got a little rowdy, lots of laughing.  I think that was the most fun I had playing that game, so far.
Excellent game! Good variation, quick to learn and nicely rounded. Will try and get my hands on one.

After many years and several thousands of plays (online included), I'm still excited to play this every time I'm offered. I believe that says it all, at least for me. However, an update. Catan sadly breaks down with people who don't play logically (weird trades, weird blockings etc.). It can take the enjoyment down somewhat. So with people who know how to play, it's 10, but the general rating for me has dropped down to 9.
Second game that brought me into the hobby.  May have played it around 20 times.  Only one person I introduced it to did not like it.
A well received addition to our game collection. I've yet to find a group that won't have fun playing this.

Very fun, very strategic, and great flexibility in players by number.  Timewise, it plays quickly.  Unfortunately, it breeds some very vengeful people.  I've seen games of settlers where people refused to trade resources with other players because they "cut off their road" 2 months ago that no one even remembers.

Have played over 100 times, mostly within the first few years that I purchased it. I took it out again recently and the memories flooded back.  I think playing with Cities and Knights is the best competition and adds complexity to keep it interesting for those seasoned players.  Even though it does not get out often it is still a joy to play. My daughter is just now old enough that she can play a good game. So its getting out more often. It will probably always stay a 9 for me as it has earned a spot as the most influential game in bringing me into modern games.
i have played this too many times (before joining BGG) to go back and add them all...the first "Euro" game I played and bought, still hits the table often with certain groups
One of the greatest games of all time.  Only gets better with expansions and extensions.

One of my favorite games.  Though there is luck involved its amazing how many options you have in this game that will allow you to win.  And you get to see some creative bargaining while you play and that is entertaining too.

Of course like most, this was my "gateway game."  I picked it up in shrink at a local thrift shop for two bucks...six years later I have a lot less money because of it.  I still think this is a great game when played with the right people.  However, there is one person with whom I will not play this because of his "extortion variant."  Extortion is not negotiation.
Is there someone who doesn't know this? :P
One of my all time favourites.  I like the idea of trading with others and being able to rely on my own strategies. We don't really play it in a ruthless manner though.
Gateway game. Balanced and fun although some balance issues with 3 player games. Recommend 4+

THE Euro game, for most of my "gamer" friends.  Good gateway for Acquire, Agricola, Powergrid, and Dominion.  Elegant strategy, pleasing aesthetics, and fun, mostly non-confrontational player interaction make this a modern classic.

Great game. Now I can see why this is the game people are always talking about when they're talking about gateway games and modern boardgames. A true classic, which I can see getting a lot of plays, most of which are balanced. There is a moderate amount of luck, but a good player almost always will beat a bad player. It's also making success with people who aren't "gamers" and they even requested to play another matches. I really recommend this to anyone, it's easy, relatively quick, has lots of interaction, an adequate amount of luck and pretty components.

Favorite for a long time, the glut of new games has pushed it to back-burner too often, but when it comes out, it's like running into an old friend again and having time to sit and catch up. Was ground-breaking in so many ways.  Still take it along to most Game Day/Night opportunities, just in case.  Also still use it to "break-in" new gamers, and is always a hit.
The game that got it all started for me. Still love it! I haven´t listed all the expansions that I own, but I have it all. Including the wooden container!
Almost perfect game. Great mechanics just a little too much luck factor. If your numbers don't come up-good luck. Also please note-German Ed
Nice game... one to draw nongamers in!
classic, got me into board games.
TRADING. One of my favorite games. Period. I am *always* up for a game of settlers, with expansions or without.
The game that rekindled my interest in games!

Un juego perfecto para iniciar a nuevos jugadores a los juegos de mesa. Perfecto para cuatro jugadores. El uso de los dados le resta estrategia y le suma azar, por lo que puede llegar a desesperar si no te salen buenas tiradas consecutivas. Aún así, resulta muy divertido el intercambio de cartas en la fase de comercio.
What's not to love??  Variable set-up. Dice rolling. Negotiation.  Strategy.  Screwage.  There is a reason this is the foundation to German gaming.
Didn't become a classic by accident.
One of the best designed games I've ever played.  So simple, but so many different strategies that need to evolve as you play.
Really good game and the rule are so simple, than everyone can understand it!!! It's very fun and good to play with all family!

Great game and was my favorite game for a long time. That is just because it is the game that really got me into the hobby though. I have played it a lot that i have become a tad tired of it for a time. Thus me not ranking it at a 10. Feel like it doesn't get enough love.

Interactive, Some Strategy and some luck, good jokes during the game.  Easy to learn and play.  Modular board.  Conflict is in the race instead of trying to destroy your opponents.  These are some of the reasons I like this game.
Great game, as long as everyone is on (roughly) the same level. It is marketed as newbie friendly, but then it's pretty easy to learn the chess rules, too...
how could you not love this
A classic. I usually have a good time playing it.
This is my preferred gateway compared to Carcassonne and Ticket To Ride.
Continues to be a game I never get tried of.
3-6 Players  Simply just fun and engaging!
Maybe I haven't been jaded by it yet, but this game currently remains as my group's favorite
One of our family favorites! A different board every time!

A classic for a reason, Settlers of Catan is one of the most fun, exciting and engaging board games I've ever played.  I recommend it heartily to anyone who wants a fun one that a non-gamer can get into.  Disclosure - I work at a distributor of this product.
classis game with good old figures made of wood
Fantastic game.  The importance of placement might take newer players a few games to really get the knack of, but otherwise a great game.
Several dozens of plays over the years and one I still enjoy to this day. Great, great game.
Box (and game) is getting very worn, and I think red is missing a road. Due for retirement and replacement as my first 'keepsake game', also my first game owned.
Rating for the 15th Anniversary Wood edition which support 6 players out of the box.  Excellent bits but not as nice as the 3D Collector's edition.
The game has aged well and is still the standard by which others are judged.  It is a near perfect balance of strategy and just the right amount of luck to make every game enjoyable.
This is the gateway to boardgames addiction!
Un joc foarte interesant, ai ales cand nu ai apucat sa te joci de toate pentru toti. Recomand cu caldura celor care nu mai vor sa se joace doar Monopoly / Bunul Gospodar :)
This was my gateway game to this great hobby :)

Gran clásico entre los clásicos, que tendrá este juego para crear adicción entre algunos. Simple de reglas, pero con la suficiente profundidad en su planteamiento, el comercio le da ese punto ritmo de juego que hace que siempre estés atento aunque sea el turno de los otros. Un muy buen juego.

just like pretty much everyone else...this is the game that made me look more into boardgames....i'm pretty sure at some time of ourlives we would all have voted 10 for it.but then again its not made to last long.best present for kids in the history
This is one to play with the little sister, brother and their other halfs!
This is my family's favorite game. I love the base set before adding any of the expansions.
Classic! I'd never turn down a game of Catan

My gateway game and probably yours, too.  Though I've arguably "moved on" from this game, I'll never pass up a chance to play it.  My wife enjoys playing vanilla, but I like adding the River (you might hate it, but I like it), Fisherman, Catan event cards, and Cities and Knights.  Looking to add Seafarers but I need an older copy.  A lot of people hate on Settlers after they graduate to other gaming mechanics, but I think this is wrong.  Settlers is what it is - a VERY well-thought out game that offers much replayability (tiles, resource markers).    Combining Settlers with its expansions--I like to play with The Great River, Fisherman, Event Cards (for the events only), Harbormaster, and Cities and Knights--makes for a long, but enjoyable, experience.  I would recommend this game to anyone trying to get into board gaming, and I'd gladly play Settlers with anyone, even after all these years.

It is only fitting that my very first post to this board be towards the first game that opened my eyes to a different level of board games -- and BoardGameGeek.  I would actually have given The Settlers of Catan a "10", if it were not for the expansions -- which are even better than the base game, in my opinion.  In any case, this was my first experience with a game of this type.  I grew up in a world of Monopoly, Life, Sorry!, Yahtzee, etc. -- all okay games in themselves, especially when playing with friends and family.  This, however, was the first non video game that really involved some strategy and thought -- and officially blew all of those previous family games out of the water.  It was an instant hit for this family of three!  We rarely play it these days due to our enjoyment of the expansions, but I would still look forward to playing it, if I did not have the expansions at my fingertips.  Overall, a wonderful game that involves thought and strategy, but is not overly deep to frighten gamers new to this realm.  I can definitely see why this is used as a "gateway game".
started my gaming hobby, rating might be bias.. but I love it!
A must-own for every board gamer!

Settlers Of Catan is probably one of the all around best games i have played... not necessarilyt overly challenging as a lot of it pays off in luck but the game plays extremly well and it is easy to see why this game is so popular.  Will always be a favorite of mine and the game i bust out when no one can make up their minds!  Love this game and recommend you all as well!

Settlers is a great game that is fun and variable without being too rules heavy. It's a game that travels well, and easy to set up for quick play if you have limited time. It takes longer while teaching new players, but experienced players can pop a game out in 30 minutes. Good game!
Pimped resources included:   Poker chips with visuals of sheep, wheat, etc. Custom robber  Custom acrylic inset holds 4/5, too base game custom Robber
Great game, easy to learn and relatively fast to play.

Everything Monopoly should be but isn't.  Frequent trading and deal making, easy to teach, elegant rules.  I personally have sold hundreds of copies of this game, more than any other game I have every sold.
Always a goto game with our group, easy and simple and fun, good interaction.
This game is pretty good.  With some groups it can bog down a bit with long involved arguments about who's going to bribe who to place the robber where.
I really enjoy playing this game!  It's great for teens, too!
The thing I like about it is that you can get resources.  I really rolling a 7 and putting the thief on people (as long I don't have more than 7 cards!).
The door in the board game world! absolutly awesome...
Good game, doesn't hold everyone's attention but I find it quite engaging
Pretty interesting. Reminded me of Warcraft for some reason.

One of my favorite board games of all time. I love the strategy involved in it (which resources are most valuable, who to trade with, whether or not to risk holding more resources, when to use development cards, etc.), and if you play with experienced players the games go by pretty quickly. My only gripe is playing with people that take forever with their turns, which can really detract from how engaging the game can be.
Good for multiple skill levels. Timeless classic.

Tried and true, I recommend this game to anyone including non-gamers and it's probably the best 4 player ~30 minute game I can come up with.  It takes quite a few plays for me to want to take a break from it, but overall a very well-balanced and fun game.
This is the game that got me back into boardgames. Simple mechanics very interactive lots of fun.
The first game that the kids really got in to with me so will always be near and dear.
A satisfying resource management game. Something to play with the family on rainy days :o)
A pretty good game. A classic, and well-worth the buy.

I will give it a 9 for now, maybe change it to 8 later. But what won't change is that it's a really good game. Addictive, exciting, so much negotiation involved. It's the best getaway game I can think of for now.
A great game that every family or group of gamers should have. Easy to learn and yet always close at the end. The expansions are all fun but nothing beast the original.

its a very, very cool game indeed. working your way to victory means being very friendly but also deceive your opponents by either bringing then of the track with trading or by offering then what they need to simply build a street whilst you can get the final victory point with that city your going to build right away.  swearing and being an aggressive or arrogant derp doesn't really help your game plan so I think being polite and friendly during the game gives you the best game experience.  there are some cons though.  there is little fun playing against people who don't have a lot of experience playing strategy games. settlers of catan requires some sort of foresight into what's going to happen on the board to make it the silently competitive game it is meant to be.
this is a game i play very often...I love it, but I am growing a little tired of the same stuff...  I love to come up with new strategies...nice to take the board to your advantage.

A classic for a reason. The game that everybody likes. Not a 10 because it needs 4 players - playing with 3 it is not as exiciting, and you cannot play with more unless you own the expansions. Anyway, very good one.
Very fun, this has replaced Risk at our annual holiday get together s.

I never played a game as much as this one, and it introduced me to board gaming's new age.  Before this game, I shunned board games mostly because the only ones I played was Monopoly and the like......No one should ever play monopoly....ever. (Unless you play with a spouse that you want to break up with afterwards)
O pai dos jogos modernos. Quem joga diz que é tempo bem gasto. Eu digo que é agradável. A família concorda e continua a pedi-lo para a mesa.
what to say...i was missing one of the greatest game ever. easy to learn, hard to master.

One of the most popular euros for a good reason. Everything seems to work nicely and is well balanced. The dice adds a bit of randomness to keep everyone on edge. Trading adds some interaction and collecting resources to spend adds satisfaction whilst your settlement grows. It has enough depth to keep players engaged whilst not too much that its hard to teach or off putting to beginners. A very nice social game IMO.

Great game, friends enjoy playing this.  It always takes a few goes with new folk before they get the hang of it. They always come back for more though.  Usually play with the 5-6 expansion.  Have the old tile version (no border).
undoubtedly, classic game which brings me to the board game world. Long live the Catan!
We still appreciate this classic for what it is even if those belonging to the cult of the new can't.
need to play this a little more considering that it is fun and easy to play.

My friends love this game, it's very strategy still uses dices. Negotiate is very important to win.  Meu amigos amam esse jogo. É muito estratégico apesar de usar dados. Negociar é muito importante para ganhar. Já perdi amigos por causa desse jogo, por isso prefiro não jogar sempre.
2011 Anniversary Gift for Zack from Julia
This is a great game, every game is different, and it is very luck based, but it is very, very fun.
the game that start it all

My copy had missing pieces but Mayfair promptly replaced them for me, free of charge.  The game itself was an instant hit with my group, it has stayed a staple of my collection, and would probably be one of my games of choice should I try and introduce some other friends deeper into the hobby.  If you have friends that really love to haggle, this game can become a great source of laughs... or a nightmare, depending on your friends, haha.
美中不足:要3人以上才可玩!!  875--> 950 sold

A modern classic, fantastic fun and the variability and two main routes to victory make for interesting and engaging games. Despite the replayability the rules and concept are straightforward enough that somebody that has never played this or any other 'Eurogame' will get involved and provided they didn't bungle the initial placement they stand a good chance of making a game of it. There's a balanced pre-placed layout in the rules that helps for the first game, it is pretty scripted for anybody who's familiar with the game though, whichever colour you get you'll know what you need to do at a glance - strictly for first games only.
Still a classic-played twice, once with 5 player expansions

My gateway into the hobby. Still one of my favorites. It doesn't hit the table much since there are so many other, newer games to play but I would never turn down a game of Catan of any flavor.  Expansion Owned: Cities and Knights, The Seafarers, Traders and Barbarians, 5-6 Player Extension, Travel Edition
One of the my favotie game, i recommend it.
There's always a special place for one's first love, and Catan is it!
If it weren't for the excessive resource randomization, this would be a "10" for me. Even with that, the free-trading resource system and the inherent balancing mechanisms make for a great time.
Genius, absolutely genius game! Currently this is my favourite
Jelenlegi kedvenc, telepesek vagyunk egy szigeten ahol nyersanyagokat kell gyűjteni és fejleszteni belőle saját telepeinket. Nagyszerű játék:)
I've played this a lot of times, and even if it's not deeply strategic, it's still fun.  I find the Seafarers expansion makes it better.

Trading mechanic makes this game evergreen classic. Despite having excitement via dice, the actual gameplay is pretty average and even dry by todays standards, but the trading makes the game much more lively! The rules are relatively simple at least for how deep game you get. It's deserving of its status as a classic eurogame that started it all. Still a good one, especially if you're introducing new people to modern boardgaming! Expansions.. meh.  2-Player Comment: * Settlers of Catan wasn't designed for two, but internet is full of variants to try (especially if you also own Seafarers). I prefer normal rules even for two myself, but play to 7 points only. It's no match to 3-4p game though and for most people some variant is a must.   Expansions: +Catan: 5-6 player Extension +Fishermen of Catan

What can I say about this game that hasn't already been said?  It's clever with lots of replay value and as much strategy as you want to put into it.  Euro-gaming at it's very best.  One of my favorite games to play.

This is THE game. Any player needs to have played this game. My complaints are numerous. First the board is horrible as are the cards, the artwork was dated in 1976 and the rules could use some variants. The expansions are a joke in that they DON'T REQUIRE CATAN TO PLAY. I want a real expansion, new resources, new cards, co-op play. I've seen Catan expansions with the last one, but this game is a play for awhile, keep on the back burner for newer players and pull this out every once in awhile for some epic (albeit old-school) gaming.  1995 ... old school. haha...
A great gateway game that should be in every gamers collection.

My first german board game, and my first modular board. I love it for those things. I also love my clock made of a settler's of catan board game. I find it's a great introduction for people who want a more advanced game, it does resource based well. And who doesn't like asking who has wood for sheep?
This is a classic!  I will never get tired of it.

Got a copy of this from friends (I think they upgraded or something).  Not my favorite game, but I do still enjoy a game once and awhile.  Another friend made a pirate version of the game and that was fun to play.  I'm thinking of making a gnome version this year.
x2, 200+ plays over the years not counting online. Also now own GIANT CATAN!

While over played in the world of games, it got me into current gaming and will always have a spot on my shelf.  Trading, die rolling, screwing people w/ the Robber, what's not to love?  I even made my own copy.
A classic that is prone to an occasional frustrating experiences based on randomness.
One of the greater boardgames played. This was the game that got me hooked to boardgames in the first place.

Great strategic game that has great pacing. Found it best with 3 players, since the board doesn't get so cramped and you have more options for expanding. This game was so fun to learn, I remember playing 4 games in a row with my friends! Really accessable to anyone, so it's good to have around.
Good to have in the stable.  Solid.
I play this all the time, another classic, great fo all the family. This is what you should play instead of Monopoly any time.
Never get tired of this one, the boards always different and while the roll of the dice plays a part, anyone with a basic understanding of statistics knows that "luck" is not a factor.
The one that got it all started...
Resource gathering/trading and building a settlement with a bit of luck mixed in. Such a good gateway game. Easy to find an audience for. It's hard to go wrong with this buy.
Great game, traditional. Happy to play a lot of the time. Really need 3 or 4 players. While I have enjoyed a game or two with more, it really drags along. Stick to 3 or 4.

A favorite of mine but my group tends to doze off after an hour or so.  We have adjusted the victory points to the length of time we want to play the game.  Personally I think it is awesome and it is pretty easy and somewhat luck based but a keeper for me.
Great game with lots of longevity. Our group has played many dozens of times.

I give this game a 9, purely based on the fun we used to have with this game.  I have played countless times now and no longer wish to play it often, but I still highly regard this game.  The fishermen expansion is a must have imo.
A great standard game to play with all friends who are interested in starter level board games. Interested in trying out expansions sometime.

50 plays:  Such elegant design! So few choices, but ones that matter! Such good use of randomness! Such simple compensation for being behind! Such pressure and reason to negotiate! So many ways to win! Just a perfect game, satisfying nearly every time I've ever played. It's true that if you aren't good at it, you won't win... that's not the same as "the player behind can't catch up".  And nearly immune to analysis paralysis, because so few options are open each turn. It can get a bit stuck in complex negotiation proposals.  Trying to play this with eight-year-olds showed me Catan's flaws, however. When the dice do nothing for you for several rounds, the game can get frustrating and boring. My daughter actually burst into tears at one point because she was getting so many sheep, and nothing but sheep!  Another parent suggested playing with kids using two rules adjustments: 1. settlements and cities can be placed 1 space from each other (not just 2) 2. on the first turn, you earn resources from both your initial settlements  I'd add a third: 3. the robber only forces players with more than 7 cards to discard one card (to avoid the heartbreak of discarding half your hand)

Expansions owned:    • Catan: Cities & Knights    • Catan: Cities & Knights 5/6    • Catan: Explorers & Pirates    • Catan: Explorers & Pirates 5/6    • Catan: Frenemies    • Catan: Oil Springs    • Catan: Seafarers    • Catan: Seafarers 5/6    • Catan: The Great River    • Catan: Traders & Barbarians    • Catan: Traders & Barbarians 5/6    • Catan: Helpers of Catan    • Catan: Darmstadt promo (Essen 2014) (Wedding Tower)

While perhaps not a true "Eurogame" in the strictest sense, this was the gateway game for me to get into these kinds of board games.  Before this it was your traditional American family board games like Scrabble and Monopoly.

This is the game that reinvented the board gaming  hobby, opening the eyes of the masses to the possibility that there was more to board games than Risk and Monopoly.  Settlers' popularity actually makes complete sense. The game is quite easy for new players to grasp giving it wide reach in terms of its potential audience. But what makes it really unique is that the game play appeals on so many different levels. Whether you like building stuff, or managing resources, or trading and negotiating, or rolling dice, or collecting sets, or building an economic engine... there really is something there for everyone to enjoy.  One of the real highlights for me is the free-trade mechanic, which I haven't seen much elsewhere. The economy self-regulates based on the availability of resources and stage of the game. Someone might pay you three resources for that brick now, but two minutes later its worthless! It's fun to figure out what kind of deals you can pull together each turn and it also keeps everyone constantly engaged.  Obviously the variability of the game is a huge plus. The hexes are laid out in a random order each game, the numbers which determine resource frequency will also change. You can try out different strategies by using development cards or ports. And there are some neat organic catch-up mechanics like the robber and negotiation, which mix things up and lead to many very close games.  I have played probably 200+ actual person to person games of Settlers and I still really enjoy it. These days I play it most often with the family or with newbies as there are better games for a truly strategic head to head. But nevertheless this is a versatile, elegant and highly repayable game - a must have for any collection.

A great intro to gaming game.  I can remember how blown away I was the first time I played it.  I think of this as a replacement for Monopoly.  (I always like the IDEA that in monopoly you would get to make shrewd trades for property, although it never worked out in practice.  Settlers brings the barriers to trading down to where people are willing to do it)

What can I say about Settlers of Catan that hasn't already been said? Nothing. It's reputation is firmly cemented into the history of board gaming. It might as well be Monopoly at this point. Except I actually enjoy playing Settlers of Catan.
Best game I've played so far. I purchased it during a trip and have not found anything so entertaining and easy to explain. Catan is so far the best family game I have put my hands on

An almost perfect game. Mechanics are beautifully elegant, plays very quickly (40~60m with my group), negotiation makes the game very fun and interactive. The only downside is that randomness has too much impact on the game for my taste. I agree that the game should contain some randomness, but if it was more controlled, I would consider this a perfect board game. A great game nonetheless. Strongly recommend it for light gamers.

The perfect game.  It is open-ended, encourages good negotiation skills, has a bit of luck, but also has an equally big strategic part to it. It succeeds on all levels of a board gaming experience and has very simple rules.
Love it.  Every player can participate in every turn.

This can be a great game. I really like the Helpers of Catan cards, though to balance some of the "unluckiness." There are a few minor things about it that I don't like, but I won't ever refuse to play it.

A great strategy game. Since starting position and luck strongly determine the victor it is better if players of equal skill duke it out otherwise someone can be left out of the running and be bored until the conclusion.

What a truly fantastic game, this board game is possibly one of my favourites. It's simple enough to introduce new gamers to yet it offers some strategic thinking as well as clever game mechanics that are really impressive.  I always want to play this game!
Awesome game, but i wouldn't play it without seafarers anymore.  Don't play this very often anymore. But the nostalgia keeps it up here.

Absolutely brilliant design. Totally deserving of my high rating.  I have a facepalm moment whenever somebody calls this game "random".  Look, the split in 10 coin flips is unpredictable. Flip it 10,000 times, and it becomes extremely predictable. This game makes sure there are enough dice rolls for luck to even out. Note: [b]Every player[/b] rolls dice on [b]every turn[/b]. The result affects [b]everybody[/b].

2 hours long replayable trading/tactical/skill/luck family strategy.  [b]Pros:[/b] - Easy to learn, hard to master - You can learn main rules very fast (and search for more precise rules later) - Good variability: --- modular board --- different starting positions --- different tactics to win (you need to adapt to your position and cards) --- trading between players - Appropriate game length considering complexity  [b]Cons:[/b] - Boring for player who positioned their settlement unwisely on the start or have bad luck with dices. But these games are often much faster so the misery is over soon.  [b]Note:[/b] I'm still trying to measure luck involvment in this game. Currently I'm thinking about 50% luck / 50 % skill

Great game to be played with friends & family (you can play it with a 12 yo kid, no problem).  It has an interesting replayability. The game mechanism is fairly simple:  You start with setting 2 cities on 2 ressources (on the board obviously), then it goes: - Throw the die - Collect ressources (everybody who has a building on the collectable ressources) - Trade with the other players if needed - Expand your roads, build a new city or buy a special card - Repeat until you win 12 victory points (by creating cities and having specific cards)  The good point of this game is that even if it is not your turn, you can partially play by collecting ressources.  And this is the strength of Catan: No one gets bored!
As of 4.2.2015, this is my favorite board game.
This was my first gaming obsession. And I will always love it.
Only played once. Components in new condition. Box shows some wear.

I *love* Settlers of Catan. The only aspect of the game that prevents it from being a perfect 10 is that the outcome of the game is heavily weighted towards the first 2 settlements you pick. Other than that, it's basically perfect!
