28.10.2009: One of the first euro-style games I played. I still like it.
[Played more than 100 times] Simple rules but endless possibilities thanks to the modular board and the trading aspect. Strong player interaction (often "friendly"). Excellent for non-gamers.
A huge fave, always a lot of interaction at the table
Don't play it as much as we used to, but it's still fun.  I guess the dice can put someone in a rough spot, but there a few paths to victory, so you can deal one way or the other with what comes.
While I don't have the expansion, you can easily add a second set to expand the number of players.

Really like the way this is made. Unfortunately, the dice sometimes get in the way. If your numbers never come up in the beginning of the game, you'll never get any income to increase the numbers you can collect from. Law of averages may work for millions of games, but it doesn't always work for dozens.
Quality game loved by most, with too much reliance on a luck mechanic.
Definitely the best gateway Euro in my opinion, and still fun after many, many plays.

This game brought me back into board games. Everybody probably says that. Still, I've introduced this game to many newbie gamers and all love it. It has become a staple game for my family and there's little doubt I'll be playing the rest of my life - and will always enjoy it. I do wish it had a better illustration and graphics treatment. It would be much more approachable.
Every playing is enjoyable.  This is the game that drew many folks into the German game craze, and deservedly so.
I just have fun playing this game.
One of the most frequently played games of mine. Easy enough for non-board gamers to join and enjoy. Best played with four players.

I have a little, personal game hall of fame.  It's got nice lighting, cool exhibits, plaques on the walls - you should see it.  Anyway, Settlers of Catan is an inductee, so I suppose it should be a 10. But, it really isn't for me.  I feel like I've "played it out", if you know what I mean.  But, I still think it's a great game which I happily play.  Always tough decisions between spending resources for the cheap things (roads and cards) and saving them for the big ticket items.
Excellent resources management game. Can be a bit luck driven if the dice gods are not kind. Great game to get adult players hooked on boardgames.
Loved it first time I played it.  Excellent starter game (beginning set-up).

What can be said about this game that hasn't been said a million times? I enjoy playing it well enough. With the right group of people it can be a lot of fun. With the wrong group it's a miserable experience. There often isn't much to do on your turn and it can get very frustating if the dice don't go your way.
Now that I've actually gotten it to the table a few times, I have to say that I enjoy Catan.  I want to play it more.  I see why it was such a big deal for so long.
Reseña en español en [b]El dado de Jack[/b]: http://eldadodejack.com/2014/08/30/resena-catan/

Elegant and attractive resource management and trading game.  Simple enough to draw new players, yet with enough opportunities for cagey strategizing that more experienced players will have plenty to think about.  10 years on and this one's still seeing a fair amount of play.
Stands the test of time and is a very fun game with great player interaction that can become dull and frustrating if you are stuck with bad dice and unproductive lands.
The epitome of "Euro" games.  The first one I ever heard about, anyway.  A bit too abstract for my top ten list, but still a lot of fun!

I have the game, and enjoy it, because it doesn't take too long to play, and it keeps you hooked while you're playing it!  A good one for getting non-geeks into boardgaming!  Can be completely hilarious toward the end of the game.
What's not to like?  A work of genius.
Fun game, but not a lot of replayability. Well I was wrong. This game hits the table at least every 3 months or so.
Excellent game made even better by Cities & Knights.
Great intro game but now I'd rather play Cities and Knights anyday.

slower game than most, but has a good ballance between randomness and strategy.  Probably one of my favorite games so far.  I can see Puerto Rico overtaking it eventually ;)  Haven't played enough to come up with a good strategy, but want to!

Great fun! This was my first so-called "Euro" or "German-style" game. Here on the Geek, you'll find a lot of negative comments leveled at this game. Don't let them distract you as the game is sound and stands on its own.  Also recommended is Starfarers of Catan, by the same designer.

It took only 1 game of my friend's German edition to get me hooked on this.. Not having bought any boardgames for a long time I was fortunate to pick up a copy of the Mayfair edition in a book shop in Manchester shortly after Christmas... I then discovered BGG and online games retailers! The game relies quite heavily on dice roling, which makes it tough for me sometimes because I suffer from dice-jinx. Still a lot of fun to be had after countless games.
I tend to win this game - a lot. Hence, it's a great game in my book!
I love this game (I know, cliche).  I've used this as an introduction to 4E games, and as a weekend party game.  The expansions are highly recommended.
Cool game that has enough randomness to allow everybody a fair chance.  Fun to play.
Who doesn't love Settlers? Wonderfully balanced and beautifully designed. I'm a big fan of the seafarers expansion, but find that Cities and Knights detracts from the overall parsimony of the game.
Great gateway game to get into the resource/building/trading genre.
An excellent light game; Personally I stick with the base game, no expansion.
I have 2 copies one is the 2007 version with a border.  2nd Copy Info $16.09, Dec. 14th 2008 from Amazon

I love the game because its simple to teach and isn't too long.  Resource management can get to be a bit of a pain, but since its based in cards, I don't mind it so much.  This was the first euro I played, so its probably rated higher here than it would be if I used the more modern euros in my scale.
This is THE game that started it all for us!  'nough said.    The PC version is well done and a nice sub for solo-play... also have it on my iTouch and iPad.

Luck factor is high but short enough not to make investment of time unrewarding even if you get screwed.  Rating increasing with play but with three it suffers too much from the 'stop the leader' syndrome and would rate a 8.
This game started it for as well.....what a surprise. Though it has lost some of it's charm, still a really fun game to play once in a while...

There isn't anything to be said that hasn't been said already.  As far as I'm concerned, this is one of the best games if you've got about an hour to kill.  The biggest weakness is that it only plays 3 or 4, but that can be remedied by buying the 5-6 player expansion.
I think this is a great game, don't understand why it is maligned
Fairly easy to learn, but lots of different ways to win makes learning the finer points an enjoyable challenge.
This game has to played with both "The Seafares of Catan" and "The Cities and knights of Catan".

I enjoy this game a lot.  It would have a higher rating, but because of the luck factor, the game can sometimes drag.  Perhaps I like this game just as I would like Vegas if I were to win a lot of money there.
The trading aspect make or breaks the game.
Fun game, known as "Wheat for Sheep" in my circle.
Have the Mayfair and Simplyfun versions.  Both are in good condition.
I think this will be an evergreen, one of most unique games ever released.
MUST make my own 3rd version since seeing those pics!

I owned this for a few years but never broke it out because I'd heard and read that 'the only way to play this game is with 4'. Before BGG.  Fooey, the thing works well with 3, no problem. Might require 3 good gamers, though. 4 is good, no question, especially if some of the group are not so great gamers.  Been playing this for years now, it's a lot of fun.
Great game to introduce people who think Monopoly is the only game around.
Great game with several ways to win.  Excellent game for non-Euro-gamers.

Settlers is the reason I started playing board games. It was my favorite game until it was dethroned by Puerto Rico. I'm not sure if I don't like it as much any more because I played it too much, but I think it is the best gateway game bar none. It was after all my gateway game!

As most people this is the game that did me decide to go into boardgames. Although it is not very balanced and the factor "luck" is very prominent... it remains one my all time favourites. Especially with one or more expansion sets :)
The game that got me back into board games.  Great game for non-gamers. Easy to learn.
Seems to be the best game to get people hooked into playing boardgames!

*Generally in most game designs players will know well before their last turn where they stand (unless vps are kept secret such as in E & T) so robs most of the players of the excitement.I think one main reason why Settlers does it for me is that there are a few elements which makes the game less likely to be anti-climatic than any game design I have played before or since.   Resource holdings are secret, so there is tense uncertainty (unless you have memorised the transactions) whether other players will overtake you in the vp race, which incidently is kept at a simple and visual level.  But the clincher is the dice which in their nature provides hopeful swings in fortune or devasting schaudenfreude. The use of the commonly rolled "7" has been used to great effect to put risk filled fear in the leader from hoarding and also the robber as another mechanic to try and level the playing field, in a thematic way.   So the tension of declaring the 10th vp is often in doubt until the right resource is secured in a trade, the vp development card is drawn or worse you have accummalated more than 7 resources and fingers crossed no-one even yourself that a 7 is rolled. The development costs menu means that an internalised narrative of needs is established cranking up the climax.
One of the original Eurogames for many, a good (simpler than many make it) development game. Highly interactive.
My first Euro game I played. Still a bit nostalgic with this one.
What can I say, totally addicting!
Easy rules, easy to play game but lots of fun.
I think I played this too much.
A bit too simple perhaps. I guess I should get the expansions.
Fun.  Like most games it takes the right mindset and the right people, but thankfully I have those people as semi-regular partners.  :star::star::star::nostar:

As for so many others, this was totally the game that opened my mind to what games can be.  Cool strategies, good interaction between players.  The dice and luck aspect is maybe more frustrating than fun, though.

Fantastic light play.  This is the game for non-gamers that I always trot out.  Moves along quickly, and doesn't encourage overly competitive new gamers (you know who they are) to get angry at others.  It also has enough strategy to satisfy the gamers in your group.  I don't tend to play it with other serious gamers anymore, but it got much of my group and me into the gaming scene.  Its reputation as a classic is well-earned.  Revolutionary then, and still revolutionary for most people now.
Classic that pulled me into the fold of German Games.  Still, I find that I rarely play it anymore.  I ought to, it is as good as ever!
This game introduced me to gaming.  Kinda wish I had just said no.  Look where I'm at now.  Rating has gone down because I burned out on it.  During its prime it was a 10+.
Fun game, very easy to pick up.

This is a great game and the classic gateway game. Great balance and enough different ways to win to make each game interesting. I think the reason why it's a great gateway game is because at the start of each turn your options for your next move are usually very clear and it's just a matter of choosing one or the other and pressing your luck. New players pick up on this quickly and it gives what some might call the "illusion of strategy" without making the game feel completely luck based. Recommended to any potential gamers out there.
What to say?  It's a classic, but I have big stack of other games I'd probably rather play.  With the right group it's still a lot of fun, though.
My gateway game to the world of Euros, this one still hits the table from time to time, and is still fun to play.

Played twice and after A LOT of eurogaming. Good game: 'resource' games are always attractive, and this is very simple too; but it's a kind of simpleness that creates elegance. Reallly indicated for non-gamers.Unfortunately, it plays up to 4 only, but after all I think that playing in 5 or 6 would really increase the playing time.
Out of all my games this gets played the most.  It is requested by my family, my friends, and my gaming group.  It is just plain old Settlers too, no expansions.
An excellent medium weight game.  Simple rules, lots of room for strategy.  Luck only really comes into play with very evenly matched opponents.
9->8 City building and trading oh my~.
A student of mine kept pestering me about how great this game was.  When I finally purchased and played it, Catan set a new standard for me of what a game should be.
The game that started it all for me. My fist "deep" boardgame, after playing Risk and Monopoly for years..... Played this to death, but like it much better with the expansion Cities and Knight.
Nice for Beginner in German boardgame style I prefer SpaceShip Catan
A great gateway game to lure in new boardgamers. One of the standards of our group.
Easy to learn, fairly deep strategy, and excellent expansions. A true classic.
A true classic. It got me started with Euro Games.
sort of a euro standard, unforgiving of bad initial position

It's a good game and a game to introduce people to boardgames, girls will love it and become good at it. In my opinion this is the Ideal Gateway Game. I think I will play Catan forever, at least once a year.
So tired, so very tired of this ... but I will keep my rating high as it has served me so well in the past for getting non-gamers to the table.

Messer Teubers classic. Plays very well with 3 or more (whilst it can be enjoyed with 2). Mayfairs production is good and workman like but dont expect the quality of DoW, FF, Alea, Ravensburger or the like. You are going to need polybags and rubber bands for this one. This one should be every gamers collection.

EUROGAME CLASSIC ESSENTIAL TO ANY EUROGAMER COLLECTION After a long gaming hiatus my reintroduction to gaming and my first taste of that Eurogaming thing.  Like many cliches it sticks because it is true - fun for the whole family.  The dice can hose you for long spells, so if that grinds your gears you may want to avoid this classic.
3-6 Players. Best with 4  Catan: 5-6 Player Extension Catan: Event Cards (Mayfair edition) Catan: Seafarers Catan: Seafarers – 5-6 Player Extension
Old school. neverending love for that game!
One of my favorite games... even though I am terrible at it.
Of course you have to own this one!!! after all its THE original game...Great game, diferant everytime.

What a wonderfully easy game to get into. There are a small number of decisions to make, but they are tough to make. My one beef with this game is the extremes in the dice can make or break you AND it is possible to go a turn or two with nothing or little to do (cf., dice extremes). HOWEVER, I am always willing to play a game.
Another "easy to get into, hard to master" game. The rules are simple, the bits are nice and the gameplay is well studied, but what really makes this game shine is player interaction. Great.
A bit too random for me but overall I am still learning the game.
A classic, amazing game.  Even with all the expansions I still enjoy breaking out the original.
Finally I played my first Settler! :) It was a nice game and I won! Nice blend between tactical decisions and luck!

A light game with good depth of strategy and high repeat play value.  Modular board is easily disrupted from table knocks so difficult to play with little kids around. There is a lot (too much) strategy in the setup and a somewhat premature ending (ends just when things start to get going). The limited use of dice adds a nice 'take that' mechanic, spices things up nicely without being too random.
great gateway game, but I really don't have any desire to play this anymore.

Overall, probably the best game I have played. Hopefully will become gaming canon, replacing Monopoly et al  Even better with the Seafarers expansion.  Have downgraded slightly after my last play. I'm starting to resent the luck of the early dice rolls and the runaway leader problem.
The greatest game I know that I've yet to buy.
Nice blend of luck and strat -

[b]Spiel des Jahres 1995[/b] [b]Deutscher Spiele Preis 1995[/b]  [i]Posted: 10/2/04, Rated: 9[/i]  [i]The Settlers of Catan[/i] focuses on colony building and trading. There is no combat element to be found anywhere in this game, although a player can be a bit ruthless with the placement of the "bandit" piece. This lack of simulated armed conflict makes [i]Settlers[/i] an easy game to recommend for children.   The game board can be randomly created, which definitely adds to the game's replayability. Interaction between players is essential to winning this game -- another plus. Lastly, the resources are represented by cards, so there aren't any complex money transactions that would require a calculator to compute.   [i]The Settlers of Catan[/i] offers innovative gameplay, is easy to understand, does not attempt to model violent conflicts, and above all is fun to play. I am looking forward to introducing many of my friends to this great game.  [i]Updated: 4/22/06, Rated: 8[/i]  [i]The Settlers of Catan[/i] was one of the first "Eurogames" that I played.  Since that time, I've developed a bit more perspective.  I still really like it, but it has lost some of its luster.  On your turn, a bad roll can benefit your opponents more than yourself.  Enough of those rolls, and the other players can prevent you from developing (with 3 or four players).  Trading in desperation just makes matters worse.  If this scenario happens to you, you're effectively removed from contention, sometimes very early in the game.
Like many, this was the first Euro game I played.  In the years since it has remained a game that I greatly enjoy, and will still bust it out from time to time.
Too much luck for me, but still an enjoyable game around beer and friends

(P3-4) An oldie but a goodie. The wild randomness of the dice used to piss me off so I "borrowed" an idea I saw for sale on eBay once and made a deck of cards to represent the roll of 2 dice instead (e.g. 1 card for 12, 2 cards for 11 etc). Works a charm for this and Starfarers as well.
I love this game. I'm not a hardcore strategy gamer, so it's got enough of a strategic element to keep me intrigued, while the luck factor keeps things interesting.
One of the best 4 player games I have. Easy to play, and still enjoyable after quite a while now.

It's a step up from Monopoly as a Family Game. A good strategy game mixed with a healthy dose of luck and negotiation.  This would be a good game for new gamers, However, there are easier and quicker games for non-gamers.
The classic.  Played a lot in years gone by, not so much these days.  Nicely balanced game that gives everyone a fighting chance assuming they don't mess up in the intial placement.

I was introduced to this when it was still barely known in the US.  I loved it from the first time I played it.  This game has simple rules, but requires alot of strategy.  This is one of my wife and son's favorite game as well.

Played 22 times. Last play was May 3, 2008.  This was fun.  It was enough different from Settlers of Cannan that I don't mind having both in my collection even though the primary reason we got this was to play with the 5-6 player expansion.  The close quarters and more evenly distibuted numbers really makes this game harder, and seems to suffer from a run-away leader problem that I didn't notice in Settlers of Cannan.  The last game we played was the first really close game - but that was because my husband didn't choose to win when he had the opportuntity and then gave me the exact trade I needed to get three points at once.  Just played the game with 3 players and it was a much closer game than when we play with 4.  I've decided I just don't like this game with 4 players.  There just isn't enough realestate and tempers get raised when one player out races another player to that critical corner.  There always seems to be one player that just doesn't have a chance.  Next time we play with 4 we are going to try and use the map for the 5-6 player expansion and see how that works. (This was just confirmed again in last nights game of cities and knights - and I was the player with NO chance.)  We just played a 4 player game of Cities and Knights and used the expansion tiles and it was a much more even game.  We didn't have as much running out of space issues and there wasn't ever a run-away leader.  But ther was still penty of tension.

Regularly thrashed by my better half at this one. Would rate it higher if I could win! We play with a 'deck of dice' to even out the random dice effect. It is one of the reasons I returned to board games after a 10 year break.

This is absolutely a classic. I would be willing to bet it is #2 or #1 if BGG polled which game is owned by the most number of BGG'ers. The best part of this game is the interaction during the trading phase. The discussions (and usually the raucousness that ensues) change it from a board game that is played to a gaming experience.
... What more is there to say.
I like this game, it's simple but not booring, quick to learn and very funny

One of our 'regular' play games for family and game days.  We've taught this one to a lot of non-gamers and they've enjoyed it.  Two editions - one is the first english version with the little cards.  Though it doesn't see play much anymore - it still is a classic that has a special place.
Good resources management game but the luck of the dice can be a little frustrating sometimes.

One of my first steps into the realm of board-gaming. A good way to lure non-gamers to the gaming-table. But nowadays I play this only with the expansions. In my opinion it is more better and more complex so.
It was one of first game i bought, and it was the reason, why i start buying more, and more games ;) one of the best ever.
Fun but game-play has aged a bit.

As with Carcassonne, this one is a great friendly, non-aggressive game that's easy to learn and fun to play.  Mediated by luck (resource rolls), but with enough strategic depth (trading) to keep my interest.  5-6 player expansion is a must, but we don't play Knights & Cities or Seafarers (we like to keep this game simple).
I love this game. It's simple to learn, but takes a lot of strategy (and luck) to play successfully.
The classic. Lots of fun, even when you don't get the rolls you want.
The one and only.  It rocks like a game about settling a continent should.  The only suck-factor, is someone way behind always tries to screw over someone else.

A good intro game.  We play it a lot, to the point where I would rather have other people do the first play with a noobie, so they don't get completely smoked.  Still, a great game, with more strategy then seems apparent, but enough luck for beginners.

Settlers is good because you can generally achieve something, and you usually feel like you're making progress. However there are periods of depression where the thief is on you or the dice aren't going your way that make you feel like you'll never get out of the quagmire you're in. It gets a slightly lower than deserved score from me because of the depression factor.

If it was not for the fact that this game has been played in to the ground in the past, I would have rated it a 9. It stands as my first experience with European boardgames, back in 95. Wow, it still holds its own after ten plus years on the shelf. The game play is clean and simply elegent. I never did get into the expansions. We tried a few, and they just seemed to dilute its greatness. I recommend this game to any noob.  I do not recommend this game to a group  of six people using an expansion while several members look for excuses to get drunk.
Has some strategy but also enough luck that a new player has some chance of winning.

Good game.  My favorite part is the fact that the game cannot be won on your own.  You must interact with your opponents, via trading, in order to get the resources you need to get to 10 victory points.
Quick and easy to teach, with a bit of luck to even things out.  I enjoy this most without the expansions.

Played a lot since 1996.  I like Settlers but I've burned out on it a bit.  I've never owned a copy but may have to break down and get one eventually.  Fun to play now and then.  I prefer it with cities and knights, because I haven't played that expansion to death.  **UPDATE - 2005/09/10** I've recently got my Mom and Grandma playing this and gave it as a wedding gift.  Both were hits.   edit: 2009/03/08 Expansions owned: SoC: 5-6 player

I still like this game, mainly because of the player interaction through trading.  Its just plain fun trying to negotiate your trades.   Played it recently using the cards for dice roll instead of actual dice and it worked quite nicely, althought it did remove that hope that your 11 or 12 will keep getting rolled...
THE GAME. Play this first before all others.
A friend introduced us to Settlers back in 2001?  It expanded our horizons with respect to borad games.  It is still fun if you are playing with people who are willing to trade.

OK, this is 'THE' classic game that exemplifies european gaming. If I am introducing some one to euro games for the first time, this is the one that I use and the game that hooks 'em all.  CONS: can get a bit repetative after several plays - buy some expansions. Players get the opportunity to amass resouces and build. This is where its capacity for further play ends. Strategies are limited.  Pros: While strategies are limited, because the game is an excellent blend of luck AND strategy, the game play is still somewhat fresh with each game. This one is a classic and it should be the law that every gamer owns a copy. :)

The most interesting family game I have played so far. Simple rules, plenty of strategy, lots of interaction. Luck is a large factor, but can be overcome by skilled play. Nongamers love dice though, making this one of the best introductory games.
Mostly played, always come back for more.  1st game that got me into boardgaming.  4 players is VERY tight, 3 is the sweet spot for me.

Excellent game. Super easy to learn, with enough randomness to make it fun for all players, and enough strategy to please gamers.   I personally haven't played this a lot, partly because it's only 3-4 players. Ticket to ride is still my go to game for introducing folks to board games.
Played once with 4 players. It's nice, much better than I thought it would be although a little too much luck. It's fun although I'm not sure that there is whole lot strategy in it.

A true classic. This game is THE gateway game that I use to introduce people to "real" boardgames. This game has spead like wildfire through my circle of friends and it's actually humorous to find out the people who now play Settlers because I introduced a friend to Settlers, who introduced another friend to Settlers, who introduced another friend to Settlers, etc. For all that I've played it, I still enjoy the experience - though I'd often rather play something else. Not because Settlers is bad, but because I've played Settlers about twice as much as my other games combined.

Had alot of fun playing this (mostly with 5 players or though I think 4 is best 6 is too many, hard on the last player). It can be very frustrating though but overal mostly fun. We hadn't played it for a while and had a game the other day and we all agreed that we'd forgotten how good it was. One member of our group has never won a game of settlers (30+ plays) that gives me alot of pleasure too. I'm talking about you Richard, "I'll put both my villages on the ports, even though they won't give me any of the products I need."
pretty simple and appeals to almost everyone. great fun for the whole family!

My copy was the village bicycle for awhile when I was in college; it was probably played by upwards of 50 different people *before* I became more serious about board games.  Fortunately, it's still complete and in surprisingly good shape (worn, but not unplayably so).  As with many other gamers of my generation, this was the first German board game that I played.  I still enjoy it quite a bit, but since I've overplayed it to some extent, I don't like playing it more than once a month or so.  This 8 rating is more historic than anything else, at least at this time.  I found a copy of someone's math problem set in the box (ACM95, for friends reading this to whom that might have meaning).  It was there for at least 2 years before I found it.  I hope the guy didn't have to redo the whole homework set.

Very solid game! Like for so many others, this was my introduction to German/Euro-type games. Appeals to many types and ages of player, and has enough variation to be played, ocasionally, for a lifetime! The 2 major expansions, Seafarers and Cities & Knights are almost a must! But beware! If you try C&K you will have a hard time returning to plain old basic Settlers...
THE classic. had it rated a 9 since July 2007 and dropped it to an 8 in July 2011. it's still one of the greatest classics, but you can't ignore how things have been improving in this universe...
I rated this lower than the expansions as I prefer to play it with all the expansions.
If only there were no dice.
A wonderful game for people of above average intelligence.
when I first saw it (in 1994), I had to buy it right away in fear never to see it again.  Now a classic found everywhere.
Received this one from my brother - a great family game.
Great for the family, we all love the trading aspect!
All-time classic, which has brought me into the hobby.Ideal for beginning gamers. My 7 year old loves the game.
Really great game. Can go a little long if the setup isn't good.  We play "food stamps" which helps move along a game with a bad setup.
The first Euro I ever played.  Very fun.
A classic that holds up well
Classic....opens up a whole new world of games for a lot of people.  Unfortunately, some of those games invovle worker placement and auctions.  Well...I guess you really can't blame that on Catan.
All time favorite game. May not be the best, but it is the first, and always loved. Never underestimate the power of soldiers!
Mint oly sok embernek, nekem is az első volt. Ízlelgettem az új világát a társasjátékoknak és újra közelébe hozott ennek a remek világnak.

Dunno what to say about Settlers that hasn't been said.  It's pretty easy to pick up but meatier and more interesting than, say, Carcassonne for me (if not as interesting to look at on the table...).  I enjoy playing Settlers quite a bit and it still got one of the most positive receptions among my lighter euro group friends I've played with.  I think, as some of the ATers have pointed out in the past, the attractive thing about the game is that it's a design that crosses a lot of boundaries.  There is trading and building with victory points but it also has a number of screwage elements like the robber and has some randomness in the design.  This is definitely a crossover in almost all sense of the word.
Our gateway eurogame, we still like it and play it often.  We also use it to "infect" non-gamers with the eurogame virus.
A true classic, but only comlete with seafarers and 5/6 player expansions.
Nice intro game for noobs and youngsters! Maybe too much dice luck involved but still fun.

The antipode to Monopoly: Finally a really good game that everybody knows. It has saved the public reputation of the hobby. While appealing for experienced gamers, it is also a perfect game for beginners and occasional gamers. I'm not playing it that much any longer, though (even for introducing beginners / casual gamers, there are other alternatives by now), so I can't give the honorary 10 here any longer. Still the grade includes a 'historic' bonus.

I'm not saying anything new when I call this game a classic. I like to play with a random hex and number setup. The game is easy to setup and play, and offers quite a bit of strategic depth. Dice adds a little luck to the mix, but only over the short term. How do I maximize my resources? Should I compete for the biggest army or biggest road bonuses? UPDATE: Dropping my rating from 10 to 8.5, since there are so many other games I'd rather bring to the table before this. Still a great game.  UPDATE Jul-12-2010: Dropping it solidly to an 8, since this game fails the "always want to play it" test. Also, I think I was mad to say the game has only a "little luck." The game often never gets to the "long term" for the resources to even out -- it's only played to 10 points.  I really need to get a newer edition of this game. The '96 Mayfair edition has some visual design issues that make it difficult for new players to tell the resources apart. Specifically, A. the hexes and cards are all photographs (and dark, at that) and B. there are different images for the terrain (e.g., forest hex) and the resource (e.g., timber). The resource is illustrated as a circle. The player aid shows the resource circles only, and of course the hexes just show the terrain, but the resource cards have both. I was aiming for a conversion of an older player into a gamer, but instead I turned him off to "complicated" games such as this. :(
I find that people like this game less when I've introduced them to Puerto Rico first.  I like the game, but several people have complained that it drags on too long for what it is.
A true classic, and a good "gateway" game.
This was the game which put me in touch with my inner geekness. Good game to introduce non-gamers to the fun of boardgames.
Settlers is the wonderful game that got me into Euro-gaming, and I'm still not tired of it!

Great entry game for non-gamers, but not only. I'm a hardcore gamer and still enjoy SoC immensely.. because SoC is all about having a good time and fun... (even if sometimes it's spoiled a bit by bad luck or others' hostile moves without a sensible reason).
Quite fun, and short enough, with three players.
Trade Interest: none  This is a great game. it's just too bad the expansions cost as much as the game itself  Moved to Fredrick 7/3/13

[i]With my Largest Army I will bring The One True Religion to your wretched and benighted peoples.[/i]  [microbadge=966]  A DESPERATE RACE AGAINST GENOCIDE  Four flavors of a mad religious cult—persecuted in the Mother Country—make landfall on an eerily uninhabited island* and immediately get cracking on converting the primordial landscape into armed camps and the machinery of war.  An uneasy détente ensues as no one has the upper hand... but soon, soon one faction will reach the tipping point and become powerful enough to strike against the heretics [i]and wipe them out[/i].  FOR GOD COMMANDS IT  [microbadge=20990]  Includes:  [thing=20038]Event Cards[/thing]  [size=7]*The whole "robber" thing is really just a false-flag op to sow chaos.[/size]
The game that Jimmy started me gaming with. I like all these Catan games and am very happy I don't have to put the boards together.

Obviously a classic.  The game that got me (and many others) back into gaming.  Although I somewhat burned out on it, I still enjoy coming back to it occasionally.  4 players is far superior to 3, as it is much tighter and more competitive.  Ratings by number of players: 3 players: 6 4 players: 8  Really, I should rate this down when compared to my other ratings.  But it still gets at least a 1 point boost for nostalgia factor and overall impact on gaming (in gerneral and for me specifically).
Evergreen classic. Good interaction between players.
The game the rekindled my interest in owning, collecting and playing boardgames.  Î
A classic game.  Seems to be one of the few complex board games that non-serious gamers have heard of.  I've typically played this with Cities & Knights as well as the 5-6 expansions.

I might have wood for sheep.  What did I get?  I got a Rock.  I was surprised how much I liked a game based on resource management and trading as much as it is on development of your board position.  The availability of online play has led me to revisit my rating and increase it.

Good solid game, excellent fun and tactical options for trading and sneak collection of cards and an excellent mechanic to restrict those who are winning (the theif). But if you're last, chances are it'll stay that way!
excellent game- got hooked a few years ago from a navy buddy and we have been playing since. got my family and friends hooked too :P
The first "German style" game of my collection!
The game is a good one to get people started in serious board gaming.  It would be higher on my wishlist if my wife enjoyed playing it at all.
The one that started it all!
The classic "gateway" game in that it is easy to teach and play with newcomers and they will have a reasonable shot at being successful on their first play.
It seems to me very simple and interesting,
What can I say? it might not play for 2, but it's brilliant!

First plays are disaster, unhappy feeling since played by the robber... After try to weaken the robber and knowing the good of the trading, the game become really fun. Suggest to use some of the variants to weaken or change the behaviour of robber if you just don't like is so much as us.

A must own for every board gamer.  The design, lay out, simple wooden playing pieces and card quality are excellent.  We fell in love with this game right away.  everyone is involved in trading, development and harvesting on every roll of the dice.  Captivating design and a boat load of fun.
We tend to play the expansions now but sometimes set up the basic - dice are cruel

Best-with-4.  My first eurogame.  It's still fun to play, but I've grown to enjoy other games more.  Still one of the best games to introduce new players to eurogames. Every few times each year, we go back and play again and it's still great fun to play.  INCLUDED: Settlers of Catan - Seafarers Settlers of Catan - 5-6 Player Expansion Settlers of Catan - Seafarers 5-6 Players The Settlers of Catan: The Fishermen of Catan The Settlers of Catan: The Great River
A classic game and the game that re-kindled my love of board games. For myself, this game is the "gold standard" to which all other games are measured.
Better with Seafarers expansion, and often I would choose to play Settlers of Caanan instead of this one.

After 10+ Plays: Great fun.  Sure, there are more strategic games, but this combines interesting strategic options, tactical decisions, a good helping of luck, lots of friendly player interaction, and just the right amount of backstabbing (via the robber, competition for city placement, and my favorite, breaking up people's longest road.  Best with 4.
Great game, the original 'gateway' game for eurogames.  After all these years the random map and dice keep this game fresh for me.  I've probably played well over 1000 games of this.

Rated after 23 confirmed games with different opponents. In first games there was lots of interaction between players, but later the interaction level drops down when players don't try to propose every possible trade. In the end, when players have more or less experience, the interaction between players is quite scarce. A good game in good company, but the benefit of experience means this is not a game I would like to introduce to new players.  Randomness in the setup means that this game is very playable for long time. Unfortunately my latest games have used the beginners' setup.  Updated after 24th and 25th plays, introducing the game to new beginners despite the comment above. After all, this is a classic game everyone should know. Let's say, I won't introduce this one to non-players very easily. :) Updated the rating from 7 to 8. Now three plays of Catan on three consecutive Tuesdays, but still without expansions...  I have several small expansions for this game, looking forward to try them sometime, when there are no beginners around.
There are a lot of other good games out there, but Settlers is still great. Maybe it is overrated, but so are a lot of other games.
There are some variants to play this with 2, but I haven't tried them yet.

A classic!  I have gone off the Mayfair art, though - it all looks a bit too fussy compared to the Kosmos edition.    2006 update: After all this time, I am raising this to an 8 - still so rewarding when introducing non-gamers.
good game for a gateway. I've moved beyond this game though. Will visit it every once in a while.
We had to buy our own copy of after playing a loaner a half-dozen times! We like the Seafarers expansion, as well.
This is a great game.  It's fun to build settlements and roads, and trade with the other players.  Trading when it's not your turn keeps you involved.  Lots of replayability.
Excellent.  A good gate-way introduction for non-gamers.  There is plenty of player interaction.  With the luck element anyone has a chance of winning.

Just like so many others this is certainly one of the top games my group plays.  A nice balance of luck (dice) and strategy.  We don't over play any 1 particular game so we have managed to keep from wearing any of them out.  This game gets thrown down about every other meeting for a game or two and we still love it.
I'd never played this until 2006. It's pretty fun, though I'm not sure exactly why. It lives up to its billing as a classic.
A true classic, and the game typically taken to symbolize the euro game boom.  A very good game with a nice bit of luck from the dice meaning everyone has a chance.
The game all can play, and will have fun!

My opinion of this game has cooled a little over the years, but I still think it's a solid game. Yes, there's luck, but there are also plenty of choices. And the ability to trade can mitigate unfair die rolls.
The game that got me into modern gaming. What more can I say?
still fun after many many plays, and great to use as an introduction to designer games.
Near perfect board game, very acceptable learning curve, variety between games is enough to make it different every time and has good interation between players making it good fun.
Tons of replay value, nice and quick. 1 to 2 hours.
I enjoy this one... I like how the cameboard is different each time.  It's a classic.

Playing on BSW has gotten me to appreciate Settlers as a 3-player game, and this is now become my preferred number of players in live games, too.  Yes, there's a little less potential for trading, but I tend to avoid trading anyway, unless absolutely forced to.  Why help my opponents?
Only game me and the GF can play together and actually challenge each other
Az elso jatekom. Kb 2001 kornyeken egyik baratnom meselt rola. 2005 karacsonyara kaptam es ez inditotta el a lavinat.

Great game for "long" lunch group; however, there is a small ramp up time for newbies.  (The second playing is always better.)  Very enjoyable player interactions.  A true classic.  I raised this rating when I added in the FoodStamps house rule (no commodity this roll?  Get government cheese chit.  Cash in chits per your current point standing for the commodity of choice.)  Brilliant rule that makes it much more fun (for the unlucky) and faster (things get built quicker.)
Settlers, it's a classic. One of my gateway games, lots of good decisions. The randomness of the dice and the bandit make it a more lively game than some other Euros. I would play it anytime.
I love this game. It's almost perfect. The only reason it doesn't get a 9 is because Seafarers of Catan is out.
A simple but interesting game. Each play is different because the board changes.
IMO very easy and good game
Still love this game.  Yeah, it wears a little but never really gets old.
My first eurogame, this short and sweet gem will always have a place in my heart and on my shelf.
Seems to work fine as a 2 player game
Great gateway game. I do not agree with the argument that it is past its prime -- the simple, engaging mechanics have held up to the test of time.
가족게임 난이도지만 길막, 트레이드 등 맘 상할 요소가 있어 가족게임으로 아주 좋지는 않다. 시대의 명작. 지금은 평작.

Excellent game, relatively short compared to others i've played (takes about 90 minutes though i have played a speed game where we finished open box to close box in about 15 minutes) very easy to learn and probably my favorite game out there

I've gotta raise the rating a little bit on this after playing again last night. Everybody I introduce it to  really gets hooked. And I always seem to have fun. It's the game I play the most. Like many, this was my intro into Euros.
A lot of fun.  Intelligent placement of your starting settlements is vital.

This is a funny kind of game after you play a lot of it. Most of the decisions during the game are pretty obvious. You build what you can, you trade to build what you almost can. The initial placement seems to be the game. It's pretty interesting and usually decides the game. The rest of the game plays out pretty automatically and is just there to resolve who played the best in the placement phase. Still, I like it.

El juego para comenzar en esto por antonomasia. Un derroche de diversión perfecto para engancharse a este vicio. Lo peor, la dependencia de la suerte. Lo mejor, que es imposible no divertirse y que hay muchísima interactividad.
Great with 4, ok with 3. What more needs to be said besides it is great fun?!
A fun game, deserving of it's classic status.
This is my first "real" board game since I was a teenager.  So far, my wife and I both love it!  She is not a hardcore gamer, but I am hoping to become one.
Played this at a friends.. I liked it.. It was different, lots of replayability, good social game, appeals to the hardcore and casual gamer.
The game that opened the floodgates still stands up.
Light enought to be played anytime.

Basic settlers, since i found the cities and knights expansion we rarely play this any more.  It was my in-laws favorite for about two years till we introduced them to Ticket to Ride.  I have probably played near a 500 games of this and would still play today if you yanked it out. 30-45 mins with people who know what they are doing.  A great game.

This was for me my gateway into German boardgames (as it was for seemingly everyone else) Lots of luck is involved and the game itself can be really frustrating when things are going your way but its still a favorite. Played this game 5 or 6 more times this year and liked it more than ever.

Everyone just seems to love this game. And for good reason. It is fun. Deep enough for serious gamers and with enough luck for casual gamers. Play this and you may never play monopoly and its like again.  The Seafarers expansion is enjoyable and easy to add on. The cities and knights expansion has a ton of rules, adding to an already large set, and is not recommended for the not-so-serious gamer group.   The 5-6 player expansions are nice because they allow for a bigger party, but the game tends to slow down too much for our tastes with the higher number of players. It seems like eons between turns. I would recommend keeping it to 3 or 4 players.
It's fun to trade! Good player interaction. Nice to play with 4 players. Luck is a major factor here, so minimizing dice result dependance is the key!

3rd real boardgame I bought (13/01/05). We still love it, and it's first in the suitcase to take on holiday. Stupid sheep!  As for Seafarers - Makes sheep seem less boring. A good expansion without making the game too long. Still "Fed up with breeek"! Gold not too overpowering
Have just been bitten by the Settlers bug... I am playing 1-2 games a day over at asobrain.com and have just bought the new box set.
This has been a really fun game.  I've played it many times with my kids, the last time including my 8 year old daughter (who is now 11).  A winner!
Our first game! Got us into gaming. Must have.
easy to learn and fun to play
Among equal players, the luck of the dice is more common.  I like that there are multiple routes to victory.  It does take a few plays to recognize which route to take based on one's starting setup.
You need to fix the dice randomness by playing with cards instead (from 2 to 12 with correct probability).

The game that introduced me and many others to Euro games.  I still think it is a very good negotiation and trading game.  Soem may say luck plays to big a factor, but if that is so I must be very lucky because I am consistently very close to winning the game.  That is if I don't win because I win a good percentage of the time.
Enjoyable game to build and expand (unless blocked out too early) and the trading aspect is always lively.

A must own classic game, a game that will change the way you look at board games.  Having purchased the event cards has re-invigorated my passion for this game.   I now play this infrequently and with just the dice but when I do it is just a pure game experience. Love it.
I need to play this more often. Back when I only owned a dozen games, this got played once a week, probably.
My first eurogame - like most people
Tons of plays, and yet we keep coming back for more.  This is still the game we bring out when introducing new "victims" to the world of Eurogaming

1/16/11: I've been playing this a lot lately because my six year old son really enjoys it.  He doesn't get the nuances of balancing probabilities, and his trades are often very lopsided (I'll give you three ore for your sheep).  But we have fun, and I'm reminded of what a great, replayable game this is.
A classical, and the game that reintroduced me to the joy of boardgames. SoC has a nice balance between strategy and luck. The idea of the dynamic board makes every game unique.
I like it. It is fun. It got me started.

This game is pretty cool. I like the variable set up best as it adds some randomness to the game.  The beginner set up ensures a balanced game, and id a good way to cut your teeth.  However, the true nature of the trading aspect of the game do not become clear until the resources are not as evenly balanced.  Two play variation for base set works very nicely.
Enjoyed it on the first play.   The luck and trading part of the game are fun for a change from some of the other "Euro" games in our collection.
A little heavy on luck but still a very fun game if you don't take it too seriously. The trading aspect really adds to the game.
A classic game, easy to learn and quick to play.  A great introduction to games for new players.
I really enjoy this game. Sometimes the randomness can be a little frustrating, but I think it balances out when you have more players.
I've played this game many, many times. It has somewhat worn thin as there are so many other great games to play. I still feel however, that it is an all around brilliant game.
A must have classic. Great player interaction.
I'm not a huge fan of open trading games but you have to admit this is a fun gam to play. I usually misplay my initial settlements and I become a non-entity quickly but I have hope that I'll improve.
This is another game which got me back into gaming and has me picking up a lot of its expansions.  It's always fun and different, however doesn't receive a 10 due to some luck factor.
Very interesting game, fun to play, lot of parts to manage though. The possibility of expansions is intriguing, and the trading adds a level of diplomacy to it.
Fun for gamers and non-gamers alike.
So much fun, only pity is that it really is a 3+ player game...
Got the version where the orange wasn't that different from the red. Shiny nail polish with glittery bits is your friend.

It's been a while since I've played this. Although I got to show my girlfriend and her daughter this one recently. To quote her "Are you really going to explain a game to us this late at night?!?" "YES!" After a games explanation and a few turns and setup - the game actually went really smoothly and while we wanted to finish, it was getting late.

Terrific game! When we first bought it we played like 20 times per week (and that was 4 years back). Great luck/strategy combination, a must-have for every gamer (unless you don't like games without war conflict)
A classic.  A fairly easy game to teach to skeptical friends or family.  I love the variable board concept making each game unique.  It is just plain fun to play!

What a fun game.  I have taught Settlers to at least 20 people by now, and every one of them (except, inexplicably, my wife) has asked to play again.  It's generally not my go-to game any more, but I still play regularly on Xbox Live and have a great time.

The first hit. The maryjuwonna of the german gaming world (though i must protest that i vehemently disagree that the bud is a gateway drug but that is neither here nor there). I'm actually still not tired of this game..
I remember playing this back in '96, when Mayfair had first released it. It was a hoot then and remains fun today.
A great social game.  Setup time has a bad rep.
Category - Civilisation Mechanics - Trading, Modular Board, Dice Rolling  Spiel Des Jahres - 1995  Expanded With Cities And Knights Of Catan Event Cards Atlantis
I am starting to buy into all the hype.  The more I play the more it grows on me.  I just bought an expansion so that is a good sign.
A little bit dice lucky loaded, but there are enough elements to make it a fun game. Trading, racing for the good new build locations, and not to mention the late-game all versus one coalitions.

I wish I had discovered this game when it first came out.  It probably would have kept me ground in the hobby during all those years I took off.  This is a solid game that makes for a decent, but slightly complex, gateway game for non-gamers.  While I prefer Starfarers over this game, this one has the options to play with quite a few variants, most of which I have not tested out.
The classic Euro-break-out game that introduced a lot of Americans to euro gaming.  It has aged well, and is still a good play.

Catan was my introduction to Euro games (I'm such a cliche) and I played ten billion games of it before I learned there was a whole genre of other games like it. I think that Catan has been eclipsed by lots of other games for me, but it'll always have a place in my heart.  WOOD FOR SHEEP
Yeah, Settlers!  This is the game that re-ignited my addiction to games as an adult.

The classic game that introduced us to German games. Roll dice, generate resources, trade, build settlements or cities, use discovery cards. Great game, and despite the dice rolling has different paths to victory.
The game that got me hooked.  Unfortunately, I have a hard time getting this one back on the table.
Replaced by 15th Anniv. Edition and gifted along with the 5-6 player expansion to a friend to spread the Catan love.
Great gateway game. Actually just a great game

As much as I like chrome and extra features (C&K here), playing this game plain is still a great way to spend time with people.  Maybe a little hard for a totally new person to understand how to do well, but learning how to play is possible for anyone.  And the randomness of the dice covers up any possible ego bruising as the new person learns to do better.  Everyone would always have won that one game if they had just rolled that 5 or 6 or 8 or 9.

Started the Euro Game love for me.  I don't care that it has become "trendy" to dump on Settlers; I still love it.  I'm aware of the "stop trading with the leader", the "stuck in a corner", and other "problems".  But we seem to see that as part of the challenge, an obvious part of the game.  Some randomness.  Some trading.  Some strategic building.  Lots of good stuff here.
Ah, this started it all for me, euro-wise.  Only a few plays?  Believe me, there have been many more.  They generally get logged under Seafarer, since I almosy never play F2F without that expansion.
Always good for a game. Always fun.  Always popular with non gamers.
A good game :) as others say "good hook for the hobby"
A good game, but sometimes the dice are against me!
That's one of the few games with large luck factor that I really like and will not turn down a proposition to play.
Great game to get non-gamers into gaming. After so many plays it kinda becomes scripted. I think the sheen came off and I'm just over this one. Heavier games are on my mind latley.
Excellent Game. Even better with Cities & Knights expansion.
Great lightweight substitute to civilization-like games for when you are only 3-4 players. Perfect gateway game for old and new board gamers alike.

A good solid game. I'm probably the 15th million person to say it... but it definitely is a very good "gateway" style game. There is the good old VP chase common to hundreds of other Euro games but there's also multiple paths to victory, trading, frustration and elation in the dice rolls, road/city building and a variable modular board which makes for a slightly different game each time. All in all a very good game... not quite great because it's still a bit too easy to be hosed by the dice no matter how hard you try to trade and negotiate your way out of the hole you are in when that damn robber is sitting on your production hex.  Above everything else this game produces fun sessions with a lot of chatter and banter. Lot's of "Why are you picking on me?" and "Move the robber there to stop him from getting the sheep he needs" type of conversations. Just for the level of interaction the game provides its worthy of its status as a good solid family game that can be played for fun without much concern who wins or loses.
Seminal game - all that can be said.

The classic "gateway drug" of board games.  Almost everybody will enjoy this game.  I prefer to play it with either Seafarer or Cities and Knights included.   I don't like playing settlers with more than 4 people, and I don't own the 5-6 expansions.
Classic that has stood the test of time for me.  Haven't gotten board of it yet.
Easy enough for non-competitive gamers, yet challenging enough for gamers, due to changing board and/or strategies.
A classic that I came upon rather late and still find it fun.  The "roll the dice and hope for goods" mechanic is unbelievably appealing.
One of the great ones.  I do like it with the Cities and Knights expansion better.
The first Eurogame I ever tried, and while the amount of times I have played this has caused me to become somewhat tired with it, I will always look at it as sort of a first love.
Recently had to up this from a 7 to an 8 because of some great sessions. A classic that I'm finally giving the playing time it deserves.

After about a 10 year break from Settlers I've recently introduced this classic Euro to a group who have never played it. Wow! I'd forgotten how much fun this one is and how perfect a game it is to introduce people to the world of board games beyond the scope of what you can get at Wal-Mart or other big box stores.
I'd love to find more people to play Catan with.

Acquired around 1997, I have a 1st edition Mayfair so it doesn't match any of the 3rd edition expansions. Played only thrice in 2007. Total number of plays > 200. Still enjoyable, although I don't enjoy the metagaming aspect when it gets ugly.

My 10-13 year olds really like this game.  It is fun to play but takes some time to set up.  Always enjoyable except when you get picked on with the robber.  (I would rather lose then get stuck with the robber 67% of the time...)
Pretty good game.  I'd like to check out Cities and Knights to mitigate some of the brutal luck swings.  Dec 2013 - after playing c&k, I think base set alone is more my thing.

I liked it in the beginning. This was my first gateway game. After a while I got a bit tired of the luck of the dice. Event cards help the dice variability. I would recommend it highly. The fish addition is also a good investment. It makes the beach properties more desirable.
Great fun, gets better with C&K but even the seafarers expansion adds alot.

It's a fantastic 3 player game, which is pretty rare. Has been one of my all-time favorites, and was definitely my gateway game. The shine has come off, but I'll still play it with good friends. Seafarers and Cities & Knights are both really good expansions. I'd be interested to try out the others, but probably not enough to actually do so.
Played it quite a bit for many yrs (including magic and church expansions).  Not so much anymore (Caylus and Puerto Rico have taken over), but pull it out quarterly for a spin.

A German friend of mine translated Die Siedler von Catan into English for me. It was my introduction into German games, and I love it!  A great game in that *most* of the time everyone comes close to winning (7-9 points).  Very effective in getting people excited about games, although newer options like Ticket to Ride mean I rarely get this to the table any more.
This is the game that got me hooked!

This was my gateway game and I've been a board game collector since. Its probably one of the best gateway games out there. Noobs and experienced players can all sit down and have an enjoyable time over a game of settlers! This one gets a slight ratings increase because it is the best game to introduce to non-gamers and get them hooked on this lifelong hobby!
A classic, just the right balance of luck and strategy to make an engaging social game.
Vanilla catan is fun but want to try together with traders and barbarians to see how much more fun it can be.
This is one of our standard games. It's fun, but when you have played it a few hundred times over the years it starts to become slightly boring of course.

I'm still able to rate this as a classic (duh) despite the fact that we had the worst game EVER of this last night (seven special cards were bought before the first road of the game was built!)  Never seems to get old.
I love the number of solid player vaiants that have emerged and the ability to find games online.
Kosmos - New German Version (plastic settlement, city, and road pieces)
It's solid, but I think it'd get a little boring after a while.  I do, however, think it's a great game with its expansions.  Pretty fun, and easy to learn!
Do I still enjoy Settlers? Oh, yes.. yes I do.  Maybe the randomness would bother me in a longer game, but Settlers is short and I know which resources to go after...
One of my favorite games.  Provides for a great combination of playing styles and strategies, meaning that all sorts of people can play.
The game that brought me back into gaming after a long hiatus.
I am always happy to play this one. An appealing theme, resource management, seeing your principality grow.

Fun game with 3 players or 4.  Ideal moves evaporate quickly, and you are left with making the best of what's available.  Good trade off of benefiting yourself vs. messing with another player.  Can suffer from pick on the leader though, so if you don't like that, then be forewarned.
One of my all time favourite games. I enjoy how it can be played in an hour or so. The game can also be played by a range of ages and skill levels. Great!
never actually played "Settlers" since we have "Seafarers" and the base seemed too...basic.

This is a classic game, but one that holds up very well to repeated playing, at least for me.  There's so much to love about the simplicity of this game.  Its so easy to teach, so easy to play, and yet it holds my interest.  That being said, I immediately bought the Seafarers expansion and can't imagine playing without it.  I feel like the game might eventually go stale on its own.  However, with the endless scenarios that Seafarers (and now Das Buch) provides, I don't think I'll ever turn down a game of this.
Seeking sheep, trading wheat? If you do not own this game, how will you ever know what that means?
Still one of the best games to introduce your friends mind to board games of all kinds. 12 Plays
My introduction to German board games - this game is great.  Admittedly I don't play the base game alone anymore unless I'm teaching new folks though.

Newbies who think they've graduated to "real" board games love to denigrate this game for some reason, but it's really pretty unique if you look at it in the context of most other euros. It can drag a little, but overall I think this game still holds up and is fun to play.

The first euro game I bought.  I use this game to get people into gaming.  It is a very fun game.  Sometimes the luck can get a little annoying.  There is also a runaway leader problem with the rich becoming richer.
The clasic trading game that seems to be everyone's first Eurogame. I take my Settlers plain with no expansions.

Picked this up to suck my daughters into gaming. Really enjoy it, as I like games where you build an empire of some sort. Will probably get the Seafarers expansion and am planning to suck some co-workers into playing.
So, this was an awesome game for quite a while, but it does tend to lose its appeal after repeated play.  Don't get me wrong, I love the game, but I came to the place where it was time to move on.
With just the base game, this is very enjoyable 3 player
Excellent game if you have at least four.
Great game.  Never tire of this one.
Still a great game that I love to play, but it is getting harder to get it to the table with so many great medium weight games being released.
Seafarer expansion good too. Am starting to get addicted to this now I've found an online version.
I played hundred of times. Thousand maybe.  Subcortical. But it's so easy to play, to explain others, it's almost miracle.
Classic game. Great fun for all family. More players = more fun.
Gran juego, sin duda....le subire la nota seguro...luego a luego, luego a luego YA.
One of the two games that brought me back to board gaming. Very enjoyable and addictive.
Good game but not the classic that it is touted as.
I'm with the norm, love this game
Timeless, but I don't look forward to it like I used to.

A great example of the differences between skill with controlling randomness and luck with trusting to randomness.  (A skill relying player will almost always beat a luck relying player.) The trick is not to always go for the best odds (as a 2d6 curve is rather flat), but to understand why lesser odds may be a better build (to spread numbers for instance).  The game holds up much better than so much flawed stuff with great production coming out 20 years later.
A classic that I was introduced to in 2004. Was certainly one 3  games that got me hooked on board gaming
Very cool and unique game.  An everchanging board keeps the game from ever being static although chance plays a big factor through all the dice rolling.  This is a classic!!!
Settlers and M:TG got me into gaming.
This is where it all started for me. Always a good time and I usually pull this out to get more people into playing board games.
Wonderful mechanics which come together almost too perfectly.

Well thought out and based on a good idea. But over time I grow tired of the amount of luck involved and the rating steadily declines. Wondering if I will ever play again with all the wonderful games on the market and in my collection...gathering dust...need to have more...

This game can be brutal if you have bad luck at the beginning or you chose poorly at the beginning.  This is a love-hate game in that some games can be quite exciting but if someone gets rolling it can be very hard to catch up.

Great game, no doubt. All the players are kept involved continously for all the game, but too much dice means to me too much luck... for the others! Update (vote raised): I admit my hate for it, I can't stand my bad luck with dice (if I've put my towns on 8 and 6, rest assured that a lot of 2 and 12 will be the dice response), but I can't refuse a play... *SOB!*

Just played twice todayt 23th January 2009 with 3 new game players. I won the first, Lost the second. I'm lowering the game rating from a 9 to a 8. The second game, even that I had 2 towns near a 10 dice, I NEVER got a 10. No one actualy did. It was just ,wait for my turn, Roll an 8, next. I manage to do like 2 roads, 1 town... another player just bought Development Cards, actualy we ran out of those. So besites the placement of the hexes, the game can be very dull.
Its best feature is its simplicity (maybe the best 'gateway' game ever created), and it is a very good game overall.

Build roads and houses with your materials to gain more chances to get more materials which which to build more roads and houses. An interesting design, and great availability. An all-time favourite, but has gone down to an 8 mostly due to exposure to other games.

Rules Complexity: :star::halfstar::nostar::nostar::nostar: Strategic Depth: :star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: Luck Factor :star::star::nostar::nostar::nostar: Negotiation Factor: :star::star::star::star::nostar: Amount of Downtime: :halfstar::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar: Fiddliness: :halfstar::nostar::nostar::nostar::nostar: Replayability: :star::star::star::star::nostar: Component Quality: :star::star::star::star::nostar: Player Interaction: :star::star::star::star::nostar: "Take That" Conflict: :star::halfstar::nostar::nostar::nostar:  The game that got me started!  Still as good as ever.
A fun family game. Everyone can learn to play this and has a chance to win.
One of the first proper board games I played.

10/11/99 Bought. I own the English third edition from Mayfair.   11/17/09 I finally played using the fourth edition. And... I think the graphics are terrible. Especially the port icons being so tiny. One third the size of the ones in the 3rd edition, and hard to tell apart from across the table. Some of the hill hexes were throwing us old hands off. They had so much green in them we weren't sure whether they were hills (producing brick) or meadows (producing wool). It seems the graphics guy decided to make every hex unique. Well, that's all fine and good if you're creating art. But a game must be functional above all else. And its very difficult to sweep the 4th ed. board with your eye and get a grasp of what is what without a lot of pausing to squint at stuff. Could Mayfair leave well enough alone? Nooooo.  02/21/17 Gamed with the 4th edition again plus its 5/6 player expansion. Same comments.   I'll let my initial rating stand, as its for my 3rd edition. But if I owned the 4th edition I'd rate Settlers a 5 for the ridiculous graphics.   03/05/16 A three-player game with the English 5th edition. The graphics were *much* better than the 4th edition. I'm not a fan of the rule changes concerning VP card play after the game is over and mixed trading & building. I feel its "dumbs down" the game. I also think taking "The Settlers of" off the box is arrogant and stupid. If I owned this version I'd rate it a 7.5.
TOP 50 GAME, the Godfather of Euro games.. if you don't know this, it's back to BG school!

Gets a little boring after a while.  If the rolls aren't going your way there isn't much that you can do about it.  Benefits greatly by that addition of the Cities and Knights expansion afterwhich I would give it a 10.
I like it best when we get a megaboard!

Sometimes rather enjoyable game. Still don't like the great amount of luck involved... My throws just suck, can't fix that.  Edit: A compact game which is a lot of fun despite its luck-driven gameplay. Still nice to play this after all these years.
1 exemplaire de la deuxième édition Mayfair  2 exemplaire de la première édition Mayfair

Still the best resource management game out there.  Nice simple rules balancing trading, careful planning, luck and skullduggery (will you stop moving the robbers onto my best producing land!).  Best played with 4 people to get the maximum out of the trading, with enough variety in set up to ensure that no two games are the same.  So much fun that I confess to huying the Â£250 special edition which has pride of place in its ornamental chest :o)

This is the bread & butter game for much of my gaming circle.  It is almost perfect.  Skill typically wins, but there is always a chance to get lucky.  Even a moderately skilled player has a chance to win despite better players at the table, which makes it fun and competitive for all.  And the board changes every game, so there is no preset optimal build.  Add in the fact that you can trade, you can take hostile action with the robber and that the game punishes hoarding and it is just really well done.

Overall I think this is a terrific game and a fun way to kill some time by engaging in some friendly back-stabbing. There are a few tiny flaws that occasionally get in the way of the game for me, but in general I think the design allows for a nice balance between luck and strategy. And I think luck is as important a part of gameplay as strategy, so I appreciate the attention to balance in games like this.   The highlights of the game for me are the player interaction (through trading and "unholy alliances") and the resource management. Thinks like the "Longest Road" and "Largest Army" also provide some flexibility to strategy, and reward players for doing more than just building up settlements and cities. Building roads and buying soldiers are an important part of the game, but I think those added bonuses give the game some extra punch. All in all I think the point system is very flexible and allows for players to pursue a variety of strategies, most of which will remain viable for the entire game.   The only thing I don't like about the game is the way that resource tiles are assigned fixed numbers for dice rolling. I can't tell you how many games have become once sided slaughterfests because the dice refuse to roll anything other than five or ten (and it's always five or ten, never six or eight). In most games I've played one resource will remain scare due to the number system, which is fine and indeed a part of the game, but occasionally a "sheep tyrant" will emerge and destroy us all. When the game takes on a sense of inevitability it becomes a lot less entertaining and rewarding.
I love this game, even though I always lose (I did win the very first time I played, but we give newbies some extra advantages on their first time playing this game, so that doesn't really count).

Maybe a little nostalgia here, but it's still so classic and great fun.

The rules for that are up on my web site, as well as a variant using the pieces from Entdecker (they're also uploaded here).

But it still holds a special place in my heart, and I have not found a game with so much tension and cut-throat negotiations, even though it is very random.  I'm still downgrading this from a 10->8 though, simply because it's not something I'd play given the choice.

Additionally, I think it plays better with 4 than with 3, because there are more people involved, more numbers being rolled, and more trading going on.  In short, it has more possibilities. It's common for gamers to sour on Settlers but its ability to get new people into the hobby can't be underrated. I think the reason it's proven so enduringly popular is its familiarity to non-gamers. Like Monopoly, you roll two dice at the start of your turn and do what they say. Like Monopoly you try to build houses to enable you to gather more resources. Like Monopoly you haggle and trade with other players to try and make up sets. And compared to Monopoly, the commonly-made gamer complaint that you can be hosed by unlucky placement and dice rolls pales into insigificance - at least you can't be eliminated!   When I first played Settlers, I was blown away by how many clever things it does compared to the 'classic' games I knew: properly makes use of probability; continuously moves towards a conclusion; keeps everyone involved when it's not their turn. Sure I can see some of its weaknesses now, and it's a game that I don't really play with gamers. But I'll happily pull it out any time with my family - my non-gamer sister and her husband adore it.

It really should have a 10, it's the one that started it all for me and my group of addicted friends. I must have introduced this game to dozens of people and only had a couple of negative reactions. But now, after intensive play, only comes out when there are newbies.

Now that I've acquired and played many more games poor old Catan has kind of been left behind.  Still, for sheer nostalgia alone I still give this game an 8.

Truly one of the best gateway games ever.  Base game can get old after a few dozen plays and the dice can sometimes be frustrating.  Game can be obnoxious if you get screwed early by the starting placement.  Few games are as dependent on the starting placement as Settlers, which can hinder newbies who try to pick up the game as it goes.  There is a lot more tension, conflict, and interaction than you would expect.  A classic I don't think will be replaced.
