The 800-pound gorilla of board games!  I really can't say much bad about Settlers.  The dice-rolling doesn't overshadow the deeper, more strategic nature of the game.  The random layout of the tiles (at setup) and the random arrangement of the outside trading bonuses provides tons of replay potential.  The development cards are a nice mechanism for sprucing up gameplay and provide more options.  My only criticism is that Settlers isn't very heavy/deep and I tend to prefer heavier/deeper games.  It falls into that nebulous middle category – not too heavy and not too light.  But it's Settlers and it's fun and I hope I get to play more games of it in the future.  And no Settlers review would be complete without the obligatory "I've got wood for sheep."  There, I said it.  Happy?

Klaus Teuber; In Settlers of Catan, players try to be the dominant force on the island of Catan by building settlements, cities, and roads. On each turn dice are rolled to determine the current production on the island. Players collect raw materials to build up their civilizations to gain enough victory points to win the game. This game is a Spiel des Jahres (German game of the year, 1995) winner, primarily because of its amazing ability to appeal to non-gamers and gamers alike. Die Siedler von Catan was originally published by Kosmos and has gone through multiple editions. It was licensed by Mayfair and has undergone at least 4 editions as Settlers of Catan. It has also been re-published in a travel edition by Kosmos and in yet a different edition for Japan/Asia, Settlers of Catan : Rockman Edition. Settlers of Catan is the original game in the Catan Series. Expanded by: The Seafarers of Catan, The Cities and Knights of Catan, 5-6 Player Expansion.

Only played once so far.  Wow, fun game!  It took close to 3 hours, which is a little on the long side, but I assume we will get quicker with experience. Also played a bumch of times on line now.  I'm debating bumping the rating up to 9 now that I've played a whole bunch of games.
Mayfair Games Third Edition 1997.  Everything in excellent condition.  Very slight shelf wear.
One of the first I owned.
Based on my online play this game is great. I just wish I could convince a couple of actual humans to try playing it with me on an actual board.
Great trading mechanic. Room for plenty of negotiating. I'm not against a bit of a luck element in my games. Rulebook could be laid out more straightforwardly though.

We never play this without the Seafarers and Cities & Knights expansions.  We also use the event deck rather than the original dice... my eldest son hurled the dice into our wood-burning furnace in a fit of pique after an evening during which 10 became the new 6.
Ah the classic gateway game.  Still great after all these years and a game my wife and I introduced to her folks that they fell in love with. Love this game.

Perfect blend of strategy and chance. While I can sympathize with those who say there is too much randomness here, I have consistently seen strong players win by positioning themselves to take advantage of probability. Mitigating the risks of chance is a big part of this game. Brilliant in its accessibility and broad appeal.  EDIT: After playing a few more times with casual gamers, I'm reducing the grade to an 8. The set up and site selection, unless you use a pre-set configuration, really does set some at a severe disadvantage. While I don't mind at all the randomness of the dice roll, it is never fun when you don't feel you have much of a chance from turn one, which can happen in this game. Also, I find that getting to that last victory point or two can be painfully slow. I usually target a number a point or two lower than recommended.
Gateway game - all non-gaming friends get to play this first.
I recommend it only with 4 players. With 3, there are not enough interactivity.
A classic in its own right. I enjoy it because it is pretty relaxing but manages to keep my attention at the same time. I can see why this started the boom in board gaming.
It was nice for 3 players. Should be better with 4!
A long-time favorite, I originally learned to play it with the dutch edition. Still feels odd to me not to get a card tagged "Langste handelsroute" when I get the longest road.

I would rate it a 9 but in two recent games I got shut out of the competition by some spectacularly unlucky roles made me knock it down.  The fact that I could go 16 player turns without a resource when I was on the seven different numbers in one game and how the table could roll 6 on more than seventy-five percent of rolls leaving myself as the only player to not get rich in the other was just astounding.  And it was two different copies of the game so weighted dice is out.
The Daddy, I suppose. Pales now, but if you haven't played it, have a go.

This game went over great with my family who only had a history of playing Monopoly, Life and Risk.  It's a really fun game where you are engaged even on your opponent's turns it has high replayability and the rules aren't hard to swallow.  Great for 3 players! (In my experience having 4 players makes the game slower and much harder to play your pieces.)
I really enjoy this game, though I rarely feel as though my actions have an impact on the outcome.  I find non-gamers really take to this one with ease.
I actually made my own 3d version of this game.  The pictures are around here somewhere

The classic that introduced me to Euros.  While I feel like I've exhausted its strategic depth at this point, it's still my go-to game for newbies.  I've had better success with snaring novices with Catan than with Carcassonne.
I really enjoy this game.  Played with an 8 and 10 year old kid and they picked it up very quickly and did well.  This is a fantastic family game.  Lots of fun.
Great game... brought me back to board games after a long absence.
Introduced by friends, always enjoy playing this.
Another good lite euro, that can be played with non gaming friends and family.
Another classic, what can I say?  Perfectly balanced, easy to learn hard to master.
always a great game with 4 players! still too much luck involved
SdJ 1995. The game that started it all - already a classic. excellent introductory game. very user friendly, but flawed trading system, makes it heavy initial position/dice dependent

What's there to say? Usually about 90% of my family members roll their eyes when I bring a game to a family night, except for this one, which everyone loves. I find it a bit too lengthy for what it is, but the bargaining element is of course a lot of fun, interaction-wise.

Gateway standard, I find 3rd edition to have overall slightly better production values than this 4th edition.  Wish I'd have bought that version, instead.  I never get tired of this game, but I still prefer Germany or Canaan overall.

This is the gateway drug of board games. Good for addicting those who don't know that board games include things other than Clue, Chutes and Ladders, and Candy Land. Also good for a quick play now and again.
Third edition Mayfair version for trade.
Its a classic for a reason.  The high interactivity between players makes this game worth your time.
I am a board game geek addict because of this, and will never regret it.  Owned: 5-6 players extension.  owned 15th Anniversary Ed. With frenemies expansion.
I always have fun with this game.  I like the player interaction.
Brilliant gateway. Right dose of luck, new players stand a chance yet rewards skilled play. Will only play with tournament rules though, normal start lengthens the game unnecessarily.
Wow, got me back into board games!
First Euro game I played, and I have played it tons since then.  Always fun when we play it, despite its simplicity.

I have Catan to thank for getting me into board games, and for that reason, it will always be a favorite.   This game appeals both to gamers(yet can a bit too easily turn them off due to the high % of luck) and non-gamers.  I've played this game over 1,500 times(mostly online).  No other game has caught me up quite like this one.. until Agricola.

If I can only name one game as boardgame classic, the vote will DEFINITELY go for this game. Not necessarily be the most compact/fun/tricky or whatsoever, game, Settlers is the game you should at least played once and I gurantee you are willing to play it again and again
First Euro game I played, I like it a lot but much better with Cities and Knights expansion.
This was a 10 but played to many times and the effect has worn off a bit
06/08/2008  El primer juego junto a Carcassonne que me incito a la compra compulsiva xD Decir que el juego me gusta mucho, aunque no pueda jugarlo mucho n_n'
Love this game.  One of my very favorites.

This is one of the few games that I can get my wife to play with me at almost anytime.  Definitely more fun with more people.  It's simple enough that my 5, 7, 9, and 10 year old can play it together.
The staple of any gamer's diet. Raise your hand if you name your sheep?
Very good game, especially for people who have never tried playing board games. Playable with very good company!
I Really enjoy this game! We dont play it enough!  Hard to play games like this when you only play games once a week and you have hundreds of games to chose from!  Hehe

Very fun game!  Very different each time you play.  Multiple ways to get the 10 points needed to win.  Some luck is involved, but if you have bad luck you still have a fighting chance to win (or at least not get blown away).

To me, Settlers of Catan is the best game ever made. The base game is just what the name says: a basic game, originally designed way more complex. As it is, it is already a lot of fun. The varying game setup takes care for fun for quite a while. But the real strength of Settlers lies in its multiple expansion.  Moreover, Settlers provides a wonderful platform to create own scenarios, and this is where the real fun starts. Settlers is the type of game that you don't get tired of. If you do, just vary it and it is an entirely new game. Up to now, I haven't met anyone who doesn't like it.
Great for non-gamers. Perhaps too much decided in the initial placement, but for a "gateway" quite a deep title. A good deal of "take that!" as well, which keeps the war-gamers happy.
I played it on the 360 and played it a ton. Bought the analog version out of respect
I love the modular board, but I like the the copper hex and the Stones to Jerusalem feature of Settlers of Canaan better, and for those two reasons I enjoy Canaan just THAT much more.
Z - Great game that we both fancy, definitely look forward to playing this one when it is available.   Downsides are you cannot play it with two people and someone usually gets left in the dust.
Great game. Like many this is what got me into the hobby. To me it's best when played with friends.
So many sheepies! Getting sick of it now.. Time for a long break

not much more to say about this game.  it's great fun.  the best strategy may not always win but that's what makes it appealing across a broader range of people.  looking for some variation beyond settlers is what brought me to bgg

Played many times, mostly with Cities and Knights. This is in large part just a roll and go (Row and go for you Obama supporters) The thing that makes this game so good is everyone is involved, or can be involved in every player turn. In other words, very little down time. It does have some luck involved with the dice rowing...er...rolling but you have so much fun it does not matter.
Just a classic gameplay. Trade, build and conquer. The map isn't great. I like the sea.

This one gets and 8 simply because almost anyone will play this game at anytime, and although there are many more games I would prefer to play on any given day, this one I am happy to play if no one can agree on another.
Played this game a ton in college.  Group was on the third set of tiles when I graduated.
Oh well, an 8 for old days' sake. I've played many memorable games, had quite some fun. Especially with 5 or 6 players and the seafarers or cities and knights expansions.

Fun but it can get a little blase if you have built up a comfortable position and/or are self-sufficient - but of course, this doesn't happen often. Can also be frustrating if you have set up positions in 6s and 8s but the laws of probability are just not working out! (just my 2 cents)
The original gateway game for our group.  We prefer it with cities and knights, and find the only downfall of the 10th Anniversary version is that it only plays 3-4 people.

Never gets old. But for a "10" it has too much dice rolling.  Especially I like the meta-gaming. Setting trade-values for certain ressources, intrigueing against the leader or up-coming players etc. Pulling the strings is great with Settlers. :)
Once this was an easy 10. After 300+ plays I only pull this one out for non gamers
I have played this for years and recently my wife bought me the newest version of this game.  I like the new graphics on the tiles and the board-frame.

Very first game I played that got me into this new hobby, aside from the games you get at Target (Scategories, Yahtzee, etc...) Fun but not real games compared to what I have recently been introduced to.

My first impression is: this is the best family game in 20 years and that's before I even knew about BGG! After my eyes have been opened wide by BGG, I would still say this' the best family game in 20 years (over the likes of Monopoly, Scrabble, Risk) but my attention was diverted to those of Puerto Rico, Twilight Imperium III, and Android... Thus I brought down my grading for Catan to 8 from 10 as I would like to try out the others first (and the BGG grading is based on willingness to play). But my impression remained the same for Catan: it's the best family game in 20 years!
Fantastic game, brought me back into the world of gaming.

Expansions: The Settlers of Catan: 5-6 Player Extension  Catan: Seafarers Catan: Seafarers - 5-6 Player Extension  Catan: Cities & Knights Catan: Cities & Knights - 5-6 Player Extension  Catan: Traders & Barbarians Catan: Traders & Barbarians: 5-6 Player Extension  Catan: Event Cards The Settlers of Catan: The Fishermen of Catan The Settlers of Catan: The Great River

If I recorded plays for games, this would be close to number one.  This game pleases me, though I'm a little burned out on it these days.  The components look nice and the game board changes.  I get into building things and collecting cards and often lost sight of the victory points.
Wife and 11 year old son like to play. Good enough for me.   Gerry
have it on my souped up xbox
My gateway into real board games.  There's no going back now.  I have played many more games than this, but it was way before we started tracking our played games, plus many on the 360.

Outstanding game! It's just as good for first time gamers as it is for long time geeks. Luck and skill are very nicely balanced which means that even when playing against total beginners you aren't guaranteed victory.

We enjoy it, although my step-dad thought that the initial placement was everything and couldn't get him to try it again.  We really need to get this back on the table.  And now we have, although with a newer player.

Finally, a game I can get my wife and friends to play.  I certainly understand that some may get a bit bored with this over 100s of plays, but for me, playing relatively infrequently, I am assured of having a great, social time with this.

Love the game for what it did and who it brought to my gaming circle. Like the islands version better than just the normal setup. I still play it once a year just for memories, but too much luck to be higher.
Always good for introducing non gamers to eurogames. Elegant, addictive. A rare game that uses dice and trading in a positive way.
How can you not like this classic "gateway" game?

This game got me started.  Great game, good amount of stratagy, but after a few plays, I wanted more strategy, more options, and just more depth all together.  However I will never turn down a play of the basic settlers..its that good.
2-6 players. Nearly classic, this is the sandby for most modern table top board gamers. Pretty easy rules, randomly generated board, lots of player-to-player interaction.

If you are only considering the game design and the ratio of luck to strategy, there are definitely better games than this. However, I have more memories of awesome times I have had playing this game than with any other game. It is very much dependent on the people playing, as I had played games that were not much fun because the players played too seriously or one player accepted pretty much any trade offer. I have won this game by only building on two hexagons before (I had four cities and believe it or not, Longest Road.) I have played a game where we combined two base sets and played to 25 VPs. It lasted three hours, but it was awesome and one of the most fun times I have had playing a board game. I love the intellectual challenge and brain burn of other games, but with the right players, Settlers is a blast, and still has enough strategy and tactics to keep me interested.
Great & fast game that is quite a joy to play. I haven't played it enough to be sick of it yet.

Learning about this and watching it, I'd never thought I'd buy it.  Looked boring and dull.  Playing it though changes that opinion, it really is fun to play and I understand the high respect for this game.

Sheep for wood?  There is something inexplicably satisfying about the method: acquiring resources through luck, trade and theft, steadily working toward near and long-term goals, cheering when the dice fall your way.  An important Euro that is responsible for bringing these games into the mainstream of the US, and a game that is reasonably approachable for most people, nearly every geek should own this.  It's not perfect, but there's a lot of charm here.

My introduction to European boardgames. Nice, clean design. My group of gamer friends reimplemented it with house rules, getting rid of the dice, in a version we call "deterministic Settlers". It plays so well we never went back to the official rules.
I still love this game. Great blend of luck and strategy makes this very accessible. Great gateway game with lots of player interaction
My Gateway Game. My friend loseaturn and I loved it, but our spouses not so much.
I love this game. Sadly I dont get to play it as often as I would like.
Grand daddy of the Euro, a true classic.
Excellent gateway game that has interaction.

A classic - should belong into every gamer's collection. Player interaction, tense gameplay, a manageable time investment of about 1 hour and quite simple rules ensure this game graces the table over and over again.

This is the game that really started the obsession for us.  It's simpler then some of the games on this list, but it's not overly simple.  Lots of strategy, lots of player interaction.  Trading and resource managment are key elements to this game.
This is the game that got my wife and daughters playing games. Better with only four players as the six player expansion slows the game down quite a bit.
nice game, easy to understand, doesn't go on for to long and can easily be played with children and adults together without the adults being bored ;) )

klassiker. dette er et must for alle brettspill interesserte. Første gode strategispillet jeg lærte for 8 år siden og vi spiller det fremdeles. enkle regler og alltid et nytt spill siden man lager et nytt spillbrett for hver gang man spiller.
A very classical game, though I would never buy it.
A One of the first games that sparked my growing Eurogame collection, and still a favorite. I also have the Japanese travel edition.
Settlers of Catan was the first game I played a board game that wasn't available at a big box store.  It started my desire to look for other games that weren't commonly available.
Still enjoy this game after countless plays. Recently aquired expansions and life but length as well.
My first Eurogame.  A classic.  Simple design, with a high replayability because of hex map design.
Great game.  I like Ad Astra better though.
good game, I admire its historical significance to our hobby, I just don't know if I like it.
Even after trying all the expansions I still prefer playing just the basic game. It's easy for newer gamers to grasp quickly and still provides a lot of fun.

After hours of studying, playing with family and playing in a tournament, I can say that Catan has a little too much luck for me. It is a great game, but I have become tired of it due to the randomness in its nature.  Plays before 2010 are estimates.
Advent of modern boardgames. If you do not know this, you are no boardgamer.
Still love it.  Always play with variant where you initial build a settlement and a city to start.  Speeds up the startup nicely.  I've got the latest Mayfair edition + a 3D version made by a BGGer.
The Great Game with long series.Have Fun

Excellent game, but remember that cities mean that you get *twice* the resource cards for the hexes they're adjacent to, not *one* per city -- and one resource per settlement and two per city that border on that resource.  Sometimes building in a port area can be helpful.  I like the newer (if more cheaply made) version of this game.  More fun to play if you use the "Cities and Knights" expansion.
Played way to much of this
Good Game never know what will happen next. It still hasn't grown into us yet.
My gateway game. Still a classic.

The game that got me into board games. Enough said. Although after playing it a gazillion times, I notice the chinks in the armor -- the over-dependency on luck, for instance. Still, I wouldn't turn a game down and it's a good foray into strategic gaming.
Игра на все времена, нестареющая классика. О, сколько было битв за "самую длинную дорогу". С каким замиранием следили за выкладыванием карты острова.
Great fun, although some games have really dragged (with unfortunate landscape layout).  The feeling of acceleration is tangible as the game progresses
Wonderful gateway game.  Lots of resource management and negotiation.  A classic that any Eurogamer should own.
To me this is the best gateway game, it got me into gaming.
Budujemy wioski i miasta na wyspie Catan, handlujemy owcami i drewnem. Lekka gra o sporej ilosci losu, czasem rzuty kośćmi są nie po naszej myśli.
One of the best resource collecting and building games around.  Game play often forces trade and alliances.
Played, many times.  Great game.  A little long, but oh so involved.  Love it.
This is the game that got me into gaming. Maybe in ten years I'll be ready to play it again.
It's been a while since I've found anyone willing to play.  It's a great game though.

I got to play this in a bar in Germany with some colleagues during a work conference.  It is an excellent game, but I would need to play again before I can speak intelligently about it.  A good game and a good Hefeveizen is a potent combination.

I wanted to rate this a 7, but have decided it is a classic that deserves a little more.  Settlers is one of the first games that introduced me to euro style games.  It's a great intro game and while there's so much more out there, it's hard not to enjoy a game of Settlers.
Good Game everbody must play this game..
The kind of game that can fill an evening with good memories.  I only play with expansions and variants these days.
Huge replay value and great game. Lots of player interaction, engaging resource management and expansion through streets, villages and cities.

The agreed definition of a eurogame. The gamers game closest to being mainstream (over 28k owners just here in BGG). With a lot of reasons: it has a fantastic theme, nice bits, great mechanics, and offers fun, tension, interactiion, and a wide range of different options. It has everything, a lot of strategy but also some randomness and even big screwage possibilities (here comes the robber...) The negotiation is what makes this game so exiting. We all enjoy it in our family and play iy pretty often. But IMHO it is just a little heavy to be the ideal gateway game (maybe it could be the ideal step two game)

In 2001, this game opened my eyes to a world of gaming beyond CCG's.  Thank goodness.  I love being able to play board games without the pressure of acquiring expensive collectibles.  My wife and I played this many times way before I ever discovered this site.
This is probably the quintessential gateway game. It's pretty fun, and it's very interactive. If you want to introduce someone to board gaming, I recommend this or Carcassonne.

One of they first games I played. I didn't enjoy it much, because it seemed to me very slow. But I like the computer version because it is much faster, I did also Czech translation of it - see Pioneers: http://pio.sf.net

Fun game that got me into modern board gaming.  I'll never refuse a game.  My biggest gripe is that 50% of the game is initial placement.  Judging from that alone, you can usually see the winner coming a mile away, and the game itself is just going through the motions.  Unless, of course, the die rolls are erratic (why haven't we rolled any eights?!)
The classic that helped launch my love of tabletop gaming is now my wife's favorite.
Great game to get people into the hobby.
Great game.  Each game is quite unique.

[3-6] This was the game that reintroduced me to board gaming. After reading an article describing its mechanics and how it helped to popularize Euros in America, I was hooked. The pace is perfect, the strategy is there, and the balance is great. Some people fault the game for very basic play but I think that's the game's genius. A great classic!  Expansion owned: [thing=926]Cities and Knights[/thing]
What can I say? Its the first board game my wife and I played that we both really enjoyed together.

The game that redefined boardgames for me. Settlers had non-hardcore-gamer appeal and a game was played in an hour.  That meant you could cram in 5-6 games in a day. This one has seen a crazy amount of play back in the 90s, so it is rarely taken out anymore.
My favorite game to play with non gamers! Heck this is the game that pulled me and my whole group of friends in.
After one game, I may have turned two friends into BGGs.
Needs expansions for sure, but still a very good game.
Best part: The art of the deal.  Worst part(s): Utterly random dice rolls (probability be damned) and thieves that camp out on choice property.
One edition back. Very good condition. Played only a few times.
My first Euro, and showed me that board games weren't bored games anymore.  Growing up playing Sorry, Monopoly, etc, sure I played 'em, but I wanted more.  I guess that's why I went into RPG!
Good game for every public. Great for introducing people to table gaming.
A game played often enough by my olds that my Mum actually remembers most of the rules and even a little bit of strategy.
Absolutely play this with the Cities & Knights expansion.  Our introduction to Euro games!  Thanks, Jim and Denise, for the great game!
A true classic, easy to learn, a perfect mix of luck and skill
Classic. However, I've forgotten the base rules as I always play with Cities and Knights.

Good game. Several strategies to use. Depending on the people involved some strategies work. So far most games with experienced players, new players, or a combination have ended up close. New players can create setbacks that stop experienced players from winning with their strategies and force them to change tactics.
Easy, fast and gives you a false sense of feeling tactical!

have plyed this a few times now with my kids. They are a bit too young for it and loose interest if its not their go. However I was beaten by one of them on the second play and I was trying to win! Its a fantastically balanced game; i like the way it changes, the choice of startegies you can employ- well everything everyone else likes I guess. I can see this becoming popular in our house.
I've played this over a dozen times, and I had a good time every time I played it. Simple mechanics, variable map, and good, light fun make this game a keeper.
This is completely addictive and very elegant, though I prefer playing with larger maps than the base game will allow.
Still one of the top gateway games. I find, however, that we don't play it much any more except with newbies. We've also steered clear of the expansions. Why mess with a good thing?
A must have, its an awesome gateway game.
Always played this with the Seafarers and Cities and Knights expansion.
Good to play anytime.  Wood for Sheep. "The Precious"
Probably one of the sleekest, social, and amazing games I've ever played.  Really, the fun is in the simplicity and the race to be the best.
Uno de los clásicos de iniciación. Los jugadores compiten en una isla por construir las mejores ciudades y carreteras. Para ello comercian con varias materias primas con los demás jugadores.
Includes 5-6 player expansion, Cities & Knights + expansion, Seafarers, Traders & Barbarians, Fishermen,
This game a golden classic. It was a gateway for me (and many others) to the world of boardgaming. I like the interaction between players.

I love negotiation games, and this is no exception. I think my favorite part of the game is extorting other players while still maintaining a diplomatic relationship.  "Well, it's not like I want to block off your road, but I just don't have the resources I need to do anything else this turn. If you give me some stone to upgrade my settlement I won't have to block you anymore."  The 5-6 player extension is a trap.
One of the Best "Gateway Games" to get non-gamers to play games. On long term loan from Mike.

Downgraded it one point after a long stretch of playing the card game.  I now enjoy the complexity of the card game over the original board game.  However, when we have more than two players for the card game, everyone still enjoys playing the board game.  It has a lasting appeal for me.

Dependent on player's starting positions, but fun if there's no obviously overpowered location in the hex set up. I'd be interested to play with expansions and/or the event deck that replaces the dice rolls. Don't play with friends who will get upset if the dice don't always go their way.

A lot of luck is involved, but just as much strategy. Great balance of power mechanics mean diplomacy is a huge factor. Grudges can be easily created. Game can get very hostile when playing with strangers via XBox Live arcade.

En la isla de Catan los jugadores construiran pueblos y caminos, buscando la prosperidad y la estabilidad mediante el trueque y el comercio. Un ladrón merodeará por la isla...uno de los grandes clásicos de los juegos de mesa de todos los tiempos. (45-75min)
An excellent game to get people started on boardgames beyond the typical Monopoly/Risk/Clue types. It's still good for a quick play.

Great replacement for Monopoly. Game is simple enough and there is enough interaction and strategy to keep the family of non-gamers interested. Sometimes bad die rolls and bad trades hurt you, however the luck isn't bad enough to destroy the game (unlike Monopoly which is almost purely luck).

A must have, a base game for every collection. Usually the winner is decided in the setup process and from then and after it is pretty obvious how one should move. Still, in a mysterious way, it's still fun to play.
This game is one of my favorite. I love playing it and the fact that the board will be different everytime we play it is a cool concept. Easy to learn and get in to.
Fun, but feels dated. Hard to imagine playing this fo real as mostly play this digitally nowadays,
It's Catan. 'Nuff said. The game that launched a thousand geeks, the basic Catan game remains a perennial favorite at my game table, even with the abundance of expansions and standalone variants.
I'll always play a game of settlers. My first real board game.
One of my favorite games of all time, with city and knights of course.  Now we make huge Islands.

Although I've gotten a little burnt out on it, it being my first Euro and something I've played many, many times, I have to give Settlers it's due. There's a reason why it's called a monopoloy-killer. It got me into Euro games, and its gotten thousands of people into the hobby. It's a great gateway game, if not the best.
my first "serious" board game, I'll never forget it
Can play this with many different groups, and has great replay value. Awesome game.  Not too hard to learn, and encourages good group interaction.
I just love it like an old flame. The opening and the luck involved is too fatal, though
5-6 player commingled with Cities and Knights expansion.

Based on one play; a four-player game.  Fun game and should be pretty simple to teach to others.  I look forward to trying this game again.  Rated it a seven at first but changed my mind and changed it to an eight after playing the SOC Card Game which I rated a seven but don't think it's as good as this.
together with expansions (5-6, seafarers + 5-6, cities and knights + 5-6, Traders and Barbarians + 5-6, historic I / II), diverse game. Revived (if necessary) by playing with my kids
This was my introduction into board gaming.

I think the interaction with people during the game is more fun than the game itself. While, it is a game that requires forethought, strategy, and the ability to play people, I think it's more the people you play with, than the game itself.

About as elegant as a game can get.  Imitation is the sincerest form of flattery, and the games that have copied this one in some way are almost countless.  It has since been surpassed by some games (Puerto Rico and Agricola for starters) - or perhaps it hasn't been surpassed but only seems so because of its age.  Definitely a classic of classics.  The one major problem (for some) is the randomness, where unlucky dice rolls can ruin the best strategy.
Probably the go-to game for anyone wanting to try something that's not made by Milton Bradley. Very fun, but could use a bit less random chance.

The game that got me into the hobby.  A friend talked about how she played it with her family.  I just sneered and said, "The Settlers of Catan? What kind of name for a game is that?"  I mocked her ceaselessly for a few weeks.  Then I went online, read about it, and ebayed it on a whim.  Dozens of plays later it remains a classic in our house.

Seems like a lot of people consider this game the penultimate gateway game (and some seem to hold this game in the same regard that I hold Battlestar Galactica). I will admit it's simple enough to introduce non-gaming types to it and nuanced enough to entertain more experienced gamers. Worth learning and having a copy of, at the very least.

Great, solid game.  Overplayed it, but realize that it is one of the best games of all time.  It reintroduced me to the wonder of boardgaming! = 8.   Dice get frustrating after a while... I wonder if there is a better way to handle resource collection but still be random?  (Note to self: The number of plays on the base game refers to all plays including the expansions)

The Settlers of Catan is a marvelous 'gateway' game for those who have only played Monopoly or Clue.  It is incredibly simple to learn, yet strategic enough to allow for some deep gameplay decisions.  It very much serves as a bridge between a game like Monopoly and a game like Puerto Rico.  If you're trying to get some of your friends to dip their toe in deeper games such as the ones lauded on this website, this is definitely the game to start with.

If u want to relax and to have a good time ,settlers is the game.Building roads and cities ,is a good idea for starting playing a good board game....I have bought also the expanison pack with the barbarians...yes this game its become strategic...but luck still exist and helps the one who dares the most hehe

The Atlantic got it right: "Settlers' recipe for success can therefore be seen as this: a well-designed game, devoid of a geeky patina, incubated by early adoption into a nerd culture that has become increasingly mainstream."

This is the game that got me hooked on board games.  I played board games occasionally before this.  After Catan, I became a board game junkie.  I stumbled across it when it showed up on the BGG hotness chart one day for some reason or another.  Excellent game to bring people into the hobby, but the 3-4 player min/max is very limiting--you have to have just that many people around to play.  I like the game enough to also own it on the iOS and XBox360.
Love to play this game from time to time.  It's even better with seafarers expansion, but I am not interested in other expansions.

Vanilla Settlers is great. It is super easy to teach. It is very simple. I would say its Simplicity:Stratagy ratio is very good. Plus there are so many great variants that make the game a little more interesting.
I also have the 5-6 player expansion.
Love this game, one of the ones that brought me into Modern boardgaming.  I still like to play it because of the group interaction, the changing board, etc.
My gateway game, this has helped me to introduce board gaming to most of my friends who are currently into the hobby as well.
Great all round family fun, just dont expect the drama of conflict.

+5/6 player expansion  Still haven't introduced this to my wife yet because of the Robber. Looking into friendlier variants.  Update: If you ever get a chance to play on one of the Kickstarter Catan boards, they are the best!

Got me into board games again (I liked the game Risk when I was young). This game is a lot of fun, but eventually everyone figures it out. The negotiating/trading aspect of this game makes it better than other games which I consider dry, such as Puerto Rico. In fact, this game does the trading mechanism better than any game I know. The play interaction in this game is phenomenal. I recommend the Knights and Cities expansion.

Best game at the office.Ok really?! This game is a must have, My office buddies play this every Lunch break now. It is the quickest to set up and shortest to play within our lunch break, and every time we play its diffrent every single time. Probably my favorite game because it's so replayable, the expansions all rock, my favorite being Cities and Knights. Excellent for people who never play board games and for people who play all the time. Great game!

This was the first considerable board game I had played since I was a child playing Monopoly.  And I must say, I love it.  The game seems simple on the surface, and is relatively easy to pick up, but strategy permeates the entire game.  From placement, to building strategies, and trading for resources, every action has consequences and there are always multiple options to choose from.  Often, a single card can change your entire strategy; I often see players about to build a development card, make a good trade, and shift gears into building a city or a settlement.  With so many ways to gain points, and so many ways to build up, there are always different strategies to try.  Combined with the interaction between players and the random board designs, there is no perfect strategy, requiring players to constantly be aware and plan their next moves accordingly.  My only complaint is the fact that dice rolls determine what resources you get.  While a little randomness keeps things changing and unpredictable, resources are so important that an unlucky streak can break even the best strategy.  Combined with the exponential productivity growth, a slow start due to unlucky rolls can quickly separate the winners from the losers.  This sometimes results in people giving up mid-game, complaining that they've already lost and making unreasonable trades to break everybody else's strategy.  There's a lack of sportsmanship apparent here, but the fact that players can get into an unstoppable losing or winning position can make the rest of the game less fun.  Still, this is an excellent game that I have played dozens of times over the last couple of years and I still enjoy playing to this day.

Great game everyone should have. However it could become frustrating if you are not getting the dice rolls you need. I would like to try this with the event cards that guarantee your numbers come up once in a while.
the game that started it all for me. love it but starting to not like the dice. too much for me sometimes and boring mid to late game is you are not in the lead. that is why it is an 8.
Catan is a great game.  The trading/interaction is fun.  I enjoy the excitement of seeing your resources roll.  I don't get to play it often, but when I do, I have a lot of fun.

Outdated but a good game. His history value is incontestable.

A classic for a reason.  Easy to pick up and play, Settlers is guaranteed to provide an hour or two of fun as you collect resources and expand your town.  If you're looking for an in-depth and full-featured experience, though, look elsewhere.  The frequent dice-rolling means players will start complaining about being unlucky (and rightfully so).  Be wary of the expansion packs; while they add some much-needed complexity to the game, some are worth your time more than others.  All in all, Settlers is a casual German-style board game that can be enjoyed with family and friends.

Bought in 2000.  Have played this many more times than three, but wasn't counting back then. Still one of my favorites, though others seem to have grown tired of it.  Replaced old version with 5th edition 4/17
What can one say, at this point?  This will rarely be the first game I pull off the shelf, but I think the Settlers-haters have a collective stick up their ass.

Les colons de Catane. Le jeu de plateau qui m'a fait découvrir le monde des jeux de sociétés pour adultes. Excellent jeu de conquête et développement.   Bien équilibré et pas trop compliqué, les fins de parties sont souvent serrées.

A classic game that I've played for years. We make an edible version (out of cookies!) that is played at Gen Con every year. It's also one of the "gateway" games for new players that I always recommend.

My first euro-game. I don't think there can be any better introduction to gaming. Over the past few years that I've owned this game I must've played it hundreds of times and it really was the game that started it all.  My friends love playing it and it was great to see how wheeling and dealing our way to success was no longer held to chance or electronically. My immediate family also soon got into it and it's always a good way to have a family evening.  Then I brought it to holiday dinners and Catan was soon being begged for by everyone. It had topped Monopoly and Risk which were two of our classic favorites.   It was one of the games that helped me forge my gaming group here at school. It's a great introduction into the genre and while lately it hasn't received much play and has lost some of it's luster to newer shinier games Catan will always hold a special place in my heart.

Prefer the look and feel of the 3rd edition, which I have. This got me back into board games, as I'm sure it did with many people. Love it as a stand alone game or combined with Seafarers and Cities & Knights. Have my own "Ultimate Catan -- Expansion-combining Scenario". Happy with what I have. Collection complete.

Even those who aren't generally interested in board games will sit down for an hour or two to play a good game of Catan.  Even after several dozen games, I'm still not bored with the mechanics and gameplay, and can't see it happening in the near future. My gateway game... This drug haunts me in my sleep.

I love this game. I love building up settlements and cities, trying to balance my need for different resources against the desire to corner the market on one of them. The dice roll to determine resource draws (and to enact hand size penalty) means that early-game positioning provides real advantages but keeps comebacks possible.  The only complaints that I have are that politicking takes some of the fun out (everyone hates me because I am ahead! :[ ), and bargaining can stretch the game out too long -- the game is on the long side to begin with, so hagglers can make it seem interminable.

We never regret sitting down to play this game. Very fun but one downside is a poor starting position can be difficult to recover from and it uses two D6 dice and dice can lose you the game. For example, nine and five should roll equally often but they are dice and of course don't neccesarily follow the "odds" leading to a bit of frustration. Traders & Barbarians expansion adds a deck that handles die rolls which does balance things some in this regard.

[b]Purchase/Selling History[/b]:  Got at the Pearce Missions Garage sale brand new unpunched for .50 cents. ‘12-13?  [b]Rating: 8[/b] [i]Design rating[/i]: [b]4.5[/b] [i]Component rating[/i]: [b].5[/b] [i]Willingness to play rating[/i]: [b]1.5[/b] [i]Fun rating[/i]: [b]1.5[/b]  [b]Players considerations[/b]:  A little empty with 2, but best with 4, also even better with 5-6, but can be really impossible for someone in the wrong starting position to catch up.   [b]My thoughts[/b]: Pretty much impossible to come back as you fall behind, but that's not the fault of this game. The genius, rather, is that you continually want to try again to win next time.

It seems overwhelming to new players who have never played but usually within 2-3 turns they seem catch on and always end up really enjoying it.
