Excellent Jeu, Instant Classic!  Comme jeu d'initiation, c'est celui qui vient en top de liste, tout board Game Geek se doit de l'avoir dans sa collection!
Could be the best game ever. Strategy, cooperation, randomness-but-not-too-much. Suffers only from smooshy graphics on the hexes--why'd they change from the photos?
Good game with well-working trade mechanism. As a dice-driven game, sometimes it can be decided pure luck, but more often not.

A great game that I probably judge a little harshly now just because I played it so much before discovering all these other games. Hold up great though, except for the risk of alienating newbies by blocking their progress with a road early in the game (I do always try to warn them beforehand, but there's only so much you can do if you need a particular resource for yourself)

Variable board layout gives 1,409,602,287,701,349,181,440,000,000 (over an octillion) different combinations. (Depending on degree to which you randomize the board.)  Perfect gateway game.  I Recommend this game for people who like variables and probability.  And Economics.
The board game that introduced me to this website.

A bit underrated here. It is a great game and only handicap is if all your rivals play aganist you you cannot beat them all. They can trade in themselves and they can stop trading with you. This is game-breaking. Detailed exp will come later. But anyway it has a great/strategical and entertaining game design. Most of us started our boardgaming history with this game. It deserves more than its current score.
In this game you can build lots of roads settlements and citys,you can also get your stuff so you can pay to build stuff.
Hard to get the family to play this for some reason. I like it!
The classic Euro gateway!  The trading aspect and the competition for space allow this game emphasize efficiency while driving player interaction at the same time.
Very good and popular game. Slight element of chance but a huge element of fun in this game of resource collection and management. Highly addictive and worth playing if you havent already

My first European designer board game. I fell in love with it right away and bought a bunch of expansions for it. Played it many times. A true classic that brought a lot of people to modern boardgames. That said, it feels rather dated now. The winner is often decided as much by the dice as by strategy, which can be frustrating to experienced gamers. It is still worth re-visiting occasionally though. Star Trek Catan, with its character-specific abilities, is a nice improvement on the original design.
"THE" gateway game. Always good family fun.
Great replay potential.  A good 'gateway' game for non=gamers.  Multiple paths to victory a plus.  It's easy to understand why the basic game is still popular after 18 years on the shelf.
The design of this game is elegant. Everything fits perfectly together.

This game has sort of been left in the dust for me.  It really is a great game.  I think the trading part can become a bottleneck for time, but not too bad.  I also don't like how you can get locked out of resources for the whole game.

This is the reason I got into board games. It's a fantastic gateway game that is easy to teach and fun to play. Great player interaction, and very fluid gameplay. This game is always a fun time, and it's my go to for introducing new people to board games.  Only reason this isn't rated higher is that I've played it too many times now. fantastic game and always a good time.
Classic gateway game. Really fun when played in moderation but unfortunately, newbies want to play this over and over again, burning me out.
Gets a bad rap. Nice balance of random elements and strategy.
Decent game at 4. Definetly a gateway game to prepare for heavier games. Nonetheless almost always fun.
An absolute classic. No introduction is needed.
It's a fine game, but runs a little dry.  It just doesn't always feel worth the time.

Great game for two couples to play together.  Not too much strategy, but enough to make the game interesting.  Kids are starting to play this one better.  Still learning that trading should be done only if it benefits both people.  I've had fun every time I play this.  Therefore, I will give it an 8.  This and TTR are the two games I always try to take out for new players.

Our first Euro and one of our favorite games.  Good: the unique (to us) mechanics, table interaction.  Bad: just now learning you haven't been playing one of the rules correctly. Could have more depth, but I guess that's what the expansions are for.
Big family favourite - really got the family gaming.  We all love it and even though there is some luck in the dice it's still highly rated
Terrific game that plays well with serious gamers and light gamers.  It's only flaw is that dice can sometimes shape the game too much with luck.
My gateway game. I love the modular board and trading elements and unlike many others, I don't really mind the dice rolling. It has a healthy mix of luck and strategy, perfect for newer boardgamers.
Slight learning curve but it is an easy enough game to pick up and learn. Definitely a keeper.
Game took too long for what it is. Just so many more games I'd rather play.
Classic game.  Problem is that the expansions can run you a fortune to make it a complete game.
I liked this game.  I wish it had a two player version though.  It's tough for me to find that 3rd player in my house.

This will always hold a special place. It's a timeless classic that has its share of flaws, but it really has helped bring a lot of people into modern board gaming. It's fun to play once in a blue moon, especially as a gateway for non-gamers and new gamers. It's tense with hoping for certain resource numbers to appear, racing to take space before your opponents, and pushing your luck with hand size limits and the robber. It's interactive through negotiating trade with your opponents and through the building race.  To help mitigate the overly swingy luck factor that I find to be the biggest flaw, I like to use a stack of cards with perfect probability distribution instead of dice, and also a board setup calculated for fairness by the Better Settlers website. (Side note:  I had a friend who was opposed to this deliberate balancing saying it was out of the spirit of the game, but then the game we played ended up with final scores of 9-9-9-10. I have never seen a 4 player game so close! Everyone was one turn away from victory.) The kingmaking aspect can get a little mean, so hopefully players don't take it personally.
Rising on my play list due to Missy the Catan She Devil!

This seems like a quality game, a Euro attempt to make an improved Monopoly.  I had thought the morphable hexboards was a brilliant innovation until I heard about Magic Realm.  Oh well...need to get in more plays of this.
Great game to introduce people to board games.
I have probably played this 50 times before I had this account.
Where it all began many years ago...sheep for wood?

Classic, but complicated. People complain about the sometimes stilted gameplay, but you really need the right group to play. If you have people who are willing to trade and/or form some sort of helpful relationship during the game, it can take on a much more interesting cast. Also, it's great that you can expand the game and combine other games with the core set, ostensibly creating an entire world to settle and conquer.
Simply a great "gateway game". Would recommend the original to any player.
Always fun with the family and guests, but never the one I suggest to gamers.
Still holding its own after twenty years.  Haters gonna hate.
В период с 2012 по 2017 гг сыграл около 70 партий (в основном с дополнением Мореходы)
Adquirido en julio de 2004. A veces es demasiado largo, y la suerte influye bastante. Si uno empieza débil, es difícil recuperarse.

I think this is one of the games that got me into the hobby. At this time I way mostly Roleplaying with my friends. Settlers was most played with family but also opened the door to Boardgaming with my friends.  Played probably 100+

Great entry game, but too much relying on dice.  Adding a 'charity deck' that follows the same rule as the starfarers' charity rule is a must for us now.  It makes the game much more enjoyable for all.  For an enjoyable 2 player game, implement the charity rule, and throw seafarers & knights in; make a big map with lotsa islands, then use two colors of peices each & set the winning points at 20 to 24.
Fun, but can get tedious if the dice are not good to you.  Would like it more if it played in under 80-90 minutes.
Great gateway game even if there are many better games out there for experienced players. Maybe it should be rated lower but it's just amazingly capable of converting non-gamers to gamers.
A fun classic.  I am getting my game group(s) to try this out, some of them have never played, and some have never played with the expansions.  Looking forward to some more plays.
Love this classic game.  Plan on picking them up again at some point.  Pretty much only one of the games my wife will play.
iPod, love it! Lots of fun even playing with AIs.

The best game for you if you don't play board games. Friends and girls love it. Best trading and social game so far (if you let it). Never get mad to the dice. Just have fun playing. A little to much luck but you can use some variants to put it in check. I advise you 2 new house rules:  If you don't receive any resource, place a token (Catan doesn't come with any, so add them to the game) in front of you. Once you have x tokens equal to your points, trade it (on your turn) for any resource. Tokens can't be stolen and don't count as cards in your hand.  If the same number (besides 7) rolls again (two times in a row), you MUST add or subtract, a value of 2, to the number (you choose, but can't never use a value of just 1). This rule is inspired from Elasund.

Ordered in March 2014. Great gateway game. At the time, I was playing at least once a month with a large group and more copies were helpful. I ordered the expansion in October 2014 from Toys "R" Us. This game is often compared to Monopoly.

Gran interacción entre jugadores. Mecánicas bien engrasadas. Múltiples tácticas/estrategias para conseguir la victoria. Azar en la producción, reducida por la probabilidad de las conbinaciones en los dados. Como juego... Todo un fenómeno mundial, y un clásico.  Saludos!!!.
One of my first boardgames...I waw playing it, when I was on university with my classmates.

A classic full of merits, great introductory game for the negotiation mechanism (one I'm not fond of), It might be a little long with 4 players, but it is fun enough to keep you engaged. Truth being told even though Catan is regarded as THE negotiation game we (my family)pretty much avoid intense trading and it is usually one for one, we just don't enjoy felling like we are taking advantage of one another.
The one that got me hooked. And the game I’ve used to get others hooked. For that, it will always retain a special place in my collection!   Next: consider the expansions…

Started the whole thing off for me.
The first game with a rule I hate.  Damn robber.
The big daddy of German games.  Clearly a much better game with 4 players and quite easy to teach to non-gamers.  Enjoyed by all that have played so far.
This is a GREAT starter game for people who are not familiar with many board games. This is the one that roped me into playing board games like a religion. ;P
Only played once or twice, but pretty fun game overall.  probably would've been rated higher if i would've won. :-D

Me gusta jugarlo de vez en cuando pero no me entusiasma. Es un juego muy familiar con un pelín de estrategia y uno de los juegos ideales para iniciar a los amiguetes en este mundo. Pero pobre de ti que los dados no te acompañen porque una partida se te puede hacer interminable. Para mi gusto, demasiado sobrevalorado.

Gotta say it's _still_ a good game. Mostly this is because of the social interaction between players (how long through the game before we screw eachother over?). Partly it's because I've been able to use it to lure several people away from the clutches of the dreaded roll-and-move.

A modern classic which really needs some of the expansions to be a good game. Still one can't go without it.  Gameplay: :star::star::star::halfstar::nostar: Replayability: :star::star::star::star::halfstar: Fun/Social: :star::star::star::halfstar::nostar: Components: :star::star::star::star::nostar: Rules: :star::star::star::star::nostar:
I do enjoy this, but it's status as a gateway game is overrated, I think.  Also, I had to buy a gray set of pieces to replace the brown ones and deal with the color-blind problems.
Really fun resource utilization game. I like it!
O que dizer do pai dos jogos modernos de tabuleiro ? Jogo simples e divertido; para gamers OU NÃO ! Como ressalva a grande dependência de sorte (dados) ! (Homemade)
This is a very nice game when you stick to the basic version and play with four people. Although, it is best to play for a buck a point.
Classic. Trade/Area Control.  My intro to gaming.

Use to teach newbies, house rules include not moving robber on 7 roll, but instead choosing a resource of your choice from the supply.  Speeds up play and makes for a friendly game (until knight development cards start being played).  I have all expansions and enjoy more room to play, even with three people.  Better borders options are available and a must if serious with catan.
[b]Expansions:[/b] Explorers & Pirates Traders & Barbarians  [b]Insert:[/b] Wooden Artists Case

This is a great game! I wouldn't turn down a game of it if asked. It's different every time you play but this is more of a lucky game that let's you think you are in control and that strategy is involved. You make decisions that's true, but most of the time the decision you make is obvious or the only choice you have. This game I know very well and may that's part of my problem, the unpredictable random nature of the dice role is too random? This game does escalate well if not evenly and the race for the final few points is enjoyed by one or two at most. .. often the other players have been left behind and for them the game ended a few rounds ago. Still for all my nit picking complaints...I wouldn't turn down a game.... is that this games magic?
Fun game, but not the thing we like... These tile building are not the games we like...
One of the great modern classics of gaming and a wonderful gateway drug.
Lengthy resource-building game, but holds good replay value.

I liked the game when I played it a long time ago, but the fact that I played a lot better games made this one stop here. I don't have too much nostalgia about it since I ALWAYS, SINCE THE FIRST GAME disliked a feature that is not only prominent here, but also something other games LOVE doing, and in its essence is what I dislike in Scythe, Kemet, GoT and here (there are other games I played in this list with a similar sudden endgame condition that EITHER give players at least a "salvage round" to cushion the disaster for the players not ending the game or make this a ): sudden endgame conditions. It can be tied to a score of sorts (8VP in Kemet's case, 10VP in Catan's case, 6th star in Scythe's case) and doesn't give the rest of the players a chance to do anything, resulting in a frustrating endgame condition.  I never liked those. I think they are a cheap (while easy) design feature made in lazy manner. I tend to like games giving the "consolation round" WAY more, since, at the very least they give the player some agency in what to do in their last round (it usually doesn't change spectacularly the endgame placement, but at least gives the player that last chance of achieving something).
Good game, also for non-hardline boardgamers ;-)

Along with Ra and Puerto Rico this was one of the very first games that got me into Euro Boardgaming back at the start of this century.  It brings back pleasant memories of when I played this with my former wife and daughter.  We had some fun.  I may pick this up again one day.
The gateway game.  The best way to introduce newbies to strategy gaming, IMHO.  And has lots of great expansions.
It's true - non-gamers really do love this game!
It's a good game.  Can't get excited about it much any more but that's not to detract from the general goodness of this game.
Lots of fun in a group, a female friendly game that's very addictive with the right crowd.
Settlers is a classic. You can't ever be disppointed by playing it. The randomness of getting the resources can be a bit frustrating though.
Downgraded to a 7.5 from a 9 because frankly, I'm getting tired of it.  Thank goodness we don't have any gaming newbies in our group, so we don't have to pull this out instead of Taj Mahal!
The first game that gave a new twist to playing games
A good family games. The ideal for my wife and family friends, too simple for me and my gamer friends.
A nice game with good strategy vs. luck factor. Not really very much depth without the Cities & Knights expansion though.
I've been owning this game since it came out in the mid '90s. It was very innovative at the time, it's still a classic but much better games have come out since then.
No explanation necessary. Good solid game. Is there anybody who HASN'T played this one yet?
A great game to introduce newbies to the world of "German"-style games.  Nice wooden bits, great player interaction, but the game has a bit too much luck IMO.  This was my first "German" game.

Sigh.  The eternally over-rated Settlers.  Why some laud this game, which is just as random and just as prone to hosing some players out of the competition early on, as a premiere example of the German style, is beyond me.  Don't get me wrong -- it's great fun -- but it's about as luck filled as Monopoly.

I am amazed to see that I've never added comments to this game...  This is a game that can be easily taught to most non-gamers, but has enough complexity that it will interest most gamers...  It's easy to learn, but has enough chance in it that it's not all skill that can make a person win... 2/25/07
A good game and a classic according to many, but lacks the complexity and variety of other modern games and pales by comparison to the two player card game in my opinion.
One of our first, and still a favorite. The whole family can enjoy this one. I don't suggest it much anymore, but still have fun playing it.
I just bought this game.  Tried it with some nongamers they loved it. They came back the next night to play again.

After all of these years, it is still a classic.  However, it suffers from being 20+ years old and having a couple flaws, which are terrible randomness and a runaway leader problem.  It's also one of the games that can be decided on the opening spots.
Always good. Even though it has lost its shine there is nothing wrong with it.
What else needs to be said. A solid family game with fairly simple mechanics that keeps bringing people back to play.
Won't play without Cities and Knights any more, unless teaching new players.

A classic, no doubts about it. An elegant design, and a game of great "historical" importance. But nowadays I find it a little bit too luck based for my taste. Good players will usually beat bad players, but if everyone is good there' s really little you can do to offset a streak of bad die rolls: without cards you can do literally nothing, thus you have no control. Despite this, still a very good and fun game, but better designs are now available in its category.
Fun all around game for everyone. Even my non-gaming wife loves this one and it eased her into Puerto Rico as well. Whats next for her? Panzer Leader? LOL
I still like this game, I'm afraid that if I play it too much I'll start hating on it like everyone else has.

Can't really add to the volumes that have been written about this game. It is very good if somewhat imbalanced due to the d6 system. Nice positional play with cities and roads, power plays with knights, and multiple scoring options. Biggest knock in a 4-player game is that someone is made redundant too early.

Nice, fun little game that I play when gaming time is short or I want a change of pace from a massive/complicated/long war game.  This game has almost infinite replay value due to the nature of the setup, but there are several strategies that work well no matter what the setup outcome looks like.  Not the "greatest game ever" as many claim, but it is fun, easy to learn, and got me introduced me to "German Style" games.  Game is great in its basic form or coupled with the available expansions (Knights & Cities is the best in my opinion). One thing I don't care for, the amount of luck involved in the die rolls for resources.  But, I guess it all evens out in the end.  Give this game a try!
The grandmother of gateways. A true modern classic.
I've just played once, but it's enough. A great game !!
My first love, my introduction to German games, the most expensive board game I ever bought(at the time...)
First time played and really found it enjoyable due to the randomness of resource generations and robber activation, the trading and planning to reach 10VP.
I like playing with a "Deck of Dice" to reduce the randomness.
Good or bad trading can make or break the game
3-player is the favorite at our house when playing for fun.  When getting more serious four player works, too. I don't like the 5 and 6 player version, it makes a light game last too long.
Ahh, my first non-monopoly type game. love this game.
It was the first time I could have fun playing with some, non-grognard, gamer. A little out-dated but always fun.
Very good introductory German-style game.  Simple to learn and play.  Too dice roll dependant sometimes.

Not my first German game, but definitely the one that was most addictive.  I am a little burned out on the basic game which accounts for my rating.  A must have game in a collection and especially great for families.

It's where it all started for me and German gaming.  I still like it, but only with 3, because I think it is too easy for a fourth player to get shut out of the action.  That said, it's pretty low on the list of played games these days.  Maybe I'll get my wife to try it again eventually.
Good game.  Getting rather sick of it, though.  It is a great entry game for gamers not familiar with German boardgames, but they tend not to move away from this one...
Great game to use as an introduction to "eurogaming", my gaming group loves it, even my younger sisters love playing it!
Perhaps I have simply played this one too many times to give a fair rating.
A classic. It's not great, but fun enough.
First European game I played/owned.  I had never heard of it before but was searching for a game on the funagain game site that I thought my daughter might like.
Fast to learn, hard to master.  Appeals to wide age range. Fun!
A second level "Gateway game", light enough to get non-gamers playing, heavy enough to keep gmers going, logn term strategies.  I also refer to it as "Civ for the Rest of us"
A tremendous design.  The ultimate gateway game.  A little to interactive and uncomplicated for my group's standard fair, but a great game for family and new gamers.
Great game to introduce to non-gamers!
Good game on its own, great game with Cities and Knights expansion.
a little over played in our group last year

(Initial comments: ) I don't get all the love for this game. It's too dependant on rolls. If you don't get good rolls to acquire resources, you can't do much as a player. The 7-high card limitation leads to some players getting screwed repeatedly.  (Multiple replays through the years have upped the score from a 5 to a 7.5 I still think it's over-liked, but as a historical game that can bring in non-gamers to a wider world of gaming, it could even warrant another .5 point)  10/30/14 Picked up a complete unplayed 4th edition copy at Goodwill for $3.99

It's a great game as a starting off point, but I rarely pull this game out now unless someone else really wants to play it.

Probably the first boardgame who showed me a greater universe of the board games and not the simple games based on basic system. Beautiful the idea to use resources and the need to plan your strategy from the first moves and placement of the colonies. However after a little it loses some of its flavour becoming to simple. I reccomand it with the expansion City and Knights

The gateway game for so many folks, Settlers has aged well, in my opinion. It seems to suffer from a high luck factor, but this has not prevented me from enjoying it for the past ten years...
Excellent trading game. Good 'gateway' game too.
Fun game, kinda played out now. Not the 'bridge' game that some make it out to be, although not bad for that either.  Main problem is that it runs a bit long compared to the tension and content.
This game is hugely popular becuase it is relatively easy to learn and be competitive.  I have not played the expanded version yet.
Like New; Mayfair (English) edition; the game has been opened, but it is unplayed and unpunched.
Have played with 3 and 5 players. Was great either way, and is a family favorite.

Like many others out there, Settlers was the game that introduced me to German board games. I've since grown tired of plain "vanilla" Settlers and I cleary prefer Cities and Knights now, but Settlers still gets broken out when it's time to introduce someone new to the hobby.
Very easy to learn, but plenty of room for strategy planning .. Lots of FUN FUN FUN time playing it !!! Excellent game to play in a hot boring Sunday afternoon.
A landmark game although to be honest, it is not my favorite Settlers incarnation. Got rid of it (for now) since everyone else has it and I would be forced to buy the expansions if I kept it around.
After finally getting to play this a bit more often, I can see why it is so popular. Lots of fun, and I love the interaction with the trading aspect.
Hazardous, simple but a good game, very fun!
Great game, but make sure your group is into it.  Played this with someone who didnt care and they screwed the whole game up.
I don't like the 5-6 player version, it's a very different game.  Seafarers is at least as good as without it, but I dislike C&K.
Plays well and is easy to learn.  I am starting to grow weary of it though as there is not as much variation as I had thought that there was when I first started playing.
Perfect game to introduce newbies to become BGG. Too much influence of the bloody lucky diesÂ¡Â¡ I Highly reccomend to play with the two expansions (seafarers and knights and cities)

This was the second German game I ever played and loved it.  A great way to learn economics: scarcity of resources.  It has a luck factor which is good for new players.  This is what we use to introduce new players to german games, most who have never played a game like this so much, they buy it.  Still great fun.  Update: now for new people with very little game experience, we use Ticket to Ride as the gateway game, but we still use this game for lots of new people as well. Updated rating to 7.5.
What can I say, this is the game that got me hooked on boardgames again!
USE THE "POVERTY NOBLES" (ARMUT ADELT) VARIANT. Without it, the huge luck factor destroys the fun, IMHO. Ask, if you want to know more.
was a fun game, but i passed that stage
I've only played a couple of times. Maybe that's for the best, as it seems to wear out its welcome for a lot of folks.
It's Settlers for God's sake!  RGG English edition, anniversary edition, German edition.

[Mayfair third edition w/ pre-2007 adapter kit] {Catan, Civilization, gateway; trading, modular-board, development, dice-rolling, resource management; optimal 3p} Settlers of Catan is a decent family game with a strong development theme. It is fun and exciting. The game flow is very smooth and has less down time. It's not a heavy strategy game but it provides many tactical options. It is of good player interaction from the trading, robber and the competition of roads. The dice rolling, though luck-driven, adds excitement to the game.  It has several novel mechanics - dynamic board, rolls for production, etc, which have been re-used in many other games.  Beginners' setup should be used when introducing this game to your friends. No matter how you remind them, they will easily overlook the importance of initial placement of settlements and priority of resources at different stages of the game. They will then feel desperate that they are blocked from the game.
I haven't gotten tired of this yet.  Amazing.
It's a classic for a reason.
Only 2 plays so far.  One 2 player game and a 4 player game.  I quite enjoyed both games but the 4 player game was much more interesting.

An excellent gateway game due to the high level of interaction through trading. Settlers strikes a perfect balance (IMO) between skill and luck.  The variable gameboard set up allows for a different feel each time.  A bit burned out on it however.   Played many more times before I starting keeping track of plays - 12+

Addictive and fun with good scalability as well. I'm not a huge fan of building the game boards with hex/octagons but this one is worth the effort and time. The randomness of building a board each time is what keeps this game feeling fresh in a way. It's also a very good "gateway" game.
Played a few times. Good game. Would play more. This one I play to win.

Well loved but flawed classic. The gateway game that seems to have worked every time I have used it. It is highly random and can get a long for what it is when people are trading with each other. But we still play it when we can.
Having played this game N times, it's beginning to get old.  Still fun with people who are playing for the first time.  Not fun with people eating WAHmburgers and drinking WHINEikens.
I prefer games without dice. But it was fun some years ago.

I won't object to playing it, but seems like a lot of energy is spent for little change of the board. The ending is always a let down. Some new players really have a negative reaction, so I'm not sure it's always a great gateway game. Winner's Circle is more fun with more activity and more of a comeback opportunity for the same time investment.
best game to introduce others to boardgames. lots of interaction, luck plays a big part on it, strategy not so much

Wow, it's pretty funny to come back and realize you haven't updated your comment in a couple of years!  Here's what I had before: "Only a couple games tried so far.  Still new to the game.  This game is so widely acclaimed, I'm not sure I've really formed my own opinion yet."
Rarely play due to it being 3-players or more.

will play anytime, but the dice roll determining production is SOOOO important to the flow of the game that the randomness detracts from the fun elements. I too often find myself shaking my head at the dice, which is my own problem, but indicative that the game is too dependent upon the production roll.  11 Oct 05 Up to 7.5 - after repeaded playings there are ways to mitigate the luck factor, and what a great gateway game for newcomers to the hobby!
One of my first Euro games. Great trading game that I still enjoy after lots of plays. But there are so many new things around, I don't really play it much.
Very good game. The only down factor here is the frustration that sometimes the dice cause, but it is part of the territory and if you accept that, it is usually a rewarding experience.

THE GAME that brought me into this wonderful world of boardgaming. THE GAME that generates the most social interactivity and fun at the table. THE GAME most played.  Update: Been having a rather long drought for this great game. For social fun, my group(s) enjoy Manila, I'm the Boss, Citadels, or even Modern Art. The above statement regarding it being the most socially interactive and most played is no longer true. :)

Good trading and gateway game. Some replay value, but gets boring if you play it too much. I burned out on this when I took it to Australia. I took a bit of a break from this game in 2005/2006 academic year, but since Autumn 06 I got back into it, then burned out again, and doubt I'll be keen to play it again since I realised how high the randomness really is. Also it is slightly too long. The game can get boring if your numbers aren't coming up.  Settlers is best with 4. 3 or 5 means it's too easy to expand, 5-6 is too slow. I think the expansions all make the game worse.  It was my first Euro. I also now realise that there is too much luck - early luck gets compounded, and players can be out of contention after 10 minutes (or 0 minutes if they put their 2 settlements in stupid places). Also it is kind of the same every time - there's only a few ways to get points so you end up doing the same things every game. Or every few games I suppose: you might get longest road one game, and largest army + VP cards the next, but there's not much strategy space to explore. Funny I'm saying this now, when I first played it I was impressed by all those multiple paths to victory.  Another issue I have is that 50% of the skill/important decisions in the game are the setup initial placement. After that the dice tell you what you should be building. The trading phase keeps me engaged because you have to pay attention and negotiate with the other players (that's the best part of the game), the robber and competition for longest road are good aspects.  These days when I see a bunch of Settlers-ers setting up, I like to watch the initial placement and then predict who will win based on resource access. More often than not I am right.  Bought Spring 2004, Sold 2009/10 via BGG
Trading and building game themed around colonial settlers on an island.  No direct conflict, but agressive players can wield roads to fence in opponents and good negotiators have an edge in trading.
I love this game with the Cities and Knights expansion, it changes the games so much.

I brought this when my current game group first got together and we played a few times, and it was well-received.  However, our group soon grew too large for it, and I stopped bringing it.  Some have moved away, though, and now we occasionally have the opportunity to play, and no one was disappointed.  As usual, it is a great gateway game.  I think, however, that it has been surpassed as a gateway game by Ticket to Ride - Settlers takes a number of turns before people "get it."  Ticket to Ride, people just jump in and go.
Excellent game to introduce non-gamers to the industry
Top game, whatever people say. And so important in the historical development of the euro.

A nice gateway game.  I also have: [b][gameid=2807][/b] [b][gameid=325][/b] [b][gameid=4103][/b] I played Seafarers, for the first time, 5 years after buying it. It was the first time I had played Settlers where everyone had played the game before. I had always thought that I shouldn't spring the expansion on beginners. I have changed my owned games list item to Seafarers. Seafarers makes the game so much better :-)
jogo de trade, com dados, meio longo, muito bom, mas sem reptir muito na joga...
Great game to start a new boardgamecareer.  Would not play it every time. There are better games out there
The gateway game to end all gateway games ...

this game is simple but a good introduction to euro type games.  Combines trading with with area control in a easy to understand package.  I gotten many non-gamers to play this.  There is a bit of a run away problem if the die rolls don't work out to get you resources  and there is no catch up mechanic but just keep up if you can.  Games can also run a little long for what it is.

Wow. Game boxes used to be so ... drab!  It's brown with some brown on it. Yawn. The game is still the same though.  After not playing Settlers for ten years or so, and playing it 4 times in a month, I think I'm a bit Settler'd out. It's a good game, but it's definitely been surpassed (for me) in complexity and fun by later games.  UPDATE: I think I've identified what "gets me" about Settlers. If you are the player that falls behind -- and there's almost always a player that falls behind -- there is very little you can do to dig your way out of the hole you're in. In the rare game that doesn't have this happen -- like the game I played tonight, which ended with 9-8-7 points -- the game is a fun contest all the way through, but boy does it suck to be the pre-destined loser.  4/2012: Updated rating to be more realistic. Settlers is still quite a good game, even if it's not one I want to play a lot of.
After one night of playing, I can see the appeal. I can't wait to play with more than two!
It was fun while I was making my first steps into the boardgaming world, but now it will not leave its shelf unless I have newbies.

Classic... my own personal Euro gateway game.  I think the luck aspect (robber, dice rolling) adds to the game, especially with the player interaction (trading).  Nice components and artwork make me wish for the fully-3D special edition of the game!
Upped my rating to an 8 on this one.  Very easy to learn and play.  Most of the fun comes from the banter between players throughout the game.  I'll be keeping this one top shelf for a while.
Will it surprise you if I say that this was the first Euro I played?  I hope not.
Only played a few times, good fun.   Have found a few thrifted copies over the years, and have gifted them: spread the boardgame virus!
First euro game played.  January 2001 in Spain at a conference.  Friends taught it to me and I kept thinking about it the rest of the week.  HOOKED!  ...and so it began for me.

This game is da bomb! In the early 00's I decided to start looking for games like I used to play back in the 80's and 'Settlers' introduced me to Eurogames and the Das Buch variants make this a game I'll want to play forever.

I enjoy the game and agree that it is a great gateway to gaming for non-gamers, but there are so many other cooler games to play. I won't turn it down if offered to play, however, and in fact, I find that I have a itch to play this every so often.

This game is truly a classic. Has a lot of luck but skill is more than essential to be a good player because things to pay attention to are very subtle. The great thing about Settlers is that it can be a beer & pretzels game but it can also be a very competitive game.  Played it online only but have played more than 1500 games so I guess that my opinion still counts for something.
I played this original game so much that by the time the expansions started coming, I had no interest in playing them.
Game that introduced me to euro games.Don't play as much as I used to, but willing to play at anytime.  Lots of fun.
Everyone knows this is a great game...

El favorito de mi mujer y fue el mio durante bastante tiempo. Muy recomendable.Depende bastante del azar, pero es muy divertido, sobre todo el comercio entre jugadores. Fue con el juego con el que me metí en esto de los juegos de mesa.  Reseña en Colle Peza: http://collepeza.blogspot.com.es/2012/04/los-colonos-de-catan.html

This is one of my favorites to bring out when there are 3 or 4 players at my house.  An excellent game that involves a touch of strategy, a forward-thinking perspective, and a lot of player interaction.  I only use the Event Cards for this - I think it speeds the game up by quite a bit, as there is the possibility with a few of the cards to reward EVERYONE playing with a resource card - which is usually a good thing.  This is one of the few games out there that can be played "AS IS".  What I mean by that is that there is no need for any house rules or other variants.  It is a very well balanced and finely designed game that does not need tweaking or modifications to make it play "better".  Not saying that is bad, but if you don't like to have to keep track of a bunch of house rules (Monopoly, Descent, etc.), then this game is perfect for you.  This game is also single-handedly responsible for the worst one-line cliche in all of gamedom - "I have wood for your sheep."  Although it is still funny to say, even if you aren't a Beavis and Butthead type fan.

3-4 players; 90min 3rd Edition  Mayfair Games sells a pre-2007 adapter set for $10 http://www.mayfairgames.com/shop/product/3000-3299/pages/3199.htm   "This adapter kit provides that [4th Edition-style] frame, the frame extension pieces for the 5-6 player extension, and the harbor pieces that allow you to vary the harbor locations from game to game."
My First German Style Board Game.  I jumped into this new world as of January 2007, and have gotten my hands on as many new games as possible since then.

This game gets extremely frustrating when the dice aren't going your way. But the trading allows the personalities of the players to have a significant impact on the game, and the modular setup keeps things fresh even after the umpteenth play. Definitely a keeper.
This game is must have if you are play boardgame. Anyway,gamer or non-gamer play this also fun
I really like this game, even though dices are not fair all the time ;-).I recommend

2007:This game is great.  Better than more fiddly games.  I underestimated it initially, but it has both elegance and bite. 2005:It is fine, and was probably mindblowing when released, but compared to PR, PowerGrid, etc., it does not seem that amazing.
The "one" that started it all...  Thanks to my little sister who bought this for us, our present gaming days and nights are all due to this little game that got us going...
My first boardgame I bought at Yellow Submarine, Akihabara, Japan.
The game that started everything for me
A classic.  Certainly always fun, with good diplomacy involved.  I'll rarely turn down a game of Catan, unless there is something I've never played before about to hit the table.
I like this game, because it is one my whole family will play, even my wife, and everyone seems to have a good time.

Eurogame classic. One of my most-played games, I actually played it enough that I'm weary of it. The theme re-enforces historical misconceptions around the takeover of the new world, however, the game is simply fun... I guess I'm just hypocritical because I still enjoy playing it.

So well balanced, cleaver and infinite re-playability my only gripe is the treacherous distribution of dice rolls sometimes. Lots of strategy and tactics to consider and heaps of player interaction in trading. a CLASSIC!

This game is super fun until you role a '7' 6 times in a row between four players and you are the one who rolled it the 6th time. Similar to monopoly in my opinion, but is better because you can actually end it and people actually want to trade.
Good gateway game,Im always willing to play.
Obviously a classic.  For awhile I burned out on it, but I enjoy it again now, especially against experienced players.
This game is really fun and i have played it with my dad a really long time.

This game is a blast! Went over great with my group. Everybody liked this game. Looking forward to a lot more plays. Update: We played this a lot more and it's really a super fun game. No one ever worries when I bring this out. When new folks arrive, it's almost a lock. Guaranteed good time for regular and new players.

I played dozens of unlogged games of this before finding BGG, including quite a few when revisiting the game in the last quarter of 2006.  A great gateway game that is still fun to play.  I picked up [gameid=1137] and [gameid=926], but my interest has waned some and I haven't played any of those expansions (I traded [gameid=926] without giving it a go).  This will still get play every once in a while, but I'm not sure if it has a third wind now that I've plunged headlong into gaming.
Wow- this was the only game in my collection w/out a comment- what can you say about *the* game?  Great anytime, lots of folks will play it with us, all-round great standby.

This is an engaging game and I like the fact that in 4 player games players are not eliminated.  This has the distinction of being my first official Eurogame. With multiple ways to gain victory points one has to focus on a goal, but at the same time be mindful of that quiet player slowly building, building, building.  It was captivating enough to get me to purchase the expansions. I keep it nearby to expand my friends board game horizons.

One of our household favourites... simple to learn & play, with a high level of interraction (trading) between players... however, I find the "luck" dynamic a bit too strong due to the high dynamic of die rolls to obtain the resources necessary to achieve victory.

In Settlers of Catan, players try to be the dominant force on the island of Catan by building settlements, cities, and roads. On each turn dice are rolled to determine the current production on the island. Players collect raw materials to build up their civilizations to gain enough victory points to win the game.  Highly recommended to anyone who wants to see how short, deep, and fun a board game should be!

Euro games owe a lot to this game. Didn't like to play it at first, but will not decline a play if asked to. Only downside I see is that you stand no chance at all if your first choice of city was bad or 2 players block you from the start. The idea of trading resources is its main asset that has brought so many people to board games. Praise for that!!

Settler of Catan is Settler of Catan is the game responsible for renewing my interest in board games.  It is the first %u201CDesigner%u201D game I ever played, but not the best.  Too much of the game depends on the roll of the dice.

Quite enjoyable, even tho I rarely win.  Good gateway game.  I recommend giving first-timers a city and a settlement to start; it may also be good play without the development cards for the first game.  Teuber's 2-player version was pretty good, too (one play thus far).
Sigue siendo un juego que cuando sale a mesa la familia lo disfruta, imprescindible para introducir en el mundillo.
My very first Euro game, although a case can be made for being ranked lower, it will have a special place in my heart.  A good intro to board gaming.

I play it in some variant a couple times per month and enjoy it most of the time. I dislike how much randomness can hurt you early in game and keep you locked out of long games due to a bad start, but you gotta love the simple rules and interactivity! Definitely top 10!
Good game, people seem to grasp the basics fast and play competitively right after the first play. Unfortunately, AP is an issue with most of the people I play with.
Enjoyed by everyone in my extended family (6 and 8 year old nieces, included), but sometimes is decided purely by luck and nothing else.
Not the most engaging of games but its a gateway game so I will bring it out when others request it.
With 6p expansion, Seafarers and its 6p expansion. Also: Cities & Knights expansion.
Perhaps too random for some, but nevertheless a very playable game.
Really fun game.  Beware: this is the gateway drug of gaming.
4th edition. New in shrink. Great Game. One of the classics.

This game would be very good if it wasn't a piece of painful agony from the very beginning to the latest move. Okay, it's not painful if you happen to be lucky, but for somebody it is. Results will get balanced in the long run, but because the game takes so long to play, you're not willing to see the long run, ever.  Do NOT buy any extensions. They only make the game unnecessary complex, long, and even more torturing.

The game that got me hooked on boardgaming as a serious hobby.  I played this at least 150 times before I started logging my plays.  I still enjoy playing but I prefer some of the "fresher" games I have.

A solid and fun game and can be quite tense towards the end of the game. Lots of player interaction and the robber can often prevent runaway leader problems.  There is a huge hidden strategic element in this game. So far it seems that trying to trade a lot is a great strategy towards winning along with trying to get your settlements on different numbers as opposed to getting a few big numbers to cut down on robber screwage.
Personalmente no me ha entusiasmado, pero "1.000 millones de chinos no pueden estar equivocados" ...
The perfect gateway game.  Great way to get your nongaming friends started
the first game to bring me to bgg.  i still enjoy it now and then.  collecting resources and building an empire is always fun.  4th edition.

Me ha causado muy buena impresión. Un juego de recursos nada complicado y que mantiene en vilo toda la partida. Lo mejor: la interacción entre los jugadores a la hora de comerciar y el hecho de que no se hace excesivamente largo (75 min. aprox.) para ser el tipo de juego que es. Lo peor: mucha aletoriedad en los dados y con mucha influencia del factor suerte.

I never really understood what all the fuss was about with this game until I finally broke down and played it.  The I went out and bought myself a copy.  Very accessable and easy to teach.  I will play this nearly any time I get the chance to.
4th Edition cardboard pieces need to be thicker.
A fun, light game that just about anybody can enjoy, but that offers  more depth than your typical American game like monopoly.  Offers alot of plyr interaction.
Such a great classic, though its age is starting to show I'm afraid.
I've played more online than on the table.  Excellent game.
Fun family game. Can be a bit long at times. Other than that minor point it is fun.
01-The game that started it all for me.

Probably one of the best gateway game ever! If You want to show what is boardgame to young children, or students, or parents etc. - You can succesfully use Settlers of Catan.  I give "only" 7.5 becouse now after years it seems to be too less thinking for me but....  ... with Cities and Knights of Catan - solid 8.0! Really nice game for minimum 3 person - the best with 4.
My introduction to Euros. Very polished.

Also my gatewaygame into boardgames. I played it a lot. Its a very good game, minimum downtime, lots of trading, building, stealing :-). I like the fact that you can create your own board. One issue: luck, after numerous plays it kind of bugged me, but still it is a must-have. Next time catan will appear on the table, i'll try one of those bgg variants. If this one is missing in your collection, do something about it!

bought for .50$   - this is a sleeper hit for me - I don't like the randomness of the die roll..but I have to admit, there is a lot of strategy here..and the bargaining for resources came easier than I thought with friends I have played with. Pleasantly surprised!
Always popular with non-board-gamer nerd friends and certainly fun to play, just not as fun as most of the other options.
Another classic game with many variations now. No game the same twice plays between one hour to two depending on number of players. Layout style one of the more winning features.
Great all around game for non-gamers.
Easy to teach. Many options available to change and expand. Easy to go overboard too though.  [b]home[/b]
My intro to Euros about 10 years ago.  Liked it a lot, bought just about all the expansions available at the time..
I have only played Settlers two or three times.  I enjoyed it.  But since it is a 3 - 4 we haven't really given it a chance.

I really like the degree of social interaction in this game versus the other Euro style games in my collection, and it's always easy to find a group to play with. This is one of the games that got several of my friends involved in the hobby.  The only reason I don't suggest (or play) this game more often is that it can easily lead to out-of-game conflict among some competitive gamers.  Traded for Puerto Rico after I realized everyone I play games with owns their own copy, and it's my duty to bring more unique games to the table.

My first strategy game. Seemed AWESOME when I first learned it but now I can only play it once in a while. Roll dice to collect resources. Use resources to build settlements. Too much luck based on dice rolls and maybe I just plain burnt out in it.
Buen juego de iniciación, con comercio, desarrollo y expansión... Su punto flojo, la dependencia de los dados... :( Pero al ser un juego de iniciación pues se puede pasar por alto este tema... :P
Everyone seems to like this one too
Great gateway game. Can get dull after many plays.

Like many, this started it all for me. It has lost the appeal it once had though. It could be the setup, but if that were it, Twilight Imperium (3rd Ed.) would really never get played ever again. :)  That can't be it. It's a keeper, as it's MY gateway game.

My re-introduction to board gaming. Plays like a dream with 4, nice level of player interaction and while prone to AP, the overall playing time does not feel that much. I can see many ppl averted by the element of luck in this game and to be sure bad dice throws can make you feel very miserable and even spiteful but this element of uncertainty makes it all the more enjoyable, at least for me.
Enero 09. Regalo de Reyes de Borja.

If you're new to gaming, starting here is a really good bet. Seriously. This game gets more people into board gaming than anything I've ever played. Even if you're not a crazy-big fan, you're gonna' dig this more than another round of Monopoly when your folks come to visit and it'll open them up to a whole new world. It certainly did for mine!
Another game I hooked my family into.
One of the first Euro games I played. Still one of my favorites.  Though my wife always beats me.

It seems so balanced it just blows my mind. Almost any board game out there with multiple paths to victory contains a few useless or inferior options, but this one is just breathtaking.  Edit: wow, that was some effusive praise from a guy who had played like 10 modern games. Yes, Catan is good. No, Catan is not god.
The euro-game that started it all for us.  This was the first game of this type that we bought, thank you Jack.  You can see the effect that it had by looking at the rest of this list.
Excellent introduction game. Can be played with family. The classic of classic. Only one reproach: too much chance. And a loosing player can be bored.
Solid game - nice artwork, so easy to learn, quick to play. This is the epitome of a gateway game. A must-have for couples. Looking forward to playing expansions.
The game that started all for me. Unfortunately, this game becomes too simple when you know more about other board games out there.
A staple of the board gaming diet.

Very replayable. If someone doesn't want to trade with you and always puts a robber on your tiles (they're playing so you would lose) it's very hard to win.   When all players try to win becomes a better game.
The classic gateway game. My first introduction to "real" board games. Fun, light, takes 5 minutes to learn, yet provides a fair amount of satisfaction.
The game that brought me back to gaming.
The game that introduced me to Eurogames, and a lot of fun.  Easy enough that my 5 and 3 year olds can grasp the mechanics, if not the strategy.  They have a blast playing a "real" game with Daddy.
Great Gateway game, I convinced friends to boardgames with this one. And I still enjoy it.

Settlers is a good game that I enjoy playing. It has been ignored a bit since I plunged into the gaming hobby and acquired too many games. My wife and I used to play it with friends quite a bit. I do not mind the randomness of the dice rolling. If a game is meant to be fun, I feel that the random chance adds a pleasant bit of tension to Settlers.
Much better with three people than my usual 2 player variant.
A lovely game nestled in a cozy little spot on the complexity scale. Perfect for a nice evening in and for introducing non-gamers to the hobby.

A deceptively in depth game put together as an attractive product. The board changes each time, so do the tactics. As long as players trade with each other the game is fairly fast and flows well. If not, it can stall a bit. It will undoubtedly get more plays over the next few months as expansions are added one at a time.

Acquired 2009-06-03  I love the modularity and the player interaction, but were I unaware of the context, I'd be hard-pressed to figure out why it's considered the absolute classic. My last game lasted 3.5 hours, and I couldn't bear it in the end.

Good introductory strategy game and starter game to lure people into euro boardgames, but I find it hard to end/win i.e. to get 10 VP and luck is a big component. When we first started, we played it 3 to 4 times per week, after work, and once stayed till 3am at my house :p I bought the online version too  1995 spiel des jahres
This game is still one of the best gateway games.
This game got me into my personal board game hobby.

This is where the hobby started, like for many. I played and liked the usual household board games, but this one opened a whole different world for me. Catan started the passion. The original gateway.
Why do people always trade with the leader? SHEESH
Some nice strategy and some luck required to win
Perfect gateway game, although in itself it is far from being perfect. I played it and enjoyed it.

I enjoyed it when I first played it, but really don't like it too much any more.  The reason I give it a 7.5 is that it really is a great introduction game and that means a lot, and a lot of people I play it with really like it so it makes the game still fun to play.
Clássico Catan. Joguei e gostei muito. As negociações frenéticas são a alma do jogo, e cada um deve se ligar muito no que o outro precisa pra poder boicotar. Muito massa.
+ 5-6 Player extension.  Base game is enough for me. Harbour Master is a must when playing with 5-6 player extension in my opinion.

Thanks to Monica and Lucian, this game and Agricola are what got me back into board gaming and away from video games. I'll still play Street Fighter, but I love inviting people to play this and other games at my house.  Seriously, guys, thank you.  Update: this rating went down because, after starting board game nights at work, I realize that the only version I want to play is Cities and Knights.
I want to play this.  We only tried a couple of times, but never seem to have enough time to bring it out.  That and I don't think that Grandma would enjoy it, so we avoid it when she is around.

Catan? Really? I know what Settlers are, but what's a Catan? I prefer [gameid=117985], even that's just an [b][color=green]8.5[/color][/b]. [i]Someone should code a nostalgia counterbalance algorithm for this sucker[/i]. NB: [gameid=34635] is, by far, the more accessible 'gateway game'.. OK, well, the price would have to come down, but compare the rules!  No dice prejudice here. BTW; you can't Roll "a" dice... and, I've played Monopoly recently; [this] is one hell of a LOT funner.  Kathy's copy. Sleeved (finally).

A good family game with a lot of luck and some negotiation that can be fairly nasty, via the robber and trading boycotts.  This nastiness is surprising, given how popular the game is in Germany.  It makes one wonder whether the "conventional wisdom" among German publishers that player conflict is to be avoided is actually accurate for the German market...  When all's said and done, I tend to prefer vanilla Settlers to its various variants and expansions.
:star: Good old Catan, I traded it when I bought the 3D special edition.
Game that feels very exciting to play, also feels very stressful. Good game, but I prefer games with less claustrophobic feeling.
我的启蒙游戏，看似简单的规则其实融合了众多机制，新人初次“上桌”的绝对首选，但如果给geek们，则仍需扩展丰富其内容。

The game that started it all for me, as with others I assume.  Great game, good mechanics but does have the capability to lead to some major arguments during play.  We don't play it as much as we should because of that.
The classic euro design. Haven't played this for ages but remember liking it quite a lot.
I play this solo on my phone more than anything else... :(
A flawed classic.  I feel like it's very difficult to recover from early setback.

I enjoy this game, but I think the randomness just strikes me the wrong way.  I like randomness in my games, but the particular interaction between luck and skill in Settlers can just be frustrating.  I mean, it's been three turns since I've seen a new resource, and, oh look another 7!  I really like the variant where you reroll 7's for the first round.  Honestly just playing this sparingly enough makes it a better game :)

My first Euro game.  Will hold a warm place in my heart for that, but there are too many other games I would rather play now.   Catan is still a great way to introduce people to the genre of designer games.
Meh. This is actually a pretty good game, but it's just such an old hat.

Good game.  Will likely not turn it down if someone suggests it, but also will probably not suggest it unless someone hasn't played a "real" boardgame before.  Like the trading aspect and like the building.  Made better by Cities and Knights.  Update Jan 2015: Played this game with my brothers over Christmas.  Awesome.  Simple enough for everyone to come up to speed quickly and liquor-fueled trading interaction was great.  And I really like how the development cards provided another path to victory if someone was locked out of building cities.  This game is classic and should be the game the general population points to when they think of "boardgames" and relegate Monopoly to the dustbin of history.

This is a good gateway game for introducing eurogames to uninitiated friends who have only ever played games published by Milton Bradley, Hasbro, or Parker Brothers. After a few dozen plays, game-play is not especially captivating as most decisions are made on auto-pilot. Your initial placements and the dice gods have a lot of influence on who wins. However, due to resource acceleration the end game is often exciting "if I only had one more turn I would have won!" finishes.
Still a classic in my book. Preferred with 3, rather than 4.

As much as I like the game I cant't give it a 10. It's far too luck-driven. You may be a cunning tactician and be capable of the niftiest of tricks: If 8 rolls half as much as 6 does and 10 rolls never, you don't stand a chance.
Still worth having in the collection. Still fun. There are better, but this is still a good game.
Very nice game. Good gateway game for your typical non-gamer.
Many plays. I like it, easy family game.

The game that introduced me to gaming. I've played this more than what shows here. I like the modular board, the trading, and the economic system. It runs a little long for me so it doesn't hit the table as often anymore.
I'll play it with people who enjoy the trading element but it's not my favorite game. It seems to take a little to long with those I've played with.

My personal gateway game.  The collecting, the trading, the building, the dice, the robber.  Before this, all I knew were Monopoly, Risk, Sorry, & Stratego.  I never knew boardgames could be this engaging.  My eyes were opened.  It's lost a little of its luster now, but still fun to play with the family.
Great game!  A new (old) classic! best with 3-4.  Really begins to drag with 5-6 especially if there are some newbies) .

Very enjoyable gateway game. I owned this on Xbox Live and played it tons. Got rid of the 360 when I bought my PS3: if they had this (or some of the other boardgames too), for PSN, I would definitely rebuy.
Classic. It doesn't need to say anything more.

Nice game to initiate people to non-monopoly board games and lure them into the board gaming arena.  I played a bit too much of that game, but I may still play it when people do not want to learn more complicated games or I do not feel like explaining yet another game (yeah, I'm the rule explainer).  Retains a good score because I too was led back into boardgaming by Catan. Thanks for that!
Points for universal appeal. Don't ever play with six, again...
Only play this as a two player game so I'm sure we're not getting the best out of it but using the two player rules it's still a good game.

While I can't stress enough how important this game is for our hobby, I have to admit the biggest reason for my recent plays was the fact that it used to be my wife's favorite game. But in our last play, even she was a bit bored. While I still enjoy it occasionally, my assigned gateways would be, in that order, Modern Art, Fearsome Floors, Carcassonne, Stone Age and Ticket to Ride.  Catan was the poster child for what the (classic) Euros did well, one important feature being keeping playing time reasonable. It was quite obvious for those who, like me, grew up playing stuff like Monopoly or Risk, but twenty years later it seems to last a bit too long for what it is (a light family game with some luck). A nice, simple idea to improve the game is simply to let each player place a city and a settlement (instead of two settlements) when the game starts, Not only this means there are now only 7 more points to achieve rather than 8, but also that the early game isn't so slow due to people not getting enough resources.
EN: a great family game  PL: Świetna gra rodzinna
Classic and THE gateway game. Other then that nothing special.
Classic. One of the 2 that got me gaming again.
Lots of replay value - a true classic - but come on; give me some more theme.

Example of a good game for several reasons, I small random element to keep each game different and keep beginners in the game, tones of variants to keep the game alive session from session and the best is there is excellent player-player interaction that gets pretty rowdy.  A real blast with the right group of people.
I'm always ready to play Catan, even if there's not a lot of tactical depth to it. Everybody I've introduced it to loves it so it's been a good gateway game.
Awesome game for new people to the hobby!

I love the variable set-up, I love the random resource allocation, and I love that everyone is involved throughout the game.   —— 7 years later, I’ve played a lot of games, Catan is outclassed by a number of games, all those loves have probably slid into really likes. I gladly play it.
The game with which we started many; ideal for going into the world of the games.
More of a negotiation game really as the winner is the one with the best deals....or the best dice rolls.
A favorite but I don't own.

Was one of my favorites when I came to the hobby but now seems too simplistic and random. Also the flow of the game is pretty static. If you can't get to the top early on, you'll most propably be lagging whole game without any real chance to compete for victory.
Nice entry level strategy game. Great for tickling other friends into boardgaming, and for fast plaays allowing an afternoon to have another things to do aside playing.

Early gateway game for me that still gets good playing time. One of the games that I enjoy introducing to people who haven't been exposed to Euro type board games and always well received. Game mechanics are superb and game plays better with 4 people instead of 3. Love the trading!
I only play this game if people ask for it. I have bought the 10 years edition for 5 and 6 players.
The classic that got me hooked on modular game boards

It is fun to play, I like the interaction between players and the re-playability.  It gets frustrating if you don't manage to obtain a good starting position or the dice you are waiting for just doesn't come!

Still one of the greatest games there are, though it's fashionable for hardcore gamers to look down on it. I knew nothing but this before I discovered BGG and this hobby, and haven't played it again since as I discovered the hundreds of other games out there, but I'll definitely enjoy this again in the future.
Used to be a 9 but it's not something I'd actively suggest playing any more.

Still a great game, what got me into Euros. I only rate it this low because I will always play Seafarers over straight Settlers, mainly because it is too easy for one player to get pushed into a narrow area, basically stuck in a losing position for the rest of the game and placed in a king-making position through who he/she prefers to trade with.

Played with friends, and it was a great first experience. I had played this once before, but did not pay much attention to it. This time we were more into it, trying to get the gist of the game. Our daugther won the game with a great combo of cities and road. We should have our copy soon enough.

This game got me started in board gaming. It's a solid game... after a while the luck factor starts to get to you. You can have the best spots but still lose the game. It's also a game in which you can start off slow... in which case you will know you're going to lose but it'll take another hour before it actually happens.  Don't get me a wrong though, it's a fun game... I enjoy it.
A great game for all type of gamers. I beleive one of the games that brought more people into board games. I still play this from time to time and is fun with the added expansions.

A great interactive and social experience. Easy to teach and hilarious when you both swap the same cards (i.e. wood for wood) with a fellow player as you have asked for the resource in the wrong way for the umpteenth time. Great re-playability and the fishermen mini-extension balances the non-harbour costal settlements. A great family game and a classic. Would have loved to have played this in 1995 when it was released - the UK was just not as exposed to these "euro" games for some reason. If my mum will play and enjoy this game, trust me, ANYONE will.
Good gateway game when trying to introduce new players to boardgames.
Not much to be said that anyone on this site doesn't already know.  Bonus points for being one of the games that showed non-gamers that board games aren't all Monopoly.
No box but everything in excellent condition.
I've only played a few games of Catan, so I'm not as much into this as others are.  Yet.  I'm hoping to be able to play a few more games against live humans instead of my iPhone AI.
Trying to teach it to my wife... She has played!!!
Classic for a reason.  Wish it was a nicer production.
My personal start with serious gaming. Liked it much ... now it seldomly hits the table. Mostly with extension City & Knight
I own three copies of this game.  One is my personal copy and the other is still in shrink and unpunched.  It's signed by Klaus Teuber.

Have played this a lot. Good game for introducing to new gamers. Can really irritate if you can't get a good starting set-up and sometimes you will want to throw the robber out a window. Very annoyed about the thin cardboard that warps. For such a successful product the quality is not good enough!
Кубики, кубики, и снова кубики, но не все так плохо, как в монополии.

(After 5 Plays) 10/12/16: Catan is a game I enjoy quite a bit. It was one of the first games I played (like many others on the site), but I don't like it simply for nostalgias sake. There is some real strategy here. Yes, there is randomness which some wont like but it doesn't take away from the fun. Its a game that is light enough to just enjoy your time with it win or lose. It has been surpassed by other games which is why its score has dipped some but its one I'm always willing to play.

Introduced me to gaming. I'm not as big a fan as I was - people can be locked out of the game by bad dice rolls, and the wood for sheep jokes get old - but I still enjoy it.  Expansions played: A fair amount worse with the 5-6 player expansion, which makes things waaaay too long and slow.
A great game, but not usually my first choice.

I'm liking this game more and more over time. My wife and I have tried many 2-player variants but they never pan out terribly well. It's a lot of fun with 3 or 4 players. For me, the meat of the game tends to be in the initial setup (placement of first two settlements). Sometimes the dice just hate you. But in all that chaos, there are multiple adaptive strategies.
Perfect gateway game. Has just enough diplomacy and fairly fast paced. Great game to introduce to non-gamers.
It seems you either love or hate this game.  Played this a ton with family.  One of the firt euro games I taught my kids.  I still enjoy the occassional game.
The game that got it all started. Of the 3 common gateway games, I think this really teaches the most mechanics and has the most replayability.
เกมส์ประจำกลุ่มที่เล่นง่าย แต่ถ้าเล่นไม่ดีแล้วเกมส์จะยาว และจบยาก
Once upon a time my favourite game. The base game is fairly light and boardgames have come a long way in 15 years.
Really good, but kind of random because of how much dice rolls effect the outcome of the game.
we played a lot 10 years ago, but not so good any more

A classic among classics. A game about expanding your little settlements, and trade what you have to other players. There's no direct confrontation, but that doesn't mean that you won't end hating your neighbours' guts. A simple and nice game, it englobes the philosophy of euro-games for you to embrace in one of its purest forms.
Got this at a totally bargain price very recently. Haven't played my copy yet, can't wait to do so. Have played the game at friends' houses; good game, fun to play.
The game that got me into board gaming.  This will always hold a special place in my heart.  Truly a great game.
很令人糾結的交易發展遊戲，還是要靠骰運幫忙
Only placed once but I can imagine it would get old fast after playing too often
This generation's Monopoly - or at least it should be.

Simple, accessible game to play with non-gamers; strong point is that there is almost no downtime; even though you know what principles you need to follow after a while and therefore it comes to lucky dice, this game remains fun to play; the Seafarers expansion is not necessary, but certainly adds something without increasing complexity and playing time. I almost never play this game without this expansion.
A classic albeit a bit old fashioned. Still it doesn't show it's age too much and you can lure non-gaming casuals into playing it :)
Introduction to euro-games.  Simple mechanics, lots of options, "thief" your friends ... good times.
My copy was stolen from me.

Pros: Trading, resource management, route building, all its mechanics work well.  Cons: The dice play too much of a factor still for my taste.   Final thoughts: The game that got me (and the majority of people) into gaming. Discovered a whole new world after playing this game. A close place to my heart. Played the hell outta this game back in the day.
Reference game. A must have for everybody. It's a good game to have when you're new to boardgames.
Always fun to play, and its importance in changing the gaming landscap cannot be overstated (well, it can, but it was important nevertheless). Luck factor is too big, but somehow still lots of fun.

This doesn't come out much lately because we keep getting new games, and we have an older version, which means we can't really buy expansions. Very frustrating. I hate when companies update a game and change the look and the backs of cards. We refuse to buy a new copy.
The game that got me into board gaming! Great mechanics although dice can be unfriendly.
This doesn't exactly get tonnes of love on BGG, but I think its a nice solid game that is especially good for introducing non-gamers to board games.
Great game, a little long for what it is but still fun.

Although highly luck driven, still a very strategic game.  Wil Wheaton says that, 'The robber is a dick!'  Wil Wheaton is correct.  I have had victory snatched away by the robber more than once.  *sigh*   [I]SOLD through the NZ Boardgame Trade FB group to Steve O'Donnell.[/I]

Played once with 6 people who had all played before.  I'd like to play it again with fewer players.  UPDATE-played a quick 2 player game last night.  Much better than I thought a 2 player game would be.
A very good game for entry the world of BG.
I played so much Settlers in college - we got to the point where we were making crazy stuff up (double blind placement - you don't know what resource or number your on). It's still a good game.
The board game that gets everyone into board games. Fun, simple, and infinitely replayable. Must-have for any board game collector.
Un clásico básico. Toda casa debería tener su parchís, ajedrez, damas, baraja española y Catán. A partir de ahi...

Of course I've played this a lot more than once, but that's what I've played since keeping track here on BGG. Settlers got so many people into games. I've taught it to my family, and it's gotten them into games too. We don't have it with us here in LA yet, but I bet we'll get more plays out of it when it arrives. Thank you, Settlers!
A pesar de que me gusta otro tipo de juegos.  El Catán es un clásico del que he disfrutado con todo tipo de personas.  Siempre dispuesto a echarme una.  Hay mucho cachondeo en las negociaciones.
just love the coexist-nature of this game, with lively trade barter on the one and mean street-building off-cutting possibilities on the other side
- Got me into the hobby - As an experienced player, I don't really enjoy this as much as I used to (rewards not trading) - Perfect for hosting newbies

My first love in board gaming. It's lost some of its luster over the years as I've discovered so many other amazing games. My main issue with it is that it's very possible to have a game become an exercise in frustration because the dice aren't rolling in your favor - and there's just nothing you can do about it. I'm ready to try some house rules to try to prevent that.

I have nothing to say about this that hasn't been said.  It is a quality game and I like to play it.     Suitability for Travel:  I have a 1 to 5 scale for four categories (1 is worst, 5 is best) in order of importance:  Portability (the less luggage space the better) - 1 Footprint (the less table space when playing the better) - 1 Scalability (the wider range of player counts the better) - 2 Learnability (the easier to teach non-gamers the better) - 3   Overall - 1
There is a reason this game is so popular. The outcome is usually very luck dependent, however.
fun when you play it once every 6 or more months
classic. simply cant go wrong with catan
Haters want to hate on this one. But it's still a classic game with broad appeal.

My first board game love.  What can I say about this treasure ;)  After playing the german version with some friends I couldn't wait until the english one was made available in Canada.  As soon as it arrived I bought it and hooked my friends into it, and at one point we had a stat sheet plotting who one the most, games played, etc.    After playing other games and expanding my board game horizons I have found that this has lost its appeal.  Still a good game though.
