I haven't played this in a while, although I quite enjoy it. Is everyone just tired of it?
Played this game too much... I still play from time to time and it's still enjoyable.

I used to really like this game, and have played it dozens and dozens and dozens of times. Usually it is a lot of fun, and can be pretty exciting with the right people. However, it can also get really frustrating, and I have seen some people get pretty mad when their road gets cut off (or something equally trivial).   I think my rating has also been skewed some by the "this is a 'really light, introductory game' to the game boarding world, and thus it doesn't deserve a high rating" mentality.  In any case, I have only played it once in the last two years. Whether it is because of how I personally feel, or how those who play with me feel, this does need to be reflected in the rating I give.
This game keeps making me and my friends crazy!!! Everybody loves it. The only bad thing here is that the dice are really evil...
Great intro game for non-gamers.  There is a large amount of luck involved as the dice rolling does not occur often enough to make the different numeric probabilities affect the outcome.
Decent game that is great for showing people who don't know about the modern state of board games different types of games with some good interaction, which other eurogames dont necessarily have.

In my opinion, Settlers of Catan is quickly becoming one of 'the' new classics of the modern gaming age.  This is a perfect gateway game for those that lived on Monopoly and Life and want to take their board game experience to a new level.  That being said, you can only play this game so many dozens of times before it gets old.  Luckily, Mayfair Games gave us expansions.  To remove some of the luck aspect, I highly recommend this rule from the expansions: whenever a production roll results in a player receiving no resources (except on a "7"), that player receives 1 gold.  2 gold can be traded for one resource of the player's choice during their turn.

The classic Euro game (one of the first I played).   This is brilliant to introduce to people who are new to the genre and are used to games like Monopoly. Although I don't play it that often any more it's a great game to come back to.
I have played this game a lot over the past decade. It is a really good game to introduce people into the board game world but overtime it loses its appeal.

This was my only "designer" game for many many years.  I wouldn't be on BGG if it wasn't for settlers.  Have definitely seen a resurgence of this game lately due to it's discovery by a lot of non-gamer friends, which is ironic because I had unsuccessfully tried to get them to play it for so long.
An enjoyable gateway game.  Great for beginners.
Way better with cities and knights
Nice and easy game to play. But the luck factor sometimes drives me mad.

Very good game. Hope to soon try the expansions. The ipad version is good too, except the AI players are too easy to beat - at least in the basic version that I have. Got it as a christmas present 2012.
This is my wife's favorite game. It's a great game full of complex strategy with simple and easy to follow rules.
box beat up but components in good shape. 2 Ed.
Gateway, but overstays its welcome after a few plays.  Need to try expansions.
My first Euro game. Maybe a little to much luck.
This and Ticket To Ride got me back into games.  My first play through of this game took 3 hours!  What a newbie!  Doesn't get much play anymore, but I still like it.
Bought in the Virtual Flea Market of BGGCON 2013.
This is the game that got me into board gaming.  I recently played again after being away from it for a while and still had lots of fun.  I'd like to try some of the expansions.
Great game, tons of fun, easy to learn and not a ton of moving parts. One of my staple "this is how I introduce you to real board games" games.

Lacking in deep strategy, Catan regardless lives on.  It is a game about dice rolls, and unlike Monopoly, there isn't anything anyone can really do to stop a run away leader.  It did, however, evolve the board game industry from Mass Market monsters to the current standards, so we all owe it a bit of gratitude.
If I had a dollar for every time I have played this game we would be independently wealthy.
Good game for those who like dense strategic decisions and negociations.
This is a pretty solid game for families. I've had some success with teaching non-gamers.
One of if not the best intro board game for beginners. (There's more than monopoly, risk,  and life)
I think this is still a great game, but you see its age. Like movie special effects from the 80s.
Good game. My brother tends to play it a lot more than me though. Trading/bartering is not really my forte, so I generally don't, but it's fun to stratagize.
A classic.  Though I've only played it a couple times.
I've player this a hundred or more times and just got burnt out on it.  Even though I don't come back to it much anymore, it must be a great game to have taken up soooo much on my time :)
This is the game that really brought me and my friends back into tabletop gaming! Easy to teach to anyone and enjoyable as well.
The classic introduction to "premium board games."  Can't go wrong with Settlers.
Haven't met anyone new to the game that did not like it.  Also own the 5-6 player expansion and the plastic board that replaces the cardboard perimeter.

2.35 BGG #166--15th Anniversary WOODEN deluxe set with 5-6 player expansion.  Fun game to play with friends/family and enjoy a few adult beverages.  Mid-game often tedious waiting for someone to FINALLY win. I now feel like I have the ability to win in most circumstances.
Great game, excellent gateway game, this is how you get people to play games
This is a favorite of my teenage sons.  Their neighbor friends will play also.
Classic. Actually own two of all sets + 2 of the 5& 6 player expansions for each up through Cities and Knights. Fills a rather large table.
One of the best games to introduce friends to "Euro-games" and a wonderful game besides.
This is my gateway game. It doesn't get to the table much anymore, but I still find the way the basic mechanics work together very engaging. I particularly like the trading and the dice rolling.
Seafarers is most likely the next boardgame/expansion I'll buy.

The famous Monopoly-killer.  This is the new "classic" family game and is often credited with kicking off the Euro revolution in the States.  The fishermen expansion helps make the outside coastal tiles a bit more balanced; it should almost be included in the base game.

This is a breakthrough hit for a reason. Very accessible to anyone new to the hobby, but it also has enough strategy and variables to entertain more veteran players. I complain a little bit about the luck element, as sometimes the dice seem to favor unlikely numbers, but usually it evens out. I also like the fact that there are several ways to try to score victory points. Watch out for that guy buying up all those development cards!

The great classic. Probably the first game people think of nowadays after relics like Monopoly, Classic Risk and Cluedo.  + It is satisfying to slowly expand your civilisation and see your settlers thrive. + Easy too learn, hard to master.  + The gathering of resources and using them in specific combinations to build seems mundane now, but every other game that does this partly builds on the legacy of SoC.  +/- a few of the problems with the game can be fixed with expansions. (Seafarers makes wool worth more, Fishermen makes coastal settlements less of a waste)  - The runtime can be too long if people take too long negotiating. - It is a tad too luckheavy for my tastes. If the dice are not on your side you won't have anything to do in your turn.   It's still part of my 'introduction trinity' with Pandemic and Ticket to Ride
One of my favorites because it first opened up the world of board gaming to me. Luckily I never got to the point where I played it enough to burn out on
I've played the base game quite a lot and I really like it. I haven't got around trying many of the expansions.
Always enjoy playing this.  Great for friends who are not big into gaming.

Much, much more interesting game with the Cities & Knights expansion. Hmmmm, speaking of that....need to trade this for the edition that matches my copy of Cities & Knights so that the cards match.  Looking for the English third edition 2003 with color rules and card box. Ideally, would swap this first edition for it.
So simple but so good, one of my favorite to play with any level of gamer
The Beatles of modern board games. I would probably rate it higher if I hadn't played it 100 times already.  When I do re-visit it though I'm always struck by how many problems this game solved.
Classic game! Does not hit the table much, but when it does it is enjoyed.
Classic.  And play and teach to just about anyone.

Our family likes this game.  We played it to the point of game fatigue.  A few years later now we are willing to play again and have introduced it to our children.  The game is very simple to teach and gameplay is straight forward.  A proven winner.
As infuriating as this game can be on occasion, it is still a solid and enjoyable game.
The perfectly adequate girlfriend you lost all interest in
Funny German-trash game. If you do not like randomness avoid it like fire. Dice governerd game here. Nevertheless is like an institution in China...

Very good game for beginners. The game has simple and smart mechanics, good replayability and nice (yet not overwhelming) design. By playing this game with somebody who doesn't play board games You can show that They can do something more than throwing dice/pushing pawn and yet it's doesn't need to be hard/boring/pointless. The game can be played with 2-4 players (where 3 players is optimal between spacial and crowded), takes about 60-90 minutes. The game is charming and fun but after couple of plays You might want to go for something more complex.
Classic gateway. Love it or hate it, its contribution to the growth of the board game community is ineffable.
A great 'gateway' game to get people interested in various builder type games. A good level of strategy and luck mixed together. Initial placement is key.
the game that got me back into board games.  I've since found others I usually prefer but I'll never turn on this one; it's a good one.
iPad & physical versions. Got the 5/6 player expansion plus all the IAP's.

We taught nearly everyone we knew in 1998-2002 how to play Settlers and it was always a hit. One set of friends liked it so much, they bought all of the expansions. So I've mostly played the Cities & Knights version, which I think is a must - otherwise Settlers gets a little boring (after you've mastered the gameplay).  I still love a good game of C&K though.

This game has a fundamental design flaw  - The rich get richer. This can be alleviated somewhat with various expansions, modifications or additions to the rules. The fan-made Civilisations of Catan is good for this.
Loved this game when I first got it, but I'm not as thrilled at the idea of playing it as much as I used to. A good game, just a little bland.
I've played with 3 and 5 players. It's always fun even with strangers as long as they are willing to talk, barter, and trade. It's not fun if they don't interact.
A classic that is often put down these days. I don't really see why, ok, it may not be the most exciting game in the world, but I think there's a bit more depth here than many realize.
Expansions Owned: The Great River 5-6 Player Extension Oil springs of catan
i do like this one quite a bit but it feels like i´m waiting for a better/newer version of it

Trading in the Mediterranean has never been so accessible. Fun, simple and great for families and new comers to the hobby. Set up time is a bit long, but generally worth the wait. The 5-6 player expansion is a must, and any other expansion is just icing on the brick and wool laden cake.
As time has passed, I have grown disinterested.  But I respect the game, and what it brings - plus it introduced me to eurogames.
The grandmother of all the board games somehow - or the game that introduced a new Level in board gaming (after Monopoly, Clue, Scrabble and those classics)
Solid game with good replayability. Another advantage in my mind is that many people already know the rules to the game.

ΠΟΛΛΟΙ ΤΟ ΚΑΤΑΚΡΙΝΟΥΝ!!εγω δεν θα παψω να το αγαπω! ηταν το πρωτο που εμαθα να παιζω,θεωρω οτι θελει καλη στρατηγικη για την καλυτερη αναπτυξη κ εξαπλωση οικισμων κ πολεων στο ταμπλο κι ας παιζει μεγαλο ρολο η τυχη..αν δεν εχεις στρατηγικη η τυχη δεν μπορει να κανει τιποτα!!

A modern classic that we enjoy the trade element to and as relative new gamers our collection needed this to show to other newbies....tried the 2 player variant and perhaps wouldn't again, but a strong game with 3 or 4 players.
Great gateway game to euro games after someone has played Ticket to Ride.

great game for everyone and every mood simple to understand rules totally random setup to keep replays fresh enough rules to keep play fair, keeping luck's impact on the whole game relatively low. a staple of every board game home quality pieces and board  This game has enough interaction of players to feel competitive but you wont be at each others throats(usualy).  Our generation's monopoly, everyone should be expected to have it kinda situation.

Fun game with easy to understand rules. Most fun with 4 players. Luck is involved however you also require some tactics in order to win. It's not all up to the dice. Do note that the further you get the less willing your opponents are in trading resources with you. :)
Very luck driven but an enjoyable classic

Probably the most significant board game created in the last 50 years. A classic. You want to trade a sheep for a brick? No! Aww. Has awesome interaction around the table when someone is looking to trade goods for other goods.

Previously played Catan online many years back a lot (a LOT!), and decided to buy a physical copy for my playing group which consists of my partner, my family and/or her family, and my friend (who is a gamer) for the following reasons:  1. Good components - components are excellent, and the hexagonal map is modular allowing for different set-ups each time [variability]  2. Mechanics - well thought out and put together, which work really well with the theme, and more importantly has a fair degree of player interaction even during other players turns  3. Simple and logical rules - concise and build upon the theme and mechanics. Very cohesive  4. Interaction - fair degree of player interaction through trading, blocking roads, and moving the robber  It may be fashionable in some quarters to bash Settlers for its success and market penetration, it still holds up as a worthwhile game (unless you detest any form of luck in games), is still relevant, worthwhile, and fun to play now.   Catan is no longer an automatic shoe-in as the default gateway game (testament to the vast range of excellent games available), however it is a worthwhile choice as a gateway game. One that I still enjoy playing on occasion.

It's a bit cliché but this is the game that started it all for me. I first played it circa 2000, bought a copy a few years later and have used it to introduce many others to board gaming since then.  [blogpost=38804]Not quite a review[/blogpost]
Great gateway game. Luck heavy. A lot of player interaction means I'll almost always play even if it's not the most in depth strategically.
Classic. Nice mix of luck and strategy.  Good for the family - my kids regularly beat me (though I get in my wins too).
Deserves it's classic status, but let's be honest, we'd rather play a million other things.
Gateway game for resource allocation that appeals to a wide audience.

The classic that got me into tabletop gaming. Probably more of a nostalgia rating than overall play rating, but still always willing to go back and play more. Those dice sure can be cruel sometimes but nothing is better than getting your winning resources off 3 cities around a 12 just cause you were that guy...
The Settlers of Catan ‐ English third edition 2003 with color rules and card box.

After playing on and off for years on various phone/tablets, I broke down and bought the board game to play with my kids.  It's too heady for my 5-year-old, but both my 7 and 10 year old daughters enjoyed it.  The game, which runs a little longer than some of our favorites (Forbidden Island, Ticket To Ride) was perfect for myself and the 10-year-old.  The 7-year-old had a good time but was a bit jacked up during play.  I'm not sure if it was because she was losing interest or just being 7.  Either way, we completed the first game and I got a thumb's up from both kids.    Update, in future game plays, both the 7 and 10 year old had a good time.  Once they fully understood the game, what it takes to win, and could estimate how much time was left (because the youngest gets a bit bored), it became more enjoyable.  Since they like this game, I'm thinking Stone Age will be our next purchase.

Simple to learn fun game with a simple game mechanic.  The strategy relies on playing the odds and bargaining, while not giving away the farm, so to speak.  While learning the game is simple, the strategy has depths to it that grow as the players better understand the consequences of their choices.  Expect to buy the 5-6 player expansion along with this game as a requirement.

Classic, our family will play it when nothing else catches our interest. We have it on tablets and computer so it's not always quick to make the table. We don't have any expansions but I know it would increase replayability
It's always unforgiving and brutal for at least one player.

Classic game, and a great gateway game. However, depending on the random tile placement during setup, the first one or two players to place their starting pieces may have a huge advantage right away, and the others may have no recourse to catch up.
pro: fairly simple to learn family game con: too much luck driven

Everyones first "Real" modern designer board game after stepping away from the Monopoly's and the Risk's.  Really good for the social side of gaming. In fact a game without that particular social aspect, heavily emphasised in Catan, would leave me quite empty.
Great gateway game. Also, most people who aren't gamers have actually heard of it.
This is a classic for a reason, enjoy trading, goes over well with everyone played with.

This is the game that got me hooked into the modern world of boardgaming. This is my go to entry game when playing with a new group of players. While this isn't the game that I want to get out to the table all the time, I always have a good time playing the game.

Probably the modern board game many people have played on their first try.  A bit more balanced with 3 players rather than 4, as the map becomes crowded quickly.  Still a good entrance into the modern board game concept.
I enjoy playing Catan.  Not as much as Cities and Knights but still enjoyable.
Catan is the game that got me into it, however I still love to play a game of it. Not a whole lot to say.

I've probably played this a hundred times by now and while I'll still play it, it's never going to be my first choice. There's a lot of luck involved, which can be frustrating but also can make for memorable games and really dramatic moments. For a more "even" game, it's easy to swap in a card deck for die rolls but I feel like the game loses some charm this way. Annoyingly, in a game where the ideal choice is usually fairly obvious, there tends to be a lot of analysis paralysis when newer players know they can work out the odds but take a long time to do so. Having a "longest turn" card which subtracts VPs is a great addition when everyone has similar levels of experience with the game.
Paul 8: very good game. Lucy 7: one of my all time favourites.
Great game, but I always want to play different games instead of this.
A good game, but just too long for me...
Gameplay Rating: 7.5  Enjoyment Factor: 7.5  Overall Rating: 7.5
My gateway game. The game that got me into this hobby. Family still loves to play it and asks for it regularly.
One of those entry level games where it is fun for the first few games, but you begin to see its flaws. Still enjoyable to introduce new table top players to it.

Catan is a must have for pretty much everyone. It's a great resource game and the trading aspect is always fun. I have never had a bad time with it and luckily it is toward the lower end of learning curves to you can show people the game early.
I wish I had a bigger gaming group so I could get more play time out of Catan really fun game and would love to play more.

Rating is average based upon 2 plays. First play was a straight 10, awesome experience and  perhaps my first introduction to modern games. I did not own a copy at this time.  Second play was recently, 3 or so years later. This game fell flat but I think some of the blame may be on the other players for becoming too intoxicated to pay attention :/ . We did not finish this play...
It's a classic now, isn't it? It's not without its problems, but it's still a good game and if not worthy of the hype, it is still quite, quite solid.
First game ive played at Spellenspektakel in Eindhoven in 1997

One of the first Euro-style games I've played, and it is still one of the best introductory board games out there. It offers a great balance of luck and skill – but that isn't to say the dice can completely ruin a game's fun.  I love that the game offers a way to mitigate the amount of luck involved by allowing players the opportunity to spread their settlements across all options, granting them access to each of the possible die rolls. Trading is fun and keeps players interacting with one another.   The modular board creates a new game every time.  Really, this game covers a lot of aspects that are present in hundreds of Euro-style games. If I have a friend who wants to get into board games, I will almost always introduce them to this one first.
Let me be honest, this is a great game. But now there are better in the same genre.
Fantastic civilisation development game. Variable board and luck elements keep it interesting.
This is a great game.  I don't know why we don't play it more often.  That being said, 6 players is too many. Takes a couple hours, and progress is slow.

(11 plays)   I like the game a lot but there's so many more doors to be opened in this hobby, that I don't see myself playing this again unless it's for recruitment purposes.  01/20/16: Played it again after a long time and I really enjoyed it. Hunting down a copy of the Seafarers expansion now. Feels good to be excited with this game again. It's a one of a king experience and am glad that my g/f talked me into keeping it. More to come after I try Seafarers.

I added this to my collection in June of 2010. This was the first game I played of the more modern games. It led me from the world of Risk, Monopoly, Clue, Life, and other classic games to a whole new world. The map is random and changes each time you play it. Build roads to expand your influence and built more towns. The dice determine the game play but there is some strategy involved. Trade with other players but be careful not to have too many resources or you may have to give some up if someone rolls a 7. Focus on getting the longest road or building the largest army. Winner is the first person to 10 points. Great 1.5 hour to 2 hour game for beginners. Seasoned players may take 1 to 1.5 hours. Played well with 3-6 players.
BGG Rank on 18/01/2017:222 Wooden version of Catan ! Everybody knows this game no ?
Good to play with friends and to destroy friendships and relationships when people don't want to trade with each other. The most manipulator will win the game

One of my groups go-to's. Always fun, with a fairly quick learning curve, and with a decent amount of strategic based competitive play. It took two years of playing it before I decided to pick up an expansion...and I still feel like we've only scratched the surface of the base game.

My favourite aspect is the negotiations. I haven’t seen that a lot in resource management/engine building games. Catan does everything else pretty well. The dice rolling keeps it light and fun, but a streak of poor rolls can be frustrating because it is a competitive game that can go a little long.  Collection: Dispensable
As the game sessions I've been in allowed for a lot of social interaction, I'm not sure if the game was the star, or if the uncomplicated and low stress nature of the game was the star.
Le jeu de colonisation de référence. L'ajout d'extension est fortement recommandé, principalement "Villes et Chevaliers".
The game that brought me to modern games it will forever have my thanks and respect.
Ok, lehet, hogy jó belépő-szintű játék, de én most játszottam vele először, és így valahogy annyira nem jött be. Túl sok múlik a dobásokon, de egy amerihez képest meg túl puritán...
Like many people, this is the game that brought me into the hobby. Very fun, love the simple resources but no longer play very often, maybe once every year.

The game that really got me into board-games - it will always have a special place in my collection as a result. My family adore it too, so have clocked up nearly 40 plays over the last 6 months or so. Works with 3 and 5 (with the expansion), but definitely shines brightest with 4 players.
Very simplistic, classic game. My wife is unstoppable and always wins.
One of the classics, and probably one that belongs on everyone's collection.
A solid classic. Good game that easy to learn, easy to play, and has a feeling of accomplishment when you win.

It's still as fun as ever.  Will I ever play again?  Probably.  After the burn out wears off a bit, when my children are old enough to teach it too.  I'm sure I'll enjoy every minute of playing with them.  It's Catan.  Classic.

Played every Sunday night with kids and foreign exchange students for quite awhile and everyone had a blast. Take too long on your turn in any game and you are now called Caesar because of the french kid. ;0.
My first foray into modern games. We've played the base game with Cities & Knights well over 50 times.
A classic that keeps standing the test of time. It’s mostly a negotiation game, with some mild take that. A keeper. Recomended.

"Die Siedler von Catan" - quasi der Urvater des modernen Eurogames und das Spiel, was Brettspielen salonfähigk gemacht hat. Es ist auch heute noch ein tolles Spiel und kann sich gegen moderne Vertreter durchaus behaupten. Und wer diesen Klassiker noch nie gespielt hat, sollte das unbedingt nachholen.Viele Mechaniken, die heute fast schon "Standard" sind, wurden hier eingeführt. Der Eine oder Andere wird sich eventuell am hohen Glücksfaktor (Würfelwurf = Ressourcenvergabe) stören, trotzdem wird "Siedler" ein Spiel sein, was man auch in 10 oder 20 Jahren noch auf den Tisch bringen wird.
Best with 4 players! Does not scale well! Great intro game! Its what got me into this hobby!
Wood for sheep, won't anyone give me wood for sheep?  I haven't played it with real people in several months, but I do play the android version on my phone every now and then.

Bought the game and 4-6 player expansion for $50-$70 (I forget) MANY years ago. After many games, I started to keep a Hall Of Fame paper where we recorded: Game Length, # of Players, Who won and what position did they place, and Least and Most common Dice Roll #. We have 91 games that we kept record of on the HOF (I won 41 of them :) ). I have played over 100 games of Catan. This has been one of the best game purchases I've ever made.   BUT, that was years ago. Back then, this game was a 10 easy. Now, with the way games are changing and new mechanics being created, I'd say it's a 7. We still play it, but it doesn't get chosen many times (perhaps because we've played it so many times).  Couple notes: My gaming group and family aren't big fans of chance, luck/lack of luck, or ganging up on. Therefore, most of the time we played without trading. This was mainly to stop bad players from giving the person winning what they needed to win... Too many times I'd be winning and I'd convince a silly player to trade me a terrible trade and game over. It's not much fun when that happens.  Another variant we did was, we played a lot of game (maybe 50%) without the thief. If you rolled a 7, you just picked someone to steal from.   Another variant we ALWAYS played with, and I think this helps the game, is that you could negotiate. If you're about to be stolen from, you can ask the thief "what do you want?" He says "wood", you hand him a wood and thus protect your other precious resources. OR he says "wood" and you need wood, so you say "good luck" and then he picks randomly. This addition was always nice to have.   When we played with the thief, you could negotiate with the thief and say, "I'll give you what you want IF you block my 12 and not my 6" etc... this rule is also great. Everyone is happy. Of course sometimes the thief says, "nice try" and just smacks the thief down on your 6 that has 3 cities on it. BOOM.  So, if you haven't played the game before. Get it. Play it. You'll enjoy it. I don't think you'll get 100 games out of it like I did, but you'll get some good mileage on it.
My gateway and one of my son's favorite games...love to play it! A classic!

A great game to have a couple over and play during a conversation.  It's either Ticket to Ride or this for that purpose.  Sometimes I'd rather roll dice.  I didn't have this years ago so it hasn't lost its charm.

A great game that keeps hitting the table for it's simplicity and easy set up. This is the gateway game for new board game groups. Highly addicting initially, and still a good time after many plays. There's a lot of luck and it can be frustrating when your resources are not rolled or when you get hopelessly blocked in. A good strategy will only take you so far. I suppose this is what makes it good and fair for experienced and new gamers. If you like it and want an expansion then the best one is Catan Cities and Knights hands down. You don't need any other expansion and in fact many of them don't combine well.

Pros: gateway strategy game, network building integrated with resource management, direct player interaction with trading mechanic, variable board set-up, high replayability  Cons: high level of luck, trading mechanism sometimes falls flat  Like so many other people, this was my gateway game to REAL board games. After so many years, it is still one of the first considerations for game night!

For myself and many others, Catan was the 'gateway drug' that got me immersed into the hobby of strategic board games after previously only being exposed to overplayed 'Classics' like Monopoly or Risk, party games like Cranium and Trivial Pursuit, or a couple of complicated war games that took an entire day to play if you were lucky.  Catan (or Settlers of Catan when I first played it) hits a lot of key areas for a great board game - easy to understand and teach rules, excellent replayability with the board being different for each game, relatively short time period with games averaging 45-60 minutes, a variety of potential strategies and paths to victory, a lot of player interaction with trading, and gameplay that typically keeps all players with a shot at victory up to the very end. The only real knock against Catan may be it's theme - which can be a little vague (I guess it's early Medieval settlers on a newly discovered island??) and not necessarily the most appealing - and can feel a little tacked on (there's a reason why there are so many alternative versions of Catan - like Star Trek Catan).  But overall, this is an excellent game board game that is easily accessible to casual board-gamers and is definitely an essential part of any collection.  Adding to its value, there are also a variety of expansions that layer additional elements on top of the basic set.  By far the best expansion is Cities and Knights, which practically transforms Catan to a different game - while maintaining the same core mechanics.
Type: Euro Style Strategy  Mechanics: Hand Management, Modular Board, Trading, Dice Rolling  Players: 2 - 6

Still a good game. Replayability is high, but it suffers from low player interaction (besides blocking & trading). The mechanics are solid however and so many better games have been built upon this one. 10 when i first bought it, 9 in 2006. Talk about a game that stands the test of time though. Still a good game to introduce your friends to gaming.

+1.5 strategy outweighs rule-book (Beginners seem to take to this game wonderfully) +1 'Engine building' aspects are enjoyable +1 good balance of "just doing my thing over here" and "take that!" mechanics which appeal to a broad range of players +1 trading mechanic adds a whole layer of depth and strategy.  +1 apparently very replayable (been a staple of a couple of my groups for years) which brings its rating up since I first owned it  -1 (up from .5 - more I play, the more playtime seems to lag) not the lightest game, with a little setup and a few minutes teaching time and an hour or  so to play -1 players who make bad decisions early on can be left with little to do for almost an entire game. Predefined placements and pips for statistical likelihood help.  -1 For whatever reason, this game seems to lead to more saltiness and hurt feelings than other games. Possibly the bluntness of the mechanics, possibly the fact that 'entirely do my own thing' is only an option for so long/if at all.   A classic for a reason. May lose points over the years, but hasn't as of yet. Still the first boxed game I show new players.

A modern classic, involving planning, negotiation, and a bit of chance. I'm not really fond of the trading aspect, but as long as you're not playing with people who constantly try to cajole you into making unfavorable trades, or people who just make any trade they're offered to be nice, it works fine in Settlers.  Expansions add flavor but also length. Usually not a worthwhile trade-off for my tastes. If you fall behind in the base game, the end is not so far away, if you fall behind when using expansions, a significant portion of your life passes while you wait for the end.

2008-04-05   Dave Loved the game and pushed for a 2nd, 3rd and 4th game - all with the basic setup but swapping colours for the 3rd/4th.  We all won once, Dave also winning a 2nd time.  The trading is the main means of interaction but being able to block off opponents' settlements and striving to win the Longest road card  Luck is a strong factor in deciding the victor, but I think a better player would win more times.   Strong similarities to Monopoly - the shared board, gathering cards, trading, the 'building an empire' theme - but with tons of advantages (trading more strongly necessiated by the mechanics, opportunities to take down the leader, no knockouts)... I can understand why this game was the one to introduce Eurogaming to America.  Incidentally, the board was slightly bent and caused much aggro.

Asking for wood never gets old either.  The game is easy to teach and easy to play, I understand how it can be such a good intro game (or even a casual game).   Expansions are nice as well - I like Cities and Knights and would prefer to play that variant all the time. Unfortunately it is difficult to add these new rules with the people who I play Catan with.   On a regular night with my group, this game would not come out. I find myself neglecting Catan in favour of newer and more shiny games, but it really is a classic.  It's not that it's the best game or my favourite game, but (along with Carcassonne and Ticket to Ride) it feels a bit like the Monopoly or Risk of the modern generation of games.  It's got a fair bit of luck, but also a fair bit of choice - it's not a 'heavy' game that will go on for hours, but you do have a sense of building something and your island will look differently at the end (and start) of each game.  It's a good solid game.

Total Score: 7.1 (Does BGG even let you rate Catan lower than a 7?)  -Enjoyment - 7.5 Really enjoyed this game each time I have played it. Sometimes enjoyment can be subject to dice rolls OR whether or not people at your table are willing to barter.   -Components - 7 I have the Catan version from 1904 (or something like that) and even then they understood the important of Wooden bits! I've never seen sexier Octagons (Hexagons? Decagons?) I can't remember how many sides there are off the top of my head. Sue me.   -"Tableability" - 7 Easy, peezy, lemon squeezy. Set it up ahead of time for -1 to your potential new game friends intimidation level.   -Eagerness to Replay - 7 This game has been banned from the table by the last group I played with, apparently they didn't like the monoply I established on sheep. I told them it was my baaaaaaaaaad, they weren't as amused as me. I'd like to play again. Hey you, yea you, will you play Catan with me?  -Mechanics - 6.9999 Sometimes you love it, the other times the dice work against you. Even my wooden dice from the 1800s still hate me sometimes. There was a time when I would have given a dice chucker a 9 or so, but I've seen the world and I'm an enlightened man now.

A very weird mix of a party game and a strategic board control game. This mix does more harm than good mechanically, making it very easy for tensions to inflame as a lot of the players butt heads with each other over the distinction between arbitrary jokes and strategic bullying, leading to an aggressive play experience for certain sorts of people. Nevertheless, played in the right setting with the right mindset, Catan is a ton of fun. The cross table banter, fast pace, and easy to learn rules make come together for a hilarious and fun time.

Many call it the gateway game. This opened my eyes to the Germanic Victory Point styled game and I have never looked back. An all time classic and favorite in my book. I actually have enough catan pieces to play up to 10 players at once. You can get custom colored pieces at boardgamebits.com.
Classic game.  Would love to play this once or twice a year.  This was one of the games that helped push me into designer boardgames.
The duration is too long for such a game. It always took 2 hours to play. But it is fun.
It´s the game that got me interested in board games. It will never leave my collection, but there are a lot of games I like a lot better end therefore we only play it 2-3 times a year
Classic. My family overplays it a bit, but still solid.  Theme (x3): 6  Art (x2): 6  Balance (x3): 7  Gameplay (x4): 8  Accessibility (x1): 9  Overall Fun/Experience (x5): 7      Total: 7.06
Nice game that wins a lot with his expansions, they give the game many possibilities.
Probably "the" gateway game and a classic. The theme and mechanism work well but to date there are better games to be played...
A good game, but it gets a little mechanical at time, like you're just going through the motions.
Best with three players (unless using Seafarers) and 12 points for the win.
Excellent. I prefer the original German artwork to the Mayfair art, it gives a more Medieval feel, more suited to the game.  Haven't enjoyed the expansions as much as the pure game.
Never met a person who did not like Settlers the first time they played it.
genious playing concept: building and trading (I only play cities and knights), problem: dice = luck (ever seen the 12 three times in 5 consecutive rounds?)
Good social game, which wins a lot with the additions - particularly Cities and Knights
This was the game that got me started in German gaming.  I enjoy playing it but do not play it to often now.
A very nice game, but maybe just a bit to simple to be a real brainbuster. But very playable and replayable!
The one that got me going again...
This game has all the ingredients for an awesome game. High player interaction, little downtime, easy to teach and learn and replay value does changes with different strategies. Highly recommended
I love how my gamer friends and non-gamer friends can both play this game and enjoy themselves.  I love the trading.  Excellent production values.
teritorial control and resource allocation game with a few random elements. Not as popular as it once was. Never really took off with our group.
There are sufficient rave reviews of this game on BGG without me going into detail - a great game
Classic, but seems our games turn into the same game all the time.  Better with the 6 player expansion pack.
I think I've just about played out the original version.  I now find it to be much better with either of the expansions.
The game that made me look into foreign board games seriously. Gives you a "craps" feel when you are rolling dem bones.

my first imported euro (Mayfair '96 version, bought right when it came out), not really a gateway for me as I had been playing games for years already, 1 of my 3 "Bring 'em into the hobby" games" as my intro to the world of games beyond what most people know
I am the baron of mutton!
Perhaps a litte bit too random and dice oriented. Still good fun.
Good game.There is too much luck,and one player can be out of the game earlier if he is in a bad position on the board
Definitely a classic.  The proto-typical German game.  It's spawned way too many expansions, and I am definitely tired of it, but it deserves its rating.
Great game, but there's a bit too much of a luck factor.
Great game till you start to play the expansions and starfarers editions.  Still a nice introduction game for non-experienced gamers.
I am going to start playing it with the Deck Of Dice.
A nice game and the varying board makes sure no two games are ever like.

Really nice. Good and simple play logic. Nice pictures. Fast Enough.  Bad: it need really high attention with starting position or you could have big problems advancing in game. Expert player have a huge advantage.
This was the best game going for a long time...I've logged a lot of hours playing this, as well as expanded or alternate versions.
Pretty much the German Game Classic.
Great game.  Really broke a lot of people into the greatness of German board games.

Settlers got me started on German games, plays well, and remains close to my heart.  I remember playing when it first came to the US and really liking it.  Now, however, I don't really feel the need to play again.

A nice game to transform easily the non-players into addicts (or at least non-anti-games people). The main drawbacks are the number of players (3 or 4 but the extension exists) and the fact that the random can have too much impact...
I think getting resources is too hard if the dice aren't rolling your way. But, I still like game. It's a good introductory game for newbie's.
Update 2014-01-25: Had to lower the rating for unadorned Settlers. Quite a bit better with various expansions. Even with the new Helpers personality cards.
The gateway drug of boardgames; although there are better games, this familiar favourite still sees lots of play.

Good family/filler game that has high replay value.  Although I'm sick of this game now I have to admit it is because I've played it nearly 100 times.  The substantial luck factor can be frustrating but also leads to a lot of the game's replay value.  Substantial luck factor due to using two dice to determine which area produces.

More players can play if more than on game is combined.  Build roads and cities to gain points.  roads and cities are built using resources.  Resouces are collected based on where your cities are placed.

The game that got me into this hobby. Already a classic. A bit too much randomness has caused it to lose some of its appeal but it still stands out as an excellent design. Endless variations and spin-offs show off the strength of the original system.
Mayfair Edition.  Good game marred by problem where some players can be basically out of the game from the begining because of bad positioning.  Can be fixed by variants, though.
Fun game always thought it was better with 3 than 4.
Saw a lot of play until nobody could stop me from winning.  I was unbeaten for about five (infrequent) years; I just lost interest.  Still a classic, but I hunger for newer horizons.
I think I've played this one too much. When I discovered it, it probably was a 9 but now I can't say I'm eager to get it out.
Very good game.  If you fall behind early, it can be very boring though.

The first german game I played. Settlers of Catan racked up a lot of playtime a couple of years ago, but I'm not as fond of it anymore than I used to. The dice affect the game pretty much and the negotiation/trading phase often drags for an unnecessarily long time. I don't see this as THE introductory game for new players anymore. There are lots of better options out there nowadays.
Can be frustrating at times when useful resources are scarce, but it's still a great game.  And it's easy to learn and play too, which can't be bad!
Still fun. A little light, a little lucky, but a good way to spend times with family and newer gamers.
Wish it were two-thirds the length of what it is. I prefer Attika, which has a similar feel, a shorter length, and a bit more complexity.

We played this game many, many times when jas0 first got it. Moved on to Seafarers, then to other games, then added Cities & Knights. The only time we play Settlers on its own now is when we're trying to recruit new players. A fantastic idea, although still a little luck-happy IMHO.
You will always find people for playing, but it plays well with 4 players only

Too much luck and the game can get bogged down with the random setup. Also, once a player is behind and choked off by roads it’s quite a boring trip to the endgame. That said, the negotiation aspect of this game is amazing and what draws me back. Every seasoned gamer should own a copy of Settlers for the sole purpose of introducing friends to real board games.
Good, but maybe a bit more random than I like.
The new monopoly... for strategy boardgames.  Look for this baby to be around for quite awhile.  Notice I didn't say that would be a good thing!  :(
This is one of the greatest games ever designed.  The game is beautiful in it's simplicity.  The only reason I rate it down is that my wife makes me play it too much.
Great with kids good with adults
This game is okay, but not great. Too often you seem to get stuck in situations  where you simply can't get the resource you need. And the thief, while a clever idea, feels like an arbitrary penalty.

The one that started my "modern era" of boardgaming for me, and I still enjoy it, in spite of fairly frequent play.  What caught my attention immediately was the lack of downtime. Even if it wasn't your turn, you were actively involved in resource gathering and trades -- pretty revolutionary at the time.  Also the first modern game I got my parents to play willingly.  Pretty much the prototype of "make the best of what you get" games, which I particularly enjoy.

The meat and potatoes of the eurogames.  A must in everyone's collection.  I'm a bit tired of it now, but I never refuse anyone a game.  I might try to convince them to play something else...but I still enjoy this one.
My son loves this, the daughter likes it, I don't mind, but the wife is resisting.
I don't look forward much to playing this any more. It's long for what it delivers.

It's hard to score this game as although its gameplay value is beyond dispute, the level of inherent randomness is way too high for most players. As a result, once every player is in possession of the fundamental skills needed to play, the winner is pretty much decided by the roll of the dice. Try substituting cards for the dice to cut down on the luck factor.  On the other hand, this game is just so much plain old fun that it is hard for me (and everyone else) to keep from playing from time to time. Just don't take it too seriously. This game is never followed by sessions of analyzing who did what wrong or right, if you know what I mean. Real solid games are almost always followed up by such discussions in our group. This is not such a game.
A classic, but not one I am looking to play soon.
Fun game with just the right amount of player interaction, but easy to get screwed by bad die rolls.  I got very burned out on this game after playing extensively 1996-1999.
Too much luck. Good game to coax people away from Monopoly and Risk, but only a starter to the strategy genre, not the main course.

When I got this game I really enjoyed it. However at this point I rather play a deeper game when with gaming friends, with more decision making. With non-gamer friends this game is good, but I prefer playing a game like Ticket to Ride or Shadows over Camelot, who's rules and strategies seem easier to grasp for many people.
This is a staple game in my group of gamers.  We've played it for years, which is why I didn't rank it higher.  Perhaps we have overplayed it a bit.
became boring after too short because of it's very-easy mechanics and it's "commercial" attitude. a german masterpiece for everyone, very better with the expansion cities & knights
Highly recommendable, for gamers and non-gamers alike. The basic version gets boring if you play it too often - get the expansions!
One of my favourites. The only problem is that you can get cornered quite badly and spend the rest of the game just trying not finish last.
Wish there was something in there that could somehow help the players to catch up to the leader.  Great game except for the last turns which usually have a predetermined outcome.
My intro into german style games.  Good game.  The only problem is a few bad rolls can leave you with nothing to do, especially since my dice apparently don't like to play this game. :)
First Klaus Teuber. First Kosmos. First Mayfair.
Too long for what it is, but still a classic.  The Monopoly of a new generation.
Fun game.  The expansions make this game much more playable!
Great fun with my group.  From the negative comments I've seen, this might change with another group or if we play it to death, but right now, it is still enjoyable.

I am lowering my rating on Settlers to a more appropriate level, considering my current gaming tastes. While I admire what the series has done for the hobby, I no longer consider it the classic I once did. It is a good game, and a sound basis for other games, but the original vanilla game is no longer that appealing to me as more than a gateway game.

Pros
- Random board
- Trading & piece placement strategies

Cons
- Luck factor
- Expensive
- Requires expansion for 5-6 players
My wife's favorite game (and me too)
There're better games out there now, but Settlers remains strong.
The introduction for most in to the world of german/euro games. A good game. There is so much more about these days that this one does not get played as much as it did.

As with many others, Settlers was my gateway game to the Euro invasion.  And while I have not recently played this one nearly as much as in the past, it is still one of my favorite.  Hint: Scrutinize your your initial placements.  Trade to your best advantage (duh!).  And while there is a heavy luck element involved, plan several turns ahead the best that you can, i.e. watch who has been collecting what.

I am tempted to give it a 6 but that was only because when I bought it the game was sitting second in the world ratings chart I use. Therefore compared to E&T or El Grande it was a big dissappointment. However for a lighter strategy game it has grown on me. I guess I can see why people like it. My friends certainly do.
Good basic boardgame--light, easy to learn.

This is an excellent game to introduce new gamers to the realm of serious gaming. I love the entire make up of the game and in theory it is one of the best games available. However, the luck involved in gaining resources can be extremely frustrating at times.
You roll dice, you trade.  I'm Settler'ed out, otherwise I'd rate it higher.

We normally play with Cities and Knights and Seafarers.  We build the normal central island, surrounded by a ring of water, surround by 4 sets of 3 hex islands face down.  The outer islands are 2 of each resource and 2 gold mines and are revealed when a ship is placed next to the one.  The 'Intrigue' card may be used to move the pirate.  You need 15 points to win.

Little too much luck for me but the game board and game mechanic however are second to none.  Allows for ruthless play that tends to keep games exciting but also does suffer from follow the leader syndrome.  It's basically a must buy for anyone that calls themselves a gamer as it is the staple to which all other games are compared.

awesome game that is different everytime you play. losts of player interaction, and well balanced, doesn't get old - it's kind a gotten swept under the rug, since we haven't played in 1.5 years. But still great, and will be the next time we play it.

I've owned this game since 2004 and FINALLY got around to playing it (not even on my copy). I get what all the hoopla is about.  A pretty quick playing time, a lot of strategy, and while there is a huge luck element, I think that there are enough die rolls that it will generally even out over time.  I want to play this many more times.
I much prefer Starfarer's over the original.
A classic, but I don't play it very often. If you get a bad start you're lost.
Old and random, but nice, simple, and fairly quick resource management.
A 7 for me. Thanks for having brought me in the new generation of boardgame world.
Good, solid, a great introduction into the world of better boardgames. This is a must-have for any game fan, and though I play it less as time goes on, I will never lose the love I have for it.

Yes, this is as good as people say it is but overplay it and, if you are like me, you will tire of it. Nice player interaction and a good introdutory game for new gamers - not as good as Ticket to Ride as an introductory game though, in my opinion.

My gateway game, and still an amazing piece of work.  I just seem to have some of the worst luck with dice when playing this game, which frustrates me in comparison to other games like Power Grid, Puerto Rico, etc.
Although a classic I haven't played it too often yet
One of the games that got me back into boardgaming (this happened a couple of times in my life)... Loved it for that, but I hardly play it anymore...

Great game to play with non-gamer types. Met one of my best friends over a game - I think he hated me after I asked him about a trade then played a robber to steal it instead. We still laugh about the incident now though. My group have never trusted me in any kind of backstabby game ever since ;)
Quite fun and exciting, but way too long. The luck factor is perhaps too large, and the gameplay is actually rather repetitive. (Based, perhaps surprisingly, on just one play.)
Classic.  This game got me started on "real" board games and ultimately to this site, etc.

Back in the days I would have rated this a '9'. Now I've just played this too much to be really enthusiastic about it. It's still a very good game and the modularity of the board makes the experience nicely varied. I don't really believe all the "it's too luck-dependent" -claims. Yes, there are dices and sometimes they can screw you really badly, but most of the time clever trading and building will make up for the dicerolls.
Just doesn´t excite me at all. Don´t mind playing it but too much abstraction and luck factor toreally enjoy it

My rating on this is perhaps lower than it should be. This is based on the fact that if your numbers don't get rolled, you can't do anything at all. This flaw can be a game-ruiner. This is fixed in the card version.
My rating jumps to 8 when this is played with Seafarers. But to 5 or 6 when you add Cities and Knights.
great fun, new gamers really like it.
One of the first euros I've played, and an undisputable classic. Repeated playings did hone some of the charm away, though.
Used to love it.  But after a few dozen plays, you know the best way to play.  So, among experienced players it's basically a 45-minute luck-based dice game.  But still good for kids and non-gamers.
Played this one like crazy... Now only interesting with with expanions, ohterwise too short.
A little bit too simple without add-ons.
good for new & old gamers, seems the bitching about dice rolls ruining the game has died down now... fun, doesn't outlast it's welcome.
A good game for negociation, especially for 4, but a bit limited and hazardous. Quite successful with a large audience, so a useful game to own...

Well, I haven't figured out the strategy of this game yet because I just got it and introduced it to our group, but we played it four times in the first sitting, so it must be good!  I think the Mayfair tiles are kind of wierd looking, so I gave it an 7.  Otherwise, gameplay, interaction and mechanics are very good, glad I purchased it after seeing it for years! Enjoy playing with my 7 and 10 year old.  A fun interesting strategy game that I can play with my children? Yes!
I have to rate this lower than most do, due to its relative lack of options and reliance on luck. Combine it with the Cities and Knights expansion though, and it's a solid 9!
Trading with people is where the real fun of this game lies. Sadly, my fellow gamers haven't figured that one out yet.

One of the coolest games out there.  great to introduce non-gamers to, I've never had anyone disappointed by this baby.  I prefer it with the Cities and Knights expansion, but by itself it's still pretty durn rockin'.
What is there to say about this amazing game that hasn't been said already?  It is the doorway from the Monopolies of the world into a sea of eye-opening thought-provoking games.
Significantly better with the Cities and Knights expansion.
The first non-retail chain game that I've played with friends.  And we still play, and I still have fun.

Perhaps the first German style game I ever played. Quickly got hooked on the truly unique system and gameplay and started yearning for more games of this type. Not only is it the game that got me hooked, but I've worn out one copy already. A "German" style classic.
SdJ 1995 DSP 1995 Good game.  Lousy Mayfair bits
Impression improved on this one, maybe still rising.
fun game to play with non-gaming friends. GEts better with cities and knights. With gamers, try something else
Settlers is the 2d German game I've ever played. I'll always have a fondness for it, and i prefer it with 3 or 4 to reduce the downtime.

Fun enough, but the loser is usually the guy who had a drought on the die rolls for a few turns, getting no resources. A little too much "string of bad luck dooms you" for my tastes, but still fun if you don't take it seriously.
After my third play. Entertaining and simpler than I expected. Not quite sure what all the fuss is about, though. I'd like to play again and also try the expansions and spin-offs.
Simple to understand and play, yet alot of fun. Great gateway game.
The Daddy of Board Games.  Simple yet effective, can play with anyone.

First German game I played. My wife likes this. Everyone I introducted to this game liked it. UPDATE: I'm leaning to just making this an intro-game for new gamers. King-maker effect is making me drop the rating from a 9 to a 7 with the ones used to the rules making it not fun at all.

I still enjoy the occasional play, but on the other hand I never really had an aha! moment that so many other gamers have had when being first introduced to this game. It's a good solid middle weight family game with a decent amount of player interaction and that's about it.
It's a great game and it's also easy to introduce to new gamers. The competition is always very tough.

By far the best money I ever spent on a game so far. Big time favorite at our house.  Dec 2015 - Got back to gaming this past year, only played Catan once. I dropped my rating from 8-7. I think my tastes have changed somewhat. Or perhaps grown. I'd much rather play Brass or Acquire.  PnP - card stand, custom colour bits
good intro to a new level of board games

Almost the best game I've ever played, but get tired of this being the ONLY game we play.  Some have not liked this game, but I'd say I have a 95% success rate in getting people turned onto games by teaching them this one.
The Settlers game to buy.  Forget the rest.

A very good trading game - and one that might attract females to games (I say this on the strength of it being one game that my daughter is happy to play, whereas my five sons have much wider tastes). One drawback is that it is difficult to peg back a leader: once they get their nose in front the game mechanics reward that with more resources.

A great game, and my first Eurogame. When people aren't constantly begging for trades that no one is interested in, it is a blast. Good player interaction, learns toward luck but strategy is also important.
my usual choice if i want to play with non-gamers

I heard a few bad things about dice rolling that discouraged me from getting it. Then I got it for christmas. And it's the best gift I got. A great game to introduce people to the field, it still holds up us fun and strategic after the initial fascination. 2012 edit - After years of plays it's still solid, but it's never in my top 5.

My gateway game as a youth (in the original German version), played very many times, and subsequently not top of my to play list this days. But I do still like it. Seafarers is a must - we also had Cities and Knights but I don't remember playing it much.
My start to board games. Have overplayed it so I only will play it occasionally.
It's ok.  I don't get the hype really.  There are many games that are better that just need a chance at mass distribution.  Still, very playable.
classic. everyone should own this game. Update:100210 Haven't played this game for years. What a fun game - and quick if everyone knows the game. Might like to table cities & knights again soon.
Originally I rated this a 9, but I guess I am getting tired of it and marked it as an 8 on 1/26/2005.

Not played very much any more. But still has a potensial after 10 years - especially as an introduction game no non gamers.  I prefer Anno 1701 Das Brettspiel or Anno 1503 over The Settlers, more options and less luck.

Lost some of its appeal after the thirtieth or fortieth play. It is certainly very addictive, but it's hard to convince myself I want to play it when compared to some of the more strategically deep games available.
Great game.  Made much better with the expansions.
This is the game that got me into the BG world. I loved BGs before this, but this one opened the german game world for me and I never looked back.

One of the VERY few games I like to play over the Internet more than in person.  Great game, but it's not so hard to get into a "no-win" situation, which makes that particular game not so fun. People who try to "beat dead horses" while trading can also slow things up.  I like this game, but it hasn't been very satisfying a decent percentage of the times I've played face to face.
A fantastic introduction to "German" gaming, and one which will keep them coming back for more.   Eventually the love affair is over, but you'll find yourself coming back for the occasional romp.
It used to be at least a 8, but now I'm a bit tired of it.. Still one of the best games ever.

This is the game that got me started on board games since August of 2004.  It also brought me to this website.  The game has been played more than three dozen times by family and friends, and we all enjoy it.  The luck factor regarding the dice makes it slightly less enjoyable than some other games.
I don't like it as much as I used to, but after a year away, it's grown on me again. Can't play it with more than 4 people, though.

I have always been a board game geek, but I lacked the people to play with as most of my friends are not in to gaming. I like to read about all the games, and see which ones I would like to play. Well, I took a chance on Settlers. I aquired a copy, and got 2 of my friends together ( the third guy backed out, he was tired ). Well, we all caught on to the game fast, and played it 4 times in a row, until it was just past 1 am. Each game was close, and we all loved it. This weekend, we are going to play again. This game is awesome!

My first Designer game, and I will be eternally grateful to it!  We played until 5am every day over Christmas for 10 days.  Unfortunately, too much luck involved for my preference nowadays.  It is still the best social/player interaction game I have (lots of discussion between players).

I think it is a great game, and I love to introduce it to newer player, but now, having played more than 300 games (including my online and mobile play), I can say that I'm ready for something else. But will never stop anyone to try this out. It's the one that brought me back to the hobby!!
Classic game that really does not need the expansions.
Great classic game, with my only beef being that once you fall behind, it's nearly impossible to catch-up (snowball effect).
When I first got this, I played it endlessly. Eventually, I got tired of it. Nothing wrong with it, I just burned out. I will pllay it if asked, but I won't ever suggest it.
I haven't played in a while, but it's a fine game to play with non-gamers, and got enough skill to it to keep me involved.

Bought this one on advice from this very board!  Thought it might be too complicated for my 8 year old, but it isn't.  She hasn't won yet, but she is getting more and more competitive with it.  Great game.
Not a bad game.  Found it doesn't have as much flavor as some of the other games I like, although still fun and strategic.

Players most accumulate 10 victory points through collecting various resources, building various structures, & trading with other players. I prefer to play this with 4 players as it offers more players to trade with.
The game that got me back to boardgaming, seemed great at the time. These days, I consider it a passable game. A good way to pass time with friends.

A good game, maybe too much "luck power" but still strategy has a great menaning unless your opponents rolls a "12" for 4 times in a row... The trading part is the best one, expecially in the beginning and mid game, when you still thrive for resources

High marks for getting me in to German board games, but this game can be complete agony!  Bad board position early can put you out of the running and then you just sit there for 60-90 minutes watching everyone else having fun.

Probably the most often played game I own, because there are always people willing to play this one. Guess I played it too often and am a bit annoyed that this game hits the table often instead of more interesting/complicated games. However, great game to begin with.

This isn't a game I enjoy much anymore, since it really just turns into a game of Yahtzee against good players.  But it is a game that is easy to teach to beginners, and so as an intro to german games, it serves an excellent purpose.
Quite impressed with this one.  Would probably rate it higher if I could get to play it more often.
I love the empire-building aspect of this, but the dice rolls can be infuriating. Sometimes the best strategy seems to be building on the 2/11/12 intersection!  Sold as I never played it any more.

Good game. Maybe a bit simple for my taste, but that is solved with the Cities & Knights expansion.  Played it a lot more in xbox live (good version of the game; it is faster and you always have people to play with).
Lovely game! Maybe a bit too random but it´s great to play with the kids.
classic. favourite of my gaming group
I've been playing this since it came out in the US, it starting to get old.
I haven't played it (I know, I know) but I am missing some of the pieces.
I've only played this a few times.  I think my rating would go up once I get a better feel for it.

The original that got me into Euro board gaming.  Fond memories of this one; my copy was ruined from someone spilling their drink on it. :(  Have played much better games since.  Still, I've been having fun with it recently, more than I remember.

A classic.  Like many, I cut my teeth on German games with this and I have played it the most times of any of them.  It has its faults - a bad choice at the beginning can make for a long and painful game and I have rarely seen a game so able to bring the Whiner out in everyone (myself included!).  But for all this, it still regularly comes to the table and is welcomed.  Still fun to play after many games.  UPDATE: downgraded to 7 from 8.  I will still happily play this game (provided I haven't played it too much recently) but I won't suggest it.  Though it is a classic, there are better games, games in which you can actually do something on every turn, where a poor run of dice rolls don't leave you out of the game.  I really want more involvement in my gaming, but I will still play basic Settlers.  Expansions however I am less enthusiastic...

A good game for introducing people to Euro style boardgames. The problem I have with this game is the luck element. The more you play this game, the more you realize, no matter how good your board position, cold dice can make for a long game.

Fell in love with this game as the first Eurogame I played.  Still think it is the best game to introduce 'Monopolists' to for converting them to better gaming.  Hard to go there with a group of gamers though when better alternatives for this number of players exist.  If we play it, we play it with one of the expansions.    Played it a lot before I started recording plays.
Great gateway game, but it suffers in repeat playings. While who wins ultimately depends on die rolls, the game always feels more or less determined when everyone has 3 settlements.

I really like this game, but recently I've found my enjoyment reduced a bit by the directness of the confrontation in the game.  I suspect I'll change my mind after a few weeks, but for now, I'm droping this a notch.

Played lots of time (both face-to-face and on BSW). While it is definitely an archetypal German game, and a significant one in the history of games, and although I used to play it a lot, it is not a favourite of mine any more. The basic system is quite good, and the randomness is not too much of a problem considering the whole game should not be too long.
It has a good, quick pace, and works well with three players. Too much luck, not enough strategy though. The best part of the game is picking your initial settlements.  ---- (bought)
Always an enjoyable experience, if not that exciting any more. Great for introducing non-gamers.
Nice tight little game.  6 Player Expansion
I have to admit that this moves a little slow for me now.  To refuse a game of game of Settler's seems sacriligious, sort of like wanting to beg off watching "Citizen Kane".
Settlers is a good game, but not the best.  Lots of luck involved and going first doesn't mean best placements.  Random number placement on tiles is usually more hurtful than beneficial.

Like many, Settlers was our first foray into board-gaming and to this day it's still a gem to play. The game's biggest draw for us is the player interaction - players gain resources out of turn if their numbers come up. Combine this with lots of resource trading and Settlers is a load of fun with little downtime.  I haven't played this game in years (we almost exclusively play 2P now). I'd have to revisit to see how it holds up.

A good game, certainly, though I've never quite worked out why it's as beloved as it is.  Too many turns where there just isn't anything to do if the dice are against you for it to be truly great in my book.

I'm revising my score for Settlers because the same end game keeps occurring - one player is out of the race and the other three are all within one turn of winning. I've probably hit a plateau with it.
basic game:               7 basic + seafarers:        8 basic + cities & knights: 9 basic + sf + c&k:        10

Great game overall.  A lot of folks say luck has too much of an impact, but after rolling the dice a few dozen times during the game, "luck" gives way to sound strategy.  This game hooks everyone who plays it.

The classic gateway game.  I don't play this one much anymore, but still enjoy it occasionally - especially with a group that knows what they are doing and will play quickly.  Though it was one of my firsts, I think that there are better intro games out there now.
Can be a lot of fun. I find it a a bit tedious after a while; while no two games are the same, the strategies do seem repetitive.
A good game, but I don't understand all the fuss.

This game is played the most in my gaming group, more like strange children of the neighborhood. :) They're not really into games although they really did enjoy Puerto Rico.  I think the simplicity of this game mixed with the strategy of placement and then the luck involved in rolling the dice make this game a great mix of the best of all games!
A nice lite game, but not for me.  The original picture artwork was much better than the "abstract" tiles in some later versions.
Usually fun. Well-liked by many people, and its strategy elememt applauded by gamers, but still more dependent on the luck of the dice than gamers would like to admit.
Have yet to play with the college crowd, but I enjoyed it with my brother.
Just about played out. Good for the first 50 plays or so, however.

My first "serious" game that introduced me to a new level of boardgames. I enjoy Settlers very much - the strategy and the edge. I like the interaction of the negotiating too. But the luck factor can hanker down on getting certain resources, and if no one else gets that resource either, it can halter the game a bit.
Great fun! One of our favorits if we play in groups (with not-all-day- gamers)!!!
It's good, if somewhat over-rated.  I never really seek to play it anymore, but will do so if there's nothing else around.
A classic. Not much more to say than has already been said elsewhere other than to reinforce the fact that this is truly a game that lives up to the hype. Clean, simple, replayable.
Still a modern classic of German board games. More random than some, but the fun factor and replayability keep it enjoyable.
The fact that all non-gamers love this has to be the biggest plus. When you get a group of gamers together play something else.
gambling... :( good idea, but as usual: dice kill the joy...
As with so many, this was my first Eurogame, way back in the mid 90's.  Fun, light, not a brain-burner by any means.
I have played this countless times. My first Eurogame. Great intro game for getting people interested in board games. Fantastic game with the right people if a bit random.
Simple, attractive fun with too much luck in the form of the robber. IMHO it should only be played with a die deck and 2 reshuffle cards unless you just want to play it with the kids.
still enjoy but played too many times, everyone who plays this for the first time loves it

A fun trading and social game as long as players don't start treating turns as though the honor of their ancestors is in jeopardy if they make the wrong choice between two virtually equivalent options.
Never gets played...wife likes it, but just too much luck. There are better gateway games now.
Classic, its an awesome gateway game.  Lots of player interaction.  A rather high luck factor though.
This is one of the first german games I played, and at the time it was a bit of a revelation.  Now I literally find it headache inducing.  Still, I always enjoy starting a game.
Prefer four players because I like the crowded board. Must be played in under an hour to be fun.

Ground breaking game.  I know people who have worn out thier copy of Settlers several times due to play. Extremely random game that I am not overly fond of. (I lose all the time, so that may be an issue :)  Also, any game that uses the phrases "I got wood for sheep!" or "I got wood for Rick...er...I mean brick" cannot be half bad.  Well, except maybe for Rick ...
Excellent comme jeu d'introduction aux jeux allemands.
Cool game. Some luck involved due to the dice roll but this can be mitigated with a good strategy.
Good, but I've played it too much
Fun game that plays pretty quickly.  The random board makes the replayability factor very high for me.
A long time favorite, but I've grown tired of playing.
Still enjoyable. Best thing is that we usually can get right down to it without explaining!
The classic one. The father of many games.
Good game.  I've found it tends to be one of the first that most people are introduced to in terms of strategic board games.
Good....not great to me. Still I'll play this anytime. Love the randomness of the board each time.

Yes, it's luck-heavy, the rich get richer, and you can therefore be severely crippled by bad dice rolls early.  But with experienced players it flies by, those things tend to even out over time, and you can learn to mitigate bad luck (to an extent).  The caprice of the dice is part of the charm, IMHO.  A great gateway to the hobby for many, this is the game my group broke out when we last expanded...it's sort of a baseline game for "gamers", giving the opportunity for some easy sociable play.  My kids have learned to love this game, too, and the fact that they can grow up with this rather than Monopoly means a lot to me.

Good game...will play it when asked - but it's just a bit too random for me to want to play it more.  It's good for non gamers - or Risk gamers as they might be more used to dice affecting the outcome more than I.
not my introduction to eurogames, but the first one i owned.

An excellent "gateway game".  Resource generation is random.  There is a runaway leader problem.  Our preference is to play with Cities and Knights, but that adds enough complexity to take it out of "gateway" status.
I like the game when played by four people with the expansion map. With this variation, the game may take quite a long time, though.
I have a love/hate relationship with this game. There will be times when I love it and want to play it all the time, but then I get bored with it eventually and never want to play it.
This is a game that we will play for a few months and then rotate it out for a while. Due to the random nature of the board it makes for great replay value.
This was our second game into the gaming world and kicked off us becoming more serious gamers. And we also used this game to catapult my family in PR that they love now.

What can anyone say about this game? I think that every board gamer should own it...You will always find people to play it and love it...The only disadvantages of the game are 1.the 4th and sometimes the 3rd place in the middle of the game are obvious and almost withdrawn from competition (they get bored...) basically due to 2. The starting positions are extremely crucial and if you make a mistake or you are cut off it's almost impossible to win and 3. Only 4 players can play it. Ok these disadvantages seem little serious but all in all the game is GREAT. Fun, arguments, strategic play, screwing others and negotiations guarantee a pleasant time, satisfaction in the end and multiple plays in the future...  PS For me it is also an entry into the more strategic games out there.
