Well, it was cool for a while, but it got old with us, still it`s one of the first Euro-games I bought.

Cities & Knights makes it a fair 8 for me. With just the Settlers it's down to a good start if you don't want to be left out later on. Still quite enjoyable. Cities & Knights adds much more to the good characteristics, that I rate that one higher.

Good fun, but it is always frustrating to some degree. I haven't played a game where someone isn't losing seriously and has little way of pulling things back. But when you're playing with experienced players it is still a lot of fun.
What can be said about this game that hasn't been said about it already.  Some luck, some skill, some trading... quite a game.

This game can be a lot of fun (especially if you win).  Great for getting non-gamers into European style games.  However, sometimes it really seems to drag and there can be some king-making issues and other times you just get screwed by the die roll which can be extremely frustrating while the rich are getting richer.
this is my first board game. classic strategy board game.simply play ,more strategy,medium luck factor..

My first German game, the allure died off only after two months of regular full day (read noon to the wee hours, we had sessions ending at 5 AM for a while there) play sessions with everyone I know and I have easily logged over 100 games of this. I still enjoy dragging this out every once in a while. Siedler mainly has a niche for the very casual atmosphere it creates, plenty of time for table talk, banter, and such during the game, one of the reasons it has such broad cross-over appeal methinks. I made the mistake of playing this with a deck of dice for a period of time, essentially trying to turn this into something that it shouldn't be, I'm back to the dice again, and the game has been getting some more play.  This game is interesting in that unlike most modern gateway games, it is actually very prone to position-destroying mistakes when you first set up the board and stake your initial claim. Most people who like it tend to play it a fair bit, especially when they first get it, and in that setting the random boards and initial set-up are a good deal of the allure, but it does tend to make the game a bit dicey when you mix "serious" gamers with newer players, as it is very easy to sink yourself with a poor initial placement and end up sitting around for the game doing a lot of nothing because of that. I would go so far as to say that the initial placement is at least half of the game, with another 1/4 being trading skills and board play and the final 1/4 being luck of the roll and development draw. Take it for what it's worth. I probably wouldn't like it as much as I do if I played it for the first time today, but I do have fond memories of this one and still enjoy pulling it out on occasion with the right group.
The randomness of the dice are it's greatest strength and weakness all in one.  Trade, trade, trade, and be prepared to be cutthroat if the opportunity presents.

After a couple plays I'd say this is a solid game with great replayability and most importantly, fun for the gamer and non-gamer alike.  However, the luck factor can frustrating.  There are few enough dice-roles in this game for there to be large devations from statistical normality.

Another fun intro german game.  One of my first on the suggestions of this website.  This and Carcassonne are the two games I like to play with non-gaming friends.  I really like the politics of the trade in this game! Updated to 7.5 from 7 after a couple years of playing.

This game is overrated. I like it a lot, and it's very fun. Also great to introduce non-gamers. But let's face it: it's barely less random than Monopoly. The endgame sucks.  ***UPDATE*** What's up with this game and my friends? They all seem to hate it now and I'm the only one to suggest it.

This was the first Euro game I was introduced to and I was hooked on the first play.  While I play it less frequently now as new games are brought into the mix I still look forward to playing this game

The classic German game.  The game is pretty simple compared to most other popular German games, but can still involve quite complex strategies in the form of trades and bluffing.  Trade is an essential part of the game, which means everyone's involved at all times, especially with five or six players.  It does have a fairly significant luck component, but competent players can hedge their bets.  A good choice for people just starting with German games.

Ah. The game that started it all. I find it fun and enjoy playing it. It does seem to take a bit long when you have the obsessive trader types in the group. NO, I WILL NOT TRADE YOU A BRICK FOR THE 9TH TIME. NEXT.
Great game for newbies and casual gamers. Veterans may not like it though.

After multiple plays, this game has started to grow on me.  I think the fact that I play it with what would be called "non gamers" has probably affected my enjoyment of the game.  Dunno.  Anyway, I'm happy the hype forced me to buy.

While a great game with three or four players, I really wish it was designed to work well with two players. However, lately I've been playing with the Borko two-player variant, which is simply excellent. It makes SoC playable by two.
Love at first play but, as I try more and more new games, my desire to play Settlers and its expansions decreases.
I like the trading aspect and the multiple avenues to victory, but the whole thing is very luck-dependent, and I also seem to lose every single game.
Best game to introduce Monopoly players to Euro-style gaming.
I like this game its quick and fun although you can get a behind if the dice arent nice to you but its good fun.
Classic game. Solid game play.  Overall pretty bland though.  Using expansions makes this game far too long and repetitive.
My family's favourite game altough without Cities and Knights it can get a bit repetative after 100th game or so :)
The Gateway game.. even though the 'wood for sheep' joke gets said a little too often to be funny.
I originally rated this game a 6, but after playing a lot over the summer, I have increased my rating to a 7. I think the role of the 'robber' should be changed in this game. A great family game.
One of my three or four favorites to introduce people to really fun games.
A classic that is fun, but not too complex even my 6 yo daughter can play.
The classic german game, but we almost never play the non expanded version unless it's with kids. Starting playing at work, good to get this back into the rotation.
A near-perfect balance of analysis, excitement and both verbal and positional player interaction. Superb. See my review for more details: http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/118883

Probably the game that I played the most (because of my parents). It's strange, I almost always have more fun playing this than I anticipate before the game starts. This game is like a blankie ("doudou") for me; it is dirty by the wear but is very comfortable!

What can I say? It started a trend and deserves every praise it gets.   Becomes more interesting when played as a match over several games which alleviates the randomness. I love it that you always think you are in control but really are a slave to the dice. Also great is the 'surge from behind' so that you can win (and certainly fight) even when in an apparently hopeless position.   I would like to see a good two-player variant and an official 'scoring' for 2nd (3rd) place to alleviate kingmaker problems.
1.Mayfair Edition 2.Mayfair Edition Wasser des Lebens Edition
A very good game for families and people who don't like to overtly mess up their opponents. Trading is key, so interaction with other players is still necessary to win the game.

What can I say that hasn't already been said?  Fun game, different every time, good player interaction, excellent gateway game for newbies; but very random, and hard to stop an early leader.    This is the game that got me back into boardgaming, circa 1996, when I started graduate school.  Thus, it has a lot of sentimental value for me.  Probably the game I have played the most in my lifetime, with Cosmic Encounter a close second.
Good game.  Classic.  Played it so much that burn-out has lowered the score.
I have have played this boardgame over 300 times. Nuff said  But it gets a littel boring now with so much new better games out :)
This has done its job as a gateway. On to better things.
the game that began it all for me.  More sentimental rating than actual game play rating

[BGCOLOR=#FFFF00][COLOR=#000000]Family.[/COLOR][/BGCOLOR] Resource Management, Trading, Building. A great middleweight gateway game, a classic, yet I can't go back to vanilla Settlers after playing with the Cities & Knights expansion (I'd only play this with beginners/nongamers).  Loan: Brian.
Not my favorite by itself, but if you add Seafarers...

This game gave boardgames in Germany a big boost. Easy, accessible and a high-replay value make it a great game to introduce new people to boardgames. Pretty luck-dependent and therefore not a favorite of many hardcore gamers.
I enjoy the game but will need to play a few more games with the boys to make sure the rules sink into their heads.
Classic game, but I think I may have overplayed it a bit.  When played with hardcore competitive players, the games becomes simultaneously more engaging and infurating.
Very good game - Seafarers expansion makes this a great game!
Still a pretty good game 20 years later, and due to its age it's now unusual. Will play occasionally even though I don't like the trading and mild take-that elements that much.

easy and short playtime, great. I always tend to lose this game. But the game is very enjoyable until the point when i realize that i will not be able to win :-).  edit: playing alot of other games this just do not have the same appeal anymore, down one point.

A fun social game, but victory can depend on initial startup position as much as it does on luck. The trading mechanic almost always goes bye bye when victory is close at hand. I can't take it too seriously since too many times I've seen a player with only two victory points suddenly get a good streak and pull a win out of nowhere.

What can I say?  My wife and best friend always want to play this game, and I always oblige.  For some reason, slow Settlers players drive me nuts.  I mean, you can only do so much on your turn, and you should have a pretty good idea of what you want to do by the time the dice get around to you, shouldn't you?
It's a good game. It can depend on who you play it with. Because you can robb each other people should be able to take this. But with a group of non fanatics, I like it.
The classic eurogame, but I never fell in love with it as much as others.
Not a bad game but we played it too much so that it never comes on the table now.
Easy to get into. A bit too much luck oriented, but that only means that beginners can win too.

Pros: attractive to non-gamers, very little down-time.  Cons: too much decided by the luck of the dice, too easy for someone to be out of the running by the mid-game, through no real fault of their own.
Good game...but it is worn out.  Does not come out very often anymore.
A very elegant game. It would deserve an higher rating if it weren't for the fact that dice rolls reduces the strategic aspects on behalf of luck.
Will rarely object to playing this classic game, which remains fresh after almost 10 years of play. The basic game, IMO, is just as much fun as playing with the expansions.
quick to learn and easy to master... yet it's the die-hard opponents that makes the game all the way challanging and exiting...

One of the games that brought me back to the table.  It's a little random, and that's what I like about it: Deal with what you're dealt and negotiate for the rest.  It's no brain-burner.  It's as friendly or as confrontational as you make it.  And it's one of the few games I can get the whole family to play.

Good game.  Always fun to play, several ways to win; the only problems I have with the base game are the seeming uselessness of sheep and the underutilization of development cards -- only once have I seen a player try to go for largest army, since longest road is more useful.

When I started gaming it ment everything to me. We use 2 play it all the time, especially with the expansions (it really shines with the cities and knight expansion). Later on, while getting to know other games the luck factor could really bother me.  So now a days I find this a good game, fairly easy to explain, great interaction, not to agressive and a good introduction to another kind of games. But a little bit too much luck involved for my taste.

This really took me by the throat as of the first time I played it: low luck factor, high on interaction, variable board, strategy ... It has it all! It was also the first of the "new" games I discovered later [I used to be a Risk fan]
Nothing wrong with it, I've just played it about as many times as a human needs to.
Excellent game, tons of replay value.  Time involved may turn off fast playing gamers.

Like practically everybody else - the game that started it all.  This opened the door into "good" board games.  Still interesting to play and always a good gateway game.  I do prefer the Cities and Knights expansion for a bit more confrontation.
Own it because it is a classic.  Also, will use to advance new players up the complexity scale from Carcassonne. Still, a little too abstract.
Bringing people to the hobby since 1995
The randomness is so frustrating, everything else - pure fun.
Probably the first "real" boardgame I played, and has started my love for games.  Would recommend it to anyone.
Good game - prefer using the expansion with it... but haven't been successful with winning lately.  Kind of tired of playing it.
Great game, got me hooked on gaming again (sigh)!
Mein Einstieg in die Eurogames. Sicherlich einige hundert Partien gespielt, mittlerweile steht es oft nur in der Ecke aber es ist immer noch der Klassiker was Eurogames (für mich) angeht

> Despite having not played this for a long time I do think this gets harshly treated sometimes on BBG. I think it is a great game with a lot more replayability than quite a few higher ranked games. I only rank it a 7 due to burnout from playing it almost every week for about 2 years.  Great intro game, but hard to enjoy as much after playing a lot of other 'euros'. Still fun ocasionally.

It took me a long time to rate this game because I lost my first set, and got it again when we visited Germany.  A very good gateway game, however the length and the unactionpacked theme could be a problem for nongamers.  I still like this game and am willing to play it anytime, though.  It has amazing replayability.
Hits all the right buttons yet I would still rather play many other games.
used to be a 9, but burned out.

I owe my gaming hobby to this game, which I have played countless times for many hours of fun.  My main problem is an inability to go after a runaway leader, which is why I really like Cities & Knights.  Though because of the increased game time, I don't mind playing vanilla Settlers at all.  In fact, I may even prefer it. 25 minutes versus an hour?  I'd choose the quicker one almost every time.

The seminal German game.  I prefer the standard game for 3-4 players.    I have two copies:    The older wooden set is expanded with Seefahrers and the 5&6 players' extensions.    The 10th anniversary set with plastic pieces is ideal for a simple 10pt, 4-player game.

My intro to modern board games.    I have used this to get people interested in playing games.  It's never failed!    I've played it so much on bsw, and can always pick up a quick game there, that it makes playing my own copy seem far less appealing.  Now I like to get people to play other stuff that I haven't played as much.
What can I say? I have to pay some homage to this; it did bring me into boardgaming, but after playing newer games, it doesn't do it for me the same way it used too.
I like this game, but just from time to time
I like Settlers of Catan with the welfare rules.
A classic game, and a nice "gateway" game, but its strategy is a bit shallow. Experienced gamers will be frustrated by the amount of luck.

Finally got around to playing this great game. Looks like it'll hit the table quite often, and will be used to advance the neighbors from Ticket to Ride. Doesn't have the production values of some of the newer games, but the mechanics hold up quite well. Really like the player interaction necessary to play (and win).

I first played the german computerized version for DOS. A friend introduced me to the tabletop counterpart years later. Now I play 'continental catan' with every expansion and bit I've got. Makes for a great long day of gaming.

Good game.    Since my regular gaming buddies are guaranteed to be stricken by Analysis Paralysis, it was during a particularly agonizing session that I developed the "secondary game" technique whereby I play an entire other game while they contemplate their turn.  Sometimes we get in a Foosball game to 5.
Ok game and one of the first euros. My dislike of dice drops one rating.
I've had this for years, but haven't played since I was much younger.  We played it last night and it was fun, but not as deep as I remember it.

Although I think I may have finally played it to death, still an all-time classic and the game that got me into the hobby.  Too much negotiation and kill-the-leader for me to rate it higher than an 8. **Update (01/09/06): Lowered rating to a 7.  This usually only gets played with six people, so my rating reflects how horribly long it can be with that many.  I'd give this game an 8 with four players and a 6 or less with six playrs.
The 1 that got it al starting again with board games.

Like many others, this was my introduction to Eurogames. While it isn't my favourite, I find it easy to introduce to new gamers and enjoy a game every so often although I wouldn't want to play it every week.
everyone seems to like this one
Revolutionary when it came out. Popularised the concepts of modular boards and player interaction through trading. I still find it quite enjoyable.
Simple, fun and easy to get people involved. Great gateway game, but after a while most people will want something more involved, or less random.
Along with Heroscape, the gateway drug that made me relapse back into the hobby.
Fun with four players. Boring with less.

A classic. Really the game that brought me into the board game world. I don't really have any criticisms for this one, except that the wooden dice seem to come up eleven a little more than they statistically ought to.

We like the mechanic whereby you collect commodities (wood, clay, sheep, ore, grain), which you then invest to purchase appropriately themed items (settlements, roads, cities) on the board.  The die-roll mechanic for determining what is harvested can be cruelly unforgiving (even if you hedge by placing settlements adjacent to as many different numbers as possible). We've tried the event cards and our initial reaction is positive. But, for a fairly quick empire-building game involving trading and luck - it's fun. My BGG plays record only a small fraction of the nearly 100 times we've played this game.
I'll stand up when someone asks

I can easily see why this is a "gateway" game for many.  It's quite fun, and the rules are easy to explain as you go.  Be aware that it can be easy to get locked out of games due to road/settlement placements and poor die roles, and kingmaking can be possible by allowing lopsided trading.
I've only met one person who played this game and didn't love it.  Massively overplayed by my friends.  Can get frustrating depending on the dice, though.  I much prefer to play with the event deck.
A great game, but I much prefer one of its spawn: Settlers of the Stone Age.

After a few plays I can see why this game was such a big hit.  However, I can also see how much further games have come.  The die-rolling for production isn't my favorite, mostly because the dice hate me.  HATE ME!  I can see the look in their beady little pips.  Why I OUGHTA-

It is difficult to give a comment to a mythical figure, the grandaddy, the best in the last 10 years. I could be influenced in both directions: either by the reputation or by the fact that I could expect much more from it. Then I agree with the guy who defined Settlers of Catan "a good "gentle" introduction for others into more complex games". But differently from that guy my final rate is: good game but too much dice-dependent!

Highly enjoyable light game.  The random dice rolls can make for aggravation, but it is almost never boring.  Trading is interesting and fun, though a single player can break the game (or make it take forever) by refusing to trade (even in overwhelmingly favorable circumstances).

Bizarrely, my copy of this game, which I have had for over a year, is unplayed.  Instead I've played on other people's sets at a local gaming club.  Despite being quite a good player I have failed to ever win at this, and it is a source of personal frustration. Okay, its got a large random factor with the dice and a popularity/shouting factor with the trading and the cards throw an extra random element into the mix, but I should win sometime, surely....?

Settlers is the game that got me into the hobby.  In fact, it was the only game we played for about 6 months. Over a decade later i find myself playing this game again and appreciating how good it really is. Deserving of its classic status

The game that changed everything for me. Everybody loves it and it is still a famous introduction to the world of games. We don't play it a lot anymore, but it is still in our mind.   Through the years, the game has lost some of its appeal because of the big concurrence. That's why my score is reduced from 8 to 7.
Always popular, and still a perennial favorite with the family, even if I prefer somewhat meatier fare.

Can I possibly say anything that hasn't been said? This game singlehandedly converted an entire side of our family into occasional boardgamers. My mother recently requested a second copy of the game so that they can keep one at camp and one at home.  For all family Thanksgiving and Christmas Day afternoons from now to forever, I am grateful. Even if Mom does wipe the floor with us.

Cities and Knights of Catan has replaced this as the 'Settlers' game of choice... so my rating for the 'basic' game has gone down.  Settlers of Catan is still well liked and played occasionally, but only to introduce newbies to the system.  I mean... why bother with basic Settlers when you can play C&K instead?

Great trading game with the randomness of dice which opens it to less hardened gamers but can be offputting to said gamers. Setup is a bit annoying but is still a great game and the expansions whilst overpriced are enjoyable.

2 - 4 players  Like so many other people, Settlers of Catan is what got me started on German-style board games.  I still enjoy it, but I'm to the point where I'm burned out on regular Settlers.  There are so many other games I would rather play.
This game is solid, and deserves mention for its role in launching the German-style genre. It is slow, however, and luck plays a noticeable role.

Civilization:City building:Resource Management:Trading:Negoiation  100  plays (most were computer version or online): Very addicting game in the discovery stage even though it is mostly luck dependant, especially when playing with equally skilled players. This is a classic example of how luck and dice do not automatically mean the game will be bad or broken, it is one of the main reasons the game is so fun but it can also get occasionally frustrating when the dice work against you. Expansions add a few more choices/decisions but the C&K is the only one worth the money and sometimes regular Settlers is really all you want. Rating this fairly high due to high fun factor and that "let's play again feeling", also this has high replay value and a few paths to Victory. My theory is the "greed" aspect of it is why it's so fun as well as "take that" when cutting off your opponet's road.  [u]UPDATE[/u]: After 100 plays this fell a little from a 9 but only a classic could see 100 plays and my rating won't ever fall below 8.5 even though it doesn't see much play now. It also gains extra points for it's "uncanny" ability to win over non-gamers to the hobby and we found some ways to play with 2 players as well.   [u]UPDATE[/u]:8.5 => 7.5 What can I say, after playing a lot more other games I now don't like playing this much (mostly due to the high luck factor), it especially becomes too long for what it is with 4 people. If you are new(ish) to the hobby this is still a great choice.
My second boardgame in the "grown-up" phase. It makes me hate statistics. :) Yet, it is a perfect 4 players game. (N. players: 4>>3)

Great game with lots of possible strategy. A good deal of "controllable" randomness but still a lot of strategic decisions in play. I look forward to playing more of the expansions and such. A great game.

This is a great intro game. It exposes the player to the beauty of german games and their bits. It also allows one to taste the sweetness of controlling ones fate, without leaving all blame on the player by including the dice. I'm not one to bag on luck, though it has neglected me most of my life, but I have lost too many games due to this aspect. Love, will be playing for years, just not as often as others.
Classic! Make sure to get the "Seafarers" expansion so you have a need for all those left over sheep...
It's ok, but the negotiation part gets a little tedious after a while.
Decent game. Heavy negotiation and interaction. Needs more complexity to warrant a higher rating.
A classic that I used to like a lot, but the luck factor is too high for my current taste.
Great fun, easy to learn.  Lotsa yelling and screaming with this game!
It´s a a good game with 4 players. Diplomacy, trades and buildings. The worth is too luck.
Played this one time, but no using proper rules.

I call this the gateway drug game. It was the first game i played when i realized how great games could be. Its not my favorite, but the design is solid and playable for all ability levels. Strategy is a little limited but player interaction is better in this game than most. the board is so replayable and the intensity of the right roll is always there in each game.

Wonderful game for non-gamers.  I've gotten several people hooked on this game.  This was also the game that hooked me into more German-style games and just heavier games in general.  Most of the time the game is pretty fun, though I have had some sessions that have run a bit dry.  Sometimes the dice just don't treat you well.

I was never exposed to this before bgg, and so I lack the nostalgia.  It was a slow grower, as I usually prefer the less luck oriented games.  However, I have played it some more recently, and really come to enjoy this game.  There is a decent bit of strategy, expecially when you start using the variable setup, which I enjoy quite a bit more.
i like this because you can crank it out  long games, and college, are far behind me now  Upped my rating after playing with tournament rules. Game played much faster.

I far prefer Starfarers and as such do not usually suggest Settlers.  My problem with the game is (especially with 4 players) is one player usually gets left in the dust and is "out of the game" and where is the fun in that?

I appreciate that the mechanics of this game are so basic and intuitive, that a person carefully watching can learn the game just from watching...however, being able to consistently win is another thing.  Well made and planned out game even if it tends to run long.
After years of Cities and Knights, I've found regular Catan not bad.  It's still not going to be what I go for but I'd play.
The German classic, I like it best with 3 players.

The fact that I still play this all these years later (and with my collection swollen to many times the size it was when I first got it) is a testament to how good Settlers is. Simple, clean rules, multiple routes to victory, and lots of player interaction. The endgame gets a little static, particularly with experienced players, but it's not a flaw too serious to keep me from coming back.
My first introduction to 'German' games, and an instant hit.

My first introduction to eurogames. after playing this, i now love most any game with a modular board. i'm growing less fond of the catan games because they tend to drag on as people gang up on the current leader.
I am still not quite seeing this game for what it is worth I suspect. A few more games should see that right.

I like this game but it is now one that I exclusively reserve for introducing newbies to boardgaming as opposed to one I would choose to play for my "own" enjoyment.  These days I'd be more likely to suggest Anno 1503 instead of Settlers.

I would rate this lower without the Cities & Knights expansion, but I don't believe in expansions rating higher than their base games, so this one is affected.  The only time I play just the base game is when teaching new players.  Settlers was the first game to nearly cross the dimensional lines and sit in the mainstream world.  I like to spread this classic 'gateway' game by giving it as a gift when the need arises.

[BGCOLOR=#99ffff][b][COLOR=#99ffff]_[/COLOR]7[COLOR=#99ffff]_[/COLOR][/b][/BGCOLOR][b]:[/b] Good game. Usually willing to play. I might even request or recommend it.  The robber is an a$$hole.  Played over the 2010 Christmas break and decided that "vanilla" Settlers doesn't do it for me anymore.  I'll insist on Seafarers or variants from The Book from now on.

OK, I finally played my first game of Settlers. It was the 2 player variant where you play to 15 and roll the resource dice twice. Anyway, I liked it a lot. We'll definitely play again.  My only problem with the game so far is that I am red/green color deficient. So all those reds and browns and greens are a little rough to tell apart. Although there is some detail on the cards it's not high contrast so it doesn't help much. Also - it would help if there were pictures on each tile of the resource that the tile produces. It was hard for me to just look at a tile and know what resource was associated with it. I had to keep looking at the resource cards and then try to figure out which background matched the tile. Ugh.
Definitely a classic game - haven't played it so much recently - maybe it doesn't last so well.
Classic Euro gateway game of resource management and trading. Lots of fun if you're not sick of it. 3–6 players.
Very nice and clever game. The game that got me hooked on boardgaming. Nice balance of luck and tacticts. It can only be played with 3 or 4 players though, preferably 4.
Fun, for most of the game.  Could use a few more things to think about for how long it takes.

Great intro into German Games, but too much luck keeps it from joining the upper echelons of gaming goodness.  Now luck is not a bad attribute, but in Settlers it always seems like one player gets screwed enough to have no opportunity to win.  I don't like luck when it ordains the amount I can enjoy a game.

Best with Seafarers.  I love this game, still, after all these years.  Seafarers and Cities and Knights are both fun expansions with different flavors added to an already fun game.  Great gateway game for non-gamers.  One of the best, in fact.
Played this to death in the late 90s. Dusted it off recently and remembered why it's such a great "transition" game for non-gamegeeks.

It really needs one or both of the expansions to keep this game interesting, but to add them all in at once for new players is likely too difficult. Still a good way to introduce strategy games to newcomers
I still like this game every time it comes out.  I think I suffer from familiarity fatigue with it and sometimes the trading mechanism can fall flat when there's an obvious leader.
This is a very good gateway game for non-gamers and my rating reflects that and the fact that this is a classic game. Purely based on gameplay though, I would rate this a 6.
Only got down here after 100+ plays.  Great game, but wouldn't bring it to the table over so many other games now.  Seven is quite respectable.
Have 1997 version for trade.  Looking for 2007 version.
Fun family game for 3 or more.  Can be a real drag if initial settlements are placed poorly.  The trading aspect makes the game very interactive among players.  Easy rules.  Light game.
This is the game that got me into games. For that reason, it has a special place in my heart. However, it's beginning to show it's age and I'd rather play any number of other games.
Can get boring quickly compared to heavier games, but still the best gateway game eva, everybody likes it. Only problem I'm starting to get sick of it.
Got a little burnt out on this a while back.  Haven't really played in a while.
It's the original Catan. What more can be said about it? Play with Cities and Knights though.

Great game with the right group. Can get a little long and players may lose interest if they aren't doing so hot, because it is difficult to catch up once you lag behind. However, this one is very interactive!
Once the most played game in the collection, now just the most worn box
Tight competition and lots of potential for excitement and frustration.  I know a lot of people are "over it," but you have to give credit to its longevity and mass appeal.
Very fun "gateway" game to introduce people to Euro games. The newer plastic pieces are great. Also own the 5-6 player expansion.
Classic.  This is a great game to play with friends who normally only play party games etc.

Update: Not current favourite anymore, this is one game that's seriously starting to lose it's shine. Even seafarers doesn't help. I think historical scenarios are the best thing Catan has to offer. It seems the game has too much luck and takes too long for what it offers. Well, it still gets plays now and then, but not on a regular basis. (Old rant: Current favourite, usually played with Seafarers. There's luck, there's strategy, and it's not too long. What's not to like?)

If the first thing that comes to your mind when someone says 'Board Game' is Monopoly, it's time you played this.  This game will give you a new appreciation for board gaming, and will breathe new life into the ways you can have fun with your friends.  My rating is lower because I've played it to death, but without a doubt, you must play this game if you are a board game noob. --- :meeple::meeple::thumbsup:
it's settlers.  what else can i say?
One of the earliest games I got; took a bit before I could get my wife to play, and now she loves it.  Have not logged every play :)
To play it or not to play it - that is the question. The mother of all games in my collection deserves some respect. So I guess - play it, occasionally.

Not a bad game, but wargaming is more my thing.  The mechanism appears to be clean and the game plays reasonably well.  I have upgraded my rating based on a play with my parents.  It was a lot of fun and, since my folks like games that are more like this a.k.a not military strategy we will play this one more often. :)

Definitely one of the best starter games for getting people into serious board-gaming.  I'd probably rate it higher if I wasn't a bit worn out on it.  But the fact that I played it enough to BE worn out on it speaks highly of it.
A classic - but a bit long for my liking...

I was VERY late to the table with this, playing it for the first time in March of 2006, and while I appreciate everything that is going on, especially the very polished feel of the mechanics, I often find my self frustrated while playing rather than having fun.
Played too much in the past.  Played it again for the first time in a while last night--it's fine, but there are so many other games out there...

Simple, not too long, never the same twice, good quantity of strategy, but enough luck to be interesting. Does have a tendancy to get old after a while, but I think that's because I end up playing it so much.
Has a tendancy to drag if someone is new.  Easy to learn though, and has some nifty new 3D edition.
This game got me into eurogames, but it now seems a little stale.

Ten years after it's release, I've finally played this classic. I got totally screwed on the die rolls (10 times as many 8's as 6's somehow) in my first game, but it was still fun. It's way too reliant on luck as the central mechanism when compared to other Euros.
Luckelement(not too high) and long length..hmm... yeah it's anyway quite good game.
Classic. Played a lot. Far more fun with the seafarer expansion

When I first opened up the box, I was intimidated by all the rulebooks.  However, I was pleasantly surprised to find that the gameplay is not complicated.  The game makes interesting use of dice roll statistics, although this can be frustrating too.  Players doing well tend to keep doing better; it can be tough to catch up.  But there always seems to be at least one elusive resource for each player.  We have played with 3 players, with 6 players (with the expansion), and with the second 2-player variant listed on Mayfair's website (each player plays only one color).  We greatly prefer the game with more than 2, since that allows players to trade cards with each other.

Luck.  Stupid 9's (or whatever it happens to be any given day).  What sucks is that your destiny is tied so directly to dice.  Like monopoly or candyland.  Even risk does not seems so bad-luck cruel.  Still, Settlers is fun in spite of the dice.  In the end my biggest problem with settlers is not the dice directly, but the lack of viable long term strategy.  This is another per-turn optimization game.  For some unknown reason, as much as I hate its problems, I'll keep playing it.

To me, this is the Monopoly of designer games.  With two exceptions... 1) The setup is time-consuming, and 2) the rules can seem unnecessarily daunting to a new player.  But once the game has started the the players are familiar with the rules, it's a fantasticly fun game.

One of the Classic "gateway" games.  It's good fun and a great idea for three players or even four.  However I still prefer "Ticket To Ride: Marklin" when trying to engage people who are new to the hobby -- especially with 5 people.  I dont think Catan plays well with the 5-6 player expansion.
Classic.  Don't play it much anymore though.
Juego encantador y muy adictivo, recomendable para no jugadores y féminas.

Seems to be ok, I'm just not interested in playing it.  The dice just seem to ruin the game for me - too much dependance on it, and I like chaos games!  Updated my score for this one.  The more I play this the more I see in it.  It needs more playing time.  Ok, this one I'm starting to request.  The more I play it, the more I like it.
This is a good game, and can be fun. But it has a tendency to go way too long, in my opinion.  This was the game that started me down the road to eurogaming.

The one that started it all for me with Eurogames.  Although I've only been tracking game play recently and not diligently, I think I have about 100 games under my belt of this one and all it's expansions.
I played this game a few times over a weekend. It's nice. I'd prefer "Advanced Civilization" any day though. But if it'll make "ordinary" folks play "real" games... then it's great :)

2-4p, 70m.This was the game that started it all for me in December 2004.It has so many elements of good gaming: modular board, multiple paths to victory, player interaction, calculated risk/odds, ...I've played lots of this game with my wife and friends, and met new friends through it.

A lot to like here, but a few nits as well: too much hinges on too few die rolls, usual runaway loser, occasional runaway leader. Baffled as to why they keep meddling with the English art, as the German/original is still the best, hasn't changed, and they don't monkey with the rest of the Kosmos line.  Weird.  But the biggest issue, esp. now that I have Seafarers and 5/6 expansion, is just figuring out the setup and takedown. Extremely annoying to have different sets of chits, etc.  I've done a bit of marking-up and it works, but...poorly thought out on Mayfair's part.

Like most other people, Settlers was one of the first Euros I played and it helped start me on the hobby. I can't add anything to the praise it has received. The design is inspired and clever all at the same time.  That said, I find myself not really wanting to play much any more, especially with four players. Part of this is due to luck as some games the rolls just don't go your way. Another part is the downtime. I find myself spacing off during other players turns. Most players I know are unwilling to trade because they are worried about helping you too much. Further, I try to not plan ahead too much as things can change a lot before the dice come back to you (roads block you, solider/robber steals cards, etc.).   A biggest part, however, is the endgame. Just when it looks like someone will win, another player bashes them and further delays the game. I usually don't mind "beat up on the leader" as this is an important strategy for winning. For Settlers, however, it makes what should be a 30 minute game into one that is 60 hour or longer.  As such, it is the best game that I rarely have any desire to play.   Note: online play against AI helps as it speeds things up considerably. I recommend, http://games.asobrain.com  Kept for nostalgia value and as a gateway game.
I can't add something that hasn't already been said.
The more I play this game the more I like it.

The basic set of Catan is a very enjoyable game, and good for some fun without being difficult. However, I would recommend getting an expansion set like "Cities and Knights". Don't do this unless you're familiar with the game already, though.
Fun game, with lots of interaction.

This is a really neat game.  There is player interaction, there are changing strategies to winning, and there is the psychological component of peaking too early and attracting too much attention to yourself.  The bonus is I get to whine and scream, "Are you stupid?  He's going to win.  Why did you put the thief on me?"
[Got it in a trade for Queen's Necklace.]
This was the game that got me into alternative board games.  Even though I never win I still love it, there are some things that could be tweeked but still a fantastic game.
The game that introduced me to eurostyle bordgaming! Played this game dozens of times and still find it very enjoyable!

I'm not a fan of trading games and I find that the game can sometimes drag with the trading and while everyone waits for the right goods to initiate thier next action. Its all just a bit too much like a long, boring afternoon for me. Not to mention, its a "stupid dice rolling game" as we say around here.:-) Except if you're playing with experienced & clever players. Then it can be a blast of a stupid dice rolling game.
Enjoyable game with roughly equal parts luck and strategy. Players are involved during everyone's turn thanks to the trades and resource collecting, which is a plus.

One of the best gateway games because it is accessible (relatively easy rules) and there's very little downtime since you receive resources and trade on everyone's turn.  This one was notable for me because I had fun playing regardless of whether I won or lost.   I still find this one fun, and a great way to bring new people into the hobby.  My one warning is that the game can get way too long if played with more than 4.
Good game, but much better with either of the expansions.  I like that the game is short because if mis calculate the first city placements the pain will be over within an hour!
Solid game.  The robber adds a fun get-your-neighbor angle without really taking anyone out of the game.
Great Game got me interduced into the Eroupean Games.

Very popular with family & non-gamer friends. One of the better "intro to gaming" game out there. Key selling points are: a) it is not difficult for non-gamers to learn & enjoy 2) no 'wait-for-my-turn' downtime 3) no elimination of players 4) various strategies to win 5) good mutual gains from trading & player interaction 6) fast play and little "analysis" factor . Hard to go wrong with this choice. After getting your pals hooked, move them on to bigger & better games! Also, playing settlers gives enough satifaction to satiate that "gamer itch" addiction. Just don't burn out on it... go play something else! Only downside is that is best for 4 and we often end up with 5 for the night...
A very solid core game, somehow now part of the definition of Eurogaming. While the base set is fine, the expansions make it so much more intriguing.
An excellent gateway game, and still hits our table occasionally even after years of play. I still like the basic game better than any of the variants I've tried.
Classic game of resource management, trading dice rolling.  The GATEWAY GAME.
The game that introduced me to Euros. Still like it, though I usually play Seafares when we play.
A classic. Played this game more than any other game on here and still play it quite a bit. Definately one of the greats.

I particularly enjoy how the gameboard is different every game.  The rules are fairly intuitive and there are not that many to begin with.  Gameplay flows well with downtime relative to the players analysis paralysis.
Good as an introduction to strategic gaming. Maybe a bit simple and random when you have played it lots of times.
I'll trade you three non-gamers for three gamers... deal?
I owe this game a debt of gratitude for bringing me to Eurogames, but too much hinges on dice for my tastes.

This one was our first Eurogame.  I loved it.  Now I am completely burnt out.  So I lowered the rating since I often turn down the opportunity to play it.  But dont let my rating fool you, its a fantastic game.
A very good game, but has a chance of dragging on depending on how the dice roll/available trades.

I think it plays better with four than three. Too much early Robber damage in a three player that you can't do much about while all you can do is pray that someone rolls a 7.... [Edit] In our last game we realised we had been playing the Robber wrong by having him stop production at any city/village he was next to rather than just the hex he was in . Doh! Still a lot of luck in this one, but maybe not quite so bad three compared to four now :)
First played Die Siedler at AvalonCon 1996 in Baltimore.  The classic first Euro that is still fun to pull out every once in a while.
It's not gaming nirvana, like some want us to believe, but it's decent game that I like to play once in a while. Only the basic version, though!

First German-style board game I ever played.  I enjoy the mix of luck (die rolling to determine which resources are produced), strategy (where to put cities, where to build roads, what to build), and player interaction (trading resources).  The heavy reliance on luck for production is the primary downside; this isn't as intense as Puerto Rico or Louis XIV.  [Update: While I still enjoy playing this with new players (it's a great introductory game), it's a bit too luck-based for my current tastes.]

I like it even thought it is all about the initial placement and the dice. The simple rules together with the elegant design makes this a good gateway game. The variable board ensures decent replay value.
After a few more plays, I'm downgrading my rating to a 7.  Relatively solid game, but there's other ones I'd rather spend my time playing if I have four people.
Settlers of Catan is a really good game.  The setup time is a bit much, though.
"The gateway game". Settlers of Catan is ok. I do not like it as much as i first started playing boardgames. There are newer and better boardgames out there. An overall fun experience

After lots of plays this game holds up very well and I have probably played this a hundred times. It really deserves its "classic" status.  The only reason I don't play this game more often, is that you need 3 to 4 players.

Great gateway game.  A bit light, not but not so light I'd call it filler. I've played Cities and Knights of Catan also and rate it higher, but since you have to buy both, it's quite expensive relative to other games.

Great game, but it takes WAY to long for non-gamers to understand and finish and it has a runaway problem as well. Game can be effectively over after the first few dice rolls, but it still takes awhile to finish.  I get my fix playing the computer version with the crappy AIs.

I've come to think that the board is slightly too crowded for 4 players, but there's not enough trading in a 3 player game. The randomness doesn't bother me at all. I'll gladly play a couple of times a year.

A much better game (maybe an 8) back in 1996 with the first german edition and bad english translation.  Could play any number of development cards.  There were less Knights in the Development card stack (as compared to the Mayfair games) and blowups required random discard.   Hate the new plastic bits.
The game that led me here.  Still fun, always a bit different and my family loves it.

My first true eurogame, and one that's still fun, although I prefer to play with 3 or 5 players.  If you have never heard of this game, you really should give it a try.   The current edition could use a facelift, but apparently a new version is coming very soon.

Yeah, so it's got dice and chance.  Deal with it!  I like a variety of games and this one scratches a particular itch.  There IS strategy to this game beyond the initial placement, but sometimes your numbers just don't come up.  That's life....
Best seller and a gateway game to other newer german games.

I think this is a great entry game into the world of Euro-games.  I believe games like PR, Caylus, and T&E are better, but all are more complicated and require more thinking.  Settlers is great for a casual group of people looking for a lighter thinking game.
fun and easy to learn, most of the non-gamers i know, like this game
Boo. :)  I don't like this game.  But I guess we owe it a lot so I will give it a 7.  As long as I never have to play it again. haha

I originally rated this game a 6, but after playing a lot over the summer (Origins/GenCon 05), I have increased my rating to a 7. I think the role of the 'robber' should be changed in this game. A great family game.

Wonderful game. Unless certain players are being particularly vindictive, everyone gets a chance, but skill does help out. Best to keep it moving along, because trading and analysis can bog things down.
A classic.  This is the game that converted me to German gaming, and I'll never go back to Monopoly again.  After dozens of plays, it has lost much of its lustre for me.

The gateway 'must own' game that introduced North America to 'real' games.  Simple, yet fun...if the dice don't drive you crazy.  (Seems there is always one person that can't get a thing to happen.)  We liked it so much we immediately bought Seafarers.  I've only actually played Settlers once since then without the expansion.  It is even better with Cities and Knights. (I would have rated this game higher, but the expansions make it so much better.)

I thought that I would love this game more, but it didn't really move me.  But objectively it is an excellent design.  My main design criticism is that I feel that whoever begins the game with the best board position has a big advantage, to the extent that he or she will probably win.  Strategy helps somewhat, but only somewhat.  You also can't gang up on the leader as effectively as in some other games.  Regardless, this game seems destined to become a classic.
Doesn't get played enough, but a very good game nonetheless.  One of very first games ordered online and purchased from Thoughthammer.
See other's comments. Nowadays we hardly only play the travel edition with tournament rules, so a game only lasts about 45 mins. We alternate between using the die and the event cards.
Good game for beginner strategists.  Lots or luck involved.
Nice game for beginners or for those who consider luck to be a part of a board game and want to interact during the game.
My entry into the boardgame realm!
Don't want to play it all the time, but I still enjoy the classic that got me hooked.

3 to 4 players (5 to 6 with the expansion).  This is a good game. It's great for teaching new people and you can pretty much guarantee everyone will like it. I thought I had played this to death and would never enjoy it again, but it's fun on occasion, or with Cities and Knights of Catan.
A relatively well-balanced trading game.  If you aren't a good trader, stay clear of this one -- it's the key to victory.
Love it but there are so many news games around that this doesn't hit the table too often.
Family favourite, in combination with expansions

Considered *the* German game by many, sold a bazillion copies and spawned many expansions. Players begin on an island made up of hextiles. Dice are rolled to generate resources, resources are traded and spent to build settlements, cities, roads and resource cards. Victory points are earned for these builds and first to ten points wins. One of the "must own" games. If it has a flaw, it is the dice can reduce a player's role in the game to watching it for 75 minutes.
A classic trade and development game.  Little needs to be said about it, it's reputation precedes it.
This game appeals to the inexperienced as well as the experienced player. Always fun to play. The good (and bad) thing about this game is that you´ve almost always got the chance to win.
it is a first rate boardgame, but also it is a goood choice for an evening with non-gamers friends

finally got down to getting this game that exploded the boardgaming world. It has been the DEFINITIVE gateway game for people, but it was not mine for sure. i got it because one of my gaming groups prefer this to Settlers of Canaan. Oh well, just another reason for me to add one more game to my collection. :)
Good fun still. Will bring it out for newbies and family.
German edition, with English replacement deck

I have to thank Mr. Teuber, whose Starfarers of Catan introduced me to the hobby.  Settlers is a better introductory game, better balanced, and deserves its place in "history".  I'd like to be able to give this a perfect grade, but sometimes the randomly generated board can produce terrible games where everybody is sitting on no wood/brick/whatever and things slow to a crawl.
Extended family still like to play this, and I will always play with them, but I think I've personally moved on.

A good strategy game. It has a huge drawback however. Several players can easily unite to play against one player and there is nothing that one player can do to succeed in this situation. Kids often get frustrated and angry at each other while playing. For experienced players the game strategy is about playing the Robber.
The gateway.  I only play this with non-gamers these days...
This is a reliably fun game.  Not very demanding, but with a nice rhythm, lots of interaction.  A beautiful family game to replace Monopoly.

This wasn't my first game, nor my first euro.  So, it really didn't seem all that groundbreaking to me at all.  Update 12/2010:  I liked it better the second time even though I had an awful game.  The key is to play with people who will trade.  I had fun this second time and would play again sooner, than later.  Update: March 2012 - up to a 7 on my third play.  I do enjoy this one...I like the trading.

This hit at just the right time for me to get exposed to it while on a downspiral of going away from gaming (for a variety of reasons). I need to get my own copy and expose a few people to this little gem.

Probably THE gateway game, but I only played it once.  Liked it well enough, but there's so many other better games that this just never gets requested or played...  I do think you need some of the expansions to make it interesting.
A classic. Almost universally enjoyed by everyone I have introduced it to. Simple and fun.

This was my "gateway game" that introduced me to the broader aspects of boardgaming.  It doesn't get played much now that I have a 200+ collection, but I pulled it out recently and it still held.  I find the dice a bit frustrating, but not so much that I would use cards, because that aspect of it is part of the appeal to the game I think.  Having played this probably 50+ times, I do find myself always going for similar types of strategies, etc. but it's still a fun game.  I really like the totally open trading aspect of this game, which is something that other games still don's seem to replicate all that well.  Other games with trading tend to have restrictions on them, whereas in settlers you can trade things like port use, robber placement, intentions on where you are building, etc.  (I know these aren't all strictly following the rules, but we allow pretty much anything in trades in the games I play).
I don't like this game so much because people just collect cards without want to trade cards with you.
Classic eurogame. It is interesting to see this played on a high level. The game can drag otherwise.
A classic.  I'll play it anytime there's a group that's interested.  On the other hand, it feels increasingly simplistic and one dimensional strategy-wise the more I play other games.
I like it, but prefer Cities and Knights expansion. Had a session take about 6 hours once because we made the field too small and had crappy numbers on there.

A very simple to learn and play. Due to the clever gameboard creating mechanism this is great fun almost always, even when lady luck decides not to shine on you. The early game is quite critical and that may sometimes ruin a play for someone, though. This is always a good choice.

My gateway game. Really nice mix of tactics and strategy combined with some luck, bargaining, and threatening make this an absolute classic. Everyone who likes games in the least should play this game.
the great leveller, the game which started it all (for me anyway). still one of the games with better direct player interaction (trade phase).
Nice game. Bit too much luck involved. Good for family/friends evenings
I never want to play it again  Grade should be probably be higher  Only play with C&K expansion
Fun game.  Got me back into gaming.  Kind of grown out of Vanilla, but will play if that is the only flavour people want, or need to teach the game to a newb.
This game has always seemed to be screw the loser. Its fun, but way to much is based on dice and random luck for my taste. Not quite sure why the game was popular enough to spawn a billion expansions

My first "German" game, like so many other people. I loved it immediately but have since discovered a whole world of games that I love even more. If it weren't for this one, I probably wouldn't have discovered all of the others though.
Too much chance involved for my liking

It's a real gateway for non-gamers. The rules are simple enough and I like its negotioation mechanism. I tried it with my relatives and with friends and it was always fun. Even my mother in low, who had hated boardgames before, tried it and was delighted.  It proved to be worth buying.

Played so much I got bored with it. If you haven't tried, don't waste your time reading this. Buy it.  Plenty of luck involved as resource collection is controlled by the dice, which can result in many grey hairs.

Excellent game.  Nice components, good length, plenty of different strategies to play.  I prefer Seafarers with an experienced group, but Settlers can be played with nearly anybody and is still a lot of fun.

The classic Euro Gateway game.  If you are one of the 5 people on the planet who hasn't played this game you really should.  It has all the features I really like in a game: a modular board, meaningful player interaction, resource management, a decent play time (about 1 hour) and moderately challenging tactical choices.  The down side is that luck can figure somewhat prominently in the game and players can make very foolish trading decisions with other players that ends up hurting you; however, that just means you have to do some table talking and stronger negotiating.  This adds in some interesting player interaction that often gets overlooked by people who don't like this game.  It's not a perfect game of course, but I think it is a good classic game that is still the gateway of choice for many.
Settler's is a bit long for the game that it is.
No me terminan de convencer los juegos con negociaciÃ³n. Si los juegas con gente adecuada pueden estar bien, pero de lo contrario pueden ser tediosos y desagradables.
After 40-50 plays, I'm not sure if I'll ever tire of this game.  The one 5 hour session we had was a bit much though...

Played a lot of this in the late 90's and then got a bit burned out on it. Trading isn't my favourite mechanic. People complain about the dice in this game but I've been far more frustrated with people handing the game to one player through poor trading.
This is my "gateway" game.  Settlers officially started my geekdom.  After many games i dropped the rating a bit, but nonethless a classic for me.  Recently playing w/ my 5yo son.

This was a good one.  I must admit, it was a little disappointing to play though.  I think the disappointment came because of all the hype about this game and how great it was.  I thought it would be much better than it was. It just felt like it was missing something but maybe it was the fact that I didn't see what all the hype was about. With that being said, I still felt like it was an enjoyable game.  If the hype factor wasn't included, I may have enjoyed it more.  There were lots of decisions to make and several ways to win.  Everybody was in the game to the end.  The game is worth a decent rating because it is a good game.  It is not worth the "Cult-like" reaction that I see so much on the site and elsewhere.  Not the best Eurosnoot out there and really doesn't see the table of my gaming group more than once every few months.

What can you really say about this great game that hasn't been said already?  One of the principal reasons there is a boardgaming revolution.  Also one of the key pieces in my arsenal for converting non-gamers.
Fun game to play, moves on with nice phace. Luck can be issue

A fun game, perhaps I've played it too much!  One of the most reliably varying simpler games around due to the dynamic board setup, such that it's always a good battle with 4+ people as each game will be so different.  The one thing that stands out is that periods of dice droughts in the mid-game can make the game feel a real drag sometimes, as it's like watching your teeth get slowly pulled, seeing the game slowly slipping away, and with nothing you can do... all while taking depressing two second turns (with your one or two resource cards) while everyone else takes long turns doing many things.  But that aside, it's certainly a fun game.  And definitely enjoy the Cities and Knights expansion as well to spice things up.
An amazing gateway game. I'm now heartily sick of it but it continues to delight those new to the hobby that I introduce it to.
3-4 players  Includes Seafarers expansion, Catan event cards, Fishermen of Catan, and Great River of Catan.

[57 plays] The first German game I introduced to our family and friends. Stumbled onto it somehow in 1999 years before I discovered BGG. We played this nearly to death over the course of a year or two. In recent years it has come out one or two times each year for some fun and nostalgic play. This game deserves so much credit for the popular revival of intelligent boardgames in America. I would say more but it isn't necessary as there is just such a wealth of information out there on what a great game Settlers is both for casual play and introducing non-gamers to the world beyond Monopoly.  Enjoy the social play (although it can be mildly contentious), respect the game for how much it does for newcomers, and relax - knowing the whims of the dice can sometimes take control of much of your destiny.  Most recent play 12-31-09 -- a 4 player game with Barb, Tony, and Shelly.

The one that brought me here. A complete finding that wanted me to rediscover board games and see what had happened when I was not playing at all. Simple game, great interaction and apparently well balanced, but sometimes, dice can turn a game into a nightmare.
Still want of the best introduction to more sophisticated family games.
A classic. Usually playing only with Seafarers expansion.
Great game! I can get my wife to play this game and she doesn't really like most boardgames that involve more than roll dice, move piece, repeat...
a great and simple games, which everyone can play
Have played our copy thousands of times, and haven't touched it in a few years.  I've heard that replacing the cards might get us going again.
Another game my wife will play. Luckily, I still like this game, even after repeated play.
I used to love Settlers.  Was one of the earliest games that brought my friends and I to the table.  Lately, it has lost its luster for me.
My first Euro, and still fun to get out.  Not a very "deep" game, but good for introducing new players to gaming, and a popular choice with our game group.
Another game played often that looks more complex than it actually plays. Setting up the map is the biggest drawback. But the game flows quick and people like rolling dice.

The classic German Game. Settlers is simple, interactive, and has good replay value. It's a nice entry level game, and I even got my non-gamer inlaws to like it. The downsides are that you're at the mercy of the dice rolls and initial positioning is crucially important. In fact, the most interesting decisions are made during the setup, before the game even begins. But I do like the trading system, and the game can be fun from time to time as a lighter alternative.
The thing that started this whole mess
My first gateway game, played a lot. Still fun to play, but not getting it often to the table. Can't deny the dice is a huge factor.
Played online too many times to count.
Great game with an optimal mix of strategy and plain old dumb luck. Fun to play with all types of players.

The game that started my reintroduction to board games as an adult. Simple game, easy to explain and I haven't met anyone that didn't like it once they played it. It has been played more by friends and family that borrow it than by me personally.

[10.6]   Location: LB  (no. of plays +~ 15, pre-bgg era :D) Warning: do NOT play with people who don't believe in Win-Win situation. Any attempt to trade with these guys just results in teeth-gnashing, hair-pulling and total dependency on the Dice God.
Fairly deep gameplay, but easy to learn and easy to teach.  Be sure to sacrifice to the dice gods before playing.  There's a bit too much uncontrollable randomness to deal with.
Gateway game. Played the java version a lot and fun with the right crowd. None of the expansions add anything worthwhile. 4 players is just right.
The placing of roads and towns is frustrating, as there never seems to be enough room. Whoever can get the 6 and 8 hexes sewn up will win.
What needs to be said? This game rules the table.
One of the best gateway games. Too random, but still offers some fun.

SDJ  [b]Unique Component[/b] - Modular board and number tiles for random resource production.   [b]Unique Mechanic[/b] - Rolling dice for random resource production.   [b]Quick Thoughts[/b] - I really enjoy this game.  I was inventive and bit ahead of its time.  I also think this games gets a lot of unwarranted crap from gamers.  It is an old game, but it still shines in my opinion.    Most certainly one of the better games ever made.  It is  a great gateway game and the game responsible for me being a big board gamer today.  The original is fine, but much better with Cities & Knights.  Always played with Cities & Knights and sometimes with the Great River and/or the Fisherman.  Rarely played with Seafarers and never with the event cards.  Got in 2004  2007 Plays = 4 2008 Plays = 1 2009 Plays = 2 2010 Plays = 2 2012 Plays = 3
This is aging a bit for me, but we played the bejeesus out of this when we first got it. Even if it's only a few months of infatuation, it's worth it.
Have now played this a ton (I don't keep reliable track on the BGG, but, nonetheless); it is pretty sweet, although I think I like it with cities and knights better.

I used to rate this a 7, and I do still enjoy it, but after having seen (and been) someone hammered down due to bad-roll after bad-roll, over a lengthy game, I do feel that the luck element is a little too heavy (and illogical - I can understand dice-rolls for, say, combat, but it seems odd that an island can only produce a certain few yields a year, of seemingly random produce). I appreciate the part it plays, but it takes me out of the game.  Still, a very solid game. Interesting mechanics, an attractive board, and with engaged players an excellent game. A high 7.
my friends seems to hate the dice-throwing mechanism
Yep, this is the one that started it all for my group. :)
My first true Euro - haven't played it in years can only remember it dragging when I did, although my gut tells me its better than that.
Much too random - but very funny and easy to learn.

Still the ultimate gateway in my books. A little strategy (position of initial settlements), interaction (trading, blocking), tactics (robber, building) and a little luck.  All this in under 90', no real downtime and except in very rare cases all players stay involved.  After a lot of plays my willingness to play has dropped a little (say more like a 6), but in general a rating of 7 seems fair
Game that truly awakened me to the European style of boardgames and whetted my appetite for more...:-)
The classic. I've played it too many times, but it's great for introducing new player to euros. Great balance and lots of interaction.
Lot of non-gamers like this game.  Like the random setup to make it different every time.
A landmark game for me, as it opened the door to the European games that I now love, but I just don't find it that enthralling any more.  Still a great gateway game, though.

An obvious classic but too prone to luck. Also played to death, although I do still use it to bring new gamers into the fold. Something about this game just captures the imagination like no other gateway game does.
The luster has faded - there are so many other games that I have more fun with. Weird that I like this game better with no trading....

This is one of the first 'gamer' board games that I played. At this point we have a monster set. Two basic sets, a copy of the seafarers, and the cities and knights expansion. I think we also have the five and six player expansions as well. Talk a bout a monster.
Good fun. Can suffer a bit from 'I dont like you ****. So no I wont give you this resource card'.

My mom one day showed up with this boardgame and we were rather eager to play it (most likely enofrced by the fact that the box looked inviting) and I have to say we weren't disappointed, even my brother played (though he normally preffered to stare at a PC-screen all day). It's been a long, long time since I played it, but I have some fond memories of this game. :)

Settlers was my introduction to German games.  I prefer it with the cities and knights expansion, but in itself it isn't a bad game.  Just make sure you don't try it with only two people...especially if you're married to the other person.  :)
The 'granddaddy' of euros, and one of the best. Seems to be as enjoyable as ever, although there's no denying it's aged considerably since its release.
The game that got me hooked on board games again! I try to play this as often as possible.
It is a classic that won me into the hobby. I think that it's becoming a victim of it's own success.
A fun game but with a lot of randomness to it.  Trading can become weighted.  Still a fun game to play.
The more I play this, the less I enjoy it - I am down rating it.

I often use this as a gateway game, and most of the people like it. Plays best with 4 sociable players who enjoy interaction and meta-game dickering. King-making and rich-get-richer scenarios are abundant, though.
The classic Gateway game.  Still gets pulled out from time to time...
Tried the Teuber 2 player variant and it played well.   Good player interaction & some decision-making. This is a solid general purpose game that belongs in any group's library.

En mi opinión el juego más equilibrado entre calidad y ventas comerciales. Con la expansión de Cities & Knights se convierte en "EL JUEGO DEFINITIVO". Un misterio el porqué no están más arriba en la lista...
Personally I don't like this game.  Once you have placed the settlements, I would say the game ends.  Afterwards it's too luck-dependent.
Good family game, not bad for "gamers" either.
Classic.  One of the best to introdice people to non-traditional style games.  Everyone that plays it loves it and ends up buying a copy.
My entry into this world of modern boardgaming, never gonna trade this, sentimental value is to strong

OK, OK, too much luck involved. But this is the game that started all, at least for the majority of modern gamers. High rating just for its historical merits.  And after all it's a good game to be played with younger gamers
A bit up to the dice rather than up to strategy
A great game to play with others.  So many of my friends have a copy that I don't need to own it.

This is my ultimate gateway game. The moment the board's set up it catches the eyes of passersby. With simple rules that can be taught in 10 minutes, continous engagement between turns and the thrill of negotiation, Settlers has always delivered a superlative first impression to new gamers. This game is a trusted friend. Highly recommended.
This is the game that got me hooked on the hobby for good.
What is there to say?  A pretty good game, but kind of random.  I can think of other things I'd rather play, but I won't reject this one.
I just got into this game recently, despite the fact that I've been playing the German style stuff since the late 90s. It's fun as long as you don't get hosed by the dice.

I think the bloom is coming off the rose here--this is the game that got me into the wider boardgaming world, but I'm finding that four-player games are increasingly agonizing, and long stretches of waiting for my number to come up, or for my number to come up while the robber isn't sitting on top of it, are not my idea of a good time.  Everyone else I play with seems to love it, so I'm hoping I can wean them off.  I'm not buying all these other games so that they can just sit on my shelf, you know.  EDIT: Oh, who am I kidding.  I just played this game, lost badly, and still had a really good time. 6 --> 7

Great game, Probably the one that got me hooked on gaming over the last few years. the only reason it hasn't been brought out lately is the new additions I picked up over the last few months, mainly Powergrid.
Great Game Quick and easy to play Never get bored as each game is different and challenging Recommend 4 player rather than the 6 player version
ATL - Every collection needs Settlers, but you don't always need to play Settlers.

My first euro game and still very enjoyable. I don't like it as much as I did in the 'glory days' when it was our game of choice, but it's still a good game. Frustrating at times, but I always get a buzz setting out the tiles and choosing my start positions. (8.5)
Just Fine. A very good Eurogame for newbies. Simple, luck dependant but with a nice trading mechaninc. A lot of interaction between players. Simple but good.
I can still play the basic Settlers game anytime, although I prefer C&K.
Fast and easy. Family game for beginners
First Euro I bought. still enjoy it with my family.   Update : Probably would play this if asked. Not a fan of the expansions - same game but twice as long.

PRO - Still enjoy playing this on occasion.  The first non-traditional game I played.  Will usually introduce this to people new to the boardgame scene after TtR and Carcassonne.    CON - While the dice-rolling doesn't bother me in the least, I do get occasionally peeved when trading turns into the floor of the NYSE.
Ever changing map means ever changing strategy. And with 2 addons available, the variations never end!

This was a major gateway discovery for us. We loved it to bits and played it  alot with the children. We still play it sometimes with our gaming group, but the outcome does seem to be decided by those initial placements and how the dice land.
Play it with the expansion "cities and knights of catan". Strongly recommendet.
Another good strategy game focused on resource collection and thwarting of your neighbors.

Instead of houses and hotels, you have settlements and cities.  Instead of Income and Luxury Tax, you have the Robber.  Instead of Boardwalk and Park Place, you have wood and sheep.  Instead of Community Chest and Chance, you have development cards.  Instead of trading, you have... trading.  Instead of "roll 2d6 and pass the dice", you have... roll 2d6 and pass the dice.  It may have a slightly more manageable timeframe and no player elimination, but let's face it: Settlers is really Monopoly in disguise.  And that's why it's so successful.
This game was outstanding at the time it was made. It´s fall from grace is at the same time a mark of the legacy that this game made. It belongs now to board game history.
Yeah, I know this is a massively popular gateway game, but I've just never been able to find a groove in this game.  Maybe Eurogaming's caused me to become yet another dice-hater.

A classic.  Loved it from the first time i played it.  The only frequent issue is that certain crops "drought" rather badly when playing, making the game sluggish.  That having been said, I LOVE trading, and this scratches the trader itch very well.
If you know just monopoly this is the best game to start with - easy, interesting, communicative. But I hate dice - thay're so unpredictable :)
We always have fun with this.
I have played basic Settlers dozens of times.  I highly recommend using the Cities & Knights expansion and the event card deck with the base game.  Rating with these expansions: 8
Settlers by itself is a bit dry.  Cities and knights makes it a far better game.  However, this one isn't bad on it's own.

My first Eurogame.  Now, I look at my collection, and I am suprised at how many Euro games I own. Settlers is a classic, in every sense of the word.  Unfortunately, not a great 2-player game, so it never even got opened. Plus, the whole wood for sheep thing gets old real fast  Sold cheap to another Geek.  Merry Christmas!
I heard this was good. They were right.
Good game.  Blah, blah blah, you've already read plenty of others.
A great gateway game. I prefer this with 3, as 4 players takes longer and really clutters up the board.
I really enjoy this game.  Most of my play time has been logged on the 360, but I don't record that here.  I'm not allowed to play with my girlfriend, cause I'm too cutthroat:(.
Along with Carcassonne, this was one of my gateway drugs. I just wish it didn't have the dice mechanic.
