Hasn't aged as well as its contemporary "El Grande", but I still blow the dust off of this once in a while. Still has that "let's play again" factor which so many games lack.
It's a classic. Too much luck.
It's difficult to say anything about Settlers that hasn't already been said. My personal opinion is that while it may not be the best of all possible games, it remains a solid playing experience.
Another one in the "to play with family" list, i still love it and i have never had an issue with luck.
My modern day version of the classic game of Risk. This is THE board game that got me hooked on playing board games again.  (Palm Springs)
NEVER play this with more than 4 players again!

Irritating game if the dice doesn't roll for you. But at the same time this one gets you all hooked up. I finally got it in a trade. Until now i have played it only online and i must say it's much better on board.
Classic game. not much more i can really say. I would say its an 8 when you add the expansions in. Depends on the group though, I've heard some terrible stories.
After about a zillion games online, I finally got tired of it.  The speed of playing online makes a 2-hour live game a bit trying.
since discovering so many other games, not playing much of this anymore. But it is still a very good game
Great game, full of nasty but fun situations. While there are better games at this complexity level, Settlers continues to bring me back - it is special.

This was my gateway game, and the board game I have spent most of my time playing (other than MTG and Blood Bowl).  Even today, this game is as fun and refreshing as it was when I first got into board gaming, although I prefer to play with the expansions now.  This game is basically the Super Mario Bros. of board games.  It came out of nowhere while the awful Atari library (Monopoly, Risk + co., etc) were dominating American board gaming.
Gateway drug if there ever was one.
A modern classic. The balance can easily be thrown off if the group is too nice about the Robber.
I can't really add anything to the tide of comments on this game, except to say that I like playing it.
with Fishermen of Catan, C&K, Seafarers - all 5-6 players.  Also own Japanese magnetic travel version.
Never hit the table after I got the 10th anniversary edition.  Traded away.
Enjoyable, but really needs Seafarers to shine.

I had first played this game once or twice several years ago, before I really got into boardgames. Playing again tonight I needed a refreshener, which really helped, as I was able to win by several points.,  A very good game, but wouldn't want to play it all the time.  ~~~~~~~~~~  Played with 6 and the event cards, and a variant where anyone could build at the end of everyones turn. It took a bit longer than I would have liked. I liked the event cards as they added some variety, but at the same time felt that they could seem lopsided at times.
Great game - GREAT - and the game that brouoghtme back to gaming. But I can no longer play it... just to bored after hundreds of games.
Original German edition, from Germany (thank you sister-in-law!)
I finally had a chance to play this game.  It was fun.  I can see why so many people play this game.
Very simple and easy, but still a lot of fun (at least when all players have equal skills). Took a half round of game play in order to adjust to the easy rules.
Extremely enjoyable game. Just lovely. Good gateway game. On repeated plays some games are just frustrating, so I'm bumping it to a 7.
Trying to figure out a good two-player variant.
At times frustrating resource handling and trading. The heavier gateway game.

Everyone I introduce this to enjoys it.  I'm a bit tempted to leave this copy with my father and pick up a new version so I can get the expansions (or possibly just the new cards so they all match).  I think we're about ready to add the 5-6 player expansion to let more people play or possibly the Seafarers so there is a bit more variety without really changing the core gameplay (which everyone loves but they don't really love learning extra rules).

Why does this game work so well?  I can't quite figure out how this game manages to hit every game players initial sweet spot.  It encourages sociability I guess, and is interactive without being downright cruel.  I don't have the desire to play it over and over and over, as each game feels a little similar to the last.  But I'll play it now and then for sure.
Ah, my re-introduction into gaming. I wonder why I used to be a Risk fan.
Always a solid choice, though not my go-to game.
A classic. A bit too simple for my taste but it makes a great beers & chips game.

This is a very fun game with the right group of people, because of the high amounts of social interaction between the players that the game encourages. You can trade resources with your opponents, you can gang up on other opponents, you can have all sorts of fun scheming & strategizing with (or against) other players. If you have a rowdy group of friends, this is probably the game to take out. Lots of fun.
Though I have no desire to play it anymore, it was an awesome game for its time.

Got me re-interested into board gaming around 1999 as my first foray into the world of Euro-games. Better yet, it got my spouse into board gaming and was easy to introduce to family members and friends, even if they didn't want to play nearly as often as I'd like. Loved the modular board adding replay value, the non-traditional use of dice in a game, indirect confrontation through competition for spaces, and interactivity brought about through trading - all in a game that runs 45-90 minutes.  Some minor flaws: bad initial placements can lock a player out early, serious opportunities for kingmaking if losing players freely trade with leaders close to finishing, while unbalanced starting boards that make resources unusually scarce or group dynamics that don't favor trading can result in games that drag longer than they should. Played 20+ more times than logged on BGG.

A classic, I still enjoy this game, although it does not get played much lately. The randomness of the dice rolls for resource can be frustrating sometimes, but overall I think it adds to the newbie appeal of the game, since there can be enjoy luck to overcome some strategic mistakes.
So good. 100  plays a year. EDIT: Comment from 2004.
The one that started it all (a.k.a. The Gateway Game).  Still have fun playing when introducing non-gamers into the "sport".  I do much prefer it with the Cities and Knights expansion though.
My first Euro game and a game that I still thoroughly enjoy. It is made better by Cities and Knights though. A solid game all around.
Fun game with the right crowd. I wish there was a way to mitigate the luck for the dice rolls.
Great game and appeals to a surprisingly large audience.
A classic game with plenty of replayability.
A good all round game. Even if my friend Lynn does win all the time.  the game from germany that won 100 000s US hearts.
Definitely on my top 5 games of all time list.  This one never gets old.
This runs a bit long for my taste, but it is a good group experience. My group uses a mash up of a couple expansions, and has eliminated dice rolling.

07/2007:7 Great game, but once again very luck dependent. It has been a while since I played Settlers, but it is still a classic game and I have fond memories of it. I believe Settlers is a good gateway game for newbies. A great game with 4 players, but anymore than that with the expansion and the game drags on.
It's Settlers of Catan.  What more needs to really be said?
I started by disliking it, but it grew on me. A solid game, not the best but good enough.
a Classic, the beginning and still one of the best gateway games on the market.
Absolute Classic - who would not have this in their collection?
With the right people ..this is a blast. Official 2 player variant it very good and makes base game more strategic.
The first Euro I owned and now gets the least amount of play.

What's extraordinary, I made (with a little help of my wife) a home version of this game. Without any printing or photocoping. Just various kinds of paper, scissor, glue, crayons, felt-tip pens. Yes, I was desperate that time. Some things happen once in a lifetime :-). What can be irritating in the game are the dice (randomness). On the other hand the trade aspect is great. It's a good gateway game (not so family anyway) and I can play it from time to time.
[Lots of games played] My favorite Negotiation game.  The reason why I am buying so many games.
The game that revived the boardgame geek inside of me. After the first introduction, immediately went out to buy Settlers, Seafarers and Cities & Knights.
One downside of the game is how easily the tiles move if someone accidentally knocks the table.
Great game for gamers and non-gamers alike.

The old, venerable "got wood for sheep?" classic.  Probably the best known game in my collection among my friends, most of whom are not gamers.  The good is that Settlers is extremely easy to explain: roll, trade, build, next player.  Play is as fast as people can seal trade deals, and there is a good deal of player interaction.  The bad is that the game is just a little too long these days has been eclipsed by newer designs.
Very fun.  Altough whenever I've played it, I've felt like the game decides the winner more then the players.  Still very fun, and a good game to get your "normal" friends into heavier weight games.

Wonderful game with several possible strategies that plays differently every time. Always ends a little too soon. A good game for the introduction of 'full scale' Euros to new players. New players would enjoy the room of the 3-player game whereas gamers need the full 4. Better balanced than the card game due ganging up to 'get the leader'. Probably should be a 7 with repeated play. Actually prefer the older edition components to the 3D version.  Unless players are of equal experience, the newer player will likely not know who is in the lead when making trades and placing the robber.

I have changed my rating of Settlers from a 6.5 to an 8.  The first time I played this game, it lasted two hours and forty-five minutes, and I wanted to pound my head against the wall.  I've since replayed this game and found why people like this game so much.  As long as everyone stays with the game, and doesn't make lengthy negotiations, it's tons of fun.  (Purchased through Thoughthammer.)
Better with the C&K expansion, more scoring opportunities, small board less confining.  But the original still holds a special place in my heart.

As a wargamer and roleplayer who favors historical or fantasy settings, I resisted playing this game for some time. Recently, I finally broke down and played the game with all the hype.  I must admit, I enjoyed it, particularly the extorting of resources from a player to avoid targeting them with the robber (is that legal?...well, we we did it!)  The only thing I didn't like is the absolute abstraction of it all.  The game system is simple and elegant, but I personally have a hard time getting into a game that doesn't realistically (at some level) depict anything.  Even Memior 44, which is hardly realistic, at least allows to me feel like I'm involved in something concrete.  I guess I'll stick with my wargames.
Improved the rating by a full point and a half recently, solely due to its amazing gateway qualities.  I still think it has far too much luck.
Would be better if I didn't manage to run into AP players

My main gripe with this game is that there is little you can do to stop somebody from winning (other than by winning yourself).  Other than that, I think this is a great game.  It was my introduction into "serious" board games.
Like so many others, this was pretty much my intro to Eurogames.  I still play it just about every day on jsettlers.
A little on the simple side but fast to play.
Use this to teach basic maths and probability to my kids. It is possible to play with a focussed 4 year old, and its fun to play with fully grown geeks.
My wife's favourite game and a classic design.
Fun game, though easy to get screwed over on the die rolls.  My wife liked it, and actually won the first game.
Very playable! Easy to learn, fun to play. Perhaps could be just a little bit deeper in terms of different strategies.

Has not aged well in this gamer's experience.  No question it, Carcassonne and Ticket to Ride are still the gateway games I take out for non-gamers.  With "real" gamers, I will refuse to play this in favour of virtually everything else.

It's a great game, I've played it more times that any games I own (except Risk). My friends seem to love Eurogames more than I do, aince their first plays of this, they have bought Mexica and Carcassone. I am planning to buy El Grande, Blue Moon City, Puerto Rico and Die Macher... I dont like Euros that much, I just want to spend more quality time playing...  It has lost some of its coolness over the plays, I'll start to bring more games to the table and then return to this.  Edit: As you see I have bought lots of other games.   Edit: Down to 7, played it again while teaching my friend's girlfriend how to play: It just ain't worth it without C&K.  [Mostly played with: 3]  Edit: I've found why I didn't liked the original game that much, most of the times I played with 3 and this should be played with 4.   [Played best with 4]

I played this game (and its expansions, Seafarers and Cities & Knights) several times a week for several years. It can be very frustrating when none of your numbers are rolled.  I use a house rule to mitigate no numbers being rolled especially at the beginning of the game. When you don't get any cards on a roll, you get a penny or other marker. You can trade these markers in on your turn for a resource: you turn in the same number as your current score. These markers can never be taken away and do not count against card limits, etc. It's been a while since I've played much. My Mayfair 3rd edition is really worn out, so I've collected the various 4th edition game and expansions, with the intent that I'd start playing it occasionally again.

This is the game that got me into the whole world of boardgaming.  Some friends had it, introduced us to it, and it was a lot of fun.  So, now we're building our collection, and we're still using Settlers to get other people into the hobby.
really a good game, but we hardly play it anymore without the cities and the knights.

Very sad when not getting resources, very happy when they come rolling in. Lucky not to have played it much - meaning I'm not tired of it.  Two years later. . . finally played it again. This time with a "food stamp" cube given to anyone who didn't get a resource that dice roll. You can trade food stamp cubes equal to your current number of victory points for any one resource card. Also, no rolls of 7 allowed on the first two rounds. These rules helped a lot!
Much has been written about this game.  I will say one thing:  the 3D version is spifferiffic and when I have more money than sense, it will be mine.
7/2/18 - More interested in playing using my fudge die variant.
Brilliant game, have almost played it too much! Crowd pleaser!  Have played approx 50 more times before joining BGG!

Talk about gateway games...  Like most Americans, this game pretty well ushered in the board game renaissance for my family.  We played the living hell out of this thing and its expansions, but now we never touch it because, well, we've played the living hell out of it.  I've viewed with grudging interest some of the mini-expansions that have been appearing, and hope that/wonder whether those event cards would help "flatten the curve" for the production rolls.  Given the number of actual rolls made in the game, it seems like either 6 or 8 is always missed the whole time!  That's wacky.

This is the game that rekindled my love for gaming and sent my recreation dollars in a whole new direction...  but I started playing with C&K which I rate VERY highly.  The base game just doesn't do it for me without C&K or a T&B variant.

Die Siedler is certainly a classic for all sorts of players the concept of an everchanging lanscape and trading with each other is great but at times it gets too cutthroat for me especially with four players and most limited growth option.  I tend to like the nicer variants in such clustered situations.
The game that introduced me to Eurogames. OK game for me. Occasionally annoyed with the luck factor, but the social and interactive aspect of the game brings me back time and again.
I will play it if others want to, but I would always rather be playing something else.

I like the element of chance and the great player interaction, combined with the considerable strategic and tactical choices to make.  Plays fast, no player elimination and no 'analysis' problems.  Overall, a great game that's usually a lot of fun. Not rated as highly as I used to rate it, because I see now it suffers from chance having far too much effect in the first few turns: if you don't get resources early while your opponents do, you're hosed for the rest of the game, and it's not much fun. I've dropped my rating of this game once again, after another un-fun game. I don't need to WIN to have fun, but when I've managed to build only one section of road while other players have built their third settlement and two cities, it's something wrong with the game. But don't forget, I said "It's usually a lot of fun" and I mean it.

I don't like it at all with the Robber.  We have to house rule him into a harvester (mobile village for the player who moves him), with no adverse effect on the 'real' villages bordering the hex.  This game has bombed on first impressions, when a new player does not get good rolls, has no resources, cannot build, and cannot trade.  Wife and daughter like the game though, and it's one of the few they play frequently.

Played it to death, but can't abide the dice nowadays. The way you can be completely screwed at the very beginning by a run of unlikely dice throws... I suppose I might give it another go with a dice deck.
One of my most played games. Will not play without seafarers though. Great introductory game. Very social so people do not mind trying something new while having some laughs.
My first Euro.  Love the variability of every game, as the island changes every time.

Fun game with medium staying power. We played this game several dozen times within 2 years, but now we only play it about once a year. It is a VERY good game for teenagers. About 40 times better than Risk or Monopoy. A game takes about 90-120 minutes.

Bring it to the table if you want to infect friends with the gaming disease. Some may say that Ticket to Ride or whatever modern light game is better for introducing non-gamers to the world of gaming but the trading in Settlers makes it so, that there is lots of table talk. Ticket to Ride can be a fairly quiet affair. So while TTR and other games might be more modern designs, the table talk from settlers makes it the better gateway game for me.

Despite it not feeling all the modern, I like Catan. It seems like a solid Euro and can be pretty fun.   I'm not really its target market, so I think that perhaps speaks more highly of the game than anything else.
It's fun, but does get kind of one-sided.
Well, I have played it now and it was OK. The luck element felt way too heavy to allow for forward planning and it felt a bit fiddly for a gateway (and a bit long). Ho hum, have ticked it off.

Con las siguientes expansiones:  - Catan: Seafarers. - Catan: Cities & Knights.   - The Settlers of Catan - 5-6 Player Extension.   - Catan: Seafarers - 5-6 Player Extension.   - Catan: Cities & Knights - 5-6 Player Extension.  - Settlers of Catan - Event Cards. - Settlers of Catan - The Fishermen of Catan. - Settlers of Catan - The Great River.
The original euro-style board game in my collection. Many nights in coffee shops spent playing this while in high school.
Settlers of Catan is the gateway drug to the gaming world!
Much better game when played with experienced group otheriwise it moves to slowly and can become tiresome.  Still get's plenty of play time at our place.

Juego de negociación, estrategia y de algo de suerte con los dados. Fácil de jugar y muy adecuado para principiantes incluso para niños (más de 9 años. Deberán intentar no dejarte cerrar y además procurar optar a todos los recursos. Aumentar de pueblo a ciudad siempre suele dar buenos rendimientos y las cartas de progreso te sacarán de algún apuro.

Deserves its status as a classic gateway Euro. After playing with a number of first timers, everyone has loved it and wanted to replay. Sometimes the dice will screw you, get over it. The other day I bought 11 development cards over 2 games, earning a total of 9 soldiers. That's why its called luck.
a nice starters game, wich you can play many hours
One play, my wife likes it more than I do.  May like it more with more plays.  Very random.
Now a 'classic' game, very fun and entertaining. One of the best entry games out there. Easy to explain and fun for people to get involved with.

A different, simple but elegant game idea. Higly recommended! My critics is that I find the game end abrupt. It is not clear to everyone when the game i about to end. Another drawback is that pacts may form that makes the game less intresting. I also think that the trading between players is a bit tideous.

Recognised by many as the game that has given new life to board gaming, this game is easy to learn, forgiving in its options, has trading between players and a limited amount of negative interference, while it is not the best game in my collection it remains a fond friend for the occasional play.
Pretty much a requisite for players looking for a Euro-style game. Luck/randomness is introduced by use of dice, but no two games play the same. An excellent game.

Nice game, but far too much luck.  Games can drag so badly just because of a bad starting position and a series of bad rolls of the dice.  Or the game can zip by so unfairly it is hardly challenging.  I'll play it, but it's not near my favorite.
After numerous plays this game has lost its luster, but I don't support the negative flak this game has generated on the Geek.

Catan definitely has it's flaws, but especially with the Seafarer expansion it is a nice exploration-, trade- and building-game. Easy to teach to non-gamers.. and they usually like it. Still I do understand if some people prefer games w. more elegant mechanics.
Expectations were too high for this game.  NOT BAD at all of course but more is expected.
On recent playing, I found I didn't enjoy it quite as much as I used to; but it is the one that started it all for me. We owe gratitude to the game and everything surrounding it.

Nowhere as amazing as I thought it was when I first played it all those years ago, but still a half decent game.  I refuse to play with more than 4 players, though.  Just bogs down too much.  I think Cities and Knights improves it for me.  Rarely play any version these days.  Probably my main beef is the dependence on the good will of others, which I rarely get since I have a reputation of winning too many games.
Good game, but luck can have too much of an effect on the game...at times the game can be, dare I say boring, if you can not expand.
My gateway game.  Still playing it.

This really is a great intro game.  My brother routinely suggests that we bring it over when we got to my parents house to visit.  It is a GREAT gateway game.  That being said, I only give this a 7.5 because I'm not sure it's the game I'd suggest. Will I ever turn it down? Not at all.  Would I recommend it all the time.  I'm not quite sure.
Not my first choice, but a good game nonetheless.
Far more plays than reflected here.
This is what introduced me to Eurogaming.  Even with all the options its various expansions provide, the original is still a compelling game on its own.
A wolf dressed in sheep's clothing. Supposedly a nice Eurogame. Have you played it? Vicious game.  Good game, but not really friendly.
Mostly on-line play, which may lead me to rate this game higher than it should be (as it plays really quickly on-line).

I used to enjoy it and play it often with family and friends (casual gamers) in the 90's. After a break of almost ten years I'm starting to get into it again. This time with experienced gamers. Men, do I suck at this. And I used to think I'm good at it.
A classic that I need to create some custom expansions for (but I guess I should wait until I've played all the other Catan stuffs).

Luck and good trading partners are the key ... unfortunately I have rubbish luck, and my daughters gang up against me ;( However, it's still a good game, and I don't just play it against my family... There's a 2 player variant, which is excellent, if heavily affected by a bad run of dice.

The game that introduced me to German games.  Quick play, trading, resource collection all combine to create a great game that has a perfect mix of strategy and luck..The trading element encourages a level of player interaction that is lacking from that other great "gateway" game of TtR.

This game is great for those who want an exciting game for gamers of all skill levels.  Personally, I find that there is too much chance involved, seeing as how the dice play a huge role in the game.  I tend to prefer the more strategy-intensive games, such as Puerto Rico.
I don't think I'll ever grow tired of this. Very simple and straightforward, yet every game provides a new challenge.
Good game for both young and old players. Simple, fast and with a fairly high replay value. Not quite serious enough for hardcore wargamers, but good for gaming with your family.
Wunderland-Variante: Anstatt Dieb gibts ein Erntehelfer. Bei 7: Ertragreiches Jahr. Erntehelfer verdoppelt die ErtrÃ¤ge einer Karte.
A fun light game. Curse the Robber!!!!
Sja voor de instap bordspel avonden. Niet mijn favoriet.

It took a few years for a friend to convince me to play this game.  When I finally played, I enjoyed it immediately.  Once I'm got a little bored with the game, the expansion sets and the variants in Das Buch livened it up again.

Quite impressed on one play.  Thing that strikes me the most is that there appears to be several very unique methods of pursuing victory.  Dice results CAN make it a bit random at odd points, though, which...not my thing

Want to hook a girl in boardgaming? This is the one. Nice little wooden buildings, cute sheep, no killing or otherwise pointedly confrontational play. The robber adds just enough excitement. A good one.
Fun game! Gets very competitive as well. :)
Otherwise known as "Whoever rolls the most 7s wins," but I still enjoy a game sometimes in spite of myself. One of those games which can be "fun" despite its flaws.
Will always keep a high spot because it was my introduction to these little things called Euros.  Recently added the event cards and love 'em.
The random outcome of the dice is often very frustrating =( Incredibly casual to play though :D
The game that started us into gaming.  We always loved games, but this got us into Eurostyle.
This is a fun game that is better with 4 or more players. It's simple and fun to play, but I like Carcasonne better. I've only played this once though.
Well-balanced, fun-for-everybody kind of game. I don't like too much the trading part, which reminds me of Monopoly :)

Probably played this 50+ times before I started recording plays.  I have no desire to play any more, but that's more burnout than hate.  Like many, this was my intro to modern board gaming, so it will always have a place in my collection.
Fun, easy, social. I can't see this game being something to get really fired up about, but I'm glad to have a copy around.
A game that I enjoy a fair bit.  Sometimes tiresome, but usually fun if played with the right people.  Does not play well with only 2 players.

What can I say that hasn't been said yet about this game?  A classic, the cause of Eurogames' boom, a really good game.  Players are colonists in an island trying to develop roads, towns and cities getting and using different raw materials, trading and avoiding thieves.
Great introduction to "Euro" boardgames, great for most ages, but luck plays too much of a factor for my taste.
Base game is very simplistic. Much better when Cities and Knights and Seafarers are added.
[many more than 3 plays] I'm not at all tired of this classic.  But I do increasingly feel that odd numbers of players are best.  The original island is too small for 4 people.
Got this game Christmas 2007. It is a lot of fun but truly shines with more than 2 players.

Catan is a classic which can be recommended for both newbies and veterans. It's nicely expandable too and translated in many languages.  + Nice combination of dice rolling, card drawing, building and trade. + Lots of interaction between players. + Relies heavily on luck, which keeps things fresh and gives newbies a chance... - ...but can also be frustrating and prevent all strategic gameplay. - Gets pretty crowded even with four players.  Review based on several plays.

Somehow the best part of this game for me is the initial placement of settlements. It does a good job of making the trading aspect tempting enough to flourish without being so necessary that you can't turn your back on a deal. Some games stall out a bit in the middle and the fun drops precipitously at those times.
Good game, but I always liked Carcassonne more.
Very good game, though a trifle light for my taste.
This game is headed for the Hall of Fame for games.  The conflict is the struggle to succeed.  Losers don't walk away thinking that they just lost an hour of their life they will never recover.
Relatively simple to grasp the basics, I'm sure Settlers would be a game to get new folks (other than my mrs) into board games.
The game that started it all for me...

I like the game mechanics of SoC, especially the trading and the development cards. I can't help but feel that the first half of the game is mostly just sitting around waiting for good dice rolls to occur. And then the last third is about players wondering how to advance while avoiding helping the leader. I must try Catan with a dice deck (easily made from two decks of ordinary playing cards) to see if it plays better. Many people call Catan a good "gateway" game I think Hollywood Blockbuster or Carcassonne are much more accessible to the uninitiated. It might work better with those who are already on the verge of becoming geeks.
Still perplexed why it was the hit it was, but it's a nice game.
C'mon - it's Settlers.  We all know it, like it and love it!  Introduced many a non-gamer to board games.
What more can you say except truly an excellent game.
Two D6. Average roll of 7. Yeah right!
Not really fascinated by this game but everyone seems to want to play it.
Good family game, but my family members would rather play others from our collection first. I still like it.
Not a big Eurogamer, but this game is fun.  i wouldn't go out and BUY it but am not difficult to convince to have a game.
Much better with the Cities and Knights expansion.
The game that got me into Euros.  Still fun, but the length and the randomness leave me less enthusiastic these days.
Fun times, relatively simple rules, but requires at least 3 players (making it no fun for a married couple unless friends come over).  A version can be played online at games.asobrain.com.

1st Euro - or at least Gateway Game to bringing Euro's to US en masse.  Although I am painfully bored of this game having played updwards of 500 games, I can find no room in my heart to give this classic any less than a perfect 10.  I think, for me at least, this was the game that helped bring games from overseas to America and continues to help bring about the mainstream board game revolution that we all hope and pray continues to grow.   Update: Victorious!  That's right, my countless hours of Catan-ing finally paid dividends...literally.  I took down the Settlers of Catan Mega-Tourney at the Strategicon last week and got 100 bucks to spend on more games.  Yay sheep!!  Update 2: Victorious again! Won the US Settlers Championship at GenCon and got an all expenses paid trip from Mayfair to Germany to represent the good ol' US of A.  I was the highest English speaking finisher coming in at 8th in the world out of 56 competitors from 28 countries.   Awesome experience.  Wouldn't trade it for anything.

Amazing fun, playable even with non-boardgamers.  EDIT: I still like the game a lot, but have moved it down from a 9 to a 7. It is great for playing with people who normally aren't into games. However, it does suffer from the problem that you can go for long stretches without being able to do anything because you get bad dice rolls for resources. I have nothing against luck in games, but sitting around waiting for your numbers to come up can be a bit dull.
I played this so often when I first got into boardgaming.  Now I'm burned out of Settlers.  I'll take part it if it's the only thing people want to play.
It's Catan...it's automatically a classic.  That said, I've had several non-satisfying playing experiences with it.

The game that got me, like many others, into the wide-world of German games.  Contrary to my low play count, I've got hundreds of plays, since this and Puerto Rico were my only two Eurogames for a long time.  During college, I came home for dinner and a few games of Settlers most every weekend (mostly with the Seafarers expansion).  We finally got burnt out on it, but it had a hell of a run.  After a couple years off, I'm starting to rediscover its greatness as a game system with the Cities and Knights and Traders and Barbarians expansions.
Played only twice before buying Seafarer Expansion.  It was fun, but have never played since I got the expansion.
Had fun playing this with the Sea expansion.

-  This is a game that will still be played 100 years from now. A ground breaking game with all the attributes for becoming a classic. A great game for the whole family. Unfortunately, luck plays a huge role and the initial placement of the settlements can often unfairly help or severely hinder a player.  The 5-6 player game is even worse in this respect. Furthermore, the game is susceptible to decisions based on meta gaming. For these reasons it has lost its initial appeal and I play it only occasionally now. Nevertheless, its mass appeal and staying power are  unmistakable. [05/28/05: rating reduced from 9 to 8.] [03/29/06: rating reduced from 8 to 7.]  -
A bit late to the party here, but I'm glad I finally tried this. Wish it were a better 2 player game, though. Note: Almost all of the plays here are against the computer version.
Another game with a quick setup.  Depending on the players this can be more challenging than it would appear.
Will not play with the dice :)
Great introductory game to move family gamers onto the better stuff. However it can be easy to get stuck in this game if the dice are not nice to you - this can put people off.
Classic game. Also play it online on my X-box 360.
own the original German edition  Not sleeved. (Won't)
Classic, fairly enduring game.  Played a bit too much of it but still worth an occasional go.
Number of plays > 50, from before deciding to log plays.

King of the gateway game to Euros.  Anyone can get into this, and the dynamic board and bargaining element ensure it is never the same game twice.  Can really suffer when people get AP, but has held up through the test of time.

Showing its age compared to many other games in my collection.  It is however the game that started it all so it rightly deserves a spot on the game shelf.  Many non gamers have heard of it too so its there to tempt them into turning into a gaming geek like me! ;)  4th edition production values are average.  Poor die punching, warped hexes and unsealed/untextured cards let an otherwise pretty game down.
Great game to introduce non gamers to our world.

The old standby.  This game, like for so many others, was my entrance into the wonderful world of board games.  If you play it too much, it can get repetitive.  However, a short rest from Settlers is all you need to want to play it again.  Most importantly, Settlers is the biggest hit with my non-boardgaming friends.  It has been such a treat to have found a game with the universal appeal of mainstream games and the strategy/depth of a very good contemporary board game.

It's been 10 years since I played my first game of Catan. It is still an all-time classic for me.  I know that with it being more than 20 years old now that it definitely feels dated among all the other games that have come out.  A lot has happened since my first game of Catan.  But it still and always will have an honoured place in my heart. Once you accept the parameters and that this is a fortune-of-luck game, then it's all fine. I forever will love the aesthetic and I still enjoy the nostalgia. So there we go. My first crush I don't mind revisiting from time to time (especially with Seafarers or C&K as part of it).  Legacy comment (from 2008): What a fantastic game!  I had to buy it after playing it for the first time -- making this the second game I have ever bought new (1st was "Khet").  The trading really makes this game engaging across the table.
Though I recently bought this, I haven't played it in a long time.  My recollection is that I enjoyed it a lot.  Hopefully, I'll get a game or 2 in soon.

I think this is one of the most over hyped games at BGG.  I do like it I just don't think it is great, can be very random.  I will always owe it a debt as it opened my eyes to what non-wargames can offer a gamer.

Can't make up my mind about this one. On the one hand, the concept still seems fresh and original almost a quarter-century later. On the other, trading with fellow players, which seems essential to a good outcome, is not my favorite mechanism.
A few friends and I would play this game daily a while ago. Even now, though we play less often, we are still fascinated with the game.
12Jan08--Finally got to play my Christmas present. Yea! I haven't played for years. "I have wood for sheep," just doesn't get old, does it?

My biggest downside to this game is that it has gotten overplayed....and given all the games we own and love, I don't like to play any ONE game to the exclusion of all others. I think, too, that since it has been seen as a good game to introduce new gamers to, it gets chosen for play quite often. But I think there are lots of good games that you can use to introduce people to the world of gaming, not just Settlers.
My first introduction to Euros. (Big surprise I'm sure...)
Just not very fun to me.

One of the greatest Euros. It introduced me to a new style of gaming, but like many I haven't returned to it in years. I think the game is too often determined by initial placement of settlements. My interest in the game was re-engaged by the XBox Live version, and now my kids are getting into it. My preferred set is the board and cards of Simply Catan with wooden pieces from an older Mayfair Edition.

It's odd that this is the de facto "gateway" game, because the aggressive and sometimes very slow trading phase is sure to put a lot of people off.  Settlers also suffers with its catch-up options -- or lack thereof.  New players can run into trouble when they don't ensure a healthy flow of resources and are stuck watching more experienced players build around them.

Great, and the randomness prevents it from being too competitive.  Unfortunately, it can also mean that luck essentially screws you sometimes and you have a terrible game.  Never play with 4 on the standard-sized board - someone inevitably is out of the running within 3 or 4 rounds.  Then they have another hour of tedium and frustration.

It was three years since I last played and I worried that such a dice based game would not be good. I was wrong. It is essentially a game of probability and trying to get the best odds for yourself. Great fun. Nice gameplay. A bit cutthroat
Good! But not as much as everyone tells, IMO. Too much luck.

This game took many plays for me to warm up to it. It was really through playing 2-player games with my wife that I began to enjoy it. Because it is such a classic game responsible for drawing so many people into gaming, I had to keep trying.  The game can be long and a bit tedious with 4, especially if the dice aren't rolling well, but with 2 and 3 I like it.   Update: It really is a great game.
Simple and amusing. Relies on a lot of interaction. My favourite trading game.
I like this game, but we just don't feel like playing it very much which says something.  We ALWAYS play with the food stamp variant.

Good solid mechanics, smooth gameplay, and simple rules.  My only complaint is that it feels like it goes a little bit too long.  Off-topic: I moderately wanted this in trade until I received about my twentieth offer of Settlers and the 5-6 player expansion for [fill-in out of print game worth at least $10 more in value].

The Harry Potter of the gaming world - re-invigorated the market in the mid 90's. Players aim to gather resources in order to develop their settlements into cities. Trading and shrewd planning are a must. Great entry level game for new gamers.

One day, I realized Catan just didn't do much for me anymore, and around that same time, my wife confessed she never really cared for it to begin with. I still have it on our iPad, and will probably get the Cities & Knights expansion for that sometime, but our nephew has promised to give our physical copy a good home.
I like this game. I never win this game. I like this game a little bit.

Just about the perfect gateway game. The rules are easy to explain and pick up and the dice mechanic and trading is a great equaliser for newbie players against experienced. After many plays I am no closer to hitting on a perfect, winning strategy because the mix of resources is different every time and the interaction of the various mechanics means there are very few "cut and dried" decisions. It's also a very sociable game with lots of talking and little downtime or brain burning. A classic.
Have nearly played this game to death. I worked in a group home once where the clients were addicted to this game and the Cities and Knights expansion. Always a blast.

A classic, definitely! A good game, no question! But, this can also be a very frustrating game. If you get unlucky in your initial placement and/or if the dice just aren't paying attention to the calculated odds and/or that damn robber just won't leave you alone, then the game can drag on for what seems like forever with you not having a chance of winning.
easy rules, fast learning and every game plays another way
If I could get would, I'd trade it for this sheepfully good time.
A great game until you add any of the expansions
Same as everyone:  "Rich get richer" [Game Surplus $24.00 Nov 2005] [SOLD WBC Auction Store $15.00 Aug 2011]
Mi primer juego de mesa. se lo "regale a mi hermano", sencillamente genial.

My first Euro game, and still a favorite. I played a ridiculous amount of Catan in college, and it led me in all sorts of directions, board game-wise.  I'd say it has minor runaway leader issues, and sometimes initial placement can be quite frustrating -- but neither detracts from what an excellent, replayable, and satisfying gateway Euro this is.  The probability aspect is one of my favorite elements, as it nicely modulates the randomness factor. I also particularly like seeing how things shake out when a vital resource is constrained for the whole game because of tile placement.
great game, but luck can be too much for some games played.

This game needs no introduction, it is the Monopoly of the 90ies. I don't actually like it that much, but it is OK. The other games in the family, settler card game and siedler würfelspiel are much better.
A fantastic entry game yet has its place in every gamer's collection.
a classic, It has a loose feel to the play due to the trading/building phase, in turn lending a certain atmosphere to the game that's all of it's own.

we played the heck out of this gateway game for a year.  i'm kinda burned out on it but still recognize that it's a great game, especially for the friends who aren't into playing new stuff as regularly.

9->8->7->8  Jo kis jatek ez kozeptavon is. Nyilvan verprofik kozott az nyer akinek szerencseje van, de kezdokkel es alkalmi jatekosokkal nagyon jo kis partykat lehet tolni, van benen interakcio, egymassal kiszuras, egymas segitese, epitkezes, gondolkodas.

Proof that 2d6 don't bell curve.  It's one of the better intro games out there (me being here is proof of that). The random element actually helps pull in non-gamers as does the quick playtime.  The novice-appeal goes down exponentially the more expansions that are added. Still, I want this game to have something to play with my parents from time to time.
Great gateway game. A bit simple, and there's a lot of luck involved, but I still enjoy playing this. Must try the expansions some time.

Interesting game which I played for the first time recently as many non-casual gamers fear it like the vampire fears the cross, I am not sure why. The game and the fun you have while playing it depends on who you are playing it with, some people enjoy the fierce competition and trying to blockade each other, refuse trading etc., others may find it too vicious. The random element is a nice idea, also experienced players have a big advantage. Another flaw in my opinion is the accumulative nature of successes, the more resources you have, the more you can build and the more you build the more resources you have, which can be a pain in the ass should the starting conditions be unbalanced because that will be hard to flatten out later in the game. Still, a neat little game which could have done with some better artwork and theme instead of the plaster-on. I reckon that the expansions add a lot to it but I am not sure whether Ill ever be able to give those a go, considering the general reluctance of geeks to play it.
This game's popularity is well deserved.
My first Euro (what a surprise, eh?), unless you count Kremlin. A fun game that can be frustrating if the dice don't go your way. Definitely one I will play virtually any time.
Awesome fun. Love the interaction of trading with the other players. Update: Slowly losing its appeal after more plays.
A good game to start with for people who don't game very much. Easy to learn.

Great game (duh!). If we have a new player with us, I can break Settlers out and be sure that everybody will have a great time. Since we've bought Cities & Knights, the basic game feels flat and too simple, hence the lower score.  Update: Upped the score to 8 after playing after a long hiatus.   Update: And the score is down again... There are other, better games we would rather play.
+ Ciudades y Caballeros + Navegantes + 5-6 jugadores expansión
I mainly play this on Xbox live.  I prefer the digital version as set up and scoring are all automatic.  It's easy to find opponents online.
I love playing this game with my friends over Xbox live.  Its always a great time.
This is a great gateway game.
I like the simplicity of the base game.  Perhaps add one small twist.
FOR MEEPLE SECURITY!!!  WATERBOARD THE ROBBER!!!!
Dispite the dice frustration, I still think StC is a great game. It's the game, if you want to introduce new players to the wonderful world of boardgames.
One of the classic "euro" games.  I'm still not a fan of the dice rolling (maybe that's just my dodgy luck) but otherwise a fun game.

i certainly respect it, but i only seem to end up playing it as a gateway game or if somebody happens to request it.  it has an incredible gateway effect with specific people, but it has also tended to make it so they never take interest in another game.  an immediate classic, though, and very important to the hobby.

Clever, simple and fun. It's easy to teach and easy to learn. I think what makes this a great game is its accessibility to many ages and types of people. I wouldn't choose this over something a little more involved, but in many circumstances this will do better than most of the games I have.  Update after 3rd game: I like it, but while it does have some significant historical importance, I just don't think as a game it deserves more than a 7. I hopped on the board game bandwagon about 12 years too late to rate this any higher.
A fun easy euro, not the best game but realy fun none the less.
My "gateway" game beyond childhood, which perhaps slightly inflates my rating.  Using deck of dice really helps game play.
Always makes for an interactive, fun time with 4 friends, as long as everyone's in it and actively participating/trading.
Done to death.  Still can be fun at times, but I only play it online or with my kids.  Never hits the gaming group's table unless we have a new person who has no idea what a Euro is.
Never had to buy it as I always knew someone with it!  HA! Now I am without it!

I've never done well at this game, and that's probably part of my rating.  My biggest issue with this game is that if you get behind it is very very hard to catch up, and you feel like you're just watching the others have a good time.  7/20/07  Update.  I just won my first game coming from behind, and oh, was it sweet.  I'm still not going to update my rating though.
A Great Old One. Still a very good game to play with people who aren't really gamers and also a very good way of converting them gamers...

Beautiful. The rules allow for a light game, with deep tournament like matches should you choose. The random chance going in one players favor can be nudged by the robber or trade embargo, so the amount of chance doesn't bother me. And besides, why should you hate the leader for taking the good numbers you should have taken?

This is a wonderful game; or at least it was for a couple hundred plays. I picked this up on a whim at a comic store down the street to play with my friends before we'd go out drinking. Except we had a hard time leaving the table. Soon we were scheduling Settlers evenings and playing repeatedly till the wee hours. Ah, those competitive nights of playing Settlers when somebody always wanted "one more game."  It seems unfair to rate this game against today's games, but I revere it as the landmark game it is and all the enjoyment it gave me, so I'll bump it up a notch. I'd be hard pressed to sit through a play of it now, however. At least give me Elasund which has a lot more going on. For expansions, I recall Seafarers and Cities & Knights as both being worth it.  This game brought me back into the hobby and, by association, to BGG, so it will always have a place of reverence in my heart.
What can I say--a better Monopoly with trading.  ** SdJ 1995 **
Even if now we have much more complex and interesting Euro games, this "grandaddy" of all remains a good and relaxing choice.
I have played this game about six times and every time I play it I enjoy it more. I am not a huge fan of settlers of catan but I do enjoy it occasionally.

Good gateway game as it involves some luck with the roll of the dice, but it also allows players to make decisions using probabilities.  Helps introduce the concept of victory points, which is not part of your typical American game.
Though dice generally hate me in this game, it's still one of the first that I recall getting me into the hobby.
Have 3rd edition - would rather have newer one
I like it because it is quite interactive (and good).

A classic - the first game that exposed me to the fact that there were all kinds of really cool board games out there that I'd never heard of.  I was completely addicted to it in college.  These days it doesn't see as much play in our group because we have a lot more games to choose from, but it and/or one of its variants or expansions still shows up at the table from time to time.
Fun, but feels very luck driven.
One of the "gateway" games that got my wife started on boardgaming. Hurrah for "Settlers..." and "Alhambra"!

This game is very popular, but is not as good as have rating. Game has several problems:  1. If your first move (placement initial vilage) is wrong game is lost for you.  2. Be richer, be better. If you have advantage, your oponents has small chance to catch you. 3. Your moves are mostly automatic. No real choice. Often only wait for right dice.   Majority games with rating 7.0 or more is better than this game. But this game is legend...
Always the first non-standard game for new players.
What can I say of one of the most famous board game? It's a good introductory game for non gamers. A good mix of luck and strategy, with a very nice interaction between players.
Kids love it, so I play it. Kids love trading for stuff. It's good, not as good as I thought it would be.

This is a remarkable gateway game.  Easy to learn and addictive.  Lots of chance and easily suffers from analysis paralysis, but those negatives don't overshadow the simple fun and tension this game creates.  My sister-in-law gave this to us many years ago, and it definitely elevated all of our board gaming interest to a new level.  We played like 80 games of it that first year.  Now, the original pales in comparison to the Seafarers expansion, which provides for the same gameplay with infinite board varieties.  Still, we always introduce the original first to friends, and we've introduced numerous friends to this.  A great game, especially for casual or newer gamers.
With the cards, this game is back to being interesting...
Great game.  However, we end up playing the "Zarahemla" version more since it is easier to setup (and keep setup - you know what I'm talking about).
I have only played the 2 player variant.
My first Euro game, still played from time to time, though future purchases have betrayed its simple mechanics. The trade system is 90% of the fun here. Experimenting with various variants, too.
Great game if you have an hour. Good for hard core gamers and the beer & pretzel crowd. Enough expansions to keep it fresh.

After 2 years I increase the vote to 7 because it is a game that more easily than others hit the board. Personally I prefer more complex games, but Catan offers a good compromise between a game tactic and duration, using simple mechanics proper for the neophytes.
Got me into Eurogames, but lost a bit of its charm after a few games. But definitely fun every once in a while.

Catan is a good game, and one that I will sometimes trot out to entice a "non-gamer" to get involved. I really don't get to play this as much as I'd like, but it will remain a standard in my collection, I'm sure.
Muy buen juego familiar, en la tradiciÃ³n del Monopoly, Risk, etc. (aunque no se les parece en absoluto). Sencillo, pero con interÃ©s.
Very solid game, but it's possible to get a helpless feeling if the dice aren't rolling your way.
I like how the board changes every time you play and I like the trading aspect of it.  Sometimes bad dice rolls can ruin your chances to win, though.
Probably the first Eurogame that I came across. Simple and fun but, for me, a little bit over long for what it is. Seems a little dated to me, in the face of so many that came after.
Who does not know this one ;) My gateway game which lured my into the great world of boardgames :)
My rating includes the Cities and Knights expansion, which makes the game much better.

A classic (not on its value, but its acceptance).  I will play this with people who are curious to try it, but have been burnt out on it myself.  I prefer the non-trade & reverse robber on 7, knights full rob variant.
9* with Cities & Knights 8* with Traders & Barbarians
Yep, my first Euro too. Still solid.
This and Seafarer's are house favorites.

The first Eurogame I played, and fell in love with.  Doesn't shine quite as brightly for me anymore, but it was my gateway into contemporary board games.  I owe this game a lot...  Probably a dozen plays before I started recording games on BGG.
Really good game.  Many euro-games owe their existence and popularity to The Settlers of Catan.

This game is a classic family game.  For many it was their gateway to bigger and better things in the euro world.  My biggest complaint with vanilla SoC is the endgame grinds, trading ceases and it seems like many turns are spent rolling dice and passing as the players behind seek to inflict "Take That!" cards or robber assaults on the leader.  C & K increases options but also increases playing time for a game that already overstays its welcome in my opinion.  I am interested in trying some of the elements in Traders & Barbarians that would mitigate some of the luck and give more options for VPs.
Fun with a friendly crowd. If you play with a bunch of people out to "get" each other, it gets annoying pretty quickly.
The game that started it for us. My wife and I often play this 2p variant: http://www.baumfamily.org/dave/settlers.html She simply owns me in this game - help!!!
German — 50 EUR including Cities & Knight + 5-6 players + event card expansions
A quality game. Beautiful in its simplicity and as a segway game. Lack of strategic depth and options hold this game down though.
I dislike the droughts of seemingly "bad rolls". I need to force people to play with the deck of cards that replaces the dice.
Fun game, but not quite sure that it is actually to the level of all the hype.

Relatively easy to learn for new players. Quick turns with minimal potential for Analysis Paralysis. Maybe a little too long. But simply fun with just enough luck to make it accessible to newbies and fun.
Not my wife's cup of tea.
A good family game that can be played by nearly everyone.

Ďalšia z hier, ktorá patrí medzi moje prvotiny a stále si ju môžem zahrať bez problémov s tým, že by ma nudila (najmä keď to hráme s mojím synovcom, ktorý má stále nejaké nápady na zmenu pravidiel hrania).
Good gateway game.  This was another game that got me into gaming.
This is still fun, though there are so many others games I would want to play before this.  I have been playing with my kids a lot recently.
This is the game that made me want to collect and play more and more Euro games. Old reliable.... I always enjoy Settlers and love teaching this to new gamers. It's a good gateway game.
The one that started it all for me.  Classic.
Allright, but takes too long for what it is, at least to me. Also trading never works in my group
Great concept, suffers from poor dice runs & hard to catch up when you are behind.  Always willing to play though.

Very well designed. Only plays 3 or 4 without expansions, so that does limit you a bit. Great social game. I love the way it simulates a miniature economy, with some resources being scarce, and some being plentiful.
Also got a German version from a charity shop in the UK.  Useful because my orignal hexes are bending, through I cannot read the rules.

Came to SoC very late in my gaming path.  One play and I was hooked.  The best thing about this ubiquitous game is that you have to compete and cooperate simultaneously.  It can run a bit long with inexperienced players, but I don't play with those.

[size=10][u][i][b]r{Initial Thoughts}r (after 5 plays):[/u][/b][/i][/size] * A granddaddy of the Eurogame movement * Initial placement of settlements seems to dictate final results * Primacy of trading makes for distinctly different experiences based on gamer styles * Expansion is the key (or, put differently, grow stagnant and die) * Good for wresting gamers away from [b][GameID=1406][/b] * Initial rating: [b]7/10[/b]

I know this is a classic.  But of the Catan games, I actually prefer Starfarers of Catan.  Also, I think component quality has gone down with the latest Mayfair version.  The water tiles that go around the island refuse to sit flat.  I may replace this one with the Star Trek Catan version if it ever goes on sale.
All those expansions! There must be something to this :-)

A true modern masterpeice.  Simple, with lots of player interaction and not a lot of decision making (since usually your resources choose your options).  Easy to teach to others and widespread in popularity.  Trading was a brilliant mechanic.  Packed in crate in Kalsel  Sold to Madcat
Everyone has played catan, it even has its own Xbox live arcade game. A classic in every sence. I won my own copy in a raffle at DiceCon 08 in Glasgow!

My wife and I used to be big Settlers fans. I still have a soft spot for it, but I'm always amazed how much the game drags for me now that I've played some more modern designs.  We discovered the 2 player variant by Nick Borko http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/60692 and play 2 players with the three dice variant proposed by Wichard Hulsbergen http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/134095 and have found that we get to play a lot more settlers this way.
Best with 3 or 4, drags with 5 or 6. Higher luck factor than I care for given that the basic game can last over an hour. Cities and Knights expansion is a better game although it also lasts longer.
I will only turn down a game of this if I'm on a mission to try something new, but I'm only too happy to teach it to someone who hasn't played it before.  Gateway rating: 8

I didn't think this game lived up to its hype but it is very fun.  My wife didn't want to play it and wouldn't listen to the rules.  After playing it, she now loves it.  I don't like it as well as some of my deeper board games like El Grande or Tigris.  I also don't like the long setup times and the ridiculous price of the expansions.
Good mix of strategy and luck. 4q, 3q
The first Euro I played. It's a very good game. A classic...  Depth/Complexity: 6  Theme: 7  Mechanics/Gameflow: 8  Artwork/quality of components: 7
This game is great for introducing people to gaming.  It is simple enough to pick up quickly yet has a decent amount of strategy for the gamer.
Used to like as a gateway, but seeing less and less use
An extremely simple and enjoyable game; but not quite as deep as those I usually enjoy.

Okay, finally played the euro game most people here played before anything else. A friend heard I owned a copy but had never played, so he suffered through two-player Settlers with me so I could at least try it.This is a great game, although I can tell that it is not nearly as fun for two as it would be with three or four, and my friend swore that Knights is really what makes the base game fun. I appreciate what it did for the hobby, but I have other games that scratch the same itch that I enjoy more.  Traded the older version with several other games for several hundred dollars worth of Heroscape.

The game's a masterpiece, even though I hate the dice rolling.  The game that turned me on to German/designer games, as well as all of my friends.  Don't play it much anymore, but it's definitely earned a permanent place in my all time top 10.  Own the [boardgame=926]Cities & Knights[/boardgame], [boardgame=27760]Traders & Barbarians[/boardgame], [boardgame=135378]Explorers & Pirates[/boardgame], [boardgame=325]Seafarers[/boardgame] and [boardgame=86669]Helpers[/boardgame] expansions, as well as the [boardgame=189097]Santa Claus[/boardgame], [boardgame=131958]Frenemies[/boardgame], [boardgame=110794]Oil Springs[/boardgame], [boardgame=86669]Helpers of Catan[/boardgame] scenarios, and the [boardgame=167841]Wedding Tower[/boardgame] promo.

A modern day classic as most everyone knows. This game got my brother and sister-in-law hooked on their first try. Watching people discover Settlers and have their eyes opened to Eurogames is an amazing thing. Although to be honest I think Settlers is better as a second-rung gateway game as the rules explanation can be a bit long for a first experience. Having said that I've seen inexperienced kids as young as 7 play and understand this game (with a little coaching).

This is my gateway game.  The first time I played this game fifteen years ago I wanted to play it over and over all night.  I have had the privledge to introduce this to a few folks and most act the same, occasionally some look at me funny when  tell them it is one of the best games ever made (they strictly view board games as roll and move.)  This game is the first games that introduced me to the
"Modern Classic" - Game's your wife will play with you!
Love to play when i get the chance

This game is a must have, throw away your Monopoly board, because this game is much better, its simple enough to learn but it has better strategy and a lot less luck compared to Monopoly, plus there is less down time for each player, even if its not your turn you can still produce resource and trade as well. It is a great game, if you do not have it, BUY IT.

It's a fun game. It is, however, dependent on the dice to push the game forward. Between that and trading, the game can drag on sometimes. I also have a sneaking suspicion that if the numbers were generated by computer so that 6s and 8s really did happen more often than 5s and 9s, 4s and 10s, etc., then it would be a much better game.

Whilst I enjoy the variety of ways to acquire cards - through dice rolls, trading and the robber - I have a couple of niggles elsewhere in the game. I get the feeling that if you fall behind you can't catch up. Somebody with five houses is going to always be getting more resources than you. Also, the game tends to drag out a bit long with no clear finish in sight.
Played  many many games of this before we had a big game collection.  It never comes out now.
Still propably the best one of the all numerous Catan spin offs.
Never did understand the OTT enthusiasm, even when it was first published, as the vagaries of the dice take their toll just too much. Still a decent game but there are many better.
One of the few board games I bought in the 90's eventually helped pull me back in.

A little abstract, a little random, but positively tends to teach people 2d6 distribution, that's the good thing in times of all-present retarded calculator-owners. Tends to be punishing for lack of geometric planning and careless play as well as high hopes for rare numbers. In general not very rewarding, when you lose you fell like a loser, not like a next-turn-to-be-winner.
An old classic.  A little dated now, but still entertaining.
A classic in our home.  I hope to one day custom make my own 3D Settlers of Catan.
Really an ingenious and enduring game.
The first main stream euro game to sweep the US, and will forever be a classic. Everyone should have a copy in there collection.

I enjoy this game, but it is rather based on luck. Depending on who (if anyone) the dice favor, you can rack up points quickly, or sit around trying to trade your lone Brick for anything, anything at all.   I've tried a couple different strategies with Catan and it seems that you can win from just about any position, unless the dice are being brutal. With even semi-decent placement you can usually trade for what you need or just buy Dev cards to improve your hand.  All in all, this is a fun game and a good gateway game.

My very first contact with boardgames. However, randomness simply killed the game since more than half of the time, you're at the mercy of the dice. The endgame is usually unimpressive because there is little people could do to stop (or even to slow down) a runaway leader.
This needs to stay on the shelf maybe forever...but it did get most of this list started by itself.

I like Settlers, I really do, but mostly as a quick and friendly warm-up game before jumping into deeper stuff. Can get frustrating with others want to replay it endlessly... relaxing and enjoyable, but not a lot of depth (even with Cities & Knights).

The game which started it all..Again luck involved in rolling the dice. It can be played with two, but it is so much better with more. This game doesn't hit the tables anymore as we own better games now. But it remains a good family game.

A classic. The randomness of the resources make the game what it is. It forces you to trade with other players. It is definitely the best part of the game. With expansions, takes more time, but is more meatier. I swing both ways... In the game I mean...
My first euro.  Still love it, but would much rather add Cities and Knights.  Good with either 3 or 4, but I hate the 5- or 6-player version.
I know a lot of people don't like this game, but I really do.  I love that the map is always different, the mix of luck and skill, and the player interaction. I'm a fan.
Players with luck at the beginning get more ressources from different numbers, which makes them nearly resistant to misfortune.  Otherwise, a good game.
Great entry-level game for people who are used to 'Party Games' but might enjoy a weightier strategy game.
The basic game is great as a gateway, but 4-players games have the serious flaw of one person getting cut off.
I can't get anyone in my current group to play :(
Another super popular game I don't really love any more.  I think I played it way too much, and got burned-out.
Fun game,  a bit overrated though.
Great game to play in the classroom with students when introducing probability.

Classic, and have practically played it to death - to death, I tell ya - by this point.  At times has been a little TOO popular at our table for my tastes.  I don't find it very interesting anymore without the Cities & Knights expansion.
Another early-ish addition to my collection, though not as early as most people.  It is still fun for me, and I know there are expansions that will add more when it finally gets stale.
A good resource trading & management game for young players and families, and a good introduction to game concepts for younger kids.
I've played this game around 50 times. At first I loved it, then I discovered other games, now I don't bring it out unless someone requests it.
The gateway game that got me into Euro's.

Too many games spent unable to act because of bad resource rolls and/or the robber have cooled me toward this one. Better with Seafarers, might try another expansion to see if it gets me interested again.
1st Mayfair edition with red, yellow, blue and green pieces
played many times before tracking 6-12 times
A game that has something for everyone.  Needs expansions to be suitable for other than 4 players, though.  Don't care much for trading games myself.
A classic Euro; I enjoy the bartering as much as the mechanics of the game.
Une partie a suffit a effacer ma nostalgie. Un jeu qui ramassera la poussière...
Used to play a lot of this. It's currently having a time-out.
This game got me into gaming.
One of the few games that I really can keep playing without getting bored.  2012 UPDATE: Don't play this much anymore. Changed from a 10 to a 7 :(.

----------  This was my gateway game.  I played it and loved it for 2 years until I picked up Cities and Knights and Seafarers.  Cities and Knights has spoiled me... the base version is now too bland for my tastes, but this game is still a classic.    If you would've asked me a rating 100 plays ago, it would've been a 10 all the way.  As it is now, I could care less if I ever played it again.  However, I'm keeping it in my collection so I can introduce friends to eurogaming in the future.  ----------
Plays quick; easy rules; lots of player interaction and strategy give this game a whole lot of replay value. A good gateway game but has its flaws.

A modern triggerpoint in gaming.The randomness in the die-roll can lead to a tedious play. Experience matters, as the savvy choice of starting locations can mean the game.  That being said, it's a classic gateway game that I've found can lure in non-gamers too.  The expansions make the game better and alternate (historical) ways to play are much better, as is the two player card game version.

Still have the original Kosmos version with wooden pieces. This is probably my most played game (except for the Settlers Card Game). Played this twice a week (with Cities&Knights), when I went to university.  I'm OK with the undeniable luck factor since I win most games. ;-)
Played for the first time. Was an enjoyable game that I would play again. A great gateway game.

Including the following expansions:  The 5-6 Player Expansion Seafarers Seafarers, The 5-6 Player Expansion Cities and Knights Cities and Knights, The 5-6 Player Expansion The Great River The Fishermen of Catan Event Cards Traders & Barbarians Traders & Barbarians, The 5-6 Player Expansion
My family really enjoys this game.

Settlers started my return into modern boardgaming in 2005. For over a year it was my favourite game. But the more I played it the more annoying the dice were. Finely in 2007 I fed with Settlers up. I remember some games I lost or won only because of luck. Wining was even worse for me. Besides, if you used to play Settlers with the same people all the time you know each reactions enough to make trading very predictable and boring. Event Cards did not help - why should I trade with anybody if I get my resources sooner or later? Now  I play Settlers very occasionaly. I tried even Teuber`s official 2-players variant which is very nice to play baut a bit static.  If you search for a family game choose rather Carcassonne - shorter, better, very portable, less luck, tactical decisions every turn, short setup, etc.
got 5-6 player, seafarers, seafarers 5-6 as well

Like a gazillion other people, my first euro, and a "so that's what all the fuss is about" moment. Nice to see the Kings & Things board again. Not something I'm that interested in playing, but definitely one of the first games that springs to mind to introduce people to the hobby.
A staple food during my college years, but have rarely played it in the last 5 years.
My first love.This game opened for me the big world of board games!!!!+)  Эль классико настолок. Очень люблю ее за большое взаимодействие между игорами.
The game I played with friends came with loaded dice... whether this is right or not?

The first game that made me realise there's a whole bunch of great board games out there that where equally as good as computer games.  Can suffer from two people doing well and the other two doing averagely, but when you get a game where every one is close its a real race to the last VPs.  I like it most with Cities and Knights.
Very good game, I like playing, but, as carcassonne, just can't find time to play it.
Wonderful game.  Can't say anything here that hasn't already been said by thousands of others.
The best game to play with laymen.
Too much luck, but very playable anyway.

This game's all about resource management. It's the Euro-game that broke open the gaming world for me. I've played 100's of games (including twice a day each day for the first 2 weeks I owned the game).  Still enjoy it many years later.
The game is pretty fun as it commences, but grows stale as the monotony of building for the final victory comes. Too long by 30-60 minutes.  Plus Fishermen, Helpers, and Indiana/Ohio expansions.
Classic game, but it tends to make everyone upset at one point or another. Making it into the Debbie-Downer of board games.

A brilliant design (for its time) that has been surpassed by many games since then. Games always seem to last too long, and too many turns are spent saying "I'm doing nothing. I designed many home-made expansions for this, to make the game more fun, but this rating is for the base game.
Solid.  Worthy of expansions and spinoffs... but the original outshines many of the more advanced versions.
Played heavily before I began tracking plays
A favourite of mine.  Bought it on the recommendation of a friend and haven't regretted it.

Settlers used to be THE game I wanted to play. I found it endlessly fascinating and challenging. I loved how the board was different for every game. But somehow, time has taken the shine off this game for me. I've begun to find that there are games where, when if I'm losing, I spend the entire game losing without any hope of recovery. The dice just don't go my way, a resource is scarce because of the board layout and my settlement placement order, etc. Settlers really offers a limited way to win, and if you can't get there, you WON'T be able to get there, and it's frustrating. I've seen many games of Settlers completely stall. It's a good game, and maybe I've just had some bad games recently, but on the whole, I prefer Cities & Knights.
It's not really an 8 for me anymore; it's not that new and exciting after playing it more times than I could possibly try to remember. But I'll never turn down an invitation to play Settlers, ever.

Popular with the game group, and often used to introduce the hobby to non-games. very popular with the family and is often brought out on family holidays. People enjoy the trading and social aspects of the game, while allowing for some back-stabbing and aggressiveness at the same time.
If you don't expect it to be something it isn't, it is one of the best games ever.
My enthusiasm for this game has waned over the years.

My gateway game...  Will always like it for that reason.  Plus, it's pretty fun - unless the dice are screwing you over >:/  It's strange, the first time I played this it seemed so "different/complex" - mainly because I had only played standard boardgames prior to playing it.  Resources?  Building settlements and roads?  Wow!  Now it seems kind of simplistic.  Simplistic does not mean bad though.  A groundbreaking game for its time.

What can I say? The second game that I was introduced to that pushed me into board gaming as a hobby. Truly a classic. It's a shame that the game has lost a little of it's luster for me over the years, but I will always introduce this to a group of potential gamers that have never had the Settlers experience before.

Used to play this a lot. It's great that everyone have a chance to win. I like playing with the expansion, they add a lot of variety. The problem with the game is that luck sometimes makes the game completely unbalanced.
運と実力のバランスが程よく凹んでいれば交渉で優遇されるし、拡大再生産の楽しさもある。ちょっと長引くことがあるのと実力差があるセッションに対する強度が低いのが玉に瑕。

I FINALLY got the chance to play this with my family and we had a great time.  There were times where I thought my wife or daughter was going to tip the game over in frustration due to getting hit by a Monopoly card, the Robber, path blocked, and bad dice.  I haven't seen that come from them so they were obviously getting into the game!
I've got wood, looking for sheep.  Come on, you know it has to be said :-)
A classic great game. "Pioneers" is a nice, open source version for Linux, Mac, and Windows.

This is supposed to be the boardgamer's board game, and I enjoy it very much, but it's not one of my favorites. Doesn't work well with 2 players, which is fine, because it wasn't designed for 2 players. Good game for 4, however.
Testing Klaus' two-player rules, works pretty well!

Dec 2018: On loan to the Shiny Garden library. August 2009: It wasn't my gateway game, and maybe that's partly why I can appreciate this game as much as I do. Or maybe it's that I love getting free stuff on other people's turns. :D However, when playing with people with AP, the game's fun quotient drops dramatically.
THE SETTLERS OF CATAN Fun once in a while.
Our gateway drug, the game that got most of my group into board gaming.
Best gateway game.  Enjoyable for all ages.  Too much dice luck reduces fun factor.
The true classic of modern gaming!
