It has a certain amount of luck and player interaction for an eurogame, both good things in my book. In my group there is a lot of commerce between players and table talk; I don't think I would like it otherwise.
I own a copy of Capcom edition by RMB 129

I love this game, it's my wife's favorite (which is very important since 95% of games I play are 2p vs. her) and all of my friends and family who have played it really like it.  It's simple to teach & learn, offers healthy player interaction (w/out being too nasty), rewards good strategy, and I think it's human nature to enjoy physically constructing little settlements and reaping the benefits.  Many logged plays are the official 2p variant, which is pretty good...    Includes plays with Seafarers expansion.
Кубики, торговля, стратегия = вот отличный рецепт для отличной игры.
A little dated but very easy to introduce to new players and get them used to some basic mechanics.
My wife will play this game and Risk - and likes this game better.
Good for beginner but too much rules for beginner.
This was one of my first games and I still like it as a gateway game with new players. I probably have close to 50 plays, but none are logged unfortunately.

This is the one that usually opens the floodgates to addiction.  I have yet to meet anyone who didn't like this game the first time they play. This is the game we usually crack out with guests, and one of the few that my wife actually enjoys playing (She prefers interaction over strategy).
Good for seasoned gamers, great for noobs.

Fantastic entry-level game.  I was introduced to it back in college and managed to play a game a week for a few months before getting distracted by class and computer gaming.  I'd still play this just to hear the line "got any wood for my sheep?"
This was my gateway game.  I still play it often and own almost all the expansions.  I love Catan for it's simplicity in design and it's myriad of options.  A quality strategic game.

It's Settlers. I've spent countless afternoons after (or sometimes at) school trading, building, scrounging together victory points. I very much appreciate what Settlers has done for the euro-style gaming, I never got into any of the expansions, nor am I interested in playing this more than once every blue moon.
I would miss Cities and Knights too much to play the base game now.

I've played this a few times in years past and I really enjoy the elegance of the game system.  It's also the only game I got my wife to ever play with me, and she did it once and very well during the trade/negotiations phase.  The system is readily expanded and has a lot of game play variety.
Easy light strategy. Everybody can learn this game in a few minutes. Great for playing with people who do not play heavy strategy or trade games.

One of the first games that I started playing.  Players tries to collect resources based on the dice rolls and the houses built on the resource tiles.  With the resources, players can build houses, roads, upgrade houses or buy event cards. Players can trade resources among themselves or with the boardgame so as to acquire resources they lack.  Players can also move a bandit piece which will disallow players to collect resources from the resource tile if the dice roll number 7.  Good points: Easy to play and understand  Bad points: The key of the game resides on the initial position of the 2 houses players placed on the resource tiles.  If 1 player can get resources almost every round in the game, then the player have a high chance to win the game.  The bandit to stop the winning player from taking resources has too small effect on the winning player.
This was my gateway Euro game, although I had played some Ameritrash prior to that. It's a fantastic game, that I play less often now simply because I've played it so much.

The second, maybe third REAL game purchased and it worked with the family but then I started buying more games and we kind of forgot about this one. Need to get it out again. Lacks the glamor of The Adventurers and FFG BIG box games but we had fun when we did play it. Good family game.
Надоела. =) Как монополия, дурак и шахматы.

This was my gateway game - like many others. I really loved this game for a long - particularly the trade element.  After many plays (play count does not accurately reflect actual plays), I now prefer other games to Catan.  Dislikes: Prone to runaway leader. One poorly placed settlement or a bandit that sits for a while early game can cripple you, longer games can drag.
One of the original gamers' games.  Good stuff.
This is the english language base game from Mayfair Games 2003.
The luck of the dice stops this being a 'very good game' but it's still fun to get out every now and again.

After many plays this game is beginning to feel a little 'played out', but its still a fun game to bring out from time to time and it's great to introduce to people new to the hobby as a whole. It is possible that, because of poor dice rolls, you can spend a long period of the game unable to do anything. As a result, Settlers has a highly variable playing time depending on the availability of resources.
Who doesn't own this...? Any why not.

Fun game but feels quite random at times. Lots of downtime if players ponder too much on the building phase or make the trading phase drag on for ages.  Also, it seems that the last important decision you take in the game is actually your first. I find it less and less attractive lately, maybe i've just overplayed it though :P
Great classic game. Got tired (of the dice) after playing it for 1 year. Initial lucky rolls can give a lot of advantages (building more settlements and cities give you even more resources later)
The game that started it all. : )
Rekindled my interest in board games in late 2007 with this one.  Everyone enjoys Catan and the strategy is easy to pick up after a few games.

This started the eurogame addiction for me......but I got burned out pretty fast....and I do think its a good gateway game.....the ladies like it too..and I don't know why tho but I think its the trading
I would have ranked this higher, but I overplayed it at first.

I love how the game weaves resource management, area control, and player politics into an easy to learn and quick playing package.  The dice are a double-edged sword here, and the options available to you on any given turn get a little dull after repeated play.

Ah, Settlers... so classic, so important to this hobby. If you have not played it, then please go get a copy and do so now. You won't regret it. While I don't have much desire to play anymore (I have moved toward wargames and other stuff), this game is too solid to not have played at least a few times in your life. And when I am convinced to sit down and play a game, I always enjoy myself more than I expected.
I own the travel version. It gets silly when you realize 3 to 4 people are playing on such a tiny board. Its a tease of the non-travel version.

評分:ForLight:8 ForHard:6.5 複雜度:4 互婊度:8  如果要擴廣紙板型桌遊給新手，我認為這是一個不錯的選擇。但對於老手來說骰子運氣因素過強，而且也有其他更好的選擇。  給新手： 1.最初的二間房子的佈置占了勝負的一半，另一半則是骰運，嘴炮能發揮的作用出奇的低。 2.怖局策略分類:  木磚建築型：擴張速度高及可封殺其他玩家的出路，標準穩定的打法。  麥石升級型：初期注重升級，後期注重抽牌的戰術，但房子提供的分數會不足，是否擁有第四個房子就成為勝負關鍵，個人最喜歡的戰術。  平均發展型：最注重玩家交際手段的怖局法，上位時很容易被封殺，個人不推薦。  交易自閉型：若地圖的狀況很差，在放第一個房子時達不到上述策略，就可以先選專攻其中一種作物，然後第二個房子直接放在相對應的海港上，作物優先度麥＞木＞羊，這種打法只要等其他玩家來求你換你手上的東西就好。
Mayfair third edition for trade or sale.

Play it a fair bit a few years ago - especially 5 and 6 handed.  Started playing it again with my daughters recently. Plays well as a family game, or as an introduction for newbies. I prefer Cuba, Puerto Rico, Parthenon, Java within this genre
The classic intro to Euro gaming.  I think it is a good game, but after now playing so many others, Catan just feels "broken" to me.
The vanilla version of this game has it's flaws.  I have enjoyed it in the past, but I won't ever play it again without all of the expansions.
Found my copy of Catan!  It felt like being reunited with a child.

Of course I've known about this game for years, but after finally playing it (Feb. 2009), I found it intriguing, even though prior to playing I had a hard time understanding how a game of this sort could be interesting. There is much to think about, it's more competitive (and even a bit more cutthroat) than I imagined, and it's well balanced and can be tense. I'd agree with those who say this game has earned a place on department store shelves next to stuff like "Clue," "Monopoly," and "Sorry." In that regard, I'm happy to see games like "Heroscape" "Axis & Allies" and "Blokus" on such shelves. Too bad other new standards like "Scotland Yard," "Carcassonne" and "Ticket to Ride" aren't also there regularly. [Note: As of 2012 I'm seeing more of these new standards on shelves in stores like Target.] I bought "Settlers of Catan" for a friend and his 14-year-old son: he couldn't figure it out, so I took it back home with me (they live way out of town) and taught myself. Then, when my friend next visited (June 2009), I taught him and he took it back. That's one way to do it! As to whether I might buy my own copy of this, to date (April 2010) I haven't yet, and I'm guessing I won't, simply because there are many other games more interesting to me. But to repeat, this is a seminal game and definitely has its place in the pantheon of outstanding games. Since of my sons got into gaming after going to college and learned how to play "Settlers..." I figured my family would play it so I traded for a copy of the 4th Edition, December 2014.

The game that got me into real games. Still have a soft spot in my heart for this one but I would rather play other games. It's too easy to get trapped if you play with four people and it's very frustrating if your numbers never get rolled. There are better games out there.
If only I hadn't gotten sick of this after a hundred-thousand-and-something plays.
I really like this game. Just don't really want to play it with all the other options out there.
I really seem to get screwed on dice rolls.  I played this again and, when it was three people that focused on the game, I liked it better.

A solid trading and negotiating game. Too bad about the limit of four players but I have been resistant to add any expansions for fear of adding any more length to the game. The base game is just the perfect length.

This was my gateway game (although I think I played LotR first and enjoyed it) and I still love it, as does everyone I show it to. I may be on the brink of wearing it thin though, I pretty much only truly enjoy it with C&K now.

good game to play with the wife and another couple

This game is fun but it can wear out its welcome.  Great for gateway situations - there's a reason this game is what got so many people started in this hobby!  I'll be interested to see how old my daughter will be when she can start playing this.
This is a fun game to kick back and relax on. It is fun if one is in the mood for it and does not take the role of the dice too seriously.
Giggle me tender, giggle me sweet, take me away, and bring me to meat
Easy to teach.  Very little down time.
Modern classic game of collecting resources to build and expand against other players on a small island.  Pretty much essential knowledge.  3-6 players, best with 4; usually takes a couple hours.

You buy and place buildings and roads near land that gets randomly activated to generate resources. You use the resources to upgrade buildings and generate victory points. It can seem light compared to more recent games, but has a certain elegance in its design and gameplay.

the one game with which i seem to ignore the luck of the dice. i've traded other games where dice rolls determine so much, but this game i enjoy even when the number 8 just doesn't get rolled (i end up with 8s a lot)
Good game, lots of luck!!! Not a game to adore, but a classic. Good "gateway".

Played on my iTouch - fun game!  I'm disappointed in the production quality of the 4th edition that I own, though. Thin cards, relatively thin tiles, and the ocean "edges" warped easily. As a F2F game -- I can see how this has become a beloved (in some cases) gateway game, but having been introduced to it after I've played some other euros, it just didn't excite me as much as I thought it might.  Perhaps more plays will change my opinion, but for now it's a game I enjoy but don't necessarily want to play repeatedly.

[b]Retrospective[/b]:  Considering it might not be my game of choice to reach for, Catan still holds a special place in my heart. At its core it introduced me to so many new mechanics (which I thought were an impossibility at that time): Being able to play on a unique board every time; using something different to money to carry out actions; trading between players to add a bit more direct interaction; but the one that blew me away the most was the use of the dice as you didn't use them to move on a board. Coming from a Monopoly and Risk background, this changed my point of view about boardgames and paved the way for my foray into the hobby.  --------  [b]Brass Tacks[/b]:  It's a classic, but there are objectively better gateway games available nowadays. This is a game that plays fine at 3p, but is best with 4p. I wouldn't go for the 2p expansion. The trading aspect makes or breaks games. If the group is undisposed then it can grind the game to a halt. After a few plays it might even become somewhat superfluous if you control the right trading ports. At its essence, dice just adds randomness which cannot be mitigated.  --------  [b]Breakdown[/b]: [c] Rules Complexity              low/MEDIUM Rulebook Clarity              MEDIUM/high Setup Time                    low/MEDIUM Bookkeeping                   low Look & Feel                   medium Thematic Appeal               low/MEDIUM Strategic Depth               low/MEDIUM Gameplay Engagement           medium Player Downtime               low Game Length Satisfaction      medium Play Through Frequency        LOW/medium[/c]
Finally had a game of this. Not too bad ( rating boosted due to winning!)

My personal gateway game still holds up well.  Rated as though it were a 4p only game.  I rate this a 4.5 with 3p; having the extra building space available removes most of the difficult decisions from the game.

Barely know anyone who hasn't played this, which is a good sign! I'm not a big fan, but it's great to see a 5-player game going. I get the most fun out of seeing all those little cities and in particular the sea-exploration with one of the addons! (only played with 5-player seafarers expansion)
Classic game that still is fun to play.
Older version of Settlers so not compatible with newer additions. Great game in its own right. Good Condition.

My group has a great time playing Settlers of Catan. What makes the game fun for my group is the negociation aspect. Our trades are generally pretty creative. We trade current and future resources, and agreements not to steal resources. We also have a fun time convincing the person using the robber not to steal from us. If my group wasn't a high interaction group this game would definatley fall a minium of 1 points on my ratings.Most of our stradegy comes at the begining of the game as we take turns placing the terrain tiles and the numbers on those tiles individually. Our games runs from 2=2 and 1/2 hours.
An Eurogame all in all.   Simple and fast. Interesting and with a lot o player interaction.

Un grand classique, idéal pour amener de nouvelles personnes dans le monde du jeu. Les mécanismes simples, la simplicité des règles, et l'ambiance générée par les échanges en font un jeu très apprécié.
It's a classic, and for good reason. Everyone should play it at least once.
Family favorite, ranked lower because you have to play with the expansions in order to break up the monotony.

Famoso giustamente per aver cambiato lo stile dei giochi moderni, ma finisce lì nient'altro di interessante.  -------------------------------------------------  Venduto a Renato Pisacane a 90 euro insieme ad altri giochi, il 28/10/2010
It's what brought me into this world of games, and I will forever love it for that, only doesn't get a ten because had a few too many yelling matches over that stupid robber.
And this was the second step, but they don't want Catan as much as Saboteur. Who the hell understands them???
Great gateway game.  Been playing on the XBOX for the last year or so.  Finally got a real copy and everyone loves it.

"THE" modern game, one of my first, certainly one of the most important even though it is probably not one of my favorites now given the increase of the comptetion. A game that belongs to the Hall of Fame of the games should it ever exist.

"I've got sheep. Does anyone have wheat?"  "No, no wheat has been rolled for 4 turns."  "How about 2-to-1?"  "No one has wheat."  "Ok, 3-to-1?"  "Again, no one has wheat."  "It's a really good deal!"  "What is it about no one having wheat that you don't understand?"  Ugh. The people who hold the game hostage while trading are the worst.
The ever changing board keeps the game fresh, but I have trouble getting excited about this game. I feel like I'm missing something.
Always a standby game at my house!
My first "geeky" game.  I don't enjoy it as much as I did when I first played years ago.  But still a great game that has a magical ability to bring in non-gamers.
Fun game, especially good with people who are new to the hobby or non-gamers.

[b]RO:[/b] [i]12/17/2015[/i]  What is there to say about Catan? Well, a lot actually. Of course, there is it's prestigious (and hardly arguable in my opinion) claim to bringing "German-style" board gaming to the world. For most of us, Catan was probably the first non-American classic you played, or at least heard of.   My group and me mispronounce the name, at first ignorantly, and now out of habit as "Kay-ten", of course the correct pronunciation is "Cuh-tahn" but we've grown so used to it, that the simple misnomer "Kay-ten", or occasionally, "Settlers", is almost always how we refer to it.  There is a lot of luck here, resource generation is dice based but player investment is constant because resources can flow into your [-]sweaty hands[/-] warehouses even when it isn't your turn, and trades are flying this way and that on a regular basis. It can drag, if luck isn't on your side or you placed your settlements poorly, but overall it is leagues beyond your normal Monopoly, Risk, or Life game in terms of interaction, interest, and ability to influence the outcome through clever play. It is always fun, even if it occasionally overstays it's welcome. Many "better" games have come along, but there is something about the nostalgia and brilliant design that will keep most coming back.

Lost in fire. Played many times with the family over the years, still comes out every now and then. Now replaced with the 4th Edition.  Mayfair die cuts are the worst. Took me over half an hour with a craft knife to punch out the cardboard without tearing the surface.

I strayed from you, Catan. I piled expansion upon expansion on top of you, tried all kinds of alternative versions and was always looking for yet another variant. Why did I do this? I don't know. You are perfect.
Classic Euro-style game that can be played too often, but if interspersed among other games, can be a long term winner. The game works as a great introduction to these types of boardgames.

FAMILY, STRATEGY  The iconic Eurogame. Gather goods and trade them to build roads, settlements, cities, and purchase development cards. It's not my favorite game, but it's very popular. I greatly prefer with with 4 players.  Maggie and I played the two-player variant at: http://nick.borko.org/games/Catan2Players.pdf  There's also an "official" two-player variant by Klaus Teuber in the files area of this game.  Recommended with 3-4 players (best 4). 60-120 mins.
On the strength of one play(!) I get the feeling that this is the game that kids should be playing instead of Monopoly. It just works so much better, with similarly simple mechanics. Very impressive.
Great ...Great ...Great quick party game that is very easy for new players.
Have played this for years now, classic game that never gets old.  Have introduced many friends to it,....should have bought stock in the company.
It takes about 1 game for a newbie to learn, and 3 to start picking up some of the strategy, but it can be a good gateway game.
A classic, best without any expansions, except for the one that brings space for more players.

I got the 3rd edition. I haven't played for quite some time. I recently got some used 3rd edition expansions, so I hope I can get this one to the table.  Update: Love this game, good interaction. All hail the Lord of Catan!

Eurogame classic, you'd be hard-pressed to find someone here [The Netherlands] who hasn't played it - at least in my experience.  I enjoy playing Catan, it's not as deep or strategical as I'd like, and it can drag on towards the end, but close matches can be fun. Rolling a seven right before you were going to spend all your 9 cards to settle at some killer spot leads to great fun (and annoyance) as well.

Our first eurogame and we still own the German edition. This opened our eyes to the new age of gaming and it changed what we looked for in a game. We had our young children learn the game and they became competitve. Can be an issue with a bad board and bad rolls of the dice. But, we like the trading aspect of the game as it keeps the interaction level high.

A classic. I've logged quite a few plays, but can't rank it too highly because I think some of the mechanics are quite flawed. Being robbed early on is a major setback, and there aren't enough dice rolls in a game to ensure the statistically likely rolls are represented as they should be.
Classic gateway game. No longer play it really.
For new players: Play with the fixed setup. Experienced players: Play with cities and knights.

A great game but the rolling for the resources aspect can leave people bitter since they could have chosen strategically great choices but fare poorly. I like playing this on my iPod Touch a lot more than in person because it can tend to drag on in person.
Tons of strategy involved with this game.  Enjoyable, especially if you like crushing your friends.

You'd think it would be easy to get in games of the mother of all Eurogames, but in actuality most people seem to have already gone through their Catan phase and moved on. I rarely see just the original base game out at the game club, and haven't been able to get into a game in three years!

Realmente es de mi hermano, pero me lo apalanqué allá por Febrero de 2009 y desde entonces forma parte de mi ludoteca.  Finalmente se lo devolví para que formase parte de su incipiente ludoteca, que parece estar creciendo poco a poco. Es justo que lo tenga el, pues suyo es. Lo paso a previously owned. :)
Great intro to Eurogaming for non-gamers.  Easy to pick up, but too much luck involved for massive long-term appeal.

3-5p. I used to avoid this game, because you can only trade sheep away so many times before SoC becomes repetitive. So I didn't run across Cities and Knights until early in 2010. I'm much happier with SoC:C+K now -- changed my rating from 6 to 8.
My gateway game, along with the illustrious Puerto Rico.
Best with 4 (3-4) 90 mins - Great game, not a fan of the trading, played this too many times.
Like so many other people here, Settlers of Catan was my "gateway game" to "modern" boardgaming. Still trying to find a game to match Settlers's elegance, interactivity, and replayability :-)

This was the first board game I learned since my youth and it really did open the door for me to see that gaming as an adult could still be very challenging and enjoyable. My boyfriend (at the time) taught it to me in March 2008 and it definitely help lead to my current obsession with boardgames.

Now a classic I would say.  This is a great game that has interduced so many into the new board game industry.    The games easy to learn, interactivity and non aggressive theme make it perfect for a family, or new gamers.  The depth of stratagy and complexity of trading maintain it as a reasonable game for experianced gamers.  If I hadn't already played the games a couple hundred times, I probably would still reccommend it to most game sessions.  The citys and knights expansion is still my favorate variant.
Fun game for four players. Was easy and accessible for first time players (brother and sister in law!)
Spanish version. Good condition. Normal wear.
I find this game a little dull now, but I still think it's an incredibly balanced game (by "balance" I mean weighing social interaction, luck, strategy, and aesthetics).    It's the ur-gateway game.

I first played at Gen Con when I was substantially younger.  I like that you have to pay attention during other turns, and that it's not a hurry up and wait mechanic.  I like the balance of the different construction options, and the different ways to score points.  However, I've always won the same way- build the longest road, use it to spread out your villages and harness needed resources ports, and once you're out of villages and have your empire in the right position, build it up to cities.  The only exceptions are when you need a city for more wood or brick to build more roads or villages.  I don't like the kingmaker aspect, and that poor strategic decisions by losing players can hand victories to other players (When 'don't give him a brick, that's all he needs to win' is ignored).  I've benefited from this before, but I don't know that deceit belongs here.     Maybe next time I play I'll gun for 'largest army' and VP cards, even though I've never seen it work.
This is a classic, but I've grown tired of it over the years.

Definitely a solid game with well-balanced mechanics.  This game seems to work well both with new and experienced players, as everyone feels like they have a chance to win up until the end.  I still worry that the starting placement has too much of an impact on the rest of the game, but so far, I've not experienced any session where that's obviously been the case.  This one hit the table a lot in our group at first, especially when we're trying to push new players toward non-party games, but it has fallen out of favor lately due to a large influx of great new games.
I have played a game or two of this a while back.  I remember liking it, but now that I have gotten into Euro gaming, I would like to obtain a copy and revisit it.

This game opened the door for me to the possibilities of board games, circa 1998.  The only reason it's this low is that our copy has literally been played to death, with massive amounts of wear and tear on everything.  If I logged them all, there'd be hundreds of plays of this game for me.
I find this to be a fun family game that most people are willing to play. Like the configurable board, but you have to lay a clear sheet of plastic down on top of it to make it stable.
Mayfair edition.  the island tiles feel really flimsy to me, but they work well when contained by the ocean tiles
Along with Carcasonne, this game led me down the dark path to board game obsession
Time is wearing on this old knight. He still has it but he does not get played much anymore with other much better games out.
Played with some random strangers one night in college (I think I much prefer the more complex Euro's that I've already found)
You know it's good.  We all played it to death.  I'd do it again, if asked.
I hate the dice, but love the game.

Simple game with lots of randomness in setup. So, there could be completely different tactic every game. Was going to rate it 9, but after finding out that settlements must to be built adjacent to your roads and playing with correct rules it has dropped a lot. Game drags and it's hard to expand and create interesting tactics. First setup becomes the main strategy. Thinking to play it more with house rule (without roads requirement).
This is the game that got me into Euro-gaming and is obviously a classic

Excellent replayability when playing with the random set up.  Ultimately though, its the dice that are the king makers.  However, the recent expansions for the 4th edition have greatly helped to lessen this flaw.
It always seems to drag on a bit too long. Not very fun without seafarers too.

Rec'd 9-15-09.Couple plays, once with beginner set-up and once with totally random. Prefer the random style. Actually got SOC after getting Settlers of Canaan. A second play with full random set-up and I'm sure the random way is the best way to go, at least for me.

Stop being a snob: SETTLERS IS ONE OF THE BEST BOARD GAMES OF ALL TIMES, because it does extremely well what a game is supposed to do: It brings people together, no matter if you personally like it or not. It's definitely not perfectly designed for the mechanical point of view, it's too short, dice rolls decide... Yes. True. But it's the most social board game I know, and that's why people love it. I'd probably rate it a 10 if there wasn't the "Cities and Knights" expansion.

One of my brothers is so rich that he actually gave this game to me because he had two copies. I finally played it a year after he gave it to me.   It's a great game. The board changes with every game, which is always a great concept because it keeps the game fresh. The trading aspect is fun and like Monopoly's, but much faster. There is a good mixture of luck and planning because there are many ways to win. I might just rate this game higher in a few weeks after playing it more.
This is a nice lite fun Euro game.  Both my wife and I enjoy playing
Gets a bit boring after a while, but still a good and quick board game.

An undeniable classic and still one of the best gateway games of all time.  After all these years, I have grown a bit tired of its randomness and excessive length (with expansions/extensions), but how many other games can claim to have remained in my collection as long?
Played many times over the years in both the 4 and 6 player variants. Always proves popular
Fun to play, elegant design, but starting settlements tend to determine the winner.
Pretty fun, with a larger crowd.  Can't see it being much for two, but enjoyable.
I seem to have a love/hate relationship with this game. I'm always drawn to it but I really hate those dice rolls
(Already) classic. Because of being highly dependent on luck, it can still be played over and over again.
This is one of my first "real" board games and i still appreciate it. . I´ve must have played it at least 200 times. I´ve just love that you can bargain with the other players.

A relatively easy to learn game that is enjoyable to play and gives everyone a chance to do well. My biggest gripe with this game is that I've found myself really "well-diversified" on numbers which, seems like a really good thing until I lose all the cards in my hand just before my turn. If it happened only on occasion or if I was hoarding resources it'd be easier to tolerate but sometimes it seems like it can happen every-other-turn or more and I try to use most/all of my resources on each turn.   Besides my nit-picking there, this game really does well at rewarding good strategy and is enjoyable with a group.
Enjoyable trading game... but I don't want to play it too often.
Modern classic. I still enjoy a game now and then, especially online.
I couldn't play a game anymore...  but it was definitely the game that ignited the boardgame interest in my playgroup.
Not my favorite. Not the worst.  Have 5-6 player extension for all expansions.

I've finally done it... I've played the game that everybody on the outside thinks that everybody on the inside is playing. I can see why it's popular: the mechanics are intuitive and there's a lot of strategy. I enjoyed looking like a geek quite well.

The game that started it all for me (and for many others). I've played board games all my life (i.e. Risk, Monopoly, etc.), but until I played Catan, I didn't know how great board games could really be. Played this recently and realized that I still really love this game.
This game is kind of a classic that I haven't actually played in ages.
this game wore out it's welcome in my house i like it and have enough parts to play a huge map with 6 players and 40 v.p. to win. which makeing scenarios is what i like to do with this game.

Классика. Нравится практичеки всем, даже людям не играющим в настольные игры. Очень простая механика интуитивно понятный игровой процесс. Очень хорошая гейтвей игра. Но в какойто момент ее перерастаешь.

I used to think this game was the greatest thing ever.  But now I'm not too sure.  Too random and luck based.  I prefer my board games "German".  As in no luck involved.   Still a good game to introduce non gamers to a world of games out there that are a whole bunch of a lot better than Monopoly!  For that it absolutly rocks!
(4p)  + Expansion Villes et Chevaliers  Last Game 05/04/2010 Many games not recorded  Pre-2009
My second favorite resource game.  Easier to learn and play than Puerto Rico,  but strangly not as much fun.  Still it stands on its own and is a great family game.
My first Euro-Game and one that will always be close to my heart though not on my table since my version went mysteriously missing about a year ago. Was very fond of an online implementation.
Sweet game that a lot of friends like to play. My liking of it tends to depend on the company these days... some people get down-right unsportsmanlike about it.
I prefer it on the computer, I can stand the haggling only with experienced players.
The game that made me come back to boardgames after years of wargames and RPG.  Now a classic.

I was several years into the hobby before I got around to playing this.   So by that point it wasn't a gateway game for me.  I was pretty heavy into more thematic games, so just couldn't understand how this could be fun.   Once I did actually play it, I realized why it's such a perennial favorite.  Truly a masterpiece game.
Great game.  Usually balances luck out over the length of a game, too much interaction can lead to "kingmakers" in the wrong group.

Ya know, I DON'T like the randomness of the dice. I DO like the negotiation part - I really get into the meaty roles of tradesmanship and deals, etc. Just the conversational part. (So, uhm, that mean Genoa is my cup of tea? Or Princes of the Rennaissance?) Haven't really dug into the Cities/Knights part yet, so some serious exploration to go. I do find the game a tad too long (by 30-60), for the level of return.
It's a good game, but it's definitely been surpassed (for me) in complexity and fun by later games.

Un clásico donde los haya, gestión de recursos y sobre todo comercio libre entre jugadores, mucha interacción. Puede que dependa mucho del azar, cosa que mejora algo con la expansión Ciiudades y caballeros.
One of few games where dice are incredibly acceptable. Great design appreciated all over the world.
It really is a classic. If you've never played it, you should.  I'd rate it higher, but I've played it a few too many times.
Good starter or "gateway" game.  We definitely added conflict just in game play style, but can be a little boring waiting for the dice to come up right.
This is the limited edition 15th anniversary version.
Own the Xbox Live Arcade version
A classic.  I'll still use this game to introduce new people to gaming, but I don't otherwise pull it out.
2/21/10: What else is there to say about this game?  A classic.  It's fun.

A classic game that transition casual gamers to more strategic thinkers.  However, the dice rolling could be very frustrating, especially when you have strategically acquired resource locations with high probability numbers (e.g. 6 or 8) but the dice rolls still keep coming up with 3 or 11!
Played at Origins in two different years.  Now owned. Obtained Dec. 2009
Interesting and funny at the same time.

This one was not a very big hit with my family, but I have a bunch of friends who are crazy about it.  I never loved it that much but it's not bad.  At this point though, I am really sick of it as my friends requested it constantly for awhile.  I don't normally mind blocking in games, but in this game it is frustrating, as the person who is able to successfully block the other person is usually determined by random luck.

Hey excellent game, I played 3 times dec 23rd and I just couldn´t stop....I know the box says is for 3 or 4....but 2 can play it too... of course we played it better when we were 3 ...was more tasty.... but it is a game that combines the competitive with cooperative way in ONE
This is the game that has gotten me to play way to many board game.  I still enjoy playing this game after so long, but it may be time to get some expansions.

The classic gateway game. Players that won't like this the first time they play will likely never rise above the non-gamer level. It's old however so there are better gateway games now.  For gamers, it's still a good, if casual, experience.

Why does this game drag on a bit ? You know how if you go into a mainstream store you might find two games that interest you. One of them is Ticket to Ride, this is other one. Gateway again, sorry I cant help it, any excuse to get more boardgaming in. Its an addiction
First introduction to a Euro game. I loved it. Game mechanics are pretty nice, good family/party game.
Wish we could play more, but it just doesn't have any way to work with only 2 players.
In Suzhou: Shanzhai 3rd edition in Simp. Chinese

Ok gateway game but this is like monopoly so more about luck than decisions - the winner will inevitably be the player who got the luck of the resource rolls and early bad luck means you will never be competitive. The expansions add interest but the luck issue is unavoidable. Good components. A 9 for family play and introducing non-gamer friends to the hobby - a 4/5 for gamers.

Jó kis építgetős, gyűjtögetős, nyersanyag-kereskedős játék, sok interakcióval. Hátránya a szerencse nagy szerepe a kockák miatt. Hat játékból még csak egyszer sikerült nyernem. Három játékossal az ideális, mert négyen már nem nagyon férnek el a táblán.  Kicsit túl hosszúnak is találom - az elején nagyon lassan indul be, amikor még mindenkinek kevés a nyersanyaga, a vége meg túl gyors, amikor már mindenkinek rengeteg termelése van és könnyen vásárol bármit.
Ok, this is the game I played the most throughout 2010! We're talking about more than 20 times with different non-gamers friends of mine! Great introductory game!  -Greek Secret Santa 2009-

7: Catan is a good game, accessible to non-gamers as well. I've played it a lot and got a bit bored with it. There's not a lot of variation between games. Also, being deprived of all resources due to bad dice luck is frustrating :)
One classic. good ressources management game. perhaps some hazard due to the dice...
I would own this, but our friends own it so we just play with their copy instead.  :)

Very good game.  I really enjoyed the way it blends simplicity of rules with depth of play.  Elegant and strategic with the right portion of luck.  My kind of game!  I've played it a lot more than the plays suggest.
Many more plays in the distant past (meaning more than a few months ago).
Classic gateway game.  Fun with some expansions, but dice results tend to dominate the game.  Also has a real cutthroat aspect.
Another default entry game. Luck can occasionally be annoying, but I still have fun playing this every time we play it.

Catan was my first entry into euro-gaming.  After I introduced it to my family, we would play a game or two every Sunday evening.  After a couple of years, tensions started building and some people would feel victimized by the Thief so it got shelved and has only been taken out a few times since.  The expansions really added a lot to this one.

This was the game that ripped me from the tendrils of Risk and Monopoly and into the world of BoardGameGeek. It gets bonus points for that. Mayfair Games has released expansion after expansion - in my mind, each one making it just a tiny bit worse than the original. I honestly don't think, in retrospect, this is a good 'gateway game'. Necessary kingmaker effect (how does a new player accurately determine who's in the lead?). It leads to a lot of player manipulation that shouldn't exist for players new to gaming. It has serious runaway leader problems if there isn't a concerted team effort to lock that player down AND a series of fortunate rolls. That being said, it's a lovely game, and there's a lot of subtlety to what is technically an incredibly simple game.
My first board game! Was so much fun. Now I don't play it at all. Expansions killed it.
upped the rating because of traders and barbarians!
The game that gives non-gamers something to talk about when seeing my collection. EVERYBODY has played this at least once and liked it, and rightly so.
It's THE game that opened my eyes to more strategic type games.  Since playing this game, I've grown to love the 'obscure' games (at least to non-gamers).
Classic game that every board game geek should own!
The usual complaints apply - runaway leader issues, luck of the dice, doesn't play well with 2 - but still, it's a classic.

This really got my group of friends into board gaming. I really enjoy the level of interaction allowed by Settlers. While it has a little more luck than I might prefer now, it is a great game to bring together experienced and novice gamers around the table for that reason.
Rules are clearly written. Somewhat luck dependent because of the starting positions. Rules (1-3): 3; Components (1-3): 3; Replayability/Fun (1-3): 1; Solitaire: 0 (0-1).

This was a lot of fun when I first was introduced, and I still enjoy playing from time to time, but there is something about the luck of the dice rolls that always makes me very frustrated with the game.
The grand-daddy of 'em all. Not as great as it used to be.

The variability of the board layout itself and numbered markers is what makes this a great game. You have to adjust strategies here. This also lends to high replayability. The dice add some randomness, but muffled some by the markers. The different ways to get points really adds to the fun and suspense.   Clearly this game (and series) has been successful for a reason. You can think 3 moves ahead, or just go; either way, it's still fun. The trading aspect here is done very well. Monopoly in theory has trading, but the reality there is limited.   Plays quickly once everyone knows how to play.   Edit: Rating down due to overplaying it and the C&K expansion being better. After many plays, not liking the trading aspect as much as early on. Still a great series.
Strength: Easy to teach/learn. High interaction Good component.  Weak: Depend on luck. Need several minute for set up.

Very cool game that is super accesible, but everyone's played it to death in my home town and church.  I *need* other options - if only they would remember how fun it was to learn a new game. Most people seem to have this opinion - "I can't immediately have as much fun playing a new game as the one I'm so intimately familiar with."  Pity!!
Fun game to play with my two girls.
Classic game! There's a lot of luck involved, but also strategy, trading and development cards. Great gateway game.
Hmm.. People love it but this game is not for us.. Returned it after the first play..

The gateway game that started it all for me, with well on 100 plays before I started recording such things. Gaming has not been the same for me since.  As I've gained a more-varied gaming experience, I do see that the random can make for a difficult game. Still a fun race, though.

Played this quite a bit years before coming to BGG. It's a decent game, but can be annoying due to high variance in the income. Also there is no real way to catch up once you are behind.  Preferably play with only the Cities and Knights expansion.
I just like this game more than I should. Deserves the fame.
I like it, but I've over played it
Still a solid design after all those yaers. A great gateway game for newbies. It's like Monopoly: every gamer should have one :meeple:

A boardgaming staple that is still plently of fun to this day. With all the trading, thievery, and dice-cursing it's a very social game, good for dinner parties, usually with wine and chocolate. Much depends on the placement of your initial settlements, but old hands should know this and be prepared to face a stiff challenge if they miss out on the best spots.

This may actually be a 6.5 for me, but it is difficult to distill my feelings on the actuall game play and design from the warm feelings it gives me as my first eurogame. It really is an excellent game in many ways, but two unfortunate parts plague it. For one, the luck factor screws it up for me. You roll two dice each turn, and these rolls give you your resources, which ultimately determine your success in the game. Of course, you place yourself on the map to best take advantage of the probabilities, but anyone who plays this game will tell you, dice sometimes have a mind of their own, and will often disregregard the probabilities. The other part that bothers me is how completely malicious the robber mechanic is - amazingly brutal for a gateway type game.   Having said all that, I'll also say that the Traders and Barbarians expansion neatly wipes out both of these issues for me, so get the expansion if my issues with the game seem sound to you.
If only I bought this when I first read about it in a glossy RPG magazine back in 1996 ish.  Instead I bought it for completeness 15 years later. It's good, but we never choose to play it really.

I like the trading aspect, so that's why I bought Bohnanza.  It served well as a jumping-off point to other Euros, but I prefer not to play it now -- and especially so if it's not a 3-player game.  I've decided what I like about this game the most is that most everyone knows how to play, so I do not have to explain the rules.  Nice!

This was my first foray into the world of German board games. We loved playing this one and it really opened my eyes. It's fallen out of rotation for a while, but I keep aiming to play this one with the event deck rather than dice. I would also like to try the 2-player adaptation.
Okay, this was better than I thought.

"Колонизаторы" с дополнением "Кол-ры: Города и рыцари" - очень удачное совмещение с указанным дополнением, так как не играю без него, то описываю лишь в паре. Нетяжелая в освоении ставша стратегической игра :), играется относительно недолго для стратегии (1.5 часа), играть может 3-4 человека, вдвоём лучше не играть. Исполнение локализации отличное. ИМХО - 5 баллов в своей категории.
It's a classic and fantastic gateway. And it's STILL a great game.
If I can't play a Das Buch scenario, Vanilla is my favorite flavor.

[SP] Lo mejor de este juego es que puede jugarlo cualquiera, muy bueno para iniciarse, de duracion corta y bastante rejugable.  [EN] Can be played for anyone, its good game for start with, short duration and replayable.
This is a classic. I've played it so many times I feel like I know all of the strategies, and for this reason, I've gotten a little tired of it. Nevertheless, it's fun to jump back into.
My first adult foray into Euro gaming. Doesn't get played as much these days but still feels good to play after all these years. Great gateway game to get new players to game with us.
The base set for Seafarers to me. But it started everything and is great alone.
in mijn bezit sinds: 2009  A nice game which most people know!
This is the ultimate gateway game, and I still thoroughly enjoy playing it. Maybe in a few more years I'll join the Hate Catan club, but I doubt it.
Gaming has moved beyond Settlers, but it's still a classic, especially among dice games.
对一般人来说，是容易上手的游戏。对我来说，却是玩过几次后，慢慢觉得好玩的游戏。
An all time classic. A bit too luck-dependent though, but that can be compensated by using the event cards (which I highly recommend).
What more can I say . . . Its great!
Although this was my first Euro, and I had some fun with it, I feel that luck plays too much of a factor.
I own both a german edition with plastic pieces, and a nicer english edition with pieces made of wood.
Probably the one game I can always get people to play. This is just a ton of fun. I can wholeheartedly recommend this to almost anyone. You won't be dissapointed.
Good gateway game, but there's just a little too much luck involved for my tastes.

Reconociéndole todos los méritos a Catán por llegar a donde ha llegado, me cuesta mucho jugar una nueva partida con él. Siempre encuentro una opción más divertida y menos pesada. Es un juego al que se le nota el tiempo, dando la sensación de ser muy mejorable sin apenas cambiar la fórmula.

Classic.  This was my first European board game and I gotta give it credit for introducing me to the hobby.  However, sometimes this game feels a bit too luck oriented.  [Have played 20-30 additional times]

Played 10+ times, Box Condition: Has some wears on the corners and a nick on one of the sides of the box. Cards Condition: Good, worn edges, Pieces: Great 4/6 colors have all, (red and green have 1 missing road each). Instructions are Included.

A game everyone should try once. Is it a classic? Probably. After the jokes are worn thin, the game endures. Regardless there are plenty of other games I love to play that owe Settlers a royalty check. Or at least a thank you card, most kids leave their folks in a lurch, so don't hold your breath.  Tueber has milked this sucker to the point of irrelevancy and each rendition sells, so I guess it is a bonafide classic. Is it plagiarism to steal from yourself, or just a sign of limited creativity?
要好大張枱的一個遊戲.
My into to eurogames. Thank you, Wired magazine.
Basic 4 player euro die rolling and area control strategy game. Some skill and trading involed, but more luck of the die. Family game. Modular board.
A classic. The trading phase alone--assuming strong personalities are involved--make it extra fun. I've rarely won this one, but always find it fun.

Some gamers I know really do treat this game as a "disposable" gateway game but, actually, I'd be quite happy to play it again.  It is possible that I might have overrated it simply because I haven't played it for ages.  One thing I do recall is that the die rolling does make it very random.  The are simply not enough rolls of the two dice in the game to get close to the distribution of totals that you use as a basis for deciding how to place settlements, which is often quite disheartening.  Perhaps too random for a gamers' game and too complicated for a family game, but quite good fun none-the-less.
The game that opened the board gaming world for me. It's a great game, but after playing the other luck free games you soon become enoyed by the dices.
Have played this half a dozen times or so.  It's a fun family game, but it lacks the depth of games like chess.
My first eurogame. I still enjoy it.
If you have only played the base, be sure to play Cities & Knights of Catan which makes it much more interesting.  Great basic game but a bit of a dice roller.
Need to play today to see if I enjoy it more than almost 10 years ago...

This was the first board game other than monopoly and the game of life that i ever played...it was my gateway drug into strategy games!  I think its actually many peoples gateway drug into strategy games.

I will always have a soft spot for this game.  This is the game that made me want to play better games.  When I finally bought this game I bought all of the expansions and 5-6 player expansions.  I think some games can screw you over if the dice aren't rolling what you want it too, but I still enjoy playing it.  However, I will only typically play Cities and Knights.
This is the game that introduced me to the world of board games.

Played this last night for the first time IRL.  I purposely avoided this game, because I believed my wife would hate it.  It turns out she enjoyed it quite a bit.  Go figure.  I guess it's a gateway game for a reason.
Carcassonne won the easy gateway game war, IMO. Plus the thief is really annoying. Still, not a bad game.
One of the 1st Euro Boardgames I ever bought.  A timeless classic of resource management and building with many ways to strategize and win.  Love it!

Clever design, lots of replayablitiy.  The effect dice roll on the outcome of the game, in theory, should not be significant by law of large numbers.  In practice, however, luck almost always plays a bigger role than I wanted.
Everyone has an opinion on this game, what could I possibly say here?
Great but I'm done here it has been played to much my first "gamers game" it will always have a soft spot in my heart

Runs a bit long but is still enjoyable.  *Dec. 2010- Updated my 4th edition for this new all wooden bits 15th anniversary collection and I love it.  The cards are a bit smaller but come with a holding tray and it will make it easier to sleeve them.  I am very happy with this upgrade I know that it will last me a long time from the great quality of all the wooden components.
We don't play this anymore because we rarely have 3+ people to play.
I like this through the first 3 quarters of the game, but sometimes that last quarter seems to drag on and on and on.

I doubt there's a lot I can say about this that hasn't always been said. A classic, a gateway, but still peculiarly requested by fans of the oblique and the obscure. But yet, I really really enjoy it every time it comes out. Classic? Or nostalgia? Who cares - there's a spark here that is close to timeless.  The one major gripe is that an initially poor position could end the game right there and then for you. Being fourth to speak on an unfavourable layout means you'll be playing catch-up all the time.
