Was my game of choice for a long time.  Then I played it too much with my parents who constantly bickered over resources, and it somehow lost its luster.  I'd break it out every now and then though, although I prefer four person games.

This game was more or less the first Eurogame I played.  It's a nice game, but no matter how many people talk it up and say how great it is, I cannot escape the fact that every turn is decided by a roll of the dice.  I've seen people occupy every number except for the 3, 4 and 8 and watch 7-8 turns pass before being able to get a resource.  It's a little too random for me, and admittedly I burned myself out on it.  You never forget your first, but you do normally move on to greener pastures.
A mix of strategy and chance that moves from fun/ny to very cutthroat quickly as the game advances.
Great game, but somewhat bland and slightly too far on the luck end of the spectrum. Significantly improved by cities and knights expansion.

you must admit this is random game, but it is awesome nevertheless. probably the best family game I've ever played ( however I haven't tried carcassonne yet)  the biggest merit is, in my opinion, trading - very funny and exciting

My first strategy game that wasn't Risk! Little did I know it was just a gateway game to all that would come after it.  Also, the resources are thus: Fire, Panda (short for Pandamonium), Chocolate, Wood, and Weed.

This game feels a bit simple for me on it's own. There isn't enough possibility to earn points. I really like the variable map (in fact that's the greatest advantage of the game) The rules are simple, but unfortunately so does the game. Fortunately the expansion adds some variability. It doesn't see much table time nowadays. Play count definitely not accurate, since I have played this before I discovered bgg.  It was 5000 HUF I guess
Un clásico. Les gusta a casi todos los no jugones que lo prueban
Love this game!  Haven't played in a while, but definitely a classic!
pleasant, light social....my most successful "gateway" game  plays 20+
That game was fun to play for 10-15 times. After that it became boring, with the output predictable too fast at the beginning.
Like so many others, Settlers is the one that started it all.   PNQ
Settlers was the first designer game that I bought a few years back and I still to this day enjoy it. I really need to try to get it to the table a bit more.
Rating is just from playing electronic versions.  May increase if my physical copy ever actually gets to the table.

The replayability on this is fantastic.  Sometimes the randomness of the die rolls gets frustrating (Another 3??), and a few other things that slow the game down for me can get tiresome too.  But still a fun game and one that many non-gamers enjoy as well.

One of the first non-Monopoly board games I ever played.  It was my gateway game.  I rated it alot higher at first, but now that I have more experience with different types of board games and concepts, I feel good about the 7 rating.  I guess currently I'm more into games with a lot more depth than rolling dice and seeing what happens.
Its popular for good reason.  Simple rules, good strategy...still quite a bit of luck involved for my taste but I still like it.
its a loved one: its my initiation to this types of games (before i was playing monopoly,go for broke and hotels)   (panoramous)

Not a bad game. The problem to have it is that every new gamer have heard about it, talks to you about it and tries to convince you to play; so with the time, i'm starting to get sick of Catan (Even when I play once a year at most)
My wife hates it because dice hate her.
I've grown up with Cities & Knights. Therefore classic Catan plays a bit too bland for my taste.
Simple to learn, short, fun trading. A good social game and a great gateway game. A little too luck-based for my tastes. I've played it to death or I'd probably rate it an 8.
Zweifellos ein gutes Spiel, aber lange nicht gespielt.
Just as fun on the computer as it is in person. A classic.
[u]Gateway[/u] game. I own it only for playing with "casual-boardgamers". [i]The Romanian version (Colonistii din Catan)[/i] has cheap components.
Gracze: 3-4 Czas: 75 min. Wiek: 10-99  Spis elementów w instrukcji.

Fun game.  I can appreciate what it has done for the hobby.  Love the modular board and simple play.  All that said, it is merely a good game to me and I would play it every now and then, but to say it is great is a huge stretch to me.
Solid simple game.  With a lot of options for strategy.  The base game is all you need I dont like the expansions very much.
Great game, but you really need 4 people to enjoy it. Randomness and bad trading are a killer though!
This is the game that revolutionized my thinking.  It got me back into board games and is a game I am always up to play.

I can't help but think that every game of Settlers I play comes down to sheer luck. I know the lands yield based on probability, but constant robbers, getting locked out of trades, and lucky victory point draws make any kind of strategy seem meaningless. To sum it up, it's an hour long experience of what could have been decided by a coin toss.  My feelings of the game aside, this is the one game that all of my non-gamer friends constantly nag me to play. It's an awesome tool to sucker them in to the world of boardgames. And for that, I thank you Settlers of Catan.

Great game that holds up surprisingly well. Good tight design and easy to learn. Some players might feel like they're getting shafted and sore loosers will get sore quite early on, I find, but there is nothing more snacks and a good glass of wine won't solve. :)

My gateway game, and still a game I love playing every now and again with the right group. I always use it to introduce non-gamers to boardgames beyond Monopoly, and they always enjoy playing it.  Lots of luck involved, but the player interaction during the game just makes this a blast to play with a group of non-gamers.

2010-11 Target / 2011 May Thrift  It is what it is. I can play a game of it twice a year and be okay with that. It's fun, but after a certain number of plays it loses it's luster. When playing with people who know the game though it can be a nice social experience.

The very one that really got me inte boardgaming and that made me frequently play boardgames. And the game is still very fun to play, hoard commodities and enjoy when the other players beg at your feet to bargain. Or despair when you realize that your buddy stabs you in the back by trapping you to one corner or even worse feel the hairs rising when there is nothing to do to prevent your opponent from playing the knight that gives him two more points and in a clever strike gain the trade route and on the top of that flash som victory point cards, all this takes him from last place to victory... A thrill each time:-D

Thrift find --- I think I've played this game at least 50 times, but likely closer to 100 (including Cities & Knights) and I still love playing it.  this is the game that we played as a family for years before it became mine and my brother's obsession which we then shared with many of his and my friends too.  This really is a phenomenal gateway game, and it's still fun for gamers, but the amount of luck is a turn off for a lot of them, I think.  I was thrilled to find this at Value Village for 6.99$ punched, but unplayed and it still had the receipt in the box from the Christmas purchase.  Lucky me!

My very first "eurogame". It's very easy but gives a lot of fun. Rules may be explained in less than 10 minutes, so it's game for everyone to play on everytime. After couple of plays it gets little borring, but has lot of expansions which save situation.  Somtimes it's too random (dice throwing).
This was our gateway game years ago.  Played it too much over the years.  Wouldn't choose to play it.

This was an immediate hit with my wife.  I enjoy playing but do not enjoyed getting ganged up on at the end of a four player match if I am in the lead.  Understanding that it is part of the game does not make it better.  Still, a fun game and a good gateway to the concept of building your own board.
Still hits the table after all these years.
A game which is easy to teach and play, harder to master, but the way it relies on dice to shape strategies makes it difficult for us to get it on the table.
My first boardgame and responsable to the current addiction to BGs.
Más de 50 partidas, pero ni una más. Archiconocido y archipremiado juego de gestión de recursos y control de areas.  Spiel des Jahres 1995

Probably my favorite "casual" game and one that I always recommend to newbies.  For people that prefer a "skill" game, the dice rolls can be extremely frustrating.  In a game with skilled players, it often comes down to who got the right rolls at the right time.  Even the best player/strategy cannot recover from a resource freeze that lasts several turns.
The tile-laying game that started it all, eh?
Hey, through a freak accident (as I see it) I actually became the first Swiss Champion in "Die Siedler von Catan" in 2002!

One of the most classic eurogames. I havent played this very much but i enjoy it. Nut much more to say really. The most important factor is that my girlfriend, who is a non gamer, really likes it. It will probably come to the gametable with her and the family more than my gamegroup.

I really like Catan for what it is.  It is a great gateway game for new gamers and a nice introduction to euros, and I have enjoyed most of the times I have played it.  However, when I play with a group of all experienced gamers, it doesn't hit the table as much.  The luck factor brings the game down a notch, IMO.
The board game that changed board games. Now it's called "Catan," but my friends and I called it "Settlers." Best with 4 players. 60 minutes Ages 8+ Medium (2.4)
This game has been growing on me for a long time. Best with 4, and best with people that have played it enough to know that hoarding never wins.
A balanced mix of strategic probability, and luck.  5-6 player game can go on a little too long for my tastes.
A good gateway game. I like the negociation aspect of this game. I played it when I begin to play modern boardgame but now I have a big collection, I prefer to play something else.

I would never turn down a game of Settlers.  It has a charm that outweighs my problems with the dicefest.  Something about building and colonizing the island just gets me.  Sold my normal copy locally via Craigslist due to lack of plays.  May be working with Barry to finally finish my custom wooden set.  Re-reading this blurb on 2018-03-07, I can say I probably would turn down a game of Settlers.  Things change!
Really enjoy the game, but frustrated at how easily the game can be lost before you even take a turn if you get a bad setup.
I use to love it. But the fun goes after a while. Excellent initiation to eurogames though.
Light game for non-gamers. Could be quite irritating for those who don't like roll dices. Sometimes you can stuck in possition with no reasonable decision to make.

This is the game that introduced me to the boardgaming hobby. I enjoy the negotiations and "trade embargos" that develop from this game. There is a fair amount of luck involved and even a sound strategy might faulter due to dice rolls or unfair trades. I will always pick a different game to bring to the table, but have always enjoyed the times that others suggest we play this game.

RL Settlers of Catan: 6/10 2-4 Players: 100+ Games  Cities and Knight: 7/10 2 Players: 30+ Games - 6/10 3 Players: 10+ Games - 7/10 4 Players: 30+ Games - 7/10  Seafarers: 6/10 2 Players: 5+ Games - 5/10 4 Players: 5+ Games - 6/10  iOS vs AI: Cities and Knight: 7/10 4 Players: 20+ Games: 7/10  Owned:  - The Settlers of Catan  - The Settlers of Catan: Cities & Knights - The Settlers of Catan: Seafarers  Status: Keeper  :A:

The simple fact that you did something and were engaged even when it was not your turn was a revelation to me; this game effectively destroyed roll and move games for me.  One of the first eurogames that I purchased--along with a Ticket to Ride.  Great family game.
Awesome as a gateway into boardgaming, but not a whole lot of depth.
ja, jag har två spel. En är faktiskt utsliten och passar inte de nya tilläggen..
Great introductory strategy game. Easy to teach yet fun to play. Quite a bit of luck through dice rolling. Easy to find yourself with bad placement through the entirety of a 2-3 hour game.
We haven't played this game in some time and really need to make and effort to get it to the table again soon.  Very fun game to play with family.

Gets a 7 for the dice aspect. A great engine that needs to be enhanced with C&K. Got rid of it because there are much much better Gateway games out there. It's still fun if I don't feel like paying attention for an hour or so.
Played a few times before discovering BGG. Its a fun, easy to each game.
Not bad. Can become quite fast-paced as the players get used to the game mechanics.

This is one of thoughs games that is a no brainier, it has past with flying colors against the test of time!  It is very simple but with the kinda depth that you still need in a game to hold you and keep you engrossed in the game.
A very fun game where making the RIGHT deals instead of the BEST deals is crucial. Luck has some impact, but the game doesn't last long enough that it would bother me.

Nearly always a great time (particularly with the expansions).  This game practically begs for double entendres regarding its resources.  Best with three players (since four or more can be exclusive).
Setlers of Catan a game of Trade and resource gathering... controled by dice, but many people use a card distribution Variant to simulate a 100% probability result.  ...eh that may not make sense.
My original version of "The Settlers of Catan" (not the fancy new Catan) is for sale with the 5-6 player expansion!

The first Euro I ever owned, though I didn't actually play it until 2007.  I still have my Mayfair first edition of the game.  I rarely ask to play this anymore, but it is still one of the better choices for newbies.  The trading mechanic creates a great deal of player interaction.  Best with 4.  I don't particularly care for the 5/6 player expansion as it drags the game out too much.

Decent, but hasn't really grabbed me the way it has other people. Still willing to give this a try anytime anyone is interested, but I'd usually rather play something else that I have.  Edit after a few more plays: the more I play this, the more I dislike it.

[i]Delightful game, but some tedium when it runs too long, which is too often[/i]  I love trading, but the game can get pretty tedious/reptitive when it drags on too long  Want to try the expansions for this game  (4 Design + 3 Enjoyment)

It is a classic and it did bring many people into the hobby. I like the trading aspect. - Rating lowered to 7 from 8 because of how much the result seems to rely on luck. - Adding that it's not very fun when you're losing.
Settlers of "Boring", it used to be one of our favorites. We keep it around to introduce people to the Catan series. Then we show them the really fun versions of Catan...America and Europe!

A really nice game. It has a lot of features that make it been loved: it's easy and enojoyable to play, even for people not used to board games because of its simple mechanics. I don't give it an higher rating because of its dice dependence, but it may be mitigated by a wise trading ability and an appropriate settlement placement.
A good game for bridging the gap between casual and hardcore gamers.  The random board and resource management combine quite well.
I would rate this game a seven but the fact that it's such an easy game to play with a variety of people makes this game an easy 8.

You know... this is a darn good game.  I periodically get reminded of that when some of my friends (who are much bigger fans) force me to play it.  Makes for an enjoyable evening.  Best features: 1. Gaining resources on other players' turns (partial reinforcement schedule). 2. Spatial element of map. Worrying about which direction to build in, being cut-off, possible ports to utilize, etc. 3. Use of the Robber to keep the leader in check.   Worst features: 1. Drags on too long, esp. if people haggle over trades. 2. Repetitive, without much of an "arc".

Dunno, just doesn't grab me. Maybe my expectations were too high, or perhaps I was too deep down the gaming rabbit-hole before I played it. I appreciate its value as a gateway, but TtR is still my gateway of choice when introducing non-gamer friends to the hobby.  Got the Gallery Edition in the Asutralian Mid-Year Math Trade 2012, so now I have a copy in my collection and can play it with newbs.

A classic for a reason and my introduction to modern board games. Fantastic interpersonal dynamics and a good family game, but success heavily depends on initial placement and dice-roll luck. Once fallen behind, it can be difficult for players to catch up in the victory point race.
ONe of the main stay games of this time. Good game that I'll play at any time. I just need people to play it. ;)
Gateway Game!  Trading mechanic takes this game to a different level than other "traditional" board games.  No one in our group hates this.

Fun game with high interaction.  For the time it takes to play a round, I would rather play many other games with my core group.    I do find that this is a good game to break people outside of the more traditional styles of American gaming.  See Cities and Knights if you are looking for a little more depth.  See Seafarers if you are looking to play with more than 3 people.
a fantastic fall-back game.  too much luck for my tastes, but it's always good for a person that doesn't have much experience with strategy games.  -this is the gateway drug of games.

A true classic family game. The new edition with the nice design and figures are wonderful and has a different atmosphere than the old edition from the 1990's. Despite it is an old Spiel das Jahres game, it is still a good game but should be played only with the extensions as the base game is flat and has a big luck factor due to the dice rolls. The Event cards which replaces the dice is definitely a must for every Catan game as it makes a better planned game (not sure why it is still not shipped with the new base game). The Traders and Barbarians or the Cities & Knights extensions give more complexity and better game experience why it still remains a family game.
For being a modern Eurogame classic, I've actually only played this a few times. Insert wood for sheep joke here. Now mainstream enough to be sold at Target, wow!
Great gateway game.  Now I am bored.
Juego de estrategia y recursos en el que cada partida es diferente porque el mapa cambia cada vez.Muy interesante con cinco jugadores.
Fantastic when you get good start points, frustrating when not. ◇最初の村がいい位置だと素晴らしく楽しく、そうでないとつらい。
The game that introduced me to Euros.
My original gateway to Euro-style games.  It doesn't make to to the table as much as it once did, but still a solid game.
I can't really bring myself to pay this without the Cities and Knights expansion these days. Still a good communicative game with an acceptable dice mechanism.

Fun little game.  Getting the right combination of resources for trading and building is the key.  Unfortunately, there's just enough luck with getting your numbers to come up, and not rolling 7s when your hand is large, to be problematic.  Inevitably someone gets the short end of the stick, and just can't seem to get resources, or gets his resources robbed.  Even just drawing a victory point card instead of "another militia" can make the difference.  It's a design decision for sure, but it's a tad more variance than I like. Nonetheless, playing it occasionally, and still enjoying this one.
A classic, and it is pretty good, but I am not as gung-ho about it as some people. Best with Seafarers, I think.
The classic.  Loads of fun.  Better with Cities & Knights.

The game that got me into boardgaming. Played it tons of times in the back days at my parents country house. Now play it rarely, because there are better (not so random) games in my collection. But still I like to play it from time to time. It is a very nice family game.

The ultimate gateway game. I can get people to play this that won't play any of my other games. Personally, I could now live without it, but I recognize how much of a pillar of boardgaming it is so I keep it.
This game really comes to life with the expansions. Very  competitive, definitely skill involved albeit the die can really mess up your plans.

Good game to introduce board gaming to others, very simple and easy going. One of the things I don't like about it is the luck factor, I am more into games that depends on your actions only, with No or minimal luck factors.
First Board Game I owned, unfortunately the dice always isolates one or two player from the game no matter how well they play.

My introduction to Eurogames.  I always enjoy the game while I'm playing it but when I'm not I get concerned about how I always seem to go for nearly the same strategies in the same order depending on the board setup.  The games are starting to feel too similar.
Introductory game for non-gamers. Fun and strategy combined with some luck. Very good re playability and balance.
I built this city on sheep and hay.

This is the game that started it all. I enjoy playing this every time, and I can even get my girlfriend to join in most of the time. This seems fairly easy for people to pick up, as even first time players seem to end up with a game plan by the end of the session.

Settlers was my first "Euro game" experience. I loved Settlers and became very obsessed with. Over time ganging up on the leader became annoying, but I will always treasure the countless games that I have played. Settlers remains the game that I have played the most.
A classic. My personal gateway game that has led me to begin exploring this hobby more fully.
This game has served us well. It will always have a place in the collection even though it doesn't get played that much.
Fun to bring out the first game I played every now and then.

The gateway game for a generation of Euro fans.  Superb design, mechanic, excellent interaction, nothing wrong with it at all.  It's just I never quite want to play it as much as something else.  But if you by any chance know any non-gamers, you must have a copy in the house.
This was the evil game that sucked me into Board Gaming. I would recommend to anyone getting into gaming, or anyone looking to suck someone into gaming. :)
Very fond of this for it introduced me to the world of games. But rarely play it now and actually - a little boring compared to most I think. But it'll stay in the collection for nostalgic reasons...

The first game that I became really hooked on.  A game that when I first started playing it, it was what I was always thinking about.  Unfortunately the trading aspect can make or break the game and can turn a fun game into a frustrating experience.  It has grown kinda stale, and the dice make for an extremely luck filled experience where a lot of times you cannot control anything.  I still think it works great as a gateway game, and was what I used to get many of my friends interested in the hobby.
Enjoy the game especially as a gateway game to introduce others to the hobby.
Played a few and the mechanics are sound.  Only thing holding me back is that I never get any resources so I can't win :(

This boardgame is based on board control and resource management.  I prefer playing this with the cards instead of rolling the dice. The stack will have one 2 card (representing a die roll of two), two cards with a 3 (representing 2 dice adding up to a three.) Make sure you put the appropriate number of cards in the deck to the odds of rolling a particular number (more for 7 than 2 or 12).
A great starter game, lots of depth and replayability.

Very fun game at first. Well thought out game system of resources, trade and building. Part of the fun is also what turned me away after 50 games: there is a lot of luck involved at the end game phase and can make the last player beat those that were on the verge of winning for the past 15 minutes. Nice accessible game for all, but hardly what hardcore strategists are looking for. A game you eventually grow out of.

Not a lot of strategy or skill is needed and much is left to the dice, but it sure is a ton of fun!  I have to admit that my favorite part of this game are my homemade 3D pieces!!  I need to get some pics uploaded soon.
I enjoyed the game, even if the mechanism isn't perfect, in my opinion. Best to play the stategic version than the one based on luck.
This is a game that BGGers love to hate.  I think it has its place, and I enjoy it well enough.  I've just played it to death so it never sees the table anymore...

Excelente juego para cuando te inicias en el mundo. Dps, tras catar varias cosas, el juego se queda obsoleto; demasiado largo para todo el azar que tiene. No obstante, para jugarlo de vez en cuando en grupos sin ánimos de perreo está bien.

It's a classic. Sure, there are better games out there, but with the right group Settlers can still be a lot of fun. That said, I think the total time per game, and the down time for each player during play, is out of balance with "what you get to do." I have a copy anyway.

I thought we had reached the pinnacle of gaming when we played Settlers the first several times.  Now, we play it once every several months.  It seems to drag at times, but it is a good game.  After some recent plays with the dice, I'm feeling that I enjoy this game quite a bit more with the deck of dice.  It provides players with more information to make intelligent decisions during the game.
Honestly, I know I should have expansions for this but I don't. Since I don't, it is rather stale and boils down to the dice gods and player politics. This would be fine, if it didn't take so long.
A fine game, I've played it to death, but am still willing to play the occasional game.

I secretly only keep this around for those times when I'm with my family and we feel like playing a game.  A lot of my other games tend to have themes that my relatively religiously conservative family would lend to being 'demonic' or morbid.  This is cute and fluffy for the most part and I think the player interactivity really helps it.  Considering trading it and the expansions I have. Need some fresh meat!  Preferably sheep.
A rare strategy board game that seems to appeal to women as much as men

The game that got me into gaming. A classic that I'm always happy to play (with the right people). It can get quite addicting for some, so be careful to not play with people who don't enjoy confrontation or who give up easily

Why do so many normal people like a game which makes everyone who plays it angry? I have the same question about Risk. Components of most recent editions are abhorrent, and warp upon contact with the air. Still, you better have it if you don't want to get stuck playing Monopoly.
We played this so often in the past, we got enough of it. Especially the trading part is getting tedious. Still: This is a classic if there ever was one.
base catan can still be pretty fun and simple although I prefer now to play with City and Knights expansion
A good warm up game.  But a bit overrated.
A good classic.  A good introduction to strategy games for littler ones.
Warped pieces and fiddly. I would rather pay extra for the super wood edition.

Until recently, I haven't played Settlers for a few years and had regarded it as, sometimes, a frustrating dice-fest. However, after a fresh play I was struck by how clean and simple the game is.  We'll be using Settlers as our gateway game, and I also hope to explore C&K and T&B during 2015.
Great to introduce ppl to gaming because its so simple, but after few games i got bored of it.
Jogo muito bom, pena que é um pouco aleatório demais pro meu gosto.
The game that started it all for me. Still like it, but seems a bit too chance-driven to really draw me in anymore.

Dull.  I have played too many games where one person ends up with a hand full of nothing or resources nobody wants and then proceeds to sit there miserably for the majority of the game.  Often, I have been that person.  Even though I know how to play the odds, it sometimes happens that an 8 never rolls in a game while an 11 will roll 5 times in a row.  You can't control that and half the time you can't even mitigate it.  I don't really think Settlers is necessarily a bad game, but the dice mechanic makes it so.  I have always contended that trying a new mechanic, such as card drafting or something else would make the game quite fun.  Hell, I rather enjoy Settlers of America: Trails to Rails in spite of the dice rolling because the gold coin mechanic and the sheer number of ways you can DO things with your resources really helps to avoid the rut that Settlers can induce.  EDIT: my opinion of Settlers has improved. I now consistently do well and can appreciate the game despite the age of the design. I've still played it too much to enjoy it more than a 7, though.

Fun. Modular board and expansions boost replayability. I am not a fan of colonialism themes in games. So many colonialist Eurogames out there, what gives? Ignoring the theme though, the mechanics are what makes it fun.
Buen juego para iniciarse en el tablero.
This game has been fun to play so far but it does depend on players who are interested in trading or not tanking.

Rating based off of first game that I played and taught my 8 year-old twin daughters. They learned it pretty easily, though the game took a while because of one of the girls not keeping her hand in order, especially later when we all started getting more cards. I won with 11 points after I played a Knight to take the Biggest Army card from one of my girls (who ended up with 7 points down from 9 and could have won the next turn otherwise) and my other daughter finished with 9 points. So it was a really close game and we were all in it to the end. Trading went well and they picked up on that quickly and were good sports about it.   My one complaint so early in my experience with the game is the components, and that was reflecting in my rating. They aren't the greatest. The perimeter puzzle pieces are kind of flimsy and bend easily with humidity. Considering the game came out so long ago, perhaps they just didn't make component's as thick back then?   My rating will likely go up with more plays. I like the simplicity of it and I love that my kids really like it, so that means it will get more play and that's always part of ratings for me.
Stripped of all the expansions, this is a pretty good game. I think I like it better by itself.
+ The Settlers of Catan: The Great River + The Settlers of Catan: Cities & Knights
Tried of the "classics" and looking for something with more strategy or something not from the 80s or 90s?   This is the game that started a new generation of board game players.

The classic. The store didn't have Stone Age or Pandemic in (they had it last time I was in a couple weeks ago).  So this was the only other game that I thought the roomies may be interested in that wasn't Power Grid.  I enjoy the idea, and the game play is solid, but the board setup and take down really detracts from me wanting to play it, even though lots of people request it.  I will give in the next time someone wants to, heh.
Along with TTR, the game that got me started on board gaming again as an adult.  Still enjoy it, but definitely played it too often at the request of others I frequently game with.

It's hard not to agree that this is the perfect gateway game. The rules are understood by new players part way through the game and the trading elements encourage frequent interaction.  My only criticism is that ten points can be a little long some times and that maybe eight or nine points is a better alternative.
Classic gateway game. Easy to teach and enjoyable to play. There are much better games out there but few are as good for introducing other people to boardgaming.
Got to play this classic at last. Still a brilliant design and a perfect gateway game.  Settlers of Canaan is much better, however.
Complete with components in excellent condition, box very slightly dished on top and one corner on box bottom shows small crease and minor ding  BIN 20
It's a lot better with the "Knights" add-on.
Pretty fun , gets repetitive after several games though.
Played this dozens of times in the early '00s
Includes Seafarers, Traders & Barbarians, and 5-6 player expansions. Also with special Catan Boards and accessories.
This is one of the most popular games in the world for a reason: it's very accessible.  Trading and building is easy to understand, and it's fun.
Klasyka. Losowe, wesołe i całkiem przyjemne - jeśli masz z kim grać.
My in-laws are in love with it. I just want to be friends with it.
Simple game to play.  Great replayability.  Kind of like Diplomacy but based on commerce instead of conquest.
We'll probably never get rid of it, but our copy has been gathering dust for years.

This is where it all started for me. After years of only playing games based upon luck (Monoply, Game of Life, Risk etc) I discovered Settlers of Catan; a game where your choices actually have an influence on the outcome of the game.  If had this game in my possession for about 12 years now, and we still play it regularly (althought most of the times with expensions).  Upsides of the game - not very difficult to explain so you can play it with almost everyone; - trading your commodities.  Why don't I rate the game with an eight? There is still to much luck involved in the Settles of Catan. And once you've played the game with one or more expansions the base-game gets a bit dull.

This game is slowly starting to become a burden to play.  It's still fun, but after getting used to playing the digital versions, dealing with the slow process of setting up the board and the pieces and making the trades makes this game feel longer than it should be.
Everyone seems to have played this out already, which is sad for me because for some reason I didn't get my first play in until 2011, and I like it a lot.
The mechanics bring some strategy into a game that relies on dice.  Trading is the best part of this game.
Yes, the game that started it all for me. It does a lot of things and does them well. My opinion of it has gone down because I would rather be playing other things.
Whitout any of the expansions, it gets old to quicly.
A nice game that can be played with new players and the family.
Also own Seafarers, Cities & Knights, and Traders & Barbarians expansions as well as the 5-6 player extensions.
de 3 a 4, tablero Ya lo tengo un poco kemaete pero sino hubiera sido por este juego jamas hubiera picado el gusanillo por este mundillo y eso que ya habia jugado al carcassonne y ciudadelas.
Despite the rating, this is what introduced me to this incredible, wonderful hobby, and for that I am extremely grateful.
Very fun game.  Lucky based so if you have bad rolls you may not enjoy it.

Personally, I would rate this a 6. However this game is a huge hit with newcomers to Eurogames so I rated it a 7 bearing in mind that it will and always will be the go to game for new players. For me, I find it boring especially when playing against newer players as the downtime can be excrutiating for such little action (roll a dice). I think that's it. It's the downtime that bothers me the most in this game but in all honesty, I find it a little fun when there is minimal downtime.

Pleasant game, 6 players version is more fun : extension 5-6 should have been part of the game in the first place. May seem frustrating for some players with bad luck or bad initial situation leading to a dead end for their growth.
Alapjatek. Mai fejjel mar azt mondanam tul nagy a kocka szerepe, de ettol meg jo, es szivesen ulok le jatszani.
I am usually able to convince anyone to play any game, by saying "It's just like Settlers of Catan."
A classic that still holds up as a great 4 player game.

Settlers of Catan is worthy of being in every gamer's library, and serves as a wonderful gateway drug.  The random setup and dice-rolling aspects of this game can infuriate players who have grown accustomed to more refined Euros, but this is one of the first crossovers that introduced many of us to grown-up board games, as we know them.  Resource management and negotiation somewhat mitigate the randomness, which is why I consider this game a notch better than Carcassonne.

People get down on this game now, but it's still super fun I think.  It's the game I can get non-gamers to play and they feel like they are stepping into my world a bit.  It obviously sucks to have the robber on your spot the whole game, which pretty much always happens to me, but it's a great game, and I don't mind the politicking.    I haven't played any of the other versions of this game, so I can't speak to them really - just the 4-6 player regular.
A great intro Euro which helped suck me in and which I have seen suck in a lot of other players.  I've gotten my money's worth, but I do feel burnt out on it.
This helped get us into gaming, but it's been a while. Still fun with the right group though.
A classic gateway game. However, I prefer to play with the expansions and not only the base game.

Has jaded a bit over time but still a classic. This rebooted the board game hobby in the 90's. States 3-4 players but plays VERY well with 2 although you loose a bit of the trading aspect (but not much).

I was really into this game until I grew tired of it. A lot of fun for me is dependent on the group I'm playing with an their willingness to trade goods. I've played games where no-one was willing to trade among the players, and I disliked those plays severely.  Another thing I've gone to dislike about the game, is that when playing with more than 2 people, 2 people can band together to try and 'wall in' a village of the third person, very likely putting that player at such a disadvantage that he/she can no longer play a competitive role in the game and has to basically wait out the game while 'giving' away goods to the remaining players.
Used to play quite a bit, but now have other games that I would much rather play.  When I was playing it, I really liked playing it with the City & Knights expansion.

Solid game.  While somewhat time consuming with more than 3 players, it's still not too long assuming everyone knows the game well.  Limiting the trading to only the person who's turn it is, to me, is a must.  Otherwise, the game can take too long, and the unlimited trading ends up hurting the game, IMO.
Decent gateway game.  Another one of my firsts while exploring these waters.
Gateway game, I avoid playing this except when its the best choice due to length or because of new players.
Expansions: - The Settlers of Catan: Seafarers  I find this game to be very group dependant.

Fun, innovative and quick.  Can be a bit frustrating as fate can often play a much bigger role than planning and strategy.  You sometimes find yourself unable to act for long periods of time despite good board position.
My family enjoys this but we sometimes get on each other's nerves as it's easy to "not trade" or "block" a path foiling the other's progress.
Good game, usually willing to play.
What can i say...the game that started it all for me! It's a Clasic
I enjoy this one, but it can last a little long for me. With 2-4 players I enjoy it, but anymore (which requires expansions) and it drags on too long.
If Monopoly is the archetype of board games, SoC is the archetype of modern, good board games.
An old classic that I still enjoy.

Good casual game for beginners and advanced players alike. Lots of variability is a big plus for me.  Expansions are a must for me now that I have played with them so much.  They add enough depth to the game to keep me interested.
I'm always up for playing Catan, however I'd prefer to play something heavier on most occasions.
Good game for introducing people to board-games apart from Monopoly. Trading resources brings cooperation on the table, which is also good for newbies.
A nice resource management game that is also based a lot on luck. Good strategies can level it a bit.
Played this a bunch online.  I know what to expect.  I am dissapointed with the board quality.  Hope the game with the family makes up for it.

I don't understand why everyone seems to like this game so much. It's made of good quality materials but the gameplay for me is just...bleh.  I play it quite a bit however because it's one of the few games I can get my whole family to play.
It's Catan. It's basically a game about waiting while other people calculate mathematical problems in their heads.
Dice frustration (or extreme happiness) is the only drawback.  Careful and creative planning could of course override bad luck, but it's easier to blame the dice.
Nice classic game about Trading which almost never occurs

This is a fantastic game, and my rating is low because I've just simply played it too many times (500+).  At this point it doesn't have the thrill it once did.  I'm usually willing to play, but I won't suggest it very often.  The card trading and amount of interaction in this game are what makes it so much fun.
Always a good play; This was one of the first games I played that wasn't found in a major chain store. Great game to get people started; well balanced and fast paced.
First Euro I played, first Euro i owned and with expansions still gets played, to many stalled games in base game.

I love playing this on my phone ... which has made me wary about playing this in person. To play quickly, you have to realize when, no matter how trade you can do, you can't do anything and will have to pass. Also, initial placement is *critical*, as is early expansion (and block opponents growth). So it can be clear early on that you are boned, but you still have play the game out until an opponent gets 10 VP.
The manageable amount of luck and negotiation between players keeps this game fresh for me. It's still the most fun way to introduce new players to gaming.
This game got me back into boardgames a few years ago, whilst not a bad game to play, but with the limited amount of time I have to play boardgames I would rather play something better.

A reasonable primer for non-gamers, and certainly better than monopoly. The 'Luck' and the 'Robber' can get very annoying, and the 'Longest road' seems perhaps a little good. Still, most people will have a good time here for a number of games. If you've never played it you should for historical reference.

Gotta give it credit, it got me into gaming and is still to this day one of the best games for introducing people to the hobby. Old style art. Little to no theme. Nasty dice rolls. But wonderful trading mechanic. Will still play this game when asked.

Still a classic but a bit burnt out on it.  You randomly generate a board using hex tiles, each with a terrain on it and each with a number.  Each turn you roll two dice and anyone who has a town or city built at a corner of the hex gets a resource card corresponding to the terrain.  Then you turn in the cards to build roads, towns, cities, or special action cards.  There is some fun strategy to where to build your towns and roads and outmaneuvering your opponents.  In some sense, this is a civ lite, building up your little empire.  I enjoyed working out the strategies but now that I have them down, I get frustrated by the element of luck as bad rolls can really blow the game.  Sometimes the two dice just want to reward the player who claimed the "2" tile for no good reason.  :P
A classic that I've never really given enough time to, but have loved it every time I've played it.
One of the best gateway games.
Includes Cities & Knights and Traders & Barbarians expansions

Friends introduced us to Catan.  I won the first game and had no idea how it happened.  Since then, I've gotten slightly better and we've passed along the love of gaming to other friends with this gateway.
I still love being able to play Catan with people who don't usually play boardgames, but if I'm playing with fellow gamers, I much prefer Ad Astra or Settlers of the Stone Age.

The game that started my interest in euro-games. I love to play this with the family. It is great with the original game, but the expansions add much more depth, not to mention the ability to add more players.

This is a best-played-in-groups game that our gamer friends never really want to play and our non-gamer friends have sometimes heard of. The people who have played it before always seem to want to play with the expansions, so this doesn't get played often. A trading game, which isn't always my cup of tea, but it's good for casual groups.

*7* (10+ Plays) Catan opened up the Euro gaming world to me. The strategy and gameplay really interested me to this whole new genre.  I still enjoy playing on occassions. It's not really a game that makes it out of the closet as much, maybe once every couple months. I enjoy the strategy factor combined with the luck factor Catan offers.

Fun gateway euro, with the resources and the conversions and the building stuff.  I especially like  the open trading.  Strategy City/Civ Building - Negotiation & Trading, Dice, Hand Mgmt, Modular Board, Route Building (3-4, [b]best w/ 4[/b]) _Weight 2.4 ♥ 75 min
Great gateway game. Was fun the first 30 times.
Fun, but it goes on a bit too long for what it is. I'm OK with randomness, but sometimes it really sucks if you don't get resources round after round (especially if no one will trade).

I'm bumping up my score, and completely revising my review. This works great as a family game. I wouldn't propose it with my gaming group/s; there are too many other games I'd rather play. But with my family, it works rather well (until my daughter is old enough to play, say Village).

This is the strategy game I've owned the longest, but it's not one of my absolute favourites. I do like it, but it can be very frustrating if the dice are against you or if you get hemmed in early on.

A classic compromise between strategic depth and simplicity, which the ability to please a wide range of players. The outcome is usually a little too random for my tastes, but that's a small sacrifice for having access to a strategy game that appeals to the casual player.
Like most.  This was the first "euro board game" I played.  Though I didn't jump on that bandwagon right away, it helped in the process.  It was actually "Bohnanza" that got me hooked.

The one and only game to introduce to gamer noobs.  Hands down, stop talking, there is no discussion.  This game is a virus.  Within 1 year of bringing it to an extended family gathering there were at least 7 more copies in the family.  From there who knows but it is ridiculous.
what to say. it is Catan. good family game that is not to heavy and most people like.
Classic family-friendly game that is very random but still takes some strategy.  I've played this dozens of times and will still happily enjoy the odd game.
Theme: Medieval Gameplay: Card Hand & Resource management, pretty fun Components: Good Replayability: I mostly hang on to it to break new people into designer board games. Rulebook: Good
Reasonable gateway game. Always found it a little dry and limited in options.
A fun game and a classic, the randomness turns me off a little bit. Also, we've tried multiple 2 player variants and none seem ideal.
Somewhat hard sell for people, but fun once you get into it.
Si no lo has jugado, no puedes considerarte jugón.
One of the best gateway games and each time it comes out, its still fun and interesting to play despite its age.
Mi primer gran juego de mesa, mas de 100 partidas y disfrutándolas todas.
Fun game, usually down to play.
Fun game with plenty of thought and strategy.
Lots of fun with the right people.  Yes randomness can get you down.  But with the right group it doesn't matter.  With the wrong group this game is torture.
這分數是出於骰運太差惱羞的結果
Have played with all expansions. Great gateway and family game. Must have for any collection. Rating is with Cities and Knights expansion in mind. Would be a 5 or 6 without expansion included.
Fun game, of course a very popular Gateway. All of ours tend to take far too long to play (almost always 90 min.). Would like it more if we could bring play time down to 45-60 min.
Fun, relaxing, great for both beginners and semi-pros.
A fun gateway game with a decent amount of strategy and re-playability.
So easily to be taught, yet so addictive. Like it a lot, now i want to try the expansions.
The first step for everyone into the new boardgames. It has everything: interaction, auction, strategic thinking and with a few rules. And it's not too long. It's a fantastic MUST HAVE.
My gateway game. Don't mind playing if asked. Can last a little longer than I want it to.
The ultimate gateway game, although after playing this so many times I find it to be a bit swingy. Your initial placement will make or break you.

This a favorite for many players. It is really fun and pretty simple to play and teach. One element that I dislike is the random dice. The dice control what resources show up. You can get completely screwed out of getting resources if you're unlucky enough. I guess I just havent played enough yet to truly get used to it.
Purchased my copy in 2007 and played it 20+ times.  I haven't played the game in over a year at this point, but it still has a place in my heart.  Always prefer playing with Cities & Knights.

I have played Settlers since 2003 and really just cannot play it anymore.  The luck involved with the dice is just too frustrating when combined with how long I have played the game.  For me, this game is just stale, but it did have the most longevity of any board game I have ever played.  If you do not have it, Settlers is a must own at some point.
A decade ago I would have rated this a 9, now there are many better choices. Still a fair choice for a gateway game.

Settlers is fun the first few times, but then it can get extremely boring.  Especially if your strategies never work because the dice hate you.  Seriously, there is no reason that the number 6 does not come up ONCE in an entire game.  However, it is one of the greatest gateway games available.  Then, it is time to move on to better games.
Подсаживает новичков на настольные игры со 100% успехом
Love the constant trading. It's a huge plus.
Good casual game for all the family !

Easy to teach, fun to play, and the best game to test whether or not you can draw your friend into the gaming world! MWHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHA!!!!  reccommmend playing with cities and knights for a more complex gameplay, though somewhat changed

This is the game that brought me into the hobby. I find it elegant, balanced (player decisions balance the dice rolls) and pleasant to play.  Meanwhile I get the feeling that other games have surpassed it, and players who are already in the hobby might be expecting more. It is still a good game to introduce people to the hobby. (In the collection, in Portugal)
This game was the Rosetta stone that translated board games to generalish population. Very good, and still fun after almost twenty years.
Nobody wants to trade with me anymore...
A classic. Inherited from Bob Cyrus, gentleman of fortune. It's a little random for some people, but I like it.
A very newbie friendly game, and it the right company, -hilarious!

Settlers - as has been well chronicled by many other people - was a bridge game for me - that took me from the world of 'board games' as I knew them (think Monopoly, Scrabble, etc) to the world of modern/Euro type board games as I know them now (think bgg.com). At the time, I was blown away by this game and it made me catch the modern board game bug. I thought the mechanics and strategy were great.  Now, however that I've been exposed to many more (imo better) games, I'm actually not a fan of Settlers.  What I don't like about the game is that you are reliant on the trading aspect of the game for success.  Meaning if your opponents decide not to play nice and trade with you, you are sunk. I also don't love how the robber can freeze your progress of the game, and if others gang up on you your sunk. I don't typically mind the 'screw you' aspect of games, but in this case the robber combined with the trading dependencies make this game flawed for me.
Yet to have a game of this, but looking forward to having a game (17/04/12)  Had the first game a couple of weeks ago and we all really enjoyed it, can see why it's won a few awards (28/04/12)

Probably the best Eurogame ever, but I think I played it way too often to still enjoy it. (Especially back during my student exchange year in Norway when this game was the only one available among all my friends there...)

This was one of the first games that got us into the hobby. A visiting friend brought it while in town on the Fourth of July in 2009. We loved the game and in fact made a copy ourselves which got a few plays. Eventually we forgot about the game until we discovered the full depth of board games at Free Comic Book day at our FLCGS. We were excited to get a copy of Settlers as a wedding present in 2011; however, with so many other games we rarely get this to a table. It is still in the collection for when people we meet and become friends with mention "Have you heard about this game called Settlers of Something?". We can pull it out and show them before moving on to another gateway game that we enjoy more.
Definitely, one of the better gateways out there, on par with Ticket to Ride
Haven't played this enough to experience true Catan dread, but I could see it happening if I played this often, which as a result, I don't. Great to have around for intro gamers, though.
The fact that it was for 3-4 players meant that I could never get it too the table.  Kind of a themeless game.  Other games were more interesting, so we traded it for Merchants and Marauders.

I can see why this is regarded as a classic. I liked it very much. The dynamics of the game are fluid and the player interactions are always fun. Playing badly in the early game leaves you so much behind though that you can't challenge other players anymore. While it's fair, it also makes the game a bit boring for the losing player. The game can sometimes drag on a lot though...
Always happy to play it until someone gets blocked in. From then on it just goes downwards. Seafarers gives some extra options to do something so I try to throw it in.
A regular at family game nights. Very easy to teach new people.
Fun, fairly simple game.  First "resource & build" game I'd played.

I'm not as keen to play this as I used to be.  I would like to try it again with some variants/house rules to speed up play--e.g. the harbor master, tournament rules (second placement is a city rather than a settlement) and the welfare variant (if a player does not earn a resource from the die roll, they receive a coin; players can then redeem the number of coins equal to their victory points currently on the board for a resource of their choice).  Depending on how much they shorten the game time, these variants might even make the 5-6 player extension bearable.
Yes it is too long and random but I still love to play every once and a while.

Rock solid classic. Trading and building never loses its appeal unless people refuse to trade with you and your neighbours 8 gets rolled every other round while your supposedly equally good 6 remains oddly absent.
The game that led me to BGG.
Only ranked this low because the Misses and her friends want to play it every time and if it was up to them it would be the only game we play. I do quite enjoy it though.

Although the expansion sets are of flimsy quality, the game is a solid design.  Based on craps, it couldnt go wrong.  Settlers is a lot of fun to play, Ive never been interested much in who wins.  It is a lot of fun to add additional pieces.  I have brought in my own soldiers, tanks, and terrain pieces.  I dont like playing this one with people who play to win.  There is a bit too much luck involved and I get tired of hearing people complain.
Settlers isn't quite as cool as it was before I knew the good Euro games, but I still enjoy a game every now and then.
Mi primer juego de mesa...y aun sale con bastante asiduidad.  Un pilar basico en la biblioteca de cualquier jugon
I'd give the gameplay a 6, but the social/fun aspect an 8 to average out to a 7. :) - Who I am playing with really matters for how enjoyable this one is.
Still a fun game, beginning to show it's age a bit in mechanics- but still great to pull this out for new players, they always love it.
Sokat játszom vele, szinte napi szinten, igaz inkább számítógépen, nem lehet megunni. Nagy ötlet, nagy játék!
It is pretty good... for a gateway game.
Do YOU have Wood for Sheep?

It's classic.  Requires some expansions to make it interesting.  The base game plays ok with kids if they can keep their focus that long.  Easily ruined by younger minds if they play favorites or lose interest.
My first bought game (2006). Romanian version of the game.
Its okay for playing games with non-gamers.
Sevens will be the death of me!!

play this on the ipad. will probably never own a physical box copy as everyone else seems to have it already. and i really dont care to play it that much. it is simply convenient when there is nothing else to play or nothing you care to teach.

Good starter for Euro game introduction. Not much there for seasoned players. Expansions and Scenarios make this one a keeper though. Cities and Knights can turn this into one of the best games out there.
Love this game, Easy to play once a new player "Gets" what they have to do, if they like board games they should like this

I was shocked when I won my very first game of Catan.  I thought I didn't know what I was doing.  This may have been entirely true, but I applauded that the game had multiple ways to win.  The strategy employed by my friends was different than the one I used on my own.  Simple to understand and easy to set up, Catan is a great introductory board game for the uninitiated (like myself).   Now that I own a digital copy on my Playstation, I've been trying to play as much as I can to stay fresh.

Played 3 or 4 times with the family. A touch of 'Monopoly' syndrome, which is exactly what we were trying to get away from - i.e. one poor soul always seems to get left behind, unable to build, and is stuck watching someone else follow their sloooow but inevitable path to victory.  Still, it's an appealing game and I can't help thinking we were unlucky in those first few plays.
Good gateway. Sometimes it would be nice to play it again
I replaced with the 15th anniversary box
Really liked this game when I first learned about it. Never play it anymore, but would still play if asked.

This is the classic Eurogame that got everyone into Eurogames. I appreciate the game very much, but honestly? I find it a little dull. Maybe the expansions make it better, but I have not had a chance to play those. Still, a solid game and an influential one.
Open, only played a few times.

This where it all restarted for me in boardgaming terms. Each game you randomly form the island of Catan by linking hexagons. Each land hexagon (barring one, the desert) can produce one of five type of resources (wool, clay, ore, wood or grain) and is given a number from 2 to 12. At the beggining of each players turn two dice and each player that has a village or a city in one of the hexagon(s) with that number get that resource. Other ways to get resources inclue trading with your opponents and, of course, robbing them. With the resources you build more roads, villages and cities, as well as buying "development cards" that allow special actions or offer VP. First player to get 10 VP, wins.  12 years now since discovering Settlers and I still haven't got tired from it.

The gateway game to all things wonderful.  My first euro game and I still play this one fairly consistently.  I actually enjoy it quite a bit with just the wife and I, although it plays better with more people.
Had lots of fun the first 10 games, but now the game is getting repetitive. I'm not crazy about the inability to move your network easily. Seafarers helps change the game up a bit.
One of the modern classics, still holds up even if some things are a bit dated. Would prefer other games to play but I wouldn't say no either.
I just like to own those sheeps!

Settlers (along with Puerto Rico) started me on the path of modern board gaming. I still love the random board setup and the Civilization-like feel of expanding your colony. I haven't played in quite some time, mostly because there are so many other games crowding it out.

One of the games that introduced our group to the wonder of games beyond the Game of Life and Monopoly this is always a fun game that incorporates resource management and negotiation skills! The chance factor comes in the rolling of two dice for resource production, other than that the most crucial factor is deciding where to start. This game can only really get unfair if in a custom game the hexes and counters favour one/two people and screw the rest over. Usually a fun game it always ends up with one person shut out and feeling dissatisifed therefore I would also like to see a variant of random/forced trading to even things out.

Replayability is moderate and the game is somewhat luck driven. Player interaction is high. It is unfortunate that it cannot play with 2 players though.  The last player to place settlements seem to enjoy a distinct advantage due to the ability to place both settlements and roads without fear of being blocked while blocking others.
Cool game, definitely one of my first Euros.

You've got to respect what Settlers did for the hobby. I would usually rather play something else, but if I'm in a group of Settlers die-hards or it's offered up I'll go along with it. There's not a lot of downtime as you are involved in everyone's turn, it plays relatively quickly (though 20 minutes too long IMO), and scales nicely.

I know some people who have played this to death, but I went so quickly form Catan to other games that I've just never gotten sick of this one. I probably won't play it more than once a year and probably only when asked, but I still find it to be a fun game. This will probably never leave my collection.
The gateway game that got me to the geek.

Good game - can understand why it is a modern classic.  The trading and robber mechanics keep things interesting, and prevent runaway leaders, but means things can become predictable.  Sometimes the board can have some very uneven spots, but the start mechanic tends to even this out.  Would be interesting to play with non gamers and see how it holds up.  A fun game overall, but there are other things I'd rather play.
+ Good strategy gateway game. Trading interaction is fun. Gets you thinking of what to do next all the time. - Extremely lucky (or unlucky) dice rolls can put an end to your game.
Multiple trade dominion expansions for this and sentinels. love it and hate it. rated 7 because i know it deserves better but i cant bring myself to rate it higher.
I will not pass up a game of Catan, but it is much better with K&C.
Great board variability. I'm not a fan of the lack of rules with respect to trading. Replay ability is low when playing with same group

Great game and a great gateway game for those new to Euro games. A little too social, the anytime trading mechanic makes the game take a while and strongly enables social players and gang-style gameplay.
A good game, but too overplayed. I have no desire to get to the table, but will still play it. I also need to get the dice deck...too many times have the dice not been in someone's favour.
i like this game with 3 people, but usually only have one other person to play with so that limits my ability to enjoy it.  tried some of the 2 player variants, but didn't like them as much

This game got me started into more serious boardgames, however once I started playing other games I realized how unbalanced this game is. If you get a bad start you might not have fun for the rest of the game.

This is the game that got me back into board games after a ten-year hiatus.  I can't say a bad word against it.  People tend to overstate the extent to which luck is involved, and it has become fashionable to bash it, while conveniently ignoring that (a) it came long before many of the supposedly superior games and (b) is THE game that made North Americans hope for and expect something better than Risk.

I think this classic is still a very good gateway Euro game, especially for families. There is quite some interaction with trading (especially if played not uber-competitively) and at the end of the game, everybody has increased his settlements. So even if you are not the winner, you can look down at the board and feel good to have build something from the ressources you produced or traded. That is probably the major appeal of Catan, which is still working nowadays.
The original does have an issue of the first placement having too much impact on who wins the game.
08+ or 10+, 3-4 players, best with 4, 90 mins. Holiday game.
Build and expand on the island of Catan. This game will give you wood for sheep.

This was the gateway game for me. Settlers is another game that my kids have won the Juniors championship at WBC. FOUR of them!  In 2012 it was Antony, 2013 was Donte, and 2014 and 2015 it was Holiday  :)
My poor wife can't stand this game.  I'm not sure what it is about it that she hates so much.
classic of the classics, have had the wooden version for a long time now, but sadly didn't manage to play it more often...need to change that...

A fine game, that I problably never would have picked up if it hadn't been the only "real" game available in a Brazilian gameshop. It's a little bit too luck-based, but nothing serious. Unfortunately Grow Jogos didn't release an expansion, and it's incompatible with foreign expansions since Grow changed the backs of the cards. May have to pick up an english version someday, including expansions. Since 4 players max is a little limited.

Played 5+ x This is a classic game. I don't think it will ever leave my collection because it's easy to teach, there are multiple strategies, it's got that great gambling sensation when you look forward to each dice roll, and it gets people involved all the time due to having to make trades.   That being said, a lot of my board gaming friends don't like Catan because they've already played too much of it or they like heavier games or they don't like themeless games.   3-5 players is the sweet spot. 6 players just takes too long.

Settlers was my gateway game.  Fun to play and with expansions like Cities and Knights, and Traders and Barbarians, it helps to stay fresh.  I don't pull it off the shelf much, but I won't turn down a game if someone suggests it.

"Колонизаторы" - одна из самых известных и самых распространённых игр среди новичков в мире настолок. Каждый ход случайным образом получаешь ресурсы (или не получаешь), строишь на них города и дороги, продаёшь ресурсы, активно взаимодействуешь с соперниками.

I think I've played Settlers out; I'll still say yes to a game because at this stage in my life I'm grateful to be playing anything, but I don't really have a desire to play this anymore. One of my gateways and I still maintain it's the best game to introduce to new gamers. I still like to play from time to time. Has a great feel, plays in a good amount of time, but I'm not chomping at the bit to play it like I used to.

Settlers of Catan fits the definition of gateway game quite well.  There is a good balance of luck and strategy.  The game can be easily taught in ~7 minutes and anyway, a new player can learn 90% of the game by just being the last player (i.e. watch the others play).  Negatives include the initial setup time and difficulty in recovering when behind (i.e. generally 1 or 2 players do really well while the rest aren't even close).
Easy game to play and pick up.  Enjoyable trading & banter aspects.  Possibly too much luck.
Every time if I have unexpirienced players I suggest to play Catan. In my opinion it's a great  gateway to board games
One of the games that got me into board games. Ironically, I don't care for it that much!

This is the game that got me started in gaming.  At the time, I would have rated it a 12 out of 10 because it was so much better than anything I'd ever played before. This being a very popular game, often referred to as a gateway game, I had high expectations for my first play. I was a little disappointed, although it is clear this is a good game. The most disappointing element is that this game is essentially Monopoly, as the rich get richer and the poor fade away. When someone isn't producing, they have no opportunity to trade and are essentially out of the game. There's little balancing there, as the only thing such players can hope for is pity. (There's no pity in this sort of game. Altruism is almost never a factor in a game unless no one is actually playing to win.) I imagine the German expansion with the helper cards (somewhat recreated in the Star Trek variant) and/or the cards that replace the dice would be a bit of an improvement, but at that point you almost have a different game. Regardless, I'll be willing to play. There's something absurdly fun about people begging for sheep.

Good game for an active and talkative group. Some strategy mixed with a healthy dose of luck, but usually not so much that it seems based on it. The dice rolls typically pan out near averages over the course of a game due to the number of rolls.   Not a lot of depth and once you have played this game a few times it will get stale as an experience. It is a very strong "gateway" game, but for people who are familiar with board games and mechanics, it will not be a very strong overall experience.  This game is definitely family friendly as well, but due to the complexity of the rules and of negotiation, it's not recommended for young children (10 and up are fine, 8-10 if they are advanced intellectually).   Games don't take too long either, although they can drag if negotiations are too frequent.   Overall, a 7, with the main faults being the level of luck and the fact that you really need an active group of players to have fun, since trading is such an integral part of the game.

Settlers of Catan is a classic board game predicated on resource trading and area control and is fun for older children. I have played it with a variety of people and would say that it is suitable for 12+. It can get a little serious for an gateway board game and I have had people lose it because they have been directly hindered by another player's actions. It is not as bad as Diplomacy, however. Further expansions such as Cities & Knights actually change the flavour of the game as opposed to adding to it.

I've been in the gaming scene long enough to know that this title is not the end all be all of gaming.  If anyone were to tell me that this was their favorite board game, I would have to ask them if they had played any other euro games.  I can't but think that anyone who had tried several titles would have to know that the genre has evolved since Catan.  Still, Catan is not completely obsolete.  It occupies a unique position in that it is light years ahead of Parker Brothers in terms of depth, but still accessible enough to be interesting to new players who are not immersed in board gaming.  This makes it valuable as a gateway game.  I still use this to introduce friends to serious board gaming.  The gameplay itself is perhaps better than people give it credit for.  The negotiations for resources are always interesting.  The biggest problem with the game comes down to how much the dice can deny unlucky players a chance to enter the game.  Good placement and smart trading can only take you so far, but I've played numerous games in which for the first several turns only three numbers were rolled.  There are house rules and expansions that help smooth out the distribution of resources, but ultimately a pig-headed group can ruin your game.  That is not an unforgivable feature of a game.  Most games are more fun with better players, but some games just do a better job of making sure the players have to really work to hold their lead.  Ultimately, I think this a title that is well worth owning.  Even though I don't really play it with my regular game group any more, I still enjoy introducing it to new players or taking it for a spin for old time's sake.  Gaming has moved on from Settlers, which may make it seem like it's gotten worse, but it's still as strong of title as it ever was.  If you don't have it, you may not need to buy it, but if you do have it, you probably shouldn't sell it.  You'll eventually be glad you still have it.  It is worth mentioning that Catan now has approximately one million expansions and more seem to come out all the time.  Perhaps they've found a way to reproduce?  At any rate, these expansions do make the game better.  However, I think this is more worthwhile as a means of extending the life of your current copy of the game than as a reason for buying the base game.  Right now, Catan with two expansions costs around $80 ($100 for a six player board).  With three you're looking at $120 ($140 for six players).  I have had fun playing with the expansions, but I don't think the experience was worth that much, especially when Archipelago is only $60 and doesn't need expansions to be awesome.

Getting resource screwed because that 8 never ever gets rolled the entire game. part of the mechanics i love and hate. I don't get mad at the robber anymore. Honest!
i used to dislike this game (probably because i sucked at it). now i kinda dig it. there's not much too it, but we enjoy ourselves when we play
The game that turned me on to proper board games. A bona fide classic I won't say no to.

Everyone's intro to modern gaming. A decent Euro game that all folks can enjoy. The art, the bits, the mechanics... everything works together towards the end goal. This is a staple of modern gaming, and while the dice rolling can really derail a game, I still hold a (perhaps nostalgic) place in my heart for SoC.
I love this game - I like building my cities and roads and creating my little empire.  Set up is rather long and there are a lot of "fiddly bits."  I do wish it had a 2 player option.  (JW)
A masterpiece. The game that started the modern Boardgaming trend (Puerto Rico and Caylus are the other 2 important ancestors). A little too abstract for me, but fun.

Needs the Helpers or get 1 gold when you don't produce a resource.  Was in a Catan regional tournament elimination about three years ago.  Had to start on 2 "6" s.  Only rolled a 6 once in the entire game - 3 Victory Points.

I'd consider myself officially graduated from Settlers of Catan. It's an amazing gateway game that just doesn't have the legs once you get introduced to other better games that are a bit more hardcore. I'd always recommend this for beginning gamers, but it doesn't last through a few play throughs. I'm glad that I have the good edition of this though because the newest version is pretty aweful. I like playing this with Cities and Knights expansion.

Played this to death many years before I even got into the hobby. Doesn't get to the table much nowadays though. Always happy to join in on a game however and will even suggest it for nostalgia's sake.  I like a balanced game of Settlers, but unfortunately not every game is balanced. Either I don't receive many resources and can hardly do anything, or I receive plenty of resources and end up feeling guilty towards the other players.  I'm not a huge fan of the 'will you trade your wool for my brick' mechanic. Many times people just don't want to trade with me (it feels like) or I feel like I ended up helping them more than myself.
I have great respect for this game, but don't play it very often any more. I bought it because I want my children to know it, not because I expect it to fill many evenings.

An amazing, well-balanced, fun game with tremendous replay value.  I don't understand why some game fiends get snobbish about not wanting to play SoC, like they're above the game, deriding it as a newb game.  It persists to this day as--by far--the best selling import, and was profoundly influential in the explosion of the hobby for a reason.  I recall vividly, how when I viewed the back of the box to decide if I would buy SoC, I became extremely excited about how the game board is rearranged every play, which launches the replayablity into orbit.  The gameplay is impacted by luck via rolling dice, but the game is a winner, regardless.  The player interaction is superb in the trading of resource cards.  A player that is close to winning will find themselves unable to negotiate trades and that is a great catch up mechanic.  The player who is close to winning will also get frequent visits from the robber as well.  I have fond memories of many stimulating Settlers games played and I look forward to more.
Good intro to hand management and route building  Jenn gives it a 9
I love this game, but no one else in my group does so I can never get it to table.
A classic game with very good mechanics.  However it does not look fresh anymore, maybe we just played it too much.
Classic, well driven by randomness, but still enoug strategy to keep it interesting. Would not say no to play, but I prefer shorter games.
Do I really need to review this. It's a classic, and I probably should have it rated higher, but I like finding new games that no one has ever heard of and that hurts Catan's ranking.
Solid, but components can break easily.

The original is still very good at what it does. This is the board game that you introduce to someone who thinks Monopoly and Clue are the sum total of what board games represent. Sit this one down in front of them, get them to try it out a few times, and then slowly introduce them to actual GAMES!  I mean, there's a renaissance out there people!  There are games on the market that create experiences you could only have if you had an actual working TARDIS: WWII battles, pursuing Jack the Ripper down a twisted branching alleyway, or defending King Arthur from a betraying errant knight. I marvel at the current artistry of the Golden Age of game design. We truly live in interesting times.  You know what? Don't play this game with people who've only ever played YHATZEE and BUNKO. Screw 'em!  If they've limited their experience of game mechanics to the intricacies of Chutes and Ladders, then this game is too good for 'em! They're in the Dark ages (which is a great expansion for Dominion, by the way). Let those people go. You can't save them. They're weighing you down. Cut the rope.  Move on.
Still a noob; so far, I like it!
My first game I got besides basic's like monopoly. I think it is a good game which would play much better with the sea expansion.

It's a classic for a reason. Probably most people's introduction to real games, and it's still cute when a friend will tell me, "I've played this game, you might not have heard of it... it's called Settlers of Catan". Aww.
