It's done a great service by introducing more people to our hobby, but I think that the randomness (HOW CAN 2 BE ROLLED FOUR CONSECUTIVE TURNS?!) limits its ability to be higher. The lack of catch-up makes the end game fairly predictable, and the negotiations are pretty simple. But still, if someone is excited about it I'll happily play, but only as a vehicle to open them up to more exciting games.
Base game meh, with Seafarers easy 9.
It was a great gateway, I can't see playing it much anymore, but it is the reason I fell in love.
I tend to favor the 5 and 9 hexes a lot harder than the 6 and 8 hexes, but hey, I gotta be me.

This game is fine, mostly because most people have now heard of it. The downside is that it relies so much on the dice--and Robber becomes massively frustrating later in the game. We have had to house-rule it to make it more enjoyable.
Expansions: Seafarers, Cities & Knights, 5-6 Player expansion for base game and both expansions.

Shadow likes the game just fine but since it's best with more players and Rogue wasn't keen on it, we weren't getting it to the table and so we traded it (7/10)  Rogue burned out on Catan and was surprised to find that a 5-year layoff didn't really improve his mood. Rogue doesn't think the mechanics have aged particularly well. (4/10)

Catan (or Settlers of Catan as I will always remember it), is a good game. It holds up by having a very timeless quality to it. People can approach the game having never played anything like it, and they will quickly be able to understand and embrace its gameplay because it has a combination of elements that are at once familiar, but also unique in how the game presents them.   Nowadays, I find that the game doesn't fit any sort of niche that satisfies what I look for a in a game. It's too random for when I'm wanting a satisfying strategic experience; it's too casual for when I'm wanting to get engrossed in a game; and yet it usually takes too long for a game I would like to play casually.   I think Catan is the archetypal "gateway game", in that, I would only ever play it when using it as such (and know it would thrive being played in that capacity), but I have no real desire to ever play it of my own volition.

My chosen infection vector when introducing people to board games. Played it at my first family game night in ages and everyone perked up and wants to play it again.  Personally, I can't wait to play it with them :D
A classic.  Got me back into board games.
Great mechanics and good introduction game. Ideally needs the map to be randomised and then "fixed" though.

This game got me into the Euro-game hobby!  I love Settlers because of the modular board and the strategies that it provided.  With expansions, there are soooo many different scenarios to play - my favourite is exploring hidden areas.  I would say that setting up this game for me is almost as fun as playing the game.

The classic Euro which got half of my generation into board gaming, I guess (I'm from Germany).  I still really love it, although now that I'm a long time gamer it is a bit too luck based for me by now. But still: A classic, great family board game, good gateway.

The game that got me started! I've played more games of catan than I care to count. And Xbox live has an awesome version of Catan that I've played to death, also.  Update: Trying playing it recently. Anti-climactic. It felt so rudimentary compared to what I'm used to. It may just be that Catan has a shelf life.

The classic gateway game imo. This game got me truly invested into wanting to experience more strategy games. I owe it a lot.  However this game became to repetitive.  Due to the reliance on luck, I have really become turned off by this game. From someone that had most of his strategy based on the social game, it became to common of an occurrence for luck to run the game. I won the first 11 times I played, then would win every other for awhile until I hit a point where I would win like a normal human.   I really have just played this game too much and have lost interest in the strategy. Great game to get you into strategy gaming, just hard to play consistently once you find others.
First worker placement ever played with my boys, along with Carcassonne. Brilliant.

Solid game. The randomly generated board helps to keep it fresh. Not hard to teach, and the constant trading means you're not sitting in silence while you play (looking at you, Dominion). But seasoned players will always win, so go easy on the newbies.

Still a fun game after so many years in print. Great negotiation game for introducing new people to "modern" games. I wish it was not so reliant on opening setup, and it can be far too random. Very accessible, though, and one that will be staying on my shelf.
Classic. And fun, despite the general hate it gets.

My first proper board game (who would have guessed). Classic, fun to break out every once in a while, but the base game is quite dry after so many plays. Usually, winners are decided by 1) the initial placement or 2) unpredictable dice rolls. There are those few games where a particularly clever player whips out a combo of moves to rocket to 10 points unexpectedly, but usually the winner is quite clear early on.
Wedding gift! As a gaming couple we had to have a copy of this game! I think it's the law!
Fun but there are other games I would rather play. This is definitely a game I would play with my family before playing with my gaming buddies.
Boring theme but nice family trading game. wood 4 sheep.

Settlers of Catan was the game that launched me into the hobby of gaming.  I found the ability to be strategic so refreshing over classic games yet there was still that familiar mechanic of dice rolling that brought along with it the factor of luck.  Its variable modular board does create a new start setup every time but the feel of the game play does not vary after the initial start phase.  The start phase is so crucial to how well you will do in the game depending on your ability to follow through on your initial plans, which I believe takes a little away from Catan.  I've found myself not wanting to play this game over and over as I originally did but am eternally thankful to it for giving me a new hobby.

This game is quite interesting. I'd probably pick up the seafarers expansion, but those no-goodies that publish it decided to parse out the 5-6 player expansions for each expansion, so, they get not a dime more from me unless they decide to skip the cash grab and just let me buy the once.

I realized the reason why Catan is so great is that your settlements and cities reach their ideal productive capacity right as the game is ending.  That feeling of getting 3 Ore in a turn, or 4 resources overall - it feels really good, and you want to have it again, so you play again.  I feel like it's hip to badmouth Catan and it wouldn't be my first, fifth, or even tenth choice to play were it my option, but I've played it live more than any other game; it's held up pretty well.  EDIT 11/17 - I'd like to lower my rating of Catan, but it's me that's changed and not the game - I've just played it too many times.

This game is perfect for a game night: simple to learn, little waiting times between player turns and finished quickly. For individual games it may be difficult to come back from a bad start but there is always time for a re-match. During a memorable vacation with friends, I lost the first seven games but came back and won three in a row.   Pros: Simple rules, all players participate to the end, short game sessions Cons: Chance important for outcome, difficult to get back from bad start  Reviewed at https://boardgamegeek.com/thread/2033271/revisiting-favorite-island-past.

Often considered by many to be the gateway game into modern boardgaming, Catan shines through interaction with other players. Simple mechanics make for an easy to understand game, although more players are required to truly enjoy it. With games lasting up to 90 minutes, interest can begin to wane, especially if one player is clearly dominating.   Despite having set up the game a few times, we've yet to actually complete a full game. Although it's supposed to be a gateway game, I'm still not certain on a few of the rules, which is a bit frustrating.
Really. What can I possibly say about Catan that hasn't been said hundreds of times before, and more eloquently than I could ever...
Light, gets boring, family friendly (with no poor losers!), randomness.

One of my first hobby games. Played it all the time years ago, however have not touched it in a long time. I am in the group that prefers Cities and Knights, and I will not play without that expansion.

Great gateway to board games. One of the classics. Every board game enthusiast should have a copy of these. Is not the best game in the world (for some people at least), but it introduces people to the hobby, it is good game for families, and never get old. I recommend this game for everybody.

The game that got me into modern designer board gaming.  Unfortunately, it hasn't aged well with my tastes.  I won't turn down a game if that is what people are looking to play, but I usually will try to steer them in the direction of a game I feel is better in the hopes of expanding their board game experiences. - 10/13/18
I have played this game. One of the firsts.
Not a bad game, overall. I can see the appeal, especially when placed into the context of what else was available when it came out.
Great gateway game, but there's simply no reason to play this as so many other games do it better- still, it's worth keeping to introduce folks to gaming.
Not a bad game but can get rather repetitive.

Settlers of Catan with either the Cities and Knights expansion or the Helpers of Catan expansion is one of our all-time favorites; either bumps the rating up a notch. (Note that Star Trek Catan is the same game but with different theme AND the Helpers of Catan included.)

I have been playing euro games and war games and the like for years now and last night was my first time playing catan and I was pleasantly surprised. I thought the random dice mechanic would make it hard to play (I played Spacefarers of catan and did not like it at all). I can see why this is such a great gateway game and I should get a copy just for that reason.
Fun family friendly game that can require a bit of strategy. I wish I could say I won most because of my epic play ability, but no.

Eh, what can I say about Settlers that hasn't already been said?  It's Settlers.  Basically what it is good for is determining how relatively new to board gaming a person is based on how recently they played their first game of it...

My cousin taught me this game at a family reunion.  His enthusiasm (and the great game itself) inspired me to teach other Catan ever since then, with the same enjoyment that I experienced from my cousin.  I try to teach as many people this game as I can!
An absolute classic. It is fun and it is probably the best game to introduce non-gamers to the hobby. Like it, but need money. Sold

I know this game has a reputation of being a classic gateway game and an intro to Euro games, but it's never been my favorite. I like the negotiation and player interaction, but it just doesn't hit the table much. I'll play it and enjoy myself, but it just doesn't tend to be a game I suggest. It's a favorite for my husband and youngest son though. Purchased from a FLTS.
A classic. Over 20 years old now, but I still enjoy it.
This is what started it all for me. I haven't played it in years now since I found games I like better.  It will still hold a special place in my heart and I would love to play it soon again.

My introduction to modern board games. After 100+ plays, I don't enjoy it as much as I used to. Still enjoy playing it once in a while with friends who are more casual board game players. It's also one of the few euro-games that my parents enjoy.

It's just a classic and one of the first real board games I tried. It's still greatly entertaining. A personal note: The game in its core does NOT support 4 players! There is simply not room enough on the island, and one or two players are sure to get cornered and have a really long and boring game. DON'T play with 4 players!
Good game, but can take a long time if dice not rolled to get right resource.

At first this game was, in my mind, a 10 Perfect Score. But after hundreds of games in person and on the mobile app you begin to realize that the game is basically 75-80% luck and the strategy really relies on the 1st move of the game.   After the 1st and 2nd move you basically watch as the game plays you.   Still a great game though but look for even better games.

Catan does something that no other board game does for me, and that's mixing player interaction with individual turns well. Of course it might feel like there's downtime sometimes when people aren't trading, but I don't feel bored when I play like some games with individual turns do. I like Catan, but I like lots of other games better.

Ah Catan, a fantastic intro to Euro board games game, which I played far, FAR too much in high school. Definitely a good game, tight rules, and a fair amount of strategy, but gets old after a while. If you need a game for friends to start to play after Risk, Monopoly, Scrabble, you can't go wrong with Catan.

Great game! Very easy to learn and pick up. Strategic nonetheless! Settlers of Catan was my gateway game.  The only reason why I don't want to give it a 10 is because it's pretty easy to tell who is going to win the game about 7 or so rounds in. You can snowball very easily in this game, however the incorporation of the crippling "7" roll can definitely balance things about. Plus, development cards can become VERY useful, depending on the timing.  What's nice is there is some variability from game to game. You will never have the same game twice. Replay-ability is definitely HIGH.  I would give this game a 9 if there were some way to buy resources from other players, much like in 7 Wonders. I don't want to talk too much about the mechanics, but you get the point.
My intro to modern strategy games. Catan I will always be in your debt. Still up for a good game any time. Prefer the Seafarers expansion.
Good as one of the first games that makes you wonder what else there is.

This is easily the best board game of all time, in my opinion.  It hits on all the high notes for me: easy to play, fast, interactive, replayable, etc.  It fires on all 8 cylinders, and I've only met 1 person ever who didn't like it.  Anyone who gives this game less than a 6 is a troll.  Yeah, I said it!  UPDATE:  For the longest time I refused to admit this game is not a 10.  While I do still like playing this game, and while I still strongly recommend it to people interested in gaming...  I just have little desire to bring it to the table anymore.  Initially I thought this was just due to burn out, but I have finally realized it's because it's just not compelling enough and there is a lot more competition from better games.  Sadly, I have dropped this to a 7.
9 years after my first Euro game, I've finally played Catan.  I can see how it is the progenitor of all of the games I've played.  Simple and fun!
3-4 players (up to 6 with extension) Have it on IOS

Essentially a Monopoly reboot. Or maybe it is better described as Monopoly repackaged? Put it this way, if you like Monopoly, you will probably like Catan. It's a fun game, but can become a bit boring after awhile. In my experience it is not quite as rage inducing as Monopoly though ;)

Still a great game after all these years.  I play just the base game with the fishermen and harbormaster.  Keeps it short, and the little expansions open up the outside of the board.  I only play 4 player and only with people who are willing to wheel and deal .  Otherwise this stays on the shelf.  PS: NEVER PLAY THIS 5/6 PLAYER
Sometimes based too much on luck.

Just a classic, people in my board game group will always want to play this if someone mentions it.  Update 12/30/14: I've now played this game for what feels like 50 times. I really enjoyed it at first, but now I'm sick of it. I've lowered its rating due to its dullness now (the C&K expansion actually has a higher rating from myself). It still has a special place in my heart though.
Not my first pick anymore, and there are better gateway games, but I still enjoy it. This has seen a lot of plays, so nostalgia points.

Easy to teach, almost universally known, great gateway game, good to get new people to gaming, relies on strategy without making it too hard on casual gamers, mechanisms have become classic, good player interaction without much obvious combat, variety of different approaches can lead to victory. For more-than-casual gamers not deep enough and too luck-dependent.

This and Dominion were my two gateway games to modern board gaming.  I've been playing for a few years (Currently haven't played since I started on BGG and keeping track of plays) so I've cooled on it some as I discover more games.

Good: -Trading -Lots of player interaction -Borderline gateway game -Easy to understand and execute strategies -Cheering for die rolls  Bad: -Waiting on rolls -Balance issues (city strategies are too good) -Encourages mean-spirited play -A little long for what it is -Starting villages typically determines who will win  Overall: The player interaction that comes from trading adds a lot of interaction and seems to be the main selling point.  But trading slows the game down and gives savy players an even bigger advantage.  This was one of the best gateway games when it came out and holds a special place in my heart but I now struggle to find a reason to play it.  It's not deep enough for play with hobbyists, not a top-tier family weight game, and not ideal for introducing the hobby.  While I definitely got my moneys worth, it will be collecting dust for the foreseable future.
My first game of the new era. Still love it. Wife love it as well. A classic and a keeper for us.

The game that started it all for me as it did for most people out there. I've lost count of how many times I've played SoC despite not having them logged here especially through the Sea3D website/app which was eventually closed down. Had a few cut-throat matches in the past which made me dislike the game somewhat, not to be played with the wrong crowd.
A great game to introduce people to board games and how awesome they can be!!! Worth the purchase as it is always good for a  replay. A classic worth having in your collection!

Catan is good for beginners, gateway game etc.   The more experienced gamers start to get put off by it for the simple reason that too much of the mechanic is put down to luck. It's just a fact that too much of the time people who should have won don't and those who aren't so hot can get very lucky. Therefore, it's kind of like a slot machine at a casino if you get a group of competent gamers playing each other, i.e. it boils down to a gambling, uncontrolled game of sorts.     Oops forgot one final point. .. It's not that fun after a while...it's just kinda there chugging away....meh
Still a fun game, after all these years. However, there are so many other games that do it all so much better.
4 Player (3-4) Depth-⭐️⭐️ Components-⭐️⭐️⭐️ Art-⭐️⭐️ Theme-⭐️⭐️ Replayability-⭐️⭐️⭐️  Traded Because: Wife doesn’t like it

My gateway game. My favorite game to play on my phone. So many feels happen over this game. I like all the emotions brought on by this game. After turn 1 of placing your first settlement thinking...damn I'm screwed.
A great gateway to a lovely cardboard addiction.

Area control; Dice rolling; Hand management; Modular board; Route building; Trading; Players gain resources when dice are rolled at the start of each player's turn. During active player's turn, they perform as many actions as their resources allow them to. Race to 10 victory points.
My introduction to Eurogames in college (~2004)...will always have a soft spot for me.
Needs another route to victory if you get cut off early on. Maybe a tweak to ports.
The game that got e into games.  Thanks Daniel!
Yes a classic and yes lots of luck.  Was one of the gateways for me too and obviously for most of the world but in hindsight I am not sure why? Maybe the luck is what is familiar with the past games?
This is where all started.  (Besides risk and monopoly)
I love flipping the tiles over to add the exploration aspect to the game.
Great game, until everyone decides that they hate each other and no longer want to trade...and then the game becomes unnecessarily long.

Great and fun to play, but with some flaws: -No fixed number of turns,when the players are trying to screw each other the game can last a long time. -The trading with other players, while fundamental, can lead to kingmaking- "I don't want him to play so I'll give you all my resources so you can win first." -It is possible to spend time getting annoyed by the everyone but you collecting resources, and the robber seemingly spending its entire time on your tiles.  Having said that, the game is still fun to play, but I prefer to play similar, more modern games that are annoying less of the time.
Rating 8.5 together with Cities and Knights.
Good game, but I think that there are better games now.  The theme and artwork are also lacking compared to some more modern games.
A classic - I still enjoy playing it; shh
The game that started my on this amazing hobby!
Kinda boring... it gets a good score for getting me into more economic board games instead of purely war games... but it plays out pretty quick.
Great gateway Euro.  It's hard to say no if someone wants to play it. There is a nice balance of luck and strategy here.
Lots of fun, a classic now
I'll never forget the game night back in 2003 when we were sitting down for a game of Axis and Allies and someone pulled this game out. Changed everything.
This is the game that got my wife and I into Strategy board games

Catan is really good at destroying friendships forever, the hallmark of a good game.  I can't say anything good about it that hasn't been said before, so I'll say something bad about it instead.  The one thing I don't like about Catan is that I find it a little too easy to get an early lead from mean positioning of my initial roads, etc., which basically subtly screws over other players for the entirety of the rest of the game.

Have yet to come across a game with cleaner mechanics. Very well rounded game, but personally prefer the Seafarers expansion. The amount it adds to the game is just too fulfilling to let go of and go back to playing the Base version.
Classic. Still fun every once and a while.
Great gateway game and I'm still willing to admit it's a good game even after playing more 'hardcore' games. Dropped from 8 to 7 cause I prefer Star Trek Catan.
Good game, I'm thinking i'll only play it with 3 players.
Great, simple family game. A classic game.
Fun game. Well designed. What more can be said?
Box is worn with dings and one small cut on edge.

made my first polymer chibi for this game for the robber pawn. What prevents more plays of this is the lack of a 3rd player regularly for us. We have played the game using a 2 player variant, but I found it confusing as to which color I was playing at what time.

I won a copy from ye olde Arcane magazine contest around 1996, so I've had one for almost twenty years. It seems now it was the game that started the revolution of dropping Monopoly off the kitchen tables and putting something much more fun in place.  The kids like it, I'd probably like it more if I'd get to play it with adults :-)
Loved this classic! As Carcassonne, I think a well made collection must have it!
I started out hating this game.  Over time, I have come to love it.  I just can't get my gaming group to play it much lol.
Good classic. Better with Cities and Knights. I still don't know how the ships are supposed to move in Seafarers but it was a cool idea.

Don't get me wrong, I have mad respect for this game having ignited the designer game revolution in the US.  :cool:  It's not quite as good as the hype and it feels a little dated at this point, but it is still a solid game.  It works great as a family game if you're into competitive trading games (which I'm not).  If I'm going to play a game about colonialism, I'm going to play Concordia - it's a far superior game in every way.  ;)

I won't let my husband get rid of this game, even though we rarely play it.  It's not my favorite. It seems the dice are never with me. Or they are, and they are killing someone else so much that it makes me feel bad.  But, like a lot of people, this was the game that introduced me to modern board games.  Because of that, it's one our friends who don't really game are always willing to play.
What can be said that hasn’t been said before? A great game that has stood the test of time and great fun with friends!
Well, well, well. The classic boardgame everyone knows, so it is not necessary say anything.
Still one of the best introductory games. It also has many expansions and different versions which provide some intresting twists on the experience.
One of my go-to games for pretty much any group of people, regardless of skill and age

Incluye expansion 5~6 jugadores. Revendido por V.Karku  Los jugadores ya avezados lo encontraran quiza con "poca chicha", pero yo lo considero un buen juego para iniciarse en las mecanicas de los "modernos" juegos de mesa. facil de comprender y apto para todos los publicos.   En mi opinion destacan las fases de negociacion. esos "oveja por ladrillo?"..."dos ovejas por ladrillo?" son ya un clasico del mundillo.   Las expansiones le vienen bien para "darle vidilla" y mejorar versatilidad (el original solo admite 3 o 4 jugadores).  de hecho ese es en mi opinion el principal defecto del juego: que se creó inicialmente para 3-4 (y SOLO 3-4) jugadores, luego fue expandido y DESPUES DE ESO fue cuando salió la expansión para adaptarlo a 5-6 jugadores... mas luego las expansiones para adaptar las expansiones existentes a 5-6 jugadores. un desperre y un caos.   quisieron evitar vender un nuevo juego base con el que las expansiones antiguas no fueran compatibles y en mi opinion fue peor el remedio que la enfermedad. :/

Igazi klasszikus. A Catan esetében a szabályok elsajátítására, tanulmányozására nem kell napokat áldozni az életünkből. De még órákat sem. Ez nem jelenti, hogy nem lehetnek vitás kérdések. :D Elég könnyen átlátható akár már első próbálkozásra. Lássuk be, rendkívül nagy a szerencse szerepe ebben a játékban is. Hiába próbálunk úgy helyezkedni, hogy a könnyebben kidobható számokat tartalmazó mezőkkel érintkezzen a településünk, városunk, ha utána mégis ritkán jönnek elő azok a számok. Szerencsére azért ez nem egy felturbózott szerencsejáték csupán. A kereskedéssel meg kell próbálni a céljaink eléréséhez nélkülözhetetlen nyersanyagok beszerzését. Ez jó kis interakciót biztosít a játékostársak között. A győzelemhez szükséges 10 pontot meg egyáltalán nem olyan könnyű elérni. Az tetszik a Catanban, hogy ha egy család úgy dönt, hogy csak az alapjátékot veszi meg, akkor is rengetegszer újra játszható a társas, mert a területlapkák elhelyezése szabadon variálható, meg persze az azokon szereplő számok is. Ez is olyan játék, ahol több úton is el lehet jutni a győzelemhez. Van, aki csak a települések, városok építésére áll rá, van aki a fejlesztési kártyákat gyűjti, van, aki mindenféleképpen birtokolni szeretné a leghosszabb út címét, stb. Ráadásul nagyon hangulatosak az illusztrációk. Nekünk már a műanyag figurás változat van meg, de nem érzem gagyinak ezt sem. Biztosan más érzés fabábukkal játszani, de nekem ezzel sincs gondom, itt legalább részletesebb egy-egy elem kidolgozása. Azért 4 fővel ez sem a legrövidebb játék, mind a két menet kb. másfél óra volt. Egyébként az, hogy minden egyes dobásnál figyelsz, hogy kapsz-e nyersanyagot, minimálisra csökkenti az üresjáratot két köröd között. Persze előfordulnak olyan szerencsétlen szériák, hogy akár két teljes kör is végig megy, te meg csak ülsz és szomorúan nézed az egy szál erőforrásodat a kezedben, ami sehogyan sem képes az osztódással szaporodásra.

One of my all time favorites. It was my gateway into Euro games, so holds a special sentimental value. I know that there are better Euro style games available, but I still enjoy the one that started it for me.
Far from a favourite; but I tolerate it and don't mind playing
Same as TtR, great gateway game to boardgames
game that i bought coz its well known and gateway for some ppl... too luck dependant but somehow my game group still like it.
Nice gateway game to other similar games.
This was the first non-cranium style board game that I ever played and it was definitely a gateway drug for game addiction!
Classic game that perhaps would be rated higher if I was rating this 10 years ago. While it hasn't hit the table in quite some time, I'll never forget this game that opened me to the hobby.

If ticket to is the perfect gateway game for people who likes playing quietly and draw cards, this is the perfect gateway for people who prefer to interact with people and don't mind a little of randomness.
This game got me into gaming.
Like many others, this was our gateway game and will always have a place in our hearts.
A wonderful game that has good reason to stand the test of time. Wonderful game.

The first game I played. It's easy to learn, and there is a lot of strategy to it. I recommend this to people getting into gaming, but I don't care if I play it any more. It was played, and enjoyed, a LOT!
Wish I could find more people who want to play this. Also, Seafarers expansion for Star Trek-Catan would be nice.
We introduced Settlers of Catan to my inlaws and they loved it.

Colonizadores de Catan foi o primeiro jogo mais "avançado" que eu conheci depois dos populares. A premissa é simples: construa seus vilarejos em junções de terrenos e ganhe os recursos daqueles terrenos caso os dados colaborem. Parece muito dependente de sorte mas, acreditem, a estratégia pode fazer bastante diferença. Recomendo muito para quem começar a conhecer este mundo.
I look forward to playing this with a deck of dice and seeing if that feels better.
I love this classic, but my group dislikes the randomness of rolling for resources.

PL: Dosyć ciekawa pozycja, rozgrywka inna za każdym razem ze względu na plansze podzieloną na pola. Chętnie zagram ponownie.  EN: Quite an interesting position, the game differs every time because of the board divided into hexagonal fields. I am willing to play it again.
I played this game once a week for a few months while living in Munich. It is an outstanding game of trade, strategy, and banter.   It showed me a world outside Monopoly.
The game that started it all.  This game is the gate-way game for board game obsessions around the world.

The game that got me into gaming. Its a great solid euro, that has proven its own worth through the test of time. Still play it every now and then, and even though i dont enjoy it as much as i use to because ive burnt it out, its still a fun play.

[b]Dad - ~2002 Gifted away the newer copy my dad gave me to my brother-in-law; kept the old[/b]   [u][b]My history with Catan[/b][/u] Since my dad passed away my mother has been slowly trying to clean up the house.  I was helping her out in the guest room where the games were stored and she offered the Catan games to me.  Those games are important to me for a couple reasons.  [b]1.[/b] Catan is the "gateway" game that got me into gaming and...  [b]2.[/b] It's the game that reminds me most of my dad who has since passed away and introduced me to the game.  We had [i]many[/i] game plays with these copies with friends and family.  It also includes handwritten notes/summaries of different games we've had, along with a stupid plastic trophy we got out of a grab bag at [url=http://www.mclintocks.com/]F.McLintocks[/url] on a vacation to Morro Bay.    Not an absolute favorite game, but one I will ALWAYS come back to for those reasons.  We like to randomize the layout of the tiles and the layout of the numbers (for the dice rolls).  This game is important to me because is was my "gateway" game that got me into gaming.  It's also the game that reminds me most of my dad who has since passed away.  Not a favorite game, but one I will ALWAYS come back to for those reasons.  I'm not sure how it happened, but we call the robber the Buddha-bum.  I think my dad started this because he never could remember to call him the robber.  Anyhow, it stuck and we still call it that.  We also have added a cheap dollar-store trophy that goes to the Victor of Catan.  [b]Expansions owned:[/b] - [geekurl=/boardgameexpansion/2807/catan-5-6-player-extension][i]5-6 Player Extension][/i][/geekurl] - [geekurl=/boardgameexpansion/926/catan-cities-knights][i]Cities & Knights[/i][/geekurl] --- [geekurl=/boardgameexpansion/4101/catan-cities-knights-5-6-player-extension][i]5-6 Player Extension[/i][/geekurl] Fun expansion with pirates.  One could easily get blocked out of getting troops/wheat.  If this happens when the pirates land and you're not helping protect the island you lose a city.  I've found if I lose my cities, I lose the game. - [geekurl=/boardgameexpansion/325/catan-seafarers][i]Seafarers[/i][/geekurl] --- [geekurl=/boardgameexpansion/4103/catan-seafarers-5-6-player-extension][i]5-6 Player Extension[/i][/geekurl] - [geekurl=/boardgameexpansion/27760/catan-traders-barbarians][i]Traders & Barbarians[/i][/geekurl] [-]- [geekurl=/boardgame/3972/catan-portable-edition][i]Portable Edition[/i][/geekurl] - Just like the base game, but with peg-like components so that it could be played while traveling, etc.[/-] [i]traded away at KublaCon 2016[/i]
The game mechanics are mildly interesting at best but the metagame makes it great: encourage table talk, make side deals, play opponents off each other and weasel your way to victory.
This is the one that started it al for me. No need for an explanation if you're on this site. Watch out for the robber and be nice to other players by trading with them.
My first boardgame. Has sentimental value for me

[December 2014 - 7] The gateway game. Like many, it was one of the first few games I played to get into the hobby. I enjoy it, but the trading and the dice-rolling luck ultimately play too big of a role in the game. Especially with the dice, if your numbers aren't coming up, it means your opponents' numbers likely are, so its sort of double whammy and the gap between the leaders and losers widens (I have the same complaint about Machi Koro). You'd think the trading might balance that, but if you have nothing to trade, because your numbers aren't coming up, then you're out of luck there, too. Meanwhile the leaders can trade and widen the gap. All that wouldn't be so bad if it were a shorter game, but it's a little lengthy.
This game is fun but we rarely play it.
Det er altså et godt EU-spil i den lette ende.
Fun game to play as a gateway to more complicated things. Easy to teach. I tend to play nice, and haven't quite moved beyond the longest road strategy.

Classic gateway game. Easy to play and teach, can be very cut throat depending on your gaming party. Overall I find it to be a somewhat casual game that doesn't involve tremendous strategy. This game has been known to ruin friendships so be mindful of who you play this with.
What can be said about this one that hasn't already?  It's a modern classic and it's helped pave the way for gaming to be brought into the mainstream.  Not to mention, it's damn fun.

This was the game that got me into board gaming almost three years ago. It doesn't come off of the shelf often simply because of the play time. The number of hours it takes varies heavily by who you play it with (if drinking is involved, you're gonna be there for a while...) and if you dare to go all the way up to the 6-player count. Regardless, it's still a fun game, but at least for me I think it's fine as is and I probably won't expand.
Gaming magic. Sometimes susceptible to bad luck though.
3-4 only, 5-6 expansion makes the game way too long
I enjoy this game even though for many it's lost its appeal. It's still pretty new to me so I'm happy to play it, or its variants, whenever.
The game that really started it all for me. Played a lot in college but haven't played it much since, generally because the 3 player requirement. Would like to get back into playing it though.
The dice rolling drives me up the wall. As does the area control aspect of it.
Modern classic that like Ticket to Ride, it might not be the most exciting game in the world, but there's no denying that it works.
Still a game I enjoy, even after being balls deep in the hobby for a couple of years.
In my opinion, overrated. Overemphasis on lucky dice results. Simple enough to teach to non-gamers, however.
Classic; accessible but nice balance of skill and luck
In general, I like the feel of this game and don't mind playing with the kids or adults with alcohol, but the trading aspect never sits well with me.

A good game. However, the starting phase is a huge drag and often the table will go silent as everyone goes through the boring moves of slowly collecting resources. It takes forever to get the ball rolling. By the time the game has some momentum, people are sometimes already exhausted from the tedious ramp-up phase. Once you're there, however, the game is fun, challenging and exciting.
Used to play this quite a bit and would like to find group to pick up again to play as one of few hubby plays as well

The game that opened my eyes to the fact that board games can be something truly special. I love the way the board looks, its a lush island with resources everywhere, in fact, I've used the board as a map for roleplaying, it works quite well. Anyway, my only quibbles are that the game can be quite boring if your die rolls never come up. I've played games where I maybe got my number 2 or 3 times. Fortunately, the game doesn't last very long....except for that one three hour 6 player game. That was brutal.   2019 update, I am dropping the score because the game doesn't hold up as well after playing so many other games.
Best with 4 players Recommended with 3, 4 players

[WrenniePennie's copy] The title that got me back into board gaming, and is very much like comfort food for me. Some of the mechanics that encourage resource hoarding seem antiquated and unbalanced nowadays, and the dice rolling, in hindsight, causes strategic placement and luck to crash rather than flow together, making resource-generating a frustrating affair for some members of the game. However, the random generation of land masses, building, and competitive factor in trading still make this one fun to play.

The grandaddy of our collection; my brother in law Jeremy taught this to us during a visit to Maine in the winter of 2004-2005. We fell in love with it and bought it, and the play count here is not accurate... Its just most of our plays of Catan happened long before I discovered BGG.
Probably still my most-played game of all time, and I can have a blast with the right group. Sure, it shows its age, but it'll always have a place on my shelf.
Probably has a strong sweet spot at exactly four players.
A solid game but it rarely hits the table because of the 3-4 player count. Most of my gaming is just me and my wife.

Much like Carcassonne, showed me a way back to table gaming via Euros, after getting burned in high school by HeroQuest (which is great, I know, but not my style at all). I love Catan, though it's not gonna get much past 8 because sloppy board setup can make for some drag-out boring games.

My wife had never played this one before, so we got a copy and we've been playing this classic a couple of times. I still enjoy it every time I play. Sure, there are probably a bunch of better games out there nowadays, that doesn't stop me from liking this classic.

I didn't know this game was only 20 years old, it's a definite classic. An exciting and strategic game of resource gathering and trading. Another great "ice-breaker" game for beginners and a lot of fun.

This is a big hit with my non-gamer friends. That alone is enough for me to want to play it. The initial setup was a little confusing and some rules we had to keep looking up. But resources coming out for everyone and especially the trading interaction keeps everyone enthusiatically engaged with little downtime for players waiting their turn.

Played a bunch.  Lives up to its reputation.  UPDATE: Not a fan of playing with the player expansions.  Games take extremely long and AP makes them unbearable.  Still a great game, but I prefer them with 3-4 people.

Can't be bothered reviewing this one.  It's a good game.  People like it.  I like it.  I get tired of it.  But then I play it again and enjoy it again.   It's an enjoyable standard.  A gateway for new gamers.  And that's a good thing.  Cause the more people who have an enjoyable first gaming experience, the more people I can rope into playing BETTER games!
Still a good game after 20 years...

The game that started it all...  Played with friends from the JAM (Jesus and Me) youth ministry at Grace Church in Eden Prairie, MN back in 2002 or 2003.  Great game with many innovations-variable set-up, negotiation during another player's turn, etc.

It seems a children's game, but there are interesting negotiations between the players and strategy to cut off the other player's development to get a bigger one for yourself. Not a long time cosumer game, it gives you fun in the winter's cold evenings... or hot summertime.

Catan is a good game that has been around forever.  I've only played the Star Trek version in real life (which I didn't really dig) but played the app on my phone a LOT when I was first getting into board games.  I can see why it is so popular but I feel that in recent years there are many games that offer more in theme and gameplay.  One I wouldn't mind owning just because it seems I should, but not one I really think, I would like to play a game of Catan right now.
One of the first games I owned. It's a fun game, but a little to luck based for me. Also, players can really shut someone down pretty easily.

The board game I've played most - over 50 online games, and over 25 in person, with 7 in one day once. I don't think it is as great with the expansion for 6, and I dislike the seafarers expansion.   I've played this successfully as a teams game with the following rules:  - sit across from each other - cannot trade more than 1 resource on your turn to your teammate  - each player needs to score 10 - can share 1 point from longest road or largest army with teammate for victory points It reduces the trading aspect of the game, but adds a fun layer of backstabbery strategy.
Yay trading. Yay building. Easy to learn, easy to play. It's a lot of peoples gateway game for a reason.
Completely replaced by Concordia. Still a great game to introduce to those new to board games.

Didn't know people still played adult board games, until I listened to a Mark Arum radio call-in show one night about, "What is your favorite board game?" One of the callers mentioned Catan, so we bought it and started playing board games again.
My first "real" game. Still fun. You can get shut out in the beginning if unlucky, which makes the game unbearable. A bit to much luck involved.

This game basically got me into modern board gaming.  Once I started playing, I couldn't stop.  It's simple and addictive.  However, after having gotten into board games and having played many others, Catan doesn't quite hold up.  First off, there's too much luck involved.  This can overcome with good building placement, but there are some games where 6 or 8 (the numbers that should come up more often when rolling 2 die) just never come up but 3s or 10s come up over and over again, rewarding the lucky player who just happened to chose those resource hexes with an easy victory.  Bottom line is: if your numbers aren't rolled, you lose.  And the game gets very frustrating and/or boring when you're hopelessly losing since the better you're doing, the easier it is to do even better.  I recommend new gamers give this a try.  It's fun and will get you into gaming.  Then, to add some complexity and replay value, get some of the expansions.  The Cities & Knights expansion makes the game great by adding the needed complexity.  Explorers & Pirates is also really fun, though it basically makes it into a different game. I've never been a big fan of Seafarers, it doesn't really add a whole lot in my opinion like the other expansions do.  Traders & Barbarians, in my opinion, is the best at fixing the original game without changing too much.  Some of the additions (especially fish and the cards instead of dice additions) really make the game less about luck and more about strategy.    Catan is not my favorite game, but I keep comping back to it.  It holds a special place in my heart I guess.  It's worth playing for sure.
I am glad that this was not my 'gateway' - it is a good game, but not one i desire to play (most of the time)
A classic game that can be made or broken on chance (die roll). Some games it's a lot of fun,and in others you just want to end the game quickly.
Enjoyable and easy, the game that started my board gaming journey
My first "proper" board game, Monopoly does not count :) I have played lots and lots of games even though they are not logged, because I have started logging games just recently.
My first contemporary board game, not played this much but is growing on me.

My first real game, and it holds up reasonably well. Dice can be frustrating but it's not really about the dice. It's mostly a bargaining game. The board itself is relatively straightforward to figure out where to be aiming for, you just have to hope the numbers you need come up or barring that you can convince someone to give you what you need.
Still a good game, perhaps because I haven't played it to death yet ^^

Hard to rank this one.  It's a classic, but such a popular game that it has now been trumped by it's progeny a dozen times over.  Still fun to play, but I rarely take it off the shelf when I can play Terra Mystica, Deus, or Barony.
Fantastic introductory game to have in the collection.
Still a great intro euro.  A perfect game to play to try to bring people into the hobby.

Gift from CA  The game that sat unopened for a long time, then engaged our family, sent me looking online for expansion reviews, and led to me discovering Carcassonne, Love Letter, Uwe Rosenburg, and BGG. Now it sits unopened again.
All about ganging up on the leader or holding grudges.
Con ciudades y caballeros mejora mucho.
Many moons ago, I ran the Catan meet-up in Sacramento.
My first modern board game on the shelf. Do not play it anymore , but would play happily if somebody asked me to

Like a lot of people, this game was an introduction to the new era of boardgaming for me. While a lot of games have surpassed it, it's good to remember how important this game was when it first came along.

Despite the fact that it has dice (therefore luck) it is a fun game. I have played it many times since now, and it seems that i will also play it in the future. A must-buy for all those who like games with resources.  Edit: After some time now, I have adjusted the rating to 7 which is closer to my gaming preferences right now.
Classic. Easy, and great replay value. Taught this to little ones and older folk, everyone picked up on the fundamentals very quickly. Expansions keep it fresh.

A classic. Aged pretty well. Some will say it's just random dice rolling, and that might seem true on your first couple of plays, but there's much more to Catan than that. It's all about positioning, trading and managing your hand to avoid the thief.

This was my gateway game. I first played when my cousin brought it to a family reunion in 2000. I have never been the same since.  I still have it in part due to nostalgia.  Good for a beginner game, but I feel that there are better introduction games for new players.   I think my biggest knock on the game is that it is normally just my wife and myself playing games, which makes it difficult to play Catan. Then when we do have a large group, it just takes too long to play a 6 player game of Catan.
Played it to death, and still holds up as long as you play with expansions.  Don't believe the hate...it's an excellent game still.

The game that got me into board gaming. Loved the seafarer expansion back in the day. Biggest innovation for me: action for every player all the time. That's what really made catan succesful in my opinion.
I actually do own this but it's at the cottage (with expansions Seafarers, Cities and Knights, and Traders and Barbarians). I think I have to consider my family to be the owners now.
Simple and enjoyable. I think I played it the most out of my collection as you can play it with just about anyone. Great pick if you want to introduce new people to the hobby.
Fun but old and there's better stuff now.
Still surprisingly fun to play. Does not feel as random as it once did.
This is getting so old, that I would recommend it to younger players... like a classic novel ;-)
Good if the players don't take too long. Played a Lot in the past, now not so much.

Ah, the one that started it all. I actually don't have my copy of this anymore due to lending it to someone and never getting it back, but man did I play the crap out of this in High School. At the time, it offered so much that no other board game I had ever played did. It's still a good light-medium Euro in my opinion, and I would honestly be glad to play it if someone offered. That being said, since I am usually the one with and introducing the games, this gateway game will take a backseat when it comes to games like Pandemic or Ticket to Ride.
Played a lot long before i learned about BGG
What can I say, it's a classic and willing to play. Kind of over shadowed by all the other games out there but a great gateway game.
I discovered this game around 2000 through my uncle. This made me realize that my dream of better board games was a reality!
Great competitive game and a good game to introduce new players to common board game mechanics.  Replay-ability is very high.
To me this game requires at least 3 players and is best with 4-6.  That hurts the score a little for me.
I quite liked the 2 plays we had with it, however we do not often play 3 player games, so it wasn't hitting the table often. I traded away soon after
The new meta game for board gaming. I must honestly say, the game is not bad, but I don't find it awesome and unique anymore.
The reliance on dice based luck is offset by the ability to implement worthwhile long term strategies, as well as heavy player interaction fueled by the trading mechanic.

It's a classic.  I have friends who want to be introduced to new games, and then they only end up playing this anyway.  It's just solid, and they haven't played enough to be interested in branching out to other things for fear of it losing the appeal.  It's a good resource trading game, but I have to force myself to trade with others.  I always try to be self sufficient and if I'm not careful I can ruin other's experiences.
Played to death before I knew there were other games.

The great "gateway game" still lives up to its name. While it pales in comparison to many many other great games out there, this game has the right mix of simplicity, player interaction, strategy vs. randomness to hook players in and keep them coming back for more.

Great game to bring out for folks learning board games. Purchase this one instead of the Family Edition as you can expand to 5-6 players whereas the family version is stuck on 4 and no hope to ever expand it.
Classic! These hexes are so cute!
Who am I to criticize Catan? The hobby has evolved, but we own much to it.  Best with 4 players.

This was my first hobby game, and it really drew me into board gaming. I have not played the game in a while, but I still enjoy the game. It is quick to learn, quick to play, and keeps all of the players involved. If there is any downside it is that the theme is a little dull. In the game you collect and trade resources with other players in order to build new cities. Resources are produced through dice Roll and traded on each players turn. 3/1/16
Classic family euro game. But if you can figure out what people like about this game, there are probably other games that do that same thing, but better.
A bad opening move can completely ruin the game for you.
Great game, combines luck, strategy, negotiation, team-work and fun in a very nice way. Perfect to play within the family or with friends.

First game I bought as I realised it was recognised as a 'classic'. I play it with my daughters and while we enjoy it we have to only play to 8 points otherwise attention flags. That said it does get requested relatively often.
The beginners Eurogame. Not the best, certainly not the worst.
I really haven't played anything Catan enough. One play total for a gamer doesn't sound like enough! However, I really don't have a lot of draw to it. No one else seems to either.

Also in the same box: 5-6 player expansion  The expansion works just fine as an expansion, but the game can get long with more than 4 players. If you are a Catan fan it shouldn't matter, but if you are trying to introduce the game to a group, it can get very long with 5-6 players.
Paladin (NSKN) sleeve size: Medium Plus - Orange ('Bedivere', 55/pack) - (54 x 80mm)  126
My first modern boardgame, still has a place in my collection, and always willing to play.

A classic game now, easy to learn and play. Has the potential however to make some players just 'passengers' in the game, with virtually no chance to win even in early stages if cornered or boxed in and unable to expand. Best played with some of the expansion scenarios, like the 'Helpers' or 'Frenemies' which speed up gameplay.

The more I play other games the less I like Catan. This game is not fun when you are crushing everyone and not even playable when you're doing bad. However, once in a blue moon you will get a great game where all the players are equal and the challenge is real. No matter how much I complain I will always come back to settlers.
One of the first games i've got. I think my son(7y.o.) likes it more then all the family.

Catan was truly my gateway game at the early years of the XXI century (i never get to knew Carcassone at the time and, anyway, it won´t qualify) so, it sets another standard point at my rating list. Englobing just a few more mechanics and set up work than a vintage, Catan has already most of the features of a modern eurogame, though at small level.  Easy to grasp, with fast playing turns in a suitable short overall playing time and keeping pure chance at low level, it was perhaps the first non abstract game that could provide the feeling of really taking your destiny into your hands while building something. Nice to go along with family, friends or even maybe light gamers (who knows), Catan still remains a quality product and enjoyable, if one is by now not tired of playing it again and again.  Edit: In spite of all what is written above, after almost 4 years of new games experiments, it is quiet unfair to other modern games to rate Catan so high (7.5), so i am forced to drop it a bit, in order to keep things balanced.
Worthy of all the attention, but I fear I've burned myself out with the Android app. Perhaps checking out some expansions would fix this..
My first modern board game. Wouldn't choose it to play but would still enjoy playing if others wanted.
I will never say no if somebody invite me playin Catan.  I find this game different that any other game and also very fun!!!
Will become better with cities & knights extension.

Fast-paced and a nice collection of mechanics that fit together well. There are not too many options to choose from in one turn which makes this easy to play but probably allows more experienced players to determine opponent moves. A classic. Looking at Catan now it feels like the trading aspect is somewhat limited.
I like it! I like the Star Trek version better.  SdJ Winner 1995

Like Puerto Rice, has solid mechanics and almost no theme. It does seem to have more theme than Puerto Rico, though. What do you do in this one again? Is it cutting down trees or raising mules? I'm no longer sure.
Anniversary edition from 999 Games. Includes expansion for 5+6 players and a hand-painted custom robber.
Good game, played it too much and have never really wanted to play it much since.
Nothing wrong with it but it just doesn't hit the table that often anymore. I guess we played it a bit too much.
Updated: 5-3-18 Plays: 7 games Total Time: 11:29 I often pull out other games over this, but have no problem playing, if that's all other people want to play.

This baby got me into board gaming. I played around 500 games of this before I realised that maybe I should see if there are other similar games out there :)  I strongly recommend the Cities and Knights expansion. Once you've figured out the few basic strategies of this it basically comes down to the dice - Cities and Knights opens up multiple paths to victory, and the game actually becomes quite strategic. Of course it is always gonna come down to die roll still, but I think it's a vast improvement if you don't mind more complexity.   The rating is a bit down partially cause I just don't play it anymore since I've almost seen every possible because the newer games today, having improved upon this, scenario played out multiple times, also partially are just so amazing and well made that I have to rate this lower than those.
Dry theme and at times it feels like the game plays itself.

This game is the epitome of streamlining and elegance.  The rules are so simple and so clearly comprised on a few cards, yet you can do vastly different things, you win on only 10 victory points, get some "haha" moments against your opponents that feel like your master strategy being executed but still maintain a non-gamer friendly level of luck and have no real downtime on your opponents turns as you also get resources and look what they do.  Compared to e.g. Stone Age, this truly is a non-gamers game.  So, why no perfect 10 rating?  After years I just grew a bit out of the simple base mechanics, the luck factor is too large for my taste and the game does not bring forth that much exitement for me anymore. Still gladly playing it though.
Classic game that's an upgrade of monopoly. But it's pretty boring especially if you're opponents are not willing to trade with you.
Produciran las tierras adyacentes a tu poblado? Si es así podras construir caminos y nuevos poblados...si la suerte del dado te acompaña..
Classic game that brought us to the gaming :) Had to leave behind in Slovakia.
Thanks to Secret Santa for this game!
Classic.  Mainly playing on app against the wife.

a good game for new to the hobby and families. majority of strategizing and thinking is done in the placing of starting settlements. after that - dont be too much of a threat and get some decent rolls.
Played this so many times.  For its time it was amazing now it blends in with so many other games that I feel new and fresh to me.
Classic entry level game. It's random, and fun but the cities and knights expansion is one of my favourites.
No deja de ser un simcity, pero en tablero.la evolución de pueblos siempre es divertida.
Preferred the Star Trek Catan version, with role cards that accelerate the game somewhat. Found the original (this version) to be a little stagnant.

My original gateway board game, really where I first got into the hobby. I still think it's one of the standard and best euros out there, and deserves its place in history for being a game which appeals to a multitude of people despite being a euro and a more heavier game than most amerithrash.  The part I dislike most about the game is the reliance of rolls to snowball into the later game. If you don't get great rolls early, it's very easy to quickly be pigeonholed into a boring, helpless position and vice versa. There is very rarely any playing from behind and the ending of the game is very anticlimactic.   Overall, I still really enjoy the game and would be happy if pulled out just for familiarity but I would almost always want to pull out other games. Great gateway game.

Great game for every one.   I recommend to every one.   Sad that i did not know about this game earlier.  Great game that has strategy + luck and is very easy to learn.  Just buy it, you wont regret it.
Catan can be infuriating when the dice rolls just aren't going your way. It's a decent game, but there are much better games out there that scratch the same itch.

My wife and I had played Catan with her sister and husband.  We had a few drinks and we had a great time.  In fact, we had such a good time, I decided to buy the game even though we didn't really have enough players to play.  I saw that there was a Catan Junior and really had thought about getting it for our family.  After thinking about it a while, we opted against it and sat down with the family to play this one.  We found that the 10yr and 7yr was easily able to grasp the general concept of the game and my 5yr was on my team.  The boys quickly caught on and I swear my daughter was a shepherd in a past life time.  We always seem to stock pile sheep.
German version. Still at my parents' house.
There is much potential for rage in this one.
Nothing to say that hasn't already been said. A Classic. My parents love this game more than they love me.
Simple euro with good interaction and planning aspects.  I enjoy playing this with my kids (ages 8 and 6).
Good entry-level game to bridge casual players and more experienced board game collectors.   It doesn't hold a candle to some of our favorites, but it's still a great game.
It's Catan, you know it. It's easy, it's a fun play. And the thief will ruin your day.
A solid gateway family game. My kids like it. Simple mechanics and easy to understand. Too much luck for my taste.

I hadn't played this one for years (since highschool) before receiving it for Christmas. The game doesn't quite hold up to my memory in terms of fun or strategy, but I'm glad to have a copy of this gateway game in my collection.
A classic, but I think next time I'll play with some house rules to try and mitigate the luck.
Have not played in a long time.

Review - I know Catan can get some hate from the more hardcore side of the strategy gaming community, but I love it for one simple reason: it’s easily one of the best bridge games. If you’re trying to drag friends from Monopoly into the world of strategy gaming you’d be hard pressed to find a better option. It does have shortcomings such as the randomness of dice rolls and map construction, a tendency for games to run long, and a lack of options/strategies (not including expansions), but some of that can be remedied with house rules. Honestly though I think that all plays into its charm. It’s certainly not a game for every occasion, but when you’re looking for something a little lighter, or trying to teach strategy gaming basics it’s near the top.

The biggest Gateway game for me.  Played this one to death.  Not sure if I will ever end up playing it again because of that, but truly was THE gateway game for me that bridged the gap from mass market boardgames into the Golden Era of boardgaming for me.

New to the game, and have only played with the base game and then the Cities and Knights expansion, but the game was very fun, quick to learn, and didn't take too long to play, which means my wife will play it with me, and it is very easy to adapt to two players.
Also contains "La Grande Rivière" Essen 2005 mini expansion.

Was the gateway game that got me into modern gaming.  Nowadays, I'd rather play something else, but I have acknowledge its success.    However, the two main turnoffs for me are: The randomness can feel punishing, when a good strategy falls flat on its face because no 6s or 8s have been rolled, despite probability, and in my experience, in a 4 player game, 1 player usually spends the game stagnant, unable to really achieve much.    The second, is that I don't like how critical the starting positioning is.  With experience players, I feel like I can accurately predict who will win 80% of the time based solely on where everyone starts.
One of the original gateway games for me. I'll gladly play it if anyone suggests it, but to be honest, it's a bit too basic and random for a Euro-ish style game.
The game that got me into modern board games. Still fun to pull out every now and then, but it does show its age a little.

A great game if the dice are kind, a total waste of time if they are not. I had flashbacks to Trouble when you could spend every turn trying to get a six while others whizzed around the board and interacted with each other and had a lot of fun.  Expansions: Seafarers

We played Settlers a lot...and then some more. I aboslutely loved the game, even without expansions. While it is still a very good game, it has been replaced by better games. It still has its place on my shelf, but does not see much action anymore.

I'm guessing this is true for a lot of people, but Catan was what started it all. It was THE game that first got me interested in modern designer boardgames and into this hobby. There were other games that really sealed the deal, but it all started with this one. I hadn't played boardgames for years until this game along. So mad props to it for getting me into the hobby.  That said, it's a good game, but no longer my favorite. We still bust it out every now and then with friends.
I'll trade a sheep for your sheep.

I still think this game is a little mean. It feels like it takes too long to me - not enough fun for the time the game takes.  It might be because we've played with players new to the game, and with slow negotiations.
Really enjoy the full version.  The family edition sucks.
Only modern game that I have played for almost 20 years as most people I know had a copy and was an easy game to bring to the table.
Loved this game at first, and still like playing with family - especially with 5-6 player expansion.  Not one I would pick first anymore.
Good family game. Very light, so doesn't offer much for the more seasoned gamer. But good for getting non-gamers to the hobby and for some family game time.
For a few years, this was one of the greatest games around, but now it's a bit dated, and was replaced by newer games.

A classic. Good component quality. Intriguing gameplay easy to teach. Game  relies on dice thrOwing and the willingness  of other players to trade. I have play the game enough to not need to play it again but I am willing if I am in the right mood and with the right people.  Stored in bitbox medium. Original box stored in Box #X at Dad's
Immensely important game. We all owe a great debt to Catan. That said, it's pretty average.
Basic but light and fun. A classic game of settling and building settlements and cities. Great game for intro into the hobby.

The dice rolls can be frustrating. It feels long for what you do, but by the end you've weald and dealt and feel like you've built something. There's a reason why it hooks people. I'm not sure it's hooked me though.
Great game but to me, you have to have fun people to play with.  The crowd makes the game IMO.  Glad we own it, would recommend others to get it.  It's a classic.
Solid experience.  Need to play with people who know what they are doing to get the full flavor.
My first entry into euro hex based strategy board games.  Just a classic, great, well designed game.  The base game can get boring after playing the cities and knights expansion though.
In general, a pretty good game though if one playing is dominating, it is a long wait for them to finish the game.
Good gateway game. Trading mechanic is fun.
Very easy to explain and learn, but has some strategy to it. It is a game I can play with my parents, just takes a long time to play.
Like everyone else this was my gateway game.  Haven't played in years.
Fun game but the dice rolls can really reek havoc on an individual during the game
Will happily play this one every now and then, for old times sake, and still appreciate it even after countless plays. It's been a pleasure to teach a whole swathe of new settlers lately.
Nice simple euro. Some people complain about dice but they just don't strategize well.

Probably my most played and most nostalgic board game of all time. Played this a million times while living in China with Mookie, Ben, Doug, and Mark. While many games are far superior, this will always remain a favorite.

Nice gateway. Only played as a beer and bretzel game. Should not be taken too seriously given how much the dice can be merciless. The most fun parts are trading and table talk. Point out every time another player is in a good position, while yours is as good or even better, trigger fun discussion in my casual gamer group.

Catan will always hold a special place in my heart as the game that opened my eyes. However, now if I play I much prefer it with the C&K expansion in order to give it a bit more depth. Seafarers isn't as balanced as I would like, so that version sees the least play from me. Catan is still a great starter game that can sway non-gamers, and has a good balance of luck/strategy/interaction to keep things interesting.
3-6 players - Competitive, dice-rolling, territory-building game with very light strategy.

An OK mainstream game that most people have played by now. But as such, i'm all played out on this game. It relies too heavily on player negotiations for goods. And you can already pretty much tell who's going to win, based on where the starting settlements are placed. This game did wonders for the boardgaming community, but it has overstayed its welcome in my collection. Get those player negotiations out of my strategy game, and outta my face! Time to grow up and play Castles of Burgundy.

Although it's lost much of its appeal to me, I still hold it in a very good spot in my heart for being a game that I played for years, before I even knew of modern board games. The first gateway game, even though dice can be somewhat of an annoyance, I'll still play it now and then. And even beyond its flaws, it's still a great game with one of the best direct negotiation/commerce features I've yet to see in a board game.

Like most people of my generation, this was the game that introduced me to the hobby game market, so there will always be a special place in my heart for it.  I don't get it to the table much anymore just because it's a bit intense for new players and I've got other gateway games to teach people.  My preference is to only play this with four players who don't mind yelling at each other across the table.  I normally recommend a good coop after we play this to calm everyone back down.  And yes, we still giggle when someone asks, "Does anyone have wood for sheep."

Catan!  This will always hold a special place in my gaming heart because it was my first "Euro" type of game that I played.  It is special because it blends strategy and luck fairly well, and being able to trade resources between other players makes for interesting interactions each time.  I would give a higher rating, but I'm trying to balance nostalgia with reason.  Still play this game fairly often, although it is taking a backseat to a lot of newer games that I frankly find to be more fun.

Like many, this was my introduction to modern board games.  I was immediately captivated by this fascinating creation.  It's strategic, but it has random dice rolling!  It's competitive but there's no player elimination!  You'll likely get stomped your first game, but once you have the basics down, most games come down to a close finish.    My wife and I soon bought our own copy and played and played, and introduced it to new people.  After a while, and a lot of plays, the game started to irk me more and more.  I disliked getting screwed over by a string of streaky dice rolls.  I disliked everyone ganging up on one player with the robber.  I disliked that the five resources were not evenly balanced.  I disliked other players making suboptimal trades with each other.  I started to discover other, newer (clearly better! lol) games, and began to turn up my nose at lowly Catan.  I've since come back around.  There are other better gateway games that have come along (e.g. Ticket to Ride, Splendor, Dominion).  There are other games I'd rather play on most any given game night.  But I enjoy it for what it is:  a solid light-middleweight euro that's fun to dust off every once in a while.  It's not the be all end all of strategy games.  But even in spite of its unprecedented success, it has a unique mix of mechanics, strategy and interaction that has never been duplicated.  approximate number of plays (pre-2017):  50+
Good fun. Not the best game, but it's the one game I can usually get my family to reliably join in on. Just keep the goddamn robber away from me or I'll stick ya.
Love it or hate it Catan is where most gamers started
Includes Citites and Knights, Seafarers, and Oil expansions
Why I like it: MONOPOLY type game, easy to play it.  Why I dislike it: Take too much time to play one game.
the classic. got me into boardgames
We haven't played Catan in many years. I know some people find a game like this and never stop playing it. For us it was an important, albeit short-lived, stepping stone into the world of gaming.
A very solid game, but I've played this so many times now that I feel the game gets dull unless you get the expansions. However, this is a must-have for anyone getting into board games
One of the best game, but really dependable of luck. Fun and pleasurable to play, but even the greatest placements and tactics fail from the unwanted dice rolls. Too much luck involved...
Catan is one of those games that I just played so many times that I got sick of it.  It's been a few years, though, and I'm willing to give it another shot.

Good gateway game, introducing several mechanics in modern board games. Allow room for some long-term strategy (not much, but enough for new players) in early placement of settlements, although bad placement could lock someone out of the game entirely.

The original euro, a great little game with a good balance of luck and some take that. You can play nice but that robber always comes up. I really enjoyed the cities and knights expansion, seafarers not worth the purchase as its the same thing.
Another classic intro game.  3 to 4, best 4.

Classic that still holds its weight today.  Some of my non-gaming friends have played this before and will ask to play this over learning anything new.  So it has value being in my collection.   Edit: traded due to need for shelf space.  it just wasn't getting any plays.
+ 5-6 Player Expansion  A solid game.  I've been beaten by a 6 year old while playing it though..
I can see why this became such a gateway game for the new generation of board gamers, but there is a little too much of a reliance on the dice rolls to generate your resources than I would like.

Fun eurostyle game. I usually like a little more thematic elements (ameritrash) but we very much enjoyed this one. Intend to buy it but a little put off by the expansions plus player number expansions that are necessary. Kind of seems like a money pit.
My tastes have expanded and evolved but I still really enjoy a play from time to time.
Easy to pick up, gets blood boiling.
Not in original box.  All pieces accounted for.
In the modern age of board gaming, I can't see myself ever playing this again. But it is a 7 for what it was!
I like a little more to my games than what Catan has to offer, but I still like the game. Isn't one that I would suggest at the table, but I'll play without to much coaxing.

Good to introduce people to gaming with, some expansions can be fun to add in. Recommend dice-deck to ensure better probability distribution, and also best with Seafarers added in. Other expansions add some complexity.
My start into euro gaming. Great game.

I have a later edition than the one pictured, but a more sturdy one than the one currently available. I also have some awesome wooden edge pieces my brother found at a garage sale, and a backyard-sized version fashioned for me by my awesome family.  There was a time, obviously, when I was very into this game. But I have a lot of other things now that I'd rather play. But it's still solid and still fun.

How amazing to make something that is a breakthrough in it's field. This game inspired an entire genre of games. It was quite fun to play, but I guess some other games have built on it and surpassed it.

Presentación: https://youtu.be/diCSpcF-Ppk  Cómo se juega: https://youtu.be/N5SljJbSRgc  Táctica y Estrategia: https://youtu.be/8MEO8M09K4Y  Top 5 Juegos familiares recomendados 2017: https://youtu.be/BnTCTnyFmKs
Great game for the family, but can drag on a little in playtime.
classic you need to have it...
Classic game, fun to play. I don't enjoy it as much as some other people though.
Fun, a game of chance though, little strategy involved.

This was my gateway game in to modern euro board games and I was only playing Risk before being introduced to this unique game. I won my first time playing and enjoyed every time I've played, but one my friends started buying other games, I started to realized that there were a lot of other better games. Still for a euro gateway game, I definitely recommend this one.
This is the game that got me into the hobby.  Call it a sentimental rating...and perhaps it is...but I will still play this just about anytime that anyone wants to.
good game. But without the expansions, it could be boring and repetitive.
A clasic, I have much loved and worn out swedish copy of the game with nice wood components.

A great game for introducing new people to the hobby.  I have many plays on this game prior to finding BGG.  The game is solid, but I have many more games that I feel are better, so this game will only see a table for new players.
GREAT game that (NOW) I'd refuse to play with more than 3 player. Great as a gateway and introduction to the hobby. NOW I wouldn't rate that HI (7), but when I just got it would have been a 10.

It's a fun game, but with my typical group, it seems to drag on for a while. I don't like that sometimes you can't do anything on your turn or that you can go several turns without getting resources even if your on 6 and 8 tiles.

Used to like this more, but all the games I play seem to last forever, like 3-4 hours. Not sure why, when playing with people who have played before. It just doesn't have the same feel as it did when I originally entered the hobby.

22 years. It took 22 years for me to finally get a chance to play this game. Despite its age, The Settlers Of Catan still holds up. Yeah, I could see having too many of the same resource being clumped together during setup cause balance issues, but that is a minor quibble. Trading, points for victory, a minor screw-your-opponent ability, and an innovative dice roll payout mechanics; its no wonder that tSoC took the world by storm and ushered in an era of interest in Euro board gaming.
