There are so many versions of tSoC and expansions for the game, but were I ever to buy it, I would probably stick to the vanilla version as 3-4 players is probably the best for game length and a theme change doesn't interest me.  Oh, and despite the official shortening of the game to just 'Catan', I will probably always refer to it by its full title as it evokes memories of the reverence people held for The Settlers Of Catan in the late 90's.
Everyone's intro to board games game!
Fun, great dice rolling and trading game. Not the tightest game however, the game tends to drag on.

It's weird to think that there will be a time when people forget that this was once "The Settlers of..."  I always referred to this as Settlers.  *shrug*  As for a comment, I have nothing of value to add to the bajillions of words contributed here.  It's great, timeless, and always entertaining.  You can definitely have "too much" of it, but that doesn't last long, imo.  Big points for being something my parents love to play.

I loved playing this game with all engineers.  I find with other, more diverse, gaming groups either i get targeted into oblivion with the robber shutting down income, taking my resources, AND everyone refusing to make trades even they want to initiate on their own terms because they want the trade with anyone but me since I might benefit fromt that.... OR I get ignored even a reasonable amount and win without feeling like I was ever in danger of not winning.  There isn't a lot of intermediate experiences between those two extremes anymore so I have dropped its rating just down to a 7.  This was my gateway into the hobby.
7 Plays - What can you say? It's Settlers of Catan. The new Monopoly, except its actually fun. Theme quite dry.

Doesn't really work in my opinion with 2 play (big surprise since it 3-5 player game) but great fun to play with a few friend. You also have to love the classic comment and now t-shirt 'no one wants your @#$%ing sheep'
Great one to introduce new gamers to for a first taste...
Has grown on me. Best when not played too competitively.
Good game, best for 4, hard to find friends to play with. I mean, in China.
A good gate way game, but van really drag out time wise.  Also very expensive for what you get, really the 6 player expansion should have come standard  SOLD to long to play 3-4 hrs with 6 players
Hard to rate Catan.  I liked it before getting into the hobby and I appreciate the design, but I don't have any desire to play it any more.
I play with children and adults. The game may take too long to end, but it's fun.
Very nice. Works best with 4 players.
Cool family/group entry game that I enjoy.
Nice game with tactical decisions, but highly dependent on luck.
I think I play it too much.
Where it all started (much like a lot of people, I'm guessing). Kickstarted Hexels to make building the board easier and more secure (ish).
Always willing to play a game with friends
This game is great to introduce new players to the hobby, but I feel like I'm passed that now.

Like many others, this is where it all began for me. I loved it as the base game, then we got the Seafarers expansion which we never played with until we got Cities and Knights as well. Those two expansions in addition to the 5-6 player extension allowed for massive sprawling boards of epic proportions where we implemented exploration and sailed into the ocean to discover land. The games typically lasted upwards of three hours or so, but I would no longer play it any other way. It is too bland without a bunch of unique rules.
Great little bartering type game competing for space and resources. This was my first real board game and still love it now. Can go on a little long for what it is though

Classic, and still is pretty good. The game has a lovely arc of development and building things up while offering fun trading opportunities. I don't love the lucky/variable nature of it, even though it's not as big a factor in determining a winner as many would seem to think it is. (What I'm saying is that Catan still is largely won by being a better player and playing the odds well).   It plays fast and is very accessible. I have fun playing this here and there even though I've grown to enjoy resource management/development games like Terra Mystica much more.   Update Apr 2019: I've played this a bit more in the past few months and upping this to a 7. It's a very good game and it does so many things better than many newer designs. It actually has some really solid player interaction, it has a good amount of depth and skill despite those who would proclaim it be about luck, and a nice little arc of engine building development.
Dozens of plays logged prior to joining BGG and logging game plays. Yucatan Narrow - Orange/Yellow (MDG-7109) CANON

Siedler! An excellent game that I dislike. Now, it’s quite easy to coax me into playing, and play will be fun and intense, but to be good at this game you cannot rely on luck and placement alone; you need to enjoy and be good at trading, negotiating, and manipulating your co-players in order to overcome shortages, bad die rolls, and poor odds. Good at this I am not; neither do I enjoy it. Still, a great game.

Fun classic game. A little tough to explain at first, but easy to play once you get it. When playing well this can be a great game with lots of planning and player to player trading and bargaining. At its worst players can be essentially kicked out of the game if they get unlucky or are put into a bad position.
Okay, although early mistakes can make the game almost impossible to win. The board sometimes comes apart while playing.
Hate rolling the dice for production. But this is my first board game.
It's a classic, but it's unbalanced. Certain resources are worth far more than others.
I have fully 3D printed out this game minus the dice and the cards. Everything else including the box has been printed out.
Es genial para iniciarse, se que es una de las "vacas sagradas" pero partida a partida va perdiendo su encanto.   Es genial, pero de va desluciendo con el tiempo.
A classic, but tends to get silly with 'wood for sheep' jokes.

Hard to argue that this game is anything but great. It's broad popularity among casual and committed players alike attests to the quality of its design. Thematically it is rather dry and if early dice rolls don’t break your way it can be a tedious exercise in frustration tolerance. Still, it is fun and just about anyone can learn to play it and play it skillfully.
Designer Klaus Teuber Buy: Livraria Cultura Publisher: Grow
Board Game PLAYED FAMILY, Strategy, Negotiation, Dice Rolling, Hand management, Modular board, Trading, Rout/Network building   3-4 60'-120'  Complecity: M/L 2,37  1998-2006
Jeu bien. Demande une bonne stratégie.

Fun game but it can take a lot more time than expected. And with longer games, I've had some not-so-serious people lose interest in the game. The more people are willing to trade, the quicker the game goes. But it's hard to have that because everyone can see how close everyone is to victory. That can sometimes lock up a game.
I love this Game still, A+   Bling upgrade:  Added a Tornado 3D Print for Robber, and 4 Different Race Placement Pieces, and Sleeved the Cards. Con: Made me Buy Expansion to Cover 5-6 Player

A classic... every gamer needs to play this at least one time. I really enjoy Catan! Simple but fun.
Really love the board variety each game.  Pieces don't always stay put in the borders. (Borders came warped a bit) but usually dosent affect play... just my OCD.

Classic game and great for people new to board games. Greatly improved by adding the expansion.
Got this game as graduation present. It is a nice game, but something is missing for me.
I enjoy this game but not as much as I should. For the time investment, I just prefer others.

Like the game but not the flimsiness of the cardboard tiles.
My first introduction to modern board games!  Is fun :)
Was previously my gaming group's game of choice.  Excellent replayability and the balance is solid. With the expansions, the game gets even more fun. Should buy staple for the older crowd.
Have Base, Seafarers, & Cities and Knights with 5-6 player expansions
Es un juegazo, pero odio el factor azar de los dados. Han sido tantas partidas viendo pasar los turnos...
A bit too much of random. But alltogether is still quite good a game i'm enjoy a lot
My love for boardgaming started at age 7 with this game. Play it once a year - just nostalgia!
The game that got me into the board games. I am always willing to play a round of Catan but it sees the table less and less with each new game added to the shelf.
I still love to play this - just since i first got it other games have come and surplanted.
Settlers of Catan is a good game. Yes, I prefer to call it the long name, and no, I won't call it the short name. I enjoy this game a good deal.
Usually refer to the Xbox version of the game as "Getting mad at Catan"
Really nice game. Easy to get started for new players.

Several paths to victory (focus on developments, towns, or spreading out). Best part is open trading, which helps players deal with the luck of the dice and allows for certain players to monopolize a resource and trade for what they need. 4 players can be quite cramped on a normal map and newer players can feel trapped with few options.  At this point I've played it so much I'm done (base game).
A classic that still holds up. Great intro game for non-gamers but still has enough to keep experienced players interested.

I like Catan, and it is certainly a classic. I love it's universal appeal. My rating would probably be higher, but it sometimes drags on too long (especially with 5 or 6 players - NEVER doing 6 again), and some games are going to be miserable if the dice rolls keep you from getting necessary resources.   I'd usually rather play Ticket To Ride - similar game, shorter game length, less susceptible to bad luck (most of the time).
Good introductory game.  More dependent on dice than I like, but you can alter your odds enough that I still enjoy it.
Good Euro intro that half the people in your group will probably have played before at some point.  Theme is boring and mechanics have been surpassed, but still a dependable fall back game.
The game that got me into euros. Still very enjoyable if you're in for a relaxed game session. Biggest drawback is the fact that it's hard to catch up if you got an unlucky start.
I still enjoy Catan alot. I haven't played with very many of the expansions, but have played with cities and knights and enjoy it

Classic game. I know this game and its supporters get flack for it but who cares. Play what you like and I like this game. Its the best gateway game, it was mine. Easy to teach, fast to learn, some strategy, some skill. Hand management, trading, resource management. All the starting mechanics for a great game.

First played this when Henry's girlfriend brought it over in summer 2013. Loved it immediately as it was my first "real" board game.  I understand now it is a gateway game, but play it a ton still with my family.  Have probably played at least 150 games if not more. I will log all plays forward from October 2016.
Ja...ook hier ligt de klassieker. Wel een beetje jammer dat het niet met twee gespeeld kan worden, maar het (pogen tot) ruilen is altijd leuk. :-)
A timeless classic. Biggest problem is setup and tear down time. Don't play this one a whole lot anymore...but like probably many others, this was my introduction to tabletop gaming.
I get a little over-competitive with this game, it doesn't bring out my friendly side, I don't like it when people won't trade
It's a game that lives in a certain spot and there are no better games for that spot.
Pretty good.  My first "euro" game.  It has the "king maker flaw" (don't play this game in a tournament in which people related to each other are playing.) I'm sick of the wood for sheep jokes.
My Mum will play this and have a brilliant time doing it. So it stays.
Pretty good game, classic intro game. Good next step after Ticket to Ride and Carcassonne.

Excellent gateway game. I would have rated this an 8 or 9 during my gateway period. Little setup, attractive board, increased replayability with randomised board. Can be played 2 player with no trading house rule.
Great competitive game, but not good for people who don't like conflict or manipulation.
Very good game, but a large amount of dice rolls can be annoying.

Even though my tastes have grown, I haven't outgrown Catan. I find a lot of value in gateway games and continue to get more and more people into gaming through them. Catan was one of my gateway games and I enjoy using it to expand the hobby. That being said, the randomness does kind of suck sometimes.
This was my gateway to euro style board games. High replayability because of the randomness of the tiles, setup takes a while though.

The first game everyone seems to play when they realise that Monopoly is not the only option. I like the modular board and the probability-based strategic thinking. Not so keen on the ease with which you can get blocked off or cornered.
The classic. Only fun now as an introduction game or with my (currently) 10 year old little sister.  (Written in 2018)
Caught the tail end of it's popularity so haven't played it much but has good mechanics.
Excellent game. Combination of strategy and some luck. Love it.
Pretty Great intro game to break people away from Risk and Monopoly. Great family game!

Erw.1: 5&6 Spieler Erw.2: Die Seefahrer Erw.3: Die Seefahrer 5&6 Spieler Erw.4: Städte & Ritter Erw.5: Städte & Ritter 5&6 Spieler Erw.6: Das Buch (Szenarien, Varianten, Finessen) Erw.7: Historische Szenarien I (Alexander der Große & Cheops) Erw.8: Historische Szenarien II (Troja & Die Große Mauer) Erw.9: Atlantis - Szenarien & Varianten
One of the first step of the new era of the board games
My first "real" board game, which I'm sure is a common story around these parts. Still usually fun around the right playgroup, though I find that the winner can be obvious about halfway through.
Really like it,play it if i'm in the mood, I don't win a lot, but I dont care, I like playing it.

People rag on Catan a lot.  I would likely not turn down a game of Catan, especially with new players that are trying to get into gaming.  Yeah, there is a lot of luck, but it is not like you are playing for hours to get crushed by it.  It plays fast enough to never feel burdened by playing it.  I like Catan.  Stop hatin'  ; )
Relies too heavily on luck for my liking. I still like to play this with my family and people who aren't really isn't games.

Finally got to play this granddaddy of eurogames. Easy to play and interactive. At times it is a bit frustrating being at the mercy of the die rolls and end up with do-nothing turns. It is maybe a little bit long for what it offers but so far I've enjoyed it. (02.01.17)
Pretty good gateway game. A lot of folks know this game, lots of folks know the rules, plays enough people to get it to the table frequently. This game replaced regular Monopoly for our home.
It may have been out for a while, but I didn't play it until recently.  Didn't care for it at first, but am warming up to it after a few plays.  Not a favorite, but do enjoy it on occasion.
Our second gateway game we bought after Carcassonne. We have played so many times until a new game arrived.
One of my favorite games. Never gets old for me
K: Grałem w Catan ze 3 razy. Gra całkiem fajna choć z dużą dozą denerwującej losowosci. Niestety nie działa na 2 osoby, wiec nie nadaje się dla nas.

+ Seefahrer + Die Legende der Seeräuber + Städte & Ritter + Händler & Barbaren + Entdecker & Piraten + Die Helfer von Catan + Big Game, Big Honor + Beste Freunde + Historische Szenarien I & II + Das Buch zum spielen + Schätze, Drachen und Entdecker + 5. & 6. Spieler (auch für alle Erweiterungen)

Eines der ältesten und mit eins der ersten Spiele in meiner Sammlung. Ein solides und leicht strategisches Spiel für zwischendurch, welches jeder auf Anhieb versteht. Der Spielaufbau ist simpel und erlaubt jedermann eine eigene strategische Ausrichtung.

Good solid basic game, family friendly (my 8 and 9 year olds handle it easily). IMHO it is better to stick with the predetermined set-up, as it is more balanced. This does however reduce replayability. Can be frustrating at times when you can not do anything as you do not have any resources, and the dice do not co-operate.
Quite random for its length, and seems to end right when you feel like you've gotten something going.  It's fine, but I'm not sure there's anything it does better than lots of other games.
Wedding Present, which worked out well since I had little interest in buying it. I have enjoyed the digital game on occasion, and I don't have many gateway games, so I'm sure it'll get its use.
With 2 expansion, cities and knight and seafarers

I use this game as an introduction to board gaming as it is such an easy game to pick up. The game works best with 3 players as 4 can be a bit crowded, but it also works with 2 players. To do this you create 2 separate islands with the same resources and same odds but with different merchants. When a 7 is rolled, instead of using the robbers, switch merchants. This works really well as the merchants allow for a HUGE advantage.   A fun game to play for a few rounds, however after that game play can get a bit repetitive.   Fun game with an unexpected amount of strategy.
It's a good game, but the basic game doesn't offer many different strategies.
Legendary Game, has a lot of strategy that someone might think with the first glance.  Although that the game is using dices , it comes to the player deep thinking to prevail. Play it!
Great game.  Players play against each other and use resources to build roads or villages.  One player wins when (s)he builds enough roads, villages, or armies.  Strategic game with 3 to 4 players.
Nice game to play with casual gamers.
Another game that's fun to play if people don't take it too seriously and push for the best possible trades.

A friend bought me this one Christmas knowing I'd started buying a few boardgames. I can see why this started the ball rolling for the modern era. It's a nice looking game, has fairly simple rules, has variability/re-playability and the trading with other players offers great interaction, with often some very funny banter! I just wish the expansions weren't so expensive as I'd love to buy seafarers or explorers but not at the prices they sell for!
I love Catan. The only problem is that games tend to drag on if players didn't choose good starting locations.
Good game for introducing people to Euro games, and I played it a lot, but there are lots more that interest me much more now.  I don't like playing without the Cities and Knights expansion anymore.
Played many many times before BGG. Enjoyable. On the minus: no luck mitigation. Lot's of luck needed.
Very nice family game. I really like to play it but only from time to time.
Easy to play game that really breezes along. One part, light puzzle. One part, backstabby negotiation.
Designer: Klaus Teuber     Artist: Volkan Baga, Tanja Donner, Pete Fenlon Publisher: KOSMOS, 999 Games, Albi

2017-11-10 Catan is finally starting to fade for me, which is why I am going to downgrade it from an '8' to a '7'.  I no longer actively seek to play it, but can enjoy it when we do.  However, I've found that other games—most notably 7 Wonders—improve on Catan's civilization-building theme by having better mechanics.  E.g., severely mitigating the luck mechanic; reducing the punitive interaction between players, etc. -- 2017-03-20 Catan has never gotten old for me. It's a great gateway game, and also a classic to play with the family on Sunday afternoons.

I kinda think it was the world’s greatest gateway game. I have the same cliches about blowing Monopoly and Risk out of my personal waters. I still think that for non-gamers this can still be the ‘I didn’t know it could be like this’ moment that brings them to our side. But, after about 50 plays, including (especially) the app, it can be super frustrating that it relies on dice, the more normally distributed 2d6 notwithstanding. So now, I won’t play it unless some wide eyed newbie just heard about it and wants to play. After all those plays, I think that’s about all you should expect from a game - this one goes in the hall of fame.

I think that I like Settlers. I mean, it's iconic, but for me it has an uncomfortable amount of dice-rolling. This doesn't bother most people, but I like a bit more control/less randomness in my games. Regardless, the idea is fun, and it deserves credit for drawing more people to the new styles of board games.
2015 Juegos Jugados. 2016 Juegos Jugados. 2017 Juegos Jugados. :goo: Dueño - Miguel :goo:
Good game, great entry level game. Cities and Knights makes is very good
Good memories and it`s still a good gateway game, but too luck dependent for a strategy game so I stopped playing with it.
This gets to the table more than it ought, but it's fast, light and easy access.
The all time Classic. Strategic but luck dependent. Very user friendly for all ages and gaming skill. Rather long playtime. Becomes more engaging with expansions

Classic game, but recent games overshadow it. Initial placement is too important and the dice makes it too random. Trading with players is rarely worth it for both sides. I'd still recommend it as an intro family game.
I always seem to be short the specific resource needed during the most crucial part of the game. Can't be my fault.

Great game to play with family/friends that are not that much into board games. It's simple and always fun. Own the 5-6 players expansion, which doesn't add anything new to the game mechanics, but it's incredibly fun to play with that many players.

The amount of time I spent playing this during my undergrad days (pre and post going to the bar on numerous occasions) has to be in the hundreds and hundreds of hours.  Still fun to this day, though not a game I'm looking to play all the time.

In Catan (formerly The Settlers of Catan), players try to be the dominant force on the island of Catan by building settlements, cities, and roads. On each turn dice are rolled to determine what resources the island produces. Players collect these resources (cards)—wood, grain, brick, sheep, or stone—to build up their civilizations to get to 10 victory points and win the game.
A good game that introduced me to modern board games. Very dependant on luck and where your first pieces are placed.
Fun game. Heavily relies on luck.

A classic resource game. Typically fun, though board flipping can ensue if player's are being dicks. Expansions, add different mechanics, but don't change the game a lot. Victory is pretty satisfying.

It can become a fun game, which depends largely on chance.   The problem is, the difficulty to get resources and move forward, if the other players do not want to exchange resources with you, then it can become a long and boring game, you can stay stagnant. As the author said, it is a game that tries to reflect that we must share in order to advance, although later, only one will be the winner.

this game does some fun stuff. I would be down to play this with 3 players pretty consistently. The negotiation/trading aspect is fun and the fact that you get resources when it's not your turn. helps with downtime. there is some randomness and that can make some games frustrating.
This was the game that really got me into gaming that is not Monopoly or Scrabble.

Solid Game.   Always a great "gateway" game to get people past monopoly.    It has done wonders for the board game industry.    At this point I've played over 100 matches, and while I'm done with it, there is a lasting fondness for it in my heart.  Yeah, there are better games.  But let's be thrilled about it for what it is.  Favorite Expansions: * Old Fisherman of Catan (impossible to find) * Cities and Knights (very complex though) * Event Deck (out of print and thus more expensive than it's worth)
Saying "I don't like The Settlers of Catan" is like saying "I don't like The Beatles" - you think you look cool... but nobody believes you!
Board Game - PLAYED FAMILY, Strategy, Negotiation, Dice rolling, Hand Management, Modular board, Route/network building, Trading  3-4 60'- 120'  Complexity: M/L 2,37  Played: 1998 - 2006

One of the first strategy board games for our family.  I guess that s common for most.  We really enjoy playing it.  Thought about expansions but I think it might lose some of its beautiful simplicity.  We don't play as often but enjoy when we do.
This game is fun for sure. Yes, there are better games but it is still good.
Administración de Recursos Construcción / Rutas Negociación
Thanks to you Catan, I think we can say that the "Euro Invasion" was a huge success.
Classic fun but i don't own this game yet. Maybe later
My gateway game, what else can I say.

It's a classic game, but it's been replaced by so many other games. It's still a good one to get people playing who aren't that into board games because they've heard of it. The randomness to it and the fact that it always plays the same (or similarly) keeps it from being rated higher, but there is some fun strategy.
Very fun gateway and family game. A bit too long but we're always looking forward to play it.
6p expansion, but it's from a different edition so the colors are different.

One of the first "New" generation of board games that I played, Catan will always have a special place on my shelf.  That being said, it is more reliant on luck than a lot of the other games I play, and as a result, it will not be at the top of my list.  My strategy is to go broad on dice results so that there is rarely a roll that doesn't benefit, but sometimes, that is not a winning combination.  It seems that there is always one number that comes up more than its distribution warrants, and no way to strategize for that.
Resource collecting Euro-game.  Create trials and settlements and hope to God one of your numbers is rolled. Fun every once in a while. PLEASE, JUST ROLL AN 8, I NEED MORE BRICKS!
As I heard somewhere, the "Monopoly" of the 21st century. Go to game that everyone knows with a good balance of strategy, luck, and bartering.

The classic game that started the whole euro craze. This game should be played by everyone at least once. Granted other games have improved upon this one but they would not be around if it wasn't for Catan.
I like this, but tend to play it 2 player and the game is quite unbalanced for 2 players.
Not bad on its own. Add Seafarers and Cities&Knights, and the real fun starts ;)

I know, I know. A 7 really?!?! Hey, what can I say. We got introduced to this game later than most. It was one of the games I credit with getting my family into modern board games. We don't find it takes long to play even at 4 and my kids can be quite competitive with this one too, which is nice. It is a classic for a reason.
Very stress-free game. Little competition between friends. Definitely a classic everyone should own.
PROS: Straight forward rules, fun trading aspect. CONS: Too long for what it is! especially with 5-6 player expansion. COMMENT: Buy it! it's a really good game.
Definitely a game where the person who has the better strategy wins.
Settlers of Catan. The Seminal classic that brought the name Eurogame to the forefront and help eschew the Boardgames, beyond Monopoly, in to the popular culture.  Still worth playing

The gateway game to modern board gaming. Harvest, trade , expand. One downside to the game is there is no combat system. A price laid is where a price stays. Still a legend of a game, but does get grown out of.
I printed out my own version, worth just to learn a little bit about game design.
Staple of board games. It's great, it's simple, it's fun. People who hate lucky and randomness, might not like this.

Variable, partidas muy divertidas y otras donde el azar juega en contra y se hace lento hasta el final. En general lo más valorable es que siempre tienes algo que hacer, aunque vayas del último (si el azar no se buggea) siempre puedes dar la vuelta, sobre todo si los demás no te ven como amenaza.
Sin duda un juego de inicio excelente.
Also own several of the expansions.
A classic! :) Not one I generally choose to bring out, but I'm always happy to play.
Great intro game. Easy to teach easy to play. Good for kids

To be honest, I don't get why people are so against games that use dice. This game was the first modern board game I have played, which this game is a gateway game for most people, but it also has depth and strategy. People can have their opinions about games that focus on dice, but if that is your opinion, then opt to not play the game instead of forcing your opinion on others. Overall good game, but there are definitely others that I would prefer to play, especially after the hundreds of times that I have played this game.
The Grandaddy that started it all for me 10 years ago. Even if it's not the most balanced game at times I still enjoy it to this day
The Wife and I love this game

Why haven't I been playing Catan for years now?! This was the third modern board game I ever played and it's still just as much fun. I enjoy the trading and negotiating aspects and secret victories, because who knows how many victory points people are hiding in their development card pile! Definitely a keeper.   Update October 2018: I have slightly cooled on this game due to how swingy it can be based on dice rolls.
Got me in the door, our group has become too bitter to play this.  No-one will trade.
A now classic gateway game, the strategy comes from making smart settlement placements and good trades. The game is a little meaner than it leads onto forcing players into take that situations.

One of the new classics.  Definitely enjoyable, but can get heated very quickly.  Unfortunately, I always feel like your starting position heavily determines your success.  Despite this, almost always a good time.
They classic that got me in to the hobby.
I don't like trading. Catan always turns into a trading game.
Simple, fun, competitive. Very easy to get the game on the table.

I like this game (having only played it once, mind you! even then, it wasn't even my copy used!), and would play it again. Hopefully anyone else who plays with me won't attempt to make Stonehenge out of the pieces out of boredom!
This game can be amazingly fun. It can also be a slog if someone gets too much of an advantage early on.
The game that started a revolution. Still like it.
Fun for beginners. When you start leading, people will gang up on you.
A classic. Definitely teaches supply and demand concepts to younger players. Great when you have a group of people who know each other well.
Good gateway game but takes just a little too long to play for what it is.
A game I love and hate at the same time! I explain why here:  Just slightly tongue in cheek. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Ev2Av17nAe4&t=7s

After Monopoly and Risk, Catan is possibly the most well known board game. The gateway game for many of today's boardgamers, Catan is iconic. And while Catan is an excellent gateway game, it's just that, a gateway game. Most board game players will eventually grow tired of Catan and move on to more complex and newer games. But Catan retains a spot on their game shelf, fondly reminding the owner of past games with friends. We feel indebted somehow to the game, a first love with a special place in our hearts. And when it's time to introduce someone new to board games beyond Monopoly and Risk, Catan waits on the shelf - smooth, simple, easy to teach - ready to welcome a new gamer to the hobby.

My fiances family is mad about this game. But I'm terrible at remembering how to play so it always takes a while for me. It doesn't help that they have changed a few rules for their own play, which makes me just keeping the instructions close by useless.
Others might not like the luck element, but on average that should balance out and I see at least part of the game as how you manage that.
Still nice to play occasionally. Researching expansions is what led me down the board game rabbit hole, so Catan gets the credit/blame for that.
I enjoy the 2 player rules by Nick Borko
Obsoleted by many other, better games. Still give it my respect.
Great Game, especially for those new to board games!
Great fun and good family good.
Simply the family leisure board game. Still nice to play after all these years.
Great game, the Cities and Knights expansion makes it much more interesting.

How can you go wrong? It is THE resource management/worker placement game that is both gateway and staple of most boardgamer's experiences. Sure, there may be games that do things better and plays more smoothly, but they will never have what this game gives - fulfillment of nostalgia.
Good. but sometimes boring game. Too much luck involved. If not played with "Helpers of Catan" it becomes boring.
Fun and easy to explain to new players.
Fun, pretty simple game. All ages can get the gist of it. Would be better with more players. It's a rip off that they make you pay extra for that.
Reintroduced with Abe recently. Fun gateway.

One of the 'founding fathers' of modern board games.  Cata is straight forward, has a high level of interaction, and is compact.  That being said, starting position and early rolls have a HUGE impact on your chances to succeed.  This game is largely focused on dice rolls - so luck/randomness is a major element in Catan.  Catan isn't a fair game, but it's still quite a bit of fun due to resource trading interaction between players.
Love this game for the first few play throughs. It's very basic and can take forever to finish.
Always fun, no complaints. Aside from the fact that I apparently can't roll the numbers I need.  Ever.
Don't hate on Catan! The game is fun and relatively quick. Roll some dice, see what resources generate, first to 10 wins! Got any sheep? Will always have around in the collection.
*Most plays have been online so far due to 3 player minimum.
It is the obligatory game for collectors
Expansion: Catan: Seafarers Catan: Barbarians and Traders
Dice rolling, too much luck dependent for my liking.

Classic, willing to play if everyone knows what they're doing, but a bit too much RNG at times and people not paying attention can get annoying. "Does anyone have any..." "NO, the last two people just asked the same thing"  Don't really like being that guy

This is where my boardgaming hobby started from. A very good gateway game to the amazing world of tabletop gaming! Requires expansions to keep it interesting after a dozen plays. Despite the classic title it has, Catan suffers when compared to more modern games of its genre.
haven't played since 2009!  great gateway game in HS/College
good if you have players all at the same skill level.  otherwise can snowball based on the start.  still one of the original gateway games, and worth playing
It's a good game, and perhaps even more an important game for bringing Euros to the masses.  I like vanilla, but prefer at least one expansion.
(10/7) 6. A classic for good reason, it's an undeniably fun game.  I don't think it necessarily is the best thing out there anymore, but there's an unwarranted backlash.  (1/19) Raise to 7.
Was finally able to play this classic a few weeks ago. My comment is probably useless since it's such a classic, but for what it's worth: we had a blast playing it!
Perfecto, para lo que lo quieres. Es sencillo, competitivo, con muchas expansiones que lo enriquece.... está abierto a tus modificaciones como el de reducir el factor suerte en los dados
Clearly a good game.  I always try and start open trading but it never happens.  I play just to build goodwill with fellow gamers that I can cash in later in more competitive games.

[b]Like:[/b] -Simplicity for what it achieves -Trading -Building stuff and receiving more stuff for it -Many people know this game  [b]Dislike:[/b] -Robber -Having multiple turns without anything to do because your numbers didn't get rolled  The game I played the most before I really got into board gaming. I mean, what other game lets you build towns and cities, and gain increasingly more resources when you do so while also allowing you to negotiate with others; am i r8?! No wonder I considered this a masterpiece at the time.  If Dead of Winter has the meanest dice of all time, Catan probably has the meanest gaming piece of all time: the Robber. This little sh*t used to make the people I played with literally cry. Luckily, we all kinda realised this and only put it in someones place if that guy was far ahead.  Also, going through multiple rounds without getting anything just sucks, especially if all the others get huge amounts.  Catan: Cities & Knights is absolutely required for me to enjoy this game though.  While I'd rather play other games now, it still's got the advantage of being the simplest build, receive more and trade game I know of. Be careful not scare the new-lings away from the hobby with the robber though!
A great classic. Always fun to play with. Offer and demand of the sheep^^

Not a bad little game. Placement and die rolls can kill you, but as long as the map is not overcrowded usually you can give it a good go. Negotiation is not a "bad" feature as long as everyone knows the game and knows how to wisely negotiate. Playing with someone who gives another player whatever they want or because they are charismatic will kill it though.
A classic.  I think it's a little chess-like, in that good players who know the opening can gain an advantage.  But with a modular set up there's a lot of replayability.
Good game to play as a starter
Good starter Euro game for the hobby. Lots of available expansions.
Great gateway, yet a bit boring without the expansions.
I love Catan, it was one of the first games I played (excluding Monopoly), it doesn't get played as often as I like as always playing newer games.
Ahhh catan. My wife had me playing this before I thought board games were fun. It’s a good light weight game, but like most I’ve moved on to better things.
ボードゲームするなら一度はやっとけゲーム。 交渉とダイスがこのゲームの醍醐味だが、ガチになると交渉ではな港ゲーになる。 私にとってはそこがマイナスポイント。
Played about 8-10 times before logging plays.
3-4 players, best with 4  Old faithful.  Remains a solid game, even if it's not very sexy after all that's come afterwards.
Challenging strategy game.  It is possible to be competitive in most games.  Hex and number placement can cripple you occasionally.
Too often end up with poor choice of starting location and bad luck with dice rolls. Generally build board completely randomly. Fun with a balanced board.
Game the reignited might interest in board gaming.  Love the simplicity and level of interaction with fellow gamers.
The grandfather. Still nice, but is starting to smell...
Enjoy playing this solo on the app.  Hesitant to play this with friends because we might be too competitive.
nothing great, but i can play if better options are not available
Classic build/resource gathering game. A good introduction to the genre for beginners. Artwork and design are a bit simplistic but I guess this is why it’s popular among fellow casual gamers!

Played this one with a couple of expansions. I'm not sure whether this would be that interesting without expansions. It's rather enjoyable game, you do really need to strategize pretty well. A downside is that it can be pretty brutal, especially if you don't have a good numbers and this can really suck. As well, with more players, it can take quite long to wait for your turn.
my kids like the game, easy to play and learn.
Was my gateway game. This was my first game that I played that helped me transition from my favorite game being Monopoly to the vast collection of boardgames my family has now.
Best with: 4 players Real time: 120 minutes Teach time: 5 minutes
Great game with a dry theme.
Our first Eurogame, everyone enjoys it. Good gateway to designer games.
Great game, the only downside is it does go on a little long, says 60-120 but we fine that 60 is a near impossibility and 120 seems more about the target
This was the game that got me into gaming. I've kind of left it behind now, as I find it a little too indirectly competitive, but will usually be willing to play.

Lucky? Maybe. Frustrating? Occasionally. But really fun. Elegant mechanics plus an engaging trade element. I can readily see why it's such a classic. After my first play, I was excited to play more. After the next few plays, I was ready to get back to playing the many eurogames I like more than Catan. I think maybe the age of Catan has passed. It's a shame I couldn't play it when it was a more revelatory experience, but at least it's still a nice time.
Игронайзер для "Колонизаторов" и расширения для 5-6 игроков http://myhobbyhour.blogspot.ru/2017/11/blog-post.html
One of my first boardgames. My hole family likes it.

When I brought it, I just moved to Japan for study aboard. I ever had my game group back in Thailand so I really missed that moment. I found this old version of Catan in used section of game store in unused condition, the previous owner just unsealed it but not even put tiles out of the package.  I decide to use this game to encourage my colleagues to play game and it is worked!!! Since then, we usually have gaming night 2-6 times a month. Even though, Catan don't come back to the table that frequent, it has special place in my mind :D

I didn't want to rate this classic game too low, because I love this game if the right conditions are met, and that is it NEEDS the Seafarers expansion. Or another expansion that includes the water tiles, because I enjoy the boating and exploring aspects of the river expansions so much more than the core game. With one of the expansions that includes the water tiles, this is a 9 easy.
A good game. Would def recommend
Fun, but I feel like its too simple and RNG based.
A good gateway game, but a lot of luck is involved

Catan is a gateway drug for board games that has outlived its original shine. Dice rolls create irreparable imbalance, trading is too fickle, and getting locked out of possibly win conditions can happen early with no reprieve. You usually know who will win based on initial settlement placement.

I am not crazy about collecting everything there is 'Catan', but I have used this game to pull family members from all around into gaming in the past. It really does work as a good intro in to the hobby.  The 5th player expansion is worth the purchase.

The "mother" of all euro-games perhaps??  There are a lot of games out there now that are better, but I still like this one. I mainly play it with the Cities and Knights expansion though. A fantastic starter game for new board gamers.

what can i say about SoC that hasn't been said before. The game that showed the world what games could be. Yes it was not the first big game but it was one of the first mass market games. Great to introduce new players to, I'd highly recommend picking up one of the expansions (I like merchants and  pirates) to turn it into a more engaging experience for the seasoned player.

I finally got round to buying and playing this old warhorse. I was afraid it would be too simple and boring for the family. This is an excellent game to get people who enjoyed Monopoly to play something more advanced, while you dont die of boredom. It gets 2 extra stars just because of that.

Ah! Catan, the game that started it all, right? I will never say no to a game of Settlers and its expansions. For what it is — a game for both family and serious play — it scores a 9, I suppose. However, I knocked it down to 7 for my tastes because I believe the game requires the expansions to fulfill my stronger game desires; I now prefer playing with both the Seafarers and Cities & Knights expansions, with 19 points to win, to make an epic game session.

I did not try Catan until very late in my boardgame journey\lifecycle. I had planned Lisboa, Terra Mystica a long time before I sat down for the first game of this. My expectations weren't too high since you always hear some gamers go "Oh Catan" and some complaint about the game. (Has not aged well, too random etc.)  Pleasantly surprised by the game - personally, I think its just the right amount of randomness - the fun kind. Even 20+ years after its release, the design does not feel old. Do yourself a favour and give it a go if you haven't already.

A real classic. Can play this one anytime.

Catan has comfortably established itself as a classic board game. The original game is well constructed, and in general players will find this game very replayable. The length and complexity of the game suits most gamers and casual parties. For the true Catan fanatic there are dozens of expansions and spinoffs to add variety of the well established formula. If you want to play Catan, but you only have 2 players, pick up the card game Rivals for Catan instead. While probably not the most exciting or captivating board game in your collection, Catan is a great option that most players will be excited to play time and time again.
A solid, classic game. Fun to bring out amongst enthusiasts, but is a bit overplayed for a regular game night. This is a good entry game to more strategic board games for casual gamers.
Do not own, but play within our game group
If you're reading this, you've already played Catan; basically everyone has. But it's famous for a reason, and a great way to introduce people to board games.
Playing Time: 120 Age: 10+, 8+ Complexity: 2.3 Players: 3-4, best 4
This game is showing its age a bit, but it's still good and is still hard to beat as a gateway game into the hobby.
A good game that certainly deserves it's fame. Tends to get a bit repetitive after a few games.
Another great game.  I usually like hex style and trading games and this covers both of those.  Way to go Catan Creators.

A good starter game to get into the hobby.  Fun and simplistic while allowing players to work on their building strategy skills for more complicated games.  The downside is that the base game only supports four players.  You have to make sure the board looks like it is going to be fair for all players and make sure everybody agrees or some players are going to have a miserable time throughout the game.
Played it a lot, always fun, but it's a dice game so your fate is tied to it.
A classic and a must-have. Not the best for hardcore (esnob?) gamers, but a great choice for the right group.
A classic! This is the game I've used to get people into gaming in the past, though now many years later it feels a little basic. Still a solid game that's always fun.
Brand new, opened but never used
Good and easy to play game.  Its major down for me is that you must play it with minimum 3 players (sometimes you cannot get the third one!)

There is no way that this game deserves the hate it gets. While it may not be a fresh out of the furnace New York pizza, it sure isn't airplane pizza either. It's a solid entry level game made for people to play and have a nice time talking and laughing at bad/good dice rolls. It's about being the "King of the Bricks" or the evil road bandit who cuts everyone off. It's a game where you remind your friend about that one time you helped him recover from a drunken stupor so he should give you some ore.   While it may be annoying to lose dice roll after dice roll or to see someone become insanely rich, the game isn't about being perfectly balanced as all things should be. It's comparing Hearthstone to Magic the Gathering. Hearthstone is simpler and based around RNG and if you don't accept that, you'll tilt and hate the game.

a pleasant group evening- the basic journey to 10 VP is achievable by beginners. Addons make it increasingly complex in a Talisman like way. everyone wishes for the ability to have a bit of direct PvP conflict occasionally.

I like this classic game, but there are aspects of it that annoy me. The location of your starting cities has outside affect on who will win the game; with many players the last one(s) to place their second city can be at a disadvantage. I also don't like the fact that you can just "buy" a victory point.

I'm not usually a fan of dice rolling games, but Catan does it very well.  Trading allows you to mitigate your risk and, while there are times luck can turn against you, the robber helps balance this.
A classic, but I don't like the randomness of the two dice. I'd suggest playing with a deck of 36 cards for the different dice results, instead of the dice.

Kind of the modern standard for board games. This is the game they were selling at target next to Hasbro/MB titles before CAH re-popularized tabletop in the wider market. Simple, modular resource management game with a lot of depth. The only drawback is it can be easy for someone to run away with the game early, but securing the win still takes a long while.
not a fan of how random the resource generation feels

A classic. Albeit slow, and heavily luck based. But...  A few changes and house rules, change the game for the better.  1. Use the better settlers app for set up 2. Combine #'s (2&3) and (11&12) on the respective hexes. (Make your own token of you must and put 3 dots for probability) 3. Robber doesn't get activated for 2 turns. 4. When a 7 is rolled (or drawn[see#7 on this list]) that player gets to roll or draw again, if another 7, then ignore it and then next persons turn. So the person rolling a 7 gets another production roll, in order to get the game moving. 5. Victory point cards have to be automatically revealed. Or remove victory point cards all together (preferred) and decrease points to 8 or 9. (Last few rounds become a drag when more players involved, and victory point cards cause a very unclimactic win). 6. Print the harbor master card (2 points for the most harbor settlements, and you need 3 harbor points to attain it [a city counts as two and a settlement counts as 1]) and use it like the longest road card.  And additionally a player can't have all 3 of the cards (longest road, largest army, and harbor master) if a player at any point does acquire all 3 they have to choose which 2 to keep. 6. 20 second timer on trades. 7. Get rid of the dice and build a deck of cards using 2 deck of playing cards. Shuffle and draw each turn. When five 7's are drawn, reshuffle. (Build the deck: Put in six-7's, five-6&8 each, four-5&9 each, three-4&10 each, two-11&3 each and one-2&12 each ( 3 if you combine 2&3 and 11&12). 8. On a 5 or more player game, get rid of the special build phase and increase robber threshold fo 8 for 5 players, 9 for 6 players.
Good game. Initial placement is key! Sometimes I may get a little to competitive when playing this one..

There isn't much to say about this one, but the dice are actually really bad in it. I find it essential to use the event cards from the Traders and Barbarians expansion so that I'm not cursing my luck all game. It's quite possible that the benefit these cards give me is entirely psychological, but I'll keep using them all the same.
Classic but just not get to table
One of the games that introduced me to the hobby. That is why it remains in my collection.
I appreciate how this game brought gaming to the general public.  But winning is too reliant on dice rolls and other people's choices for my taste.
Still entertaining as a family game. Arriving at 10 points when playing with four takes too much time though!
I get that some people don't like the "luck of the dice" that success in this game relies on.  But most of us loved this game the first time we played it.  Very easy to teach.
A bit light for my taste and too much luck but quite replayable. Upgraded Meeplesource Robber.have only played this 6 player, would like to try with just 4 as drags a little at 6.

Irony. Disappointing at first but not because of the game.  I was told in college that Catan is too complicated for me and the second time I tried, it wasn't explained very well. So, I felt discouraging to play. Catan did seem too complicated. Determined that it must be fun, I bought the game and taught myself how to play. Then, I found a new set of friends- it was indeed fun.   Then, it got frustrating...  In my gaming group, the seasoned players are more cutthroat, not willing to trade very much, making the game  feeling like the only way to win is to stay in second and pretend that you are losing. I shelved Catan until I got E&P. Much better.  I would rate Catan a 6, but the E&P moves it to the next level- 7.  .:Best 3-4:.  -- Expansion // The Fishermen- Expands the board spaces to the edge, literally, and with the harbormaster, it's another path to victory. // Explorers & Pirates- robber is less punishing, more traveling.
This would get an eight-star if I hadn't played a thousand and sixteen times.
Man, this game get repetitive after 100 games in as many nights... :)
Long time to set up. With 5 players it takes a while. Couldn't do what I wanted on such a confined space. Constantly getting blocked.

Catan (base-game, no expansions) is actually Quite Great. There is highly interactive board play, tasteful application of randomness (luck "scales with skill" and doesn't dwarf skill -- i.e. as player skill increases the percentage of wins thrown by chance remains constant.) The game has the minimal amount of rules necessary to give the various resources character and you even get a bit of subtle diversification and shared incentives.  Initial settlement placement is a bit too consequential and chaotic for me to consider this game top-tier.
Not a bad game, a bit too much luck though.

I like Catan, especially if we're playing casually. You can have a longer / more serious game too, but it doesn't have to be; it's up to you how competitive you want to be. I find that a lot of today's games are very convoluted, and I'm not a fan of that; I have a lot more fun with the simpler strategy games like Catan. I also like that it's very easy to learn, so you can start playing right away.
I have a love hate with this game. I like that there is some strategic play, but can't stand the shit luck some players get when the low/high numbers come up. 80% luck, 20% strategy.
Catan is a great entry level board game.  Nice tactical and strategic opportunities, and fun to play.  It just gets a little dry over time, with each game feeling very similar.
There's a decent amount of randomness, but I find that there's usually enough additional ways to combat it if the dice don't go your way.

won firsta time, then lost every singel time after LOL. my brother and wife try to ruin for me every time we play, but I still enjoy playing this, but need to get better at mess with people in this :)
Not my favourite by played alot by my wife and mother. I not a fan of dice as they can be loaded.

I like this, but the group is tired of it.

= 2012-05-21  The game that started it all. Some friends introduced us to this game in January of 2012 and now I have a BGG account, two shelves of board games and a wishlist that grows by three for every one I remove.  I won't say we've "moved on" from this game, but it hasn't had much play since being used as a gateway game. I blame this on us mostly wanting to play two player games and there are just so many better two player games out there than any two player variant of Catan.  = 2014-02-14 - R:6.99  Happy Valentine's Day. In sticking with the theme for the day, I'd like to share some love for this game. I gave it a 6 because, on the official BGG scale, it's a game I admire but would only play when in a certain mood. That mood is more situational than anything. There are many times when my wife and I want to play a game together and we'd like that game to have the feel of Catan, but so far we haven't been able to capture that feel in a two player game. When we do have enough people over to be able to play a four player game, I rarely want to play board games. So poor Catan never makes it to our table even though I think I want to play it. In honor of how much Catan influences our search for other games, I'm bumping the rating from 6 to 6.99.

El inicio de los Eurogames en mi grupo se llevo a cabo con este juego. Imprescindible para iniciarse. Mucho mejor a 4 que a 3.  Feb 2010: Baja de 7.8 a 7 por comparativa con Stone Age, que aunque no tiene comercio, me parece que es más útil como "gateway game" actual.
Own 5-6 player expansion and Explorers & Pirates.

Mindenki ismeri. Sokan szeretek, sokan gyűlölik. Nem egy gamer játék, inkább egy pehelykönnyű bevezető. Nem szabad azt hinni, hogy több van benne annál, mint, hogy ki dob jobban, mert akkor csalódik az ember.

堅実なゲーム。いくつか点数の取り方があり、運もあり、交渉もあり・・・でも、それに慣れるまで時間がかかる。まだ回数を重ねていないので、毎回何かのルールを間違える。たとえば、街を建てる場所、７の処理のカード上限。堅実なゲームであるので、ルール間違えがあると自分の中では、失敗と思ってしまう。統計データで、プレイの難易度も2.4もある。やはり、初心者にはルールが多い。 もう一つ、やはりダイスの運に泣かされるのがキライ。上級者は最初の段階で最適な場所とりが完了しているので、面白いかもしれないが、初心者はそれも良くわからない。上級者は、最初の陣地とりが頭を使う・・・というが、言い換えれば、この陣地とりで決まり、あとはおまけ？なのだろうか、と思ってしまう。

i don't itch to toss dice and i'm not driven to trade sheep, but for some (other) reason i have lately been craaaving a catan night. it's probably that i yearn to drop roads and plunk down settlements. there's just something about the physical network of buildings between hexes that gives me a contentment not unlike a craftsman enjoying the results of his latest accomplishment.  [i]how much do i want to play this game? (via bgg ratings)... 6.0 = "haven't played in a while but remember fondly" 6.5 = "will readily play, hoping that rating will go up" 6.9 = "lack of reliable table time drags this rating down" 7.0 = "usually a quick 'yes!' if this game is suggested" 7.5 = "let's play this unless you have a better idea?" [/i]
I'll play 3 or 5 players. Hesitant to play 4 or 6 players because it almost always seems like one or two players get cut off from being able to build on the board and end up not having fun.
Hadde det mye kjekt med dette i barndommen. Gode minner med Miriam og Yathika i Deknepollen.
It's a good entry level Euro.  It's basically solely responsible for the modern boardgame resurgence (apologies to those who have been here the entire time).
Simple to teach, plays go smoothly from the second round as players adapt.
NIS: We played this a lot (maybe too much, and all the expansions...)

A classic for a reason. The resource collection and trading are really charming.  The biggest negatives are the amount of luck in the dice rolls can kill your flow of resources; and where you initially place your settlements can lose the game for you.  I agree with the Broken Meeple that the Seafarers expansion basically completes the game.
Gateway game where your best chance to win is be in second place when everyone gangs up on the person in first.

While the father of modern board gaming it is not a perfect game, let's be honest. It's cutthroat at times and very chancy. But, it got me interested in board games to some degree and set my expectations for exciting themes pretty low. I will play this willingly as an alternative if someone doesn't want to get too thinky but it is not one I want to play more than once or twice a year.

I still occasionally enjoy playing Catan, though there are a ton of better games out there by now, I can still accept to play this if it what other people want. The negotiation and trading aspect of the game is still enjoyable and for some reason is still not copied by too many other games.
I think I've probably played this game, like, a bajillion times in my life.
Classic game destined to be remembered and played for decades by all sorts of gamers.  An excellent intro game for folks to the "German style" of board-games.
Great game!  It's a classic, I don't play it much anymore, there are other games I prefer.  For it's time, considering the hobby, it was revolutionary.
Great fun with this game. Luck is a factor, but not usually to the extent that it determines a winner. That last victory point is often the result of a smart trade. Great player interaction.
It's a classic game, with a significant amount of luck. (which is too much in this case)There are several games I like more.
Didn't grab me, but I'm willing to give it another try.  ----  Date: July 2006 Price: $31.95
The rate goes to 7.5 without the dices. That expansion of cards is so nice !!!
For trade or sale, played a few times (this is not the copy that has 51 plays).

Finally own - gift from a friend.  I've played a few times, and I can see how this would be an attractive gateway game to the Eurogame.    I am not a huge fan of trading games, so this is a lower ranked game for me.

The board is modular.  That's great isn't it?  More replayability!  Well....yes and no.  No two game setups are the same.  I like that a lot as there is no set strategy; you have to adapt to the game at hand.  Even with that though, the game is starting to feel like a lot of the same thing.  Maybe an expansion will liven things up again for me?  I did really like it the first dozen or so times I played it.  We'll see...
Family game. I am not too fond of the element of luck inherent in it.

Great building game.  Easy to teach kids.  The game simplicity is an overall plus, but it also makes the game stale quickly if played repetitively.  Also, games can be "ruined" by too many poorly distributed die rolls.
My first real boardgame.  A 10 out of 10 at the time but as I grow as a gamer this score keeps slipping.  To much chance.  Only game where you can literally loss before you even start.
Own this game for years prior to becoming a BGG member. 50+ plays probably closer to 100.
Great teaching game to introduce people to euro-style economic board games. However, without the excuse of new players being at the table it's not one I'm likely to play.

Played this one to death as a younger man.  I still like it but it's prone to leaving players with long periods of being unable to do anything.  The Seafarer expansion adds a lot of replay value to it.
Classic entry level game.  Great for introducing people to the hobby and fun to play once in a while.
Played the original version this time, and the cards were v hard to make out. [Sleeves:  fit perfectly Max Protection Neo Sleeves 82mm x 56mm  5818870598 item 7050B 8256]
Had a lot of fun with Settlers, but became bored after a while. Best game for introducing players to the genre.
One of the classics! Very good game. a must buy if you don't mind all the dice rolling!
This is was brought me into the world of board games. It doesn't scratch the same itch it used to, now that I've experienced so much else. That being said it still holds a special place in my heart.
It's fine. There are better games out there, but many of my non-gamer friends always want to "try" Catan.
+ City and Knights  iOS as well
Basic game, works wonders with the right group that do not take too seriously the optimization of the game, but still a bit far from being completely engaging with most of the groups I play.
A classic but getting a little tiring.

One snow week in January 2011 we had a week of playing the classics (Settlers, Alhambra, Princes of Florence, and Louis XIV). We pulled Settlers off the shelf and played it again. We had a great time relearning the rules and enjoying the game again.   The game is a simple medium weight game. The game is very luck driven due to the roll of the die and resource collection.

Not terribly impressed with the box and component quality.  The frame and tiles always pop up at one corner or another and are thinner and less rigid than I have seen in other games.  Quality would suggest a much lower SRP than $40.  Rather than being about building roads, settlements, etc, the games seems to be more about buying the development cards since you can build your army and collect free VPs.  Also, the robber is a little too powerful and comes into play too frequently.  I want to love this game and will keep playing it, but these features seem to cause a little too much tension at the table.

2010: An absolute classic, and still one of the best-balanced games I have ever played. Improved greatly by the addition of Cities and Knights, though the base game is well-worth playing. Rated 7.5  EDIT 2017: Played again ecently, boy this one is starting to show its age. Dropped rating to 6.75

This game was what got the whole board-game madness started. While it's still a bit too dice-driven for my liking, I still play it with friends almost once a week and enjoy it very much.   While it might only deserve 8/10 geekles, I have it a +1 for being close to my heart.  Settle on!

I changed my January 2011 rating of 7.9 down to 6.75 on 5/4/16, to reflect what I have been telling people for years - this is an excellent "gateway drug" game for getting people into the board gaming hobby, but it just isn't that much fun to me any longer.  A combination of expansionism and rolling dice, with a rudimentary card system on the side, this game is lean and mean.  Expand your abstract cities and roads based on the accrual of 4 resources; and do so in a way that makes life harder for the other folks on the board.  Many fundamental Euro game principles at play here, and thus many prospective gamers find it to be delightful.   (Written 5/4/16)
Everyone should own this, just to teach the family

Like for many people, this was my gateway game; I remember holding the rulebook for the first time and thinking how impressive it was that any game could have so much material to learn.  I had a lot of fun with the game and introducing it to all my friends allowed me to bring them into the hobby with me.  Now, the game only gets played occasionally.  Is it a good game?  I think so, I guess, but I don't feel particularly compelled by it anymore.  I may have become too familiar with it, and maybe the same thing would happen with some of my current favourites if I were to play them as much and as often as I did Catan, but I have a feeling the games that I now rank among the best have a little something, or maybe a few things, that Catan just doesn't bring to the table.

Started slow, and then we kept rolling sevens, but we all enjoyed it.  Lately it has started falling flat, especially with slow play from the kiddos.  Would probably be more fun with adults who know what they are doing.

Catan's pretty much the game that everyone gravitates to once they go past 'classics' like Monopoly, Cluedo or Risk. It's a game that while I do enjoy playing, grinds me a lot. Once you know you're just not going to win, it's a 30-60 minute grind of rolling, trading and building in a futile attempt to salvage something from a lost position. It is a good game though, I just have many better games to choose in a situation where Catan would be played.
Get Sleeves: Ultra Pro: Board Game (Light Pink) 54x80mm: x3 (120)

This is the game that got back in board gameing. Still the fall on game for my family. Update 12/9/16: Getting old for me but my daughter's absolute favorite so grudgingly Will remain in collection. I can play it still but only for her.
Got me into gaming, and I think I've overplayed it. I love it, but no game has made me angrier while playing. Probably won't buy, but wouldn't mind playing occasionally.
A classic that has held up over time.

Who I play this with:  I played this with my Fiancée and her brother a few times before I started getting more modern games. Used to play this a lot with family friends back in the day.  When & what I bought:  This is one of the first games I got in late 2017/early 2018 when I started developing the collection - just before I started really researching modern board games and realized how much this was out of date...  What makes this game unique for me:  I used to love this and play it a lot with family friends. However, I don't want to play it anymore because Ticket to Ride, Mission: Red Planet or Downforce (just to name a few) are way better Gateway games. Plus, a lot of people own this so I'll get a chance to play it when I'm at other people's place.  Rating & classification:  6.75/10 - consider culling  This isn't a bad game, but it's outdated. I have better gateway games. This will probably be one of the first "yellows" to turn into a "red" because I feel like I'm just through with it.
not standing the test of time.

--05Aug2004-- Bumped down to 7 due to increasing grumpiness with the effect of roll distributions on results.  While this is a really good gateway game - particularly for people that have been exposed to classic roll&move fare - there simply aren't enough rolls of the dice in a given game to even out a typically lumpy distribution.  As a result, a theoretically 'good' play can easily fail to be rewarded.  In the face of superior competition, then; there are other things that I would rather play.  ++ >20 unlogged plays. ++
Decent enough game.Innovative mechanisms.Why it attracts do much praise though I dont know.
Purchased From Best Dang Games on 03/02/09
不交易就了无生趣的游戏。但是，中国玩家并不喜欢交易，于是变为一个卡死人的游戏。
Fun game Too much hasard for my taste Some extension are very good (seaferers) and other very bad (City and Knight)
If you need a description I ask are you in the right place ? :)
First modern game owned. Played hundreds of times. Just finally got tired of it after owning so many other Euros. Don't like the randomness and luck in the rolls. Curse that 7!

It's a staple. But there are so many games that feed the same appetite with more flare and nuance. I usually try to steer our play group away from this, but never regret playing. I've never felt the need to purchase this game, especially since there are already two copies of it in our core game group. This game will likely stand the test of time.
Zurecht eines der erfolgreichsten Teuber Spiele. Es eignet sich sowohl als Familienspiel, als auch Spiel für ambitioniertere Spieler.

Good intro game for non-gamers. Easy to learn. Simple mechanics. Luck does play a heavy role (although there are some mitigation measures one can take). The modular board offers some re-playability, but might lose its lustre in the long run. I still consider it a fun game ... unless you're blocked off, with poor resources.

Excellent gateway game (in fact, it was *my* gateway!) as new folks seem to 'get' the game quickly and really enjoy it. The more I play however I find it a bit too random for the time involved and can be very frustrating in some games with the robber or bad rolls.

An excellent game in it's day (first game to get a 10/10 in Arcane magazine iirc). And yeah, it's still a decent game, but I think that there are about 4 or 5 games just of the top of my head that I would seek to play over this.
Good for what it is.  But just kind of dull for me.  Need to try the newer ruleset where you can do more on other's turns.

The game that started the Euro game revolution and even brought you the "I have wood for your sheep" t-shirt. Wal-mart now carries this game which makes it somewhat passe. Its a good game for a new gamer to play ... but there is a point where you graduate to better.

Juego muy aclamado, pero que para mi gusto no tiene tanto que ofrecer. Es cierto, se tiene control en varias decisiones, donde colocar tus asentamientos y expandirte, pero hay partidas que definitivamente las probabilidades te juegan tan mala pasada que sientes que no tienes control de nada, el rezago del último jugador es bastante triste.  Eso si, no es aburrido, es un buen juego para 4 jugadores de duración media, aunque creo que si durara 1 hora cumpliría mejor su rol, con duraciones de 1 hora y 30 o 2 horas pierde gracia.
A gateway game. Ive seen some drama come from the game, but it is worth it. Great design and balance meet simplicity. Prettier in original german printing than american.
Classic game, great for introducing new people to Euro games since it can be learned in minutes and mastered after relatively few games.
Good gateway game. Quite popular. Fun to play. Does have a bit too much luck element in the dice rolls but offers some mechanics to mitigate that. Not perfect but I do enjoy it.
Great game, but getting those bad dice rolls can be a pain in the A%$.

Still one of the best "gateway" games if you're trying to branch out from Sorry, Monopoly, Clue, or party games.  Over time if you find that you love this game and start playing more Euros, you may find that the luck element in Catan can occasionally make the game miserable for someone playing. The rich get richer if you are left far behind by bad dice rolling, and don't gain any resources, and are then not someone anyone wants to trade with. This chain reaction can lead to someone watching everyone else play Settlers of Catan.   That said, this was the game that launched me into Eurogames, and I'll always play it with a group of new initiates to the hobby.
A very well designed game, except for being a bit boring. There is a lack of intensity in the game.
Good game to pass the time.
It released at the beginning of a real boardgame-hype here in Europe nad I played it quiet often - I don't know many other games I can play also with kids and won't be bored to tears.
Minority opinion:  I don't like this as much as most people.  Glad it started the German game craze though.
Quick playing and clean mechanics. Still trying to get your friends into eurogaming? This should fit the bill.
Simple, yet fun.  Expandable.  Easy to explain.  Good for non geeks.
A bit overrated, but I'm usually up for a game.
Good game for beginners, a little bit annoyng for trained gamers. If played with a little of badness is more funny. Not bad at all.

Over 100 plays, much because the military leisure place had a Danish copy when I served back in 97-98. I loved it then, and it is the very reason I am into boardgames today. I don't play much anymore though. The dice are ok, but the cards annoy me. Play with 4 - no more, no less.
Could change rating if played more often
It's been a family gaming staple for years. Quite frankly, I'm sick of it. Burnout syndrome. At least in its basic form. Still, it's a milestone. My rating reflects that ambivalent feeling of mine.

This is a great game with a high replay value that has only diminished slightly over time for me. I'd say it relies a bit too heavily on chance for my tastes, but the random playing field and strategies of placement and trading make for an overall excellent game that is especially fun with the 5-6 player expansion.
this was my intro to eurogames.  I loved it.  Lost some of its luster b/c of the large dice-rolling luck factor.  Still fun and good for some player interaction.
I loved this game when I first played it, but am totally "settlered out" now.  Originally I rated it an 8, but have dropped my rating since.
It needs to be played with the right people
This game gets dull after you play it too many times. Trading, nice. Rolling dice over and over and hoping for something to come up, not so fun.
Simple mechanics make this an enjoyable game of fast moving resource collection, trading & purchasing.
Hardly ever gets played now that there are so many other more interesting games.

Another one that everyone else seems to have played to death which makes it a little harder to get it picked for a new player like me.  Update: After the initial rush this is far less likely to hit the table now. I know it's one of THE games that got us all into new board games, but for me there a lot of other stuff on my shelf I would rather play

Guess I've just played this one out.  It comes out on occasion, but it just doesn't have enough to hold my attention.  My new and casual players seem to really like it, so it's still on the shelf and not relegated to the basement (where all games go to die)
In 1995, this game was revolutionary, but now, all of it's innovations have been internalized and surpassed by so many other games, I don't think there's much point in playing it anymore.
For gameplay I give it an 8; because it is so damn frustrating to play, I give it a final rating of 6.5.  This may be generous because I doubt I will ever play this for fun.
Gets a huge bump for historical purposes, as well as for fond memories.  Likelihood of play in the future is rather low.
Good introductory game for non gamers.
Too luck, but lots of variants and house rules.
A decent game, but the luck of the die rolls can certainly swing the outcome.  We tried the two-player variant and were unimpressed.
First euro game I bought.  It was my absolute favourite, but unfortunately it's wearing thin now :|  Alas, to have loved and lost...
Again, not my favorite game, but I've had many enjoyable hours with friends over the hex-shaped pieces and their merciless numbers. The quintessential "bridge" game.

Played 3 times 3-player and several times on the computer. Very fun resource and building game with good interaction between players (trading, vying for prime building locations). Luck does play a part as dice are definitely at play. Ideal for 3 or 4 players.
A classic - but i have no desire to play anymore. It introduced me to the world of eurogames so i am grateful for that.

At first I tought this game was excellent, but nowadays I think this game isn't that good as most people say it is. It is entertaining, that's true, but not very challenging. There's just too much luck involved in this game. The one thing I hate about the game is the trading. It only makes the players with the best cards (possibly due to lucky rolls) even stronger. This doesn't seem fair to me considering the players who had a bad start. Playing without trading would give this game an 8 rating. With the trading it's only a 6.
Catan is a classic game and I like it. But I do think it is a little bit dry.
Great game - introduced to "German style boardgames" by this one.
Fun, but too lucky dependent and somehow cahotic
I don't play so often any more, but in the day...lots of plays. And I had lots of fun. I usually play(ed) with the Food Stamp Variant, as bad rolls can really kill the enjoyment level on this game.
Always playable, but with consistantly deminishing enjoyment. It'll soon be one of those "once-every-couple-months" games.
Kind of bored by it.  Not fond of the dice rolling.  Prefer playing with 3 players rather than 4 so that 1 person does not get totally hemmed in right away.
A classic for its time, but honestly in this day and age there are so so many other great games out there. Don't know why anyone would need to own this if they didn't already.
this game will start more fist fights than monopoly.

Wasn't our first, but can decidedly say it was the original, and memorable game. Nothing too difficult about the game overall, just lots of fun. The trading aspect of this one set off some internal game night rules that are always applied to other games.
I'm a little underwhelmed by this game so far. It makes me wonder what all of the hype has been about. Maybe it's due to it's pioneering impact.....
Nice game, but it is a little limited and boring if you get stuck with the wrong placement.

A friend from church got my flatmates and I into this at the end of September 2004. Since then we spent a few months playing it once a fortnight at his place although we progressed to the [gameid=926] expansion after he got it in early March 2005. I'm not really interested in playing the base game anymore unless it's to teach someone (or to play with someone that won't get/enjoy the addition of Cities & Knights).

Still a good game, but these days I have to really want to play it to enjoy it. Got overplayed a huge amount when it first came out and I consider there to be better games available today. Still enjoyable to teach newcomers to the idea of Eurogames though.
