Great game, but can be very frustrating if you don`t get any resources. Have played it to death, by the way. Wifey`s rating: 6

For a Euro type game, there is luck involved.  Although the trade mechanic is fun, it really is all about selecting the best location to establish your towns/cities.  If your numbers don't come up often, then you will quickly fall behind.  Initial placement, luck of the die and cards make a very large difference at the start of the game, but can be compensated via inter-player trade.
The game that started it all - the Eurogame pioneer. Still holds up to plays, and trading mechanic works well. A bit too long and mechanical for my taste when it drags on for longer than it should.
Great game.  This was my gateway.  It only needs something more... something to do with cities... perhaps some knights?

A classic that deserves its place in history. Becomes quite nice with the Castles and Knights extension but some sessions were quite traumatizing (dice not giving 6 or 8 for more than 60 minutes for example).

Despite all the criticism here on BGG, I generally enjoy this game.  One can see immediately why it is considered the quintessential gateway game: it has loads of player interaction and involvement and with resource collection and trading occurring for everyone each turn, everyone stays engaged.  I particularly like that the momentum builds as the game progresses, and when there is not a runaway leader, it is sometimes not clear who will win as the end approaches.  Settlers is clearly a classic deserving of all of its fame.  Having said that, with time I have downgraded my rating from an 8 to a 6.5, as dependency on the dice rolls make's it difficult to control one's destiny, and there sometimes can be a real runaway leader problem.

This still easily one of the cheapest games I got when considering cost per play.  However, even though I have played this hundreds of times, it has been over one or two years (currently 2010) since I have played it and I have no desire to pull it out again.  This was my gateway game though and I will forever be grateful to it for converting me to such a great hobby.

I'm not sure my version is the 3rd edition.  Inside the rulebook it says copyright 1997 & 1999.  However, I bought this between 2001-2002 so it's definitely not the next version.  My copy has a SDJ for Germany in 1995 and game of the year in the US in 1996.
Very inconsistent plays, but overall still enjoyable.

Odd that so many Eurogamers who seem to despise random elements are so infatuated with Settlers. This has just a little dice-rolling, which ensures that the effect of chance is huge. Bad runs on the six-siders can destroy any good plan -- and there's not too much you can do about it. Still want to play more, though. :)  29/12/05 update: Played three-player with food stamps yesterday and it was a much better experience. The food stamps didn't undermine the scope for good play, but kept bad dice-rollers in the game. The only way I'd want to play in the future.
There is too much luck with the dice rolling, and I personally prefer games decided by skill.  It is a good game to introduce new/casual board gamers to though.
Light hearted, fun, a little bit too luck dependant for me, but I'll play it anytime.
A must have game, but it can get old quickly. The expansions are a big help in preventing me from despising this game after playing it so many times.
MY first eurogame and the game that brought me into gameing hard core stil one of my fvorits and i will never turn down a game
Not complete - missing 1 red road (plastic) - sleeved

P: 3-4, T: 60+ min, SdJ-W Classic and influential although flawed. Many people's first Euro; fairly lightweight gateway,  -Dice results can be frustrating (too much randomness); sometimes you have very little to do on your turn. Players can be blocked early and more motivation to just play Kingmaker. Open trading between players can be exploited by more experienced players. 2 player variants exist, but don't play well.

I have a lot of the respect for the designer, Klaus Teuber - it is a well balanced game with a 'story arc' as the game progresses (e.g. from everyone needing brick/wood to build roads/settlements to wheat/ore for cities, etc.) The downside is it's a tad long for the fun value (esp. when there are 1-2 'scarce' resources on the board), and luck is a bit high for more - the 'risk management' aspect of it only kicks in over multiple plays and you coold be stuck with a 2-3 hr game getting screwed by the dice rolls  (NB best expansion for this is Cities & Knights of Catan)

decent game, but nothing special.  I don't enjoy the type of interaction with trading the cards.  The interaction is similar to bohnanza in a way.  The use of dice combined with the trading aspect make this game for casual gamers.  There isn't much strategy involved and the players don't have much control over the anything unless they are willing to form alliances, collude with other players, be well liked enough.  3 of the most important aspects (trading of supplies, moving the robber, rolling of dice) are out of the player's control to an extent, which is why I don't care much for the game.  If I had to play this game as a gateway game to introduce boardgames to friends, I would.  That's about the only time I would be interested though.
If I am going to play a classic, it is probably not going to be this one.  While I like it, I have played enough games with AP prone players to ruin the game.
I like settlers... wouldn't want a steady diet of it, but it's a nice game.

Have played this classic many times.  Greater exposure to more games has shown me this one is not quite as good as I had thought, but while there are better games in my collection, those games have not yet earned their way onto my Top 10 list through sufficient play time.  I do, however, expect that to change and accordingly, SoC to fall from grace.

What can I say about this game? It started my (and many others) obsession with boardgames, and I still use it as an introductory game for people new to boardgames. At one time I used to love it dearly, but I can hardly stand to play it most of the time now - except of course for showdowns with my boardgame arch-nemesies.  This game made me hate dice, and it took a long while before I was able to reconcile that fact. ;-)
A Granddaddy game.  Alot of fun, trading can be somewhat irritating, but well worth some plays.  Also gets a bonus for being so important to the entire "boardgame" thing.

I think this is a fun game.  The only problem is that people who have played it have often played it to death.  People that have not played it look at all of the tiles and pieces and assume it is too complicated.  I feel there are other games that provide a better gaming experience.

Very addicting, but I still maintain that the game rely too much on luck (the roll of the dice) and not enough strategy involved besides the initial placement of your settlements and roads.  It is also prone to play stagnation due to lack of certain resources being rolled, players doing bad or refusing to trade.  Despite of that we still enjoy the game quite a bit.
Why do the dice favour 5 and 10?
Moduler gaming board, randomizer with odds of landing points, building and set collection.  All work together into fun.
Always a fun game but luck still seems to be a factor, even with Event Cards.  Someone who plays perfect can still lose.

I don't hate Settlers, but I could live without it. The thing that kills it for me is the fact that a player can be stuck with nothing to do turn after turn and there's nothing they can do about it. I don't mind luck in games, but when it reduces a player to a spectator, then I'd rather play something else.  The thing that I think bothers me even more than that is the playing time. I could live with the luck if this was a 45 minute game. In fact, if this was a 45 minute game I'd probably love it.

A seminal Euro, of course. Not my favorite because trading is not my forte, but a very solid little game. Can't take it too seriously because the dice certainly are out to get you from time to time, though that risk can be managed more than some give it credit for.
Fun at first, but it hasn't stuck like some other games
Classic game, a good mix of luck, strategy and negotiation. I recently took the travel version on a backpacking trip and people we saw on the trail recognized the game. It's hit the big time.
Good game, but I don't like the massive use of fortune in this kind of game

It's fun but it really seems to be a slog fest through the middle part of the game.  It really does teach that probability only applies in large sets.  (How many times is a 4 going to get rolled?  In multiple games even!)
A good light game, but it is much much better with the Cities and Knights expansion.

A good game with a high element of luck. It provides enough screwage and player interaction, mostly in the form of trading, to keep the game interesting. The modular board allows every game played to be slightly different from all the others, greatly increasing its replay value.A great gateway game. In fact, this is the one that introduced me (along with many others) to the other EuroTitles. So, rock on Settlers, rock on.

Good game that works on many different levels. Definitely capable of getting old, but very refreshing. It deserves all the praise it gets. Score lowered from 9.5 after a year of playing it mainly due to the luck and better implementations of the core idea by expansions.
Classic, better if you mix in the water tiles.
I have this and most of the expansions. Fun game, easy to teach. Occasionally ends up with someone in a hopeless position, which is annoying in a game where they can't just resign early.
I prefer using the event cards.  My introduction to eurogames and although I still enjoy the game I have no desire to obtain any of the spin offs.
Finally played for the first time.    Good game and happy to play some more.

Bought this for Amy for Christmas (2007) since she always wanted the real game.  The new edition w/ updated art. ---  A definite classic.  I love it when I'm winning and I hate it when I'm not.  I do feel this game suffers from situations where you know you are going to lose and you are just going through the motions.  (By contrast, a sneaky play on a big city and a big field late in the game can turn the tides quickly in Carcassonne.)

I own the Xbox Live version of this and as a video game I'd give it a 5.5.  It's a really good way to play by meself but the trading looses 100% of its spark.  Plus it's a bit tedious waiting for your turn on a video game.  When playing with real people at the table it's a lot more fun and I give it a 6.75.
One of the better Euro gateway games, although like many, I've grown a little bored with it.

I like playing games for 5 or 6 players.  Settlers expands fairly well, except that there is almost always one player (sometimes 2) left in the dust with nothing to do but play kingmaker (or breaker).  If this person is a newcomer, it can be disheartening.  Also, expanding to 5 or 6 with Settlers can really lengthen the game, which sometimes leads to concessional trades in order to end the game sooner.
Fun and easy to play.  Not compelling for me, though I do really enjoy it.
Classic one. But I don´t want to play the basic game no more at the moment. Feels a little dry.
Got me started into real boardgames. I find it kind of boring and shallow now though.

Mayfair expandable 4th edition.   Score based on playing with dice and four people, and watching two other players rake in the cards the whole game due to lucky rolls.  Will play with the welfare variant and a dice deck next time.

Good 2- or 4-player game.  Great to introduce people to gaming, quick enough to play in an hour.  Certainly a worthy successor to Monopoly as the staple game in all homes.  People complain about the randomness, but this means they are not playing very well.  Plus, in a game so short and simple to play, who cares if there is some variability?  The option to trade can overcome many of the difficult time with the dice.
Played zillionzzzzz of times. Solid, excellent gateway game, but pretty much played out.
pretty fun.  A little too luck-based for my personal taste.
Based on the hype here about this game I thought I would like it more than I did.
My first and for a long time one of my favorite Eurogames. It has lost some of its luster over time.
The "great" gateway game. Fun for a little bit, then it gets stale.

My first eurogame (surprise!) and it helped set me down this path of geekery.  Definitely a classic, but I feel a twinge of hesitation whenever someone suggests it because I've already played it so much and those games with open trading can just be sooo sloooooow.  It's fun online too.  +++++++++ 8.5  Too slow for me to want to play these days.  ++++++ 8  Boring
I only downgraded my rating on this because I have a lot of newer games that I want to play these days; it's still a fine game, but no longer at the top of my play list.

The version I have was pretty cheaply made. The puzzle water tiles have all warped, making them fit together poorly. The gameplay can be very random. Dice rolls, trading deals, card draws, and the placement of the thief make this game very lucky. I might enjoy it more, now that I understand the mechanics better, but I have a feeling the luck factor will keep Catan from getting to the table much.  Sold it off more because of quality than anything else. If there was a deluxe version with a way to mitigate luck, maybe I'll reconsider.
We do enjoy this game, but it's not the center of our gaming lives.  It's a fun game and does make you think, but a lot is left up to chance, so if your are a strict strategy gamer, avoid it.
Ideal para adentrarse en este mundillo pero a medida que lo juegas y conoces otros juegos va perdiendo algo de fuelle, ya que es algo básico.

It's an ok game, but I'm not much a fan for a few reasons:  1) the initial settlement placements are by far the biggest influence on the final outcome, making the rest of the game sometimes feel like a slog,  2) luck of the dice and card draws become too much of a boom and bust for the players, becoming another major factor on the final outcome,  3) there's inconsistent capacity for player agency in that a player who suffers from a bad run of dice rolls really can't do anything while a player who benefits from a good run can build an insurmountable position,  4) 90 minutes is simply too long for a strategy game that's more about luck than player decisions.  I'd like to try it with Cities & Knights to see if that wins me over.  (UPDATE: I wouldn't say it won me over but I do think it adds some good stuff.)
Please, not again!  Don't get me wrong, it's certainly a good game, but I don't remember playing anything else at uni...
Luck-driven. I like thoughtful playing over random dice rolling. Keythedral takes the cake in this genre for me.
Playing on the computer has spoiled me.  Real life games now seem to move very slowly.
I respect it for its importance in boardgame design, but ultimately, I hate trading sheep for wood.

For what it's worth, Settlers is honestly a great game. However, after playing many, many plays over the last few years, I have to say that I will only play this with a very specific set of friends because it's no longer very interesting otherwise.  NOTE: Copy is in Berkeley.

I've never played this at a table, but I have 20 plus plays online. Decent game, some important decision making and negotiation, but also a LOT of random luck. Nothing more frustrating than playing correctly and losing because the last time around the board the dice roll doesn't give you ONE commodity that you need.
Given to a friend, as I now have the 3D version.

Costs too much for what you get, and I always feel like the dice ruin the game, even when I win. I'll get in the mood to play it once a year or so, but usually the game does nothing but inspire my hate.

Boy did we thrash this. It was the first board game after TTR Europe that we really got into.It fed our new lust for gaming adamantly.Still a must for new gamers. I just can't bring myself to play it anymore. Definitely got our money's worth though. We played it again after a 2 year break and really enjoyed that old magic. It really is a classic family game I wouldn't hesitate to tell new gamers to try.

Lots of conversation with this game, can be very fun, but it is also possible to get shut down early. Dice are so fickle, we can have a whole game where 11 or 3 or ? isn't rolled, or 5 is rolled only three times ... it can drive you insane.  I know I have not played this very much, but I don't think I ever want to play it again. I have found something worse than a runaway leader - a completely equal game, where no one really becomes 'the threat'; I was surprised how tedious that situation was.

A fun game that started my journey back into the board game hobby.  After playing many other games this one is definitely showing its age.  I am still happy to play it any time, though, and it still provides an excellent game to play with people who have never played a german-style game before.  I like the multiple paths of victory and the player INTERACTION!  Always a joy to play.
An addictive game to socialize. It can be burned easily

My gateway game, just like so many people's. I can barely play the base game now - too dependent on starting position and luck of the dice. It just seems like every game someone gets in a bad place early and can't ever make headway. Worst of all, the mechanics simply aren't deep enough to support the time investment. I hear the expansions are better but there are many games I'd rather play.
A good gateway game, but the luck element wears thin with multiple plays.  Cities and Knights of Catan improves this game a great deal.
By itself, it doesn't say much, But expansios make it an excellent game.
Classic game, best with Cities & Knights.
The game that started it all for me.  Love the game, but after so many plays, i feel it has lost some of its original appeal.
My comeback to boardgames... And boardgamegeek's to blame for it! It was #1 at BGG when I bought it. I have recommended this game to more monopoly players since I purchased it.

lower than deserving rating on this is the over played problem I have with it its so easy to learn and teach and its a very good starter game for any and all people EVEN peeps that are NOT gamers that it gets pulled out more than any other game I have ... I wish my ASL was pulled out as much. oh well.

Owned on X-box 360. The engine setup is nice, but dice luck plays just a little bit too big a role for me.  I am also not a fan of the trading aspect of the game, especially as there is a "don't trade with the leader" effect that generally leaves the second place player as the winner at the end of the game.

First one of the "Holy Trimurti" of the gateway games. Probably the best one, with the most strategic depth. It deserves a special place on my heart, because it somewhat was MY gateway boardgame: in 2001 I came from a period of Games Workshop only gaming, when I was lured in a game of Settlers while judging a Warhammer tournament in a gaming club. It was love at first sight...
I've only played it 2 plyers - sounds like more fun with more
... it's Settlers ... it's a gateway game.
A good game even though there is a lot of randomness. It's fun to play once in a while, but I wouldn't play it every week though.
Very good gateway game. I have lowered my rating since I have found that dice games aren't really my thing.
This game is greatly improved using the deck in place of the dice.  I have played in several games where the dice did not approach a Gaussian distribution.
Kind of a strategic settling game.
Good gateway game. I find it gets old after continuous plays but once in a while its good to get back to ones roots (and to teach new gamers!)
We all have a soft spot for Catan because it was the first Euro game most of us played. But honestly, it's been superseded by so many better games.

Huh, What comment can I make about Settlers? I don't want to say I like it, I feel so torn about it. There are way better games now, but this game is still good for what it is. Settlers feels like an awkward High School Romance that just sorta faded away, never had an explosive/dramatic break-up, You both know its over but it doesn't stop you from wondering if there [i]wasn't something there.[/i]
Gaming has moved on now, Settlers feels a bit like yesterday's news
A good game, but not very deep.
The classic that everyone has played.  The standard game is quite luck based but also very accessible to new gamers and everyone likes it.
An early example of elegant dice use. Still plays ok, if a little 'unfair' feeling at times.
Not my favorite game, but easy to teach and it sure beats "traditional" games.

One of the first strategie game I played.  Was fun until I discoverd Pillars, Puerto Rico, and all the others...  No matter what I try, my numbers just won't come out.  Or they will all at the same time, juste before a 7 to make me loose my resources.  The modular map, the development concepts are juste great, but the way you gater ressources just brings this game down...

Classic Euro. Easy to teach to new people. End game is dull because in most games there is an obvious winner and everyone knows it. Pain to play to the end when you have a loser set up at the opening.
What can I say that has not already been said?  It's Settlers of Catan.  It's decent, and I'd play it if we didn't have something more interesting to play.

Classic game that you just gotta have in your collection. I think there is too much randomness in this game. But a lot of people know the rules, so you can start playing right away. And you can have a nice conversation while playing, so that's great as well.
A classic!  Punched and never played.
Nifty economy and trading game, but the the leaders have advantages proportional to their lead. Good placement at the beginning seems to be a big factor.

Perhaps I would appreciate this game more if it was my gateway game. My first euro games were Puerto Rico and Memoir 44 and in comparison Settlers doesn't really do anything for me. It is worth mentioning that is great for people of varying gaming skills given the fact luck has a big part to play and people generally use the robber on the most experienced gamer which helps to evens things out.

At one time, no gaming get together was complete for my group without yet another game of Settlers (with expansions). Such was the enthusiasm that they readily embraced any new add-on and quirks and took them to their hearts, leaving me increasingly baffled, as the full house Settlers with everything added in is barely less complicated and slower than allegedly 'difficult' games that they constantly shied away from!  However, once everyone had had at least one game where they were squeezed into a tiny area of the board, with no hope of winning and some hours to go, the magic well and truly wore off.  It's a nice little game for 5, poor for 6 and too limited for 4 or fewer.
Not my favourite game by far, but who could resist the great looking Mayfair 4th edition version with a dmaged box for only €1,-?

The Euro-game that started it all for me.  As much as I am tired of Catan after years of endless playing, this is still a fan favorite.  All of my friends, even those that think board games are lame, LOVE this game.  We had more success getting people to play this game repeatedly than anything else I have seen.  There is plenty to do and though the game is pretty straight forward, the difference in peoples desire to trade and ever changing game board, this game has a lot of replayability.  Most on here recommend against 6 players, but I think the expansion is great.  It is always nice to have more seats open at the table...
initially ranked as an 8... definitely too high now that I am playing a wider selection of games.  too easy to get bogged down, but still a fun game with the right crowd.
This is a great game for gamers and non-gamers.  Game snobs poo-poo this game sometimes, but I still enjoy it.  Good social game.

Great intro game to convince people to play more difficult and interesting euro games.  It is hard for me to play now unless people are willing to take turns in under 30 seconds.  The game is too simple to drag out as it does some times...

Molto bello grazie alla sua semplicità. Adatto a tutti, anche i giocatori alle prime armi potrebbero competere per la vittoria finale. Spesso si giunge alla vittoria finale un po' troppo presto, con molte potenzialità inespresse

This game has grown boring in my book.  Too much luck dependant to my taste. I only see myself playing this again if using a variant to mitigate the luck of the dice roll (e.g. Giving players a token each time a roll gives nothing to them, so later they might chance 10 of said tokens for any one resource). Otherwise, this game would be broken in my opinion.   Definitely I won't play this again using  the official rules.
A perfectly fine resource trading game with just a touch too much luck in it.  I swear those dice are not truly random.  But, then, dice hate me.
I have played this game many many times before I knew that any one was counting

If you enjoy any Eurogames at all, then you must remove your hat and bow to the Settlers of Catan. Even though most of us have passed Catan by years ago, you must show respect. I still have respect and some affection.
The infamous introductory Euro game for many Americans.
The game is light, every game is different. It can be a bit random at times, which is what makes it a good gateway game.
I will wait for the Shut up and Sit down crew to review this.

2011-08-07   Initial Rating 9.5  The game (after Risk) that introduced me to the whole enchilada. I loved it when I knew only 5 games. I have fond memories of it but now, with so many fine games, I don’t find myself eager to play it again, but I’m sure I will. I really like the negotiation mechanic and the modular board gives a high replay factor. I have to recognize it’s a great game.  I have at least 3 plays before 2010 thus I have not logged them.

What can I say... this is a classic.  This is the 1st game that got me into playing Euro games.  Unfortunately, I've been burned out on playing it.  It stays in my collection because my wife still loves this game.
Neutral - on occasion  It was once great, but not anymore. The trading part is still awesome now, but the rest is just meh. I would give it a 5.5 if it's published at 2015.
A bit formulaic and predictable once the 'system' is grasped.
He probado un monton de versiones de éste juego, no se cuantas habrán sacado ya.
What seemed an absolutely essential game now seems.. tired. Wouldn't hurry to get rid of it, but there are many other games I would rather play now.

I've played this game more than the number of plays would indicate.  At first it was exciting, fresh, and seeing if you got more resources each turn was addictive.  However, with repeated plays the power of the dice becomes apparent and the fun factor wore down quickly.  I've played this dozens of times at this point, and while I'll play again if asked, I prefer games with more opportunity for decision-making and strategy (like Agricola).

This was a 9 the first time I played, an 8 the next dozen times I played it, and a 7 the next hundred... eventually I will be convinced Settlers is terrible despite getting hundreds of hours of enjoyment from it.

The first game for me (and for many others as well) that introduced me to the wonderful world of eurogames.  A great resource management type game, I just wish that the whole series was a little cheaper.
เกมแรกที่ทำให้เข้าวงการ หลังๆออกแนวเฉยๆที่จะเล่น แต่ถ้าให้ดีต้องใช้ event การ์ดเท่านั้น ไม่ค่อยชอบทอยเต๋าเท่าไรล่ะใช้แล้วหดหู่

A tad luck-heavy with the robber and the resource gathering, and what I really don't like is the deadlock mechanic - once a road is set, there's no undoing it. It's nice that this makes the game progress, and it adds some underhanded conflicts to a seemingly low-conflict game - but I really don't like how this makes you unable to recover from mistakes.  But then, I only played the game like three times, and a long time ago. My assessment meanwhile might change. But I still do like games where it's possible to grab land from each other after and counteract against a strike of luck, and Settlers doesn't appear to easily allow that.
It's all been said before. Not a big fan personally, but other family and friends are.

What can I say- it's Catan. For years I wanted to introduce my husband to it but the requirement of a 3 player was limiting for us. We has since been able to play with some other people and enjoys it; I guess this is the Monopoly of our generation: classic with many lovers and haters but still a staple in any collection.

Pese a ser una de las primeras recomendaciones que se hace a alguien que quiera introducirse en esto de los juegos de mesa, he de decir que este Colonos de Catán no me gustó demasiado. Mínimo 3 jugadores, bastante azar, bastante repetitivo. La disposición inicial predispone bastante el desarrollo de la partida. Me recordó bastante a un juego del mismo autor, pero bastante superior para mi gusto, Elausnd.

I've never owned it. But I finally played a game of it with my wife's family over Christmas. It was nice to finally play the classic gateway game. But I won't be adding it to my collection for the following reasons:  1. I usually like a deeper game than this one. 2. Enough of my friends own it that I don't need to own it.  I can see it's appeal. But not for me.
For me, all Euro games are the same.  It's like playing a different version of monopoly.  You either like the theme or you dont.
Our group loved this early on, but like many, have found that it can have a runaway leader problem.
This classic is a classic for a reason. Very good game as long as the dice haven't decided against u. Simple and playable with most people.
Cuando los dados impiden que los jugadores hagan algo en su turno se vuelve aburrido. A veces las partidas salen buenas y otras aburridas. Mejor juagr con los escenarios del navegantes.
Family game.  Fun and strategic.  I recommend a 3 player game.  Also 5, but will need the expansion.
Not my first choice, but easy enough to teach.  Fiddling with the cheap/thin board hexes drives me nuts though.
Like a lot of others, game that introduced me into the hobby. Still willing to play, but I'd rather play something different.
Easy to teach. Casual game. My go-to game for introducing new gamers to the hobby. Never disappoints in that regard.
I really like this game.  I don't see how it can be as 'luck driven' as everyone says, since I have a win percentage around 80% over 10-15 games.
i could write here what i wrote as a comment for tikal, its just not my game, though my husband likes it a lot (thankfully friends as well)
It was a miss with my family. I usually enjoyed the game.

A pretty fun game, but it can be a little tedious and repetitive depending on the trading and the dice rolls. However, my siblings and I always play the expansion, even if we have less than 5 players.

A very good starter if you have not played board games before.  Update: I almost forgot for 1/2 year to change the rating of Catan, from 8 to 6.5. I cannot enjoy the game anymore, it's just too simple and I rate it as a fairly experienced gamer. The game is still one of the best to introduce newcomers to the game world

[b]Big luck factor due to dice rolls, but good game otherwise. Played it with my parents as a kid, and still enjoy the trading and building, and robber-induced Schadenfreude. We play that you get the resources from both your settlements at the start of the game to speed things up a little.[/b]  [b][color=green]Solo variant:[/color][/b] [thread=460453][/thread]

Purely a gateway game. I only use this game to introduce people to the board gaming world. Once I've gotten someone to play it I will always try and push them on to something more strategic and more fun (and that usually works).

Would be more playable if it supported two, but great game  I think  I played this to death :(  I used to quite like it, but I reached a point where you can predict who will win 90% of the time just from looking at the starting set up

A fun game, but the standard set up is not perfectly balanced. The white player has a real disadvantage from the start. So use random set up. It's also a little bit too hard to catch up on the leader. The good thing is that every one having a great time negotiating.

This game should of coarse hold a dear and special place in every gamers heart. It was the gateway game to the modern board gameing that we know and love today. But the game is only special to me in that way. It is pretty simple, takes great luck, and be careful on which space to select at the beginning of the game (you will not get another chance of choosing!)
Wish this was a 2 player game. Usually play online with my wife.

Having had time for the novelty of both to wear off, I would say now that all else equal, I'd rather play Carcassonne than Settlers of Catan on any given day, especially as a family game.  (Then again, I only have the travel edition of SoC, so no expansions.)
... kto by pomyślał że tyle frajdy można mieć z kulania kostką i stawiania domków :D

Settlers is fun.  I know it's a landmark game, but I have to admit the more I play it the less I like it.  Maybe I've just had odd games, but so much depends on the dice rolls and the game can quickly become very boring if your numbers just won't come up (even if you've positioned well!).  So much is determined by the initial placement that, having played it a few times, it often feels like we're just playing out a predetermined script after the first settlements go down.

Amado y hasta idolatrado por toda mi familia y amigos, ya tengo el juego empalagado, no hay más opción lúdica para ellos.Según mi experiencia, en partidas a 4 jugadores siempre hay un jugador que se queda descolgado, no se si con la expansión para 5 y 6 jugadores la cosa mejorará.   -----  Beloved and even idolized by all my family and amigos.Me like too, but if there are any volunteers for games with more possibilities (Le Havre, Civilization ...) better.
Good family game, but at the end it felt kind of "meh".

My wife and I used to love this game, but the enjoyment tapered off fast. First, it was the sense of futility that we got when we realized that our initial settlement placements had been sub-par; we'd spend the rest of the game as non-contenders, having no fun.  We started using the 'welfare' variant and found that it gave us a much greater feeling of control and made bad-for-us rolls seem much less punishing. It saved Catan for us, and we wouldn't play without it.

Used to love this game a lot more than I do now. Gameplay seems now to be largely based around convincing others I'm not in the lead so I can get enough trading, which makes the meta-game more important than the game itself.   Would play if everyone wants to, but would not suggest and could vote against.
A classic! You have to play this game at least once! For me it is a little bit too long and worn out
Card collection keeps everyone involved and I like the trading interaction. The game is simple but balanced. The theme and board components/art are lackluster to me.
This game probably should have been rated higher, but I have really played the crap out of it, and it is rarely seen on my table nowadays.
Good beginner game but pointless to play once you have the expansions.
I'll play it with new players, but only with new players...
Wish I had played this game earlier than I did. Quite a bit of fun, quite easy to teach, but being at the mercy of the dice really hurts my enjoyment. All being equal, I'd rather play Carcassone.
The classic.  This gets requested pretty much because of it's appearance on The Big Bang Theory.
Not the end all-be all of games, but not bad either. Can be extremly frustrating when your numbers aren't rolled. Not one of my favorites.
No es mi favorito, pero no me disgusta. Mejora con expansiones.
I can see why this was a breath of fresh air twenty years ago. I'm not sure if it still holds up today, but I'd like to give it a few more plays with my casual group.
I didn't play this for years
Vanilla Catan only gets a 6.5  But is THE gateway game...you must give this game a try if you are new to boardgaming.
I really like the genre and the idea, but feel pretty helpless when I get bad number locations. I get sucked into playing this one quite a bit.

The classic...  Don't get me wrong with the rating 6.5 isn't bad...I just think that the game is beginning to show it's age a little bit.    I don't run out to mention this one for play anymore, but always fun with the right crowd or if you are in the mood.
A gateway game that inevitably becomes the game everyone has played a few too many times.
Has its fans and detractors, but Catan is THE quintessential board game.  The theme isn't bad and the player interaction is nice, but it can tend to be boring after too many plays.

Really simple and fun at first, but gets too repetitive, maybe one of the expansions will make it interesting again.   Edit: - You can always take a break from it, and come back to it, and it's pure fun again :)

Un jeu social, très interactif, un classique qui sait plaire à un large public. Mais il n'est jamais dans mes premiers choix... Je ne suis pas un grand fan de jeux de dés et de hasard, et l'aspect "négociation" entre joueurs enlève un peu de rigueur et de sérieux au jeu... (surtout quand les filles ne négocient qu'entre elles!)
Enjoyable with new people, not after many games with the same group who knows each others' strategies.

I understand the significance this has had for our hobby, but for me, the runaway leader problem kills this one. Someone can get boxed in with no decent expansion possibilities and have no hope of winning literally over an hour before the game ends. I understand this only happens when someone makes mistakes during the early turns, but if we're using this as an introductory game, it is very possible that someone's first experience with European-style board gaming involves putting down some starting settlements and then getting surrounded and feeling powerless for the rest of the game. That is board gaming at its worst; is that really what we want our first impression to be?  Historical rating: 10 Gameplay rating: 6  EDIT: After reading several interviews with designer Klaus Teuber, I can say that his presence in the games industry is an absolutely wonderful thing, and I admire his attitude and actions. I wish I liked his game more, but I have no trouble liking the man himself.  Klaus Teuber rating: 10/10
It is not a bad game and is much better than its predecessors.  The amount of randomness is giant, though, and can be a bit frustrating sometimes.  This is a very light game suitable for non-gamers.
My wife likes negotiating, so she enjoys this game.
the game that started it all for me. I'll probably never sell it for that reason, but it doesn't see the table much.

Probably more than 100, was our groups gateway game.. We played it for years up at the lake.. It's lost its luster once you have been exposed to all that is out there.. Great game to get into board gaming.. Still hits the table occasionally due to sentiment..

Still one of my favorites.  More "hardcore" gamers would scoff at that, but it has a lot of what I like in a game.  It is social (trading). All players are involved in every turn (dice rolls and trading). There is enough luck to make it interesting but enough skill that experience/strategy matters.  The theme is light-hearted and doesn't turn people off (a great thing for a gateway game).  On the downside, trading can be intimidating for new players.  The range in game time is actually fairly substantial.  Someone always seems to complain about the random board.  There is a lot of sheep on the board for it not meaning much (the Seafarers expansion helps with that).

Catan Christmas, as it was named, has gone down in history around our house as one of the best Xmas vacations ever. We never even made Xmas dinner as we were too busy playing Catan. Those microwaved perogies never tasted so good.
I like it, but the incesant, fruitless trading offers...

game that got me looking into board game. there are other great games out there. but I am a STRONG believer that if you would remove every single monopoly copy from household and replace it by a game like settlers, there would be more board game players out there

Catan is one of those games that gets a lot of people interested in games. It always gets the same questionable reaction at first, but after the first round, everyone are catan-pro's and are having a blast. I'm actually not sure if I should expand on the base game or not.

I played this a lot between 00-03, more than the current listing, along with Seafarers and Cities and Knights. I have grown tired of the game and don't enjoy the randomness of the dice, which always seem to ignore probability.
A little random (very luck-dependant actually), trading compensates for it a little. Customization and extensions make it a litle more replayable, but don't change core of the game too much.

Settlers of Catan deserves a place in the history books for how many people it has introduced to German-style board games. Personally, though, I'm all played out and would always prefer to play something else.

I was a maniac. I loved that game, as it was my first Eurogame. Mechanics are nice, but some games may end with family argument ;)  As of now I hate the way resources are distributed. This game is way too random.
A legend! The game that brought me into the hobby, I respect it because of that. As a game to play, its definetly too luck based and lacks depth nowadays...
It IS a classic, but there are lots of other games I'd rather play.
Too much depends on the dice and once you are behind, it is a miserable time playing as you are forced to stay in the game. Prone to kingmaking and too much downtime.
Very fun! The trade is essential in this game. The only downside is that in every game I played so far the first player won!

A game that's no bad really, but just doesn't spark my interest often enough. Sometimes I'm okay playing, but seems to take too long for the enjoyment I get out of it. Not that interesting mechanics wise either.
Despite being one of the Euros that stated it all.. The game feels too long and luck driven to me.
Luck with a mix of strategy.
It's okay, but I'd almost always rather play something else.  Still it can be fun, so I'll probably play it again down the line.
That was a good introduction to boardgame wolrd for me.

A clasic game; which probably diserves a higher rating then I gave it.  However, I found that the initial placment was too importent and could make or break a player before the game even got going.  Also, the sosial aspect of traiding cards can be highly unfair, hence throwing off the balance.

:star: nice art in this edition :star: fairly simple rules make it a reasonable gateway choice :star: no shortage of player interaction :star: plastic buildings and roads look pretty nice  :nostar: 3-4 is a lame player count that does nothing to help it get to the table :nostar: plastic settlements and cities aren't the easiest to tell apart :nostar: luck plays a bigger role here than I'd like  --------------------------- Ratings history: 2016-11-13: Rating 6.5, 14 plays  Plays of my copy: 11
Ok game, but seafarers makes it much better.
This game is more about beginning game placement and dice rolls than strategy.

used to hate this game because all the "older" kids at my church played it all the time and it's only a 6 player game so i was stuck watching from the sidelines. my older brother decided to buy his own copy, thus allowing me to actually play and i enjoyed it. now that i'm married and have my own copy, it is fun to bring out from time to time. "the hobby game that started it all"
A classic, but don't pleases me so much. It's slow and random. But I can play it again, once a year :)

Catan was such a revelation when I first played it (many years ago now) and while I think the game is very well designed I don't really enjoy it any longer. My patience evaporates quickly as turns just bog down into tedious trading that seems to last forever. The rating has decreased over time but I will still be talked into playing if it's what is on tap.

21-Mar-2014  I feel like I'm missing something with this game that seems to be hugely popular that I feel is reasonably fun to play but nothing spectacular.  I find if one player starts to pull ahead on victory points it's too hard to catch them up and stop them winning.  How you place your settlements at the start of the game is crucial. If you make a poor job of that then it can screw your whole game up and makes it very difficult to recover.  Edit 06-Mar-2017 With hindsight I feel I judged this game a little too harshly!  Settlers of Catan is over 20 years old and in that context it's a groundbreaking game.  It's a very good gateway game, but it's starting to show its age a little nowadays.

Really love the concept. Downside is the luck factor involved in the dice roll. There always seem to be a person who jumps ahead after a few rolls, and always someone suffering because of poor rolls. Too random to be a huge winner in my book.
卡坦島是三大桌遊之一，更有其歷史地位，現在的桌遊工業可以說靠著它才慢慢茁壯!它讓桌遊擺脫以往地產大亨給人的刻板印象，讓大家知道原來桌上遊戲的機制也是很有變化的! 玩家各自戰領不同的地形，蓋蓋城鎮或城堡，每個地形會產特定資源，並且用某個骰子點數來表示，每回合擲骰來獲取資源，資源可以任意打嘴砲交易，再用資源升級建築物，另外有一些特殊加分的額外獎勵，最後比分數，簡單介紹就是這樣子。

The best gateway game, other than Pandemic. The trade mechanic makes up for the random goods generation. I will play this if asked, but I never suggest it anymore, unless I am with some newbs. I still enjoy it.
Understand why this is a Games industry evergreen game. Good gateway game and useful for introducing new gamers to the hobby.

I'm torn. Settlers was the game that got me over the mainstream board game hurdle of boring themes, humdrum mechanics, and player elimination. Settlers also introduced me to variable boards, wooden pieces, and victory points. But... Settler's role as a gateway game also hurts it in the long run because there are so many more games out there that really make Settlers feel kind of, well, boring. I only play this now if I am in a very specific mood. And if there aren't better games within reach.
It's Catan. The dice are fickle.
Reduced rating after multiple plays. It's a great game, fun to play, and easy to introduce to new players. But in its simplest form it lacks depth and relies a lot on luck.

I understand why people like it but I don't ever want to play it. First town placements are way important and I hate the "I rolled a 6, I get nothing! My turn is done" aspect of the game. Any game where you can lose an entire turn annoys me.
Lots of play time in the past. Have not had a reason to play it more lately

This was our first game and would have been rated higher a month ago.  But since then, we have seen how other games are not so dependent upon the luck of a dice roll.  It seems like someone is always getting screwed by their numbers.
The classic. Needs no more intro.
Standard Settlers of Catan - often takes longer than need be and someone always winds up out of it early,  Best with 3 players
6.5 - I always set the board up wrong the first time, and when we play it's typically very cutthroat, but it's still pretty fun; also, "I have wood for sheep!" will never not be funny.
Fun game with the right group. Not my favorite.
Was one of the greatest game for the board game history, but now there are better games like Terra Mystica.
It's Catan...what more can be said?
I love what the game did for the hobby. I think there are better choices out there now.
Too dicey. Game is too long for what it is. Latest issue components aren't great. Cardboard bits could be thicker. Card quality was decent. Found it in a thrift shop for $3.
A really addicting and fun version of monopoly.

Never liked it that well because I always seemed to get shorted on resources or by the robber.  Then I got the app and played that a lot.  Like the harbourmaster and seafarer expansions.  The most important decision in the game is your placement of settlements at the beginning.
Countless plays since 2011. Likely won't see much table action any time soon. But I ain't getting rid of it!
A fun game.  It's clear where the popularity comes from.  I like it, but don't quite love it.
Essential game, however it too heavily depends on luck considering it is not a short game.
Egyszerű és remek bevezető szintű játék. Minden alkalommal változó szép színes pálya, egyszerű játékmenet, de mivel nagyban épít a szerencsére egyszerre csak 1-2 játék ajánlott vele.
Classic, but random due to the dice. Still very fun.

This is a game that has a little more depth than the old 'classic' board games, but is still a good casual party game.  I'd consider Catan an excellent way to get 'classic' board game (monopoly, etc) lovers into more modern gaming, but if you like more complex games you'll probably move beyond it before long.
Loved the game from 2009-2011 and played obsessively on an almost weekly basis. But, then we discovered all the other tabletop games and haven't looked back.
Although lots of people rave about this and it is an 'in' to boardgaming we don't reach for it too often.   'Swap a sheep for a rock?', 'No!' 'Screw you!'
Classic. Collect resources to build to gain VP to collect more resources etc. Mixture of luck and strategy.

This game makes for a fantastic family game and I recommend it to families looking for an easy board game to learn. However, if you are a serious gamer and looking for complex resource and hand management this is not your game.
This has started to become a stepping stone into the world of Euro board gaming.  It is great at what it does, but there are better within the same genre.  Great for newer players.

One of the classic games of the modern board game era.  You're building settlements and cities, connecting them by roads, in order to gather more resources for more of the same until you have enough points to win.  Light to medium weight.
Classic game. Can run long at 4 players. Friends own.
Have not found a good 2 player variant. There are a few I have left to try. I will play the App but I still get my butt kicked.
Still my wife's favourite game. I will admit it is one of 2 games that brought me into the board gaming hobby. Thank you.
This is a gateway game, yet I never played it until about three years after I started board gaming.
Good game. Age has caught up to this one though.
The "Granddaddy of them all" is showing its age, however is still a solid game.

I played the mess out of this when I first got into gaming, but I never really want to play it anymore. I'm thankful for what it has done for the board game industry, but I don't really know if I ever care to play it again.
The strategy here is actually very neat. There's a bit too much bickering and blind luck for my taste, though. The tension at the end of the game isn't too pleasant.
This is main stream game that I would not play out of choice.  However I would run screaming from the room unlike Clue, Monopoly, Risk, Escape from Colditz...  A classic worth a visit now and then.
We go back a long time, but nostalgia might be the biggest draw these days

This game had more or less passed me by until I was already quite engaged with the hobby of boardgames. Had to pick it up just to see what the fuss was about. I'm not 100% sure it deserves its supposed classic status but I can see its appeal as a gateway game. There are much more fun family games out there and far deeper euros... but not many that attempt both.   I find the theme a bit too dry.  Edit: just got bored of it. Sold.
Tired of the heavy luck swing. Big down time.

Apart from it's brilliant board design, the amount of dice roll, luck, and off-the-board trading in this game really brings out the worst in me! I dislike how much is out of my hands, and the creature I mutate into. Sorry Catan, me no love you.

This was the original Monopoly killer for us and we had friends and family who loved it too (and still won't play most other games with us).  There are better games now not as luck dependent but this game is helped by the helper cards expansion also.

I still remember the fascination: "What's this... a modular board?" There's some nostalgia involved. Nowadays, Catan feels just slightly too lucky and/or too long for my tastes, but I still enjoy it from time to time.
Still holds up as a good gateway game - also a favorite of my wife and mother-in-law, so that helps tremendously!
Fun the first few times. Wore off quickly. But I'll still play it now and then.

One of my first game purchases in the hobby, bought because I and my wife both liked it.  ---------  This is the first game I teach people that have only ever known the Monopolies and the Risks of this world.  ---------  No longer my go to starting point with games. I will try Celestia, Ticket to Ride or Forbidden Desert.

Catan.  What can you hate about it?  I am sure this is one of the most common games that got most of us into the new era of board gaming.  I will admit that this was one of my first designer games to play.  I really enjoy Catan and love playing with some of the expansions.  I usually won't suggest to play it, but won't turn down a play of it.

It's not that I dislike Catan.  The only problem with Catan is that there are so many better games available now. It's a little to luck driven.  It allows for too much negotiation. But I'll still play if that's all someone else wants to play.

players - 2-4 (6 with exp.) rules - EASY luck - MEDIUM (dice rolls) strategy - HIGH  -People can get screwed with settlement placement and be forced to play the entire game in a losing position -Player based resource trading
We never play the base version any more, but it's a nice intro to the hobby, I guess
My wife and daughter like it better than I do.
Great basic euro style game that's easy to teach. Can run a bit long and definitely has some steamroller and king making. Playing with 5-6 is brutal.
Not bad. It's a good game and I can see why it's so popular but it's not one of my favorites.

It's an obvious gateway game. It's fun game to play when there aren't other options, or if you're trying to bring a new player into the "gaming" fold. It's tried and true mechanics have been emulated countless times by other games, but this is one of the originals.
Owned by Alan Owned by Oli

First modern board game I every played. For me, it sets the standard on what a "Good" game is, I almost use catan as my part of my scale itself. It is luck based, and often a good strategy will have everyone targeting you, but it is now become a staple, and a classic.
Yep, it's Catan.  Good, but those dice rolls though. I swear something statistically absurd happens every play-through, which often turns the game's core strategy on its head.

I like Catan, but I'm just not super excited about playing it because there are so many things I'd rather play. The chance of the dice rolling doesn't bother me in and of itself so much as the fact that really the whole game boils down to that, it seems. I also wish there was more meat in the diplomacy aspects and more potential for direct competition and conflict. The Cities & Knights expansion is a must.  That said, it's a good game and a lot of fun and I enjoy the social aspect of trading. I also like that it has such broad appeal. If everyone and their uncle didn't own a copy, I might want to own it more badly. Maybe some day.  In the end, I find myself neither wanting to sing Catan's praises (the people who are like OMG, CATAN IS THE BEST/ONLY BOARD GAME), but nor do I totally get all the hate it gets from the pretentious board-game elitists.
The expansions (especially Cities&Knights) improve the game by far. Without expansions the game is "ok".

I can't say I don't like the game... But there's one thing I really hate about this game... the feeling you have of not doing anything when the dices are not rolling for you. When it's YOUR turn to play and you can't do anything... no one wants to trade with you... you just watch everyone else play... that says everything.  I think the expansions changed that feeling. You have more control on you destiny, there are more ways to win. I enjoy playing Seafarers expansion. I wouldn't play without it now.  A good introduction game for new players.  I have a mixed feeling about this game. Still eager to play when someone suggests it... but do not enjoy every game of it.

Classic Euro game. It provides a solid mix of hand management, "worker" placement, and player interaction. The length of the game is somewhat off-putting, though. At 30 minutes it's a great game. 45-60 minute games of Catan test my patience.

It is as good a gateway game as ticket to ride - especially because it has been mainstream for a while.  But I am not crazy about the player interaction.  I've had some annoying games where people manipulate others in trades or just give away their cards for next to nothing near the end of the game if they feel they are not going to win.  Granted, that is a problem with the group.  But it still makes this one group-dependent for me.
A classic! It's good to have in my collection as it's often requested when non-gamers are present.
This is kinda a classic. While we don't play it much I just can't bring myself to get rid of the game that started it all for me. Seems to be a common story among current gamers.
in Thumersbach  The game, which took me to the hobby. Rating is just for base game, although I started initially right with Seafarers and Cities & Knights, and rarely went back.

This game brought me into modern board games. The fifth edition is beautiful. Such great quality components! Great insert too!  Unfortunately, this is a game you grow out of. It takes a long time to play, doesn't support 2 players, and doesn't have too many meaningful decisions.
A classic gateway, but too much luck that cannot be nullified by strategy and tactics.

Modern gateway game for Euro-style games. I used to like it more, but getting bored with it. Really drags with 6 players. I own the app and expansions.  Takes a long time. Featured on TableTop, season 1, episode 2, 4/20/12
the game that started it all for me. certainly don't mind a game every now and then. is what it is.

Ye olde board game. Yes, it has a huge amount of luck and the initial placement can ruin the game for you. It is not completely balanced and all the time it seemed that 3,4,10 and 11 are more frequent than 6 or 8. But the amount of back-stabbing is rather small compared to the more "competitive" games.
Le jeu qui a relancé les jeux de société.  Maintenant un peu dépassé à mon goût et les parties sont un peu trop longue. (En anglais) Vendu 40$ avec ext 5-6 players sur Kijiji

Finally got around to playing this classic and the game was a bit meaner than I anticipated.  I'm not a big fan of "Take That" games, but I still enjoy playing Catan despite the hint thereof in the game.

I have played this a lot around 2004. This game was first I have bought when I came back to boardgames in Christmas 2015.  Mother of all Boardgames, classic. Pitty it must be played with 3+ players though

It is a decent game for non-gamers or a casual time. Doesn't work with people who don't want to trade. Would only play it with 5 players as it prevents too much blocking and I have better games to play with 4 or less players.

One of the best games for introducing people to board games, since Settlers is simple, short, and has a fun trading dynamic. Unfortunately the strategic element is lacking and the game is completely dominated by dice rolls. It's appropriate for a relaxed, not intense gaming environment, but don't expect the game to confront you with many difficult choices.  The cooperative trading element of the game almost always breaks down near the end, because once someone is close to winning everyone else refuses to trade with that person.

(+) Great gateway for new players, nice artwork, variable setup, allows trading between players, good mix of strategy and tactics  (-) Really dependent on dice rolls, a lot of "gotcha", robber slows down the game, needs 4 players to get the full experience, can be lots of downtime while waiting for your turn, end of the game drags a bit
I used to love this game. It's now gotten a little tedious. It's got a heavier luck element than I like, too.
Ho hum.. Yes it's a gateway game and yes, if you've not played "real" board games before, it probably comes across as amazing... but for me, it's simply 'm'eh'
Rating and plays includes my expansions.

Ah, vanilla Settlers. Played enough of this in my day for it to be boring, but as a new gamer it was mind blowing. This was one of the first gateway games that got me into the hobby, so I can't rate it too low!
the original that got me into euros back in 1998. still much love despite the fact that the dice hate me (and hate that useless sheep - nvr got the seafarers exp)

A classic game known to many, an unfortunate symbol of geek culture that can turn off many non-gamers. It's a game that's fine, nice mechanics like resource management and trading, multiple avenues to win. But the game is right down to luck: who gets to place their places in the best positions for resources at the very start, what dice rolls happen and who gets those resources, and who gets robbed the most etc. This means the strategy is almost not there, but it's easy to get into, and it's not going to actively turn away people like a long game of Monopoly or Munchkin does. Perfectly fine gateway that I'll play whenever, but I just don't care enough to win since there's not that much you can do to control it.
It's Catan... Good intro learning game.
Love the game but always with city and knights

This was the game that got me into the hobby back in high school, so I will always enjoy it. I do prefer it with Cities & Knights because I think it offers a balance to the game, as with the base game it seems like a race to see you can build cities first (which usually means they win from my experience). I wish there were ways to mitigate the luck of the dice roll.
Catan is the easiest gateway game to introduce people to what's to come in the world of boardgames. Resource management, diplomacy, trade.   Only pet peeve - high luck.
I own this just to have it
This game is a classic and still a good gateway game.

Respect the game for what it did for the industry. I'm sure if i got into gaming 10-15 years ago i'd like this a hell of a lot more. Still enjoy the trading and the mechanics of the game. A tad on the long side for what it is and don't care to being a slave to the dice roll.

Strategy game with a little bit of everything, placement, player interaction, randomness... This is the game that introduced people to euro style board games. Probably would have gotten a higher rating if I were to review this in the early 2000s. I guess the low rating is due to the fact that this has been played way too many times. Once the Cities and Knights expansion came out, the strategy to winning the base game become too straight-forward. Still an excellent gateway game to new players.

A classic and a good game. Can get stale and is often boring if you're playing with people who aren't fun to play with. It's very simple with *some* strategic depth. It's a reasonable game to introduce people to board gaming with, though I think there are better, equally beginner-friendly options.

Gateway game for me just like most people.  It isn't a bad game.  I actually like playing it online more than in person for some reason.   I think it might be with not having to deal with setup and online the pace is much faster.   If the pace is kept up, it helps with the fact that you don't really have that many choices that you can make each turn.  The game doesn't play you but you definitely are not overwhelmed with possibilities, which is probably why it is a gateway game.   I have played the shit out of it online so my enthusiasm for it is probably a little muted. I know I have more plays of it than any other game.  It isn't a bad game by any stretch.  There are just other games that have similar mechanisms and are better.  I would give the game a solid 7.  There is nothing wrong with the game, I have kind of just played it out.

One of the few games I've kept from before my new game renaissance. I'll never suggest it, but, with the one expansion I have, Seafarers, it has still shown itself to be fun when it does come out. Interesting tit-bit though: It's only the children that do ever suggest it, and we feel it always out-stays its welcome. I can't recall a game without my wife and I looking at each at some point with the 'please, one of us win soon' eyes...
Not a fan, too much variance and too easy for one player to be stuck in a bad position while others snowball.  Still it seems to go down well as a gateway game so it is useful.
Seafarers of same edition, but expansion is missing some pieces
Was the best in its category once. Now theres just so much better games in the same category, why would i play Catan again?

一片蔚蓝的海洋里，有一个孤单而美丽的小岛，它的名字叫catan。 小岛鸟语花香，四季如春，处处生机盎然。草地上白白的绵羊成群栖息，森林里参天的大树直入云霄，肥沃的土地上金黄的麦穗随风翻滚，坚硬的石头小山，为所有的生命遮风挡雨。  有一天，远远地从海上飘来几页白帆，几个长相各异的人，来到了这片世外桃源，他们惊异于这小岛的丰富资源和美丽风景，每个人都想独霸一方，开拓领地，他们就是settlers。  可是catan只是大洋中的一个孤岛，面积有限，资源有限。为了避免过度的争抢造成几败俱伤，settlers开始了一次初步建设行动。如果谁在这次初步行动中，依靠有计划的部署，能够第一个拿到10分，他就赢得了这场斗争的胜利，从此拥有了catan这块神奇的土地，其他settlers就甘愿引身而退。   卡坦岛 Catan (1995)  评分：7.2分  难度：2.35 / 5（轻度策略） 玩家人数：3—4人（最适合人数4人） 游戏时长：60-120分钟

Really like the idea of this game. I like collecting resources and building stuff, it makes sense. Trading is fun, and negotiating with resources and the robber is great.  It just becomes frustrating to play way too often because the dice rolling is feast or famine.
Not a great game but the benefits for the board gaming hobby are immeasurable. I use this game to explain/introduce the new age of board gaming.
Never played but punched out - VG condition / almost new
The components are very bad. The game is okay, easy to teach and understand. Always introduce this game to non-gamer, player who new to board game, or aged parent.
The gateway to gateway games.  A bit dice dependent and random, but loved and we'll known by most gamers.  Appreciated more by casual gamers, high accessibility
One of the first board games I've ever owned, nice gateway game and easy to pick up and play with new players.

I have it also in Android version and sometimes I play it there against the AI. I think the initial position of the two first cities balance the game too much and it could make impossible to win for the ones who did not get a good initial strategy.
Played once and in excellent condition.
Too many random factor for my taste.

Very popular light-weight gateway goods collection and conversion (trading) game based on rolling 2 dice (2xd6). Modular board with hexagonal tiles where players expand via houses and streets to generate more resources / points.   + Artwork (colorful, bright) + Trading goods + Network building (streets) + Expanding with buildings (adjacent tiles generate resources) + Modular map (hexagon tiles) + Quick playing time + Family-friendly / most kids love it + Easy to teach + A lot of expansions and variants # Robber figure is very mean and can be placed on a tile so that it does not generate goods). It can be placed when rolling a 7. - Luck of the dice roll  Thoughts: All in all, too much dice randomness for may taste.  See also: * Space Base (similar mechanic for "gamers", engine builder, no downtime because usually all player get resource on each turn, space theme, no hexagonal world, no route building) * Ad Astra (space theme, more mechanics)
Had to get rid of this because Jackie would always make Jeni cry when we played this lol.
It's a good game. It's also an overrated game.
un gioco in parte dettato dalla fortuna, ma ha fatto storia!
Combined with City & Knights in one box.
Must have for a collector. Great starter game. We will keep it for our future childs. :)

My wife isn't a board game hobbyist, but she tends to like the mainstream titles that I tend to avoid like the plague. But she's asked for Catan for years, so this past Christmas I finally did some research and bought her a like-new 2012 printing of the 4th edition (same-size components and identical tiles to 5th edition, 75% of the price). But that same Christmas, her relatives bought her a brand-new 5th edition, and I found out 5th edition has beautifully illustrated resource cards! So we re-gifted the 4th-edition copy.

I like it okay. Years ago, it was instrumental at opening my eyes to the possibilities of board games but I think Acquire did that in a better way much earlier.  I feel like whoever wins the meta-game of "you better not play the pirate on me" usually ends up winning.
Too long. Old concept. But deserves it's place in boardgaming history.
Played it again after a long time, disappointed by the dated mechanics. We owe a lot to this game, but it hasn't aged well.
If I whine, I win, if I don't whine, I lose. Go figure. This game brings out the worst in me, but now I just assume the robber is gonna be placed on me, so I just hold out my cards.
A great introductory game, however we usually play with C&K expansion.
THE gateway game.  Fun but a bit too random.

THE "gateway" game. I have played this game with SO many people that would otherwise have known nothing about the genre of "euro gaming". And even many people who have never heard of that still know about this game from a random dinner party etc..., and ended up buying it. It is too simple and random to really feel like I am accomplishing anything if I win, but I still break it out when someone really wants. I'd much rather play cities and knights, and at the very least play the game online on asobrain.com because then it goes quicker.

All Luck.  Players can quickly find themselves playing for last place.  This game gives no chance for mounting come from behind victories as the rich get richer and poor get poorer.  I love the board variety and the idea of negotiating trades but your ability to produce resources on dice rolls is suspect.  Game setup plays too heavily into the final outcome.

Fun game for the family, really enjoy the bartering, especially when it's time for the robber to move!  [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/blogpost/5457/weighted-family-game-ratings-revisiting-time-trav]Weighted Family Rating[/url]: [c]Me    (7) x4 Ebeth (6) x2 Awna  (6) x3 Sarah (6) x1 [b]Average Rating = 6.4[/b][/c]
Μαζέψτε και ανταλλαξτε υλικά για να αναπτύξετε την αποικία σας σε αυτό το κλασσικό, πολυβραβευμένο παιχνίδι.
The classic, the original, the dated.

[ESP] Papá Euro, es todo un descubrimiento la primera vez que lo juegas(si es tu primero o de tus primeros juegos modernos), pero siento que no envejeció bien.Es de esos juegos que se juega mucho y personalmente me cansó, sobre todo al ir conociendo más. A diferencia de Ticket o Carcassonne ya casi no se me antoja jugarlo.
經典的卡坦島，第一次去給桌遊店教學時，完全教錯，讓我對這款從此提不起興趣，那為什麼要買呢?因為經典而且出清特價...
The core game is fairly bland with very simple strategies.  It suffers from being "basic" after playing with some of the other expansions.  That stated, this is a good game.
All development and resource cards laminated.
un sempreverde, ideale è giocarlo con sconosciuti altrimenti ne risente l'interazione
Simple and strongly depended on dices rolls luck - that can get annoying after few games. Great family game!
Easy to learn. Too random for my liking, Takes too Long for what it is.
Classic and good.  I prefer others - particularly for the time it takes to play, but it's still a lot of fun.
Ahead of it's time and the trading aspect of the game makes it enjoyable.  Many games have replaced it at this point, but it should be appreciated for what it is and what it did for the industry
good game   but repetitive and not very re-playable
Waiting cards waiting build waiting etc

El gran clásico, gana muchísmo con las expasiones / variantes. El juego básico a la larga aburre bastante al ser tan dependiente de la suerte y tan caótico, no te deja mucho espacio para planear estrategias con jugadores avanzados, quien esté bien posicionado en fichas de numeros altos de probabilidad, o combos con puertos, o consiguiendo muchas cartas de progreso tiene gran probabilidad de ganar, aunque con la suerte ya se sabe. Sin embargo es un juego que ha envejecido bien y sigue creando adeptos y es emocionante en los torneos!

An OK game.  Pretty simple.  I am not a fan of games focused on player trading.  The more verbose and forceful players can intimidate newbies and more timid players into making mistakes which tilt the balance of the game.

The modular board and the collecting resources on other players turns is very innovative and trading is done well in Catan. Hwever, it's too easy to fall behind though if your numbers don't roll well and strategic decisions are limited after the initial placing of towns.

Pleading people to trade is the best. I'm pretty okay at this game among my friends because 1. I make frequent offers and sometimes my friends make suboptimal trades to me. 2. I have a great time when my friends gang up on me the next game and I lose a horrible defeat. This game does not warrant expansions for me though, since I assume Cities and Knights is a longer game, and Pirates is just expensive. Base game is fine since I can find a playable copy anywhere I go. Edit: I prefer 5-6 players to 4. More interesting group dynamics that way
Catan is the classic trading resources area control game. Gets very political with high player count. One of the game's I played in ±2010 that got me into boardgames.

Almost turned me off modern board games. Glad I was into Magic and thoroughly committed to the geek life. Now, when I want to pursue my dream of being the biggest sheep owner on the block I play Clans of Caledonia.
A classic, good gateway game, but nowerdays nothing more
Kinda fun by itself but really needs the expansions.

While Settlers is better than most older-style board games, it has enough flaws to make it less enjoyable than modern games. You can lose the game before you've even started due to beginning placement, and the dice can fail to roll even the most common rolls with any consistency. I *do* enjoy it, but to a lesser extent.

[2016-05-31] I have a love/hate sense of this game. I want it to be better, but I'm not sure how to go about that.   1. Have the Robber default back to the Desert tile after one round anywhere else. He won't stay long to impede a runaway leader, but he also won't stall an already lagging player.  Trading can result in a more luck-driven, dice rolling grind if no one is willing to trade. Maybe there could be more incentive:   2. Players may draw a resource card token (per the Welfare variant rules) if they accepted a trade offer made by another player.  see also:  The famous WELFARE variant [url]https://boardgamegeek.com/article/1325958#1325958[/url]  Change luck for strategy: use 3 dice!! [url]https://boardgamegeek.com/article/1162329#1162329[/url]
Hard to get a quorom of 3.

I used to think this was the best thing since sliced sheep, but I'm a bit burnt out on it now. I really prefer it with Seafarers, but no one else in my group seems to agree. It's definitely something I'd bring out with a newbie, after Ticket to Ride.
decent game, fun and strategic.  I'm not a dice man, they can mess with even the best placements sometimes.  But other than that one thing, it's a decent game.

I played Catan extensively online a few years back at Asobrain; I was very highly ranked, and thoroughly enjoyed the variations that really would have been near impossible to recreate on the table.  After that, basic Catan is just passable fun.

Rarely hits the table these days, but I'm a fan of this game and am disappointed that it  seems to have fallen out of favor with many. Perhaps in the avalanche of so many spin-offs, variations and spiritual successors people have lost sight of the original game. Or maybe it's a yardstick by which people measure their gamer cred? In any case, this is a great example of how a few simplified, interlocking mechanisms can add up to more than the sum of parts. I do tend to play with the "welfare" variant to speed things up.

I'll always have a sentiment for this game, as it was the first modern euro I played and played it more than once till early morning with friends. A great blend of strategy, luck and high interaction, both positive and negative, makes it a timeless classic still worth recommending.  I'm not that likely to play it again at my stage of the hobby though, at least without cities&knights and exchanging dice for cards.
The curiously effective gateway game. Between the dice frustrations and having played way too many times, I've won't be sad if I never play it (the base game) again.
Not a big fan of the mechanisms and the art. Would have rated higher in the past because it's one of the first modern eurogames I played.
Pretty tired of this game. Gets boring after too many plays through.

This game is what got me introduced to modern boardgames and opened up pandoras box. Now I am hooked and I have Catan to thank. The base game has just lost its appeal. Playing this without Cities & Knights makes me want to gouge my eyes out. I will still play this with new people to try to get them into board games, but I refuse to play just the base game anymore with my main gaming group.

Absolute classic that is still fun sometimes but can get very frustrating if the dice do not roll in your favour. Sure there's trading but sometimes that doesn't work either and you just sit there unable to do anything.
needs cities & knights to make it better. a bit too much luck dependent.
Classic. Nothing but respect about it.

Just sort of moved on. Like so many others, it was the taste of what board games really are and what they can be. It got me into this hobby and will always have a special place in my heart, but I just don't have any strong desire to ever play it again.
Good gateway game.  Cities and Knights adds more flavor for gamers.

Not my favorite game, and one that I still don't own, despite it being a classic.  Could be partly because of my first game, in which the owner did not explain the rules fully -- or well.  But I'm not big on trading games, which is the heart of this one. It really comes down to the group of players making or breaking the experience.  And it's a bit long for my taste.  If I ever do pick it up, it will probably be the Star Trek version, which has a more interesting theme to my, and some interesting power cards.
The "game of discovery, settlement and trade" always holds a special spot in my heart.  Most played before I started logging plays.

Trade, build, settle.  Settlers of Catan is a legendary game for newbies for board game. Rules are pretty easy to understand but still offers enjoyful experiences. Mechanics are original for its time and has replayability, player interactions.  Gameplay Mechanics :7 Replayability :6.5 Theme :8 Design :5 Time :4  6.1
