Well a classic, but I rather missed its hey-day.  Into boardgaming either side but not when this drove the hobby.  For me it's okay but doesn't hit the table that often.
It's fine. One of those games you get when you start boardgaming, but never actually play it later as you have better games.
Was good for the first 30 plays, now I'm burned out. If all players are at same experience level the winner is pretty much determined by luck. Good game to hook newbies into the "Spiel" world.
Another one of those crazes that passed me by.  Don't get me wrong, it's a fine game, but just don't love it as much as many others do.
Good game to introduce to non-gamers once you've whetted their appetite with simpler fare.  Avoid the 5-6 player expansions and Cities & Knights.
Simple strategy game which has grown by leaps and bounds.  A bit too much down time when its not your turn.
Am I the only one that really hates this game. Lots of randomness, long play, with a real anticlimactic ending--PLEASE DONT MAKE ME PLAY AGAIN!!
Once well-regarded classic is ultimately exposed as driven by initial placement and luck of dice. Expansions and variants don't help.
Great game when you're first starting out; I've become a little impatient with the luck dependence and players that slowly investigate all possible trades.  Still very good with the right group tho.
A nice family game, I rarely play this because the luck element is just a bit too heavy for my tastes. I find Carcassonne a much more satisfying experience.
Can be a good game, or tedious and luck-ridden. I have to be in the mood.
Need to play more.  Basic set is fun.
Good game, but sometimes you find yourself too much at the mercy of the resource dice roll.
I used to rate this a '9', but honestly I'm sort of sick of it.  It still rules as an avenue to introduce gamers and non-gamers alike to euro-games.
What can you say? Still better than any of the variants, but I've played it too much.
The ultimate simplistic, easy-to-learn gateway game. Also easy to move past, as there is so much more out there screaming to be played.
5-6 player games take too long. Prefer to play with only 3-4.
I like it, but luck is far too important.
Was fun for a while but eventually lost its appeal. Too much dependence on luck and initial placement essentially killed it for me.
I really like the game, but it wasn't my first German title and thus I don't think I share the same nostalgic admiration for it.
Good game but luck plays too much of a factor.
Getting tired of it. Still the de facto gateway game, but personally would prefer something new at this point.
A great way to suck your non gamer friends into the world of gaming.  I'm not too keen on playing this with my gamer friends, cuz they get really bored quickly with it.
It's fun I'll give you that, but if all players don't play 'optimal', then the game breaks miserably...
My rating of 6 is after well over 100 plays of this game.  I rated it a 10 when I first started playing.  Now it is a game of whoever gets the best dice rolls.
Rating is based on basic set.

Unfotunately, though this game is really fun to play, my burnout level has been reached and I am not sure that I want to play this one in the near future.  Update: Leaving the rating where it is.  But it does need to be said: I think this game gives you the illusion that you are making decisions rather than actually giving you decisions. A lot of your decisions are decided by what the game is rolling for you. Still lots of fun with new people though.

Innovative, but the ability to get completely screwed based on die rolls really takes alot of the fun out of it for me.  Nothing worse than watching a game for 2 hours because you can't get any of resources that you need.  This game gets props for getting people into heavier games, but I don't really want to play it ever again.
I don't like this game that much, maybe a bonus point for historical value.
Settlers started me on the boardgaming path.  It is a classic of course, but now that I have Cities and Knights, I would never play basic Settlers again.

This is the classic game that can put together many different kind of gamers. I appreciate the graphic and materials: it is not my kind of game but have great respect for "Coloni" that is now quite well known and distributed also in Italy.
not bad but draw back is the roll of the die to start each turn.  Typical victory points let down.

This game is the bridge that thousands have crossed taking them from the "roll your dice, move your mice" mentality to the tough choices found in European games. If you have someone you want to cross that bridge ...this is the game to pull out.
Fun game but way too much luck.  Depends too much on roll.  If you start in a bad position, the game would seem to drag on forever.
I like it's simplicity, but I hate it when you have two five-spaces and five comes up once (honestly, once) in an entire game. If youget cruddy dice rolles, you sit and watch other people win.
Definitely enjoyable -- although I think it's slightly overrated.  I don't feel very compelled to play it over and over.  I liked the cities and knights expansion -- which I'd give a 7 for.
To easy for me. Random is much.

This game is hugely popular because of it's accessability to non-gamers.  I can see that but I just don't find enough strategy in it.  Too often a bad series of rolls will leave a player with nothing to do for many turns.  That can get boring.  That won't stop me from playing and from time to time it comes down from the shelf for family night.  I'll take the C&K expansion when I can though.
Don't own, but can be convinced to play.
Just too susceptible to one or more players being completely out of it early in the game.  Can be very frustrating.

Ok. . .posting in 2004, Settlers is showing its age. . .I respect what it is has done for the Euro genre, but if asked to play, I'd mostly try to gracefully decline - just too much luck and bullying in trading cards - the rich get richer, the poor lose.  Better offerings include Attika, Anno 1503 & Magna Grecia for that "colony" feeling - with less luck, more strategy.
The game has too much luck involved, and the play could get a bit boring.  There were some fun moments, but over all it was too long.
What can I say, after having been intrigued by the game early on, exposure to other games that suit my tastes better has reduced this one to a 'meh'
I have the new Kosmos edition. Top-notch components. Just too long for my tastes. From now own, we will only play using the food stamps variant + (maybe) the Fishermen of Catan expansion.
Simple game of trading politics. . . lots of fun with the right kind of people.
Very good if all players are at the same level. If not - the game just bites. Cheap game though...
Rated down after several plays... such a unbalanced game...

Downgraded AGAIN the game recently. The last 6 games I played were boooooring. The first placement of settlements is SO important for the rest of the game that one error in the setup makes for a rather dull 2 hours of family gaming. There is no other game with so much potential, but this setup thing is killing it. OK, perhaps it's my bad luck in throwing the dice recently, but a bad start should never ruin a game for the next 2 hours.
Cities & Knights kicks this version out of the water; I won't play the original anymore if Cities is available. :-)
Emersive fun, but a bit too much luck.
Hvor er det henne? Udvidelsen til 5-6 spillere ligger hos Jonas
it surely is a good game. its only that it somehow lacks the possibility to build troops and kill your neighbours...
the paint is wearing off the pieces, the cards are worn.  We have more house rules than you can shake a stick at.  there are a ton of expansions these days. unfortunately my edition is out of print.
Quite funny game, but I often feel that the start position and dealing of cards decides too much.
Got into Euros the first time playing this and Carcassonne.  Like it at first.  However, I'm turned off by the roll of the dice.  Gave it away to friends.
A classic. Not my favourite game, but certainly good enough for me to go back to it for a few more games every now and then.
4-6 Players.  Great game and what led me to other great games.

The classic Eurogame.  It's a great introduction to the genre, but it has been eclipsed in almost every way by other games at this point.  Bring this out when you want to hook someone on boardgames, and then never speak of it again.
"Pick a card" it's the best strategy. Too much luck and low interaction.

Great game for introducing German type games to unsuspecting "I'll never play anything foreign" persons.  Replayed this recently ad rating dropped significantly. Fun with new layers where everyone trade freely. Not so good with jaded veterans.
Best game for getting people to play boardgames again
Fun and a good intro to "real games" for non-gamers, but limited after playing "Cities and Knights"
A testament to the many great new games out, I once would have ranked this a 10. But as the granddaddy of modern strategy boardgames, Settlers of Catan still gets (and deserves) decent marks.
PROS: continual player interaction, no text dependency, die roll anxiousness CONS: players can feel hopelessly behind, endgame becomes ganging up on leader

Well, this game relies on chance way too much for my liking. In that regard, it reminds me of Tikal. While I realize that there may be viable strategic approaches, several undesirable dice rolls may fully gut one's position and any chance of progress.
down from a 10...gets old after a while
Began my obsession with this. It broke me away from cards and RPGs, Thank you Settlers for all to date and all to come.
Almost everyone in my family likes this game a lot. Doesn't that say it all for a game? Guess not, but the game is very easy to learn and play.

One of the greatest games I have ever played.  I find myself not playing as much now as I did because EVERYONE in my group wants to play it.  After a while I am ready for something else.  That does not mean that the game gets old or is somehow losing its merits.  It has more to do with me wanting more variety.

I got a lot of enjoyment out of Settlers at one time. It just doesn't grab me much now. I've long thought that its mechanics of balancing cooperation with competition worked brilliantly, a very different kind of game from AmeriTrash's straight competition. But in repeated playing, games always reached a tipping point where there was no more trading, no more interaction, and it was a straight competition to get to the finish. Perhaps that's how it was designed to be. But it just doesn't leave enough variation to the pattern of the game. Eventually, I was willing to part with Settlers, knowing that it would not be hard to re-acquire if I wished to, in order to make room for something else in my collection.

This is a fun and easy to teach game.  Yet it can be unbalanced in favor of the player or two who get to place their settlements first.  Often the board layout is such that a few prime locations exist, with valuable geography under high probability numbers.  Players choosing later can be very hard pressed to win.  Add to this a rich-get-richer problem, and the source of our love-hate relationship with this classic become clear.  Most games have some element of chance, this game seems to exaggerate the role of chance.  I think the initial setup is a huge part of this exaggeration.
The game that introduced me boardgames again, but not one I play a lot any more.
Have played it three times now. I like it, although a little bit to much of the same. Well, it's a Euro. But still exploring option and strategies.
Showing its age but still a great gateway game.

Honestly, I don't play Catan that much anymore. Still, it's the perfect "bridge" game, when played by three players, and I've found a lot of non-gamers getting hot on this game and it's dice rolling, card trading, tile placing madness. Yes, the game is not that balanced. Yes, it is long. Yes, there are more "deep" games out there. But in 3 or 5 (with the expansion) is still one of the funniest game you can play.

Must admit I was a little underwhelmed when I finally played this.  I got the feeling I got with many Euros (and much greater ones).  Figure the odds, get the road, etc.  An exercise in probability-figuring, with randomness that borders on the unwelcome.
Loved this game when it first came out, but as everyone adopts their strategy, it becomes mundane and repetitive. Enjoyed playing with the six player expansion more than 4.

I've never seen what the fuss was about. it struck me as a game with a painfully luck factor dressed up as a strategic challenge. The number of die rolls in the whole game are low enough that I frequently saw peopl with 6, 7, and 8 tiles just painfully watch 11, 12, 4, 3, 2, come up on the dice and lose, lose, lose ...  It was still kind of fun, not a problem per se, just seemed to fill some nice in gaming culture that I never quite understood. I was playing Um Reifenbreite around the same time and somehow it appealed to me a lot - even mor eluck, but it never pretended otherwise, nor drew a huge following of worshippers and torunaments at game cons and so on, just a plain simple luck fest of a cycle racing game ;-)
I have never yet played this game with anyone who didn't want to play again. Friends, family, relatives all love this game, from 12 year olds to 65+.  Great for 3-or-more.  Not for 2 players.

When we 1st came to BGG in the late 90s, this was the ur-game. I am not sure exactly how this came to be the gateway drug to strategy gaming- I have never card for trading/negotiation games in general, and the die rolling plays a larger role than I am comfortable with here. I actually much prefer the card game.

I dislike the robber, and the 7 card limit rule when a 7 is rolled, losing half your hand (down to 7 would feel much more friendly)...  Just too 'screw your neighbor'.  Its cool when you havent played other, better german games.
Not my cup of tea, but if this is what the group is playing, I can go along with that.
A fun game and could be a great deal of fun.  However, for some reason, it just did not hold the interest of the other players in my group.
Used to have a higher rating before I got into other games.  Haven't played it in years, and I'm still ok with that.
Building and trading and cursing the dice, all while genuinely enjoying yourself.  That's what social games are all about, right?
My first German-style game. Nice game in the right mood. I've played this too much.
Still like this game, although it sometimes moves too slow.  Perfer to play with the expansions.

Enjoy this game....really calls for a strategy....luck element can be frustrating at times but always up for a game of settlers...i'm pretty good at it too!!  I like this game with the expansions much better as it is a bit too simple for my taste without them
There are some games that you love, even if you are losing - this sure isn't one of them! Bad dice luck makes you furious :-)
The gnocatan implementation makes even 2-player fun.
Nice family game.  I would have rated it higher a couple of years ago, but now I am starting to tire of it.
Classical and fun. A little simple though.
I don't see all the excitement here. A lot of luck, not much scope for strategy.

I guess this game was very unique and interesting when it first came out. When I play it it just doesn't grab me. I can think of lots of other games I'd rather play.  I don't think it's a great gateway game I'd use something simpler, like the Ticket To Ride range.
A classic, but not my first choice.

Maybe the one game that brought most of us back into the boardgameing scene as adults. Its a really nice one that I'd recommend for families and casual gamers, but it really looses its appeal once you have tasted other things later on.
Fun, light game.  Can go on too long, but a good game overall for people interested in a light game that allows for time for visiting.  Good for children and/or adults.
A classic. Cities & Knights expansion makes it even better.
I still admire this, though I am long since bored with the base game

As a fast playing game this is ok, especially for playing with non-gamers. However, once in a while you get the games where the players hardly receives any commodities, which makes the game outlast its welcome by far. Good as a 45 minute, but when it drags, it's really painful.
if the dice dont go your way, you are not going to win.

Boring compared to the card game. We get bored of only building settlement/cities and roads... Card game has more variety wiht different buildings and such. It is also hard to have a fair start with a custom board arrangement.

Have played it a bit much. And when you have played with expansions the basic game isn't that fun anymore. Rating it a 6 is probably under rating it, but right now there is so many games I'd rather play.

This is the game that introduced me to German gaming as it did for many, and to this day I think it is one of the best games to introduce people to the hobby and is still fun to play.  Gift - Christmas 1998 - First "German Game"

This is a game I used to *really like. It was my first intro to German-style gaming. It had innovative ideas, good production value and easy to learn/play rules. HOWEVER, after about 10+ games I started to resent the fact that Lady Luck decided the course of my production more than I did. Nor could I stand the tedious wait for game-end, if after set-up, I was barrred from growth by others' placements.
I played this one far too often.
Playing this after playing Starfarers left me underwhelmed. It just seemed too slow and a bit too basic. My girl liked the game a lot and I can see how it would rope in non gamers.
A great game that invites most gamers to modern gaming and appeals to non-gamers too.

A great game to introduce to people who only know MB style games - open up a whole new world to them!  A few too many rules for non-gamers, but otherwise a game people ask for over and over again.  Because of it's popularity there are tons of workable variants on rules, plus expansions.  If a piece of the gameplay bugs you, it's easy to find a variant that fits you better.
A little hard to get the wife to play...hee hee

The Classic.    A decent "gateway game," very aesthically pleasing.  I'd actually relegate it to a "second step" gateway game, as the rules are somewhat lengthy to explain to non-gamers, but it still works.  Yes, the dice are random.  Yes, you NEED to trade.  Yes, you can get screwed in spite of having a decent strategy.  Eh.  It's still a good game.

"Hey, Scotto, there's this whole series of games out there called 'German Games'..." Although this one is accessible to the nongamer, I'm a little cool to it. 4-player games seem to take too long, and I'm totally bad at games that you must trade to get ahead.
I prefer to use the "Städte und Ritter" expansion.

I'm very lukewarm on this game - I think that Cities and Knights definitely added another dimension to the game.  Very good game to introduce new gamers to, has a huge random element to it, but that can be balanced through trading mechanisms.
Nostalgia won't let me drop this.

THE classic. For some reason it never was as close to my heart as it is for most geeks. I think, the fiddly map, that falls apart everytime someone sneezes plays a role in that. I like the mechanics and do play it if the group wants to but it´s really not my favorite. I enjoy the Starfarers of Catan a lot more, even though it is even more luck-dependent than the original.

Fascinating in the opening setup, but after that there's not much of a game here.  One's trading goals are usually obvious, so it's a matter of whether others will trade or not.  Decent social pastime but not among the great ones.

It's was very good game to start my gaming career but I'm grown out of it - mostly because the problem with 3-4 (especially the latter) player games where somebody is always bound to get stuck with nothing to do and nowhere to build.
Classic. But nothing more. No reason to bring this to the table.

Classic negotiation and building game. Ideal to introduce new gamers into the exciting world of gaming. Once you master the rules and mechanisms, it is recommended to quickly progress to the even better Cities and Knights of Catan.
The game that started all of this, well, for me anyway!

Settlers, Settlers, where to start.  In the late 90's I was looking for a board game that was better than, or at least equal to but different from, Talisman.  People kept telling about Settlers of Catan and I eventually found a copy at a local game store.  After playing it turned out to be a big dud.  I eventually got a copy of Robo Rally and that turned out to be the next best thing to Talisman at the time.  Back to Settlers, I had a copy of the game, didn't like it much, bought all the expansions (the local game store only had Warhammer, CCGs and Settlers so what else was there to buy?) to see if they would add that little spark to the game.  I became somewhat fond of the six player all expansions way of playing.  All my friends liked it so I ended up playing it quite a bit (my copy of the game is quite beat up).  Why didn't it work for me?  Because Catan is a negotiation game.  And when you play with people (myself included) that love to argue about the minutest detail even vanilla Catan can become a two hour slog.  The game is just not designed for the purpose of fierce competition.  It's a family game where people get to build cool houses and cities.  These things increase a player's ability to produce.  So you feel like you are doing something as the game progresses even if you lose...except for when you get a sequence of bad die rolls that allow your opponents to cut you off at the beginning of the game.  The game is quite simple: roll dice, produce goods, trade with your opponents, build.  It's thrilling as any dice game is.  Everyone is invested in every die roll so the game can provide a fun party-like atmosphere.  It's not the greatest game, nor is it particularly revolutionary, but it is fun, interactive, popular and allows players to build cool things.

My first "German" table game, and still a classic.  Great for introducing newbies to real games.  That said, there are others that are better for the time length.  This game suffers slightly from the luck of the dice.  ***On the 10 year anniversary, it's time to move this down.  I know!  It's heretical, but really, I only want to play this once every couple of years or so.  It's too long as a four player game (excruciatingly so for the one player that gets squeezed early), and too lucky for the length as a 3 player game.***
Respect it as the first euro game that I played...But it's a bit stale.
A good game that sometimes feels a little too controlled by the dice. Not good to get a lead early on as nobody will trade with the leader.

Its a classic, everyone knows it, everyone loves it, some of us to unhealthy extremes, .. In all its a good game! I really need it in my collection :) I'm giving it a 6 because if you have bad luck you can just be BORED to DEATH during the 2 last hours of the game. (and yes you could stop, but thats just not fair for the ppl you re playing with) The other reason is that the pace just isnt high enough for me.. it leaves me bored in between turns!
Good game, especially as an introduction to board gaming. Really like it with the extended family.

A bit on the random side,  but its thematic,  you get to build and trade,  and its reasonably quick.  These days,  I feel it runs a bit long - playtime is unpredictable depending on how people get set up ( and bad choices at the beginning are tough to mitigate,  and it's possible to be completely locked out).
The original gateway game.  It's fun, but I'd probably have liked it better if I had been exposed to it earlier.

Some seem bothered by the dice rolling in this game, but I believe that this limited randomness makes the game interesting.  The combination of this randomness and the tactical decisionmaking of the players (where to build, when to trade, when to take a chance on a card) in my opinion makes this a good but not great game.  Its ratings seem a bit inflated by the nostalgia of those for which this was the "gateway".   UPDATE: The Xbox Live release of this has bumped it up a bit for me simply because it allows the game to be played much much faster.
Still a solid game that needs one tweak, never having initial setup with 2 red numbers next to each other.  Everything else that can be said, has.
Your non-gamegeek friends will enjoy playing this with you.    Inventory 2007-09-15 Inventory 2013-09-25 Inventory 2014-03-27
The dices makes it just a bit too random for my taste, but my children like it and so I play it quite often. I do like the concept ... trading, building etc. and are seldom bored when playing though.
It's best if you're willing to threaten your neighbors.  "If you steal a card from me, I will make you pay!"
Great intro to Eurogames for non-gamers.  Too luck driven though.

I play Settlers every week (that means every time we play, since our meeting is once a week). After all these times I have played it I lowered my rating from 8 to 6. I just hate (more and more every time) that one decision at the start of the game (initial placing of settlements/roads) can decide the winner, together with the luck of dice. Even if you play with a standard initial placement (booooooooriiiiiiiiiiiiing) you are screwed if the other players leave you out of the negotiations.  A 6 only for how often it hits the table.

I barely play this game anymore, and I wish I could rate it higher.  It's just a classic game in so many ways, from the randomized board to the resource trading, and it's so easy to play!  But the game bogs down during many trading sessions, and rolling dice every turn to determine who gets resource cards will ultimately leave some players sitting there WITH NOTHING TO DO for a few turns.  Settlers is a great introduction to German games, and when you've moved on to heavier stuff you can still reminisce about all the jokes involving sheep and wood.
A good game for beginners, non-gamers, or those who are tired.

If Casablanca was released today, would it be considered a good movie?  Settlers gets the Hall of Fame waiver.  Any game that is as well-loved as this and as prominent in gaming history as this (which I don't actually dislike) gets a "6" or better.  Having said THAT, there are lots of games I'd rather play than this.  If I only had 45 minutes before I had to leave a get-together and someone pulled out this game, it'd be 50/50 whether I'd play it or leave.

I originally played this game at Gen Con in 1995.  It's hard to believe it's been 10 years since the game that set off the German board game revolution came out!  Unfortunately, the randomness and the "you're screwed from the start" aspect turns me off compared to modern variants like Attika.  Still, you have to respect it for being the game that reinvented board games.
First game I ever played outside of "traditional" (i.e. on a Target shelf) games.
Doesn't everyone have this? I gave mine to a friend.
Klaus Tueber I respect this game more than I like it.  Thank God it was made.  Many games I love were made because of this one.
My mother has this game. On its own it is ok, a bit too simple for my taste, but it is one of my favorites with the "Cities and Knights" expansion.   I like it fine with 2 players.

I liked this game when it came out. But after about one hundred games it started to get boring. I guess, I just don´t like dice-driven games too much. I also miss the possibility to "attack" your opponents. It´s a good game to introduce new gamers although in my oppinion Carcassonne is the better choice if you want to get someone into more serious gaming.
Enjoyable game but without the level of interaction or the depth to make it anything more than that.

2003 A Catan-nak köszönhetem, hogy itt vagyok, s hogy mára több mint ötven játék boldogítja a femilit, s a cimbiket. Ez azért meghatározza viszonyom e játékkal. --- Módosítottam értékelésem miután láttam néhány pech-sorozattal megtűzdelt játékot, s ez elgondolkoztatott. A Catanba be van építve, hogy peches dobások esetén a játékos tevékenysége a kockadobásban kimerül. Ha szerencséje van, ő a bankos, mert akkor legalább ezzel foglalkozhat.
I played this game way too often in the past.

My intro to German games.  Loved it at the time, but I'm liking it less as I play other games.  Still fun, but about one of of five games seems to get a bad combo of resources and luck and really drags.
The game that drew me into the realm of board gaming.  Nice, but not what I expected, compared to the games I've found since then.

Every game is a bit different. The dice is present, generating the random resource output. The level of impact on the game is moderate. [Note: strangely, my wooden dice produce more 9's and 10's than 6's and 8's!]. Don't forget about that all-important port!

Sometimes I like this game and enjoy the game play...other times this game just seems to stink of crap.  People swear by it, but after a few plays, it's a bit dry.  Fun trading game and people like it so the game always fills up...but take it or leave it.

I feel a little guilty about giving a relatively low rating to a game which I've enjoyed playing many times, and which for a long time remained the game of choice when I'm with a group of non-board-gamer friends. But, the high element of chance in the use of dice to determine resources can sometimes make this a frustrating and excessively long game. The limit on the number of players is another drawback.
The game is okay, but the way in which the dice dictate whether you can do anything is too frustrating for me.
I've played this game for years now and I still think it's a brilliant design. I don't suggest it anymore but I'm usually up for a game when others want to play it (unless it's six players).

I'm not a big fan of Klaus Teuber's games and Settlers of Catan IS conventional game from Teuber. Nice idea that everytime the gameboard is different so the game is a little bit different too. But when the game starts: it's dice rolling, dice rolling… and guess what: dice rolling! If you don't get right numbers, then you'll loose. If you don't get a good start, you'll loose. Who gets the money, gets more money => rich comes richer. That is a feature which is distinguish of Teubers' games. I'm ready to play Settlers of Catan if someone wants to but it's not my favorite game.
Rating low simply because I've played it so much - used to be a consistent 8-9

Hate when the "anyone have sheep?" situation comes up. I also don't like the feeling of EVERY agreeable trade being more worth it to my opponent. I do have fun playing it but it's flaws are so visible once you play other games.

This is, without doubt, a good game. I don't own it, but if I were in the position to be introducing people to boardgaming, I would buy it.  I don't, however, have any urge to play it anymore, having long ago played too much of it and burning out.

A good game that was my personal introduction to Euros. I haven't played with a deck of dice but I would probably prefer it that way. My main concern is the attack the leader phenomenon which means that you have to be subtle to fool people into thinking you aren't doing well.

Ye Olde Settlers. Too random for my general preference when playing this type of game (euro/german). But it is quality stuff. If I had to choose, I'd play vanilla, just because it's shorter and simpler, yet still just as good.

This one continues to slide in rating, as no one really wants to play it anymore.  Our games were always very cutthroat, which hasn't helped it to return to the table either.  The robber baron kingmaker element has burned most of us out on this.

We played this at Thanksgiving w/ the family. Everyone loved it. The next day both my mom and my sister asked to play it again first thing in the morning.  The non-gamers thought it would be too complicated at first but they picked it up quickly.  It was a really good way to introduce non-gamers to higher quality games.
Can´t describe but I don´t like it

This game introduced me to Euro gaming and the entire genre. For that, I suppose I owe Klaus Teuber a debt (which I repaid by buying 4-5 expansions, Das Book, and the $400 "chest" version, plus 2 years on online play, and the Xbox version).  Played perhaps more than any game but Chess and Risk, hundreds of times online and on PC as well. I enjoyed this game, for a long time. Frustrated by poor setups, and bad runs of the dice, my solution was to play it more.  12/11/05 - after over 100 plays on MS site, 20-30 on BSW, and 30+ f-t-f, I am tiring of this game. It has it's place, but I wonder about it's affect now on some folks I've introduced it to. Is it better to get them hooked on PR, or PG? or PoF? I am winning 40+% of my online games, but what does this mean? I am clearly losing some games purely to chance, driving me to play more to counter-act this effect. But when I am winning, are others losing because of chance? How many decisions that I make really are decisions at all?  1/08 Dropping to a 6, but with no disrespect. 1/12 Dropping to a 5. Every year new stuff comes out that improves upon Settlers concepts. I do very much thank Klaus T. for designing this game and bringing me back into the hobby.  9/2014: My rating of 5 is simply my current desire to play. It in no way reflects how important this game was to me and my family. It literally brought me back in to hobby gaming, and had a strong hold on me for 10 straight years. Thanks again Klaus.
I'd still be interested in playing vanilla Catan. Played several hundred times prior to logging plays on BGG.
My first Euro, and a classic, but I don't feel the need to play it anymore so I can't rate it higher
Trading and negotiation with enough of a random element to require that you interact with the other players.  Still a good game, but it has perhaps a few too many moving pieces.

I find it juct a little too luck based. A few 'b&ad' roles for a player can make him feel like he's completely out of the game (no trading etc.). In most of our games we've had a run away winner and ganging up on him in the end only prolongs a rather dull game.

Not the great gateway game folk seem to think because newbie play can make this game very frustrating.   A superb game when playing folk who know at least a few basic strategies, although great play can be out done by bad luck and poor trading.  Will only play this with 4 preferably experienced players/gamers.  *update* will never play this with 3 and will avoid having the desert tile in the middle of the board.

Good. Games play out quickly. The end game can be a snore as you can all too often be confronted with the inevitability of your defeat some time before the game closes. The road building dynamic is fairly annoying.

Very easy to learn and fun to play. But I am not willing to give this one more than 6, since the early game and game length can drag on a bit. We use two set of production dice to speed up the game and make it easier to build and trade resources. And game length shortens to a very comfortable level.

Good family game.  Easy to learn.  Alas, I have become bored with it after a few games.  It appears to me and mine that the title should have been 'The Longest Road Wins' as it seems 4 out of 5 times that is the case.   I hate wooden dice.  I am surprised, given the country's engineering reputation, that German games would come with dice that are made of a material that is non-homogeneous thus reducing the randomness of the roll.  "What?!  A 12 again?!"
I thought it was great, back in 1998.  Now?  Meh.

Played half a dozen times now, and am a bit bored with it.  Slow buildup, starts to get interesting, then bang! it's over. I don't like the dice for resources mechanic-- I find the randomness frustrating rather than fun.  Does work well for introducing euros to new players.  Haven't tried any of the expansions yet.

This was the game that introduced me to Eurogames, but I hardly play it anymore. Luck of the die can be annoying, and for game length there are almost always other things I'd rather be playing. Not a _bad_ game by any stretch of the imagination, but it's one I only play very sporadically. I almost never suggest it.
The randomness can be frustrating. So long as none of the players drag out the trading phase, a fun game, but definitely to be played lightly.
The one thing that really attracted me to this game was the random board layout.  I've played this so often that I can pretty much play on auto-pilot, which is why the rating is so low.
This game is a great trading/building game. Usually quick games (less than an hour). Also suitable for most interests.

The original game that sucked me in. Didn't it get everyone? It has some luck issues, but over all can be overcome in some ways with skill and planning. Still the premiere introductory or gateway game. Introduces players to resource management, trading, etc. The Grand daddy.

Luck driven gateway that can ruin one person's experience if the pips just aren't talking to them.  We rarely play without Cities & knights anymore.  There are too many newer games that we find more interesting.

I'll play occasionally, and i'm starting to think this is probably the best of the Settler series.  The other games give the illusion of additional control, but perhaps this is the gamiest of them all.  Too random for my tastes, but those people out there touting the "set-up" is the only important part are hyperbolizing too much

Original needs 4 to get the board crowded enough strategically.  Edit: I could be biased because I suck at this.  Strangely enough I can do pretty well at Starfarers or Settlers of the Stone Age, but the original just has my number.

When my roomate first introduced me to this game, we played it 7 times in the first two days.  Years later, I still love this game, because of the memories of first playing it, but I can't really rate it very high any more.  The random factors are just too great in this game, although the cards from the barbarian expansion probably helps that a lot.  I built my own board out of wood now, and built my own pieces.  That should indicate how much I've actually played this game.  I've played most often with one or more expansions, and back when I played it regularly, I didn't know about BGG.  So, most of my plays of this game have not been logged.
My first "German" game. After >50 plays now, the basic game is getting a bit stale but it's still a keeper! Usually prefer to play Cities and Knights unless we're introducing the game to new people.

This is the ONLY game my wife actually asks to play. I think the key to this games broad and sustainable success is:  1. Non-violent 2. Fairly simple rules 3. A pinch of luck (that impacts all players uniformly) 4. Interaction through trading (but not unlimited interaction) 5. Random map combined with dynamic starting positions.  We much prefer playing with the Seafarers expansion and the use of unknown tiles that are discovered during play.
A solid gateway game that can fit neatly into a ziplock bag. I will play Settlers forever, likely by playing it too much, getting tired of it, hiding it for a while, and then repeating.
It's just too easy for a player to be shafted by the dice and end up sitting on their hands while everyone else prospers.
Alot of luck involved. Fun until it bites back. It's addictive but is a little short on atmosphere. Nevertheless I love it, it's superbly balanced. Expansions are expensive.
This game and i regularly do battle with me coming off second best. when nothing is going your way its easy to feel that your being victimised for being red or orange never the less i do enjoy it.
I like the strategy parts of this game. But the dice rolling adds a random element that can conquer any strategy if you are out of luck.
OK game.  I kinda feel like I could phone-in my moves or instruct a proxy.
Played this to death and prefer digital versions now.  Will pull it out for nostalgia reasons only.

A classic no one interested in boardgames could possibly pass up, at least once. But when the initial wonder is past, the luck factor begins eating away your cheerfulness. In essence, Settlers is a clever game which may or may not leave you stranded (i.e., without a decent shot at winning) if the dice are against your production and others refuse to trade.

I love this game. We used to play big 8-player games of Catan all the time with some family friends. I own three editions of the game, the first two from Mayfair, featuring different colored tokens, enabling you to play with as many as 8 players, and then the Swedish edition and 5-6 player expansion. Mayfair's double-island scenario really rocks.  Contains pieces in the following colors:  * Black * Blue * Green * Orange * Purple * Red * White * Yellow
Game is fun for the first few plays. Game wears out pretty quickly for me. Its quick to play though so you can possibly play a few other games in a gaming session.
A classic that is always fun to play.

I understand its hallowed position in euro-dom, but I've never had all that much fun playing. I hate the robber all out of proportion to its influence of the game, and in general, I never seem to have *that* much fun playing Settlers. Shrug.
Everythings already been said.  Great game.  Accesible by all.
(With the 5-6 player expansion.) I don't really enjoy playing this game anymore but I can't bring myself to remove it from my collection.

I really liked Settlers when I first got it as part of the modern wave of board games, but it's steadily gone down in my ratings as I get other games I like more. I'm not a fan of the random resource generation, and the end result of your city and road building isn't nearly as satisfying as in other games such as Ticket to Ride and Agricola. At this point I'll only play it if someone else really really wants to play it.

Our first family gaming session  with "Catan" was pretty dynamic.  After a few turns getting to know it, everyone just came alive.  The trading was like a Bazar with deals and haggling.  The sadistic delight taken by moving the robber to a place where he could take "revenge" for past bad deeds!  Loads of fun but can drag on a bit.

Classic. Good social game, although a bit too much luck dependent. (I have not tried the dice deck to reduce the element of luck) Its strongest aspect is the high level of player interaction. I would probably rate the game higher if I had not played it so often. With Seafarers I would rate the game 7. (I do not have enough experience with the Cities and Knights.)

Before Settlers there was only Chess, Risk, and Scrabble in my little world. Best gateway game. After 6 years I still can't pass up a game. It still has the best variable board set up in all my gaming expirience. Most fun negotiation as well.
I'd enjoy this game more if my usual group could play it faster.  2 hours is too long for this one.  I don't even know what it is that takes so long.
Ahh, the classic Euro gateway game. Great for drawing non-gamers into the hobby.

Settlers is a fun game that depends a lot on the dice. However, the rating gets upped on this one due to the fact that it draws people into board games and gives them a window into the world of strategy.
Dice can't be consistent....Great in concept tho. Granted if you are a good trader you can play VERY consistently.
One of my first Euros.  This game has numerous pre-BGG plays.  I have the iPad edition of this game as well, but I don't log these plays.
Not something I play a lot nowadays, but let's face it, a lot of people (including myself) owe it ALL to this one...
Good stuff!!   I'm glad I finally took the plunge, in spite of the dice/luck/random naysayers -- it isn't luck, so much as it is calculated risk.

I can't believe I took so long to remember to rate this game!  Settlers is of course a classic game of resource management and trading.  I find it to be a goodie but an oldie.  Its age shows with the blandness and over-simplicity of the theme and mechanics.  We probably all owe it a lot though for what it did to define the hobby.
I must be burned out. I have not played this in over 3 years and I don't miss it at all!

Like many, Settlers is the game that got me in. But after years of playing better games Settlers has lost its shine. It's really not as fun if you play with a bunch of people who know what they're doing. It ends up all coming down to dice rolls. It's a very good game for a bunch of inexperienced players since they will have lots of fun turning sheep into wood.

I have a love-hate relationship with Catan. The game re-ingnited my interest in board games in 1999/2000. When jim pinto told me he couldn't stand Settlers at GenCon 2000, I thought he was insane. Now I see his point. SoC is a good game, but I've played my fill of Catan.

Solid game. I like it. One problem, though, is that one player always seems to get left behind in the dust with no way to catch up. And the player who does a little bit well in the beginning gets robbed the hell out of, which annoys me.  You might think two wrongs make a right, but no.  >10 plays

The historically quintessential German gateway game, and also the one game I find in the hands of people who have heard of little more than Monopoly.  It was the first game I bought when I decided to get serious about collecting German-style games, but I'm getting a bit worn out on it as I get deeper into the territory.    9-2-08: Have to move this down to a 6.  I appreciate what this game has accomplished, but I've thought about trading my copy and would, were it not for the sake of respect, nostalgia, and some degree of hope that I'll find some resurgence in interest through one of the expansions, or the right group, or what have you.  As it is, can't think of a time when I wanted to pull it out even for old time's sake, and I'll even try to avoid playing it.  That probably means I should rate it a 4.  I'm not one to rag on a game just because it's popular, so that's not "it."  I think, at the risk of being inconsistent, it's ultimately the dice that do me in on this one.  I generally don't mind games which rely so heavily on dice rolling, but this is one that can really make me look at my watch if lady luck is canoodling with one of my rivals--there seems to be too little I can do in too long of a game.    12-24-07: Played the game again recently on Xbox Live.  Maybe it's the extra options, the built-in session report, the detailed statistics tracking, or the sense of playing with an  animated version of the collector's edition, but I give it an extra point over the base board game.

Once a 9, threatening to rate 10.  I like the core system, and I enjoy playing this on the computer a little (against AI opponents), but it's just never fun in person.  It's getting less fun every time I play.  Perhaps it's my opponents, but it seems that there's always someone at the table that is stuck in a crappy spot and is having no fun at all.  And the game just drags.

This is one of the first board games of the new generation that I played, cuz that's what everyone said to do.  It's an okay game, but since, I've played many a better game.  UPDATE:  Lowered from an 8 because, since moving on to more euro games, I've NEVER come back to this...not once.  And, since becoming more aware of the current board-game scene, I can't believe so many people consider a game so heavily based on player-to-player free-form trading to be such a good gateway game.  I often times have a tough time getting my "non-gamers" to follow the very specific basic rules of a game, let alone making up free-form trade offers based on resource needs that they don't understand yet.
A Classic, but it didn't strike me that much. I think my opinion would be different had this been one of the eurogames I played. Willing to play every now and then.  Owned and sold.

I played this game out - yes, it's a great Gateway game, and yes, it's easy to teach and we owe a lot to the game; but, ultimately, the shortcomings are much more apparent 10 years later, with the host of games we've been exposed to since then. Still, it's something everyone should play, at least once, if only because so many other games build off some of the concepts in Settlers.

Definitely a gateway game for many people.  With 4 experienced players, it can play out very quickly and when this is done, the game really shines.  If the game play starts to drag, the play experience will definitely go down.  It is still highly playable, but perhaps a bit too much luck based for more modern strategy fans.  Planning for the luck element will mitigate all but the most die-hard opponent of the game.  [GTI Code: TPCL]
A great game, this started me on games and is still played occasionally amongst my other 50 or so games.  Good strategy and luck mix with personally interaction and doesn't take too long.

I enjoyed this game on the few times I played it with gamers and non gamers alike. So far, I havent encountered any of the problems talked about here on BGG of being locked out of the game early on. However, i think it's over long for what it is and the game loses its fizz as development slows down in the mid game.

This is a decent game, but I got sick of it after playing it extensively for a while.  The randomness factor gets irritating if your numbers aren't rolled for several turns in a row. A good "gateway" game for beginning board gamers.
Un clásico que ha envejecido mal y al que no quiero volver a jugar nunca más.
This game re-ignited my love of gaming.

I gave this an 8 but downgraded to 6. I feel like item trading gets monotonous. When I think of this game I realize not only am I not the one to suggest playing it but I try to convince others to play something else. That said I could see this averaging to a 7 at some point.

As with many people, this was my gateway to modern Euros. Having had far too many games where someone has won by rolls of "4" coming up almost every turn, I now prefer to play with a 'deck of dice' instead.  Actually, I may have to revisit my rating for this at some point, as I'm really struggling to think of when I would choose to play it; nostalgia, maybe?
It's good, but it's boring compared to Cities & Knights.

I have never seen the appeal of Settlers as a gateway game.  My non-gamer friends and family were bored by it.  I don't mind dice-rolling but the mindless monotony of rolling for resources stupefies me.  The trading aspect can be fun, though with a little experience players know what not to trade.  My kids do enjoy picking the card out of an opponents hand when they play the thief.  This game is especially unpleasant on BSW.     My ten-year-old son loves the game however.

Initially I gave it a ranking of 8; it was a great gateway product but the game lost its allure with each passing play...it got long and the same tactics got old. Still a good way to introduce a game to new players of Euros but I rather try other games first.
Enjoyable every now and then, better with Cities and Knights.

This game depends heavily on gambling on die probability distributions.  Nonetheless, there is something appealing about it.  The configurability of the game is probably its strongest trait.  My main problem with it is that after a certain point in the game, I really don't care what happens most turns, because I can't do anything - especially if I'm on the verge of winning.  (And you'd think that's because people won't trade with me, but oddly, the problem is just that the other people take exponentially longer, the closer someone is to winning.

Enjoyed it much more when it was one of a very limited supply of games.  Partially because of the lack of a good 2-player variant, but more because I've found more challenging games, I just don't play it much any longer.
FINALLY got to play this classic, and although the beginning of the game is somewhat slow - it does improve and gets to be quite an exciting game! I like!
Showing its age, but still a lot of fun.  Much better gateway games have emerged, so these days this makes a better "second" game.
A groundbreaker, to be sure. Still a solid gateway.
Seemed fun enough, but also random in an annoying way. I've only played once, though, and I won pretty much just because of good luck.
A little dry but I still enjoy an occassional game.

While not my favourite trading game, I like Settlers. It's easy to teach and fast to play, making it a solid introduction to the hobby (though you probably knew that). Luck in the dice rolls can have a big impact, though it is sort of balanced with the thief, which acts as a "bash the leader" mechanism.   Its luck factor gives the impression to have a larger impact than the one it actually has. This is both good and bad: good because it means skill is still important, bad because even though it can be mitigated, some players will simply refuse to play, arguing it's completely luck driven.  Rating: :star::star::star::nostar::nostar: [i]Number of players:[/i] :thumbsup:4  [i]For more information on how I rate games, [geekurl=/user/Kodeir]go to my profile[/geekurl][/i]

Already a classic, but to be honest, the basic game without any expansion is not that exciting. Thus the rather low rating from me. With "Cities and Knights" or "Seafarers" this game becomes somewhat more fun, hence I kept the high ratings for the expansions.

Best played with 3 or 4 players (i.e., without the 5-6 player expansions), Settlers of Catan is a game that all gamers should have in their collection. The mechanics are easy to learn and the "in game" trading allows for interesting player-to-player social interactions. Although tha game is described as a 90-minute game, you may want to allocate a bit more time for it.  :star::star::star::nostar::nostar:

I unfortunately played many other games before this one and while it's a good game, there are so many others I enjoy better. I love many of the other Catan games (Starfarers is one of my alltime favorites).
Half of the game is decided with the initial placement. And hope for good rolls!

A classic. The one drawback I can think of is that the luck of dice (especially if 7 is thrown repeatedly) can swing things uncontrollably towards one player. Better might have been to let 7 be some other action, and make the robber a less common roll, like 2 or 12, say. The 3-player game works much better than the 4-player because in the 4-player one player always gets locked out with no choice but to twiddle their thumbs.

It's a classic simply because of it's gateway status and popularity alone, combining the features of negotiation and building tactics.  Everything about it screams "interaction".  Since I've played this so often over the years, I find I'm more interested in other boardgames but it hits the table for me b/c others play this so much.

Playing with three people seems about right to me: the game takes too long with four, but I'll still play it with the right people. Catan would be better served if trading could happen at any time during the game (the robber would create a musical chairs reaction when the music stops). The slowest part of the game is having to wait for the current player to suggest trades.

My first real official "Euro".  I like it, but not crazy about the need for 3 or 4 players.  No 2 player ability is a killer.  I prefer the Catan card game.  After this one, I am starting to see a pattern in Euro games:  Build, get resource to buy more buildings to get more resources, ad infinitum.

Not nearly as much fun as it once was; suffers from aging mechanics.  Don't like the luck of the dice and the ganging up on the leader.  Recommend using the dice deck.  Still, I have to give it props in the annals of gaming history.
Played only once, and was a bit disappointed.
Rating for the game without expansions. Cities and Knights is the only way to play the game for me now.

Interesting game. If some game company had published this one in Brazil in the late 90's, the boardgame market could be extremely better than today. It's luck driven, and if the dice don't help, you'll loose badly.
Rating drops to 4 or less with the expansion... too long!

For many players this is the introduction game to the hobby, but not for me as I learn to enjoy euros through other games. That is maybe why I don’t have the same nostalgia associated with this game as many other gamers. The game is fairly straightforward to explain, where the phases are distinct and simple. During the game there is usually not much thinking about how to use your resources, but there is definitely an amount of resource management.  What it comes down to in most game in my experience is two things, die rolling and initial set up. If you get your machine going in the beginning of the game you are hard to stop. The robber is simply not enough to stop and by not trading with him you might lose out on that too. That is also my main complaints about the game; there is too much luck and circumstances.   I like to play this game with either 3 or 4 players. With 4 players the board is a little tighter, so players can be shut-in, but that is generally in the end game anyway.
Easy to learn building and bidding contest. However, a few 'unaveraged' dice rolls throw off close games.

It gets a 6 from me because in it's heyday, sometime in the mid 90's, it would have been a 9, and now I will never play it again if I can help it, so I will settle in for a 6.  Not offensive, but not gushing, either.  Classic gameplay, with classic rules that opened a whole new world to me, and spawned the creation of Robespierre the Thief.  Also "Help Me" spelled out by Ziskin.
Solid, but after many, many plays (in my pre-BGG days) I never seem to want to play it over other games in my collection.
Was a great game, but now overshadowed by some new arrivals. Still a good game though.
A pretty good game with a rich-get-richer problem.
A seminal boardgame, though I prefer the cardgame personally.

2500 magyar. elnyűtt faverzió  settlers along with ttr and carcassonne is the best entry game. everyone likes to build things after all and tradig is fun as well after some time it gets boring though you have a plan and then you just wait for the number rolled also there is one clear winning strategy only the dice can stop you...
It's OK with the food stamps variant.  Cities and Knights is much more interesting but takes longer.  4th ed. traded.  Gift to MRJ; AA.

This was, as with many, my first eurogame.  It was awesome.  Since then though I've come to find the dice very frustrating to deal with.  Questionable house rules for trades are another irritation.  Maybe the 5-6 player expansion ruined it for me, but I currently believe that winning this game does not necessarily require a huge amount of skill.
Traded Danish edition in Beautiful wooden box  Australia Maths Trade to Tyndal.  A bit boring and slow. It is only a good game if played very quickly.
Always one of my favorites, since it was my first introduction to "Euro Games".  Replace the wooden dice with plastic ones ASAP for more random results!

The game that got me into hobby gaming still mostly holds up.  That said, I just don't really find the "hope for good dice rolls to get enough stuff to build what I want" core mechanic to be all that fun anymore despite the design overall being quite elegant for its age.
Great because it got us into gaming... but we never play it anymore.
For all its history, I don't play this game much.  It's okay, but there are lots of games out there these days.
Fun game but too much luck.  It doesn't seem like it at first, but it's all about luck of the dice.
Played a few times and it was OK. It kinda introduced me to Euros (like a lot of people) and showed me that a family game didn't have to be the usual Department Store fare.

Great gateway game of light to medium complexity.  There is a fair amount of randomness in the game, but where the game shines is in the amount of player interaction.  Definitely a good game for social gaming.
A decent game, personally I think it's too stiff and undynamic to be really great.
Played with some friends for their first time, they really seemed to enjoy it. I've found it's great to introduce folks to more designer games.
A good game, but a bit long for the level of luck involved. The board play is clever, but the trading is missing the player incentives found in games like Bohnanza and Traders of Genoa.
I'd like it better if I didn't always seem to get screwed by the dice!

I've got the PC version of this (DOS, with lousy AI). Well, it's a nice introductory game with strategy combined with luck. Can't go wrong with that. Just doesn't click with me as much as other games do.
The trading makes this game.  The dice almost ruin it for me.  I either feel like I'm winning because the dice went my way, or losing because the dice are against me.
I can't say more than has already been said.
The start of my gaming addiction, so the rate is for old times sake. Way too much expansions right now (next year #1254?).

I liked this quite a bit when I first started playing it on the computer (as an MSN Games download). I got tired of it pretty quickly though. As fickle as it sounds (and is), I think I'd like this game more if it had better artwork. I purchased the travel edition to play instead of the regular version, solely because it looks better. I might pick up the 4th edition as it looks nicer to me.
A little easy to get burned out on if played many times in a row.
Russian version, that i bought on a trip to snt. petersburg. Had to drop ratings as i noticed that i dont really that often want to bring this on the table when playing games.

[4p] Terrible game with 6 players.  Too much negotiation & downtime.  2 player variant on Mayfair's site (15 pts) is actually quite good.  Not as great a gateway game as it gets credit for.  Just not enough of a catch up mechanism.

It's Catan. It's fun. We play it in a weird way, by mixing all the water tiles with the land tiles and playing with bridges that cost 1 wood, 1 brick, and 1 sheep to build a road across the water. Something about needing a sheep sacrifice to make a bridge. . . . Also makes sheep slightly more useful.   Anyway, the reason I don't own the game is because everyone else does. Like literally everyone else.
Played Settlers to death in college.  It's a great game, but I have a bit of an aversion to it now.

Truthfully? I was bored. Sorry, Whole World. I was bored by Settlers.  UPDATE: Played it again. Liked it a little more, but not much.  UPDATE UPDATE: I think I've figured it out a little. The times I've played, I've played with people who understood it FAR more than I. Perhaps if I played it with people who were on the same level as me, we could figure it out together. Or something. Maybe that's the problem.  UPDATE UPDATE UPDATE: I've now traded for a copy of Settlers. Let's see how my opinon changes with likeminded others.  UPDATE UPDATE UPDATE UPDATE: Ok. I like it now.
Also suffers the "Yeah, but I'd RATHER play" syndrome.  Update: traded in Nov '06 math trade
Standard gateway game. Hasn't aged incredibly well, although the negotation aspect keeps it alive, methinks.
This game gets to be ridiculously frustrating and vicious after playing it a lot.
Classic. The gateway game. Created four new gamers with this game and TTR. Fun with expansions but the base game is all you need to have a great social gaming experience.
Great gateway game, but can run very long and gets pretty boring after the first 30 minutes.
Got me as well as many others back into gaming.  I don't own it, and won't suggest it as it is over played for me.

I enjoy settlers alot.  It is a nice resource management game that has a fairly fast pace.  The learning curve is not onerous, but it's definately there.  This was one of the games that returned me to my love of board games.  But it is losing it's tarnish.  I enjoy it, but I am starting to lose interest.  It's not so much that I don't enjoy it, every time i play I am challenged, and enjoy myself.  But when it gets pulled out I kind of sigh and think "settlers again..."
This is a very enjoyable game. I won't give it an 8 because I will sometimes turn down an offer to play.  I think it's Steve's game that lives at our house.

Settlers of Catan is a fun game. I like how the board is always different and how it forces trading/iteraction. Like most, this game got my group going and for that i am grateful.  I think it lacks a bit of confrontation, and thus sometimes get's a bit repetive and even a little boring after long a drawn out game.  updated: too long
Our first introduction to the world of euro games.  Still love it, though we rarely play vanilla Settlers anymore.

Superb!  An absolute classic.  I overplayed it when it came out, but there weren't any other Euros available to play and thin out the experience.  I've recently recovered from burnout and am now enjoying it again.
Everytime a new game, the hexes island idea is wonderful. Dice play a too large role, but some players manage to win everytime anyway! Too long and repetitious for the XXI century
Lot's of fun, the randomness has started to get to me though.
This game opened up serious gaming with all my non-wargamer friends, relatives and co-workers!
Great game, although it is much better when the Seafarers expansion is added.  EDIT:  My rating is low because of the amount of play this game has received, not due to any shortcoming of it.
The classic Euro.  Great gateway game to get people into the hobby.  Fun, simple to grasp and easy to teach.  After several dozen plays, it does get old though.
Played this a LOT when it was new, then over-dosed.  Was an 8.5 or so for that time, but the O/D has dropped it.
Nice game - but don't think I'll be playing it much more.  I found the thief mechanism just slows it down and makes it more confrontational (not good with family).
Classic. But I played it so many times that it gets repetitive.
I still like plain Settlers of Catan; but it's harder to find people who will play it with me.

3p: It shines as a 3 player game. I'd give it a 7. Sadly there are way better 3p games out there, so it doesn't get played much. 4-6p: The board gets too crowded and is hard to get anything going if the dice don't favor you. I won't play this game with MORE than 3 players... I'd rather get a root canal!
I owned the whole game at one point...before the craze. It got me into more gaming, but I can't stand it now...I sold it and all expansions for $100 several years ago.

Well, it was my first author-game.  I liked it very much, used to be my favourite till ... I discovered games like Puerto Rico, Caylus in which there is no dice... If only the dice was not so important in the game.  Most of the time you are waiting for goods to be produced based on dice decisions.  You rarely make some decisions yourself.
I put off playing this for so long, but ended liking it quite a bit.
Great mid level game.  Nice combo of strategy and luck.  A little heavy on dice for my personal preference, but still very enjoyable to play
A nice light game which is fun to break out once in a while, or to use to introduce new gamers to the hobby.

We were really looking forward to playing this game as it's so famous, but we were disappointed.  Becky found that she was unable to make any moves for most of the game, and Ally found it a bit boring.  I think we need to play it again to get a better idea of what it's all about.
Ok, but I don't like that you can get in a position where you have 3 or 4 turns in a row with nothing to do.

I think this is a great game for playing with certain light gamers. It serves as a benchmark by which all my games are rated.  This can degenerate into a really mean game in the right (wrong) crowd. There's the potential for one sided trades to assist blocking the leader, multiple bashing the leader on the same turn through the black knight, etc. I only want to play this one with the kids - keep it away from the serious competitive gamers.  I really can't stand the Mayfair edition - I don't like the colours and why does the ore symbol on the player mats use the same colour as the clay bricks?
I'm always surprised when I come back to this game that it is still fun.
My first German. I spent a couple of years playing SoC over and over again before I discovered there were other (and as I found, better) Euros.
Played once, three-player.  The fact that I more in awe of its place in history (in regards to the rebirth of board gaming) than I was from its game play is worrysome. Not bad, just... meh.
I don't really see what the fuss is about. It's fine. I'm not a fan of trading mechanics, though, so I guess it was never going to catch fire with me. Bought in a sale.

The play count on this is way off--the 3 plays since the beginning since the beginning of 2007 reflect my rapid acquisition of new games that I like better.  We played the crud out of this from 2004-2006, especially with the Cities and Knights expansion.  It's still OK, but kind of slow to me for the enjoyment I get out of it.  We never really explored Seafarers much...maybe I will some time in the future.  I won't ever get rid of this I think, but I'm content to only play it every few years.
Really what do you say about this game.

Another old standby that doesn't do much for me.  Too luck-based.  Even though the luck of the dice should balance out over the course of the game, people who benefit from lucky rolls in the beginning can lock the others out of the best spots.  Too long a game for that level of frustration!

I kinda like this game, though not as much as I like the card game version. I find the boardgame a bit boring sometimes since the chances of getting the right resources seem to be smaller than in the card game, thus resolving in situations where the players do nothing but roll the dice for resource and then their turn ends. But then again, these two games are quite diffrent from eachother and there's nothing wrong with the board game, though I DO prefer the cards...

I have been on a bit of a rollercoaster ride with Settlers.  Like many others, this was the first Euro-style board game that I played, and it opened my eyes to a whole new way to game and a whole new type of game to play.  For that alone, it holds a special place in my heart.  I played this game almost exclusively for a year or more, and then became burned out on it.  There was a point when I didn't want to play it anymore.  But now that I play it with much more moderation, my opinion of it has increased again.  It has some great strategic decisions when it comes to placing your initial pieces, and the player interaction and replayability are fantastic.  You are certainly at the mercy of the dice in this game, and it is also possible that a player who is not winning can suffer when the other players jump on the leader, merely by sharing a space or two with the leader.  The game is not perfect, and sometimes a particular session just falls flat.  But the fact is that this is a great gateway game with a lot of strategy and a good dose of fun.  In reasonable amounts, it is quite enjoyable.
TOO luck dependant to become a real favourite, for me.

If this game didn't exist, this site would probably not have half the games listed on it. It brought board games to a new level. I get a little board with the game, but I have heard that cities and knights really beefs up the complexity of the game.
Interesting mechanic and all, but the base game can become bit boring with very frequent play. Good game to play with infrequent gamers.
Good game, but I think it's nothing really spectacular.

My primary introduction to eurogames a number of years ago, Settlers of Catan will always have a place in my heart.  However, the mechanics grow more and more stale to me every year, and there's a little too much 'wait and see what the roll of the dice brings' to make this a top tier strategy game.

Everyone seems to rate Settlers that highly and I've introduced a few people to it. I don't often get to play it, mainly because I play a lot of 2 player games with my wife. Although I like Settlers, I don't rate it as highly as some. Mainly because it can be a little boring if you sit in games where the dice don't go your way. Although intelligent placement of settlements is necessary, even that isn't enough to help you sometimes.
A classic but actually we don't like the base game very much.
I enjoy the building aspect of Catan.  I especially enjoy the quality of expansions available for this game, so it's easy to mix it up a bit.
I've played too much Settlers, so my ranking is a little low here. I'll probably drop this rating the next time I play it.

I've probably played Settlers too much (a few dozen games), and it can get a little samey. But it is fundamentally a great design, and is a good introducting to gaming beyond the familiar childhood games

I find this game annoying. Even a minor mistake in the resource management can turn in a nightmare if followed by poor dice rolls. Several turns can be spent hoping for the right numbers to get at least something to trade. I don't think this is a flaw of the game, however, it just isn't very funny for me.
Played recently with Foodstamps variant, and will not play without it now. Too luck driven otherwise and barely rates a 5 in its base form.

I've never been a huge Settlers player, and I'll play occasionally.  I feel it goes on too long for what it's worth.  However, given the group I played with tonight, that was so casual, the game was a lot of fun.

I used to love to play this game but it has fallen out of favour in my game group due to it being too predictable and random. The expansions do little to address the problem and really only make it worse. Still, a great game by any standard.
My first real game away from Risk and Axis and Allies.  This was a classic in our game group for months until we moved onwards and upwards.

This is the game that got me to love board games.   After this game gatewayed me to other designer games the fire to play has diminished severely.  Fun for a social environment, or if used as a gateway game.  Repeated playings will show the few number of real decisions for a player in the course of an hour.  I now think of it more as a party game,  and compare it to Apples to Apples and Scattergories.   This game holds its own.  Don't mess with the expansions or other "Things of Catan".  This is the gem.  The modular board and random placement of chits does not infuse a ton of replayability.  The strategies are the same, it just toggles the strength of them slightly.  The reason I probably over rank it based on my current desire to play it is with new players its way too slow for what the game has to offer, and with players who can get at this quickly there are games I enjoy more I'd rather be playing.  With that being said,  with a couple of cold ones the pacing of a snail does lead to a nice casual very social experience so I can't imagine ever turning down a game of vanilla settlers.  I gave it a whirl after it's been ages sinces I've fired this up.  It is still a good game, but not one of my favorites.

This is only like the one game that revolutionized the entire board-gaming industry.  If you haven't heard of it before now, stop what you're doing, go out and but a copy, and then play it constantly for the next week or so.  Then you'll be able to resume your life a more complete and satisfied person.

[microbadge=5]  No point in being diplomatic.  No point in trading.  No point in developing a strategy that requires more than what's in your hand.  Too many "no points."  I used to say I'd never play this again, but it is worlds again better with Cities and Knights; I'll play that willingly.

Ahhh.  Now I know what all of the fuss is about.  Easy to explain and teach this game.  Can see how this appeals to both gamer and non-gamers and is one of the most popular "crossover" or "gateway" games because of ease of play and enough meaty decesions to be made throughout.
Too long and too much down time as other's play/trade.
I hope to play the cupcake version someday.

There's really just too much luck involved for me to take this game as seriously as others do. You can stack the odds in your favor and still lose, while the player with the two dot ore mines becomes some sort of mining baron. Sure it's fun, but how many times can you replay it? Maybe it just seems tame in comparison to Diplomacy or Traders of Genoa where the negotiation aspects of the game are far more developed.

A classic that I'm still willing to play, but most around here have burned out on. Admittedly, most of my plays were long ago, and I would prefer the Star Trek version, but would still be willing to play the original.
A classic intro eurogame. I still enjoy this with 3 or 4 and with the seafarers expansion. The 5-6 player expansions seem a bit kludgey to me.

Finally got a chance to play this one.  I can see why it was so huge in 1995, but I can also see why its popularity has gone down since then.  Good intro game, but not something I'd play regularly.  Nothing particularly wrong, just so many better options out there now.
The decisions made at the start of the game are the most meaningful, and the rest of the game is just scrounging. Any amount of strategy is ruined by the dice and the whims of the other players.

Once a great gateway game for non-gamers but there's better choices now. Heavy luck factor which can be shifted with a "deck o dice" though most people don't like using the cards. I played this often with only 2 players, there's just limited trade opportunities. With the 5/6 expansion games tend to run VERY long and I played that expansion just once and instantly turned around and resold it.

We have not yet played this with three or four players yet, so I can't give it a fair rating.  We tried many of the two player variants found here, but none of them really worked for us.  Probably the most fun part, the trading, was virtually non-existent.  As a result, the game became a basic resource/building game without too many frills.  However, there was a significant runaway leader "rich gets richer" problem---the first person to get a city saw their resources start to take off well beyond the other player.  There were few ways for the second player to come back.  There were a few games where the robber was parked solely on the losing player's side for most of the game.  As a result, this left a bad taste and drove us away from all things Catan for a long time (which we regretted since there [i]are[/i] some quite good two player Catan games).  To be fair, [GAMEID=13] looks like it would be a lot of fun with more people, but with just two there are much better games.
A whole grade better with the Seafarers expansion
Purchased from Pair-A-Dice Games in Vista, CA

Played this zillions of times with the first and second Mayfair editions in 1990s, then gradually burned out a bit.  2007-02-27 played Polish version "Osadnicy z Catanu".  The trading aspect was challenging for me in Polish. :/  2008-08-23 played a 2nd time in Polish.  Again, the trading aspect was frustrating in a language I don't understand well. :/
SEMPLICE .. un PO' TROPPO.  --------------------------- BY Pallando 30 year old.
