What can I say that hasn't already been said?  This is the game that started it all for me.  The decisions in the base game are not meaty enough to interest me.  I don't dislike the game, but there are so many others I'd rather play.
Too random. Too many sheep jokes. A bit long for a fairly light strategy game.

This is probably one of my favorites but has worn a little thin with me lately. Still fun though.  Update: I've played this a lot online and so I haven't been too anxious to get it to the table lately.  Update 2: The initial love affair with this game has worn off and as I continue to be exposed to more diverse games and game mechanics, I find myself less and less inclined to pull this out. The trading aspect is probably the only thing that will incline me to play this game in the future.

Everyone says this is a great gateway game for non-gamers, but I have never found that to be the case. The game itself is pretty basic and extremely dependent on luck. There always appears to be one logical choice of action given your hand of cards, and given your roll. The trading element is extremely dependent on the group you game with. New gamers tend to trade not at all since they are unsure of the value of things.  [UPDATE] After further playings, I'm lowering the score. The game can come to a standstill if the right resources don't come up.
Got me started in the world of Euro games, but the rich-gets-richer problem and the wild effect of luck at the beginning of the game made me weary of it now that other options are available.

If you don't have cards, you can't build.  You can't get cards unless your numbers come up.  So, this game is entirely based on luck.  It takes no skill to build on the best spots... and even that doesn't always win as the nature of luck means you can see a string of ten 11's in a row.  This is a great concept, but you need to accept that this game offers very little real control to the players.
We only play this with the Cities and Knights of Catan. Seafarers is hohum.
Interesting, though too much depends on initial setup.
The original German version had better artwork than the latest Mayfair print I have.  Anyone wishing to trade the original Siedler version, let me know.

Settlers is a good little game, and at its time was a bit of a breakthrough. I just don't fine myself wanting to play it these days. There are too many other games that I find more satisfying. It still seems to hold great appeal for introduction to "new" gamers.

I can see why this game helped launch a movement. The actual mechanics are easier to see than explain on paper; the turns take just about the right length for me and give you interesting enough things to do. Of course, the hole you may be digging for yourself is your own grave as you drop further and further behind if you don't start off fairly strong or at least competitive. The midgame on can feel like a total drag if you're just treading water without much way of improvement.  The new Mayfair version is pretty nice, and there's absolutely no reason to get the older one instead. However, there's very little reason *to* get the new one if you have the old one unless sliding tiles was a real annoyance for you. In fact, I'm not sure how well the puzzle pieces will wear over time, and it wasn't that easy to get the hexes in it around the edges.
A classic game of negotiation where the dice have more to do with luck than with any relevant probability.

I understand that this game has it's draw.  I taught it to my mother and it is now her favorite game.  I find it somewhat boring though.  The more I play it the better it gets.  I can see different ways of winning and I am getting better at the game.  PI still find it a bit dry though.

Lots of folks love this, but not me.  It's OK.  Sure, it's one of the first Euros I've played, much like everyone else, but this is not one that screamed to me "I gotta get that".  Picked it up from a thrift shop for $3.  It's missing a card and the blue player pieces, but that's OK.  I only need two colours to play with The Kid(tm).

The dice run this game, you just try to do your best with what they give you.  Initial setup is the most important part of the game, after that you just hope that the dice are kind.  You can go for a nice spread of numbers or concentrate on a few.  Either way the dice will go the other way and you sit there cursing for an hour or so.
Got the new one with the plastic bits.

Plays: 9 I'll never get rid of this because of it's gateway factor, but because of how easily you can get resource-screwed based on die rolls, I recently introduced components into the game to play the "Pauper" variant, and won't play without it now.    Unfortunately, I'll never suggest a game of this with other experienced gamers.  For new gamers however, I'll always bring this out to introduce them to the world outside of Monopoly.
a little random and a little long, but a solid light game anyway
I am not particularly into it. But I can see it value as the first-boardgame to introduce people.
Dice rolling at it's finest. This is a nice game, everyone gets it, and almost everyone enjoys it.  The trading makes the game have higher replayability.  Lots of plays. 40-50 perhaps?
good game for its historical value
The game depends far too much of the initial positioning. Miss it and you'll spend the game looking at what the others do.
It is a dice game, but it lets players imagine they have control by allowing them to choose how to spend their resources. We use house rules to make the robber less devastating.

Traded away 9/14  I can see why this kicked off the German Game craze, but for me it's just not that fun. In a 4-player game, 1 player inevitably gets stuck at 4 VP's, doesn't produce much, and sits there with almost nothing to do for 45+ minutes. Not a great time.  With 3 players the board is more open, but trading is harder with only 2 trading partners.  With 5, the board is once again open, but building on every turn makes the 7-card max basically worthless  6 is too long and too crowded.  Cities/Knights is excruciatingly long, and Seafarers adds some stuff that's basically the same as the base game, only played on blue hexes.
Mi primer eurogame. Muy facil y divertido para iniciar a los no jugones. Todo un clasico

Although a classic among its type, not one of my favorites. I think there are better “dice” Euros of the same weight including Kingsburg, Yasphan and Stone Age.    Traders & Barbarians Seafarers Cities & Knights

What can I say?  It's the game that got me into this hobby.  Looking back, my guess is that it's the distinctly NON-euro elements (dice rolling, robber) that were able to make the cross over to the American audience and introduce so many players to other euro-games.  Our last play of this was excruciatingly slow, which is what happens if certain resources fall on certain numbers.    I almost always want to play this with Cities & Knights.
I'm not as big a fan as many of this game, but it is easy to play and makes sense. Certainly a well done game by any measure, although it can get boring if one is used to heavier fare as I am.
This game is great for about two plays every so often.  Then it starts to lose its sheen.
Traded a second copy for Road to the White House
Do you have wood for sheep?  My game group does!
I like Settlers... but the waiting between turns as people try to trade can be painful. A good gateway, but it's lost a little luster to me.
My 7-year-old loves this. Finally, something other than Uno that I can play with my kids.
A lot of dice rolling. Don't understand why it's a gold standard for eurogaming.   Way too long for what it is.
A world-wide favorite, I just can't love it. The game is okay, but not great amounts of fun for me.  Spiel des Jahres 1995.

This is a great game that I bought years ago, before ever becoming a "gamer."  I had heard good things about it (can't remember where) and bout it, despite not really having any gamer friends (much less two, so that we could play this).  Since then, I have had a chance to get into this game, and I love it because it's like a different game every time we lay out the tiles...  EDIT: Pales in comparison to Keythedral.
Definitly not bad, but too much luck. It lasts too long to compete with other better games.

UPDATE: Didn’t feel I needed a shelf full of Catan. Sold.  Like it or not, this is the classic Eurogame. Trading, building and domination in one neat little package. I am continually amazed when I talk to people that I don't consider "gamers" and they say they have played Settlers. If you've never tried it and you're at this site, you should at least give it a shot.  See my review for more details.

I'll admit this rating is a little harsh. It is a good game, but I just don't like it. I want more depth. Haven't tried the Cities & Knights expansion, but I have a feeling I might like it better with that.

Feb 2019: Still a well-designed game. I'm turned off by the weird player interaction that can happen; ganging up on the leader (w/ the robber), or potentially king making.  Original: My gateway game. Loved the balance and the clever mechanics. Played it so much that I got tired of it and moved on to other games. Revisited it again recently and find I still enjoy it. Just not as much as other games.

Decent game. I don't like the pinned because I need a 4 for a resource mechanic. Would like to try cities and knights. - Rerated the basic game to a 4. Boring!   Edit: 10/12/16 - Rerated to a solid 6. It's really not a bad game, and it's very easy to get people to play (including myself). It has it's flaws but the game itself is very easy going, and I can appreciate that.
The dice.  They hate me and I hate them.

Generally overrated. Play with experts only. Play with Cities&Knights expansion!  The trouble is that in most games that I played it was clear after 30min who would win, yet it took another 90 min just to find out for sure. Phew! The game is ok if all participating players know the game well and are clever enough to set themselves up properly. It is usually bad for the entire game if someone manages to have both initial settlements on the same big number - for either this player will win if that number occur es often or that player wont stand a chance if the number occurs not all.

Does a lot of things well, in particular the fairly open trading rules, but there are two major issues I can't get past. First, there's enough strategy that you have to play well to win, but the dice add just enough randomness that the best strategy often will lose to a decent one. I've lost games I should have won due to dice, and worse still, I've won games I had no right winning because of them. In some ways, this is almost more irritating to me than games that are mostly luck, because it gives you the illusion that your strategy matters. As of this writing, the most recent game I played is a good example of this. I was on two 9 hexes of the same resource, which I had a 2:1 harbor for. Another player was on several of the 6s and 8s, and had high probabilities for all resources - but no 9s. We proceeded to roll something like 7 9s in 10 turns, allowing me to rally and take the lead to win. Some might call that risk/reward; for me, that was a hollow victory. My bigger problem with the game is that the structure makes it so that some players may face a fate worse than elimination: being mathematically eliminated from victory but forced to sit through until the end of the game anyway. Some have argued that a shrewd trader can still come back, but it's very apparent when someone cannot do it themselves, so only a pity trade could help them, and nobody likes a pity trade. This probably sounds overly negative, and it's probably a testament to the rest of the design that I still give it a 6 after all that complaining. Those two points are pretty much the only faults I have with the game itself. (Mayfair's pricing practices are another matter...)
recomend this game to everyone easy to learn but I dont own the expansions probably a slight raise on the rating then.
Good 3-4 player game (5-6 w/expansion), but requires lots of room and set up time.

Settlers is fun, and a great way to bring potential board game enthusiasts into the fold, but I feel that it leaves too much up to chance (which can also scare newcomers away if they get really unlucky).
A bit too long, and the second/third edition art is a snooze.
OK, I'll play 3 players with a tourney style start to speed things up. Glad this wasn't my first Euro or I may never have tried another.
The base game is wearing on me.  But it was my first love.  It has a good amount of strategy but the luck factor is a little overwhelming at times.  Sometimes you just can't play around it.
Used to be the most played game in my collection. It has lost that place to either Bohnanza or Caylus, depending on the people i'm going to play with.
To much luck involved. Too simple, but great to introduce new people to board gaming (tried it and succeeded).
It's settlers.  Not my fave, but its gateway appeal is undeniable.

Fun game which I play mainly with my school age girls. Had a proud gaming dad moment when I got up one morning during the school holidays and found my 8 year old playing my 6 year old on the rumpus room floor.  Without me suggesting it!

This is a wonderful board game that can be explained to new players, setup, and played well under 1 1/2 hours. This to me makes it a wonderful experience. Every time I teach someone this game, they want to play it again and again, and with a game time around 40 minutes, this is never unreasonable.   This is one of the best games for non-gamers.
I will never play this game with 3 players.
Great staple game for 4 people.  A perfect intro into euro-style boardgaming.

The classic eurogame. Fun for all ages, with more luck than strategy, but has paths to go for the skilled ones. 2016-09-18: downrated from 7 to 6. I noticed that I don't really have much fun playing this game. I still think it is a classic, it was very original and deserves a place in history, but today there are better games.
A colleague at work got me into to this. It has lost its lustre over the years.

Update: Rating dropped from 9.  Basic Settlers doesn't do enough for me these days.  I need to "kick it up a notch" with expansions like Cities & Knights... or maybe Das Buch (which has some interesting variants like hot air balloons).
Only played this once, average game, must be much better with an expansion.

What is wrong with all the millions of people loving this game? Settlers of Catan without expansions is as much fun as playing soccer without a ball. I simply don't get it, though I know that I'm part of a minority ;-)

SOLD IT!  A classic staple to own... Of course if you want to play with more than 4 people, buy the "extra people" expansion... Come on Mayfair!! If you want it all (both expansions and the ability to play with 5-6 people), get ready to spend almost $200!! Wow, they make those wood bits out of expensive trees!!

Классика. Однако, количество значимых решений на единицу времени слишком мало по сравнению с современными играми. Игру спасает только возможность (и необходимость) торговаться (меняться ресурсами) между собой.
We used to play this game a LOT from 1995 to roughly 2000. At the time it rated a 9 to me, but I've played it so much that it no longer seems fun.

Good game for beginners... It's a luck based game... If you have luck in the beginning of the game, you'll probably win. Very few things to do. Few things to think about. Poor strategy. But It's funny to play with no gamers.
A gateway game of social interaction and getting the most of the dice roll. And I win often :) ----- 2009-09-18: 8.0 -> 7.5 There are better games I want to play more.

One of the most difinitive Euros in existance. More randomness than later Euros, but absolutley awesome. That it has had such appeal for so many people for so long is a testament to this brilliant game.  See my [url=http://www.boardgamegeek.com/article/1781161]review[/url] for my full thoughts.
I'm not crazy about the game, but i respect what it has done for the hobby. Somewhat better with cities and knights.

Uno dei pochi boardgame tedeschi che vendono nei supermercati, e in italiano: gli va quindi reso merito per essere una delle teste di ponte nella diffusione dei german game in Italia. Il gioco ha regole semplicissime, e c'è moltissima interazione tra i giocatori: oltre alla possibilità di sgambetto (col brigante e con la semplice occupazione territoriale) c'è lo scambio di materiali, indispensabile perché all'inizio è difficile essere indipendenti. Il gioco è enormemente influenzato dal fattore-culo (anche se la distribuzione normale dei tiri di dado aiuta chi non si distraeva alle lezioni di statistica), ma rimane godibile e leggero. Da giocare quando si ha fretta - anche se allo scopo ci sono in giro titoli migliori - o per catturare nella spirale dei giochi da tavolo gli amici non praticanti. Nota negativa: nella versione italiana la spiegazione delle regole è demenziale.
HAvent played this in a looong time.  UPDATE: played again yesterday, this game really doesnt do it anymore for me. It felt boring meaningless and random. Sorry Catan.
Sold to make up room for more gaming goodness!!

I *still* play this game from time to time so it's hard to rate honestly. I don't much care for it anymore. A lot of my family does, however, so it continues to get played. And I don't have an awful time when I am involved.
Nice trading & development game. Good entertainment with the right players, needs people who are willing to haggle & trade. Some luck but keeps everyone involved throughout. Good game.

Good game to introduce non-gamers to Euros. Otherwise I'd rather play something meatier. Trading is fun. Occasionally, games can start to get very long and drawn out. Don't feel drawn to buy any of the expansions. I don't have the latest version, which would make the new expansion editions problematic.
Much better Catan games since, also don't like reliance on dice
Fun Family game.  Only play for fun.  3 people game can be stupid if they wont trade. Also, the robber early on can be too devasting and make the game boring.  Too much based on luck and diplomacy.

More interesting as a historical artifact than an actual game. An undeniably clever design, but familiarity breeds contempt.   It shows its age (and I like old games), and it's unbalanced and takes way too long. It's a high-interaction game that I'd rather play against computer opponents. There is no way I'd use this to introduce someone to the hobby, evene if I owned it. But I'll play it on  a dare.
My gateway into the gamer world. It was my passion and obsession for a few years, but as of late it seems that it just does not make it off the shelf. So many new games to explore instead!

Only one play to date (and a win at that) - rating could move a point or two in either direction, but a great first experience.  The only knock is that, looking back, I played this as a pure abstract - the theme was non-existent in my head.  Maybe that's why I won?
Too random and has no real strategy for me.
Bland game without the expansions.  Far blander after having tried the expansions and going back to it without them.

The game that started it all. It's great, but it has it's flaws. Last time I played, my wife cut me off at the very beginning, making it virtually impossible to win. I called her a bad name, and later shamefully vowed to never play it again.  The trading aspect is great, but once you know the trick to a great setup--it loses its fun.
It's not bad, I just played it too much? And this game wears off quite fast. Maybe due to it's lightness or noticeable random factor.
Finally has has come into its own as a family game in our house as the kids have gotten that little bit older.
While Settlers is a good gateway game, I have found that it just does not interest me as much as it used to.  Still worth having and playing I just won't suggest it anymore.

I still remember my very first play of Settlers when it was just released in Germany ... and I didn't like it much. I guess for us in Germany the mechanics etc. weren't as much a revalation as they must have been for the US gamers. The trading aspect is nice, but overall it doesn't inspire me very much.
Not really my cup of tea.  Play is balanced and interactive however.  This is one of my wifes favotite games.
Good game but there are too few dice rolls for resources. This can make the luck factor too important given the length of the game.

Considered along with Puerto Rico to be one of the classics.  Overall I like the theme and the approach to the game, the only thing that drives me crazy are the dice.  Despite long term probability the dice in settlers seem to enjoy tormenting players, (myself at times especially) which seems to take the game from having strategy to mainly having luck which I don't like.  I certainly like having a random element in games, I just think in settlers the dice have more influence than they should.
The game we play more than any other in my group. And for a good reason!!! (not so much anymore, thus rating goes down)

I enjoy the resource management and trading that this game offer.  However; the charm of this game has waned for me over repeated plays.  I still enjoy it, but the rating has suffered a bit for me.  I would rarely slap this game on the table to play, but if invited I would rarely say no.

This is a 10 if played with dice decks instead. It has the bell curve for planning, trading/robber for interaction, and some blocking for cut throat play. Just a magnificent package, except for the dice!   Update: 4-16-2007 This is the game that got me into this hobby.  I loved it and even played this 2 player and still loved it.  I thought it was the greatest game ever in the world.  I don't know if it is a good or bad thing, but the aforementioned sentiments has passed.  I find the gameplay/strategies in this game to be elementary and dull.  Really, the only exciting thing going on the game is seeing where the dice will fall.  Those two bones greatly affect how you are going to do in the game.  Of course there are somethings you can do to help you out, but the luck in this game is significant.  This game is hard to rate as I respect it and have nostalgic baggage that comes with it but I just don't want to play it more than I have to. Update: 9 -> 6
It's a classic game here on the Geek. It still is a good game, just not as much fun as some of the more recent stuff that built on the Catan system.
Nice game. Rarely play it without the Cities & Knights expansion. Still an excellent gateway game. Sold game & expansions Oct/2011. Had not played in 2 years.
K - markiert  incl. Erweiterung "Städte und Ritter incl. Erweiterung "5+6 Spieler"
While not a massive fan, there's no denying Catan has class.

I know this is the classic gateway game, and I like some of the mechanics, but I just find the base Catan a bit bland for my taste.  You should try it at least once, since it's a classic and has some neat mechanics, but I much prefer Struggle for Rome, which uses the same mechanics in a more streamlined and directed way.  If you're going to play regular Catan, at least add Cities & Knights, which adds some more good decisions and available routes to resources (e.g. bonus cards).
One of the few 'go-to' games for infecting newcomers.
As for most, this was my entrygame for eurogames. Have played it to death, but am burnt out on it ... at least on the base game.  It is what it is and that it'll always be. :)

(> 20 plays) Settlers is a good gateway game, although I must admit that I don't play "vanilla" settlers anymore, as I'm kind of burnt out on this one. I'd rather play one of the variants which come with the Seafarers expansion, with "Siedler - Das Buch zum Spielen" and with "Historische Szenarien II". I particularly like the "Troy" scenario.  Rating lowered from 7 to 6 due to burn-out.
I've had a lot of fun with this game, and it's one that I'll break out when there are non-gamers around, but I don't really enjoy it anymore.

Over hyped game, the Limited edition set was very nice, but fatally flawed game play due to the randomness of dice rolls and the ability for the muppet at the table to trade victory to an opponent. One random mechanic is acceptible in a game this has many random mechanics and it not acceptible.
Solid game and a classic.  Given the choice though I'd probably rather play one of the variants or expansions.
Liked it much better the first thirty times I played it than the second thirty times...
After dropping off of my radar, it's made a slight comeback, and gotten played a couple of times.  Best if played fast!
Fine game -- enjoy playing.  I even have the travel edition, which is especially handy when going away for the weekend.
Christmas present - played a few times now. Not as good as I remember it being - would rather play something else.
Traded away after few games. I don't really get the trading part right, random and boring as hell.

I don't like this game, which has grown into a true classic.  I think the strategy involved mostly dries out after the first colonies have been placed, afterwards, the game becomes boring and too luck-dependant.  Settlers has done a lot to draw more people to board games, and for that I am grateful.
Doesn't really do it for me. Too simple, too dependent on the trading mechanic and the initial positions.
It's a classic.  I like it whenever I get to play this one.

One of the first German-style games I played, I played it so often when it first came out I am now burned out on it.  The problem is that it is very easy to have execessive down time due to your number never being rolled.  I will play it once per year - thats it. I will make exceptions if there is a newbie who has never played (because it is a very important game in the hobby's history) but I never ask to play it.

A great gateway game, but also introduced me to a number of issues I have since judged all games by. A player should not be eliminated from a potential win by the beginning turns and a leader should not be able to continue his run towards victory so easily. Sure he can be robbed or denied a trade, but for such a cutthroat style of board setup, the actual chances to screw your neighbor are low. I moved on, although I enjoyed my time in Catan.  60-90m (too long!), best with 4 players. 10+ plays.
It was really fun before I played it to death.
With turnier rules on BSW this is still fun.. only way i play the original settlers anymore
Good party game/non-wargamer fare.  Needs more violence.
Once a great game, the Settlers are starting to feel a bit old.
While I would likely rate this a 6 or 7 today, there's no denying that this is by far my most played game. Great gateway game, but I've moved on.

I really like settlers but often feel it's missing something.  It's easy to teach people how to play and I like how something can benefit or penalize everybody on every die roll.  The game can seem to drag at times and has that feeling of "missing something" once you've played a lot.  I don't really like the way a player can hide victory points and surprise you at the last minute that they've won.

A simply economic game for whole family. For me too much randomness and not enough blood ;)... I've played it about 15 times with my family and several times by the Internet (flash game) with my friend. And I don't want any more :P
Interesting but not one of my favorites
I have nothing specific against this game, but I feel that there are better ones out there.  For a modular board game, I don't find it to have that much variety.
Classic game. I really like it and so does everyone i pull it out for. Wish the setup wasnt so annoying and i would rate this game higher.
I heard a lot about this game, so we got a copy.  To be honest, I found it a bit dull after 3-4 plays.  Not a whole lot of strategic depth to it.  It is suitable for play with children, though.
Can be really good, or just really long and slow. Has a problem with obvious winners that take an hour to reach the win condition.

Classic game, although now it seems rather basic by comparison with current Euro-games.  However it's still a great starter for people new to gaming and probably responsible for getting lots of people into the hobby.

Collect and trade resources to be the first to expand your settlement to 10 points.  Plays: More than a dozen? Type: VP engine = a game where you build an engine to collect victory points most efficiently. Complexity: Family game = a game that is easy to teach and play. # of players: 4. Playing time: 90 mins. Player interaction: Trading. Competition for scarce resources - settlement locations. Targeting - placing the robber. Randomness: Medium - dice, but you can prepare for rolls to some extent.  Replayability: Medium. This is always a good experience and most people are fine to play again, but maybe not right away? There is some depth to explore. Fun: Good fun. Trading makes it highly interactive. It's fun when your numbers come up, less fun when they don't. Memorabiity: Not so high, it's still a VP engine that doesn't create stories.  Thematic integration: Weak. Components: Nice.  Who will like this: Family gamers.
resources to often don't get generated in ratios suggested by numbers due to randomness of dice rolling

One of the best gateway games (Carcassonne is the best, IMO). Most fun when everyone gets into it and trades with each other, which isn't hard to do in a game like this. But after so many years of playing it, we've moved on to other games.

My first German game and it is what got me into this hobby.  Has nostalgic value and I still enjoy it time to time although it can be really frustrating when dice rolls don't get you resources and you can do nothing to improve your position.  So should I rate it higher because it was so great when I didn't know better and therefore led me to other games?  Nah.
Very nice gateway game. You can make the Settlers test with your friends: If they like it, they'll probably also like "heavier games". If not, too bad!

Very fun, good balance of strategy (in placement and diplomacy) and luck (sometimes good/bad dice can make/break a game)  A regular in my group.  edit: after many plays this one comes out rarely - but when it does it it still good fun.  Considered something of a beer and pretzels game for my group now more than the creme de la creme
trading, strategy game. Good at teaching the art of negotiation.
Great game to introduce a US game player to some Euro mechanics.  Still involves Dice Rolling.
There's no doubting its historical value and its elegance, but age has treated it poorly.
Not a big fan of Settlers, but if we have to play, vanilla with 4p max is my preference.
If you don't roll the dice like a god... forget this game. Too luck dependent.
A nice classic, but too long for the level of randomness in the game.

I actively avoid this game.  Too repetitive, too few decisions, too much annoying futzing around with the resource cards, great potential for a randomly-selected runaway loser.  The Settlers of Catan did help me discover the broader world of German games, though, so I have to give the game some credit there.  Better with Seafarers, which allows for some variety at least.

I like this game when the dice cooperate, and I hate it when they don't. They usually don't. There's nothing worse than waiting 15 minute before you can do anything because the right numbers didn't come up.  It's so strange that this is the ultimate gateway game. It guess it makes some sense from the perspective of complexity. It's got some interesting mechanics without being hard to learn. But it has such huge flaws. Every game seems to drag about 20 minutes too long. Careful planning can be ruined by unlucky dice rolls. And the difference between winning and losing is actually very subtle. Getting those last two points is crazy tricky for a game that's supposed to be relatively simple.
This used to be a 10 for me, but has gone down due to the repetitiveness that I've found with the game.  Still, a great game and my introduction to German gaming.  Much more fun using the expansions.
2 Versions:  1) Red, Green, Blue, Yellow 2) Black, White, Orange, Purple

Rating would be higher if I weren't so burned out. In my mind, I get really excited about buying up cool development cards and so on... but once I actually put my hands on the box, this strange feeling comes over me and I put it down.
Didn't really like.  Winning seemed to depend more on luck than actual player diplomacy (ie. trading).

BestWith:4>3_not5,6 [Dice rolling, Resource Management, Building, Trading] Play 2 Variants: Variant 1: Robber 7's are rerolled for the first 2 times round the table. Variant 2: Food Stamps: If a player doesn't receive a resource during the Raw Material Phase, he gets a Chip. If a 7 is rolled, all players get a Chip. At any time on his turn a player may turn in chips equal to his current Victory Point total to receive a resource card of his choice. (Victory Points includes Largest Army and/or Longest Road/Trade Route, but not hidden Victory Point cards.) Spiel des Jahre 1995.

A classic intro game, but free trading can really hurt a game from becoming really great. I will always use this to introduce Risk and Axis & Allies players to boardgames though. I remember one game where a friend of mine said "I can't believe that a game can actually be this much fun without us killing eachother."

Birthday gift 2008 from Brittney. This game shows its strength because it is one of the most frustrating games I have ever played, yet I love it and keep coming back for more. It creates intense rivalries that do not exist outside of this game among my friends.  I am pretty sick of this game at the moment. I need to take a nice long break. It's frustrating for me that this is the game that gets requested most often by my fiance and my friends. There are so many other games I would rather play.

I was quite late to the Settlers party, and it's hard for me to have much historical appreciation for the old warhorse.  I get that it opened a lot of eyes to the Euro possibilities here in the States, but I just wasn't blown away.  I got my Gateway on playing Carcassone H&G and Ticket to Ride Europe, and that was enough to send me on my way.  By the time I got to Settlers, I was all, "Oh.  That was...nice."  The best part of this game is that it can be very social and very tense.  The worst part is when it's neither social nor tense.  The VERY WORST THING about Settlers is that you can go several rounds (or half the game) without doing anything on your turn.  Roll the dice, pass the dice.  Yuck.  Basically, I think that the set collection and building mechanics were improved upon quite a bit with the Ticket to Ride franchise.    I'll play this when my just-getting-into-gaming friends suggest it, but I'll never offer to play it again.

Ah, the gateway game.  This was where it started for me, to a certain extent.  I like settlers.  The computer version is wonderful, as it removes setup completely, which can be somewhat arduous.  The random board aspect is both good and bad.  Occasionally the randomness is problematic, and that can lead to unbalanced resource distribution.  Still, a fun one.

A great introduction to gaming game.  Personally, I found the game to take way too long to finish.  Also, the randomness of the rolls can seriously affect the game, which in this game detracts from the experience.  That said, still a good fun game.

This is a fun game for what it is, and was my "Euro" gateway game.  I think that there is a lot wrong with this game, from the run-away-leader syndrome from getting lucky, to the sometimes extremely bleak availability of resources sometimes produced from a random set up, but I will still play it most of the time when my friends suggest it, often as filler between heavier games.

At one time, was the game of choice. It's sat on the shelf for quite some time now, because the trading aspect can make or break the game depending on who else is at the table.  My set contains 8 colors, which is both of Mayfair's editions. Red/Blue/Green/Yellow and White/Black/Orange/Purple
The game that got me into Eurogames. Still think it is a reasonable game, though I greatly prefer it with the Cities and Knights expansion.
Not bad, a little too dependent on die rolls.

A classic that completely deserves all the international awards (and commercial success) it received. Still, in my humble opinion, it did not stand the test of time very well. When compared to modern day classics, it suffers from a lack of options and the fact that it really only shines with three players (with four, one player runs out of building sites very, very quickly). Much, much better with the Cities & Knights expansion. As far as cosmetics are concerned, I much prefer the original version with its wooden components.
One of the first euros I ever played. I wouldn't mind getting into a game now and then, though most others around me are pretty much settled out.

Fun luck based game with some strategic decisions to be made.  Particularly important is the placement of your starting villages.  Good introduction to the hobby; however, I feel that this game wears thin with repeated playings.  Just revisited this one after a long hiatus, and the honeymoon is definately over.  I found myself bored shortly after the set-up.  Dropping Settlers down 1 point- I will play, but would rather be playing something else.
The Grandaddy of euros still finds its way to the table on occasion but is not met with the same passion it once was. It can be too frustrating if the dice do not cooperate.
Fun, simple, and fairly fast.  Can be pretty tense when several players are in contention for victory.  Nice to play with friends, not fun at all with a bad group.  I avoid online play.

If you deploy properly in the first turns, you can play in a mediocre way and still win.  Mess up on the first turn and no amount of brilliant play can recover the situation.  Dear Wife and I play more Carcassonne now, and it has a more ding-dong down-to-the-wire feel about it.

OK game. If I'm looking for a trading game I'd prefer to play Chinatown, but this game does have some interesting elements.  Must play with the "Harbor Master" (A settlement on a harbour is worth 1 "harbour point". A city on a harbour is worth 2 "harbour points". The first player to reach 3 harbour points gets the "Harbour Master" card and the 2 VP that go with it. A player who achieves more harbour points than the current Harbour Master takes the card and becomes the new Harbour Master.) and play to 11 VP to balance the game out.
Purchased 4/3/08  Sold in my game auction Sept 2009

I've only played the beginners games as instructed in the rule booklet. After a couple of plays it hasn't quite got me looking to flog it to death like most games I enjoy. My family enjoy it and like the trading with each other aspect but prefer Ticket to Ride. Problem is I'm itching to play a deeper game and I think that's the reason I've rated it so. I think after a few more games playing full rules this rating will improve.
Excellent starter game. It was the one that brought me in to German games. It also holds up well after you move on.

Juego para mi muy entraÃƒÂ±able, extremadamente recomendable para principiantes en este mundo. Fue de los primeros que tuve y aunque ahora ya no juego, siempre tendra un espacio privilegiado en mi memoria.
There is a reason that this is considered by many to be THE gateway game.  A great resource management game.
Many plays.  Classic, but I am hopelessly burned out on Settlers now.  This game was the first to get on my list of "Games I Don't Want to Play for at Least a Year."
More complicated than I like in game with such minimal graphics -- overtaxes my mind when I want to have fun.  I got this game by accident when I really wanted Carcassonne.  :-)  Traded it away.
Great with four players, less great otherwise.

I played the game a lot some years ago. Now I am not so excited about it any more. Still a must have in your collection if you want to get new people in board gaming. That is why the high rank - I am willing to play it often because it is easy to convince people to play it.   UPDATE: Actually it gets quite a lot of play as my wife and my brother g/f do enjoy it a lot.   UPDATE AND NOTE: I downgraded the rating as now I am only willing to play it with new people. With seasoned bordgamers I will not play it anymore (if given a choice)

My gateway game. Still fun, because I never played the snot out of it, like a lot of other people did. Initial placement is everything. I don't like to play with 4 players, as it seems to screw up the end-game, and the extra negotiation and downtime can make it not worthwhile. One of my favorite things to do in all of board gaming is to plan for and play the Monopoly card.  4+2

A fun game that our gorup likes to fall back on.  Sort of like our "old Reliable".  I really enjoy the trading and bargaining involved.  Yes the game has some luck elements but they are manageable.  It's a good game for introducing new players to the hobby.  Rating lowered to a 6.  All of the above still apply but I would add the following.  Never play any flavor of SoC with more than 4.  More than that and the game breaks down to the point of boredom.  Avoid playing with whiners or AP types.  And finally, only play base Settlers when you're teaching someone the game.  Seafarers and C&K are just plain superior.
The penultimate Euro game. Because it skews too far in that direction, that's why it's not my cup of tea.
Liked it, but don't love it.  I really prefer Ticket to Ride.
This was one of my gateway-games. Great for beginners!

January 2011: This was one of the first boardgames of mine. We played this a lot back then, but now there just are so many better games to play, that this rarely hits the table. The problem here is that the game is a bit too luck based for my taste and takes a bit too long to play. My wife likes this, so I guess I will be playing this every now and then.
My first game that opened me to the world of Boardgaming. Right now, there are many better games than this, but this game will always remain nostalgic.
I'm extremely lucky in Settlers. I like it enough for a 7, but giving it a 6 taking into account the expressions of the other people around the table whenever I play.

It's fantastic as a gateway game in its huge improvements over classic games -- notably Monopoly.  But compared to all these other modern games now, I don't think it's as outstanding.  It's solid with some light decisions of what to build and an effective trading angle.  But it does have a bunch of die rolling that can influence the game to much.  I'd usually rather play something else.
Pretty fun. It amazed me how this went from 'uber euro game!' to 'light spend-an-hour euro' as the group's abilities and 'gaminess' picked up.
The design that set the eurogame standard, but now outdated.
The classic introductory game. It has aged well, but serious gamers are likely to outgrow it.
Classic game... excellent short game to teach new gamers.
Increible, seis años y aún me sigo picando con el
this one got a little old for a while until my kids were old enough to play now i enjoy it quite a bit again.
Simply: very good.  Went down to 6, it did just wear off a little bit...
Only play with C&K now, don't like the vanilla settlers much but great for a session with non-gamers.
I give it a 6 without expansions, 8 with cities and knights.

Nice tile laying game. Good resource management, negotiating skills and a considerable modicum of luck required but, always good fun to play. Fiendish use of the thief is essential to knock back those who are doing just a little too well!  Gifted to Kathy at Frome Games Club 03/04/2014.
Why is this game in my collection if I never play it?  Is it nostalgia?  One has to wonder...

Glad I finally got to play. I only played the base game and that only twice. Not an exciting game and seems to be very luck driven {Not a bad thing because some of my favorite games are luck driven}. I hear the expansions liven things up a bit but the base game experience is just O.K.
I don't crave playing this game, but everyone else likes to play it because they know it, I get stuck playing this game too often.  Good strategy easily succumbs to bad dice rolls.
the more I play this, the more it's starting to grow on me
New ed purchased '08 - no-one ever plays it so not sure why I bought it now. Got to stop checking out the sales! Traded away in Oz Math Trade May 2011

My only few sessions with the UVA boardgaming club (or whatever it was called) involved playing this game and it was my first Euro experience.  I was disappointed that this was the kind of game that dominated the club, though I found Settlers to be decent.  I'm sure if I played it more now, I'd like it better, and I'm sure I will play it.  I do prefer a deeper theme and that's a major reason I'm slightly biased against Euro games.

Lots of player interaction and my friends and family like it.  The dice are frequently annoying and it's sometimes possible to determine your odds of winning immediately after placing your first 2 settlements, which can suck the fun out before the game even starts.

The game mechanic can be a refreshing change.  I enjoy playing this game but not as much as I enjoy other people enjoying it (if you know what I mean).  I taught my nephews how to play it, now I'm going to have to get the game for them.
There must be something wrong with me, I just dont get on with this game.  Is it too cereberal?
Great with my wife and my 8 year old son.

Great stepping stone, one of my family's fav's, and even after a ton of plays it's still not a game I'd turn down. (I generally enjoy each game more than I thought I would)  This is a staple for every game closet.
Just as much fun as all the people say it is, but the light nature of it does not make you wanna play it a lot.
Solid game, but I'm a bit burned out on it.

There are a lot of things to love about this game, but there's also a lot not to like. The only thing that really bugs me, though, is that you never get the benefit of the last city/settlement/road you build. You have to build it to get the last point to win the game, but it doesn't do anything in-game.
4p 3p Have travel version also. Trading is fun but the dice can be cruel; prefer Ticket2Ride for gateway play.

Of course this is THE gateway game. Of course all began with this game.  But's it's too long (have you ever played basic game without extensions for two hours straight? I had even longer games)  Maybe with cities and knights it's ok but I didn't tried this one out yet

You can loose on turn 1, or you can loose to the dice - both issues are no good with me.  It's probably still the best gateway game there is (alongside Ticket to Ride).  It gets much better with 5 or 6 players.
was great back in the day, but now i find it a little boring. would like to try some expansions for this, but won't search them out on my own.
The game that got me sucked into this whole thing... If only I hadn't seen it in the store that one day...
Excellent game to introduce new gamers.
Quieres introducir a tus amigos a los juegos de mesa más allá del monopoly, pues ya sabes, ponles delante de un Catán.
Mayfair 4th Edition.  My "for trade" set includes Seafarers of Catan, and the 5-6 player extensions for base Catan nd Seafarers, all in one box (with the original insert removed).

Classic and for a good reason.  I want to play this with my family more often once things settle down more.  I can see why it makes a great gateway game.  EDIT: I'm rethinking my rating and views on this game ... again.
Used to love it, but have since cooled on it somewhat
Played several times between 1994 and 2000  Minus: 1 - 2 - 3 (i just don't like it)
Loved this game for a long time but maybe due to excessive playing the rating has dropped from 9 to 6. A Good game still, but I won't be the one to lay this on the table.

Light but very nice game, I like that it's quite short and very interactive, can work well as a break between longer and heavier games, but you can also spend the whole evening playing it. Still it's a lot better with at least one expansion set.
Was fascinated by this game initially, but don't have much interest in it anymore.

Like many, Catan got us into gaming.  Cities and Knights makes it so much better, but I'm plenty happy with the vanilla version.  It is the fastest growing game in the US for a reason.  My copy is well played. We played it a ton before we started recording plays on BGG.

I used to play this one a lot.  It is a good solid euro.  Unfortunately, after about 40 plays, started to get bored of it.  There is a problem with players getting behind and being stuck forever with no hope of catching up at a certain point, so not everyone feels really 'in the game'
Never really clicked with me or anyone I played it with.  Eventually sold it in the FLGS after playing a few time and then it sitting idle several years on the shelf.

4th Edition.  I played this a ton online before I "found" board games.  I'll play but it's starting to show its age.  There are other games I go to now for gateways, and sometimes I just can't get into the trading.
played many times in a previous life, there are now too many better games
just goes to show, any game can be ruined with the right players
Play it constantly. Luck is a huge factor
Fun but you are mostly at the mercy of all the other players.  One poor player can ruin it.
too long for what it is
Good design and fluid mechs. The peices aren't bad for a Euro and the robber is cool to overtly backstab (don't find that too often in Euros). In the end I prefer Hansa for a very similar experience.

Still a family favorite after all these years. We've taught dozens and dozens of people how to play and not one person did not like it. We buy copies as gifts for friends now and they go on to teach other nongamers. This game is still THE gateway game.

I started playing this because everyone was playing this. I soon learned that it's easy to end up with no early resources or in a poor position or on the receiving end of bad dice rolls and antagonistic trading... and spending 90 minutes watching other people win while unable to do anything is not my idea of fun.

This was a completely new gaming experience when I first played this. There's a lot of luck with the resource generation, but it is really a matter of "covering all the numbers", or making sure you can generate/trade resources whenever you can. Easy to play, but filled with a wide range of strategies, and just the right amount of luck. I've used this as a gateway game to convert several Scrabble die-hards into enthusiastic Settlers fans! The Cities & Knights expansion adds another layer of complexity, and more tension. The 5-6 player expansions add yet another dimension to the game, with the addition of the "special build" reactionary phase. Seafarers seems to be suited for scenario play, but not much else. Initial rating: "8". Peaked at "9", briefly with the 5-6 player expansion.  Update (05/28/2009): 6 F2F plays. This is turning out to be a frustrating game, in terms of the trends in dice rolling. Some games are simply dominated by an preponderance of 5's, 9's, 10's... any number that I happen to NOT be on. Or it could go the other way; there have been games where several people sit around and cannot do anything, simply because the rolls are not coming up in the frequency that they should be based on statistics. Either the dice are funky (which mean don't play with the dice that came with the game), or this is just one of those things. The Law of Large Numbers indicates that eventually, EVENTUALLY, the dice will start rolling favorably. But this trough of bad luck could last most of the entire game, making play extremely frustrating. It may be time to start using the "number cards", because this is starting to break the game for me, as well as others. This is evidenced by the fact that most meetup members refuse to play this game because of its excessive randomness. Dropping to a "7".  Update (08/17/2010): Lately, it hasn't gotten the love it once engendered. Downgrading to a "6".  Update (12/21/2013): It has been 4.5 years since last play. It is a significant achievement in the world of board gaming, truly a "classic" in every meaning of the word right up there with Monopoly--a game that is even "better" than Monopoly. It was a great game for the period, but the group has moved on to greener pastures. It looks like the game doesn't have the legs we thought it had; since there is too much unmitigated randomness, it has alienated most of the veteran gamers I know. But, the design is a perfect blend of competition, negotiation/trading, randomness, and skill, with a very accessible rule set and game mechanics, I am sure it will continue to bring in and endear many new generations of board gamers to come. Still holding at a "6".  Update (03/13/2015): 7 F2F plays. Finally! After nearly six years, we played a 4-player, base Catan game! It's like a homecoming. We forgot some of the basic rules, but the fun was back. Nice, quick romp, just like Dominion--a classic that you never forget. Still a "6".
Not to bad. If you are used to the tournament version on brettspielwelt, the original version just takes to   long.
my first euro, I loved it, I played it nearly 3 times a day for months, then at least two times a week for a few years.  Now I cant bring myself to even look at it.
1995 Spiel de Jahres  Its ok for what it is (a random negotiation game). But the kids enjoyed it, so I can see us playing it some.
I pledge myself to this game - it brought me to boardgaming! Nowadays I'm not so much eager to play it because of the amount of luck involved, but would never reject a game or two.

I HATE Settlers.  Is it a bad game?  No, anything but.  Why then?  Becuase we played nothing else for *months* when our group first moved from MtG to board games.  Once every 6 months is fine for me.  So why do I dislike it so much?  In an ideal game everyone would have equal luck with the resources at an equal time during the game.  However, the game can be skewed so badly by one player getting their share of the luck early on in the game. Once that player or even those players are ahead it is very difficult to rein them in simply because if they have not been stupid with their expansion plans they will be getting resources more often than everyone else.  A good starting position while essential to win, in no way guarantees it.  How many 5 'n' 9's games have you had when you have been able to get a 6 and 8 for your starting villages.  Some randomness in games is a good thing, perfect information and grand strategy has it's place but for me the spice and seasoning is the little random events that make you re-think, re-evaluate and plan on the fly.  Settlers has far too much of that good thing.  It is a frustrating game for that reason with a lack of control to go with it.  Sure over time the skillful player will win more games in the same way that an expert backgammon player will beat the novice every time over a set of games.  Oh and heaven forbid that you as the unlucky one be adjacent to the "leader" in which case the robbers directed at them will happily sit on your resources as well.   Yes it is a great game that can simply bring new and innovative mechanics to an audience raised on the gaming hind teat that is monopoly and Clue(do).  Yes it has been hugely influential in the expansion of this hobby and yes I hve probably played this more than any other game that I own.   But there are better games.  Better games for gamers with more control ahd deeper thought; better gateway games for non-gamers with simpler rules and a more forgiving start.   Settlers will always have a place in my collection the trouble is twce a year is more than enough for it to hit the table.

Played 3 times. Each game, after the first 20 minutes, there was an obvious leader, and those in last place were forced to suffer through the remaining 45+ minutes. Knowing there was no way to catch up less than halfway through the game makes for a frustrating experience.
I've got the Polish edition. Nice game, depending on the dices - snowball effect is noticeable.

My gateway to the world of boardgames via Xbox Live. A very special game.  Still a classic, still enjoy it but a little of the magic has worn off, esp after playing Cities and Knights. I'm also more excited to play something newer to me, since I still have many games that have yet to be played, or only played a few times.  I've printed up the Harbor Master card but have yet to use it. I also ordered some purple pieces for Catan/Cities & Knights/Seafarers for the wife.  Played this a lot before I started logging plays at BGG.
A nicer starter game.  However the better the players are the more randomness controls the game.  There is to much manipulation between experienced players and new players.
I'm over it, but will keep.
The trading aspect can kill this game for me.  It drags.

This game suffers from a lot of criticism due to its popularity.  But it remains one of the gold standards of gaming.  It is fun, relatively quick, simple and accessible.  And it's more than a gateway game : it represents the fun that board games can provide at a more elemental level, or the creativity that games can generate through its myriad official and unofficial expansions and house rules.  An essential part of the core of any games collection.
Needs one or both expansions to really shine.
Played a lot back in the day.  The components and board are nice, but other similarly themed games win out over this one nowadays.

(As of [b]2+[/b] plays) The poster-child for contemporary boardgaming. I have a very hard time getting excited about playing this, especially as my past experiences with it have always felt a bit too long for what it's worth, but it has all the ingredients necessary for a decent two hours of gaming. Its brand-name recognition makes it worth a place on my shelf.   [b]3 year verdict:[/b] How shall I say this? I respect it for what it is, but I'd only play it to humor a new gamer.

Played once, and enough for me. Too much dice luck involved and the trading phase is tedious, nowadays there are lots of games that are better to introduce people to boardgames IMHO.   *update*  Traded, and I'll never regret.  *update*  Several years later, I get another copy in a gaming poll but I'm trading it in shrink.

Fun little game. I've only played it on the Xbox and then, only against the AI. I think this would be a really fun game with people as the trading aspect encourages a lot of interaction. There's maybe a bit more luck involved than I would like, but it's not bad.
Wonderful gateway game.  Doesn't hit the table too often in our regular game group anymore, but is always a great thing to break out for new people.
I good game, but doesn't get much play now.
A great game for both family and the hardcore gamers, strategy is important but alot of random elements invites the lighthearted ones too.

Used to be an 8 but I’ve played so many times (perhaps 100) that I’m played out. Would only play the base game with 4, might consider seafarers with 3, all other combinations tend to overstay their welcome.

A solid game, but not one I really go out of my way to play. I completely understand the game's popularity and its historical significance. Without Settlers, board games would still be relegated to the toy aisle. I also realize that many people cut their Eurogame teeth on Catan and most of those who did are still absolutely loyal to it. I get it, but I still would rather play something else.  As one of the first Euro's to cross the pond, it often gets a free pass for the parts that don't always work. I'm not usually one to bitch about randomness, but I have had more than a couple of experiences where I've had to sit around for half an hour doing nothing because my territories simply would not produce. Again, I know that's just a dice thing and it's not likely to happen ALL of the time. It just seems to really irritate me when it does happen...and it always seems to ruin my experience.

This used to be a big hit in the 1990s, but since then, much more interesting games have entered the stage. The luck of the dice roll makes this game not look so hot anymore. I own the Japanese version.
I enjoy this game but can take longer then what I like.

Just the base game doesn't have enough to it to hold my attention squarely anymore. I'll teach it if somebody really wants to learn it, but I tend to hang out with board game crowds where everyone either already knows it or already knows it's a little too random and pre-determined for them. I like to play with the traditional randomized board setup on a single, hexagonal island, with the dice chits in alphabetical order. I say this because there are lots of variants, even on the base game. I've also played the Cities & Knights expansion, and while that's more interesting, it's also too long without adding enough depth. I think I've never played the 5-6 player version, even though I think the off-turn building rule change sounds pretty fun.

One of the first strategy games I played and it was fun at first, now though, too much of the game comes down to seating order and luck but still play now and then and I would like to try some of the expansion versions.
I have the Mayfair Games pre-2007 adapter kit with this, as well.

Solid game. It is everything people claim it to be. I find there are other games I would rather play. I think there are two main issues for me. First it is either too much or too little engine building depending on whether you are looking for a filler or a middleweight loger game. Second especially in the early game there is not always much to do. I am just not on the edge of my seat playing this. This may need to go down to a 6.
Jake has copy, donated copy to cabin [thing=926]Cities & Knights[/thing]
I think I would enjoy this game more if I didn't have to teach it to someone every time I played.

A classic that most people like. Except that as the years go by, and the more variety of games I play, the less I like this game. It's becoming a "Monopoly" of sorts. Someone said something about this game on the geek once that I agree with very much.  "Play it once for new people to experience, then never speak of it again."   Maybe I need to get some of the expansions
Enjoyable, but it's too much of a trading and luck game for me to love.  It was, several years ago, one of the games to bring me back to the idea that board games are not bored games, though!
classic that infacted me with gaming virus. meanwhile i know better games though.

This was the first "designer" boardgame that I ever played. Though I have better games in my collection, I'll never pass on an offer to play this classic. Every time I play Settlers the game is always close, and I never feel like I wasn't able to compete, even if I didn't win. It might leave my top ten eventually, but it will always have a special place in my heart.

Managed to finally play one game, after owning it for over a month. I did really enjoy it, but I don't think I'll be desperate to play it any time soon, as I feel I have better games in my collection; but I definitely wouldn't say no to a game.  I managed to get pretty much all of the rules wrong when we played, which was fun.
THE Gateway, but after ca. 100 plays, I hate it.

[u]September 2008:[/u]A game that has a broad appeal. Not really for me as it's a bit too light but I still enjoy playing with my cousins in Cadaquès for an enjoyable afternoon.  A great gateway.  [u]December 2010:[/u] Changed my rating system, the game is now rated 6
The perfect "gateway" game - simple, diverse, enough interaction. But it's only good as an introduction - later it becomes too simple and not satisfying enough compared to the wealth of other games.
Interesting game, but a bad start means you will lose... and then it drags out for another 30 minutes without you having the ability to do anything...
We don't often have 3 people to play it. We were gamers before we played Settlers, so it was not our intro game, but we enjoy it just the same, and keep it on hand.
One of the better games from the family/gateway genre, I used to like it more but now I'm less into family games and more into gamer's games and find this game a bit too simple and repetetive.
I love to hate this game. I will play now and then. I absolutly despise the expansions for this game as why I dont have them.

Easy to learn, hard to master. I've had fun with this, although right now I don't have a group to play it with. ------------- After being in this hobby a while I really moved away from Settlers. But recently we played a couple games and had a good time.
Warm and fuzzy. Catan is a good game for beginners but is mainly based on luck. Best part of Catan is undeniably trading. Besides this is a very easy game to learn.

We hadn't played this in around a decade, but we introduced it to our daughter in September of 2018. Our arc of rediscovery went from "This is boring," to "Okay, it's not bad," and finally to "Hey, this is pretty fun as long as you play with the full four players."  There's the opening strategy, the ongoing tactical decisions regarding route building, and -- of course -- the social aspect of trading.  I wish there were more ways to mitigate the luck, and just more in general, but this 23-year-old game certainly surprised us.

(Not)* Gaming nirvana.  And it gets even better with Cities and Knights!  This game really shines with random hex and chit distribution.  I really love thinking about how to best exploit the limited resources on the map; and throwing down my roads, settlements, and cities in various winding and twisting configurations.  There's no need to worry if an opponent takes a spot I want as long as I set myself up in a good trade position, and not get tempted by the deceptive chits that whisper odds that may never play out.  It's a wheeling and dealing puzzly game where every move is a calculated gamble.  It's a pirate in a merchant's clothing, and I'm always up for a game.  2017 Update after owning the game for ten years: I hate the way you can trap people early in this game and they'll just sit there with nothing to do.  I also get kind of bored waiting for my resources to roll. It feels too slow, even when it goes fast.  *Ten'ish year update
It's not awful, but it hasn't aged well. Compared to any other games that I could play with 4 people, this is low on the list.
The winner feels like the best thief, not the victor.
An old standby. Fun, but my group has overplayed it, we don't really pick it back up that often.
Will play it, but tends to run long and get bogged down in midgame as everyone is often just sitting and waiting for needed resources to be produced.

Fun, simple mechanics with lots of possibilities for scheming and backstabbing.  The game has some major problems though. It is for example very possible for one player to be totally screwed and has no chance of winning after just the first two turns or so, which makes the game really crappy for that player. In general.
I really don't like this game, but due to its "classic" status don't want to give it a score below 6. Way too random for my taste.
Don't play Settlers as much as I'd like- very nicely balanced game, but I often have dumb luck which favors opponent resource builds. Still a modern classic.

I was too young and/or too ignorant to get into this game when it first became all the rage in the mid-nineties. And when I finally got to play it, I just didn't care all that much about it - maybe it's because of the other, more refined games I'd learned to enjoy by then.

I don't think Settlers is a bad game... quite the opposite.  There are just so many other games I'd rather play and it is no longer the best gateway game out there.  I find I much prefer playing electronic versions these days as it plays much faster.
As a newcomer to euros, I think this game has earned its reputation and longevity.  It's a good balance of luck and skill, and a fun interactive experience.

My gateway game.  Always fun, although I can't play it anymore unless I'm playing with one of its added expansions/ scenarios.  (Most notably Traders & Barbarians or Barbarian Invasion.)  I'll probably always undulate between hating this game and loving it.
I've always liked Settlers, though lately it seems that it doesn't get to the table much.
Can take a really long time to play with 2 people.  Best with 3+.
A dated euro, but a decent game overall. Slightly lengthy.

La primera vez que jugué este juego, mis amigos lo odiaron y eso arruinó la experiencia para mi, todabia estoy esperando reunir un grupo adecuado e intentarlo de nuevo porque a mi si me gusta, puedo ver que las mecanicas son interesantes y que es un juego con muchas posibilidades.  40 EUROS  vendido por 20$ (80.000 bs) el 14/12/2016
Played this a number of times .... nice little, and lite, strategy game.

I always find this game exciting.  Catan, more than almost any other game I play, makes me feel like I'm building a little civilization. I feel such pride when I build a road, or when I put up a new settlement.  It's also quite exhilarating to roll the exact number needed to get the resource that you need just as it's devestating to roll a seven when you've got a hand full of cards.  With as many times as I've played this game (I got it before I started keep close numbers on my play stats), I still enjoy it a lot.  The only thing that I find frustrating is the dice rolling.  If Catan had no dice, and instead had some other way of allocating resources, it would possible be in my top ten.  Instead, it's a game that I play sometimes because it's a classic and because it's a game that I discovered fairly early on in my development from game enjoyer to game enthusiast.    ***Update***  I haven't played Catan in months because I'm just not that interested in it now that I've passed the gateway stage.  The dice just bother me so much that I never take it out and play it.  Rating lowered to a six.

The hit of my teens. Must have been played a hundred times or so. Now I tend to find it not so enjoyable, partly because of the luck factor that will have you blocked for a whole game without being able to expand.
The gateway to Euro games, but something you want to move on from to better options quickly
Groundbreaking back in 1995 but I feel it's day fast approaches.
This game just got stale.  Prefer other games and this now rarely hits the table. At Home, not with me at Uni.
Gateway game that got us hooked but is now past its prime; we've just played it too much
The first big mainstream euro game... it has lost favor due to the dice luck, but a classic everyone should play once.
THE classic that got me into gaming, I suppose.  Rated 6 without any expansions. Cities & Knights improves the game to a 7.  Up to 3 points can be added for the nostalgia factor ;-).
A great start for non-gamers but can be frustrating and seem a bit redundant when you've played other Euros.
Deserves most of the praise it gets. A good strategic game that most people can be talked into trying, while offering enough fun and replayability to keep me interested.
Propiedad aula estudis  Incluye gestion de recursos, suerte, comercio, construcción, puteo, multiples estrategias.  juego muy completo, no muy complicado. Perfecto para los recien iniciados.

the game is just wonderful. It doesn't take long time to play, has simple rules, allows players to interact during the game and has a good replayability. One of drawbacks of the game - the role of luck is too high. Your success depends on dice too much. But we play it almost every week since we bought it. Must have.

This is a well done game. Balanced, takes 2 hours, and most important - it is a social game! We have fun with every couple we introduce this game to. It's nice combination of strategy, luck, ignorance ("I don't care who is first, I need sheep!"), and what I personally love - it allows different strategies. What's not to love?  Played some other games and now I really appreciate one for me the most important attribute of tSoC - it's very social, superb blend of group play and competitiveness.
Prefer it on the xbox to save on setup and always players

I do find that the hexes have a tendency to move about which can be really irritating. As far as playing is concerned, if you don't get the right positions early on, and/or the dice goes against you, it can be hard to catch up.
For some reason, the tendency for the random elements to influence the game in this one annoys me more than it does in games like Risk.  It's a bit too much of a gamble that ypu can't plan around.
basically a pretty good game, though always when playing, i feel like something is missing...
Settlers is a good game, as you always find people who know it and want to play with you.
I got rather tired of this game after hundreds of plays online. Like a lot of folks, this is the one that got me into boardgaming. Cities and Knights was a welcome expansion.

[b]Owned expansion: Cities and Knights[/b]  [b]Star ranking[/b] Fun: :star::star::star::halfstar::nostar: Satisfaction: :star::star::star::nostar::nostar: Esthetics: :star::star::star::nostar::nostar: Replayability: :star::star::star::star::nostar: [b]Verdict: Not essential. Owned by GF.[/b]

Really luck based, but so much fun. The main problem with this game is after you start playing with expansions you really can't go back. I won't play this ever again without the fisherman expansion at the very least, although Seafarers or Cities would be preferred.
Definitely better in person than online, though online isn't a bad option, either.

Had very mixed experiences with this, and it's not really lived up to the hype... (perhaps for me Carcassonne did the gateway thing?) - sometimes it just seems to take forever and be just boring, for some reason... other times, pretty quick and fun, even with more players. Like it in the main, but I just wish it was a bit more consistent for me - or I was a bit more consistent for it, perhaps...?  EDIT: Bumped up a bit since the 6 rating of Jan 2010, as it deserves more than that, not least for the game with the kids where we got real fruit for successful trading, but it's still not the best game, I think, and is a bit slow to get going perhaps? Takes too long to do much.
Decent balanced game but score drops for being very pricey for what it is.
Most people love 'Catan.  I've only played a few games but it was fun.
Only played once, but I found it a little tedious. I think it suffers somewhat because I don't have any nostalgia for the game, and newer games use the same mechanics in a better way.

I'm sure a lot of people would be quick to tell me that I'm 'playing it wrong' but Settlers of Catan is just too damn random for me.  If you have bad luck near the start then you get behind and barring some great luck you will get further and further behind as you just trudge through the motions hoping that one of the players who actually has a chance will just win.
Basically, I played this far too much when it came out initially. I became burnt out on it, and games seem to vary in length a bit too much for my tastes.

Games with open trading lead to victory through social manipulation. This game is a prime example of that phenomenon. The winner is the one who convinces the most gullible player to make the worst trades.
My "Gateway Game".  Drawbacks:  -When playing with experienced players, everyone gangs up on the frontrunner and the game becomes overly vicious -High level of randomness (dice rolls)
Turning point in the board game industry I guess. Was great in its time but have been overtaken by even more splendid game concepts over the years.
While I can see how great this game is, it just doesn't interest me as much as the newer Euros.  I'd not pass on the chance to play with friends or introduce this one to non-gamers though.

I've played this on various computer games, and it's always bored the living whiz out of me.  ALWAYS.  But, hundreds of thousands of copies sold can't be wrong, right?  EDIT:  Played this and had a great time.  It did run a little long even for as reasonably streamlined as our turns were, but that was nothing that couldn't be solved by say, playing to 8 rather than 10.  What I really liked about it, is if I had to come up with one game that encompassed all that it meant to be a game, with negotiation, strategy, and luck in all equal parts...  this would be that game.  08-15-11:  This game always takes just a hair longer than it aught to.  It's probably me that causes it, too.  In the end though, I'd rather play almost anything else.  Oh, and grind the development stack.  You can't go wrong.  SOLD.  09-18-11:  I think one of the things about this game going too long, is that it's a bit of a fractal representation of everyone on the board.  That is, the story doesn't really ever arc even as a winner is emerging.  People still trade, because it's helping their individual positions anyway.  The guy on the board who is getting the most shit, will find a way to get even more shit just as well getting his 10th point as he is getting his 7th point.
Classic gateway game.  Still enjoy this one, although I prefer the Cities & Knights version.
It's, y'know... ok.  I guess something has to be the "mainstream" euro, I reckon this is as good as any to be that one.
Ah, the old classic. These days I enjoy playing only with newbies, to get them into the game-playing mindset.
I find Settlers of Catan a bit sluggish; there always seems to be some point in the game where everyone cannot get enough of a certain resource and things just start slogging along turn after turn.

Good gateway game.  The randomness of the resources means there can be a fair amount of time when some players can't build while others can, which tends to make the rich get richer.  Hard to catch up if you fall behind.

Enough cannot be said. My only complaint is a bad start (with rolls) can hose your whole game without recovery. That can leave you uninterested in the rest of the game. But, it is still a fantastic game. We came up with a house rules that I'll post up on the forum.
bored bored bored...needs cities and knights.
Good game - set up takes a bit - would like to play it again before giving a full review
A solid gateway game that seems a little intimidating at first, but clicks for most people.
The standard Euro game...good for playing with non-gamers!
Love it but it's so much better with Seafarers.

The game is more luck than skill, but some skill is needed to play. However, what makes this game very fun are the players. This game is best when played just for fun. Even if your numbers are never rolled!

2-21-10 Lowered my rating from an 8 to a 6 now that I've played both ways (randomizing the board and playing the 'beginner' setup). I realize this game isn't as much fun as I once hoped.  It's too random as to who is getting which resources, you can't really get any type of momentum going unless the dice are in your favor.  You can trade, sure, but if you have the same junk everyone else wants, you're out of luck.
