You can get built in if other people are able to expand faster than you, and it can get to the point in a 4-player game where one or two people get 'eliminated' by the halfway mark of the game.  It takes too long for the level of depth.  Two hours for this game is absurd!  There needs to be more points in the deck as otherwise it's just not a wise investment.  Too many knight cards.  The social aspect of the game is fun but the game itself doesn't feel much more fun than games like Monopoly, because really, if you don't get the dice rolls and don't have the right stuff to trade, you lose - just like Monopoly.  At least in Monopoly when you get to the point where you know you can't win, you can just trade away your money and properties and go do something fun.  Here you get stuck being useless until somebody finally gets 10 points.
This one has gotten a bit tired to me. While it's incredible accessibility is great, I often feel like I want to play other games now.
Kind of 'love at first sight' although sometimes the luck factor can ruin it quite a bit.
Too much luck based. Still good game.
Little to much luck for my liking. Needs an expansion to really be fun. My group found it very boring as a stand alone game.
The basic game is too dependent on the luck of the dice.  The Cities and Knights add-on make this an 8 for me.  One of those rare games where expansions actually make the original better.
Ahhh, settlers. My mom's favorite game. I liked it at first. Less and less with each game. Maybe I'm just spoiled now by so many other great games.
I can see it's appeal but in my opinion it takes to long for what it is. I'll play every once in a while especially with non-gaming family.
Turns out I don't care for negotiation games. That really is the biggest feature of gameplay in Catan.

The biggest thing that this classic lacks from its newer brethren is the consolation prize when a player gets nothing from the resource roll (newer games award a gold point; gold can be traded 2-for-1 for any resource and aren't counted for robber purposes in the meantime). This would probably be really good with that added in.  Play with real dice, not a dice deck.
The Settlers of Catan: 5-6 Player Extension Catan: Indiana & Ohio
Mayfair 2nd Edition. Cards show wear. Includes PNP volcano and Jungle tiles. PNP event cards and scenario selection cards.
Too boring as standalone game (or with 5-6 player expansion).  Need to find a way to spice it up.
Loved it back then. Still willing to play it once in a while. Will always prefer this to Carcassonne but if heavier games are within reach Settlers loses big time.
Hasn't aged as gracefully as TTR but no other modern board game has come close to bringing in new players and hobbyists.

For me there are just too many turns of roll the dice, think a bit, do nothing, say next. If it was streamlined so that there were fewer turns where nothing happened I think it would be a pretty good game of trading, snowballing, spatial management, and figuring out which route you need to take to win.
This isn't a game, it's a personality contest.
Pssst.... buy seafarers to make this better....seriously.  Pssst.... Actually, just buy a different game all together.
A good game that can get a bit crowded with 4 players.  Use resources to build roads and towns to gain the most victory points.
Too fluffy for my liking. Dice randomness can be frustrating. Trading lasts until last 2/3 turns.

Decent enough game, there's just better stuff out there to play. I'd never play with more than 4 people because the game starts to drag so much that players start to help each other just to end the game, not even win.   Good intro game, decent with 3-4. Wouldn't mind playing now and again.  Sold. No need to own it, everyone else does.

Dice deck or bust! Consistent dice rolls of unlikely numbers have ruined many a game. My version is the Mayfair 2nd ed. with odd colored pieces that can be used in conjunction with the 1st ed. for a 8 player variant.  The box is very worn, the pieces have held up well.

Another classic that I'm almost always happy to play.  I enjoy attempting to manage the sporadic nature of the resource gain.  You must be ready to change your plan if the situation isn't what you wanted it to be.  Update: Bumping down to 7.  I stand by what I said before, but this one is starting to show its gateway status for me.  There are deeper titles on my shelf more worthy of play.  Update: Bumping down to 6.  It's a fine gateway game, but I don't see it getting pulled out again.  We all prefer deeper experiences.
Nu mi-a placut, prea multa negociere.
I prefer to play with the Cities & Knights expansion.  It just adds so much more to the game.
Still go to the iOS version and enjoy it but it's a bit tired now.
A classic game, even though it doesn't get much play I always like to bring it out to introduce euro games to a newbie.
Classic, but eventually just comes down to roll of the dice. Very simple, better than monopoly and VERY easy to learn. Everyone loves to pick up resources and steal them from friends! :)

What can I say that hasn't been said before? Great gateway game, much randomness, modular board, good graphics, nice mechanics. It doesn't stand its own hype but is worth playing at least once to know what all this fuss is about.
Good game for introducing newbies to board gaming. Heavily dependent on chance.
Classic euro, past its prime, but still fun for the occasional play.

Nice interaction during trading. Basic development cards aren't very exiting. Much better with "Cities and Knights". It seems that some times, it can be very hard to get the 13 points and the game can last way too long (3 hours...) Barbarians are cool feature, but being hit by them slow the game donw, and is probbaly a losse for the player being hit. May be not for noobs...  Main issue is that most of the game is played when you first put your buildings on the board... I'll keep it to retest the base game someday  If you are behind, no way to come back... and that sucks
This was a go-to at my gaming group for a while which burned me out on it.

I played Catan weekly with my friends in my late teens but since then I've hardly played it anymore.  I will not part with my copy as it has an emotional value now but I know that I have much better and nicer games to play right now.
I've played this far too much and can't abide the base game anymore....Seafarer still hits the spot on occasion though!. =)

I give this one a 9 because it's not the MOST fun game i've ever played, and even though we don't play it often anymore it still is THE best gateway game in my opinion.  I can honestly say that I have never had anyone DISLIKE this game after playing it.  It's usually they're first REAL boardgame and it ends up being the best one they've ever played. Edit (2/4/13):  I've changed my ranking from a 9 to a 6.  I've grown so tired of this game that I cringe when someone suggests it.  It is a good game, but there are so many better games that I can't believe we're still playing this as a group.

One of my first played modern boardgames. But not the first one. From today's perspective, it contains too much luck and too little choice for my taste. But it was a good game for me those times.  Vienas iš pirmųjų mano žaistų rimtesnių žaidimų. Tiesa, ne pats pirmasis. Žiūrint dabar, mano skoniui per daug atsitiktinumo ir per mažai pasirinkimo. Bet tuo metu visai tiko.
The ultimate gateway to euro games ... that said ... I don't know if I can ever play this game again.  I've had my lifetime fill of Settlers.
A solid game that appeals to most non-gamers.  Fairly easy to teach and has plenty of interaction (via trading).  Con:  Can't be played two player.

IIRC, I first played Settlers in 2006. Played 2-3 times, tops. There was some curiosity about modern boardgaming, so I thought I'd get a companion game to Settlers for the group, which ultimately ended up being Carcassonne. In other words, I pulled a standard Gateway maneuver many years after these two games were released, but I left Settlers behind so quickly it never made an impression on me. I played a lot of Carc (about 20 sessions), but half of that was at the request of more casual, non-gamer friends. So they responded to the "gateway game" while I was off and running.   I say all of this because I came back to Settlers recently (10/28/09) for one session just to see how it would strike me as a died-in-the-wool, hardcore gamer. I don't have any nostalgia for this game. I never experienced it as the only game in town or as the forerunner of a whole movement.   So to me, in 2009, Settlers is a distinctive but fairly unengaging game. In essence, the game is built around a random distribution of goods that is, in theory, corrected by manipulation of the odds and player negotiation. In practice neither of these things really do enough for the game. It does play quickly and simply. I've also read that 4-player Settlers is inevitably "an exercise in futility for one player, an exercise in false hope for another, and a real contest between the other two." That's been my experience as well.   As gateway games go: TtR < Settlers < Carc < Pandemic. Althought as a cooperative, Pandemic doesn't really introduce people to the mainstream.
A classic.  Great game for the family or with none gaming friends.  Easy to teach and always fun.
The classic gateway game, but in my opinion it has to be played with Cities & Knights.

Still like this game - especially with expansion.  Update 12/15:  Super classic, but only kept for nostalgia.  It was one of my first euros, but unlike Carcassone (that I still play a lot), this one has been eclipsed by far better games.
It's almost 20 years old, and while it might have been a great game then, it isn't anymore now.  But it is fun for non-gamers.

It is hard to say anything unique about Settlers, but for me it earns its place via consistency.  Sure, it is rare to finish a game feeling as if you arrived at the pinnacle of gaming, but it is equally rare to feel the time wasted.  Eventually the baseline experience for games in my collection will eclipse the zone where Settlers lives, but until then, its a trustworthy and faithful inclusion.
Im in the Siggins camp here. Too long and dice dependant.

This seems to be the only Euro I ever see in retail stores, and the only one that my non-gamer friends have heard of.  It's significantly better than a lot of 'classics' like Monopoly, but compared to a lot of the Euros I've played, it's just so-so.
Descent game, mostly play with (nongamer) parents
Played it only a few times. I need a good theme and/or a good mechanic to enjoy a game. Here, the mechanics are not good enough to compensate the theme.
Other light games are more replayable, but I know of none that is such a gateway for the hobby.

2005-2006-ban a Carcassone mellett ez volt a másik játék, amit az "újabbak" közt volt szerencsém kipróbálni (új alatt azt értem, hogy nem activity és társai). Rám a kettő közül ez volt nagyobb hatással. Számomra addig ismeretlen elemek (pl. az alkudozás, a nyersanyagszerzési mód, stb.) nagyon színessé és vonzóvá tették a játékot, annak ellenére, hogy nem igazán voltam benne jó. Mára kicsit megkopott a varázsa, sok jobbat láttam már, de most is szívesen játszanék fele, főleg hogy van egy kiegem, amit még nem próbáltam! --- Kipróbáltam a kieggel is. Nos nem rossz játék ez a Catan, de így hogy több mint 400 féle játékot ismerek, azt mondom, hogy vannak abból az időszakból olyanok, amik sokkal jobban kiállták az idő próbáját (El Grande, Tigris, Hannibál), bár a felsoroltak mindegyike eleve komolyabb játék, mint ez. Ma már csak nosztalgikus okokból ülök le a Catanhoz. --- Újra előkerült, ebből is látszik, hogy még ennyi játék ismeretében sem zárkózom el tőle, de azért már nem az a megkerülhetetlen játék, ami 10 éve volt. Tegnap 2 partit játszottunk, és 10-8-4 ill. 10-4-4 lett az eredmény kb. azonos képességű játékosok közt (nem mindkétszer ugyanaz nyert, és nem is pont ugyanaz volt a játékosok összetétele). Ha az induló 2-2-2 pontokat nem számoljuk, akkor 8-6-2 illetve 8-2-2 a végeredmény. Az első parti másfél óra volt, a második 1 óra. Több játékossal simán lehet 2 óra feletti a játék, ehhez képest nevetségesen nagy a végeredményben mutatkozó különbség. A második partiban fél óra elteltével látszott, hogy ki lesz a győztes, és nem lehetett ellene mit tenni. Szerintem többek közt ezért áldozott le egy kicsit a Catan csillaga. De nosztalgiának továbbra is jöhet, csak fenntartásokkal fogom kezelni.

The Settlers of Catan is a classic. It's what really got me into contemporary board games. There's a lot of expansions for it now, but only the classic game is really worth playing. Shines with 4 players. Ideal for new players and families. Can be a bit random, but at least it feels strategic.
Good, competitive, intro game.  Cities and Knights expansion
Very good gateway game that has done a lot for the hobby. But theme-& mechanics-wise I prefer the card game, and gateway-wise I prefer Ticket to Ride.
I can understand why people like this game so much - but I don't cause there are no options to fight each other.

Willing to play when welcoming newbies to the room. Need to engage in active trading to appreciate this game. Need to play this several times in order to make productive trades. If I'm going to play something several times, I'd prefer another game.  Overall, a decent gateway, and still a clever use of dice. There's a potential for disaster if some of the players have no grasp of the distribution of 2d6.  EDIT: Thoughts as of 2012. Have you ever noticed just how long it takes to explain this, for a so-called gateway game? Also, it's been around so long that many folks seems to have learned it third- or fourth-hand, which is to say that many unintended house rules have mutated into the gene pool. Earns nostalgia points for having brought many of us into the designer-name-on-the-box world.
The one that got me into the hobby, but frankly it just feels too long for what it is nowadays.

A clasic and a must have! Great social component combined with strategy. the only flaw i feel is that when someone is behind he usually stays there until the end of the game, very anti-eurogame climax.
I'd owned this for almost 10 years without having ever played it...untill recently!  I do like it a lot, in spite of the luck involved in resource rolling.  My son thinks it's fantastic!
After having played Cities & Knights I don't enjoy the original as much. It feels incomplete.
Strategic and fun but frustrating if the dice aren't on your side.  Placement of first towns has too much weight over the rest of the game.

Decent enough to play. Random board layouts make the game extremely unbalanced and the open victory points usually make for a "Lets make sweet deals with each other while not letting the leader do anything!"
It's very... german. Wood. Thin theme. No direct conflict. It's good, but not my cup of tea.
Fun in the beginning, frustrating later. After everybody learns the right strategies, luck decides it all.

This gets played as the family game. I of course, prefer games more complicated, with more options. But as a whole, this is a great family game.  I have owned this game for years, but only recently started using BGG to record etc.
Classic, though I find the base game rather boring.
My wife enjoys it. That's important.
Good game for 3 or 4 player.  This game use dice in a clever way to produce ressource.
A reasonable game with a group of casual gamers. Bog down to an irritation game during tourny situation.  A good mix of strategy and fun for a family gaming session. Very average throughout.
Also own homemade cards in Esperanto.
The game that made me a eurogamer.

A great gateway game and played it a lot in the past. Its an older edition of the game.(1996 3rd edition?)  These days however, I feel that in the majority of games you can pretty much predict who will win from the setup.  Then it's just dying a slow death waiting for that outcome.

Like Kingsburg, this game has been significantly diminished for me by the ease of computerized play.  The randomness usually punishes one person disproportionately and it's difficult to set oneself up not to be that person.

I'm not a Catan hater like many others seem to be. I occasionally play it with some coworkers over lunch. Some people spend far too much time on the trading part of the game, which can make the whole thing drag. Maybe the trading why I'm so ambivalent about Catan? I don't think I've ever played a game with trading/negotiation that really grabbed me.  For "gateway" games of this weight/type I prefer Ticket To Ride.

How I got back into boardgaming.  Since that time Ive come to realize this games faults (dice driven luck, I dont like the robber, and you can get stuck if people dont trade).  I dont want to be too harsh on it, I still enjoy the game and play it periodically.  You just have to take it for what it is.  A GREAT way to show others that boardgames dont have to be Candyland or Monopoly.  Re-rated from a 5 to a 6, based on the fact that I like this game, I Have a soft spot for it, and Ill usually play when asked and enjoy it win or lose.  This game will always be in my collection.
It is a good, classic game, but I don't like it. I just don't and I don't know why.

Classic board game but I haven't played it in a long time now. The basic game is pretty limited on ways to win and thus depends a lot on dice luck. Never got around to buying expansions because a friend got the game with everything and now it's incompatible with the reprints, I think.
